Mandatory. If you only do one excursion, this is the one. Fantastic experience, well worth the Tripadvisor "Hall of Fame" award.

Beautiful journey in underground river cave. Of the three different tours we took while in the Riviera Maya area north of Playa del Carmen, this was by far our favorite. It is well organized, the tour groups are reasonably sized (we had 10 people in our group) and the group leaders are excellent guides and educators. The caves and the underground river you walk thru are just magical, and unlike other attractions in the area, these are real and natural environments. Caves that over 1 million years in the making and at every turn you get a different view of clear water and cave formations, that in total just leave you kind of breathless. After doing the tour, my wife and I said to each other we would consider this a 'bucket list' kind of To Do. The only negative thing I can say about this tour, and this is in general for all the tours we took in Mexico, is that the price they charge for picture packages is outrageous, ranging from $120 for a "complete" package, to $40 for 2 pics. You are not allowed to bring cameras into the caves, so if you want a memento of your tour, they definitely have a captive audience. The price may not be bad if a whole group is paying for one package, but it's ridiculous for a single person or couple. We didn't take the picture/package option so you won't see any of our pics on this review.

A MUST DO!. Went twice and it is unbelievable. Our guide Paulina was fabulous! Small group and not commercialized! DO NOT waste your time at any other cenote.....this is THE BEST! You will wear water shoes (bring if you have them otherwise they will give you them), wet suit (water is cold), helmet with light and a walking stick....Use the stick...trust me as the water is in the cave and it's nice to know how far the step below is. This is a one and 1/2 hour experience walking/swimming through a cave that was just found in 2010. There are three different paths and all are different. I'm excited to go back my 3rd time to see the Suprema path. Only 10 % of the cave has been explored, they continue to find new ways around it. It is breathtaking! I think anyone even if clausterphobic can go on this.... people who struggle with walking may want to think twice as the ground is uneven. This was the highlight of our trip AGAIN and our best day during our seven days. PICK RIO SECRETO!

Just otherworldly...Journey to the Center of the Earth!. Don your wetsuit, helmet, water shoes, and life jacket and head into the Mayan underworld for a truly unique hiking/spelunking adventure. After a Mayan blessing from a local shaman, your will descend into a hidden world of darkness, silence, water, and stone. You walk, float, and swim in the milky waters of the only water source in the peninsula..an underground river. Our guide shared the both the geology and the history of the caves as we spent 90 minutes back in time. At one point, she turned off the lights and we floated in complete darkness and silence. Connect to the yourself and the universe on this tour. You will never do anything like this again! And kudos to Rio Secreto for striving to keep this cave as untouched as possible while sharing its mysteries! GO!!

Fun underground Exploration. We had a fun morning Exploring the underground river., with our guide Nico. Nice lunch followed, including several Mexican dishes. Walking sticks, water shoes and wetsuit provided and are all needed.

What an adventure . Visited with my family last week. This place was amazing, magical even. Beautiful scenery and I would imagine quite memorable for geologists and nature lovers. It would be a challenge for the not-so-agile to be able to manouver the uneven terrain, but my 62 yr old mom (who doesn't swim) was able to manage, albeit nervously at some points. Thanks in part to a very patient and helpful guide, Nico. He was also quite knowledgable and shared a lot of info about the history of the caves and its unique inhabitants. Wonderful experience was had by all. One flaw, I suggest you walk with your own beach shoes, cause, the ones they loan you are kind of icky...errrr...may not be the most sanitary.

A Natural Beauty. My sister and I went on this trip as an excursion pick on our cruise. There were so many options to choose from but this was one of the only excursions that received 5 stars across the board. While we were nervous to be so adventures, we decided this was what this vacation was all about. Once we got off the ship we were greeted by a guide who took us on a 30 minute ferry ride to Playa del Carmen. From there our guide split our large group up into 3 smaller groups where we were loaded into 12 passenger vans. It was another 30 minute drive to the caves along very bumpy (but fun) dirt roads. It's a good idea here to start getting to know some of the passengers on your van because you will be spending the next 6 hours with this small group. Once you arrive at the caves you are greeted by your new guide who will be taking you through the caves. Our guide was JULIAN. While most people say they had the best guide, we actually did! You are given a key to a locker where you store everything. While Rio Secreto will provide water shoes, it's a good idea to bring your own. Next you are asked to rinse off in the provided, extremely cold showers. I recommend not putting on any lotions or perfumes before your trip. They try to keep the water there perfectly clean and pure. Once you rinse off, you are given a wet suit and a life preserver to put on. Definitely wear the wet suit because the water is bearable but definitely cold. Make sure to get a walking stick as well. It was not an option with our guide. He told us to each take one. We then took a short walk to where the cave was. Before going in, there is a short, non religious ceremony by a Mayan representative that was wonderful to be a part of. Once you enter the cave, we all sat for a few minutes to introduce ourselves to one another. Julian told us that for the next hour and a half we were like a family and had to treat each other like family, always looking out for each other. The tour through the caves was amazing. Julian was great about pointing out some of the most beautiful things in the caves. He always took the time to answer all of our questions. Our group truly became a family and all got along so well with one another. This excursion was one of the most amazing things I have ever done. The walk/swim through the caves was definitely work as you have to be so careful of your next step, but the hidden beauty that is inside is worth everything. Most of the tour consists of walking but there are a few areas where the water gets deep and you need to swim through it. Because of our life vests we basically floated through being able to look at everything as we did. There is one part towards the end where the water is higher and the ceiling is lower. My sister felt a bit claustrophobic but it didn't bother me at all. (For those of you that could potentially get that feeling at times.) All in all, we could have stayed in there forever! Afterwards, we changed back into our clothes and had a wonderful buffet lunch. Everyone was so hospitable! You can also purchase your pictures at this time. I bought a thumb drive for $89 but you can also purchase individual pictures for $25 each. The pictures were not as good as I was hoping for, but in order to have any remembrance of the trip I felt I had to buy them. The ferry ride back to the ship was not so much fun. It was very rocky and the ferry went very fast. Several people on board got sick. I strongly recommend sitting upstairs where it is all open and towards the back. All in all, an amazing day that we will never forget!

Awesome Surprise. We are a family that travels "off the beaten path" and enjoys UNtouristy local sites. We found this site online when looking for fun things to do while in Cozumel. We were completely prepared for a tourist trap complete with Hollywood-style light show, cement paths, lighted cavern chambers, and crowded spaces. The reality was completely different.While you do get herded from one place to the next, the "herds" are small, right down to the individual groups (no more than 10 people) that enter the caverns together. What was particularly impressive is how the several groups enter the caverns at different places (and tour different chamber groups) and never run into each other.All the required equipment is provided (wetsuit shorty, water sock booties, life jacket, walking stick, and lighted helmet), including your own personal paparazzi. :) Once you have received your briefing, showered, and received your gear, you hike about a quarter mile to the entrance of your cavern and begin your tour...no paved walkways, no lighted caverns (aside from the lights on your helmet), and no big show. Just you and your little group, your tour guide, and some interesting information about Mayan culture and their relationship with the caverns.When your tour is over, you return your equipment, change clothes (if you want), and then get served a very nice buffet of authentic Mexican food. Once you are fed, you can review (and purchase) photos of our tour (of just your family group, not the others in your group) and some very nice stock images of the caverns - but not necessarily the caverns that *you* got to see on your tour.Authentic, well done, and definitely an activity that I would recommend. It has a good price tag ($79/adult, $90 for the photos of just your family (although there are bigger and smaller packages), plus the cost of getting there, but it was worth every penny.
Excellent. Fantastic experience. I think I have enjoyed this most of all the things we have done in Mexico. Our guide Lara was very knowledgeable and made it fun. Would definitely recommend.

Great adventure in our amazing world. My siblings and I booked this excursion through our friend Juan Carlos who works a Best Day Travel. He suggested it and it was fabulous. We were expecting one cave tour but there was a 2nd one. We were there for about 6 hours. Fantastic fantastic fantastic. One thing we might never get use to is Mexican meal times. Lunch wasn't until about 2:30pm. We had a great time and didn't starve!

Happiness trail. What a wonderful experience. Alfredo is a magical guide. We have an inspirational tour. Alfredo's love and respect of this magical cave made this a truly exceptional day. The sheer joy of floating down a river through a cave cannot be limited in words

Natural Wonder near Playa del Carmen. Kind of a twist on the cenote features, Rio Secreto is entirely underground. The tour includes wetsuits, helmets, headlamps, and water shoes. Most of the tour through the cavern involves wading in shallow water, ducking stalactites, etc., but the last stretch is for floating in the underground river,and a few moments of meditation in complete darkness. After the tour, there is a sampling of the local honey-anise liqueur and a buffet lunch -- not the highlight, but it helps if you are hungry.Santiago was a fantastic guide -- very knowledgeable and helpful. He really made this a special experience.

Amazing Snorkeling or Dive. This is a very interesting snorkel or dive. Definitely worth the tripo and a lovely little family run/owned Mexican restaurant near the parking lot where you can grab a beer and taco after the activity. Very clean bathrooms and kitchen. Highly recommend.

Very Cool but Only if You're Not Claustrophobic. First of all, I have to say that Diana, our guide, was amazing. Super knowledgeable, great sense of humor, and made sure we stayed safe. That said, this whole tour is 40 feet underground, the water is varying depths, and you're wearing a used wetsuit. The stalactites and stalagmites are very cool, but if you are even remotely claustrophobic, you will not enjoy this.

Well Done Tour. This was recommended to us by some friends. It was ideal for us because it was not a full day event. It was beautiful. Our guide, Valentino, was awesome. He could have made watching paint dry enjoyable!

Fantastic. This was one of the most amazing afternoons we spent. There was a lot of info given about rocks, caves and the environment of Mexico. We spent about two hours under ground, but it felt like a minute. Make sure you take the walking stick(even if you are young and do a lot of walking). The only draw back to the afternoon is the cost of the pictures, $25.00 American for one picture is crazy.( I did spend it though). Our guide Valentino was great and called us his family. Great afternoon, worth the cost.

Amazing doesn't do it justice!!!. This was the best excursion we did - by far! The facility is clean and well organized. They provide you with water shoes (no additional charge), a wet suit, PDF and helmet with light. Our guide was extremely knowledgable about the whole area and the geology of the caves. You do need to be physically able to do this tour - there is a lot of walking - but more than that it is over VERY uneven ground, especially in the cave. There are times when I was more comfortable with one hand down for stability. You are walking in water a lot of the time - some knee deep, thigh deep and waist deep. There are big caverns - but also some tight spots. There is one area where you are in water up to your neck and the ceiling in about 2' above your head - so it can be a little tight for those with those kind of issues. And then there is swimming - you have your PFD, so no under water swimming - but you do have to swim. It was incredible - so peaceful and restorative. Highly highly recommended!

Great Excursion. This is a unique excursion. I never been in any caves before. I can not imagine being able to visit any better than this. We got an intresting tour, because for how many people were there that day and the group I was placed with spoke only spanish, they took us in the exit and we did a special tour. It took a little longer because the guide did this in Spanish and English. Bounus for me, learned a few new Spanish words. The guide was the most accommodating to all of us. I enjoyed the little extra time to really enjoy the amazing caves. I know this was truly a special tour, we were climbing into caves with on 2-3 feet of clearance. What a truly amazing river and cave system. Thanks to all at the Rio Secreto for an unforgettable experience.
amazing place. This was a great tour and just an amazing place to see. Lunch was delicious as well. I highly recommend going to this if in the area.

Nice Visit. Duration : 90 minutes of activity (give or take), lots of transportation on the site + the transport from your hotel / lodging. Equipment : They provide helmets, wet suit, life jacket and water shoes. Bring your own if you do have. What you do : You walk a bit in the "jungle", you have a prayer to a mayan shaman saying grace to the sun and a thank you, then you go in the cave. Some route have more swimming than others, at time your feet wont touch the grounds. Some routes have more climbing and crouching. Guide : our Guide was Romain (french) and he did an awesome job explaining the history, fauna, speleology and so on. I recommend him. Appreciation : We enjoy our visit ! The time in the cave is interesting. Take the opportunity to look around, dont juste follow the trail by looking simply ahead, you might discover amazing scenes . Photos : 25 usd a piece or 89$ for a usb with the pictures of all your group. Make sure you smile and take a pose when the photographer is there ;)Food : interesting at most. Kept us from storming the buffet back at the resort !Overall : It was a nice experience, a bit pricy, but i recommend it !

Amazing Tour and even more amazing sights. If any of you guys are looking for a once in a lifetime excursion, then Rio Secreto is the one to do. I didn't expect to have as much fun as we did, it felt as if we were doing a lighter version of spelunking rather than just being on a tour. Jorge was an amazing guide he definitely knew what he was talking about and made it fun for us all. And to top it all off they have a buffet style lunch for you afterwards, and trust me after all of this that you do you will want it...haha...

The amazing secret river was awesome!. My family and I loved it! Very exciting, adventurous, and amazing! Diana was our guide and she was terrific! She was fun & informative with a personal touch! We never felt rushed and the photo ops gave you more time to just look around. Everything was very organized. You are in the river cave for about 1.5 hours. My 6'6" husband fit into the wet suit and life preserver! We booked this as an excursion from our cruise ship. You can't bring cameras with you, but they provide lockers. $25 for a picture or more for all of them. The food was very good! We even had some time to look around Playa del Carman before getting on the tender to get back.

Amazing Family Adventure!. This was the best part of our trip to Mexico. The adventure is straight out of National Geographic! Probably not well suited for 4 year old although that is the minimum age. Our 4 year old was not too happy, but our 6 year old lead the way and had the best time. Our guide, Alondra, was amazing, amazing, amazing. She was informative, so funny, and great with our kids. I would recommend her to anyone going.

You cannot miss this experience. Its priceless. OK, this is our second time here. We live in Mexico and were having family visit from the US. We had to bring them here. Its an experience you will never forget. It is not a pretend theme park, its a real underground cave/cenote. You will receive all the gear you need. Its not cheap. This time it was around $79. But the experience is worth it. All the other local parks and tourist things to do cost more and will not leave the impression that this place does. Its really something else. Don't cheat yourself of this opportunity. Book it.
Rio Secreto. Amazing underground water system! My family and I thought it was the best thing we saw on our trip to Playa del Carmen. A definite must see for anyone going to that area of the world.
Once in a lifetime. Very interesting excursion. If you are looking to do something a little different and something you can't do anywhere else, try this!

Amazing place. Take this trip if you can. It's a very unique experience. It was only discovered about 10 years ago. It's a guided tour that involves a dry cave, and rappelling into a cave with water, where you mostly walk in knee-to-waist deep water but does involve some floating.

the 4 h trip was well worth it!. Alfredo, Mariana and the photographer Oscar were fabulous, knowledgeable guides who clearly love this 4 h trip. It's pricey ($300) but well worth the unforgetable experience of wading or floating or snorkeling through this extensive cavern, chock full of stalactites and stalalactites.

Very interesting and fun. We had Danielle as a guide and he was fabulous. We really were surprised at how different and fun the experience was. I would recommend for families. The caves were so cool and it made our trip!

Amazing experience on Yucatan. Río Secreto is a fantastic creature of mother nature! Wonderful service, including helmet, wetsuit and water shoes. Delicious food. Our tourguide Alan was very helpful, gave many infos, we liked him a lot!

Awesome "Bucket List" Experience. Amazing....never knew this existed! Julio was our guide and he was so informative and worked so hard to make sure we had a great experience. I'm in my mid-50's and in fairly good shape, BUT caution to those with knee issues and basic "clumsiness" (like me). I took advantage of their "no charge" walking sticks.
spectacular place. highly recommend to visit this place. it can be a little bit cold in a cave, so if you have wetsuit - take it with you.

Great Day, Great Experience. My wife, 13 year old daughter and I loved this experience. We booked this on an NCL cruise which was more expensive but we wanted to ensure the ship would wait for the tender to return before leaving Cozumel. If you go to the Playa del Carmen area, do this trip, it is truly breathtaking. Walking, and swimming through underground fresh water caverns taking in nature in all it's glory, magnificent. Our guide 'RRRaul' (yes, that's Raul with 3 R's!!) was friendly, passionate about his work, and very knowledgable about Cenotes and pretty much all thing to do with Mexican nature. I would not normally have hesitated at giving this attraction 5 stars, but I (and many of the others on our bus) was disappointed at the operators trying to charge $89 for the photo's they took of us. (no, that's not a typo, $89). My advice lower the price of the photo's, then more people will buy them giving you the same income, but so many more people will walk away rating this one of the best attractions in Mexico.

A great adventure. An exciting, rugged trek through an underground river in the Mexican jungle. Very well organized excursion. We booked through our cruise ship. Were taken in a group from ship which was docked in Cozumel by ferry over to Playa de Carmen. This is a 45 min ferry ride. Were met on dock by van driver and rode for about 45 minutes into jungle location. There we met our wonderful guide, Julio. (He was very informative and passionate about this site.) We were given wet suits to put on over our swimsuits, fitted for life vests and helmets with lights and given water shoes. We had been told you could not use your own water shoes but that was incorrect. If you have some, preferably with thicker soles, use yours! Everyone had to do a quick rinse off in a shower (cold) to rinse off lotions, body oils, etc before heading to the cave. Walking sticks are available - highly recommend using! After that we were led into cave. You are in cave approximately 1 1/2 hr. It is a rugged walk over very uneven terrain in water. You need those walking sticks! There are about 3 spots of about 8' deep water where you basically float and paddle in your life jacket for about 10 yards. This is a very unusual, beautiful and interesting excursion. Following the walk through cave a buffet lunch is served. The grounds are very nice, well kept, with lots of relaxing hammocks. Restroom and dressing rooms are clean. You cannot take your camera into cave as you need both hands for maneuvering through the rough terrain, but there are photographers at scenic spots taking photos. Of course you can purchase these. After lunch we were then driven back into Playa where we had an hour of free time before boarding the ferry back to the ship. BTW, I am a 75 year old woman and with the help of Julio and my walking stick I made it through the river cave without too much trouble.

Very Well Led Tour of Rio Secreto. The "secret river" is an underground cavern that is really a natural beauty. I signed up for this tour at my hotel...wife wanted to chill, couple we were with did a day trip that I'd been on before twice so tried this...it was new for me. Once you arrive at the check in area, which is just south of Playa del Carmen, you are then given a sheet of paper with your tour guide's name. Mine was the Mexican "hippy" guy (forgot his name but that's what he called himself). You were then put in a van with your tour group...no more than ten and with an English or Spanish speaking guide. Then you were driven what seems like about ten miles into the jungle. We were first taken to a restroom and locker area where we were given locks, wet suites, life preservers, water shoes and helmets with lights on them. We were then lead about another 1/4 mile on foot to the entrance of the cavern. Let me warn you. This is no Disneyland ride. This is no-kidding cavern exploration. Once we reached the cavern, had to go down some stairs that were cut into the rock. (Made the big mistake of going for a run in the morning...had an afternoon appointment at the Secret River). This is a pretty good workout. Once down in the cave we entered ankle deep water. Stalactites, bats, and all the stuff you'd think you'd see in an underground cavern. For much of the tour you were in water...at times over your head so you'd have to swim, other times you were neck deep in water with the cave roof just over your head...some tight spots. I had concerns of claustrophobia but our guide was so mellow (though totally professional and very knowledgeable) that I never got nervous. Were down there about two hours. The only lights were on our helmets and the flashlight our guide had. Afterwards a pretty steep walk up stairs to the exit. You need to have strong legs and good footing to do this as the bottom was often not flat. You had to watch your step every step of the way or you could fall into rocks and get cut. After we exited, walked back to the locker/bathroom area, we turned in our gear and then were taken to a lunch buffet. A photographer accompanies the group for most of the tour and pictures are available for sale at the end (shocker!). The buffet was just okay, not particularly good but not horrible. Water and lemonade were included but soda, beer and booze was extra. No problems with transportation to and from the hotel. This was a great experience. I'm very happy that I did it and I greatly enjoyed it. Just make sure you're in reasonably good shape or you might be miserable doing this tour.

Amazing Experience. Booked this tour from Carnival Cruise Paradise. I'm glad I booked this excursion since it was probably the highlight of our trip. Alfredo was our guide at the cave. He was very nice. He was specially attentive to my 7 year old son who was a little scared at the beggining of the tour so Alfredo took time and eventually made my son feel safe. Everyone in our group was happy with our exprerience and will definitely comeback, next time we visit Mexico.

Very cool. We decided to visit this spot known as the best for Cenotes. We were not disappointed. The guide was excellent, interesting and we learned a lot during the visit. Everything was very well organized. Just be aware that the site is about 10 miles from the lobby so there is ride in the jungle with a van. Not very comfy but this the price to pay to be in the good spot !
Stunning, best tour guide ever. What a beautiful place! We had the best tour guide ever. Raul P. He was so passionate, knowledgeable and so funny. My husband and I, had such a great time.
Must see. A must see if in the area. Visited with go naturals tours. Don't forget your water proof camera and snorkel gear.

AWE INSPIRING!. The Cenotes and underground rivers were one of the reasons we choose to visit Cancun. We had already experienced the fun of jumping into and swimming in an open cenote, but I was really looking forward to seeing the beautiful formations of the caves and this tour was amazing, I would go so far as to say spiritual, from the traditional blessing by a local shaman at there beginning to the pause to meditate in total darkness before leaving the caverns. The buffet lunch was delicious. They will warn you about the green salsa and it is no joke!

Cool place to visit. While in Playa de Carmen, my family and I visited Rio Secreto (Secret River). The tour consist of traveling in a cave submerged in water. Depending where you buy the tickets, make sure you make reservation. They only allow so many people in the cave at any given time. The whole tour takes about three hours, however you're only in the cave for about 1 1/2 hours. The first 45 minutes you watch a video, given instructions, then driven 3 miles to the cave entrance, and then given life vest and a miner's helmet. Once in the cave you either walk, crawl, or swim to the turn around point. A tour guide is with you the whole time along with a photographer. There is no lighting in the cave other than the light on your helmet. Our guide was a guy named Andres who spoke English and a really cool guy. After the tour your taken to a buffet (included in the entrance fee). I personally wasn't too thrilled with the food, but my wife and her family liked it. Over all I really enjoyed this tour and the only thing I didn't like is they don't allow you to take your own personal camera or phones in the cave. Afterward staff shows you the pictures that were taken by the photographer and you may purchase them. The pictures are pricey, but we ended up buying them because we split the cost between three family members. If you buy the pictures, they are given to you in a USB drive. Personally I don't think this tour is for anyone younger than 10 yrs old.

Wonderful experience. I visited with my family and friends. We all had a great time. Our guide Mely did a great job leading the tour in both Spanish and English. The whole experience was well run and well worth the time. It was one of our best experiences in Cancun.

Don’t spoil yourself by looking at too many pictures!. Like I said in the title, don’t spoil yourself by looking at too many pictures. This is the kind of place you have to discover by yourself.Our guide Romain was very kind and really helped to make this tour even better.The only downside is that you can’t take any pictures. They take pictures of you and try to sell them after the tour, but the price is really high (25USD for one picture and nearly 200USD for the complete package which included maybe 30 pictures, a t-shirt and a bottle of alcohol).

pretty awesome, cept the photo cost. stunning inside, photos are $89US. food is great, they have water shoes and a wetsuit for you, there are 3 different caves, your tour guide will bring you to 1, we went to the one with the most water. It's a bit expensive, but Alex as a great guide, just wish he would have pointed his flashlight around more, as my headlamp was not bright enough.
Lovely educational tour. I took my daughter on this you and we both lived it. Lots of education about the geological formations in cenotes, and Mayan culture. A great after noon.

DON'T MISS THIS EXCURSION - IT IS FABULOUS!. This excursion 'Secret River' Rio Secreto - started in 2008 - so if you have not been to Cozumel/Playa Del Carmen in a while, you will be pleasantly surprised to find this one!It is so organized, with friendly pleasant knowledgeable employees - who take personal care of you in small groups with your personal guide and photographer!Dont worry about what to wear - just put on a bathing suit and take a change of clothes!They provide the water shoes, short wet suit, hard hat with light...and a nice changing room with shower, toilets, and personal lockers with locks!Then be prepared to be AMAZED.....you will walk, swim thru caverns full of stalactites, stalagmites, coral formations that are 100's of thousands of years old...Mayan knew about these caverns but they were not rediscovered and mapped for guiding until 2006!The price includes all transporation, equipment and a nice luncheon! The photos are worth the additional price - and delivered to you on a USB...your friends will be happy to see you in this environment!Dont miss this excursion! It makes the others look very boring!

Go to Rio Secreto. If you only do 1 activity, this is the one! The experience was great, you will never forget it.Our guide was very exceptional and really enhanced the experience. Go early to avoid the crowds. Ours was a 1/2 day trip with lunch included. You can't bring your own camera into the caves but they provide excellent photos for you. Quite pricey though. I would not recommend the trip for children less than 10. Older people may have some difficulty as the ground is very uneven and you need good balance. Some may find it claustrophobic but I don't think this is a big issue.

Amazing!. This is one for the record books. Valentino was awesome and very helpful guide - learned alot from him about the formation of the river and caves surrounding it. The ride in was pretty bumpy. But was something to experience, words cannot do it justice. I would recommend BIG TIME! Bringing your own water socks!! You have to use theirs and its seems un-sanitary.

Cenote. This by far as to be on of the coolest experiences! German was our guide and he was so passionate and knowledgable. I definitely recommend this trip. We started off with a walking tour of the caverns. German taught us about the animals that lived in the cave and the geologic formations. There was a little resting point were they had this sort of light show/movie on the walls of the cavern. It would have been cool but it was just really weird. After that we were able to swim through the caverns. It was so amazing. We had lights on our helmets and at one point our guide had us all turn them off. I've never experienced complete darkness before, there was no light for your eyes to adjust to, it was such a simple idea but really cool to experience. They fed us a meal when it was all said and done. The food was good but the only complaint was that they charged $60 for the CD of photos because we weren't allowed to take our own. But other than that, it was one of those moments that I will keep with me and talk about for years to come.

Great attraction. We had a great time, this is very close to Playa del Carmen so you don't loose an entire day away from the beach. Our tour guide Taco was very nice and shared with us his passion for this amazing underground river and caverns

Truly Amazing Adventure!. The beginning of the trip was a little rough. The van ride was EXTREMELY bumpy and felt we were on a roller coaster ride on the road. After arriving at the cavern things went very smoothly. Very organized. Our tour guide, Yayo, was the best. Very informative and patient with all guests. While the water may be cold, with the wet suit and life jacket on, I was sweating by the time we got to the swimming area and it actually felt pretty good. The formations in the cavern are breathtaking. You need to be very balanced and agile on your feet. You can't touch anything in the cave so you have to have really good balance. There are places you have to duck low and places where it drops off a foot and half. Super glad we took the excursion.

Pot holing in the yukatan. Great tour we were the only people on our tour the guide was great Tips take a waterproof camera, be careful on the way down to the entrance it's tricky and slippy You are given a wetsuit and a drink the the tour begins.

Best experience ever!. Raul P was our guide and he was amazing!!! The entire trip was an adventure we'll never forget and it was super educational. Not recommended if you're extremely claustrophobic but definitely give it a try if you even a little bit interested in the caves. Best thing we did while we were in Cancun

Amazing!. From beginning to end, the staff handled every bit of our visit with efficiency and a high level of detail. We loved wading and floating through the underground caves while our guide taught us more about the cave ecosystem and the underground rivers' role in the region's history. It was one of our family's favorite activities during our week long stay in Cancun.
It was ok. Beautiful Place but Sad that you have to Pay so much for something that is Natural. normally I like places like this but I was hoping to find something with a better price

Worth Visiting. Went here based on other ratings and this was very intriguing. If you've been to cave tours in other parts of the world, this is similar, but the fact this is all done in water is different and fascinating. Water is cool but not cold. Just amazing ecology when you think about it. Meal was good but not fantastic. Tour guide was great. Pricey and has the usual photographs scam, but definitely good value for money. Take the collectivo there and buy your own ticket.

Awesome Excursion . This was a much difference excursion than I would have normally picked but that's why we did it. It took about 30-40 minutes to get there from the port but we truly had an amazing time. Our guide was very knowledgeable and helpful the whole tour. The cave was truly beautiful and such a great experience, water was a little chilly but we had wet suits. I would pay to do this excursion again, they feed you some lunch at the end. My only disappointment was that we couldn't bring any cameras or anything inside and the photos are $90 which how can you not buy them....

Worth it!. We booked this as an excursion from our cruise trip. It was about a 45 minute boat ride from the port but trip although a bit choppy was so beautiful. The boat guides were fun and interactive throughout the ride and brought smiles to everyone's face. Once we arrived on land and got into the compound we were joined by Diego who was our guide for the rest of our trip and he made our journey one of the most memorable excursions we've been on. From paying our respect to the spirits, to his knowledge of the cavern, we left wanting to do the excursion all over again. The cave was beautiful and having to swim the end of it was the icing on the cake. I'd talk more about the cave, but it's best you experience it for yourself. Oh another thing about Diego; He was even nice enough to help one of the people in our group "swim" the rest of the way because she couldn't finish the rest of it. I cannot say enough good things about Diego. If you find yourself in Mexico this is simply something you cannot miss.

Wonderful attraction, worth the price, great guides.. I'll keep this fairly short as I see other recent posters have covered a lot of detail. We went with my 14 year old son and almost 72 year old mother (hubby and I are late 40s). The cave system is beautiful. The guides are very well trained. Our guide, Tomas, informed my mom at the beginning that she would be his "VIP guest", meaning that she was up front so he could assist her with getting through the more challenging spots. She made it all the way through the cave system just fine with a little assistance from Tomas, but then had to sit down on the way back out. He patiently waited for her to catch her breath and was able to send the other 4 people in our tour back with another guide so they didn't need to wait.So two pieces of advice if you do this tour:1) take the walking stick. It's optional but very useful as you can't always see how the depth underwater is changing. The one guy in our group who didn't take the stick had to lean on his wife a lot of the time.2) Well, not really advice, but if you can spring for their photos, they do an excellent job. You can't take your own camera in. They send a professional photographer in with your group who puts extra flashes around so the lighting comes out really good. They have various photo packages... if you want no prints but all of the pics on a memory stick, I think I paid $89 US. Oh, one last piece of advice since I mentioned my older mom. My dad, who has more mobility issues now (he's 80) didn't come along. He would not have been able to do this tour. He can walk, but the uneven terrain was too much.

Not to be missed. Nico was our guide through this underground river. They provide you with everything you need for the tour. There are no set paths and you will need to crawl, squat and swim. Very beautiful experience. Nico is very knowledgeable and helpful throughout the tour. He answered all our questons and gave a very detailed history of the cave and the river.

A must see!. Oh my gosh! this was so great! As long as you are not claustrophobic you will love this adventure. Walking and swimming through caves in beautiful clean, clear water! Awesome! We had a nice Mexican lunch afterwards that was very good. Fantastic!!

Great tour second time. This is a don't miss tour in Playa Del Carmen. It's unlike anything you will ever do and the guides are awesome! We had 5 kids (age 8-14) and 4 adults and everyone had fun. Also they limit the number of each group so it's not crowded like other tours. The lunch is authentic and good. This is great too for people who need a break from the sun or sunburn easily. Definitely take the walking stick they offer you won't regret it!

Closest thing to real spelunking. Fifty years ago I dabbled in spelunking during my college days. Rio Secreto comes as close to that experience as one can find. Beautiful cave with no lighting...only the lights on your helmets and a few flashlights. This is truly a great experience for everyone, young and old. You are cared for in an exceptional way while exploring the cave in very small groups. Our family group included teenagers up to Grandma and all of us thoroughly enjoyed it.A great experience that is not to be missed.

Second visit to Rip Secreto. Visited on 3/31/16 with my twin 12 year old boys, another friend with his 12 year old son. We had another Mexican couple with us and their young son. We loved this adventure even more than the first time. This is a highlight for our kids Spring Break visit to Mexico. Our guide Fernanda was very knowledgeable, personable and enjoys working with people, highly recommend! She had no problem tradition ng between Spanish / English for our group. We will be coming back next year to explore the last cave we have not seen, Supreme, and will ask for Fernanda.

Amazing experience wading through a becautiful underground cave. This is truly a one of a kind experience. Rather than just walking along paths in a fully lit cave, you decend into and then explore a beautiful stalactite and stalagmite filled cavern by way of the river which helped create its amazing beauty. Only the lights on your and other visitors hard hats and a few high intensity flashlights illuminate its beauty which enhances the shadows and helps make the experience truly exceptional.Wow, wow, wow.Yes, the precautions about being able to walk on uneven terrain, deal with being in a not fully lighted environment and being in a cave are all valid. Having a bit of fitmness and no back or joint impairments helps too - you do walk a bit in the jungle on the way to the cave entrance and there are uneven steps to get in and out of the cave. But while I could tell not every member of our small group (four adults and two 10 year old boys from one family and my husband and I) were sure they really wanted to do this, it was CRYSTAL CLEAR every one of us was thrilled they went a bit beyond their comfort level for this wonderful experience.Our guide (Alfredo Ponce) and a photographer were with us the whole time to teach, support and educate us. And, although we were in the cave about 15 minutes than usual it seemed like the experience ended moments after it started. All that was said in the other positive reviews is correct. WONDERFUL.They also sell photos and will have pictures of just those in YOUR group if your tour has more than one family as ours did. Are pricey but proceeds from their sale do help support maintenance of this very unusual site. Would suggest getting at least one. If you want more than one you might as well choose the package with many additional pictures not from your tour. They are phenomenally beautiful. The provided wet suits, swimming shoes, hard hats and (at the end) towel were all clean and the staff made sure they fit well. One of the added bonuses is that you get to see a bit of Playa del Carmen and some of the local roads and highways, as well as the lush vegitation along the curving dirt road which leads to the entrance to the cave. We also had a very nice local meal after our cave experience. There was also beer, soda and snacks for sale. if you are on the tour from a cruise ship you also get a delightful but fairly long ferry boat trip from the ship (will be docked at Cozumel) to Playa del Carmen. You may even have a small about of time to explore Playa del Carmen in the area near the ferry dock while waiting for the ferry back to Cozumel. Don't worry about missing the ferry. The tour staff closely monitor everyone gets to the ferry. If a trourist misses it, that would be the tourist's fault.

WOW. 58 of us are on the tour to the “Amazing Secret River”. We were broken down into five groups traveling in five large Toyota mega vans. The drive out of the city on paved roads went about 10 miles. (Amazingly, there are sidewalks all the way out here on one side of the road = Future expansion I suppose) to a point close to where you would normally turn East to Tulum (small Inca structure on the ocean front), where we turned West onto a dirt road into the jungle for about 5 miles of bumpy road. The property we entered is private with what “they tell us = we did not see it) a very large gravel pit at the far end of that dusty road (now I know another reason other then the sun, why the vans are all white).The property is a natural conservatory area (outlined by National Geographic magazine a number of years ago) to preserve the wild life (Black puma’s / Leopards / Raccoon like animal / etc.). Back in 2006, the landowner stumbled across this opening in the jungle floor that allowed access to an underground Lambeth of caves.Background = About 6,000,000 years ago the Yucatan land mass of today was an underwater coral reef that was lifted up above the water (not sure if this was a geological lift or a drop in sea level).Today as you fly over this area (the Yucatan peninsula of Mexico) you do not see any flowing water (streams or rivers) as due to the porous nature of the limestone the water flows under the surface, and is only occasionally exposed as cenotes (cave-in’s of the surface stone exposing pools of water.The cave and underground passage / river was open to the public 8 years ago and has been a hit ever since. Open all year round, with high water inside the cave being experienced in October.You are given a guide (there were about 8 sightseers in our group) who first gives you a lock and locker for your belongings, then has everyone shower (in your bathing suits) to remove any chemicals / stuff, then the guide provides you with a 3 mill shorty wetsuit & beach shoes & helmet with light & life jacket & walking stick. = You will find the Walking stick and Life Jacket are VERY important!!!!Hint – Hint = Get the next bigger size life jacket so that you are more flexible in the caves.We brought along our own beach shoes, but not necessary as they provide such. I would suggest (but not necessary) we would have been better off bring along our wetsuit shoes that cover our ankles (that’s what the guides wear). BIG PROBLEM --- THEY DO NOT allow you to bring along a camera or an additional flashlight. At first I though ---- YEA you want to sell us pictures (and they do a great job of having a special photographer accompany each group). But I later realized you need your hands free as you go through the cave & water passageways and even a hand held waterproof go pro camera would be a determent as it would restrict your hands keeping you upright. NO they will not allow you to take along a Go Pro that mounts to you helmet (again they are out to sell you pictures).Anyway --- The Guide (Valentino for us) gave us a very detailed explanation of the cave history and how to process through it. He was instrumental in helping us along all the way with very caring concerns and excellent information. I have been in a number of natural caves (spelunking) in my exploits (Brown County in southern Indiana / Mammoth Cave in Kentucky / Ruby Falls & Lost Canyon in Tennessee to name a few. Not to mention WW II Japanese caves in Pellilue / New Zeeland / diving underwater in Cozumel). Sure there are most likely other great caves to visit, but THIS CAVE is the BEST I have ever been in!Because there is a LOT of up and downs / tight passages / on & off water entries (water depth was mostly around 2 ft but there was one location where it was 10 ft deep = Yea life jacket is a must) I would NOT suggest this tour for anyone that is not very flexible and stable on their feet, although my BIG BROTHER of 30 years age (with 50 years of additional experience) made it through OK, (but by the end he had enough)! There were two groups that had small children, and those groups bypassed a lot of the difficult walking areas. This cave system is MASSIVE with only about 10% open to tour.Following the exit from the cave, we turned in all our equipment, changed into dry clothes and then viewed our pictures --- WOW = Really good stuff. Option to buy was $85 for all the pictures of us (just John and I) along with some Fu Fu fill pictures, or $25 for just one picture (well I had to get that one).We then had lunch, which was very good, followed by our return trip in the van.

Great experience . We have visited caves throughout the UK however havnt been able to experience them like this it was a wonderful experience and we highly recommend it. The mayan blessing at the beginning was very special also
Spring vacation. I highly recommend Rio Secreto to anyone who is in Cancun. What an amazing experience. I suggest the plus package and its from 10 to 5:30pm.

Forever Memorable.. My adult son talked me into taking this tour while on a cruise. To be honest, I was not expecting much but it turned out to be the highlight of our tours. The entire experience was intriguing. Every detail was down to a science. We were fully outfitted in wetsuit, water shoes and helmet. Then led through an awesome tropical jungle like setting to the cave enterence. The guides were exceptional in knowledge and safety. I'm 63 and was made to feel just as important as anyone taking the tour. They treated me with care and respect, as if I were their grandmother. We also had lightweight life jackets on, even though the water depth was never over 3-4 feet deep. The total experience was like being in another world. A fantastic adventure!

Very very good. We took this as part of a Celebrity reflection cruises excursion. It was great. We were dressed up with diving suits, float vests, crash helmets, and water shoes. Our excellent guide then took us into this one hour cave tour, including walking and swimming in water. Pitch black darkness at times and total quietness. We enjoyed it!!We then ate a included good lunch!!Only one sour note. The usb photo that we paid 70 dollars for did not work. No pictures at all when we tried to view them with our pc back home. So maybe you should skip the usb photo.
Well Done!. Don't miss out on this unique and fun adventure. Good guides. Kids loved it but will need to watch over them. Nice job preserving this gift of nature.

A unique experience. This is a must if you are in the Riviera Maya. Though it is 100% a tourist attraction (complete with the option to buy a photo package at the end), it is a unique experience and the opportunity to see amazing natural underground caves, rock formations, and clear water. The Rio Secreto experience involves a brief video orientation followed by a short van ride to the cave site. Once at the site, you are given a wetsuit, helmet with light, and water vest. You should bring your own water booties. You then walk to the cave and descend into a truly remarkable natural setting of clear shallow water, amazing rock formations, and darkness. Though there are a couple of areas where the water is deep enough in which to float, you are walking most of the time. The guides are extremely helpful and knowledgable during the 90 minute excursion into the caves, and you always feel safe. My wife and young adult daughters enjoyed themselves throughout. Though they boast a buffet feast of Mexican cuisine afterward, the food was pretty awful and not worth eating. Despite this, the caves are worth taking a morning for this excursion.

Incredible!. This cave tour/adventure was incredible. From our arrival at the site everything was well organized, sizing for wetsuits, footwear, lifejackets etc. The tour was conducted in small groups (ten) and it was a short walk to the cave mouth from the arrival site. Along the way our guide identified different types of flora in the region. There are six different routes that are used, which is great because you never run into another group while in the cave.I have never been in a cave like this before and it was very informative. We spend at least an hour and half in the cave. There was some swimming and most of the time was wading through the refreshing water. I would definitely recommend this as an item to do if you are in the Playa del Carmen region.

Really Amazing!. This was really fun, interesting and amazing. I booked this excursion when my cruise stopped at Cozumel and am very happy I did. Here's what you can expect.From Cozumel it's a long excursion, about 7 hrs, with a ferry ride to the mainland (30+ min), then a van ride starting on smooth roads and ending on very bumpy jungle paths (45 min.)Once there we were given a free locker to change, then asked to shower off before being given and donning wetsuits, life vest and helmets with lights.Our tour guide Alondra was absolutely wonderful. She lead our group of 9 through the jungle where we took part in an ancient ceremony before descending into a sinkhole to the amazing caves and river below.1.5 hrs later we returned to the surface, walked back to the lockers, were given a free shot an unusual local liquor, browsed our photos and were given a free lunch before leaving.Tip: Bring comfortable water shoes as you will be walking much more than swimming.Tip2: Walking in varying depths of water on very uneven terrain for a long time can be difficult and dangerous, especially since you cannot always see clearly through the water.Tip3: If taking the ferry back to Cozumel, know that there are two different docks for cruise ships there and the ferry might not be taking you to the dock you want. Although a cab on shore will.

A must for your visit to the Yucatan!. We spent a week in the Yucatan and this was the high point. Definitely a once in a lifetime experience. We had Pablo as our guide and he was outstanding. We were literally inside the earth and in a place few have ever seen. Not for the infirm or overweight; and I'd recommend taking the optional walking stick. Accept that you will pay extra for the pictures; you will want a record of the experience and it makes sense that you are not permitted to take pictures. I really think they do care about this place and are not running a tourist trap. Our experience was very reverent. Book in advance.

I would give it a six!. We took our two boys, ages 12 and 6, on this wonderful tour. We were fortunate to have Raul P. as our guide. He recognized early on that our younger son was going a little slower, so he had him come to the front of the pack and set the tour to his pace. The caves were beautiful! Swimming, climbing, learning--all unforgettable. We called and booked a few days early and got a better rate than what was listed. Transportation costs seemed quite high, so we found our own way there. I think our whole family will be talking about this experience for a while!

One word: Holyguacamole!. The newest cenote discovery in the Yucatan is a treat for cenote fans! After filling out a form regarding language preference you are put in a group of 8-10 people with a bilingual guide. Then get changed into swimwear and they provide you with wetsuits, water shoes& lighted hard hats. A 15-min walk in the woods to get to the cenote entrance but not demanding. They provide you with a walking stick if you need (we had a lady who'd just had hip surgery and they were quite solicitous about her welfare). Upon entering the caves you must switch on your headlamp as this is the ONLY lighting(NOT for claustrophobes!). The ceiling dips down to just above your head thru some parts, swim thru other parts. I was left speechless at some of the sights. A God's piece of work!
Unforgettable!. This was the best day of our vacation. The caves are incredible! Our guide Andres was great, very knowledgeable and easygoing.

Amazing!!!!. This was one of those things that you remember for the rest of your life! It is up there with swimming with wild spinner dolphins in Hawaii and stingray city in Grand Cayman.Our guide, Argelia (Leah) was phenomenal! Very attentive to safety of everyone. There were 11 of us in our group. We were 39 ft under the ground in this secret grotto. Sometimes water to your ankles and other times no bottom to stand on and swimming is necessary. You are outfitted with wetsuits (optional) and life vests (not optional). Yes, it is sometimes a bit claustrophobic but it is certainly worth it.Meal at the end was very good and the shot of whatever it was....tasted like Sambuca with an aftertaste of honey was delectable. A must do thing if you are in Playa Del Carmen.don't pass this up!!1

Awesome cruise excursion!. My mom and I selected Rio Secreto while on a cruise to Cozumel this past week, after a lot of research and reading reviews. It was everything we had hoped it would be, and more! The ferry ride from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen was VERY rough, and many got seasick, but it was worth the 30 minutes of a little discomfort to get to explore the caves. Once we arrived, we were given wetsuits, water shoes, life jackets, and helmets, and was a very simple process. Our tour guide was Alan, and he was knowledgable, enthusiastic, and clearly passionate about giving tours. We were in a group of 12 from our ship, and everyone worked together as a team while walking through rockier and steeper parts of the cave. We did buy the pictures on a USB drive, and while expensive, completely worth it for the 15 or so pictures they captured of my mom and I. It was a once in a lifetime experience, and I hope to make it back someday!!!

An experience not to be missed. We had been to many caves in other places but never in a cave with no lights. You need to be in relatively good shape as you will walk a lot and will swim a little as well. You arrive at the caves after a 6km rough dirt road ride but do not let that deter you. You walk a short distance and receive a Mayan blessing prior to going down the stairs to to caves.The water shoes, wet suit, life vest and hard hat with light are all provided. All you need is to wear your swimsuit. The guide will lead you through the caves which are loaded with Stalactites, stalagmites and columns. At one point the guide has everyone turn off their lights and the place is pitch black. Great experience and kids seemed to love it as well.Our tour included a lunch buffet. It was good and make sure to try the lime soup, a Mayan favorite. Watch out for the hot sauces they are very very hot.

Something special . I have got a recommendation from reception. It is not so commercial like entertaining parks , we love nature so we have chosen this trip. We took a taxi , because it is close to Playa del Carmen. It is not cheap , but everything is very well organized. You get wet suit, helmet, shoes , life jacket, guide and a lunch, well almost vegetarian lunch but ok. Photos are overpriced, we took only one for 25 Euros ??!!Dario was our guide, really enthusiastic guy , funny and kind. First we drove then we walked through the jungle. He was looking up for birds , still I was terrified because of snakes. There were a lot of groups inside the cave but we didn't meet any , because each has its own way. Water is crystal clear, we saw a bat and a catfish. Really great experience. Enjoy!!

Great Place !!!. Rio Secreto is really a great place to visit. The beauty of it is something I had never seen before. They set you up with all the gear that you will need and lead you on the tour. I was afraid at first but that quickly went away and I really enjoyed myself. Our guide Taco shared some very interesting information about the cave with our group. So glad I didn't miss out on this place. You don't have to book a big tour to visit here. We came on our own. We looked for directions and rented a car. Its an easy ride from Playa Del Carmen. We saved lots of money. We also visited some of the cenotes along the highway. However you get here, you'll be glad that you did.

Great experience!. We did the plus tour with kids ages 10, 13, and 16 and they all really enjoyed it. They really enjoyed going in the water in the cave. The fact that it was all natural was truly amazing and something that will never be forgotten.

last minute excursion. Great trip - wasn't too long so it left time for other activities. Our guide Bohish was excellent, very passionate about the cenotes and very informative. We started with the ATV's - wear pants, they get hot around your ankles. One of my friends dropped out because of that. The road they take you on wasn't that exciting - the ending of the ATV's we went into the jungle and was more challenging and fun!The cave was so special and amazing - truly a once in a life time experience. Would recommend!

Better than the pictures. I am not a super adventurous person, especially on vacation. This was totally worth going to. I'm so glad we went here. The pictures you see make it look like the cave is all lit up, but it's actually dark in there with the exceptions of your head lamps. Guoda was our guide and she was fantastic. We could tell she knew so much about the cave and really loved the environment. She was also pretty funny and snarky. I enjoyed having her as a guide! The water is really cold at first, but I warmed up quickly (and I'm a small person who gets cold very easily). I was sad when the tour was over. It wasn't scary and instead was amazing. I loved the picture we got of us standing on the rocks with the stalagmites behind us. So awesome! I would recommend this to everyone.

Great adventure!. If you love a little adventure then this is it! Love every moment of it. Never been to a cave and it was awesome! Our guide Nico was excelent as well! Truly recommend him to be your guide! Knows Spanish, English and German! Just a great overall experience!

Best excursion I have ever been on. Rio Secreto takes you into the amazing Mayan underworld. We truly had our breath taken away when we got into the cenotes (caves). The road in to the jungle is very rough so be ready for that. It is well worth the ride. You get an introduction to the cenotes and the area before putting on a wetsuit, helmet and light and hiking down into to caves. You spend about an hour moving through the water inside the caves and see amazing sites. Some of the terrain is a little rugged, you need to move carefully. There are a couple of spots where you can float along in the water. You can pay extra for photographs. I recommend doing so, since you can't take any photos yourself.

Rio Secreto Experience. This was a once in a lifetime experience that our whole group enjoyed immensely. Our guide, Andres, was fantastic! He was very knowledgeable about the history of these caves and the facts surrounding their discovery. He was humourous and very intuitive to the needs of our group, helping when people needed it, and keeping us moving so we all got the most out of this experience. He made this experience lots of fun and very enjoyable for everyone involved. Thank you Andres for giving us memories that will last a lifetime! I highly recommend this activity to someone with an adventurous spirit. The water is cold at first, but doesn't take much time to adjust to. I would make sure people are well aware of the physical intensity of this activity before deciding to go, as some parts are quite rough to navigate through but those who are up for the challenge will certainly not regret it.

Great adventure!. This was a fun place to explore. It's a bit of a ride from Playa de Carmen, but the underwater caves are worth it. The water is cold, but you get used to it quickly and you are wearing a wet suit. Our guide, Diana, was fantastic - knowledgeable and friendly and committed to preservation of the caves. You have to be ready to crawl, swim/float, and maneuver around rocks. All of us loved the tour and would definitely recommend and do it again.

Breathtaking!!. Well worth the money and the pictures. It took 3 1/2 hours from start to finish and they put you with a small group about your same age and language spoken. Very professional, informative and safe. The water was cool. We did not need the optional wetsuit. Everything I wanted in a cenote!

absolutely breath taking. I had no word how to describe how beautiful and amazing this experience was. I didn't know how to swim, but I had so much fun. I had to wear a wet suit and life jacket. Even for some people who know how to swim, I would still recommend them to wear the wet suit because it serves as an extra layer of protection from the cold water.We booked a private tour with a party of three. The tour guide was enthusiastic and very helpful. He was basically hanging on to my life jacket and dragging me across the water. ;) Refreshments and lunch was provided. But don't drink too much water before the tour. Washroom is not available until the end of the tour, which might be 2 to 3 hours away.

Unique, fun, amazing. I have been in several caves, but this was hands down the coolest experience I have ever had. Your journey starts by getting into your bathing suits, showering (to remove oils that can negatively effect the cave,) and then squeezing into a wet suit, water shoes, hard hat with LED light, and a life jacket. Walking sticks are optionally provided.You take a small hike through the jungle to get to the opening of the cave, or cenotes. On the way they perform a Mayan blessing with amber incense as the locals are very respectful of Mayan tradition. Next you enter the cave.You descend into the cave and are immediately exposed to water. 90% of your experience will be in water; however, you never submerge. Most of the experience is knee to waist deep but there are a few areas you have to swim or rather float, as the life jackets are incredibly buoyant. If you have trouble, the guide will help you.The cave formations are absolutely incredible.Afterwards, they serve an authentic Mexican lunch.The one negative about this experience I had was you stop quite frequently to have pictures taken. They do not allow personal cameras or photography of any kind. Everything must be purchased through the tour service. The full picture package was almost $120 and you can buy a single picture for $25.

Amazing Experience . My husband and I chose to do a private tour which was incredible. Everything was arranged for us including wet suits, snacks in the cave, and a beautiful picnic lunch. The tour was about 3 hours and we went in a separate, completely private area and were really able to appreciate the beauty of the caves. Raul was a perfect guide and we can't wait to come back!

Do this!. Had an amazing experience!! Julio was our guide and it's obvious he loves his job. He's very knowledgeable about the cenotes and has a respect for their history and preservation. It's something everyone should experience. **dont wear hairspray, perfumes, make up or use any sunscreen. This will affect the quality of the water and may interfere with the delicate ecosystem ***. The lunch after was lovely and the group (only 10 per guide) was a lot of fun.

Amazing. The underground cavers were absolutely breathtaking. The water here is so clear its unbelievable. It's also good to know that they are trying to preserve the cave as much as they can. The tour guides were very knowledgeable and entertaining. They provide you with everything you need-showers, towels, gear, water shoes. The lunch was also really good. The only thing i wish they would different is to take more pictures during the tour and pics are pretty pricey too $80 USD for a digital copy. However, the pic we did get were amazing, especially with the lighting effects. This tour was definitely once in a life time experience.
Amazing. Amazing trip, the guide was nice, the lunch was delicious, awesome underground river. Our guide is Tomas, really funny guy, took us on this incredible adventure.

Worth every penny. Pros: *unbelievable views of the caves*tour guides are very knowledgeable (Loved Julián, our tour guide) *facilities and equipment are clean *wetsuits, water shoes and life jackets are provided by them. *new water shoes are $10 if you want to purchase them. Cons: *Food is included but only OK.*No cameras are allowed in the caves. No GoPros, no iPhones. *if you want photos of your trip, you need to purchase them through Rio Secreto. One pic is $25 dollars, or you can buy them all for $89.My recommendations: *do the tour with a walking stick. They are next to the life vests. It really helps to balance and also they help you judge better the depth of where you are stepping into.
very nice half a day excursion. We were looking for a short expedition: few minutes away from Playa Del Carmen downtown. Very interesting and nice installation. Thanks to Pauline, our French guide.

Amazing! Again. Visited rio Secreto last week for the second time. It was equally as interesting the second time. Our quide Miguel, was very knowledgeable and well spoken. We were impressed with the lunch that was included ..

My favorite part of our vacation!. The Amazing Secret River tour was the best part of our vacation by far. The boat ride from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen was ruff the day we went and the bus ride to the cave was bumpy and hot. Ok, there I said it just like everyone else...but the Amazing Secret River is AMAZING!!!! Well worth any inconvenience we encountered. The water is cold but after getting in it is pleasant, our guide Andres was EXCELLENT! He stopped and explained every time anyone asked a question. He helped people who were afraid of the water or of taking a step (this is not difficult walking as reported in some other reviews, if you can hike you can easily make this trip), and he was pleasant and very informative. He even sat with our family for about 15 minutes while we waited for the lock on our locker to be cut off when he could have easily left us to fend for ourselves. The cave is beautiful, you are allowed to look closely at the stalactites and stalagmites (I know which is which because I asked Andres), you are asked not to touch any natural formations but you really can't help it because you are walking among them. I loved this and will go back to Playa del Carmen again just to take this tour. Thank you Andres for making this a memory I will never forget.

Super guide. We enjoyed our tour at Rio Secreto. My husband and I have swam in cenetos before but this was a different experience being inside the caves. It was a little difficult to find, but well worth the tour. Our guide was knowledgeable and friendly. We were surprised because normally everyone on our trip expected a tip, but not our guide at Rio Secreto. When we went to find him to give him a tip, he was quietly on his break eating a snack and not expecting a tip for his amazing service. A nice surprise.

Absolutely Amazing!. I could not imagine the adventure we were to have. Our tour guide was brilliant, informative and clear on how to best handle our adventure! The scenery was awe inspiring; to think that these caves and the river were such a recent discovery! My wish is that this will be preserved and cared for, in the right way. Take the tour! Don't miss it. Good water shoes needed. The place provides them, but if you have your own, bring them!I toured with my daughter and other family. Ages 21-53.
Extremely Happy. Our guide Alfredo shared his passion for the caves and underground river with us. We enjoyed every minute exploring the caves!

Exceptional site. Must see!. Just minutes from Playa del Carmen, Rio Secreto is an amazing experience if you have some Indiana Jones blood or fantasies! It lasts half a day including travel from and to the hotel, preparation, visit and lunch. The staff was friendly and our guide Rodolfo was very knowledgeable and had a lovely French accent. We did the Allegria tour and heard afterwards that there were at least 3 or 4 other paths, meaning additional opportunities to come back and explore. It is not that cold contrary to one could think. The toughest part is to take a cold shower and slide in that tight wet suit. Once you are set up with the helmet, shoes and life jacket, you will be in for a walk through the jungle and a mayan ritual ceremony. There the journey underground starts with its natural wonders. We walked in the water, discovered bacon and popcorn natural formations (yes that is a teaser!), meditated for a few minutes in a lake in the dark among bats and catfish, swam among the stalactites and stalagmites. The groups were small which was perfect to connect respectfully with this unique and fragile environment. If you like adventure and nature, this is a must see!

Great Tour. My wife and I had a great experience Our guide Aly was terrific, our groups age range was 50 -67 and she was very concerned for each of us. Taking time to make sure everyone safe and having a good time. She called us family and took care of us. The tour itself was very memorable. After the tour we had a celebratory drink and then a lunch. all in all a great time

Unique Experience. Exploring the underwater river is a spectacular experience. We were fortunate to have a group of just five people, three of whom spoke only Spanish and the two of us who spoke only English. Our guide, Valentino, did an excellent job guiding us and translating in both languages. We are not certain how the tour might have worked had we been in a larger group with three or more languages. The cave system is so vast that a number of different tours can take place simultaneously. We only saw one other group, at a distance, during our time in the caverns. As a result, it was easy to focus on the experience. The only downsides to the experience were the emphasis on taking our pictures through the first half of the tour, in hopes of selling them to us at the end. At $25 a pop, there were none sold in our group. The other element that could be improved was the lunch included at the end of the tour. It was not at a standard fitting Playa Del Carmen. Overall, however this is a first-rate experience and we would recommend it highly.

Well with the money and time!. We traveled here from our hotel on a vacation to Cancun. The whole experience was amazing! The bus that picked us up from our hotel was professional, timely and COMFORTABLE! All the staff at Rio Secreto were simply amazing. We always felt we were in good hands and totally cared for. Our guide was Jorge, who was just fantastic! They were all so incredibly organized and each group is no more than 11 people, and we felt as if we were the only ones in the cave. You truly get a one of a kind experience! They also provide a lunch which was simple, but delicious! The cave is its own world, with so much wonder and beauty. We truly loved this experience and are eager to do it again!!

Nice excursion. Booked this through our hotel. Good outing. Most of time is spent underground in cave. After you arrive there is about a 10 min drive to the site. They transport you in a van. Road is quite rough. When you arrive, they get you partnered up with a guide. Small groups. All gear supplied including wet suits. Change rooms provided. If you have your own water shoes along I'd recommend using them. Their's are pretty beat up and may fit a bit sloppy. The terrain is rough down under and a decent fit on shoes is good idea for better traction. Instructions and what to expect all given by bilingual guide. They offer a walking stick, which in hindsight we wish we'd taken. The terrain inside is very uneven and rough and several places you're required to take big steps up or down and into the water and you can never be sure how you land as it is dark except for the headlights on your helmet. If you're vertically challenged, (short) you will need a bit more help in spots due to steep drops into water or out. If you are at all unsteady this is not for you unless you have someone to help and steady you. The guide can assist one person but the rest must help each other, which we all did. We had one older gentleman (70's) that required a fair bit of assistance, which I think surprised him as he seemed quite fit otherwise. Was only maybe 1- 2 spots where it was over our heads, but short stretches. The food after was satisfying. Fine for vegetarians, vegans, gluten-free and meat eaters. The guide, Pauline was knowledgeable and interesting. Her English okay. Sometimes others in group helped her find the best words to interpret for us. I'd recommend when questions asked by others in Spanish to interpret all for non Spanish speaking. We felt we lost some of the conversations because of that. Use mosquito repellent when outside. They had some eco friendly on posts to use. Overall would recommend.

Must experience. If you do only one excursion while you are here, this is the one to do. The underground river and cave formations were an almost spiritual experience. The majesty of nature is hard to describe -- it must be seen.

Magical. We were spellbound the entire way through this beautiful underground world. So many various rock formations, swimming in the crystal waters, experiencing the profound silence and darkness of the cave. Our guide Jano was excellent - very good English and was so knowledgeable about everything we were seeing. We were a small group of 6 which was perfect! Would highly recommend this outing

Nature As It's Best. I have nothing negative to say about this tour. From the pick up from our hotel in Playa Del Carmen to up to the end of the tour was just excellent. Our guide Tomas was really knowledgeable and funny. It is a jaw dropping nature wonder. I would definitely come back with my children.
Beautiful . Beautiful, informative, a must see for anyone who likes exploring caverns. Swiping in crystal water, walking through cave formations. Truly beautiful.

Rio Secreto, A Hidden Wonder. Rio Secreto is an attraction just south of Playa Del Carmen, Mexico. (This attraction should not be taken by anyone that is unsteady in their walking, as the surface inside the cenote is uneven and it is sometimes hard to see to the bottom.) That said I really enjoyed this site. Everyone was sorted into different languages so that our guides could better tell us about everything. Groups were taken to the entrance where we received out life jackets, wet suits, safety helmets, walking stick & our lockers. When we were changed, our guide escorted us to one of four entrances to the cenote, where a short Mayan ceremony was carried out. Once inside, we were transported to an entirely different world. Romain, our guide was very knowledgeable and helpful. We were cautioned to avoid touching any of the stalagmites and stalacites. We used the walking stick to steady us and in other areas we swam for a short distance. The overhead clearance was fairly good. (When there is a large amount of rain, certain sections may be closed as the clearance may be too low). I loved the fact that there was only the 8 of us and the guide in our area. It was nice that we were not overrun by a billion other tourists. We only started to hear another group just at the end of our 1.5 hours underground. Once outside, we changed and were treated to a Mayan liqueur and a hearty lunch before departing back to our hotels. This attraction was very cool - most of us never get to see stalagmites & stalacites up close and personal. If you are looking for something different in the way of excursions, this is the one for you. It was well worth the price.

amazing cave adventure. This was an amazing cave adventure ...beginning the adventure with a mayan blessing ..the beautiful rock formations and adventure of climbing, swimming fortunately no crawling for 2 hours is an experience I would repeat again if I return to mexico.
