I would definitely suggest to others!

Rio Secreto . I was able to experience the Rio Secreto in May. It was amazing! Our tour guide, Alfredo, was great! He was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic! I would recommend this adventure into the culture if Mexico!

Spectacular Experience. Overall I think the experience is well worth the $67 entry fee. The cave itself was beautiful and did not even look real! Our guide, Ro, was awesome: so caring, professional, friendly, and funny. He made this an experience for us all. Getting to see the cave while swimming through the water is a memory not to be forgotten.The lunch served after the tour was very good, considering it was a buffet. We did not buy the pictures - pretty pricey!ALL IN ALL AN AMAZING EXPERIENCE!

Good experience but skip the pictures. Overall I think the experience is worth it. The cave itself was beautiful and our guide was great. Getting to see the cave while swimming through the water is a memory to last a lifetime. Unfortunately as an amateur photographer myself my only complaint is the picture package they sell to you afterwards. They have a dedicated photographer take pictures of you throughout the tour as bringing your own camera is forbidden (even if its waterproof). They give you an option of $25 for one picture, $50 for two and $75 for the entire package. First I understand that the high price may be justified to cover for maintainence of the property and wildlife, and I am actually glad to contribute to this cause. However, all the pictures that we got are really really small (800 - 1200 pixels). Most pictures were did not even have enough resolution to cover my computer screen, forget about printing anything larger than a 4 x 6. It does not cost them any more money to give larger images so I don't know what their rationale is. I would still recommend the tour but if I knew this beforehand I would definitely have not bought the picture package.

Spectacular/ not to be missed. We were a little wary of spending 79 dollars to see this as we read other cenotes in the area had very less entry charges but we went with it as it was recommended by the hotel but at the end we were very satisfied with the whole experience. The caves are spectacular and stunning and one feels like being in an Indiana Jones movie. A special mention to our guide RAUL, he was fantastic. He was so passionate about the caves, conservation and wildlife. Very informative and great sense of humour. My husband has a problem with claustrophobia but he was fine here. My boys aged 16 and 21 also totally enjoyed. Cameras are not allowed and would not be convenient to carry as it involves a bit of wading and swimming on the uneven rocks but a professional photographer follows you. Not recommended for elderly people. Buffet at the end was good. Only downside is that they could make the price for one copy of photo for keepsake a little reasonable after spending so much on the entrance (it is 25 dollars for one picture and 80 for the whole usb) All in all we loved the whole experience.

Jorge is the best!. This tour was beautiful. Our family loves caves and this one did not disappoint. It was fun walking/swimming through the passages. The lunch that was served after the tour was delicious. Jorge was very attentive and took good care of us. It was very convenient to meet the van so near the ferry from Cozumel. Definitely will recommend this tour to our friends.

Amazing..everyone should experience this natural beauty!. We went to Rio Secreto in May on a excursion through a cruise line. The whole experience was amazing and I am still talking about it two weeks later. From the moment we arrived, the staff was very friendly and helpful. It was nice that they had small tour groups and that they were very good helping to explain everything so all the guest that spoke different languages could understand. The hike to the cave is beautiful and the blessing from the Mayan upon entering the cave was perfect. You can tell the staff and people really care about the land and nature there. Fernanda was our tour guide. She was what made the tour unforgettable. It was adventures for all the guests, and our group laughed and learned a lot while exploring the cave. She did a great job making everybody feel comfortable and safe. Any kind of question she would stop and answer for us, and her knowledge on the area and the land was unbelievable. The lunch after was actually pretty good. I was very pleased with the service outside of the tour itself. I would recommend everybody to go and see this natural wonder, and I myself would like to go back and see it again. Fernanda was a great guide and I recommend her as well. Thank you Rio Secreto for being the highlight of my vacation.

One word...Wow. Rio Secreto was simply amazing. If you are interested in doing the caves while you are in Mexico I highly recommend going to Rio Secreto. The staff is so friendly, speaks English, and wants to make sure you have the best time possible. The caves are stunning and literally take your breath away. They provide you with a great lunch and take pictures for you in the caves as well. We will absolutely go back!

MUST SEE! Surreal, one-of-a-kind, unique experience!. Unbelievably amazing experience. You cannot see anything else like this anywhere in the entire world - take advantage of it while you are in Playa! My (21 year old) daughter and I were picked up about a block away from our hotel at 7:45am. After picking up the rest of the group (10 of us in total) at various other hotels, we arrived at the Rio Secreto entrance - which, by the way, is less than 10 minutes from Playa del Carmen.After receiving our wristbands and watching a short video on what was ahead of us, we got back on the bus and drove another 15 minutes up a very bumpy road to the actual location of the caves. We got lockers for our belongings, rinsed off in a (very cold) shower, and received our full gear - water shoes, wetsuits, life jackets, helmets, and a headlight. The caves themselves cannot be described in words - you truly have to see them for yourself. Even the best photographs do not accurately portray the beauty of the place. The tour guides are incredibly informative and keep you entertained the whole way through. There's also a photographer that follows alongside the group, and the photos he takes as well as shirts and other souvenirs can be purchased after the tour. A delicious buffet lunch is also served after the cave exploration! Really yummy food. Transportation is provided after the tour back to the hotels.Some tips: consider getting the "walking stick" that they offer at the beginning of the tour! The caves are rocky, uneven, and very painful if you happen to fall or scrape yourself. You also can't touch the limestone for conservation purposes, so having the stick there to brace yourself if you feel unsteady would be very helpful! Additionally, bring cash for tipping the driver, tour guide, and photographer - also if you want to purchase photos! You'll definitely want those to remember the experience. Do not hesitate booking Rio Secreto - you'll only regret it if you don't go!

Almost one-of-a-kind. This excursion is among the few that I can say is almost a one-of-a-kind experience. The entire experience was refreshing and unlike anything else we've ever seen. Being in a cave this this? Incredible, but can be done elsewhere. Add the opportunity to swim in the cenotes, spend so much time on the tour, and have a moment of silence and complete darkness in a silent, sacred place? That just takes it over the top. I enjoyed my time in the cave, with a small group of my fellow travelers, and with the guide Lalo and photographer Fernando.One small detraction was the emphasis on posing for photographs if (like me) you aren't intending to spend the money on their photography ($25-75). I understand the reasons behind not allowing cameras and taking professional photos, but I didn't love the posing. I felt it took away from the moment but that's just a personal preference. A few people from our group enjoyed the photos so I'm glad someone was able to capture the experience for them. The food afterwards was bien auténtica (authentic Mexican food). We had handmade tortillas, refried black beans, scrambled eggs flavored with a flower from the Yucatan, rice, pico de gallo with nopal cactus, and some hot sauces with agua de jamaica (hibiscus-flavored drink) to share with our group. I enjoyed my time on this unique excursion and recommend it to anyone traveling to this region.

Rio Secreto. What a wonderful experience. This was well worth the time and money. The guides are very knowledgeable and fun. Our guide, sorry I don't remember her name, a female from France, was outstanding. The water was refreshing and clear. We would definitely return.

Paradise. We went through a Disney Fantasy excursion. They picked us up at the port and we took a ferry to Playa Del Carmen. The ferry ride was awful, but the crew were attentive. After 45 min you arrive to Playa Del Carmen and you meet your guide. They take you to the Secret River and let me tell you; once your there you forget all about the ferry ride. It is so beautiful and the guide was so informative and wonderful. We were blessed before going into the caves by a Mayan descendent, it was a very spiritual moment. Then you get a very good buffet. Everything was perfect. The photos were expensive, but I just bought one. That was enough for me.

Amazing expierience! . Hi, we are just back home from Mexico and this was the TOP expierience of our holiday. Every day we talking about this beautiful underworld. We had the chance to do this trip with a very passionate guide Alfredo. He has so much knowledge of caves. I was speechless of all this underground beauty! We were one of the lucky ones to go for a long tour (2,5 - 3h) only with cameraman and guide Alfredo. This is a MUST SEE when you're in Mexico! Many thanks Alfredo! Tom & Saskia

Amazing caves, shame about the photography focus. The underground cave system at Rio Secreto is well worth a visit. After a transfer deep into the jungle, about 7 miles, road is bumpy, we got kitted up for the hour and a half in the caves with Julian our guide. The caves are spectacular and should be accessible for most people. Julian was very good, pointing out the interesting formations and helping the group in the more difficult areas.Our only negative point is regarding the photography. There is a large emphasis on posing for photographs at the various areas, which takes up a large amount of time. Whilst this is important to those who would like to buy these photos as you are not allowed your own camera in the caves, the price of the photographs was very high and put us off buying them, $25USD for one photo on a CD or $79USD for all the photos in May 2015.
Hope you're with Epco!. Wonderful tour and worth the price. Epco was a great guide and very genuine. One of the better excursions!

Beautiful Rio Secreto. Going to a cenote was on my bucket list, so I did a lot of research before going on our trip to Mexico. If you are looking for a beautiful and tranquil underground experience, I highly recommend Rio Secreto. I selected this one because of the TA reviews, a total underground experience, close proximity to our resort, and Amstar provided this excursion from our resort.They provide water shoes, wet suit, helmet w/light, and walking stick. Wear your swimming suit under your clothes, so you can easily slip off your clothes and shower in the outside shower area before putting on the wet suit. You will wear your swim suit under the wet suit. They do have towels, but I suggest bringing one with you.I recommend using the walking stick since the ground is uneven, and it helps to determine the depth of the steps in front of you. There is one low area when you enter the cave that is a little challenging if you have bad knees; however, my 6 foot + tall husband was successful going through this area and the cenote.After the trip through the cenote, they provide a delicious meal. We had chicken, tortillas, rice, black beans, and fruit.You cannot bring a camera into the cenote, but they have a professional photographer with the group taking pictures. You can purchase one picture for $25.00 or the CD for $79.00. They take pictures from the beginning of the tour which begins with a ritual blessing until you depart the cenote. The CD includes pictures of the blessing, group and individual pictures inside and outside the cenote, and the beautiful environment in the cenote. I purchased the CD, and I'm so glad I did. It is well worth the money (see pictures). For the number of pictures you receive on the CD, the cost is approximately $1.00 per picture.Our guide, Pablo, was very friendly, informative, and concerned for the safety of all our group members. Thank you, Pablo!!! The groups do not exceed 10 members in order to provide a wonderful and safe experience. We had two children in our group, and they did just fine during the tour. There are 2 sections where you will need to swim.I'm so glad we selected Rio Secreto and will enjoy this experience for a lifetime as I look at the pictures over and over again.

Rio Secreto: One of the Most Mysterious yet Beautiful Places on Earth. Rio Secreto. . Just thinking about the place makes my heart beat faster. Crystal clear water glittered in the ray of sunlight, shining through a hole above the cenote. Yet, the surroundings were submerged in pitch darkness and dead silence. I was standing in awe, unable to breathe easily. I was afraid to break that silence. I felt like I stepped into a holy place without permission. We chose Rio Secreto Plus, which was a mixture of riding a bike in a jungle full of butterflies, rappelling down to the cenote, and walking and swimming in the cenote. Our guide Alfredo had a great passion for Rio Secreto and cenotes. He showed us many interesting creatures living in Rio Secreto, and he taught us many things about the cenote. He was extremely kind and thoughtful, too. One of my friend couldn't swim well, and he was helping her throughout the whole trip. Our photographer Abraham was amazing too. He took time and effort to take our pictures, and it really showed in the photos. I strongly recommend Rio Secreto Plus, but only if you have high energy and adequate bike riding and swimming skill. Otherwise, I would recommend just simple Rio Secreto Tour. Whether your choose Plus or not, you will probably fall in love with Rio Secreto, once you visit the place!

Great morning out. . We arrived at Rio Secreto around 9 ish and left 1200 ish. Frankly the time passed easily. There were no crowds of people and everything appeared to be choreographed to perfection. The caves were extremely interesting as was Epco our guide. The rumours of extremely cold water are very misguided the water was cool/fresh but definitely not cold. Anyone with a worry of claustrophobia should not miss out. We did not feel unsafe all day. However, I would suggest that if you are infirm on your feet then care should be take; although, the guide was ready on hand at all the difficult places. Many thanks for a great experience.

Don't miss the caves of Rio Secreto. We visited the caves of Rio Secreto while on an incentive trip for our company. It was not to be missed! The caves are absolutely amazing - breathtaking. Our guide, Raul, was so knowledgeable and so helpful. We learned more than we expected and came away with an appreciation for the caves, the Eco-system and the conservation efforts to maintain this beautiful piece of heaven. The terrain is uneven and has a few strenuous moments. You should not be claustrophobic of you visit here and the water can get deep enough that you need to swim - albeit with a life preserver and wet suit.

Unique and Amazing Experience. We donned our wetsuits, water shoes, helmet, and lights and went into the most amazing series of caves. Absolutely fascinating adventure. We were in the caves for about 90 minutes with an excellent guide and photographer. We waded and in some cases swam through the underground rivers, saw resident bats and spiders, had a few minutes of complete silence in complete darkness which was very spiritual. The stalactites and stalagmites are amazing. This was followed by a wonderful lunch. The guides were terrific, our group was small, 6 people, and the photos (that you can purchase separately) that the photographer were wonderful. This is worth your time and money for a very unique and enjoyable experience.

An awesome experience. Myself, my 7 yr old daughter and my wife had the pleasure of doing the Rio Secreto on an Cruise Line Excursion. I'll cut to the chase and say that it was awesome. The caves themselves were beautiful, the water was refreshing, the equipment provided was more than adequate and our guide was excellent. I would recommend this to anyone that I knew was headed to the area.

Very interesting. Rio Secreto is not so much a river but a series of connected underwater limestone caves. It is certainly an amazing natural wonder. This is not a full day excursion but they do include a nice lunch. The guides are wonderful.
Amazing. If you do nothing else visit Rio Secreto while in Mexico. More amazing than the pyramid in my opinion. The guided knowledge is second to none.Very powerful and moving experience.
WOW. Not to be missed. You must be in pretty good shape as there are many uneven areas to explore. A must for any adventure seeker.Beautiful...mother nature at her finest.

Amazing!. My bf and I did this excursion through our cruise about 2 years ago, I recommended it to friends as we are going to cozumel again next year. This was so awesome! we were hesitant at first to do this (my b/f mostly!) but we were glad we did! Also bought the CD with all of our pics, plus they included a few others of inside the caves. There were moments where we had to float in water but it was clear and not too cold since we had wet suits. Also there were times when we turned off the helmet lights so it was pitch black and just listened to the sounds for a minute.
Wonderful!. Being able to swim in caves, climb and trek through the jumgle....fantastic tour guides.A must return!

Awesome Experience. I've been to other caves and cenotes in Mexico before, but my experience at Rio Secreto was unlike any other. After a 20 minute journey by van, we went into the jungle to get suited up for our adventure. Everyone was given wet suits, life jackets, water shoes, a helmet and walking stick and we were off. First, we were cleansed by a Mayan. It was very cool. We learned to say hello and thank you in Mayan, but I can't remember now! Then we walked into the cave. We did a lot of walking/hiking, so it was a good idea to have that stick! Eventually, we came to the part where we actually swam through the caves. Near the end of our adventure, they let us turn off our lights and we sat in total darkness. It was so cool to hear the sounds of the cave. What was supposed to be a 1.5 hour trip took about 2 hours, but I won't complain. It was amazing. And they provide a photographer, who captures your entire trip and lets you pose at many different stops. After the trip, we had a traditional Mexican lunch and then took the bus back.I absolutely recommend Rio Secreto to everyone!
Amazing trip under the ground. Amazing tour with Julian. Thanks for the day and pictures!The only negative point: we would have done it all day instead of half d'Ay...

Rio Secreto. My daughter and I went on an excursion to see the natural reserves in Mexico. The Rio Secreto is a must see!!! I was in awe. If you ever visit Mexico, you must go on this excursion. It is definitely a sight you do not want to miss. It is a once in a lifetime experience.
Wonderful . Once in a life time, must do.. you need to have good balance and agality. Can not be afraid of tight or small spaces.

Must visit . If you like caves and water, this is a must. Had a great time, one of those must do's when you visit Cancun.The staff there were great. The guide we had was very knowledgeable. If you can, ask to be with Julio's guide. The best!

A little different, but magical for sure. If you want to cool down after exploring the ancient ruins, or you just want to learn about the local ecosystem then this place is right for you. You'll be traveling 30+ meters underground, exploring the diamond blue rivers of fresh water and learning about the geological curiosities of Yucatan. Few tips: - if you can, ask for Carlos. He is a wonderful guide, really passionate about the preservation of this ecological marvel.- Don't forget to bring your own water shoes - lots of sharp edges there. You can rent/ask for the shoes at the place, but some are damaged and you never know what you'll get.- Cameras are not allowed inside, so all Facebook perfect pictures should be purchased after the tour. The quality of the pictures is not great and this service is way overpriced, but you can try and bargain your way out. Just make sure you pay cash (however, cards are accepted but this will nullify bargaining efforts)- you'll get a chance to try the local buffet (it's included) so try Lime Soep

A Must See for an adventurer!. This tour was awesome. If you get nervous about being in a darker area and in very deep water at times even though your very safe with a life vest don't do it. I have trouble with my balance due to 2 knee replacements and your not to touch anything so they gave me a walking stick and my husband helped me at times. You have a life vest/ helmet with lite and its a long tour. We have been in a lot of caves & cenotes but this experience gives you both hiking and swimming too. I wouldn't recommend it for very young children. It's truly amazing so just do it!!!

RIO SECRETO - LITERALLY " OUT OF THIS WORLD" !. We went on the "plus" tour which includes the light show in the cave of dreams. This was a great start to an amazing and wonderful experience. Our guide was Diana, who was excellent, funny, informative but overall clearly passionate about her job and her "office" ( the caves lol!) Following on from the light show, Diana took us to the area where we could change into our swimming costumes. The changing rooms were clean and well maintained. We were all given a secure locker to store all of our belongings, and then took a quick shower to remove any perfume, oils, sunscreen etc so as not to contaminate the water system and ecology below ground. All equipment was supplied, from water shoes, helmet with lamp, and a buoyancy jacket. The guides will show you why we need to shower, and why it is VERY important not to touch the formations you see - this is the most important piece of information they give you.Safety was excellent, and we had no concerns throughout the tour. I would say that whilst not requiring any athletic skill, you should be reasonably mobile, and have good balence as the tour requires walking across uneven surfaces, walking through water with uneven surfaces, and swimming. The tour guide can supply a walking stick if it will help with you balance.The sights you will experience are just amazing, and Diana even produced a special" fireworks show" for us! ( you have to do the tour to see what I mean!)I could write so much more, but overall you absolutely must go on this tour - a rare opportunity to experience first hand what so many more will only ever see in books or films!

Lemon... made our day!!!. Our second excursion in Playa brought us to Rio Secreto. We were driven down a long dusty road to the cenotes where we met our guide Lemon and where we were to change into our bathing suits, given water shoes, lockers and keys for our stuff. We then took a cool shower to remove any chemicals so to not disrupt the natural pH balance of the waters and given wet suits an helmets with lights. Prior to entering the caves, its commonplace for a short blessing ceremony to take place by a Shaman who blesses your passage into the caves. The caves were amazing, otherworldly it seemed, it was quite enlightening to learn about the stalacite and stagamite. Our guide Lemon was very comical and kept us laughing throughout. There is usually another fellow following who takes pictures which you can purchase at the end. If you're lucky enough to get the same underworld route as ours, you'll get a kick out of what's known as "The Stairway to heaven" exit. We were now topside and walked a bit back to the main area where we were given lunch and some time to chill in hammocks before taking the vans back to our resorts. It was a great day, we met some really nice people in our group including a couple from Korea who didn't speak a lick of English. We were back at our resort before 3:00 pm to lounge by the pool catch some rays and have some Mojito's.

Great experience!. We loved this tour! Going into underground caves and hiking/swimming through the water that flows in it. Helmets and all gear is provided. Absolutely gorgeous scenery. Husband and I have a two year old. They offer an on site babysitter which was great to give us the time to enjoy this experience since our daughter was too young to participate. Alan was a fabulous tour guide. Worth the hour to get there from cancun and very reasonably priced. No cameras are allowed but they do take a lot of photos for purchase at the end. We never buy those photos anyway since the memory of the experience is more important to us than looking at some photo every 10 years.

An absolutely amazing experience!. This tour was booked as an excursion from a Cruise stop in Cozumel. A rough 45 minute ferry ride and short ride in a van later we were ready to be wowed. I am happy to say we were not disappointed. They took care to provide all the necessary gear; lockers, towels, water shoes, wet suit, helmets with headlamps and even walking sticks. The guides are very friendly and knowledgeable. The excursion did not require extraordinary physical abilities, just easy hiking, some moderate walking over uneven surfaces, some under water and a bit of swimming. Doable for almost anyone in good health. They take photos you can buy later and serve you a delicious Mexican lunch. The photos are not the best, but buy them! You will need to look at them again to remember how magnificent this tour was! The caves were absolutely beautiful. So amazing and untouched. We were in constant awe. I could have stayed all day! We were so happy to experience this natural wonder.

Pretty Worth While But Full Day. Having been in caves before as kids, I can't say the formations were much different except the way you view them with headlamps and flashlights is cool. The water parts are really pretty!!! Our tour was quite athletic. We rode bikes and rappeled into a deep hole which was awesome but hard for us beginners. Our small 5-person group was a total plus. The trek was a bit of a challenge at times with some real tight and tricky spots. We left with some scratches, callouses, and muscle soreness but thankfully no twisted ankles or broken bones. It would be an issue if you got hurt in the cave I think despite the guide being a trained paramedic. It was a bit cool in the water and almost 3 hours in the cave was a bit long because we got a little cold despite wetsuits after a few hours. We also got quite hungry even having had breakfast because our tour bus left Cancun at 7:30, we started ~10:30 and didn't get lunch till 2 or after. Snorkeling and biking parts were not really the highlights. The drive time to and from Cancun was also longer than we had hoped due to frequent stops (passenger pick ups and drop offs) which was really annoying. This is an all day thing and kind of wipes you out. Our guide Alfredo and photographer Juan were really great. Fyi, You cant take your own camera but the professional photos are cool if you want to buy them on cd for $80. Equipment and necessary gear were provided. Food was a good mayan/mexican buffet. Soda, bottled water, and other beverages other than a tea provided cost extra. We probably would have given 5 stars if it had been a much shorter day trip.

Stunning. This was actually the highlight of our trip. It is pricey but worth every penny. Plan to stay there for at least 4 hours. It was marvelous to see the stalactites and stalagmites. we were in the caves for about at least one hour. Our guide was terrific. The guy with the dreads. We had a late lunch afterwards. Thiss is a must see

Great, but no photos allowed, so disappointing. A brilliant cave tour, ruined by the stupidly priced photos at the exit.That said, the tour through the caves is excellent. It's a long walk in rubber booties from the center to the caves so be prepared.

Great Mexico Experience. We had the best tour guide EVER. Super knowledgable about the river and the cave formations. There is nothing in the world quite like this experience. Also, for people who avoid caves due to claustrophobia, i had no problems here whatsoever.

We'll run and stunning experience. Decided to book this experience as a last minute thing, partly due to proximity to our hotel (Occidental Grand Xcaret) and partly due to the good reviews.We were picked up as arranged and driven to the attraction HQ where the guide went through the safety procedures and what we would see. It's worth pointing out that we were the only English couple on our tour of 9 people, but the guide went to great pains to explain everything in both Spanish and English. Our fellow tour members were a three generation family, and we all hit it off really well despite the language barrier. After the safety briefing there was a 20 minute drive through the jungle to the site of the cenote that we would be exploring.We were kitted out in wetsuits, helmets and life jackets after the mandatory cold shower to remove and sun cream etc which could contaminate the water.Then it was down the stairs into the cave itself. The cenote was only discovered in 2007, and the only things added are stairs down and stairs out again. Everything else is exactly as it was found. This is probably the closest you can get to a genuine caving experience, but at no time did it feel scary. To start with there is a bit of clambering and wading, with the guide explaining the cave features as we progressed. Further into the cave the water is deeper and swimming is required, but the buoyancy from the wetsuit and life jacket mean that even non swimmers will feel safe. The exit involves swimming through a pinch point where you have a few inches clearance between the water and cave roof, but again it never felt scary.There is a photographer with the group who records the whole experience and you can buy the photos on a CD at the end. These are pretty pricey at $79 for the set, which doesn't include any 'stock' cave shots so you may want to think a bit carefully about this.Once you leave the cave you change out of your gear and showers and towels are provided, and then proceed to a restaurant area for a perfectly decent lunch of traditional Mexican dishes. Be warned - the red chilli sauce is hot, but the green one is hotter!Overall this is an experience I wouldn't have missed, and a big vote of thanks has to go to our guide Julio for making it such an inclusive event.

Rio Secreto underground river/karst features. Awesome! A stalagmite/stalagtite paradise. Guides are awesome. Lunch in the jungle and an hour and a half tour of one of the largest cenote' caverns in the area.
Rio Secret Caves. One of the best and safest excursions. Absolutely beautiful! A must do when you are on a cruise in Cozumel. A short boat ride then a car ride to no where...so worth it!!!

Just WAY Cool!!. This was a great and unique experience... I must have liked it because I was smiling in every picture the photographer took of me! Raul, our guide, was THE BEST!! He was funny and animated, full of facts..both serious and silly... and all about being helpful and assuring our safety. If you like nature with a little adventure, I would definitely recommend doing this...it was the best thing we did in Cancun! I agree with other reviewers who say to ignore the complaints about not being able to take photographs and the cost of the pictures. Once you go, you will realize that having everyone taking their own pictures would be dangerous for the participants and for the cave, and the price just isn't that over the top...just budget for it, because you'll definitely want the pics. You're on vacation...let someone else (who knows the best shots) do the photography and just take in the experience. Pick up and drop off at our hotel helped make this an easy and totally enjoyable excursion.

Awesome Experience!. I will admit I was TERRIFIED to be in a cave wading/swimming through an underground river. However the experience was well worth the fear of getting there. Our tour guide was Eduardo. He was very knowledgeable and I felt very safe with him. The rock formations were stunning. One piece of advice - take the walking stick when offered. It really helps to better navigate the awkward ground of the river/cave.

Great Experience. Excellent cave excursion, knowledgable friendly staff and beautiful cave. Highly reccommend. Dont listen to people complaining about the price of pictures. All the tours in mexico are the same way. Expect to pay $75 for pictures anywhere you go.

Beautiful cave but the price???. This is a fairly new attraction and the cave is a sight to see. It is still a live cave and was a lot of fun to go through. The downside is the price is way to high. It cost a little more than Xplor and has a lot less to do. The buffet which is included had very little selection and the food was just average. The guide was very friendly and knowledgeable. Unfortunately the price is just to high for what you get and for all the other options available in the same area. It is worth seeing if you've seen all the other stuff and want to see something new. Don't now if I would pay that much to go again.

Rappel, Bike and Swim. My boyfriend and I chose this tour over others upon the recommendation that it was a little more "authentic" than some of the larger parks.We were not disappointed.We chose the new "plus" package which included a short ride through the jungle on bicycles and rappelling into the first underground cave.Both were lots of fun. We are mountain bikers, so the riding felt easy and flat, but lots of fun. The rappel into the cave was about 20-30 feet into a small hole that quickly opened up into a huge water cave. Also fun. We had lots of time to swim and explore the edges of this cave and enjoyed stories about the cave formation and wildlife.We left the cave via another exit and rode back through the jungle (fun in your bikini!) to don wetsuits.A brief stop with a beautiful medicine man who smudged us with chaparral before we entered the cave.This cave winded through open spaces, to tighter areas that you could just float through under stalactites. The guide Jorge was great- lots of great stories and explanations.The photos, yes, were very expensive (especially with the Canadian-USD exchange rate), but worth it for the keepsakes, and they were quite good.Remember to pose for them, or get some in special spots if you think of it, because they are all included if you buy the lot!

my kids' favorite activity of our entire Disney cruise. Because we had already done the Cozumel stop on the Disney Magic, I only wanted to do a shore excursion if it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.This fit the bill, and did not disappoint!! This cave system was only discovered in 2006 and opened to the public in 2008; because it's part of the freshwater system for the entire Yucatan Peninsula (if I remember correctly), there is a very real chance that new laws could close this location to the public at some point - so we were glad to have the experience while we could!From youngest (8) to oldest (40), we were all wowed by the opportunity to swim in an underground river. Our guide, Yayo, was friendly and incredibly knowledgeable, and since our "group" consisted solely of our family, it was like having a private tour.The best part was when we reached the area that was deep enough for swimming, and Yayo had us turn off All.The.Lights. It felt like what I imagine a sensory deprivation tank to be like, but amazingly none of us felt claustrophobic or scared.The Mexican buffet at the end was delicious!And yes, the photos are spendy (we spent $89 for a USB stick with 100+ photos), but not any more so than the other excursions we've done in the past (e.g. dolphin experiences, etc.). We highly, highly recommend this for anyone that is up for the uneven surfaces inside the caves (they do have walking sticks available, FYI).

Beyond our expectations. Ok so my girl friend and I were backpacking Mexico (everywhere is gayfriendly) and we decided to go visit the famous Rio Secreto. As a backpacker it can be expansive but it's definitely worth the 80$ CAD. Our guide name was Raul, he was great on every level. You leave as a 10 people group and at first I thought this was way too touristic for me but in the end I appreciated it so much! It was fun and unique, nothing like the other caves you'll get to see. Some went over their comfort zone (claustrophobic, scared of the dark and non-swimmers). It comes with an all inclusive buffet that was pretty good too. But then at the end comes the scam, (you can't bring any camera inside) they charge you a crazy price for pictures that comes on a disk. We really wanted photo memory of this moment so we managed to get 2 pictures for 30$ CAD.. Overall it's a 10\10. A Must see, really. Oh and it comes with shots at the end, right before supper.
Great experience. Better than expected.felt like Indiana Jones.tour guide Diana was lovely and experienced.didnt feel claustrophobic.a great adventure and amazing place to visit.

Must visit this place. The whole package is refreshing. The cool swim, accompanied by the educational sharing of stalactites and stalagmites, and how the cave ecology works. This is unbelievably great! It's an apt move away from the drinking and pub stuffs at Cancun and Playa del Carmen.

Unique "must do " excursion!. This is such a fun, unique, educational excursion. Your day starts with a bumpy twisty and turny ride back into the jungle. You stop to watch a quick video about the caves and the steps we were going to go through before the adventure started. First you must take off jewelry, hats, sunglasses, shoes and remain in your bathing suit. Lockers are provided free of cost. Next, you are given water sox to borrow, or you can purchase your own. Then, since the cenote is fresh water it is required that you rinse your body off in an outdoor shower. This is to remove oils, creams, lotions, etc that could make the water impure over time. No big deal! The next step was everyone is given a wetsuit. Now the fun starts! Lol! We had a group of 12 people and we all were hysterically laughing as we tried to squish into the suits! You are also given life vests and helmets with lights since the cave is completely dark. You walk a little bit further into the jungle and then you see the entrance to the cave. The feeling is excitement, nervous energy as you descend into the cave and water. Our tour guides RAUL P. was amazing! He was the perfect mix of humor, and interesting facts. He moved at a great pace so people of all fitness levels and ages could keep up. The water is fairly chilly, but the wetsuit helps keep you warm. We saw such amazing beauty on the formations under ground. It was so cool to see how over thousands of years the stalagmites and stalactites have formed. They have a person taking your photos which was actually nice because you didn't have to worry about where is the perfect spot or keeping up with a camera. The photos are reasonably priced, and you get alot on the disk...posed, natural, and some stock photos of the cave. After the tour is a lunch, which is pretty decent authentic Mexican food. Our group was so psyched about what we had just done, we had no complaints! This is a great excursion for adventurous couples who want to have a once in a lifetime experience together!

A must do!. This was top of my list of things to do in Mexico and it exceed my expectations!
The photos at the end are a bit expensive but it's really worth it. My guide Frances, was very knowledgeable and made such everyone felt comfortable.

Highly recommended- our favorite excursion!. We were in Playa del Carmen last week for 10 days. We booked a trip to Rio Secreto before leaving based upon Tripadvisior reviews. It did not disappoint!This was the very BEST excursion of our 10 day trip. We had a very knowledgeable guide- Julio- who is passionate about his work, the environment, and the culture of the area. We had two teenagers with us, one was a 14 yr old boy who was not impressed by much. Less than 15 minutes into the tour he exclaimed that this was the best, and the rest of the week he compared everything we did to this excursion. I personally was very impressed that it wasn't treated as just a regular tourist activity, but that spiritual reverence was given; in a blessing with copal, in the way the trees and plants are treated (this is in the jungle!), and in the treatment on the caves and water. Highly recommended for anyone who can hike and do basic swimming.

Couldn't do this in the States!. It wasn't my first cave tour, to be sure. But it was the first time I could swim in the waters of an underground cave!! If you like caves then you must do this. But make sure you have some physical capacity to handle uneven terrain, and a few steep areas. We had an abuela (grandmother) on our trip that required lots of assistance. Our guide, German, was a kind man, patient and most friendly. I highly recommend this.

Cave and Swimming. This was an awesome cenote cave. At first I was a little worried because I tend to be a little claustrophobic at times. When we arrived they told us to shower, which was outside to remove the lotions from our skin. This is to protect the water environment in the caves. They provide an optional wet suit which I used as well as many of the others and a mandatory life vest and helmet with a light attached to it. They also provided us walking canes to help us maneuver the area we would have to walk through. Before we entered the cave, a Mayan priest said a prayer over us to protect us and ask permission for us to enter the cave. This was really nice! There is a photographer with us the whole time to take pictures and you can purchase these at the end of the tour.Julian was our tour guide and he was really nice. We turned off our lights several times to get a feel of what it was like to be in the cave while it was totally dark and quiet. You could hear the water tinkling and you couldn't even see your hand in front of you. It was totally dark and awesome! We swam around in some of the deeper areas and took our time going through the cave. If you don't know how to swim its no problem because you can float with your vest holding you up. We had several individual who could not swim but they had a good time because they would float right next to us.After we came out of the cave they fed us lunch which was very good with some hibiscus tea that was also very good. You have to pay extra if you want soda and chips.I would do this excursion again it was so much fun!!!

Very educational. Worth the money. This is one excursion that I would suggest. It was a great experience and very educational. It's not highly commercialized. Food was great and the money for the photos is worth it. They are done by a professional photographer, that accompanies you throughout the tour. These caves are in their natural state, rather then set up for tourists. Well worth it.

Unique experience. I'm usually not one for "typical tourist" activities, organized tours or similar things. I'd much rather explore by myself and get away from the crowds.I am very glad that this time we took the chance on a "tourist" activity - it was excellent. This is not a "stay in line, follow the guide with an umbrella" tour. Our tour was a 1 kilometer tour through some amazing caves, narrow passages and pools of water. Ranging from a nice walk to a bit of a scramble to wading through knee-deep water to swimming through crystal-clear pools... totally unique and well worth it.Our tour guide, Francis, was excellent. He took great care of his group (six of us) from start to finish and made the tour fun, educational and exciting.

We loved our day at Rio Secreto!. We were on a cruise and booked this excursion through them. Francis was our tour guide and he was great!!! This experiance was amazing and beautiful. Have to be careful of some of the rocks and light swimming but it was really a once and a lifetime experiance. I would suggest this to anyone looking for a fun adventure!! I also enjoyed the minuet of silence (headlamps off complete darkness) it was so peaceful. We purchased one picture that day and I remember them saying their system was being iffy. When we got home our cd was blank so I emailed them and they apologized and emailed me my picture that same day! Such great customer service. Such a fun unforgettable day. Thank you to all :)

Worth the Cost!. A bit pricey, however so worth it. Only discovered a few years ago, you take a walk though an underground cave system. It does take a while from time of hotel pick-up to the start time of the actual tour inside the cave. The caves were interesting, first time inside a natural system like this. Diana was our tour guide and she was excellent. Well worth the tip that we left behind for her - noticed that others in our group didn't, so felt a bit bad about that.They have a photographer join in on the tour, so try and sell you pics at an outrageous price at the end, which I thought was a bit of a shame. They serve lunch, however if you are coming from an all inclusive resort, it just doesn't compare.Tour as a whole, it well worth the $$. I highly recommend it.
great a must visit. this is a must, waters are clear and warm, we loved our day in rio secreto, lunch is poor, but we were not hungry

Well organized , a great excursion. We had the pleasure of having Benito give us a tour through these wonderous caverns . An unforgettable experience ,,, This takes some effort on your part . You wear a wet suit and helmet with a light . You are touring under the ground with your guide for approximately hour and a half .Some bending and maneurving around does takes some effort . There is Also some light swimming involved . Not difficult but definitely not a leisurely walk either . My only suggestion is that I wanted some extra time to hang out in the water toward the end. Even 10minutes at the end . I want to sit an take in my beautiful surrounding . There was wasn't any time . That being said, don't think twice . This was a great experience !
Diana S great tour guide. Very cool trip and with a great tour guide who gave very detailed descriptions of the formations. Water was crystal clear against the limestone.
SOOOO worth the money. This was an excellent experience. Beautiful with some challenges, but easy enough for people of all ages. Would do it again any time!!

A must see for all ages. My family and I were just here and had a great time. A natural wonder well worth the time and effort to see and explore. My kids 14, 11 and 7 had a blast. Exploring and swimming the river were great fun. Our guide Numes was helpful and informative.

A must do in Mexico!!. What an amazing experience!! Thank you to our wonderful guide (a lovely lady whose name we have forgotten) who was very well informed and made us feel very safe as we moved through the caves.

Under ground adventure. It was an experience of a life time.The amazing structures on the ceiling was something worth seeing . Our guide Ebco was great and knew his way around the cave.he made us fell very calm in the dark cave.we enjoyed the walk and swim through this breath taking place .

Best excursion ever. This was most definitely the most exciting thing I did the whole time I was down in Mexico. Everyone had a good time. The information was very helpful and the tour guide was friendly and fun.

Interesting, but a bit dry and overpriced. This was a very interesting tour. However the tour is quite short compared to the time it took to get there, suit up, and get briefed. The actual tour through the caves was very interesting, but not very exciting. If they had installed some lights (like was implied in the tour propaganda photos) then it would have looked more impressive. At the end they make you walk through a shop where they show photos taken of your group and of course try to get you to buy them. All the photos of our group were slightly blurry, which my husband identified as a backfocus issue on the camera lens (we've had the same problem with our own camera.) When he talked to the photographer about it, they insisted there was no problem. The lunch served afterwards was uninspiring cafeteria style.

A Great Experience!!!. The experience starts out a little shaky driving along a very bumpy dirt/limestone road for about 15 minutes. Once at the location, you are tucked into the trees at a beautiful location. Lockers are large enough for a backpack and water shoes are a must. You can rent them for just a couple of dollars. Definitely get a wet suit as they are provided for you. Our guide was Alfredo. His passion for the caves was incredible. He was extremely knowledgeable and a joy to be with. Others in our group had other guides and were complimentary of them as well. I'm not sure I would have signed up for this but was definitely glad I took advantage of the experience. If you are considering this, you should do it.

A Really Great Experience. We had a flawless 8 AM pickup from our hotel (with the usual stops for others at other hotels) and got to Rio Secreto about 45 minutes later.Once there, we got our bracelets, and then a briefing and short video about the attraction. You can buy water shoes for $10 USD at this point, if you like, but they supply wáter shoes later. We got in another van and got a deep tissue massage, courtesy of the bumpy, dirt road drive to the next stop. It´s not too long a drive - less tan a half hour for sure.You need to dump all of your belongings at your locker after the van ride, so - no cameras, nothing goes in the caves with you. You strip down to your bathing suit and then squeeze into a wetsuit, life jacket and helmet. Take a walking stick. They come in very handy.There is a short hike to a Mayan (?) who blessed us before we entered the caves. Then it was headlamps on and into the caves. The walk through the caves was not terribly slippery because the watershoes gripped well. There are a few climbs and drops but nothing treacherous. The wáter that you sometimes walk and swim through is cristal clear and warm with a very few fish.The caves are gorgeous and sometimes very high - sometimes so low that you need to duck to not hit the roof of the cave. Bad scene if you are claustrophobic.Our guide, Alina, was amazing. She was profesional, friendly and fluently shifted from English to Spanish to Russian. She was quite knowledgeable and very safety-conscious.The Suprema cave route that we were on is only open sometimes because high wáter often makes it impassable. After exiting, there was another very short hike back to the lockers.Lunch was next, with an egg dish, a couple of rice dishes, soup and lots of fruit. A fruit drink was supplied and beer was $4.After lunch, we got herded into a room to view the photos that they took while we were in the caves. They were really expensive ($25 for one) and the ones of our group were bad. Really bad. It might have helped if I had known that some of the shots were group shots and I might have smiled for them instead of thinking my solo photo was going to be taken next.It was a great experience and highly recommended. I suggest having some dollar bills for tips and also that you not wear prescription sunglasses into the caves. I did, and had to take them off because the light from the headlamps was too dim to see anything. The wáter temperature in the caves is not uncomfortable at all. It was a most unique swim!

Amazing Life Changing Experience. This is the most amazing thing we have done. You actually go into the crystal cave of the Mayan underground world and walk on the crystal formations and swim through the waters. Our guide, Ro, was incredible. He was so helpful, knowledgeable, trustworthy, and friendly. He took my daughter by the hand and my son on his back. We will never forget this experience. If you are in this area of Mexico and can only do one thing, this is it.

Outstanding. My wife and i loved our trip to Rio Secreto and could not have had a better guide than Eveliene!! The whole trip was very well organized and very respectful of local traditions and the environment

amazing. Only problem we had was our driver picked us up, spoke absolutely no English and took us the back way to the next resort thru Puerto morales and a very treed area. the guide Fernanda was awesome. Very friendly and knowledgeable. I would do the tour again and again. You sit in the dark and listen to the water drop. An amazing experience I would highly recommend

Simply mystical!!. When booking this excursion I was a little nervous because I am a little claustrophobic. When we got there my mind was swirling and I didn't know if I could go through with it. This was quickly changed when we met our guide Alfredo. He made me feel completely at ease and with his knowledge and passion for this place he had me engaged from the start and my fears quickly disappeared. We were completely mesmerized by the beauty of the cavern. He was very informative and knowledgeable about his surroundings. He led the tour with safety always being number one. We also had a wonderful photographer Raynoldo who took wonderful pictures. Lunch was advertised as a snack but by no means was this the case. We had a hot full course homemade lunch that included fresh home made corn tortillas and fresh hot sauce-the only thing I would say is pay attention to when he says stay away from the green sauce because I was not listening and that stuff will light you on fire lol-wonderful adventure and my husband and I would recommend to the fullest!!!

Amazing views. The view was amazing and our guide was very informative. The food was good, some of the equipment (wetsuit) required replacing. The one I wore had holes on the inner thigh, never having worn one before I didn't realize how significant it was. When I removed it, I had severe chafing, which resulted in an open sore and severe discomfort for the next 3 days. I could not go into the ocean for the remainder of my trip and had trouble walking due to discomfort.

Breathtaking. There are not words to describe the beauty of this place. It has to be seen to truly understand. Our guide Fransisco made our private journey special with his vast knowledge and excellent english. Much to our surprise we were treated to a quiet candlelight couples bottle of wine & cheese deep inside the spectacular caverns. This is one tour that should not be missed.
Amazing!. One of a kind place around the world. Mind blowing view. Must see once in life time. Value for Money

Outstanding!. Spent a very special afternoon with my sisters and their husbands enjoying the subterranean experience of Rio Secreto! Our tour guide Alfredo's enthusiasm and passion for sharing this experience only made it more interesting and special for our group. Thorough and thoughtful with our safety, enjoyment and comfort was Alfredo's pleasure for every step (or float) of this delightful excursion! It was one of the highlights of the vacation! Thank you to Alfredo and the entire staff!Constance

RIO SECRETO CAVES. Booked the plus tour of swimming and walking through caves full of stalagtites and stalagmites.Superb value for money. Try and book Pablo a most fantastic and knowlegable guide going.

Great morning expedition. We visited with our six year old and all of us had a fabulous morning. The caves were absolutely stunning and the guide really looked after our little boy. I was slightly anxious about pushy 'up sell' of extras but it was all fine. The photos are expensive but you don't have to buy. Lunch was plentiful. Would definitely recommend

For the Adventure Seekers! . This is a must see! If you have a physical ailment or trouble walking this might not be the best fit. Take the earliest tour you can get. The bus picked us up at 6am and we arrived at 830 am. You get to a place that's similar to a welcome center. Here you will sign a waiver, bathroom facilities are offered and you get assigned your tour guide. We had Gorge. Highly recommend him! From what I remember he was part of the exhibition team that was first to go in and check out this cave once it was discovered 7 years ago. Lots of knowledge!From this point you get into a smaller bus that goes far into the jungle on dirt roads. I loved it! That part added to the fun that was ahead. Once you arrive at the site you get a locker, wet suit,water shoes, and helmet. The tour guides inform you to check your equipment because Scorpions have a tendency to crawl in there. Well, someone in my group found one in their wetsuit so be careful. Next you move on to the prayer area (you don't have to participate if you don't want to). Then to the cave you go! If you like adventure this tour is for you! It's educational along with being a great adventure. You do have to swim in different locations. Some spots are over 10 feet deep just a heads up. It's an amazing experience! When you come out of the cave you get a shot of local liquor that tastes like black liquorice. After the tour you eat local food in a cabana style structure. This was so cool I wanted to go back through again! 5 stars

Amazing experience with a terrific guide. The whole experience of the underground river was beyond description. Our 6 year old twin daughters couldn't get the smiles off their faces, and a big part of that was our guide Alfredo, whose passion and love for Rio Secreto made the entire tour amazing. We did the private tour, around 3 hours, and saw bats, insects with crazy long antennae so they can feel their way along in the dark, and catfish and plankton. It's like being in a cathedral created by nature. Would highly recommend.

Superb. Great fun for kids and adults alike - surreal experience to hike/float through underground caverns and river; if you can get RODRIGO as your guide do so for sure - he was perhaps the best guide I have ever had for any excursion - superb guy and great knowledge.

Hidden Gem!. It was absolutely amazing! The blue water in the underground mayan cave! When you're inside, it was like you're in a different world. You could imagine - and feel - how Mayan people came here thousands of years ago to get fresh water from here. If you have the money, definitely go for it! It's quite pricey. But it was once-in-a-lifetime experience to see nature in all its perfection. To management, though, I wish it could be a more peaceful tour. The guide kept telling stories along the way - he was doing his job - but it kinda ruined the magic of the quiet moments underground. Maybe tell us everything they want BEFORE entering the cave? Then in the cave, you should keep the yelling/shouting/giving directions to what's necessary. Although, while we understand that you care for our safety,you didn't need to yell at a poor old couple who couldn't walk fast enough to catch up with the group. I think people want to the experience to be spiritual; so yelling should be prohibtted. Also, definitely more swimming time! A few minutes are not enough. And would definitely be great if we could bring a camera! Would give like a two-star for the tourguide / management; but the cave itself is a must-see!

Really cool!. Rio Secreto was a great half-day expedition for our family of four. Their "plus transportation" tickets seemed a bit pricy, so we took a cab from Playa del Carma and paid far less (about $20 bucks).From our arrival until the end, everything was very well organized. We boarded a van, rode deep into the jungle (on a very, very bumpy road), and jumped out to meet our guide Epco. He was phenomenal. Told us exactly what we needed to do without being pushy and explained everything in clear detail. We were given wet suits, water shoes, helmets and life vests (even small kid sizes). They offered an optional walking stick, which I took just in case. Turned out to be very helpful. Everyone should take one.The cave was super cool. I was initially concerned one or both of my kids (6.5 and 9 yrs old) would be scared or have problems, but we took our time, let them ride on our backs through the deeper water areas, and held their hands through all the tight spots. Epco (our guide) was very patient and aware of their needs and offered many suggestions on where to walk, where to step and not to step, etc. Much to my delight, our kids loved every second of it and never fell, slipped or cried once. Rio Secreto does get very dark (we actually turned off all our lights at one point to focus on the sounds of the cave), so keep that in mind.Like some other area attractions, no cameras are allowed in the cave. Instead a photographer from Rio Secreto follows your group and takes photos along the way. Upon exiting the cave and seeing the images I was initially very dissatisfied with the image quality and commented on how blurry they appeared. Someone working there said (in broken English) that the screen on the iMac was low resolution, which I interpreted as B.S. Faced with the prospect of having nothing to remember the trip by, I went ahead and shelled out $75 for the CD of images. Much to my surprise, the images on the CD looked way, way better! They must have loaded image previews/thumbnails at the store, which would explain why they initially looked so bad. So, so glad I bought the CD.All told, it was an awesome little expedition. You'll love it.
1st Class. Wow.. This place was truly amazing. Tour was guided in the most top notch fashion. Yayo was our guide, you could tell the man loved these caves. If you get a chance don't pass this up!

A must see !. The whole tour was amazing ! our tour guide Epco was so friendly and full of information , everything was provided to you the lifevest,wetsuit,helmet and swimshoes if needed ! The food was fanstasic. The light show was so interesting and everyone had a great time swimming through the cave .

Celebrating my BIG 50. This execution I must say was the best one out of the 4 we booked. Julio was our guided and he was very knowledge making this experience more enjoyable,right from the ceremony before entering the cave to the singing me happy birthday! I felt that the company took extra care when it came to the preservation of the "Centinelas" We felt safe going through them, and just amazing sites as you continued through. (only disappointed was when it was over) I would love to send a BIG GRACIAS to Julio for making my birthday so memorable!! (these one is close to my heart!) We suggest that everyone makes this apart of your visit to Mexico!!

Great way to stay cool and more!. I have been to the Mayan many times and never thought to try this spot for some unknown reason. On this trip we went for it and I was glad I did. The drive up to the place is the hard part. Plenty of ruts and holes in the dirt road so be prepared to have your "preserves jarred!" Once we got there they broke us up into groups - English, French or Spanish speaking etc. - which was very smart - and put a guide who spoke that language in charge of each group. We got into wet suits and helmets with lights, put our personal stuff into lockers, got a little info from the group leader, a blessing from a local and off we went. The water is clean and cool. The caves are beautiful! They give you water shoes to keep your feet safe as the floors are very uneven and slippery - but there is very little risk of injury as they give you a walking stick if you want one or have someone hold your hand every step of the way if necessary. However, I would not recommend this for the elderly or small children.Some areas of the cave the water is deep and you can float along through those areas with your life jacket on.There is lots to learn from the guide, professional photos are taken for you all through the event and then at one point they turn off all the lights (on your helmets) and you are in complete darkness. It's amazing and I can't wait to do it again!

Mostly good really 3 1/2 stars. A nice surprise from our usual excursions. These caves are the real deal, unlike some man made ones thru out the area. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable. Our group consisted of 4 adults and 6 kids 8-14. Everybody had a fun time. I would not recommend for anybody who has physical ailments as this is a physical activity. You need nothing except a bathing suit. Everything else's is included. Wet suits, life jackets, water shoes, and a mining helmet with an attached flashlight. There is a meal at the end that was so so but they tried hard to please us. The only real negative is that they will not allow for any photos (real, phone, go-pro, etc). This is so they can charge you an exorbitant amount of money for the package. It would have been nice to have some memories but I'm not paying $150 for a few pics!
amazing tour. its a must see. it was very interesting and beautiful. we were there in 2011. this is a late review and it would not let me select that date

Loved It !!!. First , our guide was Diana S. and she was great. The caves were beautiful. Our whole family went youngest being my granddaughter, Kylie who is 6. Diana S took great extra care of her. All three of my grandsons loved it also. They provided a walking stick along with my son in law that was a great help to me. After our adventure they had a very tasty buffet that finished off a wonderful day. Would definitely do again.

Yes, do this one!. Looking for a more intimate adventure and this was it. My wife and 11 yo daughter loved it. Great people, not crowded, AMAZING sights. Carlos was our guide, he was great with the kids, knowledgeable and fun. Our group was about 12 people. It was tougher than I thought it going to be... in and out of water, rough terrain underground and above. It felt like a real adventure. We spent 3ish hours there I think. Included getting gear on, hiking a little to the cenote, exploring underground for an hour?, then eating a decent lunch buffet with the group. It was our daughter's b-day the next day and Carlos brought out a special brownie surprise and we all sang... Good stuff! We booked same day. As we were staying downtown Playa, we grabbed a taxi out there and hopped on a "colectivo" to get back. Very easy. Yes, they don't allow photography which I was disappointed with at first. But quickly I understood why. It's hard enough to walk through all together w/o taking pics. There is a pro photographer that follows the group. They charge a lot, but I think it's worth it. (should go w/o saying in Mexico, but you should haggle a bit). A highlight of our vacation!

Amazing cave experience!. I was there on 2 April and it was far better than I could have imagined. Well organized from pick-up to drop-off. Our guide, Fabien, was a hoot. Best part is that I prefer to swim on my back and with the light on my helmet, I lit up the ceiling as I floated along. Phenomenal! Great colours among the thousands of stalactites. At one point, we just floated in complete darkness and silence for a couple of minutes. It was the closest one could come to floating in space. One recommendation: Take a walking stick. You don't need a big or tall one, but it makes it so much easier to navigate the areas of shallow water.And when they give you the choice between finishing up with a swim or walk...take the swim.

Not worth it when the cenotes at xplor are much better.. I visited Xplor, Xcaret, and Rio Secreto on my last trip. This was the most disappointing of the three. Xplor was better cenotes with better lighting. The trip begins on a long bumpy road, a very long 7km ride.The few pools where they allowed you to swim was very nice.They say they don't allow cameras under the guise of protecting the habitat but why not allow gopros or cameras attached to the body? The only reason they don't allow cameras is so that they can sell you photos later for $79. A total rip off.Also, the food was not very good. Everything was bland and the chicken was hard.

Awesome!. My husband and two kids (ages 10 and 12) booked this tour as a last minute thing to do on the last day of our vacation and we were so glad that we did! We went early, picked up at our hotel at 6:50am. I know, ugh, but we were the first tour group out and then were back at our hotel to enjoy a whole afternoon at the pool, so it was worth it to us. Victor was our tour guide and he was great! He was very knowledgable and very good about letting us know how to safely navigate the cave. The cave was amazing! One of the coolest things I have ever done. You have to be very careful walking and swimming, but what you get to see is awesome. They provide all the gear that you need including wetsuits, water shoes, helmets, and towels. The only unpleasant part is taking the cold outdoor shower before putting on your wetsuit! After the tour everyone who wants to or is of legal age gets to take a shot of a very good Mayan liquor as a celebration. Our course they also sell bottles in the gift shop, but we thought this was a nice touch to end our tour. After you change you get to eat from their local food buffet. It was all good, especially the lime soup and the hibiscus water. My only complaint about the trip was the very bumpy ride in a van from the check in point back to the tour starting point. I get motion sick very easily and this was pushing the limits of what I can handle. My advice is to sit as close to the front of the van as you can. I was in the back on the way there and it was rough. I sat in the front on the way back and it was much better. The only advice I would give is that this is recommended for ages four and up. It is a pretty rough tour so I would think any kids under the age of eight would probably struggle. Also anyone with any mobility issues would probably have a rough time as well. Overall a great trip and not something to miss!

Cool Adventure!. Went to Rio Secreto while in the Riviera Maya. Not sure what I was expecting but it was way more adventurous. This is as close to legit caving as you can get and still be a tourist destination. Our guide, Alfredo, was awesome. He obviously loves his job and did his best to help us share that love. I was expecting more of a river float, but in fact this is a cave. No lights, minimal paths, some very low ceilings. Your guide's flashlights and your helmet light are the only things keeping you out of darkness! The first part of the exploration is on land with the second half moving through the water which was very refreshing. Loved the experience and loved Alfredo!
Rio Secreto. We went Feb 2015 with the NCL Dawn. One of the best things I've ever done. Great staff and beautiful site.

Just amazing!. I have visited the place because some friends have recommended it and I truly didn't regret it. It was an unforgettable experience. The place was amazing, the tour guide was really informative, even the food they offer you at the end of the tour is quite good. I totally recommend it.

This Should be #1 In the Area!. Wow, wow, wow. If you are AT ALL adventurous or are AT ALL in love with nature, Rio Secreto is not to be missed. We booked through the Norwegian Sun and everything went flawlessly. Our guide Victor was very informative and patient- how lucky is the Mayan hunter who found this place! From poor to a millionaire!Overall it was a great experience except for one thing...THE PICTURES WERE TERRIBLE!!!! We NEVER buy pictures but from ones we have seen on TripAdvisor, we went in thinking we would buy the big $79 package. WRONG. I was so disappointed with the poor quality of them. The lightning was nothing like I had seen in other pictures. We did end up buying one, but even the one we purchased was not spectacular. TIPS (From someone who booked through a cruise line)- You ONLY GET 90 minutes in the cave. Victor said they had longer trips but those were for people staying at nearby resorts.- Cozumel is an island, so you have to take a 45-minute ferry ride to and from Playa Del Carmen. Bring snacks for the ferry ride. I get very motion sick, and the boat was obnoxious for me.- It is VERY physical. If you cant bend down, don't do it. If you can't swim, don't do it. If your body aches at all, don't do it. The tour company stressed this many times, but you will have a horrible experience if you are not in decent physical condition. - Afterwards, you will have time to shop in Playa Del Carmen. You might as well shop here, as there was a great variety of items to purchase. You will have time in Cozumel, but it's very rushed.

Caves like you have never seen.. Took our two grand daughters to Rio Secreto and had a great time. Every thing inside the cave was well presented. The fact that you had to do some swimming made it even more fun and interesting. Our guide Benito was excellent. I just wished they either paved the road in or did something to smooth it out. However the ride was well worth it. Great for all ages.We had one man in our group who could not swim well. Benito made sure he was able to float through out the swimming part. Benito also made sure anyone with any difficulties was well taken care of.

Go before the secret is gone!. On our cruise my wife was hard pressed to try the attraction park or Rio Secreto. While the weather was awesome, a day in a park with a lot of sun and big crowds lost out to this surprise for our son. Boy, were we ever pleased with our choice.After a ferry to Playa del Carmen from our drop off point in Cozumel (approximately 20 min. of travel) we boarded our bus to the site. Highway traffic for 10 minutes ended on a bumpy and hilly 20 minute drive to the Rio Secreto. We didn't hate the drive....we just went with the flow.We met CARLOS -- our guide for the day. He was awesome. We showered, got on our shorty wet suits, booties, helmets and lifejackets. We're strong swimmers and I didn't think we needed all the gear .....than is until we got into the caves.(Note: You have the option of being given a wooden staff. Take it. It's like a third leg in this cave system and allows you extra balance while climbing in these uneven caves.)We had a Mayan ceremony before we were escorted down into the caves and the coolness of the caves was a blessing from all the heat and sunshine. We travelled through a couple of kilometers of caves -- over, under and through so many formations. It was really neat. Once the group turned off all of our headlamps it was amazingly dark. CARLOS was awesome. Helpful and full of information. The kids in our group really liked his interaction and the photographer with us was more of an afterthought. You aren't allowed to take your camera below, so they provide you with one for the optional photo package afterwards. The gear provided us with enough protection from the stones and outcroppings. Even with the gear, one of our party sliced up a finger and I took a good scrape out of my shin. Most of the time we floated and bounced through the cave system. The water was cool and refreshing and the tour moved nicely. In total, our group was 9 people and we were told they never take more than 10 through. Even with the numbers above ground, we only saw one group in the caves.Lunch was nice and filling and included in the price. Overall, a super time if you're looking for a unique excursion.

Awesome!. It was an amazing experience to swim in the underground caves. It was about a 10 minute walk down a trail to get into the caves. Get ready to wear a wet suit and helmet/flashlight. I'm not one who loves to hike or be in nature, but this was definitely worth it! Even if you aren't a good swimmer, you can do it because the water is not too deep. There was only 1 point in which you had to float w/ the life jacket, but it was harmless. I don't recommend it for children younger than 14 because of all the rocks and need to keep your balance. Diana N. was a spectacular tour guide - request her if you can!

WOW! Super cool experience!. This has got to be one of the most coolest experiences in my life. Complete thrill ride inside this cave with all the features being mind blowing. I don't recommend this for young children maybe under 10 years old or for persons who have difficulty walking as the terrain inside the caves is bumpy and rough. The water was cold at first but with the wet suit, it was fine after a few seconds of being in the water. Our guide Nuenes was awesome at helping me through the swimming parts and he was great at explaining everything! If you love cave exploring this is the place for you!

Underground cavern tour. We had a wonderful tour at rio secreto. Our guide, Alena was wonderful and very informative. It was a wonderful experience to wade and swim thru an underground river. It is better if you are sure footed in that there is a lot of uneven ground that you can't see under the water, but makes it more real and adventures. The whole family loved it.

A decent day trip - if you want a break from the sun and a little adventure. We decided to do this day trip as we actually wanted a day out of the sun (halfway through our vacation we were all pretty sunburnt). It was a neat thing to do BUT both of our children (ages 6&8) were scared at times. By the end, our 6 year old was terrified and I felt horrible. The guide was excellent and did his best to calm them (so there wasn't a complete panic attack). Overall, I would recommend it if you haven't experienced anything like this before BUT I did find it pricy for what we did there (you do not get to see any animals as advertised) and the ride there is REALLY bumpy (2 of us got car sick - so take medication if you tend to get motion sickness). The overall cost for the 4 of us (+ you have to buy their photos if you want any which were crazy $$- we still ended up getting them) was close to $450. Value wasn't really there. I think $50 a person is more reasonable for this type of activity.
Really amazing. Had a blast in the caves. Our guide Francis was really great. Ask for him by name if you can. Would recommend this trip!!

Secret Treasure!. This trip was like entering a new world. I have been in caverns before, but this was much more interactive because you go into the waters yourself and theres no one else there but your group and tour guide. My husband and I did this as an excursion from our cruise in March 2015. We were glad to get out of the crazy Playa del Carmen to a quite natural area. We first change into our bathing suits, water shoes, wet suits, and helmets. After that we walked through the woods and met a Mayan who did a little ceremony to allow us into the cenote. After walking a little further into the woods, we entered the cenote and it was magnificent. This is an experience everyone should have... showing how beautiful this world is. Yayo was our tour guide, and he was magnificent. He truly loved what he did and taught us all a lot. He added a lot of excitement and adventure to our journey through.
