The only downer for me was that you were not allowed to bring your camera along with you, as they take photographs of the group (and posed pictures at certain stops). The whole CD was $75 and one photo was $25! It does all go for a good cause, to keep the land to the Mayans and natural. Afterwords, they had a Mayan lunch planned for us, which was pretty tasty. I would recommend this journey for anyone in the area. We found Playa del Carmen too touristy for us, so Im glad we made this journey!

Magic trip!. I highly recommend this tour. It was very well organized from start to end. Jerman was our guide, and I have a lot of praise for his enthusiasm, knowledge, and professionalism. He went over and beyond, guiding us through a magic land, assisting along the way, pacing the group, pointing to things we would not have otherwise noticed, really speaking with passion about these sacred plances. Afterwards he stayed with us during lunch, and made sure we were all on the bus heading home safely. Mandy Rattner, Toronto, Canada

Amazing adventure. We arranged for a private tour through our hotel for a group of six ranging in age from 6-50 years old. The activity was highly recommended by the concierge and it did not disappoint - it was far and away our favorite activity that we experienced while in Mexico. Alfredo was a wonderful guide (including carrying the 6 yr old when she got cold) for a once in a lifetime experience in the caves. The activity was a bit challenging - definitely not for anyone who is claustrophobic or has any significant balance or mobility issues. But for the sure of foot (even as young as 6), it was a wonderful experience - the caves are stunning. The lunch that was provided after the tour was also fantastic. Highly recommend this activity!

So cool!. This was an awesome excursion. We purchased the trip and transportation from Cancun all through Viator. It was such an awesome experience--I can't believe things like this exist. Our guide was Jorge and he was so knowledgeable and friendly. I honestly wouldn't have changed a thing about it and we are so glad our friends suggested we do it. The lunch they serve at the end isn't your 5 star buffet but it is certainly good and there is plenty of food. I highly recommend doing this. We got to the Rio Secreto area (you take a quick bus ride down a winding road after you first arrive) around 10:30 and we were done by 1:30, I believe. It was the right amount of time, probably about 2 hours in the cave itself. So cool, I would definitely recommend this!

ANOTHER WORLD!!! Absolutely amazing!!. ALFREDO was the most amazing cave guide ever! I am so glad that my best friend and myself did this excursion through Carnival, it was absolutely incredible and the experience was amazing. The sights you will see are breath taking and this is NOTHING like caves we see in the US. I have been to many beautiful caves such as Luray Caverns in Virginia and Mammoth Cave in Kentucky and nothing tops the beauty of Rio Secreto!

Wow and whoa!. We did this excursion as a family group (10 people ages 9-75). Some of us had done Xcaret and some hadn't seen any caves yet; though we had done an excellent excursion to Chichen Itza earlier in the week. I was surprised at how natural the caves have been kept and the rustic-ness of the experience. Aside from a small step down at the beginning, you're walking thru the caves much as they must have been when found. It's almost all walking, not floating/lazy river for those that thought this would be more like Xcarat or Xel-Ha. Though a few places where it's deep enough for a short swim. There's no ropes, steps, etc. Just you, your guide and the headlamps. Oh, and your photographer. While I was a bit miffed at the beginning to not be allowed our camera, I was glad enough to be able to focus on the experience. I do think the pics are far too expensive, and the hard core haggling needed to get a more reasonable price took the shine off an otherwise great visit (still think they are too expensive).On the positive side, it is a stunning visual experience. Our guide was Allan, and I think he did a great job showing us around. Allan was especially supportive of the few of us that needed some extra care with some of the sections. It's not hard but this is not a smooth, polished experience. Part of the fun!I liked that you had the choice of bring your own water shoes, use theirs for free or buy your own (which were the same price as our hotel, so not bad). All helmets did the trick (we had a few bumps so we put them to the test) and all headlamps worked very well. Especially nice is that the groups were spaced out well, so that we didn't see anyone else in the cave but our own.So aside from the photo haggle/hassle, a great experience and one of our vacation highlights.

Lots of travel from the Port, but worth it.. If you book through Carnival, the excursion brochure indicates the tour is 7 hours; however, the tour of the cave is actually only about 1.5 hours. You are not permitted to bring a camera. You cannot wear jewelry (not even a watch) and you must take a rinse shower before taking the tour.You’ll disembark, walk from the disembarkation pier to the next pier over and board a large ferry boat (air conditioned on the first level and covered/open air on the top level). The ferry will then take approximately 45 minutes, bringing you to Playa del Carmen. You’ll then be directed to a guide and you will walk approximately 5-10 minutes to a van. The van ride then takes about 30 minutes to the site. Once at the site, you will be given a safety briefing and all necessary gear. That includes an optional wetsuit, a lighted helmet, a life vest and water shoes. You will also have free lockers available.That being said, the experience was amazing and not to be missed, so don’t be discouraged by all the travel time. The caves were breathtaking and our guide (Victor) was awesome. We were told there are three different underground rivers to explore, and the one you experience is dependent upon when you arrive. The stalactites and stalagmites were absolutely beautiful, and the water was a cool 75 degrees.Most of the people in our group wore wetsuits. I chose not to, simply because I didn’t want something too restrictive. Although the guides recommend you wear a wetsuit, it isn’t mandatory. I’m glad I didn’t wear one, because I think it would have been too warm. 75 degree water may sound chilly, but after traversing the caves, it’s very refreshing.After the tour is over, they provide a buffet style lunch with traditional Mayan food. The food was much better than I expected. If you have the opportunity to take this tour, take it. The guides are very knowledgeable and friendly, and the scenery is incredible. At the end of the tour, we had an opportunity to do about 40 minutes of shopping in Playa del Carmen. The return to the Cozumel port, is the reverse. Walk, van ride, walk, ferry, walk.

Unique Experience. Strongly suggest visiting this. Very cool experience. Francis was an amazing guide. The caves themselves are beautiful, and you will never see anything like it anywhere else. Plus, you will have the option to experience complete silence and darkness for a few moments -- and it is unforgettable. FYI: Lunch is provided after the excursion. One note: you're not allowed to bring any cameras or phones on the trip and there will be a paparazzi taking pictures, which you can purchase later. Don't forget to haggle ;)
Cave tour. Fabian was an excellent guide, very nice and helpful, even though I was not a swimmer he helped me through.

Do not miss this .... Amazing caves with over 35 miles of rivers. Guided with wet suits, safety jacket, amazing guide. One thing, no cameras allowed and the ones they tried to sell us where mediocre at best and very pricy.

spiritual experience. The Rio Secreto visit was phenomenal. In our wetsuits and helmets, we traveled into deep caverns, swam, listened to the playing of the stalactites, and learned about the formation of the stalactites, stalagmites, and columns. At one point the guide has us turn off our headlights, and we enjoyed the complete silence and darkness. Very moving experience in this ancient spot.

Great Excurson. Visited Rio Secreto March Break 2015, our tour guide Raoul was a great leader. My son wished there was more "swimming" but the caves were amazing. Like others said, the price of the photos was a little too expensive for my liking.The food included with the tour was tasty!

Great activity. We had lots of fun on this tour! We went on a day I was sunburnt and the cool water in the underground caves was a nice change from the hot sun. Our tour guide was great and really made the trip exceptional.

Intimate and breathtaking experience. My family experienced Rio Secreto while on a Western Caribbean Cruise for March Break. This excursion was offered from the port of Cozumel. The excursion was 7 hours so we were all a little leary about committing that much time but it was well worth it. After a short high speed ferry ride from Cozumel to the mainland, we were met by the tour guides and quickly bussed 20 minutes away to the site. After a lengthy process of being outfitted for the tour we were ready to go for a hike into the "jungle" (it wasn't really...) and we were blessed by a local prayer which was nice.We arrived at the entrance to the cavern not knowing what to expect and were transported into a completely new world 70feet underground wading through the most clear mineral water and thick colums of stagmalite that has formed over thousands of years. The best part of the exploration was when we had some time to sit in the complete darkness and feel the peace of a time long ago and also when we could float or swim around the deep clear pools. I wish there were more time for this activity! All together we were underground for 1 1/2 hours but it flew by. We had a photographer follow our small group of 10 and we could buy the CD afterwards for a pricey $60 (of course we had to buy it!)The excursion was followed by a taste of a local liquer and an authentic Mexican buffet. Thankfully we could purchase a Dos Equis to wash down the lovely meal.All in all well worth the time and cost of the excursion. This adventure is only for those who can handle the bumpy bus ride, brisk hike, and climbing through the cavern. I'm not in amazing shape, but it wasn't too challenging for me :-) although there was a gentleman in our group who was struggling so head their restrictions to be safe.

Not as easy as they say. There was a lot of walking through the woods over large rocks, uneven surfaces, fallen limbs and big tree roots. In the cave you cannot touch anything, and there is nothing to lean on for balance except your stick (not much help), or to steady yourself as you walk over very uneven ground. There is a fair amount of swimming, too, and not all that much to see. Great nature, but a bit underwhelming and harder than it is represented

underground caves. we have visited these caves before. they were only found in 2008 and are very new on the activities list. when we visited before they only had one cavern open for tours and now have 3, i mentioned i had been one one before and after figuring out what tour i had taken they changed the days tour to a different one so i could see new things. absolutely breathtaking. a well tour well worth the money to take but do not go if you are afraid of the dark or claustrophobic as the tours are in underground caves.

Beautiful tour, upset about pictures. I was so excited for this tour. The cave system was absolutely beautiful and it was thrilling and eerie when we all turned off our lights and sat in the darkness. I have to say, it's extremely disappointing that we couldn't bring in a camera, and the price of pictures was ridiculous. They wanted $85 for the lot, which wasn't many pictures, or $25 for each individual picture. I really wanted pictures but I wasn't willing to pay that price, and they wouldn't budge on it.

beautiful tour. Great tour in a new cave system. it was beautiful and fun. The pictures were a bit expensive but they started to haggle with me. I just accepted their lower price. (which was 60 dollars for the Full set of pictures and a bottle of liquor. And to be honest I didn't even try to go lower with the price) I would absolutely suggest this tour and getting the memorable pictures with it, but know what price they are willing to take. :-)

Crystal clear river, walking tour.. Just came back from Cozumel and Playa del Carmen and this was one of our favorite activities. Water is cold and the trails can be slippery, but the company provides the necessary equipment. I whish they make so make frequent stops to take posed pictures to sell the guests later, but overall is a good experience.

Beautiful, Amazing experience. We've visited caves before, but this one was truly magnificent. You get to do the true cave diving experience. The staff prepares you with the right equipment, they are knowledgeable and friendly. Our guide, Raul P, did an amazing job caring for our daughter who was the youngest of the group we were in. Highly recommend!

My son was even impressed. Just a warning, if you are not in shape and have a tough time walking on uneven surfaces, I would avoid this adventure because for once you start, there is no heading back.I took this tour with my son and I do have to say that if it was not for Diana our guide,the going would been tougher.Our guide Diana was very knowledgeable about the underground rivers and caverns.The way she presented it was educational, mysterious and adventurous and yes, don't forget the fun part.About half way through my son turned to me and said " this has to be one of the best tours I have ever been on". Reason I bring this up is he is a very hard person to please.At the end of the tour they do have a buffet which is very good and you can sit with your group and discuss the tour if you want.After the Buffet you can go into the gift shop and purchase the photos that were taken while on the tour.

Great Adventure. This underground river was amazing. Since I have a bad ankle, the walking was tough at times. However, our excellent guide, Rodolfo provided me with a walking stick. He was great. He cared about our safety, the preservation of the cave and was very patient. Afterwards, we had a buffet meal of local foods. I would recommend this adventure.

Great outdoor experience with the family. Thus is a great outdoor experience to do with your kids, this is real natural underground water rivers unlike those artificially made in parks like xplor. You can see they really take care of the natural river and they do not drill though it to the benefit of the park or the money. There are different systems so you will have to go a few times if you really want to see it all.

Being there is worth every imaginable reality of the ancient world.... First, the tour guide was what made it the experience, I am sure all guides are trained for this, educational, spiritual, and well-rounded in personality...I was never inside a cave before and with the river made it surreal...imagine the Mayan people there 1,200 years ago...it does take careful steps and paying attention to the guide to navigate through...pictures taken along the way make it a true memory...the spiritual part for me was the beginning and the time we sat for 3 minute in total darkness and silence, and if you are a believer in meditation, LOA, you are the creator of your reality, then when you go you will know what this place vibrates...just breathing in there puts you into deep recognition of why we exist...anyway, I'm getting off track here...but go, it is so beautiful and you can see a beach/scuba or whatever tropical excursion you might think otherwise; but, how many unique experiences like this happen along the way? Enjoy!

AHHHMAAAAZZZINGGGG!!!!!!!. This was our excursion on our second port we had a long day on our Myan Ruin tour the day before so I was looking for laid back. THis wasn't so much laid back but something I will NEVER forget!!!!!! We brought some bottled water (my tip to travelers, lots of water lol) and our own water shoes (cause I skeeve feet) we had to wear some silly gear but it was all good. I choose to take advantage of the walking stick that was offered and I was glad I did. Rol (Rodrigo) was our tour guide and he was very very good. He knows these caves I will give him that, and he's so comfortable in them that I felt at ease. A blessing was first and to take part in such an ancient ritual was awesome. After a short walk through the jungle (dare I say????) the enthusiasm was building, the pictures just don't do it justice. You really have to experience it. You climb over and under these delicate rocks the whole thing is an oxymoron. To sit in complete darkness and silence and be one with nature. You can hear the water drips creating these stalactites and stalagmites (and I know its more than water, the whole limestone, calcium carbonate, and carbon dioxide etc.) it's amazing I was in awe complete awe. The exploring through the cave reminded me of the Goonies (and I wasn't the only one lol) and the tree roots seeping down to the water crazy nature. I hope to return again just laying in the hammocks outside was perfect! Buy the picture package it's worth it. Lot's of so so pictures of me but the documents of the experience was worth it. We got some kind of deal $119, all the pictures on disk, a souvenir book, a tshirt, and a camouflage hat. They give you a small meal at the end of the tour, the green "salsa" is HOTTTTTTT some chips, salsa, diced chicken, rice and beans, corn tortillas, fruit, I don't remember what else honestly that's all I ate.

An amazing underground experience!. Our caving experience at Rio Secreto was an amazing afternoon! The formations are stunning, the water crystal clear, and I can't say enough great things about our guide, Alfredo. Alfredo's love of the caves and his job was infectious. He was knowledgeable about the caves, the wildlife seen and the Mayan history of the area. The meal provided afterwards was delicious, an authentic Mexican meal. I highly recommend this excursion.
loved it!. we booked this excursion on a port call during a cruise....best excursion we did! so glad we did it, and also being in the caves...no sunburn! i loved the fresh water.

Very educational - great for eco-tourists. This is a really fun half-day excursion if you're in the area. It was extremely interesting to learn about the 700km cave system below the Yucatan peninsula and how it was revered by the Mayan people. Our tour guide covered a lot of information...not just on the formation of the caves and their historical significance, but also what lives in the caves now and the future of the cave system. How much walking vs. swimming you do inside the cave will depend on the season and how much rain they've received. We visited this March and it was about 50/50 walking and swimming/wading. Everyone was required to put on a wetsuit, water shoes, life jacket, and helmet with an attached headlamp - so if you don't know how to swim, you'll be fine! The water was cool but not uncomfortably so. Even a mildly claustrophobic person would probably be okay with this tour. There are some spots you need to squeeze through, but even in those areas the cave is very large and open - you just have to get between two rock formations in order to stay on the designated path (this protects the cave from excessive wear and tear). I would NOT recommend this tour for anyone who is feeble or unsteady on their feet, however. The cave floor is very uneven and often times sloped and slippery. They offer everyone a walking stick before going into the cave, but I'm not sure how much that would have helped in some instances. We did walk about 10 minutes each way through the jungle to get to the cave opening, and the path was uneven and rocky there too (what can you expect - it's the jungle). Upon returning to the hut and collecting our belongings, we were taken to a souvenir shop to look at our tour photos - sadly, they were all horribly unflattering. And they were also very, very expensive to purchase! A buffet-style lunch was included after the tour - the food was just okay.The only thing I did not like about the experience was all the rigamarole to actually get to the "tour" part of the trip. When we arrived at Rio Secreto we first stopped at a ticket hut near the entrance and got our wristbands. Then we were taken to another hut where we filled out waivers. Then we walked through some sticks to another van and were driven like 20 minutes through the jungle to yet another set of huts, where we were shown to our lockers and the restrooms, walked to the showers (yes, a very brisk shower is required before entering the cave), and finally given our equipment for the tour. It was then that we set out through the jungle. It just seemed like we spent a lot of time going from place to place and not as much time with the tour guide as I expected. Fortunately, the trip home was much more efficient - we went directly from the last set of huts back to the resort.

An Exciting Adventure. Close to Playacar. Very rough ride from gate to site in jungle. Took very good care of tourists. Great meal provided. Water shoes provided but not mentioned in brochure. Lots of obstacles so watch your step and above your head. Kind of makes you feel like a real explorer. Not good for elderly or claustrophobia cases. Staff very friendly and helpful. Very modern lockers for your stuff. Don't put on sun screen or anything else. Some minor mosquitoes. Gear condition good. Don't bring lots of stuff because you can't take it into the caves. Just your bathing suit and eye glasses. Our guide Carlos. Very good English and French speaking. Takes about 90 minutes in the cave depending which route your house takes you. Well worth it.

Ah-mazing!. We (myself, husband, 7-yr old scaredy-cat son) did this as part of a cruise excursion. It did eat up our entire day at Cozumel, but we all felt it was WELL worth it. We explored the caves with Anna and she was EXCELLENT!! As mentioned above my son is a little timid and she helped calm him right away and helped him navigate the caves with FUN and ease. My tip is to take the walking stick. I'm 33, female in good shape, but it helped for sure to find big dips in the water and rocks so as to avoid getting scraped or scratched. The post cave meal was great and everyone was very helpful and kind. Will recommend to everyone that I can...it was that good!

Rio Secreto, The secret river.. Had a wonderfurl time with this excursion. We had tour guide Carlos and he was wonderful. We were able to stay in the caves for a long time and experience this siteto it's fullest. Would definitely do this again!!!! Thanks Carlos for being so wonderful with our group!!Food is provided on this tour as well and it was very good!!!

One of the best tours I have been on in all of my travels!. My two kids and I along with my girl's boyfriend went on several tours recently while traveling to Cancun. We wanted to visit as many local attractions that we could while in the area. We were very happy to go on this tour with Tita who was a great guide and was very friendly and offered as much information as we needed and made us feel very comfortable with all of her humor and good explanations of what we would be experiencing. I was very impressed with the local Mayan Shaman who welcomed us and smudged us off before entering the cenote. Tita was awesome by helping us feel very comfortable when rappelling down into the cave. What a blast! The cenote water was incredibly refreshing and then we had a local Mayan lunch. My girl and her boyfriend are both vegans and they didn't have any problems at all eating the awesome food placed before us. We are very grateful to the local Mayans who treated us very well and very courteous and respectful as we were to them. It was an awesome experience and I would go again if I had a chance. Thank you Tita and the Mayan people who hosted us!

eye opening. I am so gracious for having the opportunity to explore such a beautiful part of nature! Our guide Yayo was very knowledgable and kind! The company provides you with everything you need. you cant bring a camra, but the photos that were taken came out beautifully- I think the photograher was crystal. If you like adventure this half day trip is perfect- go early in the morning if you want to see the batts! happy trails.
Awesome. Loved this! I am claustrophic so was not sure I could actually enter the cave. WOW, I'm glad I did! Beautiful place
Mind Blowing. You go 20 meters underground, you do a bit of crawling, you do swimming and everything down there. Great time we were down there for about 1.5 hours our guide Raul (STACHE) was awesome.

Great time!. It was beautiful and educational. The drive to/from the caves was a bit of a damper, but well worth it once we got there. Alfredo was fun and informative. Great times down below the ground!

Better than I thought.. This was a very cool place. I don't like big tourist traps, so I was skeptical. We were the very first group of the morning, at 9am, which I would recommend before the tour buses arrive. The caves and cenotes were beautiful! Our Guide, Diana, was knowledge and very helpful. Very organized. The buffet was a little better than ok, but I wasn't expecting much. The only bad thing were the photos. It seemed we stopped every 10 minutes to take a photo. At the end of our tour to purchase a photo was way too pricey; $25 for one photo or $69 for all photos. We ordered one photo just to show our friends, but we forgot to pick it up before leaving. :-(

Beautiful!. They provided us with everything: water shoes, helmet with light, and wetsuit. Once you put everything on, you take a shower (brrrr, it's cold!!). Then you walk over to the opening of the cenote. Before you go in, you participate in a Mayan ceremony. Julio was our guide and he very really good. He was very informative and made sure we were safe and happy. One person in our group had a fear of dark water so he kept him near him at all times to reassure him. Once inside, it's a lot of walking in and out of the cool clear water. The water is beautiful and you are surrounded by stalagmites and stalactites. It is all very beautiful and amazing. A photographer came with us and took many great pictures. We purchased the CD at the end for around $75 (we were three couples so we split it which wasn't bad).When we were done, they had a buffet lunch of rice, beans, chicken, veggies and fruits. It was pretty good. This is something I would definitely do again and want to bring my kids to do it.

Unique beautiful family adventure. My family of 6 (2 parents and 4 kids ages 12,10,10,5) visited Rio Secreto today. There are certain activities that we have done that everyone agrees was worth the money, expense and travel time and this ranks among the best. The natural beauty inspired awe in all my kids, my wife and me. I had looked at going to several of the cenotes in the area but settled on this excursion because of the proximity to Playa and the reviews. There are no zip lines, no waves to body surf in, no over commercialization, just nature. Our tour group of ten included 6 kids, 4 adults and was led by very knowledgable and personable guide who took pride in the area and his job. This is a well run tour worth the time and effort. It was truly something I have never experienced.

Unlike any other excursion...amazing experience!. I will try to be as comprehensive and detailed as possible because I know how important it is to choose the right excursion when you are traveling. I have done the Rio Secreto tour 3 times. I have not been disappointed even once. It is an experience that is unrivaled by any other excursion.I want everyone who goes on this trip to be prepared so I will try to cover advice and suggestions. I will use a bulleted list to help make it easier to follow.-Make sure you are on the pier on time. They are very prompt.-If you get carsick, go prepared and take your meds or wear your bracelets as they vehicles are a little bumpy and swerve a bit to avoid rough patches and holes...(A side note: My daughter bought me little bracelets with pressure points that are supposed to be for seasickness. I was dubious because they don't seem to have much to them but they worked great!!) -Pay attention! On one trip out to the site, we spotted a huge cat dash across the road in front of us...turns out it is a rare type of Jaguar that is so elusive it is almost never seen and one of our guides captured a picture of it. On another trip, we spotted a spider large enough to watch it strut across the road! It was huge! Keep an eye peeled for unusual things you might see as you go through the jungle area.-When you arrive at the site, listen! The guides will explain how the caves were discovered and are really knowledgeable. My favorite guide was a graduate from the University with a Masters degree and you could tell he was so passionate about the information he was eager to share. -I was really concerned about being cold as I get cold quite easily and the thought of being underground worried me. The wetsuits they provide were wonderful. I didn't feel cold at all. You will wear a helmet with a light to help you make your way through the caverns. All of it was very comfortable and everyone was very helpful in making sure you are suited up properly.-Before you enter the cave, you will receive a blessing from a Mayan priest. There is a feeling of being part of something very special and a bit profound.-The journey through the caverns is slow and cautious. There is a sense of a team in that you accept help from the person in front of you at times and you turn to help those behind you. When you are in areas where it is rockier or narrow, that helping hand is really helpful. -Be aware that the caverns will go from being dry and rocky to ankle deep in water to shoulder deep. There are a few places where you actually dog paddle to the next dry spot. The water level changes according to how much rain they have had but it is really an exciting experience. The swim through the cavern is amazing because you are swimming in relative darkness and it is humbling to be that far underground and making your way through this maze of natural formations and water....just breathtaking.-It is important to keep from touching the walls around you as it can damage the ecosystem of the caverns. -There is a phosphorous pool that is breathtaking...and a huge open cavern that is awe-inspiring. Our guides had us turn off our lights for a minute or two to experience a depth of darkness that is unrivaled. It is absolutely profound.-While I want everyone to experience this trip through the caverns, it should be noted that there is some stepping up and down from rock ledges and such and that it might be hard if you have a severe back problem...but we had people of all ages and body types on our tours and everyone did just fine. -There is a photographer who accompanies your group and he takes some awesome photos. The photos are a bit pricey but my only regret is the one trip I took when I declined the photos. I will always buy them on future trips.-After exiting the caverns, they served a very good lunch prepared there and we had the opportunity to ask our guides questions and take photos.-I will take the tour again...and probably again....There is something unique and very special about the experience. I think anyone who is up for the walk should do this excursion at least once.I encourage

A MUST See - my favorite attraction in the area. We went to Tulum, Chichen Itza and Rio Secret and Rio Secreto was our favorite destination! There are so many cenotes in the area and it was not easy to pick just one but I did a lot of research (thanks TripAdvisor!) and so glad that I decided to Rio Secreto! You can book your trip on their website but I was having technical difficulties and ended up using their 'live help' feature and booking my tour through them. They gave me %15 discount, which was a nice bonus!Also, there were no transportation options available for the date I wanted to go, so my family just ended up taking a cab to Rio Secreto from our hotel in Playa Del Carmen (Paradisus) - it was a short 20 min ride and ended up costing us around $25 or so. And that was cheaper and a lot more convenient(!) than using the transportation option provided by Rio Secreto. Coming back from Rio Secreto we were able to use one of the mini vans they use to take you to and from the cenote - and that also was around $25 and so convenient. So depending on where you are coming from, you may want to consider skipping the transportation option provided by Rio Cenote and cabbing it instead.Now back to the cenote - although the whole tour is 3.5 hours, you only spend about 1.5 hours - 1.45 hours in the cenote - the rest of the time is taken between filling out paperwork, driving through the jungle to the cenote, changing into wet suites, changing out of the wet suites, looking at pictures and eating lunch. But we felt that the time we spent in the cave was enough. It was really stunning - caves are not lit up but each tour guide has a flash light and each person on the tour has a flash light on their hard hats so we were able to see everything OK. The tour is a partly walking/partly swimming - it was not difficult - we had our 7 year old twins with us and they did great. You don't need to know how to swim well, they give you life jackets so you can float.No cameras are allowed inside but each tour has a photographer with them, he takes pictures that you can purchase at the end. We ended up buying all pictures - $109 included a CD with all the images PLUS three items from the gift store, which we thought was a bargain.Overall, it was a great experience, my kids absolutely LOVED it (even though at first they were not very convinced about leaving the comfort of the hotel) and I highly recommend it.

Truly special .... Amazing!Landed a private tour somehow, so it was only my, my husband & the guide. If you want to see caves that are 100% real, deep underground, this is a must. It can't be described how breath taking or spectacular this tour is. What a special day. Be prepared, it can be quite a tricky walk through the water/rocks/cave ... not for someone that has trouble balancing or walking with ease. ps don't watch a horror cave movie before going...lol

Amazing Tour!. We had a fantastic time touring the caves. Our tour guide, Diana S. was very knowledgable and pleasant. Our family has made numerous trips to this region and this is by far the best excursion we have taken. Beautiful Rock formations and refreshing water.

A really good experience. This is a really good half day excursion. Guides are very knowledgeable and cave is beautiful. Here is what to expect. You will arrive at the location and watch a short video about the cave. You will link up with your guide and then your group will transfer to a bus. The road to the cave is extremely bumpy. Do try to sit in the front of your bus if you get motion sick. The shocks on the buses are poor and the drivers swerve around huge pot holes. Once you reach the end of the road, you will undress (down to your swimwear) and put all your clothes and personal items into a free locker. The locker key will be a bracelet so don't worry, you won't lose it. They will then provide you with water shoes. These are a must, the rocks in the cave are very sharp. You will then be asked to shower outside to wash off any sunscreen, dirt, perfumes, etc. They will fit you in a wetsuit, a helmet and then a life jacket. Once your group is fit, you will take a short walk through the rainforest. A Mayan priest will give a short blessing before you head into the cave. Once in the cave it is only a few steps before you get to the water. The water is chilly and the wet suits help keep you warm. if you can't walk well this is probably not the adventure for you. Yes the guide will help and there are walking sticks but let's be honest, you have to jump around in water where you can't see very well. Don't be nervous by your photographer, he takes a few alternate paths to make sure he can capture some really great photos. The heart and lungs section of the cave is the only place where you will really be able to swim. My favorite part was the last "swim" as you go down a very narrow exit and your head is just inches away from the top. It was a really cool adventure.

Great underground adventure. A very interesting underground excursion with a guide. They provide wet suits, a locked locker and head lamps. Tour last approximately 90 minutes and they provide lunch afterwards.

Not a bad morning. This was not the best excursion, our guide was very knowlegdeable and explained things very well, i do agree with some of the negative reviews with regards to the gear, the wetsuits and watersocks stunk the helmets were disgusting. getting past the long wait at the entrance the long drive through a very bumpy jungle road, and another long wait at the place to get your stinky gear. you get to see a wonderful, natural, underground beauty. This is raw, natural and pretty much untouched. yes you must pay attention to where you step and where your head is but take a second to look around and the beauty of it all is there to see. I would go again, as there are multiple routes through the caves.

The Real Deal. Cenotes are not uncommon in the Yucatan region and there are lots to choose from. We had heard of Rio Secreto and it was on our list of possible excursions. We chose it because it was one of the few 1/2 day adventures leaving us to enjoy our all inclusive resort and beach in the afternoon. My first impression was wow, this feels authentic and not like the typical tourist traps so common. The second, our guide, Carlos is very passionate about what he is showing us. We spent 2 hours touring the underground network spellbound by the natural beauty. The photos shown online are not typical of what you might see here and there but what you will see for the entire tour! A small buffet it provided and I'd recommend using their booties as they will keep the limestone pebbles from gathering in open sandals. While not as vast as the Grand Canyon or Rockies in its' own way it still provides that experience that you can only feel when you are experiencing yourself.

Rio Secreto!. Our family was just on a Caribbean Cruise, One of our shore excursion was the Rio Secreto. Our tour guide was Ro, Ro was a wonderful guide and awesome with our kids!! The caves were so beautify and amazing. Ro took us on the tour of JOY, We have already booked our next cruise for next year and this is definitely is going to be one of our shore excursion again, I will definitely be asking for Ro to be our tour guide again. Ro gave us so much information on the caves and the kids may not have noticed but this tour was very educational, Ro is so full of knowledge and so much fun to be around I couldn't have asked for a better guide to go with then Ro! cant wait to see the caves again! Thank you Ro for an amazing time!!

A must do.. This was an amazing experience! Jorge was our guide with a ton of knowledge (he helped map the caves when they were discovered nine years ago) and humour. Do both tours cause you are there anyway. One is in the clearest water ever and the other one is dry. Smile cause they are taking tons of photos which are good but they wanted $80 US for the images. We didn't buy them but it's Mexico so we should have negotiated. The buffet was great!

Breathtaking. This trip was unbelievable. Walking through these amazing caves was unreal. Priceless experience. Don't go if you don't like small spaces, are scared of the dark, or afraid of water. Smile for the camera, because they will sell you the pics after.

Amazing and Unique Experience!. This was not your ordinary day trip tropical excursion. This was FUN in the SHADE -- not sun -- a day of enjoying secret places of an underground river. The cave formations, stalactites and stalagmites were beautiful. We went with a group of 10 and had an exceptional guide - Rene. He was not only informative, but amusing and made the experience a memorable one for each and every person in our party. The Mayan traditions are explored, you get a taste of science and nature, and follow it all up with a yummy yet authentic Yucatan buffet. If you are looking for a day to get a break from the tropical rays and enjoy some thing extraordinary, this is it!

Swiming into the belly boutton of earth. What a great experience, something I will never forget. Our guide Diana, was extremely knowledgeable and always gave us great explanation. I wish we would of been able to do more than one cave. Prepare for cool water, and it's challenging. Lunch was included in out tour

Amazing! A must see for anyone in the Area.. We purchased our tickets for this excursion from a travel/tour agency onsite of our resort. Normally the price for this place is $100.00 US/person- however on the weekends (Saturday/Sunday) Rio Secreto has a special of buy one admission get the other 50% off- so for the two of us we paid about $154.00. If you don't like crowds than this is a great excursion as they promise groups no larger then 10 per tour guide- our group had 8 people in it- Groups were separated far enough that you never saw another group once in the caves - or at least we did not (at the time of check in there were 5 other groups). Rio Secreto provides all the equipment you need- even though their brouchure indicates you need to bring or rent your own water shoes- they actually provide them free of charge. Equipment that we had was in good conditions- though I did hear some complaints from other people at the resort that the water shoes they had weren't that great (i.e. falling apart). The best time to go is probably the morning tour as most of the equipment is dry -though there was still some wet items- my guess is that in the afternoon tour everything would be soaking wet and would have had no time to air out before being used again.When going into the underwater caves they tell you that you are not allowed to bring anything with you i.e. cameras, watches etc in order to help preserve the condition of the caves. The actual tour was fantastic and amazing. For much of the tour you spend walking through water from ankle to knee high deep- deeper into the cave though there are areas over 6 feet deep that you need to swim through- though you do have a life jacket on at all times. There are some areas that are extremely tight (this is why they recommend that this tour is not suited for anyone over 250lbs- though there was one person on the tour that must have been about 270lbs and he was able to get through the tight spaces. Note also that at the beginning of the tour they provide large walking sticks for those that need it- older persons in our group (60+) did use them and found them to assist with the walk. Both of us in our early 40s and healthy found no need for the walking stick- if you are fit then this excursion will pose no difficulties. This cave is the second largest cave in the world- with a cave in Kentucky US being the largest- but this cave is considered dead with no life and the one in Maya Riviera is considered alive. We did see some very small fish, one bat and a few very unusual spiders that share characteristics of the scorpion. This excursion was by far the best experience we had and we went to Tulum ruins, Xcaret Park and Xel-ha. In our opinion a must see.This excursion is also only about half a day: from your resort to the site and back. Some have commented on the food, but we did go to this excursion for the food- all I can say is that it was okay.I would give this place a 5/5 were it not for the ridiculous price they wanted for 1 photo- $25.00 US and $80.00 US for all photos- this is a rip off and was a bit of a disappointed at the end of the tour.......There is no reason why you can't take a camera in the underground cave except for the reason that they want to scam you by charging you a crazy price for pictures that they take of you. If you can get over this fact, than this should be a definite place to tour especially if you don't like large masses of people.

You Have to See It To Believe It. Based on a suggestion from a friend, I visited Rio Secreto as part of a trip to Riviera Maya. I was a bit apprehensive about spending a portion of the day underground instead of enjoying the Mexican sunshine. Nevertheless, I boarded the bus and headed to the cave. When we arrived, we were instructed to take everything off except for our bathing suits. We were given wet suits and water shoes. (well after taking a communal shower). After receiving an initial overview from our wonderful guide (Diana), we embarked on an amazing journey to a beautiful underground environment. Here are a few things to know: 1. TAKE THE STICK: When you are offered a walking stick before the journey; please take it. You will definitely need it and use it. 2. YOUR HAIR WILL GET WET (but it'll be so worth it) 3. ASK for DIANA to SERVE as YOUR GUIDE (As mentioned, she is wonderful as is the knowledge she provides. 4. TAKE the HAPPINESS route. The routes have different names; take the Happiness route 5. EAT the LUNCH and drink the hibiscus water (it's really good and you'll be quite hungry after the tour 6. BRING YOUR OWN WATER SHOES (with a great deal of support on the bottom). The shoes provided are a bit worn and the rocks inside and outside of the cave can wreck havoc on your feet. 7. HAVE FUN and ALWAYS SMILE PRETTY (the photographer is everywhere---it is possible to be cute in a cave)8. WEAR A BATHING SUIT 9. TAKE A CHANGE of CLOTHES

What a waste of time and money - Another TA blunder!. We go to Cancun and the surrounding areas 4-5 times a year. We're very familiar with everything Mayan and Yucatan. We've been resisting the temptation TA reviewers have caused with their glowing accounts of Rio Secreto; we've experienced some serious disappointments in the past when we ate in a restaurant "highly rated" by TA reviewers or stayed at a hotel considered "fantastic" by them. We said "the place received 4.5 stars, it has got to be at least interesting" and went for it. After paying $1** per person on line and getting our payment codes, we drove to the entrance of Rio Secreto, almost directly across Xplore, on the Riviera Maya highway, south of Cancun, app. 75 minutes drive from the middle of the Hotel Zone. We got our bracelets and assigned to a group of seven others. Our group was driven in a minibus on an awful back country road 18 minutes. Upon arrival we were given a smelly wet suit, life jacket and ill fitting water shoes. Our jolly guide took us to the point where our misadventures were to begin: we descended on some uneven and steep steps to arrive at the beginning of the underground river system, which our guide claimed was 32 miles. He assured us that we were going to explore only 0.6 miles of it. We walked and occasionally had to swim in about 75 degrees F water. As we walked we had to focus entirely on where we were stepping and what was above our head. The floor is so uneven and there are so many little boulders or holes that a moment's negligence is enough to stumble and twist your ankle or scrape your skin (two people suffered these mishaps in our group.) So, except for the six occasions we were asked to stop and pose for our pictures to be taken by an accompanying photographer, we had no time and interest (because of fear of falling) to look around to examine all the formations nature built over millions of years. After the walk we were given lunch, which was characterized as "gastronomic experience" that consisted of some of the worst, I mean worst, Mexican food, we ever had - as I said earlier we go to Cancun often and spend there at least two months a year and know what is good, fair, and bad Mexican food. The trip to the parking lot was even worse as our mood had become quite bad. The bottom line is take very positive TA reviews with a grain of salt and if you are not a typical tourist who would be perfectly happy with a can of XX and any activity that would break the monotony of your beach days, but serious about nature, culture, and good food my advice is "skip Rio Secreto!" Any of the Mayan sites will offer a far more rewarding experience.

Beautiful Underground World. This was an unexpected fabulous tour! We didn't really know what to expect or how difficult it would be, but it was absolutely worth it. We had a fabulous guide, Victor, who was not only knowledgeable about the caves, history etc. but he was able to guide a group of people through some semi-strenuous and physically demanding terrain inside the caves. The process and information about the excursion is well documented in other reviews, but I wanted to add a short review to encourage people to see this. It's magnificent and I will definitely go again!

Great experience. An amazing place. Very adventurous and lots of great sites. You can see the way they are trying to preserve the natural side of it and not make it too touristy. Def not overcrowded and small groups of 8-10 people. It was a great feeling walking in the cave and swimming in the natural underground water to get around. Our guide was very helpful and knowledgeable. We enjoyed every moment of it and despite it being a lot of money I feel it's worth it to help preserve it.It can be a bit commercial with the photo side of it and pics are pricy but I understand the need for preservation and we bought just the one.I liked the lunch included after but can be not to everyones taste as not a great variery.The 2 things I would suggest though are first of all there wasn't a lot of time to take in some of the magnificent sites down below as we had to keep up with the rest and didn't stop a lot. Maybe make the tour 2 hours long and get to take in some of the beauty of the place. Second of all, there are 3 different cave systems for the public and we only get to do one of them without being able to choose. I highly reocmmend having the option of the cave or maybe offering a package doing all 3 caves or 2 of the 3. All 3 have different things to offer.I would highly recommend this even if you're not too adventurous it's not too hard. Def a must see and perticularly if you are ingterested in natural preservation.

A Natural Gem. My husband and I visited Rio Secreto on our trip to Cancun in February and had a great time. We appreciated getting outside of the touristy Cancun to enjoy some of the beautiful natural surroundings. The overall operation was well run and we enjoyed our tour guide. Seeing the largest underground semi-dry cave was a special experience (and we even bought a picture to share). It was nice to be active, though the excursion was not too physically demanding. This is really good for all ages.

excellent experience but expensive. This tour was amazing! the cave experience was awesome and our guide Victor was great. This tour is fairly demanding physically so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who has problems with balance or hiking. The only drawback was cost. We paid almost $200 us for 3 hours and they don't allow cameras in the caves. You can purchase their photos for $35 for one picture or $89 for a package. We paid for the package because this was a once in a lifetime experience.

Best excursion in the Yucatan. My wife and I went here for our first excursion and it ended up being the best excursion we went on ( we also did dolphin swim and Xel-ha, both were awesome but in a different way, this was more interesting and awe inspiring) Our guide Yayo, was amazing, the sites were phenomenal and the service for lunch and beyond is outstanding! Hands-down the best and most exciting and interesting thing to do in all of the Yucatán. Plus everything was provided (helmet, headlamp, water shoes, wet suit and life jacket). The whole experience was simply breath taking. Enjoy the Xtabentun at the end, it puts tequila to shame Keep it up Yayo and the team, your doing a fantastic job!

Unbelievable and humbling. Absolutely surreal experience. We wanted to do something other than snorkel or zip-line, and chose Rio Secreto as it seemed like a quiet spot to go. I am very humbled by the beauty that lives below us, formed by millions of years of change. The caves are serene, a bit creepy, and SO majestic. The staff were extremely friendly and helpful. The ride from the main entrance to the cave system was very bumpy, but well worth it!Highly recommend this as an excursion with your all-inclusive visit, or just a side trip if you're ever in the area.

A top highlight of my Caribbean cruise. An absolute blast on this adventurous excursion. After our ship docked in Cozumel many had shore excursions or activities right there. For many of us our trips were still a short ferry ride over to the Mexican mainland of Playa del Carmen. For those of us going to the Secret River we had a short drive into the jungle to get to our destination. After arriving we were greeted by very informative and helpful guides. And one note here for both men and women, leave modesty aside and be sure you wore a speedo for guys or a swimsuit for gals under your clothes since you first off need to strip down to those and take a quick outdoor freezing cold but quick shower. This is to keep the water clean of all oils, lotions, etc... There are separate changing and restroom areas for men and women and you have a private locker to store your valuables with your own key on a wrist bracelet. After this you are fitted into a wet-suit along with a skateboard/bicycle type helmet with a flashlight style light. You also get some water shoes to wear in case you don't have your own. After all that you are given another introduction about what you'll be seeing and we are all blessed in a ceremony by a medicine man. The entire walk from the main 'lodge' and changing area to the actual river entrance is about 15 minutes at most. The gripping ability of those water shoes is very important from here on out. Every group is limited to about ten people plus the main guide and the second guide usually brings up the real and also acts as the official photographer. Don't worry he gets pictures of everyone, and everything, even several one-on ones with you or your friend. Upon entering we are told to link hands and be turned to the same direction. The main guide will relay specific instructions which each relays to the next in line. For the river itself it is mostly only knee deep but in some instances you are told to push off and swim lightly and at one point to swim on your back. When walking you are told to take one step, plant it and then move your next foot. Not only for grip but also not to kick up the silt and make the water muddy. You are instructed not to touch the stalagmites/stalagmites or the sides so the off-and-on hand holding and slow procession helps maintain balance. You are constantly having to be aware of your footing as well as watching your head and back/shoulders due to low-hanging formations. At one point in a large room we all sat down in the water, turned-off our lights, and were silent for about two minutes. One of the most surreal out-of-body experiences I have ever felt. Absolute pitch blackness and silence. Throughout the guide points out the plant roots growing down as well some of the small sea life and, yeah spiders, that live here. The formations are mainly formed by mineral deposits (calcium and magnesium if I'm not mistaken) and the water is full of it. To demonstrate this, and also why we earlier had to take a shower, our guide held his flashlight under the water to illuminate it and then poked his finger in the water, and you could see the mineral deposits repel away, such as oil to water, or negative to positive. He then wiped his finger over his forehead and nose, re-dipped it, and the mineral deposits were like the first demonstration but on steroids. They were all gone instantly. Just goes to show they are serious about preserving the natural balance of this natural wonder. I believe the entire explored network is about 8 miles or so but our tour only includes about somewhat over a mile of it. We exit and hike back to the main lodge much the same way we came in. Upon exiting you change out of your 'explorer garb' and our group all meets and has a celebratory toast/shot, or two, of a local anise/licorice liquor. They have non-alcoholic available. You're taken to the photo/gift area where you can purchase what you want. For photos I believer it was $25 for one, about $75 for every photo, and somewhat like $125 for all the photos, a bottle of the liquor, and a souvenir shirt (they are nice). Then you are shown where lunch will be and you go to change back into your clothes and grab your stuff. Then you get a very nice local lunch with a lot to eat, you won't be hungry. You can then go back and pick up any pics you ordered, all downloaded onto your own CD and any other souvenirs before boarding your particular bus back to town.Now for an overview. I have been to beaches, and ruins, etc... before and I wanted something different I had never done before. This was certainly it. My description maybe sounded a bit scary of complicated. It is not. I saw people on groups which included children as well as older adults. Granted, you must have mobility and be somewhat agile, and not get claustrophobic, but almost anyone can do this. It is a bit of a workout, but not exhausting or strenuous. It almost reminded me of a corporate team-building event. When holding hands you are entrusting yourself to pretty much a complete stranger to give you guidance and help you get through it. Like I said both younger kids as well as older adults were as well. I myself have been through basic military training back in the day, and this was nothing like that. It was an absolute fun time where everyone helps everyone else enjoy the day. Bravo to all the people involved in making this the best offshore excursion of my Caribbean cruise.

It was amazing. My daughter and I went on this excursion and we really enjoyed every second of this trip. It was beautiful. The water was cold at first but we quickly adjusted to it. The guide was very knowledgeable and very nice.

Rio Secreto Mexico Yucatan. Just back from a week in Playa del Carmen and the Rio Secreto excursion was fantastic. Swimming through the underground caverns was as breathtaking as the brochure looked.Guide had lots of interesting information to share. The route is pretty strenuous at times but the pace is slow giving recovery time and time to see everything surrounding you.Highly recommend you visit the Mayan underworld.

A unique and enjoyable experience. My wife and I visited Rio Secreto as part of an anniversary get-away, and we enjoyed the experience. Nowhere else have I seen a set of caves like these that are accessible to the general public. Here is what to expect:You arrive at a small parking lot off the highway. (It is well-marked and easy to drive to if you have a car, or you can pay more to have them pick you up at a hotel.) We waited about 15 minutes and watched a brief video about the caves before getting in vans for a 20 minute ride over bumpy dirt roads back to the cave area. There we took a cold shower (this is required to keep chemicals from sunscreen, deodorant, etc. from damaging the caves). Then they gave us lockers and gave us safety equipment (helmets, head lamps, wet suits, water shoes, walking sticks, and life jackets). The equipment was in okay but not excellent condition with holes in the water shoes (so if you have your own water shoes, you may want to bring them). Then we took a short walk with our guide and about 10 other people to the start of the cave exploration. The cave exploration consists of a combination of walking, swimming, and wading through a little more than 1 km of caves. The water was cool but not cold and the wet suits kept us warm. The hour or so that we spent in the caves was active but wasn't strenuous. (The guide said he had someone the week before who was 87 years old who managed to get through it, though he said she needed a lot of help.) The caves were beautiful -- truly stunning stalactite and stalagmite formations -- and the guide explained things along the way. (Definitely recommend using the walking sticks that they make available to you -- mine kept me from falling a couple times when wading through the caves.)After completing our pre-selected route through the cave, we returned our gear, dried off with towels that they provided, and got to see the pictures they had taken of us in the cave. (You could choose to buy the pictures or not.) Then they served us lunch. Food was decent and seemed to be reasonably authentic. After eating, we piled back in vans to return to the parking lot (others were returned directly to their hotels). All in all, we enjoyed the day and are glad that we included this in our itinerary. It takes most of a day to visit this attraction since it is a 1-1.5 hr drive to get there and takes a little under four hours at the site. If you drive, we would recommend visiting Tulum (35 minutes south of Rio Secreto and worth a quick stop if you have any interest in the Mayan civilization).

Titre: Amazing underground system. A group of us did the tour at Rio Secreto which had been recommended by some friends back home… We saw so many great comments on Tripadvisor that we decided to book it. We booked beforehand online and we asked to have a specific guide Benito only because he came highly recommended by our friends. We ended up having a private tour (there was six of us) so that was awesome. Benito was very informative, professional and funny. He told us about the story of one of the land owner, how this system was found in 2006. Supposedly he saw an iguana which hid beneath rocks. Some rocks fell down and splashed in some water. Realizing that there might be an underground river, he decided to explore further with a team that mapped out the cave. Benito said that they use less than 10% of the entire system to minimize the impact on this fragile eco-system. If my memory serves me well, the length of the cave is 33 km long and 26 meter deep. If you are in Playa, you need to see Rio Secreto because the access and the beauty of this place is like watching Discovering Channel or National Geographic.Thanks Benito for sharing your love, passion and knowledge!

Beautiful Place. We had a wonderful experience at Rio Secreto. It is breathtakingly beautiful and an amazing experience. Our tour guide Alex was wonderful. We went with our 2 daughters that needed some assistance at times and was right there for them and provided them with the assistance they needed and kept them right by his side at all times! He was very informative and this is an excursion we will never forget!

Loved it!. Great way to spend 1/2 a day! The trek down into the cave was sometimes a feat if you have any mobility issues (or even if you don't), but they have walking sticks available to help steady yourself. The water is amazingly clear and the cave is a real experience. We really enjoyed the 1 minute of silent floating...not a single sound or light! But don't worry, you have a head lamp on with your own light source at all times. Our guide was amazing and hilarious - he made the tour lots of fun. Note that sunscreen or fly repellent of any kind are prohibited to preserve the quality of the water. Also, the gravel road from the main hwy to Rio Secreto is VERY bumpy and motion sickness was an issue for sure.

Very interesting place to visit off the beaten path. We found this as an excursion on our cruise. We were ferried to Playa Del Carmen from Cozumel and then picked up in a van. We drove approximately 30 minutes to what seemed the middle of nowhere, down a bumpy road, but were told this was a "Mayan Massage" which made us laugh. Once we arrived we were greeted by our guide, whose name escapes me, but he was very personable and funny. We were taken to an area where restrooms were so you could change into your swimsuits, then taken to an area where a very primitive jungle like shower could be had. This was to remove as much of the oils from your skin so as not to disturb the natural ecosystem. We were then provided with water shoes, wet suits (an experience all their own if you've never put one on before) and head lamps. You are taken into the caves after walking down a jungle like trail to the area. The tours are done in small groups of about 10 which was perfect. We then entered the caves and began our walk through. The water was crystal clear, our guide was very informative throughout and was very concerned about everyone's safety. Our group worked together by alerting others to upcoming rocks, step downs and slopes. The caves are amazing to see. I feel that could be a little difficult for those with physical limitations and perhaps some who may be afraid of small spaces. There is some crouching down, some low ceilings, and swimming (doggie paddle) required as you go through. the final end of the tour requires some uphill climbing such as you would encounter on a hike in a wooded area. Tour lasts about an 1 1/2 hours. You are then provided with a meal which our consisted of Broth to which you could add chicken and rice, beans, veggies, etc. Very delicious. Overall a great experience that you should enjoy. I wish the pictures were less costly at the end. We only purchased one photo $25 or we could have purchased that entire tour for $89. We did not wish to spend that amount of money and truly wish they would have been more in the range of $50 for all of the pictures since they are downloaded onto a disc.

Rio Secreto is a fabulous experience. This is an amazing attraction of natural beauty and wonder. There is nothing quite like it that I have discovered anywhere else where it is possibel to experience being in an underground river first hand. Our guide, Deana, was exceptional. She was well-informed, personable and presented the information equally well in Spanish or English. We brought our grandchildren (7 and 9) and had no worries about their safety.

Great caving experience. Excellent opportunity to get a little taste of caves in a unique environment. If you have done caving before then this is probably not the tour for you - it is targeted at the uninitiated and general tourist - that said it is still fun. The company have set the whole experience up very well, with the different groups going off on different routes to give a feeling of being an explorer in a remote environment. The wetsuits, helmet and lights are in good condition - just don't be sucked into buying the $10 booties - they are part of the tour price and will be given to you to use when you get to the actual point of departure. Of course if you are worried about wearing booties that someone else has already worn then go ahead and buy them! The lunch at the end of the tour is satisfying and hits the spot. The tour guides are friendly, knowledgable and you are put in a group with a guide who speaks your language (english, spanish, french). Good experience and one that most could do.

Newly discovered secret of the past!. Recently rediscovered Cenote (cave) in 2006 has managed this natural wonder very well. The transportation our resort was comfortable and the driver Trino was delightful and informative during our transit to Rio Secreto. Once we arrived we were met by our guide Francis and brought through the check in process. We were given a locker to secure our personal effects in and a place to change into our bathing suits. After a quick shower to rinse off we moved through getting our water shoes, wet suit and safety helmet. The water in the caves is chilly 72 degrees F so take the wet suit!!!Off to the cave after a quick safety briefing, prior to entry we were treated by a Mayan Shaman to be blessed. The cave was wondrous and a must see! There are three routes in the cave system we went to the Palace and I hear tell that Supremo route is even more beautiful. There in no photography allowed by the tourist in the caves. The do have a photographer assigned to the group and of course the photos are available for a modest fee. We were served a lunch after we had changed into our dry clothes, recommend that you bring a change of clothes. After lunch we were brought back to the check in area to meet up with our transportation back to the resort. So in a nutshell we'd go back to check out one of the other routes!

A Breath Taking Experience. The Rio Secreto tour is a must when visiting the area, From the moment you arrive until the tour is over your tour guide goes above and beyond to make your experience wonderful. I would recommend this to anyone who loves explorer the underground wonders of the world. Worth the value I paid.

A must!. I cannot recommend this adventure enough. It is something you will remember for a long time. I think anyone from singles to families will have a great time on this tour. I pre-booked this tour online via Princess Cruises about a month before my sailing. Everything was arranged so that all I had to do was meet at the designated time on the ship and meet my fellow thrill seekers. After the 30 min ride over to Playa del Carmen from our Cozumel port, it was about another 30 min ride to the Secret River. Once there, we were fitted with wet suits, swimming shoes, and hard hat and flashlight. they have lockers for secure storage and this is included in your tour cost.After a short walk to the entrance of the cave, we enter and immediately begin to see the beauty of the Rio Secreto. Stalagmite and stalactite formations in all directions. Our guide pointing out blind shrimp and fish. We move along and the water gets deeper. You quickly realize why we have to swim in some parts. It gets deep and you can just float over to where you are going with a little steerage. Surprisingly the water is not cold..I think the wet suit helps. There is a lot of calcium in the water which is cool and the water is extremely clean.We reach one point and everyone sits in a designated spot. Our guide says ok, everyone turn off your lights. It was completely peaceful and serene...and totally pitch black. Lights back on and we head on for a bit more.The entire time spent in the cave was about an hr and a half. And it was totally worth it. After we got out of our wetsuits and dried off, we were treated to include lunch prepared on site. Amazing food. Great people.You have ample time to buy photos of your time in the cave or lay in one of the hammocks, as I did. After the ride back to Carmen we had time to do some shopping before catching our ferry back to Cozumel to the ship.Definitely book this excursion if you haven't before. I would even venture to say that anyone with slight claustrophobia should be okay on this tour as I did not get a sense of that. The cave is pretty wide and the lights help.You will not be disappointed. This reminded me of fun times with my dad and family back in my childhood when we would do this in the USA.

Very cool place!. This place is awesome by itself! They make you feel a profesional putting you your diving suit, helmet and lintern! They explain very well everything and it's quite an adventure! Don't forget to bring shoes!!! and not be claustrophobic!

Breathtaking!. This was an amazing experience...I can't even compare it to anything I've every done, it was simply amazing. Our tour guide, Alejandro, obviously loves what he does and he made the experience that much more enjoyable for us. We are so happy we ended up booking this excursion last minute on a rainy day...it ended up being the highlight of our trip to Playa!

Amazing Secret River. We really enjoyed this excursion! We took a ferry to Playa del Carmen and then got in vans to the site. Raful was our tour guide. We had a group of 8. We washed off in a cold shower, put on wet suits, life jackets, and a helmet with a light and walked through the jungle for 5 minutes to the ceynotes entrance. It was stunning! The water was "refreshing" (cold at first) but you got used to it. The caves were beautiful, and we got to see some special cave fish, shrimp, and some bats. At the beginning during our walk through the jungle, we got to participate in some Mayan respect ceremony. It could have been alright, but it was really awkward and phony feeling. I would recommend getting rid of this piece and just sharing about the ritual.Raful was very enthusiastic and informative. You could tell he cared about the cave and the story behind it. He also did a great job on keeping an eye on all the participants, making sure we were all safe and comfortable.The 4 stars is because of the pictures. You can NOT take your own camera into the cave (which we knew before) and is smart because you need your hands free. We had to pause many times for the camera guys to take our pictures, which was fine, but turned annoying. We had planned on purchasing a picture since we couldn't take any, but once we got out, we learned that ONE picture cost $25, and then the packages got larger and more expensive. We didn't think it was worth that much. For all the stops ad picture taking, there were only about 10 pictures of us at the end, and maybe only 3 we actually liked.Afterwards, Raful and our group stopped to take a shot of their version of tequila. They provided water for those that don't drink. We then had a lunch together, which was yummy. They had a hibiscus tea, chicken tortilla soup, stew chicken and potatoes, and many other sides to try! It was buffet style so you could help yourself.This excursion takes almost the whole time you are in port, but afterwards, we got to spend about 30 minutes in Playa del Carmen before catching the ferry back to Cozumel. We enjoyed looking around the places there and finding good deals.The experience is irreplaceable and we couldn't find anything else like it elsewhere! All other cave tours were just tubing and less interactive and adventurous.

Most amazing thing you can do in Mexico!. Underground river are absolutely amazing. The chance to swim and experience this should not be passed up at any cost. We enjoyed it very, very much and would do a longer tour in different caves next time we have the opportunity! So amazing the see the beauty of nature is its natural forms. Our tour guide was ANDY he was absolutely amazing!! We enjoyed a Mexican style lunch in the caves as well. All around amazing experience!! So glad we had the opportunity!

Very disappointed. Poor value.. Not pleased. They took many photos of us, but we could not take our own. They then charge you $25 for a single photo. A complete rip-off. We now have no photos of our day. The lack of food options ruined entire tour. Rice, beans, and fruit. No meat, no chicken. I will not return or recommend.

Fun, unusual excursion. We had already done the stingray city and we're looking for something else in Cozumel.This was a fun little adventure. We got on a ferry right on the cruise pier. The ferry ride was an adventure. We had rough seas which made for bouncy ride, several folks got sick on the ride (they had seasick bags). We then had to ride to the caves. This was quite a ride over some very uneven roads. Finally after getting there, we got in our bathing suits, took a shower and slipped into wetsuits and vests (all included). The tour itself was down into the caves, walking through the underground river and also swimming in it for some time. It was not the most beautiful cave I have ever seen, but it was really cool to walk in the water and lay back in the water underground.They did not allow pictures in the cave but had a photographer as you went along. We did buy the pics at the end.There was a light lunch at the end, not much but OK. Then another bus and ferry ride back to the cruise ship. We were actually late returning but since we booked it through the cruise line they had to wait on us....

This excursion was one of the highlights of our Cruise!. Recently visited with Cruise excursion from the Norwegian Jewel.This was a fantastic opportunity to not only see but to EXPERIENCE this natural wonder.This 90 minute tour is unlike anything else we've ever done! In a wetsuit with a group of 8 and a tour guide you get to swim and crawl through and truly experience the underground river and the amazing underground limestone formations.Our guide was amazing. Yoryao did a great job of guiding us through this experience.We paid $99pp for this experience including ferry transportation from Cozumel, the tour, an after tour toast with a Mayan liquor (which we purchased a bottle of) and an authentic Mexican lunch. Very much worth the price we paid!Helpful hint: take the walking stick they offer... you'll be glad you did!

Awesome experience!. We rented a car and drove to Rio Secreto, and it was awesome! The highway is great, and well kept. The staff gives you a quick training video, and I bought some Rio Secreto water shoes (I still have them, and used them on other warm vacations). The first stop is at a local mayan who performed a mayan ritual. We all went in, and had a really great time. It would have been nice to bring our own camera, but oh well. We still purchased the CD after the tour. That would be my only issue. The guide was awesome, and I particularly liked it when we all turned off our lights, and kept quiet. What a peaceful experience. We never get to feel this quiet anymore. I bought a t-shirt and brought back long lasting memories.
Excellent experience. I and my wife went for this trip in Feb 2015. It was totally worth it. The tour guides are amazing. Worth giving it a try specially if you have even a little affection to nature

Great adventure to do on a cold day. This adventure was amazing! Groups were nice and small this allowed our guide to explain things better to our group and it felt like a more personalized experience. Sad we could not bring our gopro to take our own pics as at the end we found out it was $20 per photo or $125 for all of the photos. Was a great time otherwise and will have great memories from this trip

Great tour for the whole family. This was a great tour for our family - ranging in age from 6 to 72. We enjoyed the walk through the jungle to the cave opening and got a kick out of the Mayan "ceremony" before entering the cave. My youngest was a little nervous about the dark and the cold water but once the tour started, like the rest of us, she was mesmerized. Our guide, Epco, was great. He clearly enjoys what he does and took the time to explain how the caves formed, were discovered, and so on.Of note - During the tour we were accompanied by a photographer who captured photos along the way. I know some people don't like this sort of thing and and think it is a rip-off but we really appreciated this. I certainly would not have been able to get as high quality photos and would not have wanted to risk ruining my camera in the caves. Glad we booked this tour and would definitely recommend it to family and friends visiting the area. Perfect "mini-adventure" for a variety of ages.

a-m-a-z-i-n-g.
