I've visited Rio Secreto twice and both times I've been amazed.I love the fact that they don't use artificial light in the caves, so it feels more like an adventure and it allows you to see the guts of earth just like they are.They provide all the equipment that you need: wet suit, shoes, helmet, light, etc. All you need to bring is your swimming suit...Keep in mind you'll need to walk and swim. Sometimes the water will be up to your ankles and sometimes it'll be deeper. Also, once the group is in the cave, there's no way back (there's only one guide per group), so if you get tired easily, or you don't like darkness or you're a bit claustrophobic, do yourself a favor and book another activity.The caves are very very beautiful and the guides do a good job in teaching you how stalactites and stalagmites are formed and how to protect them... and if you're familiar with the Mayan mythology, you just can't help thinking how close to the Xibalba you are.At the end of the tour they pamper you with a shot of a Mayan liquor and a nice buffet style meal- I highly recommend the tamales : )

One of the best tours we've been on. Our Tour Guide was Diana N. She was amazing and knowledgeable. We had transportation from our hotel to the tour and back. Once at the tour location, we were formed into small groups of 10 based on language (French, Spanish, English). They then transported you through the jungle on a VERY bumpy ride to the site where they provided wet suits, vests, water shoes and helmets with lights. They also give you a locker to store your items you will not be bringing. You cannot wear any perfume, lotions, sprays etc so they make you take a quick very cold shower. Everything is in Shade or inside so you do not need sunscreen. You also cannot wear any jewelry (prescription glasses are okay) and cannot bring cameras, not even waterproof ones, as they need to preserve the area and all these items can damage the natural area, not to mention some of the river water feeds into the drinking water of the Mexican natives. There are 3 paths to the river so each of our groups went to separate locations. We only ran into one small group once. This also means if we go back, we can ask for a different path, making it a new experience. (and we will go back). There is a photographer that follows your group taking many, not so skilled, photos that you can purchase at the end. As a photographer my self, I was not too happy with the photos we were presented, but i can understand why they do not want you taking your camera in. On the tour we had use of walking sticks that I needed as I am short and this greatly helped the hiking though the caverns. There was some swimming and walking through water as well. You had to pay close attention as to not get hurt/fall. The guide told us exactly where to step and what to look out for. She gave us history and science behind the river/caves and formations. We experienced complete darkness for a minute when they had us stand in a specific location and turn off all our lights. Something you think you have done, but trust me, you haven't. The walking through the caves lasted a little less than 1.5 hrs. At the end we were provided a small towel, and changed into dry clothes. I recommend bringing a change of clothes because afterwards were provided a lunch buffet in a lunch hall area. It consisted of local foods (fruit, rice, beans, cactus, soups, salads, etc.) as well as a shot (or two) of the local Mayan liquor which is a fermented honey, but more like a Sambuca than a Mead. There was beer and other snacks available for purchase as well, but they are not needed. We purchased the CD of Photos that you can view before buying. For $89 it contained all the photos of us, group photos, about 50 "stock" photos of the cave/jungle/animals that are gorgeous and we negotiated in a bottle of the liquor. Otherwise it was $25 for one photo or a package for $109 that included a shirt and hat.This is an amazing experience and I highly recommend it.
Luis is the best!!. This was a fun filled and extraordinary experiance! Luis is an excellent guide, Awesome caves and water so blue.. Beautiful

Wonderful experience. We had a small group with a guide as we travelled through the underwater caves. They provide everything you need. The only disappointment was the cost of the photos they take. $100 US
It is a good place but..... Take this tour a year ago and I still have the feeling that the ride was too fast for the guide attempts to prevent the group behind us will meet with us.

exciting and Fun. I went to Rio Secreto when it first opened. One of the best tours I have ever taken. Under ground cave and ponds. they give you the proper wet suit and helmet with light. they bless the tour as you enter the cave. Then they feed you a healthy lunch when it is all over.

Breathtaking!. We were on this tour Feb. 9th and had a wonderful time. We received a wetsuit, water shoes, lifejacket and hardhat to wear. After suiting up we walked a bit through the jungle to a site where they preformed a Mayan ritual before heading in. What laid before us was breathtaking to say the least. After walking the river and swimming in the pools we climbed out to enjoy a very nice luncheon. The only negative in the entire trip was the fact that they do not allow camera's at all and the cost of their pictures is ridiculous!!! Not one person in our group purchased a single picture because of the cost! So here we had this wonderful experience and nothing to remember it by.

Rocky Road Ahead. The Rio Secreto experience was different than other cenotes we visited in that the majority of the tour was walking with very little swimming. The price was $75 US per person and the group sizes were large and you waited on site until ten guests had paid to form a group. The guide was knowledgeable, the equipment provided was top quality and included a towel to dry with, but we found that the water was not as crystal clear as many of the other cenotes we visited and so it was difficult to walk as you could not see where you were going, even with the head lamp provided. We did not see many fish, but the guide did point out a large spider and we definitely appreciated the Mayan blessing ceremony that preceded our entry to the cave. My recommendations would be: be prepared for a long van ride to the site, arrive early as by noon there were lots of people, possibly bring your camera as far as the lockers where you get equipment, be prepared for a lot of stopping for photo shoots and a long walk through the jungle to access the cave. I felt that the photographer took away from the sanctity of the experience and would recommend asking for a smaller group size and no photographer if we were to visit the site again. In comparison to the other attractions at Tulum, including several cenote visits, this one was the least value for our money.

Step into the underground river. Took the 4 hour morning tour with nine family members. They supplied us with water shoes, wet suits , life jackets and helmets, wish I had my own wet suit and shoes. Carlos our tour guide was an awesome young man with a world of info as he led us down into the caves and river. It's an amazing site to see.with rock formations millions of years old, crystal clear waters and trees that send roots down 90 ft to tap into this water source. They also let us connect with some Mayan culture,before and during tour. There are some tight spots to walk around and down , but safety was first for Carlos . The headlamps and flashlights of both Carlos an d the photographer created some awe inspiring moments . Photographer follows you the while tour and takes some awesome pictures ( $109.00 us for about 70 pictures on flash drive, or a group one for $25). They have 4 different caves to visit so you can return and have a whole new experience . We had a shot of a Mayan drink after and then lunch(it was just ok). Great day for 129.00

Educational and so beautiful. We were there last Thursday. Took the Colectivos there from the Grand Bahia Principe and it took about 30 minutes and cost $3.50 USD each (+$79 USD entry fee which includes the wetsuit, head geer with headlamp, wet shoes, flotation vest and meal at the end), rather than a $109USD, so we saved about $23 each..so up to you but really but easy to do and very safe. We were only about 6 in our tour and our guide was Diana and she was amazing, a lot of fun and so energetic and was able to answer all questions we had. We had a lot of fun. The caverns are very beautiful, it is an experience to live in itself and am unable to put what was felt in writing but we highly recommend it. We got to swim quite a ways also but even if you cannot swim not a problem as the flotation device will assist you. The only negative point are the costs for the pictures which was $25 for only one (REALLY) and $79 for 19, this is a scam in my opinion as they refuse you bring your own camera. Although they claim it is not theirs...YEAH right. So, we did not buy one. Still recommend the tour w/o pics :-)

Awe-inspiring!. There is one word that describes Rio Secreto in my experience: Awe-inspiring!The beauty you will witness as you visit this underground system is spectacular! We had a guide named Benito and he navigated us through the system with humour and a constant flow of information – what a teacher! And a very passionate guide. He encouraged two young kids, who did not want to do the tour, to at least try it. Let me tell you; by the end of the tour they were raving about the awesomeness of what they had seen! This was my first time ever visiting a cave and it left me in Awe…We were at 20 meters underground, walking and swimming in pure, crystal-clear water so clear that the water is blue and the bottom extremely white. Surrounded by thousands and thousands of geological formations such as stalactites and stalagmites etc.My awe-inspiring moment came during the silence. At one point during the tour, Benito made us sit in a circle and shut off our lights. We remained in silence and in complete darkness for a few minutes. In this all-encompassing darkness, where we disconnected from the outside world, I felt an intense connection with Mother Nature’s womb. Words cannot express what I felt, the connectedness with all that was present within me and around me. This was a very inspiring experience, one I will never forget! Useful info: I brought my own water shoes and wetsuit. They do offer shoes and a wetsuit but I was glad to have my own as some people in our group complained about the smell of their wetsuit and that some water shoes had holes in them.You can buy water shoes at Rio Secreto for 10$ (US)Xtabentun: you can taste this local liquor of Honey and Anise once you finish the tour… its delightful!ENJOY!!!

It really is the Amazing Secret River. This was by far the greatest cruise tour I have ever experienced. It included a ritual to the Mayans asking permission to enter onto their land. After that our guide Julio lead us underground to a river cave where he explained everything we saw in great and knowledgeable detail. The water was crystal pure and the formations beautiful. Every effort is made to maintain it in it`s natural state so you are asked to shower before you enter and not to touch anything while in the cave unless instructed by your guide. Following the tour you stop at a pavilion for a shot of a Mexican liqueur that had an Anise flavor with your guide .After you are changed back into your clothes, you go to another pavilion and have a delicious meal with your guide. The whole experience was just fantastic and I can`t imagine not seeing it if you had the opportunity.
An Absolute Must See. Rio Secreto is breathtaking. A voyage underground into a cavern where the water is so pure and the formations are "magical".

Wow. Wow what an experience Alberto was our guide through these caverns VERY knowledgeable and knew what he was talking about. Answered all question and made sure we were all comfortable. He is someone who enjoys his work, he is very educated but like cave exploring and it shows. Well worth every bump in the road and the cavern!

Very Good!. We booked this trip from our Carnival Cruise ship that moored in Cozumel. This was the highlight of our cruise vacation. Our guide was Alfredo and it was obvious that he was totally enthralled with what he was doing. We wore swim suits, and were given the option of wearing wetsuits (which i recommend), a helmet with light and a life jacket. There are multiple paths in the cavern so each group is kept to about a dozen, and we did not see any other group during our tour. It is a very neat expierence. For the most part the water was not so deep as to require swimming but we had a couple places that were over our head, but the life jackets make it such that you do not need to know how to swim. The path we were on was flat but uneven, so if walking is an issue this won't work well. We were in the cave about an hour then had lunch. Alfredo warned me that the green salsa 'is pure hell" pure habeneros. It was pretty hot.To sum up, if you enjoy visiting caves, this excursion is worth the effort.

Great experience. We booked this as an excursion from our all inclusive resort. What a great experience. It started out pretty canned but by the time we were in our group of 8 it was all good. Epco was our guide and we would highly recommend him. He is very friendly and knowledgeable. Definitely would recommend this tour experience!

Your life is NOT complete without visiting this world wonder. Just a few minutes south of Playa Del Carmen, Rio Secreto is a fairly new attraction and only discovered within the last 10 years. It is an underground cavern with areas filled with fresh water. The entire tour is very well organized. You arrive and fill out paper work, watch a short video presented in English, Spanish and French and then are given all the required gear (wet suit, aqua shoes, life vest and lighted helmet). They provide lockers for your personal items and towels. The groups are small to protect the area from damage. Each group has a guide, who is knowledgeable about the cave, Mayan history and about efforts to protect these geological formations from being destroyed. Our tour guide was “Ro”. He was a delight and very knowledgeable. His enthusiasm was contagious. You start off with a “dry walk” thru an area and end within a seated space and a light show on the cave walls telling the history of mankind. Then we went and had a great breakfast, but I think if you are an afternoon group you will get lunch. After this, we were given our gear and then off to the cave where there was water. You have some areas with dry ground, some with a little water and other areas where you swim thru deep water. The brochures do show a good representation of what you will go thru. Along the way there is a photographer taking photos, which you can purchase at the end. I have seen many things in Mexico, both above and below ground and this by far was spectacular in a way I will never forget. I strongly encourage any able bodied (you need to be steady on your feet) person to see this. It has taken millions (I think) of years to create this world wonder and it would be a shame to miss it. The group who discovered and created this as a tourist spot has done and is doing a great job at preserving it. They are a very conscientious group with the sole purpose of preserving the local flora and fauna and various environment programs to protect this unique place on earth. It was kind of expensive but when you consider that there is no other place like this then it becomes a priceless experience. I know you will agree.

Great place to visit!. Beautiful tour, so glad to have been able to see it! The tour guide was so-so, kind of just left us at the end so we didn't know where to go, but was knowledgeable, and answered our questions! She was friendly, but not amazing.

Amazing experience. Great experience and we are glad we took the time to see this amazing attraction. Our guide Carlos was very knowledgeable and made it an great experience to see the caves in their unaltered state. A little pricey but worth it

Well done tour. We booked this tour through a Princes Cruise. We had to ferry to the mainland. Nice boat but if the water is rough it can be a problem for those who get sea sick. It was rough on our trip and people did get sick. Once on the mainland we were put on a van for a short drive on a paved road then onto a dirt road for about 15 minutes. Once you arrive they put you in small groups, then you meet your guide. They will set you up with a locker, wet suit,shoes and jacket. You take a quick shower to remove soap and oils from your body. Alex our guide took us through the caves and was very informative. It is a special kind of tour, You hike and swim in this tour. If you have difficulty walking on uneven surfaces this tour may not be for you. After the cave tour you hike back and check out the pictures the photographer has taken. They provided a delicious Mayan styled lunch.

A very unique experience. We visited here as an excursion while on a cruise with Carnival. I'd recommend it to anyone. We are not "caving people" and this is definitely the only way we'd ever see anything like this. The excursion takes all day, except for 45 min or so of shopping time in a relatively nice area just before returning to Cozumel. First we traveled on a boat with 200 other cruisers to Playa Del Carmen from Cozumel. Then we walked 3-4 blocks, where two groups of 7 of us got into a small van / bus and drove 10 min on the highway followed by 15 min on rough, bumpy, rocky roads leading into the jungle. I became seasick on the boat ride, the bus was not bad, just bumpy, they called it a "Mayan massage." Once we arrived, we were met by our guide (Luis) and issued wet suits (short legs, long sleeves), helmets with lights, and water shoes and a walking stick. If you have your own water shoes you may wear them, and the walking stick is optional. I think the stick would have been cumbersome but I am relatively fit and preferred to have my hands free. Then everyone was STRONGLY encouraged to visit the bathroom, as it would be 2 hours before you see another one and it's not good for the features in the cave and the river if you pee in it. Next we had to step under a (cool / cold) shower to wash off body oils, deodorant (skip it, don't even apply it that morning), any chemicals. I wore make-up on my face, my head didn't go under water and Luis didn't insist I wash it off. [One could even skip sunscreen, sit indoors on the boat, middle seat on the bus, then it's mostly shady at the site, then you go underground.] Part of the time in the cave you're in ankle or knee deep water, then there are short times where you float and "dog paddle" yourself through the spaces. Luis was careful to point out sharp projections in the rock formations where you might get cut. A photographer goes with you as no tourist cameras are allowed, plus it's relatively dark without the helmet lights. The photographer takes plenty of pictures of the group throughout the tour, then you can purchase photos after the tour. I heard someone say they bought one for $25, another paid $79 for 2 complete "sets" of shots. After the tour (approx. 1.5 hours) you get a "snack" which is indeed a large meal of authentic Mexican food. Then you travel with the group back to the port area in Playa Del Carmen, where we had 45 min to shop before boarding the small boat back to Cozumel. Upon arrival in Cozumel we were told to go straight to the ship, no time for shopping, though you do have to walk through a long duty-free shop to get there.All you need to bring with you is your ship card and ID to get on / off the ship, money for shopping, and a change of dry clothes. They give you a locker key (hubby wore it around his neck) where we put our personal belongings, they give you a small towel afterward. I didn't bring clothes and wished I had, I was still somewhat wet when I got back to the ship. Luis was great, full of information about the nature we were seeing and how the river affects and is affected by the local environment, and how to best navigate through the cave and the water. The whole experience was worth the price, I'd recommend it to anyone.

Rio Secreto - one of a kind experience!. What an amazing experience to walk and swim in this cave system with all these stalactites and stalagmites, crystal clear waters and pure peacefulness. Our guide Rafful did a great job. He was very knowledgeable and and was patient with us slower ones. I'm a heavy woman and needed help sometimes getting up or down steeper areas and was slower when the bottom of the river was uneven or couldn't see it. I was grateful for small breaks for explanations or pictures where I could relax a moment. Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend this for those with real problems walking or with balance. They really made our group ( of 7) feel like a family. There are lockers, wet suits, helmets and life jackets provided at no cost. We brought our own water shoes, but I think there was a $10US fee to buy some. You had to remove absolutely everything else except prescription glasses before entering the river (all jewelry, no cameras). The lunch provided was ok. The photographer took many beautiful photos. You get to go see them before lunch and decide if you'd like to purchase them. I bought a thumb drive (or you can get a disk) for $80US. Very expensive!! But, I really wanted something to remember this by. There's about 30 photos of our group with about 12 of them of me and my husband, plus an added 15 or so stock photos of the caves and animals/fish in the caves. You had the option to purchase one photo for $20US or a package with the CD, an album and a T-shirt for $130US.

Fantastic second time around!. This was my second tour at Rio Secreto, twice I had the wonderful guide BENITO!The first time I visited Rio was in 2013 with my family on the Carnival Cruise ship. We had just the most amazing experience. My second time around, I decided to come with my mother-in-law who is 72 years old and my kids who are 9 and 12. I had specifically ask for BENITO as a guide as I thought not only was he a wonderful guide but he was also very attentive to all. He treated my mother-in-law like she was his own mother. She had much difficulty walking and he personally made sure that she was well taken care of. Also one of my kids was kind of afraid of the water so he also walked behind BENITO. We absolutely recommend this activity for all the family and although this was my 2nd time around- I enjoyed it as much as the first time, if not more! Thanks for all Benito and we shall return next year probably to try out the third route.CHEERS to all your team!

Very Interesting. We booked this tour prior to leaving for Mexico because quite frankly, the pictures looked good and it seemed like a unique experience. Sure enough, it was unlike anything that we've ever done or seen. First off, a reminder to everyone.... DON'T BOTHER bringing a camera because they are NOT allowed. This was a bummer for us because we brought our GoPro with us with the intention of capturing some really fascinating displays of nature. The cave, the underground river, the stalactites, stalagmites were all so interesting. They were all a marvel to behold. Our guide made it more fascinating with his humor and anecdotes. At one point, he had us all turn our headlights off and we were in complete and utter darkness that we couldn't even see our hands in front of us. Very surreal. For non swimmers, don't fret because everyone gets a life jacket whether you want to or not. Most of the 1 kilometer or so of the tour was walking on uneven surfaces and the actual swimming.... well, floating really as the life jacket just makes you float to the surface, was very minimal. All the same, it was a great experience. The actual time in the cave was about an hour and a half but the total time of the experience (lunch, changing into wetsuits, etc) was about 3 hours or so.Though not spectacular, the lunch provided was good and adequate. Of course because a camera wasn't allowed, you have to buy the photos that they take of you during the tour if you want souvenirs from the experience. Kinda pricey but you have no choice.I highly recommend this tour as it is very active and captivating.

5 stars became 3 stars. PROS: wonderful experience IF you don’t get Benito as your tour guideNot too difficult if you are not rushednice cave sightings, especially if this is your first time in this kind of caveGood even if you are not a swimmerI would have given this 5 stars but i didn’t because of Benito. CON: the only con was that we got a really bad tour guide. However, this one thing ruined our entire experience. Benito was bossy, even to the other employees. He snapped his fingers at them and shushed them during the introduction in front of the customers. He could have asked them nicely.I have a different religion, so although I respected their intro prayer, and stood there politely, I didn’t repeat the first part of the prayer. I saw Benito glance at me and give me a scolding look. It was annoying and i felt like i was on a field trip as an elementary student.I was the last one to get a helmet and wetsuit, which was fine, but this means that i would be finished last putting it on, since I was given one when the others already wore theirs. However, even though he knew this, he told me that i had to hurry up. I HAD JUST received this wetsuit in my hand and he told me to hurry.I could honestly tell you that it was a very doable experience, and that it would not have made any time difference (in minutes) EVEN IF i had taken my time and went slowly at my own pace. he was rushing us because he felt he had to be on time. but i think this is just his personality. it wasn’t that difficult and everyone could still have finished on time even at our own pace. HOWEVER, because he was scolding us each minute, we felt stressed, rushed, and was prone to falling more because of the rushing. Benito kept telling the people in front of me to “keep up “ and pulling them aside and shaming them by saying “if you don’t keep up, it will be a problem.”Honestly, after finishing the adventure, there would not have been any problems even if we had gone at a slow pace. It is not a long route and we would have had Plenty of time. The same tour with the same customers could still have finished in the same amount of time AND enjoyed the experience, if it was with a DIFFERENT tour guide. it was not scary and it would have been so much more enjoyable if we were not scolded during the whole trip. I was jealous when I saw other tour guides smiling and laughing with their group. UGH what a waste of money and beauty. Overall, i recommend this, but just not with this tour guide.
Undeground Cave, worth the visit. I wasn't sure I would like this, but turns out I loved it. Really great guide and super interesting cave to hike and float through. Highly recommend it.
Amazing cave. Don’t miss it. It is a great experience and I highly recommend it.Photos are expensive but worth it. Ask for original photos, otherwise they only give you low res.

Highlight of our cruise trip. We booked this as an excursion through Princess and are so glad we did. It is a once-in-a-lifetime experience and we highly recommend this if you're physically able.Pros:- Our tour guide, Yayo, was perfect—possibly the best tour guide I've ever had. He was first and foremost knowledgeable but also patient, communicated well and conducted himself in the most professional way.- So fun! I usually get bored quickly, but we were in the cave for more than an hour and I didn't even notice. Between looking at the stalactites/stalagmites with wonder and swimming in complete darkness (only briefly), time flew by.- Well-organized. This place is a well-oiled machine, we never felt like we were waiting for someone, there was no idle time.Cons:- If you take a ferry in from Cozumel, be prepared for a very bumpy, nauseating 40-min ride. They said our trip was worse than usual and handed out barf bags "just in case." A few passengers made use of them but thankfully, the return trip was much more manageable.- The photos were terrible! They forbid guests to take cameras on to the tour (which I support) and had a dedicated photographer take photos of our group. We were let down when we saw the results: out-of-focused, blurry images that looked horrible. It was a disappointing end to an otherwise wonderful experience.Note: This excursion is not for everyone as it requires a moderate level of physical movement. There are a couple parts of the trail that are small and require crouching down and squeezing through small spaces.

Ability. We just returned from this tour and it was great , I'm a big guy awaiting knee replacement so the excursion was extremely painful to walk , climb ,up/down etc . I only say this because i would go every day if allowed we only saw 1 kilometer and there are 30 down there , absolutely a must for anyone who gets a chance to see this.

Great excursion!. My husband and I visited Rio Secreto on our recent trip to Playa Del Carmen. I highly recommend this activity as a nice change of pace from beach scene. The underground caves are absolutely stunning. It was completely unique from anything I had experienced. Our guide, Dianna was very informative. I found it interesting that the caves were only recently discovered in 2008. I recommend that if you have any mobility issues that you use the walking sticks provided. Uneven ground and low light could pose problems for some. It was a little dissapointing that you can't bring a camera though...

Fantastic Experience. We booked the excursion through our travel advisor in our resort. The booking process was fast and efficient. Unfortunately, the driver was almost 30 minutes late to pick us up. Once we finally arrived at the parking area, we had to hop on another van to the actual site 7 km away. Because we were late we had to miss the introductory video. We were quickly issued wetsuits and helmets with lights, and were offered beach shoes, but we had brought our own. Our guide Pablo took over and provided probably the most enjoyable 90 minute experience I have ever had. We started with a Mayan blessing to get permission from the Mayan Gods to enter, and then descended into the Mayan underworld. There was a lot of walking, mostly through water, and several spots where we swam in water that was anywhere from 3-10 metres deep. We turned off our headlamps at one point and got to experience the amazing quiet and total darkness of the cave. The only lighting in the caves is headlamps. We were in a group of 9 - 10 is the usual limit. My only issue was when I was bringing up the rear and couldn't see the cave floor because of the silt that the others had stirred up, and manage to fall twice, scraping both shins and a knee fairly impressively. They gave me first aid at the end, so no big deal. The food was pretty good. The facility, for being a fair distance inland on "interesting" roads was very well maintained, and the staff were very friendly and helpful. Note - if you are 6'4" like I am, you may find the low ceilings in some spots a bit challenging. Thank God for helmets! The only downside was that a CD of all the photos (about 15 or so) was $69 USD. Individual photos were $20 or $25 each, so we boought the CD. For some reason, people that were not in Pablo's group had to pay more. I highly recommend this experience and would do it again in a heartbeat.

So cool I would do it twice in a row!. TL;DR version:Awesome place, good equipment, no time wasted on waiting for anything, acceptable food, pricey photos, fun for everyone.Longer version:We were staying in Playa del Carmen, and on our first day we couldn't be bothered to drive to Tulum, or Coba ruins. But we thought that spending some time in a cave system would be fun. And it was.It's a close drive from Playa to the start point, where they gather people into 10-11 persons groups. Then it's a 10-20min drive through the jungle/forest. You get a wet-suit, a life vest, a helmet with a headlamp, and a walking stick. You can store your belongings in the free locker provided. Make sure the wet-suit is tight. They give you one that might fit, and it did work fine for the most of our group. But my wife had to ask for a smaller one, and we suggested to another girl in our team to do the same. Poorly fitted wet-suit will NOT keep you warm. The headlamps can't be adjusted, i.e. you can't adjust the angle otherwise than by moving your helmet up and down. If you ever had a Petzel headlamp, you will definitely feel the pain of using an nonadjustable lamp.The cave-walk takes about an hour. And there's a short swim involved. The life vest together with the wet-suit will keep you afloat. One person from our party can't swim, but was ok with us dragging her around in the water. So: swimming capabilities are not a must.You can't take any light and photo equipment, but there's a photographer following you around. The photos are ca. $20 a piece, or $75 for a set of perhaps 10 (on a cd, with some extra stuff). Might make sense if you're a bigger group. We looked stupid on the photos, so decided against it.After the cave part there is a buffet lunch (but first showers and changing back to your clothes), with some vegetarian options. Not mind blowing, but also not disappointing. After lunch we even had some time to swing in the hammocks. Then a bus right back to the meeting point, and it's over.Our guide was well informed, and quite nice, but nothing special. But she did make sure we don't waste any time, be it taking photos, or changing into the wet-suits, etc.All in all: excellent way to spend our time. Our non-swimming friend, and a 3 months pregnant lady did not complain, and in fact loved it. It might be a bit physically demanding for some, but unless you have a cast on your leg and have to use crutches, you'll be fine.

Excellent adventure. Amazing, incredible cave!! And our tour guide was excellent and very caring. I wish I could take my camera with me to the cave but I understand that it is for the best/safety. But I'm very happy about their photographer's photos! Nice job!
Magic!. This was my best experience of my life. So magic to be in the cave. Very beautiful! Good guide and food and liqueur afterwards! A must!

Fantastic tour!. I went on the tour a few days ago. I enjoyed it because it is unusual because you have to wear a wet suit and a lifepreserver .The cave has only been open since 2008 to the public.I am not a good swimmer but I made it through the cave with some help from my fellow travelers. You are given a walking stick to help keep your balance for the wet and dry part of the tour. My guide Irina was very helpful and knowledgeable. I had a private tour with her after the wet cave tour in another section of the cave.We given lunch and She explained the Mayan traditions and it felt spiritual and relaxing.

Good trip, for kids and families. We took this tour as we didn't want a all day thing, with ziplining and a million other things in it like all the other tours are around this area. We wanted to take our three and four year old boys who Quad at home. This was a good trip for them. Likely a bit boring for a experienced trail rider, but good for families and kids. The boys sat in front of us and we never went above 20miles in the ride so It was a good pace for them. The cave swim was great, but I wish there was more time spent there, we would like a tour that took you there for a hour or more and maybe had a light picnic or something included. The end of the ride I think all travelers were hungry but the kiosk only has pop. No snacks, chips etc to buy. I think there is a missed opportunity there for sure, for them to create more revenue. The pictures they take are a good price for the disk, $100 I recall. Also they don't allow bags or backpacks on the trail or sunscreen, for safety of the water but we were not told when we booked - so just be aware :)
Underground river. We explored an underground river with a 7-year-old kid and her grand-parents. It was great. Our guide what he was talking about.

Well organized. We booked this through Carnival Cruise lines. It was rated as "difficult" and it fit up to its rating. We docked in Cozumel, so we had to take a ferry across to the mainland, which was fine, but took about 40 minutes. Once on the mainland, we were met by representatives and taken to the nature reserve in a van. Once at the Rio Secreto site, we were given wet suits, helmets, water shoes if you didn't bring your own, head lamps and walking sticks (take a stick - they are helpful to keep your balance). There are lockers there to lock up your stuff. You are not allowed to take cameras of any sort - a photographer comes with you and then you can purchase the pictures on a CD at the end of the trip. We walk out on a root covered trail to the site of a Mayan who blesses us and does the smudging. Then we entered the cave - we were walking through many parts of it - knee deep, waist deep etc., but parts were quite deep and we had to swim. There was one part where we had to jump off a ledge into the deep water - very cool. We explored the caves for quite a while and learned about the geology and the history of the area. Our guide was very good. Towels were provided and outside showers too if you wanted once you came out of the caves. Afterwards, we all had a shot of something that tasted like sambuca to celebrate that we made it out unscathed! Lunch was provided - rice and beans and tortillas and fruit etc. It was okay. After lunch, we were able to literally hang out in some hammocks while we waited for our van to arrive. I bought the CD of pictures. They wanted to sell it to me for $79 but I talked him down to $55, so do not pay full price. The pictures are fantastic though - see one attached. We were driven back but then had almost an hour to hang out and/or shop before the ferry came. Not the best shopping here - I enjoyed it much more on Cozumel - but there was a free beach you could hang out on until your ferry time. Your guide will provide you with the ferry ticket and walk you to the front of the line. Well done. Highly recommended if you are physically able...

High adventure...underground!. Who knew caving could be fun AND spiritual? With our outstanding guide Pablo leading the way, Rio Secreto was the best of both.. and one of the best adventure tours I've ever taken. Go for it! TIP: opt for the walking stick; it'll help you maintain much-needed balance to navigate through the caves. Even experienced hikers use them, so I'm curious to know why they aren't part of the mandatory equipment..?

Best Experience of My Life!. Holy cow! This place was a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and I recommend it to EVERYONE!!! We were in a really fun group, and our guide was amazing! If you get the chance, I highly recommend you request Alfredo as your guide. This man lives, sleeps, and breathes CAVES, and it genuinely shows in how he conducts his tours! This tour will stay with you for the rest of your life!!!
nature and fun. loved the tour guides, they know their stuff and went out of their way to share it.Food was mediocre but I did not go for the food

Julian made our experience even better. I am a professional tour guide in Niagara Falls. When I take a guided tour, I ask a lot of the guides. Our guide, Julian exceeded our expectations. In short, everything in the park is as advertised. The jungle is lush and encompassing, the cenote is beyond description and the included meal was great.Julian knows every aspect of the park--geology, history and cultural. During our lengthy swim in the freshwater caverns (cenotes), we were thrilled by his narration and interaction. You need to be in reasonable physical shape to appreciate this experience. If you are going to Mexico, you should definitely see a cenote. If you are near Playa del Carmen, see this one and ask for Julian.
Perfect!!. I was there with my girlfriend. Our Guide Fernanda was worried about us we love everything. Mexicans and New Zealand must visit this place!

Excellent experience with a great guide. Rio Secreto is a gem you have to experience. We toured the cave in early November. We arrived at Rio Secreto after about a 15-minute ($150 peso) cab ride from Playa del Carmen. We arrived a little early, and were invited to relax in comfortable chairs outside until the presentation began. The tour starts with a recorded overview presentation, then there is a short hike over land to get to the cave. We were in a small group of 6, along with our guide, plus a guide in training, and the photographer. Unlike cave tours that follow a paved walkway at major caves in the US, here you'll don a wet suit, a life vest, and cave helmet with a light. The gear was in good condition and in a broad size range (we are 2X and 3X, and had suits that fit comfortably). The floor of the cave is covered in water, and it is often quite uneven. Note that if you have any foot problems or balance problems, the tour might be difficult for you. The tour was mostly walking and occasionally swimming a short distance, although our guide told us this can vary by year and season. Our group chose to join hands in a line to steady ourselves, and that was very helpful in traversing the uneven floor. Walking sticks are also provided as an option, but I’m glad we chose the hand-holding option. Our guide, Nunes, did a fantastic job of helping us to navigate through the cave, stepping, high and low, over rocks, and under formations. We opted to buy the photograph package, both because the pictures were very good and to support the organization. I’m very happy we made that decision; we love the pictures and shared them with family and friends. Although some have said the water was cold, we found it more refreshing than cold. (We're from Wisconsin, so that may have something to do with it.) I would definitely recommend this tour.
Fun and educational. We had an experienced tour guide, Julio, he really cared about preserving the underground rivers and it was a really good tour. I would highly recommend it!

Wow!!. I have been to Mexico many times and was convinced there was nothing else I wanted to see, BUT I WAS WRONG. Our tour operator recommended we do this excursion and the only criteria he said was you needed to be able to walk. As a person who is a little unsteady on their feet, I found this a little more challenging than I was led to believe. What a spectacular sight to see nature at its finest. Rio Secreto provides all the gear you need so you only have to take a bathing suit. It really is a sight not to miss.

Once in a lifetime experience!. Phenomenal! The Rio Secreto is one of the top 3 experiences I've ever had in my life. Our guide "Ro" was absolutely wonderful. He truly loves what he does and it shows. He was excited to share this wondrous natural gift of Earth and the Mayan/Mexican culture with us. As far as touristy vacation experiences go, the facility was a haven, the staff felt like family and the food was the best we'd had the whole trip. This experience will stay with us our whole lives through. Thank you.

Never seen anything like it. We were told that this is a tour that needs to be experienced. The photos are great but don't give you the full feel of what you are going to see. They are right. What an amazing showcase of nature. I loved floating down an underground river with stalagtites nearly scraping my helmet. It's a very up close and personal tour with nature.

History adventure science mystery all in one..... Julio is an amazing guide. He took us through the tour and stopped frequently to give insight to the underworld of the Mayan culture. Crystal clear water, limestone rock formations, all of this appears to come out of nowhere. The short ride to the cavern does not give you any clue as to what you are about to see. The lunch and photo's top it all off. Older folks and anyone who can't walk very well may need to use the cane or walking sticks they provide. I would do this attraction again and likely try to do the private long tour we were told about.

Fantastic!. Rio Secreto was much more than we expected. We have done river caves before, but this one was different. The Mayan connection, the ecological component and the spectacular cave formations made a perfect package. Make sure you take a walking stick! The limestone formations are not slippery, but the paths throughout are uneven and steep. The walking stick was a lifesaver. Out of all our excursions, this one hits the top. Dont miss it if you are able bodied and healthy!

Unforgettable experience. we had extraordinary experience - I went with my kids, ages 6 and 9. Kids loved it. It was an adventure - something we've never done before. It was amazing - i highly recommend it to everyone. We'll go back when we go back to Mayan Riviera. We were all in awe.

Awesome Adventure. Fun, but a bit challenging for3 overweight seniors. Beautiful limestone formations. Water was cool, but clean.You are supplied with water shoes, wet suit, life jackets and helmet with light. Guide, Epco was informative. Lunch was good, all vegetarian. Pictures are expensive, but good quality.Definitely recommend!

Was fun. Actually went there in 2012 and really enjoyed it. I love caves so this was up my alley. The guide was great, food after and bought some cool pictures. I would definitely go again with friends that have not.
Cave excursion. Rene was the , "best tour guide ever"!!Fascinating views.very bumpy bus ride to cave entrance but part of the showany money spent goes to preserve the area so well with it

Fun time in Rio Secreto. At $80 US dollars it is worth the price of admission. It's cheesy to buy the pictures but they say the money goes back to help protect the environment and educate the children, los ninos.Nico, our tour guide helped us get into our gear, wetsuits,a lot easier getting on than off, ladies watch your bathing suits, helmets, and wet shoes. You need the helmet especially if you are 6'9" tall and some of those stalactites hang a bit low. They do not hurt if they break. Try not 2 break em, the environment you know.Nico explained how all the water of the Yucatan flow through the limestone and are all connected. I am glad we went. It was a great experience.

An unforgettable and unparelled experience. This adventure takes you into a cenote in the Yucatan. After a mayan priest blesses you . You get to go into a cave swimming through the secret river and viewing cave formations . We've been to dozens of underground adventures but nothing quite like this and they fed us after the adventure.

Fantastic Cave Adventure . With great apprehension I agreed to go on this crazy excursion. We were a party of eight which included kids ages 11-15. The worst part was the ferry ride to playa de Carmen. It was very rocky even though the sea was not rough. I think the ferry had a design flaw that caused it to rock. I recommend sitting up top to avoid the fumes that consume the bottom cabin. Once you get to rio secreto the fun begins. They fit you in the gear you need. I recommend the wet suit. Off you go walking stick in hand. The cave is amazing and the guide Alexandro was great. After the caves you are fed a lovely meal. They also take pictures throughout your adventure which is expensive but well worth buying it.

Other than the no photo policy and looong wait to return.... I was so excited about this trip, so much so that I bought an underwater camera. Well, nothing in what I read indicated that NO cameras were allowed. I understand its a way to generate more $$, but you MUST make that very clear so as to not annoy your patrons. Others who were on our tour were also quite annoyed. Not to mention the ridiculous cost of the pictures. 1 for $25!?? Really?The tour itself was amazing. I loved every minute of this experience and would suggest all add it to their bucket list.Our tour guide was great, until after the tour was over and he disappeared, leaving 10 of us waiting over an hour for our return van. Lastly, be prepared for a very long ride.It's a great tour with just a couple of "bumps".

One of a kind experience. Our family would rate this their number one experience on our maya riviera vacation. It was thrilling to swim in these breathtaking caves and learn about this unique ecosystem Yes, it is expensive at 80$ per person, but the tour is limited to 10 people at a time and you feel the experience is yours alone. Yes, the price tag for photos is unusually high and we were not prepared to shell out an additional 79$ for the CD.

Second Rio Secreto visit. I toured this cave in 2012 and again this year. I rate both visits as "most excellent!" I learned this year that there are 3 different routes through the cave, and I have now taken two of them. For those who enjoy caves, this should be at the top of your list of things to do. I don't think I've been in another cave with so many stalactites and stalagmites. The guide was well-informed and socialized well with the group. The lunch afterward was tasty - I had chaya for the first time.

Beautiful. The tour was great both informative and inspiring. Our guide, Gorge, was fun and made the trip personable. It was the only excursion we schedule on our 14 day cruise with the ship. It was worth the $118.00. I was not expecting great food after our adventure in the caves. Yummy.

Cave swimming. Booked this attraction from the Princess cruise line on a one day stop at Cozumel. Started out with a ferry ride to Playa Carmen and was met there by the local guides. Short and bumpy(mayan massage) van ride to Rio Secreto. After a brief information about the place and was grouped into 10 people we kicked off. The water was cool but they provided the wetsuits and helmet lights. The place was amazing!! Not enough words to discribe whats inside, and the experience alone was worth the money. Even though the place seemed packed at the lobby, we did not encounter another group inside the river caves. Nico was our guide and was very knowedgeable and had the patience to deal with us as a group. I came with my family with 2 young kids ages 8 & 10. My only gripe about this place was the food. It was served as buffet style and had very few choices.

Amazing place but it was a lot of work to experience. This was an expensive, once in a lifetime experience but I can’t give it 5 stars. It was a harrowing drive from the hotel to the site where we waited for the shuttle down a 5K bumpy road to the river. The check in process was smooth, we were issued wet suits complete with a scorpion, rubber shoes, etc. We were introduced to our guide Raul who was excellent. He was knowledgable, fun and kept the tour rolling nicely. There were 12 of us in our group and despite the huge number of tour groups we didn’t see anyone else on our tour. The caverns were amazing but this was not an easy walkabout. I was beat by the end of the tour. Even the kids were tired. The surface was very uneven with many opportunities for a sprained ankle. The tour lasted about an hour but when they came to sell us the photographs we got pissed and disappointed. They wanted $83 for a set or $25 per photo. This was ludicrous considering their costs. What was more annoying was that the photos were quite good and would be a memorable item. No matter how good they were I was not going to be ripped off. They offered a traditional “gastronomical” meal which was included in the price and quite enjoyable. We then spent another 1-1/2 waiting for buses back to the staging area and back to the hotel. This was a very cool experience so if you can deal with the cost, an entire day of your vacation then I recommend you do it.

A must list to do. if I could only pick one place to go , this is it, You are going back in time ,So much more to discover in the caves ,This is a new find in 2007 and is very rare to see.The staff are great , Try to be in smaller groups 8 or less Bring water shoes and no pictures in side caves , They have their own staff

Fun and safe adventure. really interesting tour, the guide was very knowledgeable and wasn't racing to the end. we stopped in several places so the guide could tell us about that part of the caves. I would do this again!The only tip i have is to take a supplied walking stick, i found it difficult to maintain balance and the limestone is really sharp, had a few cuts on my hands.

Amazing experience. This was such a fun and unique experience. Rio Secreto is beautiful and a great adventure. You must go here if you are visiting Playa Del Carmen. My only complaint is the exorbitant prices for the photos that they take. That is a huge rip off.

Surprising beauty. The brochure the hotel gave us did not do Rio Secreto justice. It was absolutely amazing to see caverns so up close, something that would never happen in the U.S. The guide really knew what he was doing, fully explaining the formations. Definitely a Secret in the Playa del Carmen area and 100% worth a trip.

Breathtaking. This cave system is truly amazing. I can't even begin to explain how amazed I was. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because of the price. It is extremely expensive and you can't bring any cameras in. Then it was an additional $80 for pictures are the end. Bonkers. It should be included in the admission price. Especially since they wouldn't let you take your own.

Set aside a few hours for a unique and educational experience. We considered visiting many of the caves during our visit to PDC. We chose Rio Secreto based on the Trip Advisor reviews. The tour is well run and the caves are spectacular. The give you everything you need, wetsuit, water shoes, life jacket, all in good repair and clean. The guide was knowledgable and entertaining. The only thing you need to be prepared for is the long bumpy ride from the parking area to the cave entrance. I would not recommend this to anyone that has mobility issues, there is a lot of walking including stairs and uneven ground.

Impressive and well organised. We took this tour from a package on the cruise ship. It Highly interesting and just plain "wow" ... The more you walk and swim in these cavers the more you are impressed. The guides (ours was Alina) know their subjects inside out and you can feel their passion about it. The physical challenge is light (I consider myself in good shape) and just enough to wake you up from these days at the beach doing nothing! After this marvellous experience, a light lunch was served (basic ... but enough to sustain until you go back to the ship). Obviously and as usual the pictures are a catch ... after asking for 79$ for all of them, the photographer tells you that he could do "a special price for you" at 60$ ... so negotiate and ... you know: these pics worth the memories they will bring back to you!Great experience that I recommend

Amazing day out. We had read about this trip in the Mexico Rough Guide and we were so glad we took the time to do this. The experience was incredible and made even better by our knowledgable guide Fernanda, who spoke the tour in both Spanish and English. If you want to see a truly natural and breathtaking Mexican underground environment, then don't miss this one out!

Wonderful adventure for all!. Rio Secreto is very well maintained and probably one of the least explored cave / cenotes in Mexico right now. Everything was very well organized and even my 6 yrs old daughter was able to experience the tour and have a ton of fun! The guides are very knowledgeable, patient with kids and have a great sense of humor. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip!You will get all the equipment you need at Rio Secreto and it is all included in your admission - wet suits, life-jackets, water shoes, helmet / head-lamps etc. No need to buy anything. There is also no need for you to know how to swim, our daughter doesn't swim and was able to just float along holding lightly into my husband. However, this is still an underground experience, so if your kid is uncomfortable with closed spaces, darkness, water in general, I wouldn't advise you to try it. Our kid is a pirate at heart and an explorer so she had no issues but I can see it being scary for some kids. The lunch after the tour is pretty good and there are options to all tastes. We scored a wonderful deal through one of those touristic information booths in Playa del Carmen so we ended up paying just a third of the price for all our group, but even if we had paid in full it would be well worth it!The only thing not included are the photos they offer you ate the end, a professional photographer goes with your group and takes pics all the way which they sell to you in a CD for $79 - kind of expensive, but the pics are great and you can't just not buy it.

Stunning!. A wonderful trip with the family, our guide (Epco) was enthusiastic, professional, and personable. The caves are absolutely gorgeous with obvious care to preserve them long-term, and the trips are well-organized so that the caves can be properly appreciated by strong and weaker swimmers alike, with wet suits, life-jackets, and head-lamps provided. Entirely worth the money!

Wonderful tour, shame about the overpriced photos. Rio Secreto was a great underground adventure into a cave system which was only recently discovered. The guide was very knowledgeable and filled you with confidence. Very well organised, interesting and a fantastic experience. The food was also pretty good. The only disappointing part was the charade of trying to sell you overpriced photos of your tour at the end. They start off trying to sell you a CD for something like US$60 and then try the hard sell and tell you shhh don't tell anyone else but you can have the CD for US$45 etc etc and they won't go any lower than this. Such a shame because I would have loved to have photos and if it had been a sensible price like US$10 or US$15 I would have bought it, but it was essentially a scam which otherwise ruined a fantastic experience. The managers need to sort this out and sell photos at a more reasonable price in a less pushy way. Maybe even include photos in the ticket price and just charge $10 more for entry? None of our group purchased the overpriced pictures, which is a shame, as I would have liked them, but we didn't appreciate the attempt to rip us off.

Great caving adventure!. I thought this would be a float trip in a cenote river, but this is a hike and swim! The cave was discovered by the current land owner in 2006 and was opened to the public in 2008. It is well developed and thought out. There are nice, clean bathroom facilities. There are wetsuits, swim shoes, helmets, head lamps, and life vests that are mandatory and are needed. There are lockers and nothing, including watches and earrings are to be taken into the cave. You can't bring your cameras, even if they are waterproof so if you want photos, you have to buy them. It would be very hard to carry a camera due to the uneven ground and water level. Depending upon rain and season, the water in the cave can be throat high. They require everyone to shower before putting on wetsuits to remove any lotions or suntan lotions that would pollute the water. The shower water is from the cenote and the water is cold-around 65 degrees F. Although the tour was about an hour, we were really cold and happy to get out of the water at the end. We were glad our tour was the last one of the day; 500 people had been through that day, twice as many as usual, probably because we were there on 12/31. Our group was small and we didn't see anyone else in the cave so it was an intimate experience. After a brief presentation, we load up in a van for a bumpy 7km ride to the cave opening. A Mayan priest gives a blessing and prayer to the spirit Gods to protect people who enter the caves. This was a respectful brief ceremony in Mayan language. There is a brief walk down into the cave and then we had to swim into the cave. The manager who has the wetsuits decides which of the 3 routes your group will take. Of the miles of cavern, only 10% are open in order to try to preserve the ecosystem. The ground, which is submerged rock formations, is very uneven, sharp, and varying in slickness and depth. The mandatory wet shoes are very much needed. There are walking sticks available with the wetsuits. I was often crouching to feel rocks and drop off areas. The area is dark except for the guide's flashlight and our helmet headlamps. The guide was friendly but was unable to answer many of my questions. He stated he would ask someone else and get back to me, but never did. After the cave, there is a meal but it was unimpressive. There was chicken, rice, salad, and fruit. There was a good lime soup, a traditional Mayan dish, but the chicken looked unappetizing and due to food safety issues, we didn't eat any salad. We also passed on cooked cactus, which looked good, but it had raw tomatoes in it. Over all, we loved the experience. We been in many caves in the US and Central America and this was one of our favorites.

Excellent guide, beautiful historic location. The Rio Secreto is protected and it shows. Our guide spoke 5 languages and was very knowledgeable. Showers, washrooms and change rooms were provided before our trek. Wet suits, water shoes, and helmets with lights are provided. You will be putting them on wet which is normal. There are showers to finish off after as well. The meal is pretty simple...tacos, nachos etc. Nothing to get excited about but that is not what we came for anyway. This cenote is large and you will be walking/swimming in complete isolation other than your group and head lights. Pay attention to the guide as she/he knows the way. One of nature's wonders, this activity was beautiful! Truly a wonder. Pick up from our resort, tour, meal and return all in about 6 hours. Well worth it. We do not recommend the X trips as they are amusement park geared activities...unless you are looking for that.

Excellent tour. Diana was or tour guide and she was amazing. The cave is fascinating and really beautiful. The lunch was ok, but really who comes to a tour like this for the buffet lunch.I highly recommend this trip!

Great family attraction. We were a party of 12 with kids ranging from 4 to 16. It was amazing to go into the caves and experience the natural beauty created over so many years. I would highly recommend that people use the wooden canes provided to keep your balance inside the caves. Afterwards we enjoyed traditional Mayan food. Everyone enjoyed the adventure and it is highly recommended. Nico, our guide was also fantastic as he engaged with the kids and we learnt a lot from him. They also provide all the gear required, including water shoes.
Great Time. This was an incredible experience. The entire family went on this excursion and all LOVED it. Be prepared to have a great experience.

An Absolute Must!. Rio Secreto is the excursion that you don't want to miss. Discovered only six years ago the underground river complex is divided into three segments. One of which will comprise your tour, the section you get is randomly determined and each section takes about two hours to explore.You are provided everything you will need. You will need swim suits and clothing to change into after the tour. Please do not apply any lotions, shampoos, conditioners or any chemicals to your body or hair prior to the tour that could damage the fragile ecosystem.There is a large restroom/changing room/locker building. You will be given a locker key for to safely store your clothing as you change into your swimming suit. They also strongly suggest using the restroom to keep the cavern waters pristine. You will then be provided a wet suit, life jacket, lighted helmet, and aqua socks. I recommend you use their equipment as it has been selected specifically for the environment. They will also offer you a walking stick. I recommend you take one of these as well as they are very useful in finding underwater footholds and tripping hazards as well as helpful when bending low under stalactites. You will take a cleansing shower to keep the cave system free from body oils.It will be a short walk to the Cenote entrance and your guide will point out native jungle plants and trees along the way. Before descending the group will stop to partake in a traditional Mayan blessing which is amazing. Then into the underground cave complex for an hour and forty-five minutes of an unbelievable, beautiful, and unforgettable experience. Please don't touch anything. The oil from your finger can prevent the natural formations for growing for over 100 years. Unfortunately we saw people touching the cave environment as handholds, please use a walking stick.There are some low areas so people with knee or back issues should definitely use the provided walking stick. There are wet and slippery rock surfaces so attention to foot placement is important in places. The water depth will vary greatly but your head will never be submerged. Knowing how to swim is helpful but not necessary. There are brief times of total darkness but the caverns are large so claustrophobia should not be a major problem.After the tour you will return to your locker to change into dry clothing before being offered a delicious Mayan honey liquor and a lunch offering local foods and dishes.
Would highly recommend. Great tour with an excellent, witty, knowledgable, and helpful guide (Luis). This caving expirence exceeded our expectations. We went batty for this cave.

Definitely do this!!. We did this as an excursion during our April 2014 Princess cruise. When we arrived in Mexico we got in a van and were driven to the site. Let me just say the ride was as much fun and exciting as the caves themselves...well maybe not. It was a CRAZY ride to the caves! Bumpy dirt roads and our driver thought he was Mario Andretti. Seriously, I think we took some corners on two wheels! When finally did arrive, in one piece, we were met by our tour guide, given some wet suites, helmets with headlamps, water shoes and a locker for our things. We took a short walk down a dirt path for a short spiritual service and then continued on the to the cave entrance. Its completely dark and that is why you have the helmet with a headlamp. Along with our tour guide we had a photographer that took some incredible pictures. You'll walk through shallow waters and crawl over rocks and swim through the deeper parts of the caves. We saw a few fish but not many and a huge spider! At the end of the tour we were served a Mexican lunch under a large pavilion. A very memorable experience!!

A Perfect Adventure!. The “Rio Secreto” underground river tour and the caves excursion simply have blown our mind. The caves have been only discovered some 6 years ago, and they are an absolutely must see natural wonder! When I showed the pictures of the stalactite and stalagmite halls to my friends and family they couldn’t believe that we have actually been there!

Go.. You will love this experience!. My sister recommended this excursion for us and we were so glad that we went.You get suited up in water shoes and wet suit. You take a traditional walk and spiritual service for going into the cave. Take the walking stick for wading around in the cave.You might see bats or huge spiders that live in this cave. It was so amazing to turn off you light on your helmet to see how dark it actually is in there. The water is cool but definitely not cold. It was easy to get around and you were never filled submerged in water.This was one of the coolest things we have ever done. The lunch after the caves was extremely delicious. Take the shot of the anise liquor on the way out, it was spectacular!

Great tour!!. My wife and I have been on this tour twice and we had different experiences. The first time, was only about 6 months after the tour opened and we felt it was a lot better. There seemed to be a lot less people there and less commercialized. The tour itself was still great as the cave system is absolutely beautiful!! You definitely must be mobile to get through some areas. I tend to get claustrophobic and I did not have any issues with any part of the tour. Another big difference between the first and second time we went, was the tour guide. On our first tour, the guide was very knowledgeable and spoke perfect English. The second time, she did not know the answers to many of our questions. It seemed that she just had a bunch of facts memorized and just spat them out. I think that it was overcrowded in general the second time and this definitely brought down the experience. That being said, it is a must see in the Riviera Maya and I guess just luck of the draw whether or not you get a good guide.
Caving. Very cool! My wife and I loved the experience. Would do it again for sure. Only thing is be prepared to pay if you want any photos for your memories. There is a reason cameras aren't allowed.

The Cave Tour to End All Cave Tours. Outstanding attraction to visit during a Playa del Carmen visit. I went with my brother (who said this was "the cave tour to end all cave tours") and my two teenage daughters. We've been to Mammoth Cave and several other caves, but this tour is far more "authentic" and intense.We purchased tickets online prior to traveling to Mexico, for $67.50 each, and took a taxi from our resort to Rio Secreto ($31 ride). The entire operation at Rio Secreto is smooth and professional. We watched a short video, then took a 7km bus ride to the actual cave. Upon arrival, we were placed in a group of 6 (the 4 of us, plus another couple) with our own guide, Epco, whose Dutch humor and overall knowledge of the cave were entertaining. We were issued wetsuits (down to the knees), life vests, helmets, and water shoes, leaving everything else besides our bathing suits in free lockers. Then it was off on a short 5 minute hike to the cave opening with Epco, along with a photographer who ran ahead of us throughout the tour.The cave itself is simply wondrous. There is no artificial lighting, no wood walkways, no handrails, just the cave itself, in pristine condition. Within minutes we were up to our knees, then waists, in cool water. Most of the 90 minutes in the cave were spent submerged in 2-3 feet of water. In some spots, you actually swim (well, float - the life vests are strong) across 30-50 foot stretches. This is incredibly fun and exciting.The stalactites and stalagmites are in perfect condition, and massive abundance. Epco pointed out all sorts of different formations, explaining the conditions that cause the variations. Compared to more commercialized cave visits, everything feels incredibly authentic.The path through the cave varies - you're never quite certain what's around the next corner, but you definitely wish it would never end. At some points, we had to crawl under low ceilings. No passage is too narrow to cause claustrophobia - the feeling is awe rather than fear. The cave is, of course, pitch black, so the only lights are from your headlamp and from the guide's flashlight. It's just barely enough light to make out the floor and figure out where to step next.I'd invited my 79-year-old father to join us on the trip, but he declined. In retrospect, this was smart. While he's in great shape, I think Rio Secreto is probably best left only to folks around 65 or younger who can handle situations requiring a lot of balance and a lot of creeping and crawling up and down some pretty dicey footing. Also, obviously, you should be reasonably comfortable in water (although you never really "swim" due to the buoyancy of the wetsuit and life vest).After you emerge from the cave, there's a very nice Mexican buffet waiting. This hit the spot, and killed the time until our van was back to take us the 7km back to the front entrance. I also dropped $25 to purchase a single digital photo (I think you got every photo for $80, but we really only wanted 1 group shot inside the cave).We went to Rio Secreto frankly not expecting much. We were all absolutely blown away by this excursion. They've done a great job preserving the cave and crafting a visit experience that left us thrilled and satisfied.

Very professional . Booked online and went there with taxi. Upon arrival asked the driver to pick us up later. The driver was very helpful and talked to the ticket lady for pickup time. The site and crew are very skilled and professional. Our guide Alina was very informative and good! All in all, well worth the trip.

One of the most amazing experiences of my life!. This is a must if you stop at Cozumel on a cruise ship or are visiting Playa del Carmen. My friends and I (6 of us) were on a cruise from December 6-13, Carnival Glory, Western Caribbean. I've been to Cozumel before so did not feel compelled to stay on the island at this stop. We decided to go on the Amazing Secret River excursion. We took a 45 minute ferry ride to the mainland then a bus to Rio Secreto. We met our tour guide Nico who was absolutely fabulous! They provided the wet suits, helmets, head lamps, life vests and shoes or you can bring your own which I did. You have to shower before putting them on to get rid of fragrances, oils, etc before going into the caves. We then had a ceremony with one of the natives before hiking into the caves. We were in the caves for about 1.5 hours. A photographer followed us the whole time. We took many group and couple's photos together. Nico was very knowledgeable and had a great personality. After the cave tour, they gave us a couple of shots of the local moonshine. We then had an authentic Mexican lunch. Food was excellent. They sold us the CD with all of the pics on it for $69. Then we took our bus and ferry back to the ship. When we got home, we realized we lost the CD somehow. I emailed the company and they responded immediately. They emailed all of the pictures to me, free of charge. Saved the day! The pictures are gorgeous and a must by if you go on this tour. Just make sure they charge you the correct amount. They charged us in pesos and I think we were overcharged. I highly recommend this tour. It does require some athletic ability including swimming and hiking. No pregnant women allowed (one tried to go on this tour and was told no, didn't matter what form she signed). This tour is for adventurous people who are not afraid of the dark.

Natural wonders - amazing experience!. We could have gone to theme parks such as Xplor, Xcaret, etc., but we decided to see something that's natural and underground.Rio Secreto really opened our eyes on what the underground water system was like in Riviera Maya. The stalactites and stalagmites were amazing, with its cool formations! Thanks to Raffull, our guide, for showing us the various parts of the underground caves and structures. But this attraction is not for the weak of heart. If you're phobic of the dark or not very mobile, it would be challenging on this tour, as you need to walk/swim/climb through caves. The tour provides us with wet suits, life jacket, helmet with head lamp, and wet shoes. There were lockers to store your personal belongings, and you can't bring your camera. There will be a staff that joins you along the way, taking pictures, which you can buy at the end of tour. Package costs approx. US$79 on a disk, which you can share in a group. Tour comes with a nice lunch. But make sure you take some gravol if you can't bear a rough 25-min ride between the main entrance and the cave itself. Overall, I would recommend this excursion.

Very unique and interesting expereince. This is a very cool experience. We choose the 1/2 day excursion which gives you about 1.5 hours in the cave. Overall it was excellent and very unique. They provide everything you need and our guide Nico was really great. The caves are incredibly beautiful and the water is crystal clear. Before entering the cave you receive a Mayan blessing which was awesome and following the tour a lovely Mayan lunch is served. You are with a small group 8-10 and the guide stays with you the entire time. There is also a photographer that follows you and at the end you have the opportunity to purchase photos (you can't bring a camera into the cave). Photo packages range from $25-200 USD. A couple of warnings, if you're claustrophobic this is not the tour for you. Also if you are expecting a open air cenote with aquamarine water to swim in, this is not the tour to take. This is very much a cave tour. If you have mobility issues I wouldn't recommend this either as it was a little difficult navigating the uneven floor. Finally the drive from the entrance of this attraction to the actual caves is quite long and on an extremely bumpy dirt road. I suffer from motion sickness and this drive really bothered me, something to consider if this is an issue for you. The water is chilly but not bad once you're in.Overall I would highly recommend this tour, the facilities were very nice and the tour guides and employees truly are concerned about keeping this natural wonder in good shape for years to come. It's very peaceful in the cave and is like nothing I've ever experienced. .

Awesome!. Our guide, Alex, was awesome! Very informative and willing to help us navigate our way through the caves. This excursion is something that you will not get the opportunity to do very often --- I highly recommend it!

Very cool tour! Unique and Awesome for the family and kids!. This is a beautiful and largely untouched cave system that they only began touring recently. The water inside is absolutely clear, clean, and stunning. The cave formations are beautiful and amazing as well. It takes a couple of hours to hike through it and it is dark and cool under the ground in the water but it was a lot of fun for our family. The guide was great and very educational as well.

Do it while you still can. What an amazing place. This river was just recently found in 2006 and is still basically untouched. It hasn't even been explored all the way through, and has the potential to be the largest underground river in the world. This is definitely something you should check out while it's still new.Gonzo was our guide and he was very informative. You could tell he loved his job. On this trip, you will learn about the science behind the river and the culture surrounding it. It is definitely one of the coolest things I've ever seen.

A unique experience. walking through an underground river and in neck deep water is something I never thought I would ever do.It's literally the underworld. The tour is very safe and you are provided with a wet suit, life jacket, helmet with a headlamp and water shoes.Our guide was Fernanda and she did an excellent job of guiding us through and explaining how the river came to be and its meaning to the environment. She made very sure we stayed together and kept us safe at all times. Afterwards, we were provided with a very good lunch which is needed because you will like you had a bit of a work out. The tour is something you will never forget. Well worth it

Bucket list check off. This was a very highly recommended tour that everyone must experience! From the driver who picked us up at our resort to the tour guides. Our tour guide was named Epco and was very informative about the mayan people . We really enjoyed the mayan ceremony before going into the underground world that is rio secreto.The underground world was such an amazing sight!
