The water wasn't as cold as we thought and the stalagmites and the stalagmites were the most amazing things that I ever saw! We were underground for about one and half hours.... I would of stayed down there for another few hours gladly!Our tour included a very tasty lunch with traditional Mexican food.The only thing that we thought a bit of a negative was the price of the video of our tour...(no camera's allowed) but I would highly recommend experiencing this! Many Thanks to Epco for this amazing experience:)

Highlight of the Trip. This was a great trip. There are two options, the basic - I think $99 which goes through the underground river and the upgrade - I think $119 that includes more background info and a light show underground. All 4 of us thought the upgrade was worthwile. Then there is the trip down the underground river. There are three paths and we took the most challenging (you don't have an option but this worked well and may always be the one used when you get the upgraded tour). It's a half mile underground combination walk and swim. It pitch black and the only light comes from headlamps that everyone wears. Each person wears a light jacket and the guide for our group of 4 people helped my wife who doesn't swim. The lunch that was included was pretty good. Highly recommended.

The real nature. We have been visiting Rio Secreto already the second time. First time it was two years ago. We were pleased, that it didn’t got artificial like the other attractions starting with a X---. You still have the opportunity to visit the natural path of the underground rivers. The guides are very knowledgeable and are speaking very good English. The tour takes about 1.5 hours with additional 30-45 minutes to drive out and back and get the equipment on and off. You get all the needed equipment at site – wetsuit, swim west, water shoes, helmet and head lamp. If you want, you can book the tour with a buffet style lunch after it. We preferred to book without and went for a nice lunch in nearby Playa del Carmen. We booked through internet and paid by credit card over phone. I can highly recommend this tour to every one interested in nature and exploration.

Once in a lifetime experience!. I booked ‘The Amazing Secret River’ tour through my Carnival cruise ported at Cozumel and found it to be very well organized. We were escorted to a blue and yellow jet boat that loaded and embarked on the ten mile journey to Playa Del Carmen. This was the only time I felt queasy at sea. Playa Del Carmen, visited 23 years ago by me was shockingly modern. There’s a new outdoor mall with many upscale shops just like in the United States being built. I stopped into Starbucks for an iced espresso and my app worked on my phone in Mexico. It’s that seemless. We took a van ride from Playa Del Carmen with 6 others from our ship and about 4 more people to the recently discovered Rio Secreto complex between Xel-ha and Xcaret on the multi lane divided highway 407 running from Cancun to Tulum in the Mayan Riviera. Once on the property, there we rode another 35 minutes on a rough road to the coordination areas. Our group of 12 was led by a very gracious English-speaking guide who helped us with the whole experience. This is a natural wonder that is run by a very savvy management group. Between 300 and 400 people tour the 18 mile underground caves daily, generally in groups of 8-12. Admission on the Rio Secreto website is $109pp with transportation, so Carnival isn’t marking this one up at all with the extra boat transfers from Cozumel. After putting all of our belongings into lockers, we donned the optional half wet suits with aqua socks and lighted helmets, showered and then trekked through the jungle to the Cenote opening of the cave system. The guide recommended walking sticks for the caves because they help with stability and give you a sense of the underwater cave floor beneath you. We stopped along the way for pictures by our photographer who accompanied our guide. Along the way, a separate, optional stop included a blessing by a guy acting as a Mayan priest with incense. We spent about 90 minutes in the cave itself, which was spectacular and definitely a highlight of my trip. It’s unbelievably cool and otherworldy there with all of the stalactites and stalagmites. You'll duck and swim a little along the way. It’s also potentially very dangerous, but we were in good hands. We ended the trip with a shot of a local cinnamon-anise liqueur and a pitch for the photos and packages. Since you can’t bring any cameras into the caves, these are your only options. They have a modern pavilion showing you pictures from your tour on little ipads and imacs, (surprisingly sophisticated!) and the packages were available with pictures available singly for $25 a piece, an entire personalized CD of pictures of your group and 50 additional shots of the cave for $89, or for $119, the CD with 2 T-shirts and 2 bottles of liqueur. Ka-ching. The liqueur is delicious! We finished with an all you can eat Mayan buffet of soup, vegetables, mini tacos and fruit. Drinks are extra, but the meal was adequate and filling. It gave us an opportunity to get to know our tour mates just a little better and fill out their feedback forms on how to make the experience better. I couldn't think of anything. They're doing pretty much everything right with this tour.

Fantastic Tour!. Amazing job by the entire crew! From our pickup to drop off the crew was amazing. The lunch provided is wonderful. Our guide, Benito, was stellar. He made us comfortable and was accommodating to all age ranges. The photos are breathtaking and the experience was well worth the money. Another bonus is the natural exfoliation you get from the mineral water. We highly recommend the trip. Take a Dramamine if you get car sick. There is a 7km ride from the entrance to the caves. Book it today!
Scenic but costly. The caves and the tour was amazing. Unfortunate they do not let you bring a camera for the only purpose to sell you a $25usd picture at the end.

Enter the depths. This is not for the faint of heart. If you like adventure, this is a nice place to get down and dirty in one of the most newly discovered natural cenotes in this part of the Yucatan. We had a really great guide named Victor who was patient and informative and really cool about everything. He even made sure we were comfortable at the end of his tour when we had our lunch service. There was a lot of ground to cover, but we never felt rushed, and we never felt unsafe. This is definitely something to put on the list of things to do when visiting.

This can't last - don't miss out. A real gem, to travel through the caves in small groups of 7 - 10 for 1.5 hours and enjoy the natural beauty and serenity. Since they can only accommodate about 120 capacity a day, this opportunity to visit the nature preserve will be sold out before you get settled in your room. Book early so you don't miss this awesome opportunity.

Totally and completely awesome.. Our guide was informative and great! The river/caves were amazingly cool. The food & drinks were also really enjoyable. My daughter had a water proof arm cast on during our tour and we had zero problems. The whole family loved it.

BETTER THAN THE HYPE. This was a wonderful adventure. Julian, our guide was the best!!! I am 72 years old and needed a bit of help walking at times, and he was always there for me. Our group was only 6 people, and the sights we experienced were at times beyond words. I would recommend this experience to anyone who appreciates natural beauty at it's best.

Must visit and best place in PDC. - Amazing place- Very well organized and co-ordinated- Value for money- 1 Lunch is inclusive with the tour which is quite good.- We had a good guide, Alfredo. He took good care of us- The photos of the family are available in 1 CD. Expensive but worth it.

Beautiful caves but very touristy and photos are a rip off. I really enjoyed going into the caves, they were beautiful but first of all it takes ages to finally get into them. First you watch a video, then you sign a waiver, then a 20min van ride (careful if you get car sick) then it takes forever for them to take you through all the rules and regulations and then get into all the gear and then a 10 min walk to the caves.Once you were inside it was awesome apart from all the photos which you had to pose for - these were ridiculously priced at the end - $80 for all of them and $25 for one. We got just the one and then it was only on a disc and not even a print of it!!After that there is a very average buffet and you wait around until all the groups are done before getting the can back.....I wish there had been an express option that didn't include the lunch. It also felt long as we were the last group in the cave and the first one out which was annoying as we then had to wait around. Not sure if this is because we had a shorter trail or if we did it faster.
Awesome!. The caves were beautiful and Guoda was an awesome guide- so interesting. I wish we could have spent more time swimming in the big pools!

Great experience!. Such a cool experience to walk, hike, swim through this underground river of caves and natural wonders! It was very awe inspiring and one of my fave lifetime experiences! It was really cool when the guide turned the lights off and getting to experience and feel what it would be like to be down there without light!Make sure you bring proper water shoes to get through watery, slippery, muddy, rocky areas. Also, I did this with a sprained ankle with some help from my bf and the walking stick they provided. It IS a bit physical, but there were kids as young as 6-7 that were with us. It gets a bit chilly, but if you keep moving it's fine. They also provided wet suits and helmets with lights (make sure you get a good light!). FYI- you can't really bring anything with you.No cameras are allowed (not much of a chance to be able to pull one our and take a pic anyway, too dark without a really good cam and flash), you are going to want to buy the pics later which I think were $50? Can't remember, but worth the $!It's a long, windy, kind of scary drive to get there, and the tour takes a few hours too! At the end, we got a great buffet of food and the tour guide talked of the caves and his personal adventures.

The most fun I've had in a while!. This was so very exciting and beautiful! My parents always took us to caves in Blanchard Springs, Arkansas. And I always knew that you are not allowed to get in the water or anything or touch the walls or anything like that, so actually getting in the waters of these underground rivers/caves was so exciting! My husband and I chose to do this as an excursion on our cruise. We were not at all disappointed. We would recommend to go with friends (Also, on the cruise as well) for the single reason that you will be grouped with strangers with the possibility to mar the glorious creation you will be seeing with foul language and conversation. And your pictures of this awesome excursion will also be with these strangers... That said... It was so beautiful and wonderful and proved to us ever more that we have a Grand Creator who has made these things for our enjoyment!

Absolutely Incredible. What an amazing time we had at Rio Secreto. It's a place of astounding natural beauty, and the company does a good job of trying to preserve this. It does NOT feel like a tourist trap, even though hundreds of people travel through the underground cave every day. It's hard for me to pay for extra excursions while paying so much money for an all inclusive resort at the same time - but this one is certainly worth it. I would have gone on a repeat journey right away, let alone when we come back to Mexico.They provide all of the gear you need - wet suit, water shows, helmet, and head lamp. The water is cool, but I wouldn't call it cold. I may be biased from swimming in the Canadian Atlantic ocean my whole life though! The food at the end of the tour was authentic and well prepared. The only odd thing was the lime/tortilla soup had no chicken or tortillas!They take photos of you during your trip and because you are not allowed to take your own camera or GoPro with you, those are the only memories you can get. They are also very expensive, but they were really nice and there was enough of them to make it almost worth it. We loved our trip so much we did buy them, and are begrudgingly happy with that decision ($80-90USD for all of the photos, $25USD for a single photo).Take a 1/2 day out of your plans and visit Rio Secreto - you won't regret it.

Incredible Experience. If you are sure-footed and not claustrophobic, then this excursion is for you! We experience beautiful caves, incredible "scenery" and had an unbelievable experience. Our trusty tour guide was Rudolpho and he was pleasant, patient, and most of all, very knowledgeable.I did this tour with 3 friends and we all had a fantastic time. Lunch was included. I would highly recommend it for adults and teens

Our favorite attraction near Playa del Carmen. The Rio Secreto is an underground river in a cave. Participants don wet suits, helmets with lights, life vests and water shoes and follow a guide in a small group of about 10 persons. Ours was a family group ages 8 yrs- 80 yrs, and everyone enjoyed our tour very much. Much of it is in water, and sometimes floating. Our guide made it seem quite safe, yet a bit fantastical. At the end of the tour we had a buffet lunch of mexican foods. The adults had a small drink of a local anise flavored licour Rio Secreto was the highlight of our trip to Playa del Carmen.

a wonderful experience. The caves are beautiful. Be aware that you need minimal swimming and the surface under the water is uneven so you have to be careful where you walk. If you follow the guide carefully however, it is magical. They offer a wet suit and water shoes and yes you do need them. The water shoes are especially important - do not bring cheap walmart ones - you will slip and slide when you go up the embankments. The pictures at the end are wonderful but be aware that they are not cheap. The CD will only have pictures of you and your spouse - not everyone in the group so dont think that you can just email them to a new friend you made in the group and split the costs. They do tell you that at the end and it is true. We bought the pictures and do not regret the decision. The food at the end is good, but you dont get much time for the lunch - just the 15 minutes it takes for them to prepare your CD. Something you should do once if you happen to be in the area.

Words can't describe how beautiful this place is!. This tour is a must and worth every penny!! You can't prepare yourself for how beautiful and amazing it is! We spent almost 2 hours in the underground caves, walking, swimming, hiking, and enjoying the amazing rock formations nature has created. We are a young athletic couple, but there were people of all ages and athletic abilities on this tour and they made out perfectly fine! You don't need to know how to swim, as they provide lifejackets. The ground is rocky and uneven, but they also give you watershoes and a walking stick for balance. The guides are amazing and make sure to stop and explain things to you along the way. They also send a professional photographer in the caves with you to take pictures throughout the day, which you can purchase later. We had an amazing time and would definitely do it again!!

An Excellent Caving Adventure. My fiancé and I were vacationing in Cancun in November 2014 and Rio Secreto came strongly recommended to us by friends that had recently been to Mexico. We were fortunate to be in a small group with only one other adult couple. Our tour guide was named Rodrigo, who is often called "Ro". He was excellent with very good local knowledge of the caves and historic trivia to keep things interesting. All the equipment you need is provided and included in the price of the tour. No personal cameras are permitted, but there is one staff photographer per group that takes plenty of great photos throughout the tour, without slowing things down. The optional photo package is competitively priced and includes dozens of excellent photos. We bought the package and were pleased with the photos. A buffet style lunch is provided. We truly enjoyed it!

Unable to cancel this tour. I booked this tour on Sep. 6, 2013, for a Jan. 15, 2014, tour. On Nov. 8, 2014, I sent the company an email request to cancel the tour. After a second email and two phone calls, it is now Dec. 2, 2014, and they still have not refunded my money. I am disputing this through my credit card. I have noticed that since I booked my tour, Viator now has tours of Rio Secreto. I would definitely recommend booking the Viator tour, not directly through Rio Secreto.

Underground caves. If you don't like to be underground then this is not for you, also the ground surface is very uneven, difficult if you are unsteady on your feet. Interesting experience, probably a little overpriced.

Great Family Adventure. My family and I(especially my 7yo) enjoyed this amazing and beautiful adventure that our guide Luis took the time to give us. PAY ATTENTION TO YOUR INTRUCTIONS FROM YOUR GUIDE. Very neat and interesting history facts. We would do this again!Note: if you are crossing over by fairy (from Cozumel to Playa Del Carmen) and you are prone to motion sickness, take a good look at the waves and weather before you go. If the waves are high you will be in for a VERY bumpy and sloshy 45 minute ride.

Nice guide and beautiful, but... We were grouped with a couple of families with kids. Lots of screeching and overly reactive little ones did not make this an enjoyable tour for two adults. Would recommend booking your own tour or requesting no children in your group to really experience the intense beauty and potential of this cave system.

Do it once kind of thing. It is very pretty it was more of a field trip kind of excursion. I personally wouldn't do it again but was very informative. The hammocks were awesome and the food was great. We encourage everyone to see the beauty of the cenote had a great guide. Will not return but glad we did it once. We just prefer more adventure

A Can't Miss Adventure!. Best attraction I have been to in years! Don't go to the competitors with the 4x4 add-ons; this is the real deal and is run by a eco environmental group which funds research. You will learn more about the culture, and this part of Mexico more in 2 hours than anywhere else - and it was FUN!

A truly amazing experience!. A group of six of us went to Mexico for Thanksgiving. We wanted to experience the underground rivers near Cancun that we'd heard so much about. But, we didn't want to go to the most popular site that had been described to us as an "amusement park" style experience that most tourists visit via large tour buses. So, we made arrangements for a private tour and headed to Rio Secreto. We arrived not really knowing what to expect, and there was a bit of a delay once we arrived while we waited for a few more people to arrive. But, once we were all suited up in our wet suits, life vests and water shoes we were ready to head down into the caves. Once we entered the caves, all we can say is WOW!! It's an experience unlike any other we've ever had and we can't recommend enough. If you want to experience the underground caves and rivers as they should be, and not as an amusement park ride, this is the place to do it. Our guide, Raul, was wonderful and we look forward to returning again soon. We hope to have him take us through another part of the preserve.

One of the coolest things I have ever done.... My family visited the Rio Secreto last week while visiting Mexico while on a cruise. Truly, this is a magical experience. The cave is beautiful and the terrain is challenging. Our guide, Alina, was very knowledgeable and patient and she helped to guide our 7 year old. The gear that was provided was clean and helped to keep us comfortable. This was one of the best excursions we have ever been on. The pictures are quite expensive. We brought $50 thinking that it would be enough but it was not. We also had a nice Mexican lunch following the tour that was included. It was a great experience.

Do This At Any Cost. Seriously, this is by far one of the top 10 excursions of all time. This advice comes from a traveller who has been to 35 U.S. states and 17 countries on three different continents. Be sure and wear the wetsuit as the water is roughly 67 degrees. Even if you don't swim, you'll float along nicely while wearing the life vest. You may have to doggy paddle in a few places as the water is deep in areas. Bring your own water shoes (if you own any); if not, they ARE provided.

Wonderful experience. We loved our visit to Rio Secreto. We had been through caves in the US before but this was unique because we had to walk and swim through water. It was a little challenging but our guide Alex took very good care of us and made sure we stayed together and gave us interesting information throughout the tour. I would suggest taking the walking stick they offer before the tour. It really helped. The cave was beautiful and the professional photographer who came along with us got some amazing shots. We highly recommend this tour!

Best Excursion Ever. This was one of the best excursions ever for us, its a natural caves and the waters where amazing cold but amazing, anyone looking for a family adventurer this would be the best one :)

Girls vacation. What a great adventure. Nature is so amazing. Rio Secreto is just 10 minutes south of Playa Del Carmen. You are delivered by your driver who gets you your bands. You then watch a short safety and history film. You are then driven 12-14 kilometers into the rain forest where you are greeted and taken to changing areas. They do have lockers. You are given water shoes if you don't have your own. I recommend using your own because some of their shoes are quite worn. You are fitted with wet suits and a helmet. There is a ritual process that welcomes you into the caves by the Mayan gods. Then you walk through the rainforest approx. 10 minutes to the entrance of the caves. There are 4 different entrances. When you enter the cave, you must be careful because there are narrow passages and it can be very slippery because of the wetness. They do discourage touching the formations because they can be ruined. You will walk through foot paths as well as swim through others. Inside the cave can be very tricky to maneuver. It does require some physical agility. This takes approx. one hour give or take. There is a photographer that takes photos and you are able to purchase photos or the whole DVD. When you are done, there is a nice lunch prepared for you...included in the price. Our tour guide was Louis. Very good at what he does. He was also giddy because he had just gotten married 2 months ago. His wife works there as well. I highly recommend this tour. Just make sure you are able to walk without difficulty and take your time. It is slippery and you can get hurt.

Unforgettable, spectacular life experience not to be missed!!. It's nearly 6 months since our trip and our 11 year daughter still talks passionately about our amazing experience on our trip to Rio Secreto. Our entire family agrees it was the easily the highlight of our cruise or any vacation destination and we want to return one day. This is not a superficial, commercialized, passive, wet your toes tour! You have incredible access to the inner caverns and their beauty is magnificent and awe-inspiring! It was one of the best spent 1.5 hours of my life. The cost is ridiculously low for the experience and overall quality of the tour. Our guide, Alfredo, was exceptional and highly recommended if you can get him! He was professional, knowledgeable, friendly, helpful, patient and fun. We still talk about him and miss him like a friend! The CD photo album is a must! The pictures were clear, high quality, well framed, and documented every desirable step of the journey. It is a memory maker we cherish and is worth much more than it cost, which was reasonable. The additional bonus photos provided are spectacular. We even received high quality t-shirts for each family member as another bonus! This not just an incredible and unique experience of Mexico, but of our planet! We were thrilled and I still get excited and rave and recommend it to anyone and everyone I meet. The organization of the tour was excellent and provided for every need. The buffet is included at the end and was delicious with a wide variety of food and generous time given to enjoy it. Overcome any mind blocks and taste the majesty of creation! THANK YOU TO ALFREDO AND ALL THE PEOPLE at Rio Secreto who made it possible for us to share this cave of true wonders! God bless you!!!

Rio Secreto Shouldn't be a Secret. This excursion was fantastic. A cost of about 90 dollars two years ago. They give you wetsuits and water shoes and lighted helmet. The Cenote is amazing with stalactites and stalagmites. Small tropical fish. Enormous underground caverns. Could only compare it to Shasta Caverns in California, except with water.

Absolutely Must-Do!. In short: from start to finish, the experience was not only immensely informative and adventurous, it even pushed me out of my comfort zone while still helping me feel safe and secure. Yes, even in the pitch black of a cave many meters underground.When we arrived at Rio Secreto after an hour (roughly) drive from our hotel in Cancun, we were greeted by a friendly reception team that got us checked in quickly and helped us get oriented to the excursion with a short video in Spanish, English, and French. (I’d imagine they have other languages too, depending on the native languages of guests.) Since I was taking the ‘Plus’ tour, I piled into a van with several other guests, including a couple who would be the only other two on our private tour. I will say that the 7km drive into the jungle was not friendly to me and my motion-sensitive stomach, but after arriving, the activities kicked off so quickly that any woozy feelings I had were soon gone.Our guide, Rodrigo or “Ro,” was the pinnacle of perfect adventure tour guide. His attentiveness to the group made us all feel not only like VIPs, but as unique VIPs, experiencing the caves in a special way that nobody had before. During his custom-built itinerary, we explored all of the major paths through the cave, rather than sticking to just one. But I’m getting ahead of myself already!To start out, we went into a dry part of the cave to learn more about cenotes, caves, underground rivers, and the importance of these geologic features to the ancient Mayan people who inhabited the Yucatan. Through the introduction of four ‘portals,’ we learned how the Mayans viewed these cave entrances, and the spiritual inhabitants therein, as sacred places, and made sacrifices accordingly. We also watched a fascinating video that combined spoken word/poetry with moving images (moving as in, they moved and they were evocative), and the intensity of cave walls to tell the story of the universe…. Sitting in an underground theater to watch the 25-minute show was oddly relaxing and also anchored me even more to the significance and uniqueness of the experience I was about to have.Once we suited up and donned our wetsuits, Ro led us through the jungle to be blessed by a Mayan priest with a traditional saying to help us be purified before entering the caves, and transformed by our experiences. Then, we descended.Underground caves are fascinating—I’ve been in several before, but never one with water, and never one so open for exploration—most caving tours I’ve done have limited access to ‘hallways’ and ‘rooms’ (I’m not sure about the technical terms here, folks), but the team at Rio Secreto has done an immense amount of exploration and though they claim to only take their tours through a small portion of the accessible caves (there are miles of fully submerged caves below the ones the tours can move through), it feels like you’re exploring a huge space.In the process of our tour, several other notable things happened: first, I learned how to walk in deep water with limited visibility. The water is very clear, but as the group moves in single file, there is sediment that can be stirred up, and that makes seeing underwater rocks tricky. With the help of the guide and my trusty wooden walking stick, I soon became adept at navigating unseen obstacles, and our group was so proficient that Ro remarked that he was rarely so lucky as to have such an able tour. Hang on, let me brush the dirt off my shoulders.We did a complete ‘black out’ in the caves—Ro brought us to a stable, calm part of the caves away from other tour groups, and had us close our eyes while he turned off all the lamps we had brought with us. Opening one’s eyes into complete darkness is truly disorienting but also a great test of mental grit—I found myself almost terrified by the loud pounding of my heart.There’s also a photographer that moves throughout most of the tour with each group. With our small group, I got some excellent adventurous photos and the photographer is quite good at capturing moments for posterity and later enjoyment. If you see the camera up, it’s best to smile, because there’s definitely a photo opportunity coming! This includes the dry portion of the caves if you opt for the ‘Plus’ access.After arriving back above ground level, we took a leisurely walk back to camp to rinse off and change for lunch. Before we tucked in, Ro brought our group to the lodge where we could review our photos, and made sure we all tried a sip of a local annis and honey liqueur that I made sure to buy a bottle of for consumption when I want to be transported back to the Yucatan jungle. A traditional meal of tacos, rice, beans, lime soup, and papaya were served buffet style, and it felt a bit like being back at summer camp.I’d highly recommend Rio Secreto for people who are interested in exploring underwater caves—while I haven’t visited other excursions in the area who take advantage of similar formations, I believe that Rio Secreto’s focus on just giving an immersive experience in the underground river helps guests have a uniquely focused experience, rather than a jumble of exciting adventure activities. The tour is long, especially the ‘Plus’ option—we left our hotel at 8am and didn’t arrive back until almost 3pm, and definitely felt as though we had enjoyed enough of the caves to feel like we would have gotten our money’s worth. There are some rules—children must be a certain age, you must be physically able to navigate the passages (which as I’ve mentioned are at times a bit strenuous), and there are plenty of stairs and uneven pathways to conquer–, but that shouldn’t stop most adventurers from making this a necessary part of their itinerary. There’s a whole world beneath your feet when visiting Cancun and the Yucutan, and if you’re looking for a truly immersive way to experience it, Rio Secreto is the way.
Best ever!!. This tour was the best we have ever gone on. The guide was awesome, the cave was even better then expected. We would go again in a minute.
Beautiful. Just as good as the first time. The views are amazing, check out this unique adventure... I think it's the nicest cenote in the Mayan

Outstanding. Took the chance on this attraction the day after a day long excursion. This half day jaunt was very close to our hotel in Playa. We were a group of six and looking for some adventure. We got picked up at our hotel and spent ten minutes getting to Rio Secreto where a ten minute video and a half hour ride on a brumby road led us to the staging area. Our guide for the walk/swim was Carlos. He took us on a very beautiful, safely conducted walk through underground caves filled with clear water and spectacular features. Carlos, who spoke three languages, was able to convey the beauty and importance of the caves and water network to the Mayan and Mexican economy. We were led safely for about a half mile through the caves and had nothing but wonderful things to say about Carlos and the photographer who tried his best to stay out of our way and still get fotos. If you are in the area and have a half day you gotta go to Rio Secreto.

AN EXPERIENCE OF A LIFETIME!. I do want to start off with saying how helpful and informed and considerate Luis was while giving us the tour of the Mayan Underworld. With most guided tours I usually feel a disconnect between the tour guide and the rest of the group. But with Luis everything was easy; we were all in on an adventure together, and we were going to help each other through it and discover and enjoy as if it were the first time.Luis guided us through the most beautiful experience I have ever had. One thing to keep in mind, as others will say, is that the water is COLD; however, they provide the water shoes and the wet suits for you, and after a few seconds you forget how cold you are because of all of the AWESOME around you. There are definitely times where you may lose your footing, so I would definitely suggest to either go with a group that you are comfortable with falling/grabbing onto, or get very personable very quickly. No spoilers, but if you get claustrophobic this might not be the best tour for you. Amateur spelunkers, this is a must.The tour ends after a few hours with a group shot of Xtabentun, and a surprisingly good buffet dinner. Hammocks are ready for you as you wait for your bus to take you back to your hotel/resort. I could not recommend this trip more. GO GO GO!!!

Awesome!!!. The coolest trip underground through limestone caves where you get to see nature and time collide. This was one of our favorite excursions, and the staff did a fantastic job! They will provide everything for you, including wetsuits, lifejackets, helmets, lamps, and even water shoes if you don't bring your own. Take the time to see this ecological wonder!

Life changing!. We really had no idea what to expect when we signed up for this adventure - which turned out to be a truly rich cultural and personal experience. You're definitely not in the U.S. as the "pathways" are often narrow with many tripping hazards - but you will be hard pressed to find this type of experience anywhere else. After your expedition is blessed by a traditional Mayan ceremony, you head into the "underworld" of cave and river systems. Sometimes walking, sometimes crawling, sometimes swimming, this active adventure will not soon be forgotten.

River in the caves. If you want to touch the heart of the nature and get a unique out-of-this world experience, this half-a-day adventure is for you. Physical conditions: slow walk on uneven surfaces, terrain is mostly flat, with few steps up or down, some swimming/floating, a few tighter spots to pass watching your head and/or back; nothing physically too challenging, 50-year old couple made it with no problems whatsoever. Underground experience: ~1.5 hr of stunning colourful views, perfect fresh air, pleasant to touch crystal clear water; even for a person with some fears of confined underground spaces it was an amazing positive encounter.Pros: --extremely well organized event; every stage was thought through and well implemented; all went on time, smoothly, at a comfortable pace--perfect balance of physical, spiritual, educational and fun aspects--all equipment, required for safe and enjoyable experience, was provided by the company: non-slippery shoes, life vests, helmets with lights, wet-suits, walking sticks; dry towels after the tour--other features included in price: lockers, showers, food & drinks, rest area with hammocks, enough computers for everyone to review pictures--our guide Alfredo was experienced, knowledgeable and caring--welcoming and friendly staffCons: --no cameras allowed, and price for professional photo CD is a bit steepOther info:--no jewelry, makeup or creams allowed underground to preserve quality of the environment--be prepared for a substantial (~20 min) slow drive on unpaved road in the middle of nowhere--all you need 1) swim suit/dry cloths; 2) cash for purchasing your photos done by professional photographerSummary: --time and money well spent--highly recommended

DO THIS!!!. If you are reasonably fit, can follow instructions and want to see one of the wonders of the world, make this the highest priority of your stay in this area. Check physical restrictions before going, but the picture above doesn't do this amazing place justice. It's an extremely rare opportunity to experience a massive, magnificent cave system up close like no where else I've seen. Please visit this place so they can afford to keep it open. It's on valuable land and must be preserved for future generations. The images of our day will stay with me forever.

Under caves. This was a very interesting place to see. It's about 1 & 1/2 hrs of walking in the water under the caves that the mayans found 7 yrs ago. It's a fantastic tour. Takes about 5 hrs from the time we left our hotel (20 mins away) till we got back . You learn a lot with the very informed tour guide. You will enjoy this excursion .

Truly Amazing. This was a truly amazing excursion that we took on our cruise. It is a long trip to get there - a ferry ride (we were docked in Cozumel), then about a 40 minute ride in a van, but totally worth it. You are deep into the jungle when you arrive. You a given a locker, wetsuit, water shoes, life jacket and helmet with a light on it. Everything goes in the locker - you cannot take anything with you into the cave. Your guide (we had Luis who was very knowledgable) will explain the history and how the caves were formed. After a short walk you will stop to be blessed my one of the natives before you enter the caves. Once you descend underground you are taken into a beautiful underground river flowing through caverns with exotic formations all around. Tiny droplets hanging on the end of the stalactites look like stars because there are so many. The water is cool (you would not want to be in there without a wetsuit) but very clear and beautiful. The floor of the caverns can be very uneven and you will need to duck your head in places. There are a few places where you actually float but the water is not that deep in most places. If you are physically able to see this place, you should see it. I would go back again and again. The area is well kept up with clean restrooms and even hammocks. My only gripe is that the photos they take are very expensive. Otherwise this is a must-visit place.

Awe Inspiring. A must see if you are in the Riviera Maya area. No words can describe the incredible beauty mother nature provides. All the equipment you need is provided (I strongly suggest taking the walking stick if you have knee problems or are unsteady on your feet, it was a great benefit to me and my husband). Our guide, Julio, was exceptional. He was very informative and passionate about the cenote and the preservation of the caves and jungle in which it is found. From the stalactites and stalagmites, to the columns and crystal clear water, everything in the cave is absolutely breathtaking. We were not disappointed and would go again given the chance. There was also a delicious Mexican meal was provided after the tour.

Amazing. quite the experience to visit. After a 7 mile trip on a backroad into the Mayan jungle we arrived at our destination. Nico, our guide, got us prepared with wet suit and helmet. He offered a walking stick---would take it next time as some of the walking was quite treacherous with the uneven cave bottom floor which was obscured with the ever changing water level in the low light, underground cave.Journey though the cave began with ceremonial Mayan cleansing, not sure of how I felt about that--- and the whole idea of the Mayan underworld theme. The cave itself was intriguing--- beautiful, Cool and no place to wind up without someone to guide you out!They don't allow cameras and so we had to buy a photo to have a memory--not inexpensive at $25 for one pic (cheapest option).The lunch after, left something to be desired. A bit pricey all in all, but the cave tour was a bucket list experience.

Rio Secreto is the Real Deal. We took this tour while staying at our resort in Riviera Maya and I have to say, this was a major highlight of our trip. Our guide, Gonzo, was the best! He was very knowledgeable about the cave and cenote and answered every question we had. All equipment was provided (wetsuit, hard hat, water shoes, and life vest). The caves were indescribable - so beautiful... We couldn't have ever imagined the beauty that exists underground. This is not a "water park" or a Disneyland. This is true, natural beauty and if this is what you would like to see, I can't recommend it highly enough. A nice buffet is provided afterward as well. Don't miss this!

Amazing experience. The very best cenote and cave experience we have ever had. Underground river and pool trip about half a mile in length. Very knowledgeable guide ( Victor) who was very considerate of our 9 visitors, with different ages.

You have got to see this underground paradise. We booked a trip from the Riu Palace Mexico to the Rio Secreto underground river. It is only about 30 minutes away from the hotel complex at PlayaCar, Playa del Carmen. What a fantastic experience. When we arrived we were given a wet suit, non slip slippers and a hard hat to don. I would suggest that you bring your own deck slippers for this trip as the ones we were provided had seen better days. If you have a wet suit bring that too as the ones provided were - well - very wet and cold to put on. However all were minor compared to the absolutely spectacular journey underground. We were treated to a Mayan ceremonial blessing by a Mayan Shaman which was unique and ghave us some insight into the Mayan heritage.Then we were led underground by our excellent tour guide Alex who spoke fluent English and helped all of us every step of the way.There were 9 of us altogether (one family group) and the expereience was simply breathtaking. The crystal clear waters of the underground river and the lagoons with stalactites coming from the ceiling just took your breath away with their beauty.We ended the tour in a large lagoon and shut of the lights to experience pure darkness and silence. You could almost hear your own soul.This is quite a physical journey but not too difficult. A good pair of knees is essential though. But very well worth the effort to see this spectacular natural phenomenon.

A true spelunking experience. Rio Secreto is part of the extensive cave/cavern system in the Yucatan. After you (finally) arrive, you will be shown a short video about it and then taken 7km up the road where you will be equipped with river shoes, wetsuits, helmets, life jackets and lights. You will also take a cold shower and will be blessed by a Mayan elder before entering the caves. There are 4 different paths but you will only do one and it will take about 1 ½ hours walking and swimming through the caves. The pathways have had little or no improvement and the formations are pristine. And you can get very close to them to see the details in their structure. Groups are 10-12 people with a guide and photographer. You are not allowed to take cameras so if you want pictures, you must buy them (very expensive) at the end of the tour. A very poor lunch is provided after the tour. Lockers and towels are provided. It was nice to see a pristine cave and it was more authentic than walking on flat paths through a commercialized cavern but with transportation, orientation, gearing up and lunch, from a hotel in Riviera Maya, the 1 ½ hour tour took 5 ½ hours.

Great time!. The underwater river was fantastic! Very good time and very beautiful. We also did the ATV which was the first time I have ever driven one and it was great! Stopped at a cenote where the fish nibble on your feet, it was Fun!

Higfh point of my vacation at Playa Del Carmen. I thoroughly enjoyed the tour. Gonzo my tour guide was 5 stars. He was very passionate and well educated about the underground river and formations. I have asthma. Gonzo always kept an eye on me and always within an arms reach of me. Due to my age and asthma , I was very proud to have completed the tour. This is something I will never forget !! This is the real deal.

Beautiful. The underground river system/cave is really beautiful. When you arrive you are outfitted with a wetsuit, water shoes, lifejacket and helmet, everything you need to enjoy this experience. The cave itself is beautiful and our guide, Linda, did a great job explaining and answering questions in English and Spanish. If you are claustrophobic or really afraid to swim this might not be the tour for you. When we all turned off our lights you could not see your own hand in front of your face. The result of quiet and complete darkness was incredibly serene.

Makes you appreciate Mother Nature. After getting geared up and have a shower to rinse off all products and oils, you take a trek to the mouth of a cave. There are many different entrances to this natural wonder. You will partake in the "cleansing" ceremony performed by Maya descendant. You are wearing a wet suit, because the water a bit chilly, but after the hike to get to the cave, it is refreshing. There is uneven ground with rocks in the water to navigate around. I recommend bringing your own water shoes, the ones I had, had holes in the toes which let in coarse sand. Water levels varied from calf/knee deep to swimming (you do have life vests on). There are spots you have to crouch and waddle thru the rock formations. This is an amazing tour. The guides are very informative and passionate about preserving this wonderful piece of nature. Do not participate if you are claustrophobic or afraid of darkness. You do wear a head lamp on your helmet, but there are times you will be turning them off to truly appreciate the marvels of this cave. It was an experience of a life time. There is a lunch following the excursion on location. Delicious. Highly recommended.

Amazing!. Visited Rio Secreto 2 weeks ago ; we asked for a tour in French and got the best guide ever : Alex ! He gave lots of information and was funny and relaxed. Rio Secreto is a must if you do not suffer of claustrophobia. The experience in total darkness was amazing. Long minutes where you can see absolutely nothing !! Loved it and I strongly recommend it.

Amazing!. This place is close to Playa and it is awesome! The caves and cenotes are something that are a must see. The workers and tour guides are very passionate. Our group loved it! Also its underground so if the weather forcast calls for a lot of rain, it's the perfect excursion.

A Must. If you do nothing else whilst staying in the beautiful Maya Riviera go to Rio Secreto, this was one of the most amazing experiences ever! Our guide Hulio was very informative and obviously loved his job and so would I if I could do his job everyday. Obviously these are guided tours so there is definitely no going off on your own, if you did the likelyhood is that you would never been seen again! There are kilometres of caves with more being discovered all the time. Groups are no more than 10 and this tour is even suitable for non swimmers, wetsuit, bouyancy aid, swim shoes and helmets are provided. Rio Secreto definitely needs to be added to the To Do list

Fun time..but be advised.. It was alot of fun. The staff was friendly. The caves are amazing yada, yada. But there are a few things you should know...I'm sure other reviewers have probably covered this, but here goes:Its a 100% guided tour, so don't expect to be able to explore the caves on your own...the guides keep a pretty tight lid on the tourists...which is fine, but if you are like me and are more of an adventurous type, it may annoy you. Also..the water is cold guys. It bothers some people depending on how sensitive you are to that type of thing..the staff will dish out thin ply wetsuits to those that want them to aide in the cold temps, but I still heard a few people whining about the cold even with the suits, so just be aware of that.All in all a good time...worth the time and pesos if spelunking is your kind of adventure.

Awesome adventure. Off the beaten path. Great for nature lovers. Not too touristy and very informative. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking for an excursion that isn't an all-day affair. Also good when its rainy weather.

Trip of a Lifetime. A true trip of a lifetime, it left us totally speechless - literally.Our experience was with the Privilege Tour which was 5 amazing hours in this wonderful underworld. A short orientation, we were outfitted with top quality gear: full wetsuit, lifejackets, booties, helmet and headlamps on, we embarked into the underworld journey deep into the jungle to find one of many hidden entrances of Rio Secreto. There is just four of us, our gentle guide extraordinaire Alfredo, our very own photographer Carlos and us. Alfredo is a physcologist living his dream everyday at Rio Secreto. His passion and deep personal connection for this place echoes from every single word he speaks. Carlos meanwhile smiles quietly in the background capturing our marvel on film. Some have commented about not being allowed cameras, being a amateur photographer myself I would have loved my camera also but I can understand why it was better to leave it behind. I thought about how much a camera would change my experience. I would be so busy with photos I would forget to enjoy what I was seeing and feeling. The second thing is the light, you really need professional camera and lightning to do justice to this magic place. What’s so pleasing about Río Secreto, aside from being the Riveria Maya’s jewel destination, it’s 100% Mexican-based and it’s mission is based around eco-tourism. This is truly evident is everything we saw. I don’t need to tell you that I highly recommend Rio Secreto, you already know that and if you miss it on your trip to the Yucatan then you’ve missed a real treasure. Our Privilege Experience was sponsored by ‘Rio Secreto Mexico’. As always, our thoughts and writings are based solely on our experiences. You can read more details about our amazing day herehttp://worldwideadventurers.com/rio-secreto-mystical-underworld-of-the-riveria-maya-mexico/

Awesome Underground River & Cave. My friends and I visited Rio Secreto on October 30, and we really had a great time. The cave itself is absolutely stunning - the formations are so pristine, and the river itself is crystal clear. When you go, keep in mind that you will NOT need to apply any sunscreen (or deodorant or hair gel or lotion) because this adventure is all underground. When you arrive at the location, you're greeted by your guide, who explains the process and advises you what to expect - you should know right away that you cannot take your own photos or videos on this excursion. There will be staff there to take photos of you... and yes, you can purchase those photos on a CD for $79. While that may seem like a lot of money, keep in mind these photos are incredible... they truly do a great job of capturing the moment. You would not be able to capture the same quality of photos the staff does since the cave is LITERALLY PITCH BLACK when your headlamps are turned off. There's a part during the tour where our guide asked us to turn off all lights and just sit and listen to the cave... and as crazy as that sounds, it was nothing short of other-worldly... sitting in pitch-black darkness, listening to the cave drip is an experience you'll remember forever. In total, the tour takes about 90 minutes, and when finished, you'll have a buffet-style meal - ours was chicken with beans & rice, tortillas, pasta, and salad. The food was okay - nothing stellar. After your meal, you'll be swiftly returned back to your hotel for whatever your night may hold.In my opinion, this was a great excursion - I don't think I'll find myself visiting another underground river and cave system anytime soon. I highly recommend this tour for anyone looking for a natural experience in the Riviera Maya.

Great excursion!. Just returned from cruise on Princess Cruise Line and really enjoyed this excursion. Booked through the cruise line. Great tour...very professional staff. Very safe and a lot of fun! Scenery was beautiful and the caves were awesome. Our guide Luis was the best!!!Highly recommend this to all!

Breathtaking sights and very unique. My husband and I recently returned from Mexico, where we went on a couple hour journey through Rio Secreto with a small group of about ten people. The cave system is absolutely beautiful with many different formations all throughout. Our tour guide, Alfredo, was wonderful - he was knowledgeable and welcoming, and he obviously has a passion for his job and exploring the world underground. My husband and I have visited many different caving systems, but none quite like this. It was a very unique experience to wade and swim through the crystal clear waters. We were lucky enough to spot some cave wildlife on our tour, including a catfish and bat. The staff were professional and friendly. Since we weren't allowed cameras inside, they had a staff photographer go through with us and take photos. He did an amazing job, and we purchased their DVD at the end of our tour. We enjoyed participating in a Mayan soul cleansing ritual before going into the caves, and then a delicious authentic Mexican lunch afterwards. Overall we were very pleased with our tour and we would definitely recommend it for anyone visiting Mexico.

Nice tour for the first half hour. We toured the underground caves and river on Oct 24. It was enjoyable and informative, but we probably didn't need an hour and half of it. After a while its a lot the same and even though you are wearing a shorty wet suit, it gets a little cold. Lastly, they don't allow any pictures hoping you'll buy their $89 picture package, or $25 for a picture. We couldn't even take a group photo once we were dressed in our set suits and helmet with light because you have to leave all photo gear and phones in the locker before you get dressed. Having paid $100 a person, we should have been able to come away with at least one group picture.
So Cool. Loved our time at Rio Secreto. Our guide was informative and fun. We had a terrific time and loved every minute of it! Highly recommend. Lunch buffet included and not too shabby either.

Swimming under ground. Sounds spookie but no! IT was a blast! after a 4 mile ride into the jungle. Every on gets fitted for wet suits (some find the water a little chilly, its not that cold) and helmets and in groups of 10 or less you walk down to the cave entrance about 200 yds, get blessed by a Mayan priest and down into the cave. the guide does an awesome job of explaining the geology and makes sure every one knows the footing and then you climb into the river and float along seeing all kinds of Stalactites and Stalagmites. I can't say enough about how cool this was to do...... GO!! you will love it

Worth the time to see.... The cost was a little heavy ($100 per person more or less) but the tour was worth the money. Our guide was Julio Sierra who made the trip very informational and safe. The cave structures and the cenote are a must see. If I could have floated around in water over my head in the dark for hours I would have been content. An almost supernatural experience that I'm glad I have.If you have any issues with a bumpy ride you may want to think otherwise though (hence the four star and not five star review). The road to the attraction was very, very rough. The ride was not ten minutes from N. Playa Del Carmen as we were told. It was much longer.
fun times in a sinkhole. So much fun and our tour guide Rene was amazing. Spent a lot of time with our group and didn't rush us.

If you enjoy walking/wading/swimming through history.... Not to sound like a 12-year-old girl, but Oh eM Geee! :-) That was Ahhhhmazing. First of all, be sure to NOT be afraid of dark (mostly enclosed) spaces, and be sure you are able to walk on very unstable ground ... The rest is a Fabulous adventure! You are given all the gear you will need: Wet-suit, booties, life vest, helmet with a light... and you're set. They divide every tour into small (no more than 10 people) groups, and you're given a nice, knowledgeable, friendly, and yes - English speaking, guide. A short walk through the rain forest and you're entering a magnificent cave - stalagmites and stalactites EVERYWHERE... some place you walk, some you're hip or waist deep, some you have to swim. Towards the end we had to take off our life vests so that we can crouch down enough to pass - the space between surface of the water and the top of the cave only as tall as your head. Barely. :-) Like I said, no Claustrophobics need apply ;-)It was Spectacular. I highly recommend.

Best Excursion in Cozumel!. We booked our excursion through Carnival Cruise Lines. Everything was perfectly organized and planned. We took a 45 minute ferry from the port to the mainland where the Rio Secreto staff met us and took us by van to the site, which was about 15 minutes inland. Our guide (Nunez) met us, explained everything, got us our gear (wet suits, water shoes, life preservers, helmets with lights), and took us to the caves. (Clean bathrooms and secure lockers are available for your use.) The 1 1/2 hour walk/swim/tour through the caves was unbelievable and amazing! Our guide knew as much as any scientist, and guided us every step of the way! The water was warm, the cave was a comfortable temperature, and the route was well marked, so there is no fear of getting lost... After the tour, you eat authentic Mexican food from their buffet...the food is excellent. You are taken right back to where you started. Very professional. Everyone is very nice. You won't find a better excursion. Unforgettable. Thank you!

Yucatan History. The Rio Secreto experience is a walking tour of a partially flooded underground cave. Located approx. 15min outside of Playa Del Carmen the tour starts above ground with a quick video tutorial offered in many languages. Small groups, based on spoken language, meet a guide for the tour. You're outfitted with a wet-suit, life-vest, helmet and water shoes (or bring your own). All personal belongings, including cameras, jewelry, hair clips must stay out of the cave system. You'll even wash the soaps, deodorants and perfumes from your skin before entering.You learn about the cultural and water-supply significance of the cave system on your tour. A quick group blessing and you're off to the underground.You'll walk and float your way through the pitch black - blacker than any black you've seen before - led by your guide (hola Paolo) and a helmet light. The water level on the predetermined path will vary from a few inches to a few feet but there are a few passages that you will need to float across in your life vest.The cave adventure is relatively new. This system is a recent Mexican discovery and has only been marginally mapped to date. This is an experience that only a few others have ever shared.After your tour you are treated to a meal of typical Yucatan cultural relevance; all fair claimed to be from the local lands. The Modelo Especial is available for purchase and is a perfect afternoon beverage before your shuttle ride back to your resort. Booking through the resort tour operator we paid $70US per person. The all natural underground river of the Yucatan, Rio Secreto, is a fun day trip while visiting.

Beautiful hidden paradise. Booked our Rio Secreto through Best Day excursions from the Royal Playa Del Carmen (99 dollars per person). We had 9 people in our group. We were transported in nice vans supplied by Rio Secreto. We were very impressed on how everything was above anyone's standards. Pablo our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and passionate about revealing the beauty of an otherwise unknown paradise. Rio Secreto was a true body, mind and spiritual experience. Miguel, our photographer did a great job in capturing our beautiful adventure. A simple yet delicious meal was offered at the end of our excursion. We highly recommend buying the disc with your pictures (135.00 dollars for four discs). They offer poles to help you get through the underwater terrain. Take one even if you are athletic. It helps.
Awesome. This tour was fabulous. Amazing and informative. Well worth the cost. Even bought the cd of pics. Tour guide really taught us a lot.

Awesome day out. Have just spent great day at Rio Secreto. Booked online, staff very helpful in making phone booking.Travelled by car from Cancun, journey time approx 1hr 15 mins. Easy to find and well signposted.Upon arrival, met by hosts, short briefing, before being taken to shuttle buses for 7km, bumpy bus ride.Introduced to our guide Julio, who kitted us out with wet suits, helmets, life jackets. Shoes provided, but we bought at reception, only 10 U.S. Dollars, cheaper than the supermarket!I also took stick to help in the cave, glad I did, others in party wished they had done the same, as you cannot touch the surrounding rock.The actual tour took approx 90 minutes. Julio was very knowledgable, and very enthusiastic about showing us his underground home,the network of caves was incredible and even more so to think they were only discovered 7 years ago.We clambered over the cave floor, through water, at some stages having to swim.The whole experience was fantastic, absolutely stunning caves. A photographer joined the group, capturing some very special memories for us.When we emerged from the cave, we sampled a local Mayan liqueur, before lunch.Lunch was disappointing, although we had been warned by our hotel concierge.Would thoroughly recommend this venue, one of the highlights of our holiday.

Go!. This was an amazing time! We were, I believe 20 meters below ground. You are supplied with a wet suit, life jacket, water shoes & a helmet that has a headlight. Water was very refreshing! As there had been lots of rain, we swam more than walked. Excellent guide, Alina....

Bucket list-CHECK!. I can't say enough.... This was amazing. It was breathtaking and well worth it! My husband and I love Playa del Carmen and wanted to do an excursion this time. We were married in Playa and had been to a cenote, so decided to do Secreto instead. SOOOOO HAPPY!We took a taxi from our hotel, ($15US) instead of a bus and got there at 9:15am for a 10am tour. This proved to be very lucky. Usually they take you in a group of 8-10, but some people for the earlier tour did not show, so we ended up being 4 people in a 9:30am tour with Viktor. The whole experience was positive. Viktor was knowledgeable and answered all of our questions- he was patient and easy to listen to. Here are my tips1. take your own water shoes and make sure they are snug with a good sole-you do walk on uneven terrain and some areas in the water you have to walk very carefully as swirling sediment will impede your view.2. unless you are very athletic- take a walking stick! this helped my balance but also helped me navigate depth3. be steady on your feet- this is not for someone with mobility issues4. enjoy the silence and the breathtaking cave!When we came out we were greeted with a shot of 'mayan' water and towels, then taken for lunch and to see our pics. On one hand,I wish we had a camera, but on the other hand, the beauty of these caves are the silence and the light. Too much picture taking would have been too distracting from the experience. I also think (trust me) you need all of your hands for balance and navigation. Four people on this tour really worked for me- I feel 8-10 too many. Viktor didn't need to shout and it was incredibly intimate. There are times you are swimming, then crawling, then climbing. Our guide really helped to show how to step etc.. so as to not slip. We bought one pic for 20$ and were happy with that- lunch was good and they provided a service that took us back to our hotel. Do yourself a favour- spend some time in these caves. You won't be sorry!

Absolutely stunning!. Just completed a vacation in Playa Del Carmen and the highlight of the trip was The "Privilege" tour at Rio Secreto, which was my 4th time there. The "Privilege" tour, although a fair amount more in cost than the standard tours, was well worth the experience. Our tour guide, Raoul (with 3 r's) and photographer Juan were outstanding and showed us some of mother natures (Xilbaba's) most spectacular creations. RRRaoul and Juan's professionalism, knowledge and love of the cave gave us a once in a lifetime experience that will last a lifetime!Thanks for sharing one of the most incredible and beautiful parts of Mexico with us.

Amazing!. We had a wonderful time at Rio Secreto! Our tour guide Gonzo was so great and very informative. We loved the service, meal and the tour is something I will always remember and tell my friends and family about. I highly recommend this to anyone who is adventurous, loves water and caves and wants to be educated and informed.

Peaceful Beauty. We did the Rio Secreto as an excursion on our Disney cruise. I cant express enough how great this excursion was. The jungle, the people, the caves, the animals... it is quite an experience. The only two complaints i have (and they are not even very justifiable) is that you can not take your own camera and the there was a little bit of communication gap when it came to purchasing the photos and book. You have to watch your step at all times so i understand not taking your own camera in the safety sense. I wasnt real impressed with the photos we purchased but the memory and experience more than make up for it. We also had a lunch afterwards that was very good. The guides are very knowledgeable and you can tell that this is more than their job...they are passionate about what they do.
Amazing. The advertisements do it no justice. IN-CRE-DI-BLE!!!Tour guides are very knowledgable about the geography and geology. As much free tequila and food as you can consume afterwards too!!!

Mind blowing experience in underwater world!. Entire trip very well organised. Caves are something special and our guide Alfredo was excellent in knowledge and enthusiasm! The caves, the water and the experience is stunning and is a holiday must. Ok photos are pricey but they were good and food at the end reasonable. Great day out!!

Nice place to see but not as advertised on the website. Its a lovely attraction to see indeed a cave is impressive however not the price and the fact u can't use your camera, Im a very good photographer and won't accept your poor explanation that your photographers know exactly how and where to take great photos- I do too ,however of course I would not leave you $25 per photo- absolute joke and rip off totally spoiled this excursion
WOW. Short walk through the jungle absolutely amazing it was it was raining and thundering that just added to the romance of the trip the cave with absolutely amazing our tour guide was great

AMAZING!!!. We booked this tour from the website(not through a tour company) and so glad we did. They picked us up from our hotel and took us to a meeting point where we met other people going. Then we drove about an hour to the caves. One we got there we were assigned a tour guide and got ready to go see the caves(shower, get helmet/wetsuit/and shoes on).Carlos was our guide and he was THE best ever! He made sure we were all safe and explained in detail how the cave has become what it is today. It seemed like we were in the caves for hours! Then we got out and viewed our pictures for optional purchase( 1 picture $20, all pictures from the day $79, or all the pictures, a shirt, and bottle of liquor for $109) and ate a great buffet meal. Now I will say yes, the pictures are expensive but keep in mind a photographer follows yall inside the cave and not only captures everything as it happens but he also will find a few spots for you and your partner to take pics. All in all this was a FABULOUS experience!!!

Amazing experience. Some hiccups.. First off, the cenote is unquestionably one of the best in the world. It is beautiful, well-preserved and maintained so that visitors feel safe. I've been yo a few others, and they don't hold a candle to Rio Secreto. Its just that amazing.Our tour guide, Alejandro, was kind and knowledgeable. He wasn't the most fun guide in the world, but we learned a lot and felt safe and welcome. He was very accommodating of our mixed-language group.The hiccups:1. They never sent me a confirmation or any other email besides my receipt. When we called to inquire about our pickup, they told us to take a cab because they didn't know where to pick us up. We had entered the info on the form. We hadn't been contacted to find out more, or to let us know they weren't coming. This was obviously a fairly common mistake as they had a system for paying the taxi driver upon our arrival. 2. They refuse any cameras. They say its because people were looking at the digital camera screens and falling down in the cenote. However, they also won't allow go-pros or other mounted cameras. Instead, they take a series of posed pictures throughout the tour and sell them for $77-$170 at the conclusion. They need to change the policy.

A must see. Something to mark off your bucket list! Cavern is only open 4 years. Been to many other caverns, but this one beats them all. Saw so many things I've never seen before. There are areas that you actually float/ swim. A little tough if you have mobility issues.Highly recommend!

Amazing. We had 8 people in our group. We didn't know what to really expect. We arrived and were greeting all the great friendly workers at Rio Secreto. It seems everyone really enjoys their jobs, everyone was very friendly. Our tour guide was Alex and he was excellent, especially since we had one person in our group who didn't know how to swim(which you don't really need to know how to swim) and was nervous. Alex made him feel at ease and was very patient. Rio Secreto is a natural underground river with stalactites and stalagmites. It's just amazing to see. Use the walking stick, it was very helpful for all of us. Also, we learned that there's different levels easy, medium and advanced. When you get your wetsuit, they size you up and determine which course to take. We took the medium, kind of wished we had the advance. We all had a great time.

Awesome Experience at Rio Secreto. Awesome experience doing the underground tour. A little scary if you are afraid of tight spaces - lots to manoeuvre, however the guides are very good. The tequila at the end isn't too bad either.

Thrilling and utterly amazing experience.. My cousin and I nervously booked this tour on the recommendation of our hotel concierge. The pamphlet sites looked amazing so we were determined to go. Our tour guide Carrine sensed our nervousness and guided us through the most amazing scenery and fun experience of our entire trip. Ask for her.
Real Cenote cave tour. Not the playground manufactured cenotes but the real thing, great tour, great meal. The guide was very knowledgeable and cared about his ecosystem. Great tour.

Amazing Must-Do Experience!!!. I visited Rio Secreto yesterday and it was one the most amazing experiences I have had so far in the Riviera Maya. Our guide Alfredo was right when he said there are no words that can describe it!!! It is an experience that I strongly suggest to everyone! The tour took us through magical places combining the views of amazing stone formations and the contact with the crystal clear water. Our guide Alfredo was amazing!!! Apart from explaining in detail all scientific facts he created a feeling of security and we was always sharing his enthusiasm for the place!!! Our team had an amazing time and I strongly suggest the tour to everyone!!!

awesome. My family did this and it was great my 4 year old loved it and so did my family. tour guide was amazing food was great loved the whole day this is some thing everyone should do and try to do all three different tour i want to go back and do it again. so glade i took my kids they learned a lot. and got to see and do something amazing.

Mindblowing. Not gonna lie, I was a but terrified to do this, but I'm so glad I did. It was an unbelievable experience that I will never forget. Our tour guide was Rene and he was equal parts informative and hilarious. He even took us on a little detour at the end after we should have exited and we got to see some extra parts of the cave. If you are in the Riviera, definitely do this!!

simply amazing. Best trip we ever made in our 16 days vacation. Well worth the money and the guide (rodrigues) made it even better. Never met a guy with a bigger passion for nature and everything around it. Thanks for the great time.

Loss for words. Alfredo was our guide today. He took us down into the Mayan Underworld after a brief blessing of smoke and insence, and all I can accurately say is "wow"! This isn't purely a cave under the ground, this truly is a life changing journey. The long and twisting caverns systems are absolutely filled with stalagmites, stalactites, columns, and underwater features too! Everywhere you turn, you will be amazed.This wasn't simply some touristy trip. Very little of the long tour was on even or paved ground. You get in a wetsuit with lifejacket and water shoes for thos excursion. You will be walking through ankle to knee deep water almost the entire way and swimming in water over your head for a good quarter of it. If you want an adventure found only by cave divers without the danger of running out of oxygen in your tank, this is the closest experience you are going to find! Our guide Alfredo was a wonderful person and very knowledgeable and honest. I wish I had thought to give him a tip because he certainly deserved it. He helped my 7 year old daughter out almost the whole way through and we truly couldn't have felt more safe in such a magical and somewhat scary place. Somewhere I never knew existed, yet felt like I was returning home. Thank you again!

Most unbelievable experience ever!. Wow this was something out of this world, a must see if you are in the area. We did it perfectly seeing a few smaller Cenotes prior, all where impressive and then this just took our breath away. Thanks to Gonzo our awesome and very passionate tour guide!

A natural wonder!. We booked through our hotel to go to Rio Secreto- an amazing underground freshwater river near Playa del Carmen. It was going to be a rainy day so we figured it would be a great way to spend the day. What an awe inspiring place. They provide everything, transportation, wet suits, water shoes, helmets wit lights, Lunch and a guide! Very well run, not commercial feeling at all. There seems to be a genuine concern about protecting the history. Crystal clear water, small guided groups. Would definitely recommend it!

Fantastic!. This was my second time to Rio Secreto. They even asked which tour I had taken the first time, to take me on a different one, so I would see different things! Very wonderful guide, and hiking, and swimming was such an experience. I will definitely go again. They offer 4 different paths, which means I will go 2 more times to see the whole thing! They equip you with a wetsuit, safety helmet with light, and life jacket. No fear of getting lost or drowning. Not for people that are unsteady on their feet.

Great excursion. We took our 7 year old son (typically excellent swimmer) to Rio Secreto as an excursion while on a Disney cruise. Even though he freaked out in the caves, our guide, Pablo, was terrific with him. The water is cold and we appreciated the wet suits. In retrospect, I think the dark and the cold got to him. This tour pushed him outside of his comfort zone. I didn't mind the no outside camera policy. According to the Mayan tradition, we were entering a spiritual realm, the underworld. From our experience swimming and climbing and ducking through small tunnels, I believe that the caves would suffer damage from visitors cameras waving around. We were asked to immerse ourselves in the cave as a spiritual journey. It was nice to not see people taking selfies for a change. Yes, we took photos as a tour group. However, it did not distract from the tour. We purchased one photo as the rest were not in focus.It's rare that you can experience a living earth type tour with children these days. Seeing the water droplets that formed the caves really drove home the magnitude of the formations for all of us. Lunch was great. It was healthy and delicious.

AMAZING**********BEST TOUR EVER*****ESPECTACULAR. If you don't' like nature wonders, miracles and mystery, than this is not for you. This tour provided in partnership with Carnival cruise and it was great. The boat to Cozumel is top of the line with a bar inside and air condition. Then very professional drivers will take you inside the jungle on a 15 minute ride trip. We were very lucky and our guide, Linda, was amazing. She was very knowledgeable, patient and fun.She speaks perfect English and Spanish. Inside the caves" Cenotes" is amazing. It was a total workout. The tour inside is about 2 hours, but it is more than enough. Our photographer Sergio was amazing. he took pictures of us the whole time.After the tour was over, we finished drinking a native drink, prayer and a super great buffet included in the tour. The food was delicious. The pictures are 75 dollars, and they are worth it. Some reviews say they are expensive, but they are wrong. Normal cameras cant take pictures because there is no light, and second it will ruin the experience. 75 dollars for almost 60 pictures in great resolutions in cheap.thank you everyone for making our experience so good. hope to see you back soon

Pablo is the best guide!. My fiancee and I went to Rio Secreto back in May and we were very impressed. It was our first excursion in Mexico and we are so glad that we did it. Pablo was our guide and he was very knowledgeable and entertaining. We went on the Allegria route and we will return to see the other two the next time we are in Cancun! We have recommended this trip to all of our friends going to Cancun. It's just amazing. Also, like the other reviews say, grab a walking stick for the tour. It makes the experience much more enjoyable and helps with pulling a partner along if they are weak swimmers during the swimming portion. Stick+Pablo= good times! Oh, the buffet is pretty nice after the 3 hour tour as well. Caldo de pollo, arroz and some other basic stuff. Drinks cost money etc... We ended up purchasing the photos even though we felt it was a little on the expensive side. However, the photos are well worth it!

Excellent tour from our cruise. Luis showed our group of ten mostly middle aged adults an excellent time wading, crawling, and floating thru the Secret River caverns. One needs the agility to find your footing on very uneven surfaces and don't be claustrophobic. The pace was good. The sights were awe inspiring. The tour is conducted in such a way as for your group to be virtually alone 99% of the time. The outdoor showers are a bit of a joke but hey, you get a little used to the temp of the hew water in the he cave and it makes getting into the equipment easier.We were able to wear our own water shoes although they have plenty for guests to use.The food was very very good.
