We have taken many of the tours in Mexico and Carlos was the best guide we have ever had. Very informative and friendly. Small group so it is quiet and tranquil they make sure groups don't run into each other in cave. Then a fabulous buffet at the end all included. We will be back every time we can.

Unique. This tour is an unique and amazing experience! Alfredo is an extraordinary guide, friendly, funny and always watching over the group. I highly recommend this tour!!! A big "thumb up" for Alfredo! I hope to go back soon with my family!

Stunning!. Gonzo was our tour guide. He was super entertaining, very knowledgeable, and kind. The experience was breathtaking. It was the only excursion I did in Mexico and it was worth it. It is a little difficult to walk while in the water, but for the older women in the group, Gonzo helped them along and made sure we were all safe. It's tough to describe the beauty we witnessed in the cave and the crystal clear water. You'll have to see it for yourself! And I highly recommend you do.

Amazing Spectacle w/ Great Staff. We just visited Rio Secreto while on our honeymoon. This is a must see!!! The caves were beautiful and the water was so pure and clear. It was a lot of fun and our tour guide, Alfredo, did such a great job also! He was so nice but also very intelligent and a really funny guy!!! Highly recommended for it's beauty and also the professionalism of the staff!!!

Please go and support them. Throughout the entire trip this is the only time I witnessed real care and preservation efforts by staff of their natural treasure/tourist attraction. Please be advised that they ask you to take of your sunblock and ensure that the cenote system has the least bit of foreign impurities introduced into it, therefore you will see no automated vehicles going through here and that is how it should be. I am very happy we went, the trip was suggested by my parents and I thought it would be an after note to all our other excursions, I was wrong. This one was a highlight and some of the other trips we have done included chichen itza, coba, tulum, snorkling and horseback riding. The guide was very informative and ensured we had a great time on our 2hr tour. Our safety and comfort was always emphasized. Only one downside: no cameras. I was absolutely ok with this, however I believe that if the prices of the photos were lower, more people would actually purchase at least one photograph. The absurdly high price of $25/one photo was a little too much for us especially since we were at the end of our trip and were running low on spending cash. Too bad though we def would have liked one. I think that $15/photo would have earned the operation far more in the end just because its within a more reasonable price range for visitors. Also in Mexico a lot of tourist attractions try to gouge tourists, at the end of a trip it gets harder to justify $25 for just one photo. Sorry guys, I really wanted to support you some more but couldn't. Final Verdict: A must see especially since these cave systems are very unique to this part of the world. Better to support this one than others because they put nature first and that way maybe even your great-grandkids may even get to see it some day.

Mystical Swimming Underground. We were celebrating our 15th wedding anniversary, and we thought this particular place, sacred to the Mayans, would be perfect for the occasion. A natural underground cathedral, where Mayan priests went for oracles and sacred ceremonies.Our knowledgeable and professional guide, Pablo, seemed to enjoy the tour just as we all did, a true believer in his role and in the history of the caves and culture. He led us safely through rocks and water, showing us the way and counting heads (helmets) as we proceeded through the most difficult passages... A professional photographer came along with us, and had us pose in the different environments and atmosphere.My personal experience became a spiritual one, as I went further into the bowels of the Earth. I felt like a child in the womb of our Mother, safe and cared for, as I slowly made my way out in the open world. The climax of this journey happened when Pablo had us shut all lights out. We stayed in meditation in the absolute wet darkness of the womb, hearing only our own breath, heart-beat, and the water dripping down along the stalactites and into the crystal-clear pools...Once back into the green of the jungle, we were taken to the center in order to get rid of our specific equipment used during our trek. A tasty, traditional Mayan buffet was ready for us to enjoy, after having toasted with the rest of our group and guide with an herbal shot.Transportation to and from the site was well coordinated, comfortable and on time. All in all, a fantastic moment in our life, we will cherish forever.

Highlight of our vacation. My wife and I went to PDC to celebrate our anniversary. I had contemplated visiting Rio Secreto in the months leading up to our vacation, but decided not to. However, our first day there, I decided I would regret not going. I'm glad we went, because if we hadn't, I would have been right. Rio Secreto was the best part of our vacation. It was breath-taking. It's hard to explain the feeling we got when we got into the heart of the Cenote. It was a once in a lifetime experience. We really like how it was untouched; nothing man-made or altered. I really don't understand some of the negative reviews I saw regarding the conditions of the Cenote. Yes, the terrain is untouched and has a lot of undulation, but since there's no light, it's not slippery. Yeah, we bumped into rocks, but to me, that is part of the expectation. I would be disappointed if we walked through it like an amusement park. We never felt we were in any "danger" and the terrain was very negotiable. You just have to be careful. We didn't use the walking sticks offered and are very glad we didn't. I feel like that would have been more of a hastle than help. I also read about negativity regarding pictures. Again, I would expect that to be part of the expectations. I never felt like it was a nuisance and was very happy they took pictures. And the price for the pictures is high, but that's the case with every excursion in Riviera Maya we took part in. That's just part of it. I'm glad we bought the CD because those are memories I never want to forget. I would go back time and time again. The tour guide (my apologies, as his name slips my mind) was fantastic. I learned a lot about Cenotes and it was apparent he really enjoyed what he was doing. Not being a fan of Mexican food, I can't comment on the quality of the food, but my wife seemed to enjoy it. One additional comment: the guides split our group up into English and Spanish groups, which I thought was outstanding customer service. We went on other excursions where they were combined and trying to understand the guide was very difficult. All in all, I am so happy I decided to go, because this is an experience I will never forget.

Good but slightly disappointed ... We visited Rio Secreto on May 15th, 2014. This was the only excursion we did for our trip to mexico. Unfortunately our experience wasn't as great as everyone else. We did the before noon tour. Our resort Best Day representative advised us that this was a 3 hour excursion. All in all it was 6 hours. The best day driver was late in picking us up. Then we proceeded to drive through downtown playa del carmen for 20 minutes to pick up more people. When we got to their resort they were not there and seemed that the driver made the mistake. Once we got to Rio Secreto we sat in a waiting area for about 45 minutes waiting for more people to be dropped off. Then we spent another 15 minutes watching their video in three languages. The whole trip was disorganized. They told us which tour guide we were going with and then they kept changing it on everyone. Then you pile into a bus and drive thru 7 kilometers of terrible dirt roads. Once you get to the location and head in it was pretty cool. We had never done anything like this before. NOTE: they don't allow you to take a camera even though it may be water proof so they can sell you an overpriced picture disc. The tour through the cenote is definitely a cool experience. Our tour guide Julian was great. You stop several times so the photographer can take photos. They were very serious about not allowing you to touch anything in the cave. Make no mistake, there are no lights in the cave, you have headlamps to guide you. You spend about an hour and a half in the cave. Very minimal swimming. Then you go to the photo place where your options are $70 for maybe 10 photos of you, $100 for the photos and a t-shirt. Way over priced. Then you proceed to get some food and wait around til your ride picks you up to back to your hotel. The whole tour was disorganized and very pricey.

Had a great time. We visited Rio Secreto on May 24, 2014.It was a very professional tour. Luis was our tour guide and he was incredibly knowledgable and kept the group safe. He was very funny too. His english was excellent and he spoke french very well to accommodate one of the couples that was part of the group.I would recommend this tour as it's truly not something you see everyday or ever read about. The natural water is also very refreshing. I would have given this tour an excellent rating but the driver who drove us back to the resort at the end of the tour was completely lost and had to stop several times and ask people for directions. It ended up taking us 2 hours to get back to the resort compared to the 45 minutes it took to get their in the morning. Hopefully, you have a better driver.Lastly, we would have liked to buy some of the photos but found they were incredibly expensive based on the quality. If you want photos your looking at 30 USD to 100 USD depending on how many you want. Pretty sure they would get more business if they lowered this cost.

Loved this place!. We went on May 19th and absolutely loved this place! Luis was our guide and he was the best! He made us laugh throughout the entire guide. My husband and I are both outdoors people and love to explore. The only thing that could've been better is if the tour laster longer! I could have explored all day. Only issue is trying to contact someone at Rio Secreto regarding souveniors. We didn't really get time to purchase them at the tour and was told we could for up to two months. I can't seem to get anyone to contact me. Even though the souveniors are priced high, remember the money goes toward helping to perserve the cave.....so consider it as a donation!

Great trip, a little pricey. Luckily we were able to get a group discount (12 People), but even at $98 a person, it was still a bit pricey. Don't get me wrong, this was a great experience and one of a kind and definitely worth witnessing once in your life. It could have been that I've seen these types of caves in Bermuda, so I knew what I was getting into, but I wasn't blown away. Still, this experience is pretty cool. Being able to swim in the cave was awesome and you're really more walking/treading than you are swimming. You don't need to know how to swim to do this excursion. Our tour guide Luis was awesome and the whole team is professional and very helpful. They provide water shoes and a wet suit and after the tour you get lunch which was pretty good. Lockers are free as well. If you've seen the caves before and you're on the fence with this, I'd pass, but if you've never seen anything like this, you definitely have to check it out. You're on vacation, splurge a little!

This is a definite MUST DO!. Just got back from a quick visit to the Riviera Maya region, and definitely one of the highlights was our Rio Secreto outing! It's hard to describe the experience - part tour, part adventure, but totally amazing! The caves themselves are incredible, and we had the BEST guide, Paulo! The pictures on the website do not do it justice!

Gorgeous caves, pleasant swimming, but overly priced pictures.. Our very knowledgable tour guide Carine clearly loved her job, and gave us an excellent tour of the caves. The cave is stunning, and comprises of countless stalactites and stalagmites. Very tasty lunch afterwards, lovely jungle feel to the site. The only complaint is that the pictures are 25$ US for a single cd-rom of a single picture taken on the trip through the caves. The rest of the packages range up to about 100$ (don't quite recall), but it seems excessive considering they give you only a digital copy. Highly recommend, but be prepared to spend money if you want to keep a picture.

This was on the ol' bucket list for years. We visited Rio Secreto in early May. I'd seen pictures on Pinterest and put it on my bucket list ... was anxious to see it in person. We had read that finding this place on our own was difficult, so we arranged them pick us up from our resort. We prepaid with paypal and were able to save 10%. I believe we paid 50 each. The road through the jungle is very rough so if you have car sickness issues might want to take something prior.  You need to bring your own bathingsuit and bring money for pictures just incase you decide you want them. You can't take your own camera or water camera but they have a "professional" taking pictures which they sell for 70 US plus money to tip your guide. The pictures are pricey but I decided to buy them. Our photographer was just ok .. didn't take alot or do anything very interesting but wanted some pics of this once in a lifetime adventure. Our guide , Julio, was excellent!!! He met with our group and got us set up with Wetsuits, helmets with lights, water shoes and lockers. They broke us up in groups by what language we spoke. We were told the groups would be no more than 10. Julio was very patient and informative. We felt safe at all times. They will offer you walking sticks ... everyone should take one. The tour is difficult walking and the stick will be a big help. Before entering you are "blessed" by a Mayan preist which we found somewhat offensive. This cenote is magnificent and worth the effort and expense. We had went to several other cenotes but I dare say there isn't one to match this one. The meal they provide ... well I decided to wait to get back to our luxury resort. We did drink the water /koolaid they had to drink and we both got Ill so i would bring your own bottles of water and stick to that. There were all ages and physical abilities on this tour .. though it was challenging ... YOU CAN DO THIS and you will be glad you did.

Outstanding: Great natural site and excellent value. Rio Secreto is an amazing underground river in caves filled with stalagmites and stalactites.This is an exceptionally well organized excersion, including the round trip transfers, drive to the area, outfitting you with the water shoes, short wetsuits, life jacket and helmet with light. You will feel silly putting on the gear, but it is all well worth it as certain areas of the caves are rocky and slippery, and it's super to have the life jacket during the swim sections as you can just float over to the next chamber. There were 6 or 7 of us in each group and we were divided into 3 groups. Our guide was Victor and he was super, knowledgeable and friendly and careful. You may feel having the photographer is a "money making spin" and it may be, but at the end it is lovely to have a momento of the trip, and you have the option to buy just one photo for $25, the whole disc for $69 or an entire package for $99 including a bottle of some lovely syrupy anise flavored local Mayan alcohol, of which you get to taste after the tour, before lunch.Lunch is buffet style and there is plenty to eat, ice tea and fresh water are provided or you can pay $2 for bottled water or sodas. It's about 4 hours, because of the van rides there and back, and lunch. I think well worth the time and money.

Awh Inspiring. Highly recomended by our car rental place so we had to check it out. It was super. Only thing dissapointing is we couldnt take our own pictures. They take the pictures and they want over $20.00 each. The helmets really stunk. If you could bring an extra water proof flash light, it would help see more stuff. the lights on the helmets suck. Bring swimming goggles too. Next time we do it we will bring the extra stuff. Simple mexican food for lunch was good. The guide was very good at his work too.

Fun & Challenging. Although I read prior reviews I wasn't expecting to be blown away assuming this was just another touristy thing. I was wrong. If you're looking for a safe adventure and a break from the beach chairs and margaritas this is a good choice. It's not cheap at $79 pp (although we were able to get 10% off) but the guides are great and for 1 1/2 hours you're in a different world. The formations are amazing, the water super cold and the trail is challenging. Definitely grab a walking stick, makes walking easier. All the gear is provided, lockers and facilities are clean even though in the middle of nowhere and the lunch at the end is fine. It's not 4 star restaurant quality food but it's much needed fuel for rest of day!
Don't miss this!. And even a beautiful Mayan incantation before entering the cave. Victor was a superb guide. It was truly a spiritual and reverent experience.

Wow!. They advertise this as a life changing experience and it lives up to the hype. The cave is absolutely amazing. Our tour consisted of 6 patrons and our guide, Alfredo. He was awesome! He has been spelunking for 20 years and it shows, he truly loves his job. His attitude and enthusiasm for cave exploring is transmitted to his guests. My wife and I can't say enough good things about Alfredo, he did a wonderful job. Words can't describe what you will see in the cave, it's something you have to see for yourself. Definitely worth the time and money to visit.

Muchas Gracias!. Andrei and Nicolae B. Rio Secreto is definitily worth seeing! The caves, the stalactites/stalagmites are striking. We enjoyed it a lot. Our guide,Paolo, was very nice - friendly and professional. My dad who is a PhD in Geomorpholgy was impressed by his knowledgeable presentation and expertise. Great job, Paolo.

Wow!. Rio Secreto is definitely a once in a lifetime experience. They give you a wet suit, water shoes, life vest, a helmet and head lamp, plus a walking stick if you think you will need it. They take you underground into a cave. Part walking, part swimming, your tour guide takes you deep into the cave for about 2 hours. You swim in the fresh clear water and see the stunning architecture of the stalagmites and stalactites. It was such a memorable experience. I HIGHLY recommend it!! Just Wow! Thank you, Pablo for such a great tour!

Great experience!! Do it!!!. This was one of the highlights of our trip. Absolutely beautiful. Our tour guide was so knowledgable and excited to share the information with us. We had different types of people on our tour (young couples, older couples, and friends) and everyone seemed to enjoy it and it didn't seem too challenging for anyone. It's truly a one of a kind experience! They served food after buffet style. It was pretty good too!

Amazing!!. My husband and I booked this excursion on our honeymoon to Riviera Maya. We wanted something unique to do other than lounging around the resort, and this was the highlight of our trip! The cave was beautiful! The experience was unforgettable! Our tour guide, Luis, was the best!! He was friendly, knowledgeable, and funny. When we arrived, we were split into 2 groups, one for English-speaking visitors and one for Spanish-speaking visitors. Luis' English was very easy to understand. If at all possible, I'd recommend requesting him for your guide. If you are looking for something spectacular to make your trip memorable, I highly recommend Rio Secreto and Luis. You will not regret it.

Rio Secreto Adventure. This was a wonderful trip into the some of the cenotes (caves) and the main underground river of the Yucatan. Exciting, fantastic scenery, fascinating, fun, and amazing geology. This is a highly recommended stop for visitors to the Yucatan around Cancun. Our guide, Alfredo, was very knowledgeable and a genuinely great person. Lunch was provided after--great food, too! Highly recommend Alfredo and this tour.

Great Experience!. If you are interested in seeing beautiful underground caverns, I highly recommend visitors to come to Rio Secreto. The beautiful caverns are an amazing experience and our guide, Carlos Pineda, made it that much more pleasurable due to his knowledge. At the end of the cavern experience you are sat down for a delicious authentic meal (buffet style). Was well worth it!

Beautiful. 2nd time there and went through a different part of the caves. Loved it. We were the only couple that spoke English out of a group of ten and the guide made sure he explained everything to us so we didn't miss anything.

Beautiful Adventure in the Cenote. From the moment we arrived our group of 12 were well taken care of. We had to split into 2 groups for safety reasons, but ended up meeting within the cave for a group photo. Paulo, our guide, was awesome and very helpful. Incredible experience. Would like to explore other centoes next time.

Great Caving Experience !. Hard to add to the mostly rave reviews with which I 'd agree ! I would say that as a 66 year old guy with bum knees and size 14 shoes I was somewhat challenged by traversing the water filled cave floor which was often uneven and sometimes slippery. Our English speaking guide Carlos was only on the job for a month but he was excellent and if he'd said he had 5 yrs experience doingthis I could easily have believed him. He was very well informed on Mayan lore and the geology of the cave system and very attentive to our personal safety and to having us get the most enjoyment out of this almost two hr underground journey. Thanks, Carlos !

Amazing experience!. My wife and I visited the Rio Secreto as part of an excursion on a Carnival cruise. Our guide, Luis, was the best. Funny and knowledgable, he put us right at ease. It took about an hour to get there from the ship but it was worth it! The caves are so unique... there is NOTHING like this I've seen before.Be forewarned, it's quite the physical trek and there are, um, bats. Again, though, it was worth it. Don't miss it!

Amazing experience you won't find just anywhere.. Great little adventure if you don't want to sit at the pool all day. Rodrigo was a very enjoyable guide with an obvious passion for what he does. The length of the trip was just right given the amount of exercise involved. Be prepared for sharp rocks, lots of swimming and climbing.

Absolutely breathtaking!!. The tour of the "secret river" is amazing. The scenery is beautiful and our tour guide (Louis) was entertaining and informative. If you do only one thing in Playa de Carmen, make sure it's this tour.

Our favorite excursion!!. This was an absolutely amazing experience. We did not really know what to expect, but since we are not really the 'lay on the beach all day' type of people, it was perfect! It is slightly physically demanding, and I would suggest bringing your own water shoes (I wore Chakos), but the wetsuits they provided were more than adequate for the temperature of the cave and the water. Ahh, the water. It was SO beautiful. So clear, and clean, and the cave was breathtaking. We went through in a group of nine, which was just the perfect size- enough helmet lights so that it did not feel claustrophobic, but a small enough group that no one was ever left out and we were able to get answers to any questions. Our guide, Jorge, was FANTASTIC. Absolutely awesome. Funny, patient, enthusiastic, and very obviously passionate about his job and the cave itself. The meal afterward was fun, the hibiscus tea delicious, and lazing about in a hammock after the trip and the meal while waiting for our van was wonderful. We did buy the pictures- the photographer was at every turn, he was so talented and spry!We also very much appreciated the lockers, as we could bring nothing with us into the cave.I would go again in a heartbeat!!

Amazing experience!. We booked this excursion through the Carnival cruise ship. Allow about an hour to go by ferry from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen and then a van ride. The tour guides are waiting for you at each destination and the same when you're returning to the ship. When we arrived at Rio Secreto you will shower off, put on a wetsuit, water shoes, lifejacket and a helmet with a light. Before you enter the cave there will be a traditional Mayan ritual. You're put into small groups before you head down into the cave. You will hike, walk and swim in the cave. The cave and formations are amazing and the water is crystal clear. Cameras are not allowed. Lost cameras and/or the batteries will destroy the ecosystem. A photographer stays with your group and will take individual pictures and group shots. Buy the CD, the pictures are worth it! Hector was our amazing guide! He's very fun & knowledgeable! When you have finished the tour there is an authentic Mayan buffet lunch waiting for you. We highly recommend Rio Secreto!

Rio Secreto 2014. My husband and I found this excursion from a Princess Cruise, we were on Ruby, and I'm sooo glad we picked it! Since we were coming from Cozumel it did take a bit to get there (ferry and then van ride) but worth it. If you are already in the area, for reference ~ Cancun is about an hour north and Tulum ruins an hour south, then even more of a reason to give it a try. Our guide was Hector and he was very good. Very knowledgeable, made it fun and that our group had a good time. I really enjoyed this tour as we were in small groups so easy to hear and see everything. If you've ever been to Luray caverns in VA (or similar caves) then I'm sure you'd enjoy this adventure. You hike and swim through the caves (wet-suit & life vest provided) and the water was so clear and not too cool (high 50's-low 60'). Lunch was provided after and then had time to wander, shop or hang on the beach at Playa del Carmen before ferry back to Cozumel. Definitely one of the best tours out there.

Amazing. Absolute awesome experience! We arrived and were advised to wash off got or wet suits and life vests and chose our water shoes we were also outfitted with helmets with lights. Our guide went through the safety and advisory part of tour and then we were off. The trek to reach the caves was longg and uneven paths at times. On arriving in the cave we climbed down some steps and made our way into water. Beware water is cold but you acclimatize. The tour took us through creaks and cervices as tour guide explained stalactites and stalagmite formation. Some areas were deep and involved a little trek through water. A photographer accompanied group and took many pics along way as you are not allowed to bring anything into river even underwater cameras not allowed. The entire tour was around 1hr after we came out washed off and got a chance to see pictures and purchase if desired and then we enjoyed a nice lunch. Would recommend for the adventurous traveler who enjoys natural beauty. Physically demanding so not for those with back, knee or any bony ailments. Overall a very good experience!

A fantastic, beautiful experience. Approx. 90 minutes in one of the best caves I've ever been in. The guide was fantastic (Kiki). He was knowledgeable and obviously loved the site as much or more than we did. Your kids will love this experience and will retain the memory forever, check for ages, we were all adults.

Awesome adventure!. Overall, this was an amazing adventure and one I will not soon forget. I was very close to giving it a 5/5 star rating, but held off for a few reasons. Let's get them out of the way first. If you are planning this as part of a cruise excursion and your ship docks in Cozumel, be prepared for a long journey of tendering and driving with a crowd of fellow travelers. They provide all the gear, but the life jackets and wet suits are cold, damp, and smelly. If you have your own wet suit, bring it. If you don't mind cool water, pass. Even the helmets smell. I realize this is probably hard to avoid, but it was still nasty.Now for the actual adventure. Our guide was Alfredo. I have never met anyone more passionate about his job. I doubt he even calls it a job - his joy for what he does and the Rio Secreto is palpable. We knew, before even entering the cave, that we were going to experience something amazing, and we truly did. Once I was inside, I forgot about the travel time, and the stink of my gear. The cave was beautiful. Alfredo was very knowledgeable about the cave and river and was able to answer all of our questions.You really don't need to know how to swim to enjoy this adventure (you have on a life jacket), but be prepared to climb, duck, and squeeze through some tight and tricky areas. Fortunately, Alfredo made sure that we were all safe, and pointed out any areas that required a bit of extra precaution. After the tour, a lunch buffet was provided. The food was decent, nothing spectacular, but it was included in the cost of the excursion, so that was nice. I highly recommend visiting Rio Secreto, even with the few cons that I mentioned. Don't let those minor nuisances keep you from experiencing this amazing destination.

Great tour, very interactive. Great tour, very interactive. Guide was friendly and knowledgeable. Being only a recently found river it is very pristine and seems to be well cared for, guide was very clear about the damage we can cause to the ecosystem by touching anything but the path we walked and swam along.All in all, a great tour.

Extraordinary!. Excellent adventure, very well organized. Lia, our guide was passionate, knowledgeable and interesting. Loved every minute of it. Highly recommended. I wish all tourists respect the environment so it can be enjoyed by many for years to come. Thank you Lia, you were totally awesome!

Don't tell everyone. Cons - water shoes had holes in the toes, wetsuits were already wet, shower was cold, lunch SUCKED!Pros - beautiful, beautiful, beautiful! Loved the cave, loved the tour, loved being in a situation I've never been in before! It was sooo cool!

Pretty cool. Saw this in planning a trip back to Cozumel and thought it was something I HAD to check out. I was worth taking the ferry over to Playa and a quick collectivo down the highway. It lives up to the billing. This tour is not rushed, so take it all in. Mauricio was the guide for the group and was informative and generous with his time. Moved the group well but not fast. Be prepared, it's not a stroll down a sandy beach. Plenty of climbing, a little swimming and lots to see. At first, I admit, that the rules of NO cameras was a disappointment, but once taken, I understand why. I'm not sure that I would have made it through with my underwater camera without breaking it myself. And if they stopped every time for a person to take a pic, it would take away from the experience. The CD of pix taken by the cameraman alongside us was a bit expensive, but after the fact worth it. Decent buffet at the end and plenty of time to relax. You won't see caves like this anywhere. And to think the Mayans did these without flashlights and mapping is astounding...

Awesome!. One of the best decisions we've made for a long time. On Apr 14th/'14, another couple and ourselves, despite a bad back and 3 bad knees between us decided to do an adventure that didn't involve leaving early and getting home late. As we were staying a short distance from Playa Del Carmen, another plus for not having to travel half the day, we signed up with Sunwing Tours at our hotel (also fabulous - Grand Sunset Princess). Everything was first class and nothing left to chance as ALL the equipment was provided - water shoes, wetsuits, life jackets, helmet and light. Just follow the rules re: showering, jewellery, cameras, etc. and enjoy. Our guide Paulo, was outstanding and obviously very passionate about his role in introducing people to his special obsession. The food afterwards was excellent, the special drink was wonderful and the pictures would have been impossible for anyone other than the professional photographer - definitely worth the fee as the best souvenir you could bring home! The Carters & Wamers

An Amazing kid friendly adventure. Just returned from a week at Playa Del Carmen and was so glad we booked this. We tell everyone to go. Love the natural atmosphere it really makes one feel like a true explorer. We are a family of six with my youngest being four it was hard to find activities that would satisfy us all. This place nailed it. It is extremely kid friendly and the guides are so informative and they teach you so much about the beautiful caves and underground rivers. Hector was our guide and he is fabulous. They take care of you from the beginning to the end. He was there for all our needs and took really good care of the kids. He even teamed up with our youngest and called him "the leader" which made his day. We all felt like we were in national geographic magazine in a place that was unreal. The water is cold but the life jackets are great. They provide you with all the equipment and have sizing for all. The food was great. I would recommend going early the cave seems fresh we were the first group in. Plus you have the rest of the day to go to the beach.

Interesting tour of pristine underground rivers (cenotes). My wife and I visited Rio Secreto during a 4-night stay in Cancun in March 2014 for our honeymoon. I was very interested in checking out the Yucatan cenotes and swimming through the refreshing, ground-filtered water. This was one of the only tours that didn't involve adrenaline junkie obstacle courses involving the cenotes. The drawback of the adventure tours for me was that they don't seem to preserve the natural environment as well, exploiting it more to push large numbers of tourists through.Rio Secreto features several guides speaking multiple languages, from English and German, to French, Portuguese and Spanish (of course). Our guide, Mauricio, spoke great English and had a wealth of geological and cultural knowledge of the environment, including how the cenotes were formed, how they're affected by human interaction, and how the Mayans incorporate them into their culture. We had a few older people in our small group (8-10 people per guide) and he ensured their safety throughout.The terrain is rough and rocky underwater, involving some stepping (i.e., staggering) and some swimming (while wearing rubber-soled water shoes). It's pitch black in most places, so you wear headlamps (along with wetsuits because the water is chilly). The guide has an underwater flashlight to cast excellent lighting on some phenomenal rock formations and showcasing some great colors.The tour includes individual/couple and group photos throughout - available for purchase afterward. The price of all 75 photos was about $70 but worth it. It's not possible - nor would it be easy - to take photos in the underground environment. So it's nice to have a professional taking high quality shots from angles only they would know through experience.The tour wraps up with a really nice buffet lunch. It's casual but tasty and authentic Yucatan-style food.We got transportation to/from our Cancun hotel and the driver was prompt both there and back.Overall, the tour is highly recommended, especially for people looking for a more relaxing immersion in the cenotes. My only complaint is that the tour territory doesn't involve more lengthy swimming/floating.
Great tour through the underground rivers. Good value for the price, very friendly guides, totally different experience. The food provided was also very good compared to what we got in other tours.

Subterranean caves and rivers. Loved the beauty and adventure. Crystal clear cool water which we hiked in through several caves following along a river. They supplied all the gear. Our guide, Raul, was excellent. The photographer captured amazing shots that we purchased for a very reasonable price. Great adventure!

Wow! An experience not to be missed!. Don't listen to the warnings in the AAA Mexico Guide - they are ridiculous! The road to the caves is not a problem at all and the walk to and from the cave entrances are easy even for us older, less mobile types. Walking in the caves is a bit of a challenge but so worth the effort. Paolo, our guide, led a group with 3 mobility limited older ladies and two non-swimmers and we all had the best time! This is absolutely an experience not to be missed. From the moment we arrived at the reception area Jesus made us feel welcome and answered all our questions. Once we met our guide Paolo we were outfitted and taken excellent care of. Paolo absolutely made this the best experience. His knowledge and attention to us made it doable and enjoyable.

Incredible!. We booked this excursion thru our cruise, Ruby Princess, because we both agreed we needed to step out of our comfort zone! Boy were we glad we did!From the minute we stepped off the ship in Cozumel, Angel and Tomas were there to get us on the ferry to Playa del Carmen and then on the minivans to this amazing hideaway in the jungle! It was a little bit bumpy once we got off the highway but I was already armed with Dramamine from the cruise and ferry ride so it was all good. Once we arrived, our already small tour group of 22 was further broken down to 8 and assigned to Rodrigo as our guide. He seemed rushed at first, while getting us suited up in our wetsuits, water shoes and helmets (all part of the package), it was easy to see why....he wanted us to have as much time enjoying this incredible experience as he does! Equipped with our walking sticks (when he encourages you to take one...listen!), We headed off on a trail into the jungle and were met by a gentleman who performed a sort of cleansing ritual before heading into the cave. After entering the cave itself, it became so evident that Rodrigo loved his job! He was so enthusiastic about sharing the beauty of what lies underground it made the experience that much more wonderful. The formation of the stalagtites and stalagmites were almost whimsical in some areas and, while they don't allow the guests to bring their own cameras, they do provide a photographer who was with us throughout our journey capturing individual, couple and group shots! The cost of individual photos were pricey so we bit the bullet and got the CD of the entire tour as it made more sense. We did enjoy a shot of something similar to Sambuca with Rodrigo after we emerged...not for the faint of heart! Ha! The "snack" as the excursion description told us was more like a full lunch and was delicious! Beware...the green sauce is NOT guacamole but one of the hottest salsas we had ever tried! Not long after lunch, we loaded into our minivan and were taken back to Playa del Carmen. We only had about an hour of free time before we needed to regroup for our ferry ride back to Cozumel and the ship. We would have liked to of had a little more time there but not at the expense if cutting our time with Rodrigo!If you are looking to do something different, spend the day out of the Sun and to see some of the beauty that lies below Mexico, make this a part of your trip! You won't regret it!!

Really an amazing adventure. We booked this excursion through a Carnival cruise. It was fun and informative. We were given hard hats (good thing since I bumped my head a few times!), wet suits, and life jackets. Our guide was very helpful and concerned with everyone's safety. This is not an excursion for anyone who cannot move around well in uneven, tight spaces. We most walked through the water, but did float / swim at times. The water was cold, but not miserably so and was easy to adjust to quickly. We also had an authentic Mexican meal after our tour that was included in the price. I would highly recommend this for adventurous people.

Amazing Secret River truly is amazing!. This was one of the best excursions we've ever been on. We came on a Carnival cruise to Cozumel and everything was totally taken care of from getting to Playa Del Carman on the boat, vans to our destination, wet suits, hardhats with lights and venturing with a great and informative guide (Carine) through the amazing cave. Afterwards, a wonderful Mexican lunch was served and we headed back. Total time about 6.5 hours. Well worth the fee on this one!

Secreto Best Kept Secreto. We took this tour through Carnival from Cozumel. This was the best excursion we have been on. It takes a while to drive back to the cave which is not very deep. You arrive to a settlement in the middle of the forest. There are restrooms and lockers. You will be issued a wet suit, life jacket and helmet with light. You will need aqua shoes or you can get some there. You can't wear sandals. Because the river is pristine and human contact can destroy that, you will be required to shower off before entering the cave.This cave was considered sacred by the Mayans. Before we entered the cave, a Mayan descendant burned incense and said a blessing. It sounds cheesy but really wasn't.The cave has uneven areas and I strongly suggest that you take one of the walking sticks offered; they come in handy.Pedro was our guide and he was great! He was very passionate about his love of the cave and was very sincere. He ensured that we all stayed together and took good care of us.The water in the cave varies in depth and there are a couple of areas where swimming is required. There are no lights in the cave; the only lights are on the helmets and the guide's flash light and cameras are not allowed. You won't miss not having a camera because they take fantastic photos that you can buy later. Now, for the cave itself...it is beautiful with stalagmites, stalactites and columns galore. There are little blind catfish swimming in the water but I never saw them. However, do not touch them; they are still living and if you touch them, they will stop growing. After the tour, we enjoyed a delicious Mexican meal and sampled a shot of some honey and licorice flavored liquor. Note- be careful of the green sauce,it is hot!

Underground River. I really enjoyed this. Love that they kept the cave natural with no artificial lighting. I didn't think the water was that cold with a wetsuit. I actually wish the tour took us through more of the deeper parts, as I liked swimming through the cave much more than walking through it. The photos are admittedly overpriced, but I still though it was worth it. They really should give people the option of taking their own cameras.

Awesome Adventure. Booked this through the agent at our resort. This tour was recommended to us by friends. Our group consisted of 6 people. My wife,I, and our 6 yr. Old son and another couple with a young child. Paulo our guide was spectacular with the kids. After our ride a few miles into the jungle we prepared for the best tour ever. We were underground for over an hour and a half and unlike other tours we have been on, we never saw or heard another group of people. There are several routes used by the guides so you totally feel alone. Paulo was very educated and passed information along to us and even let the 2 kids hang on him while swimming through the deep water. They have a buffet at the end with what is described as traditional Mayan food and it is wonderful. I would not recommend this tour for anyone that has difficulty walking on uneven ground as this consist of most of the tour along with stooping down and hunching over. I do recommend this tour if you want an adventure and to visit someplace that does not have that "tourist" feel. Did I mention that Paulo our guide from Brazil was incredible?

DO THIS!. If you are even thinking about doing this...DO IT!!! It was by far one of the coolest things I've ever done! Just FYI: the water does stay cool year-round so you have to wear a wetsuit. You can still feel the cold water but the experience overpowers the cold! Beautiful, breathtaking and educational. The food was yummy and the staff excellent.
Oustanding and unique!. Oustanding and unique "Jurassic Park" like experience! This was a once in a life time experience! It really feels like being at the Batman cave :)

Very authentic experience. I had booked Rio Secreto prior to going to Xplor with my 2 teenage kids. After swimming in Xplor's underground caverns, I was concerned that Rio Secreto was going to be much of the same thing. This was not the case. Where Xplor and Xcaret caverns have obviously been touched by and modified by humans to cater to the tourists, this was not the case with Rio Secreto.Rio Secreto was a very authentic experience. I liken it to caving with a water component. The cavern we entered appeared to be untouched by humans and was an amazing experience.The ground is quite uneven and there are many rocks and ridges to navigate. You are offered a walking stick prior to entering the caverns and I recommend you take one. You are not allowed to touch the formations even to support yourself. This is where the walking stick was very valuable. As it floats, it was also very easy to swim with.You are given wet suits to wear as well as water shoes. We packed our own water shoes, towels etc, but these were not needed at all. Basically you only need to have your swimwear, dry clothes (the clothes you arrive in are fine + underwear) and your wallet for purchasing the photos if you choose. You are given a locker with a key to put everything in when you arrive. We purchased a disk with all of our photos on it for $69; I personally think it was worth it. The photographer takes quite a few pics while you're down there and he ensures you are positioned to get great shots. You are not allowed to take your own photos in the caves.If you're doing the tour, lunch is served after. Our guide, Alina, was great.If you're afraid of dark spaces, this may not be for you. It is very dark down there, but you are given helmets with lights to help. We enjoyed this experience very much.

So unique,,. Amazing experience and unique. Luis our guide was wonderful! He look out for our safety and made it fun. He took special care of those in need. No need to bring anything as all is provided. They have free lockers and equipment is provided.. No photos allowed and was disappointed as the photographers camera was not working hey we had to pay full price for very few pics. Otherwise I would have given full marks. They seem to care about the environment. Luis our guide gets top marks!

Wow - really awesome day!. This was an awesome day - super cool tour of the caves, something that I will remember forever. The caves are big, most of the ceilings were at least 20 feet high, so I never ever felt closed in or claustrophobic at all.Our guide was fantastic - the experience was awesome. We had to swim about 4-5 times, but it was for a very short distance. I HIGHLY recommend the walking stick, as the floor of the cave is very uneven and the stick helped greatly.Overall just a fantastic experience. The only downside was the waiting for the vans to take you to/from the caves, and to/from your hotel ( you have to stop off at all hotels for guest pick ups). But...it was worth it...awesome day!

Among the most spiritual. Was an amazing experience. Julio was a wealth of knowledge and insight into both the scientific and spiritual significance of the cenotes in both the Mayan and Yucatan histories. Among the most spiritual experiences we've ever had. Truly something we will never forget!

Expensive photos duplicate charge.. We enjoyed the experience touring underground this past September 26 and were impressed by the various language skills and knowledge of the tour guides. The problem is if you want photos. They have a photographer along with the tour documenting the tour. They then offer the DVD for $69. After viewing the photos, we decided to purchase. They ran the card but their wireless lost connection. So it was run again. They were upfront about it so I knew to look for a duplicate charge. When I got the bill in October, I notified Rio Secreto of the duplicate charge. They requested the statement showing the duplicate which I gladly provided. They replied that they were sending to accounting to return the charge. After that they have been unresponsive so I have had to open a dispute with my credit card company. It appears this is a common problem. My advice, open a cc dispute rather than deal with them on a customer service/business level. That is why the terrible review. Otherwise, I would probably rate average to very good experience, but prices keep it from anything higher.

Very cool experience. Make reservations and buy tickets in advance - they plan for particular sized tour groups. We were very lucky that a large part of our group was very late, and our guide agreed to take just the two of us on the tour. Alex was our guide, and he is fantastic. You can tell he is passionate about the cave and what he does, and is engaging and fun. He sets the tour according to who is on it, physical ability and moving through the cave. Perfect. I'd recommend a walking stick - not for walking, but to use as balance in the cave to help you not touch anything. You'll need it. The constant photo taking was a bit paparazzi like, but when you see all the photos at the end, it was worth it. You will want to buy the photo CD! I love the buffet lunch at the end, and the guide eats with you. That was a nice touch, to get to spend more time getting to know them and asking questions. Food was good, and the grounds are just beautiful. Nice equipment and buildings. There are lockers, restrooms and showers. Can't say enough good things about this place. You should do it.
Great guide. Awesome and unique experience. The guide (Miguel, I think) made it all the more worthwhile. He speaks great french and english, and made sure everyone had a wonderful time.

Budget for the Photos CD!. The Rio Secreto was an outstanding and enjoyable tour for our party of four! You will be provided with life vests and wetsuits. There are changing rooms and bathroom facilities on site. Although underground and often dark, I found the tour area to be spacious and one that can be happily suitable for claustrophobics. Extra Costs: If you appreciate keepsakes of your travels, be sure to make an allowance in your budget for the CD of photos you will have the option to preview and purchase at the end of your tour. A photographer will be taking photos of you as you make your way through the caves, some candids and many for which you will pose, and the result is incredible. The cost is approximately $70USD and we purchased one CD and shared for duplicates. There are t-shirts and baseball caps available for purchase as well.

Just amazing. I don't think I've ever seen anything as beautiful as Rio Secreto. Just breathtaking .. In wetsuits and life jackets you are guided through a maze of stalactites and stalagmites. Newly discovered in 2006 the cave still remains unaffected by humans. The guides are knowledgable, passionate and careful to preserve the cave. Before you walk down in the cave you undergo a Mayan blessing.You do not have to be an athlete to experience the caves but the ground is uneven with a lot of step downs and step ups that are quite steep. There are walking sticks available that you can use.

Amazing. This was truly an amazing tour! It is so relaxing and so interesting! Our tour guide, Hectar, was wonderful! At the end of this tour you get a buffet meal which was absolutely delicious! We will definitely be doing this tour again if we are ever in the Cancun area again! Fabulous job!

rio secreto - a must see. An excursion to Rio Secreto was breath taking! My husband and I took this trip in March 2014 and was in total awe of this place. Our guide Paulo was knowledgeable, passionate and very informative. The caves were magical and a must see if vacationing in Riviera Maya area. We purchased the CD of the pictures that were taken of us in the caves by their photographer and would recommend this CD to everyone. Very well done...and a great experience! We would definitely go again. Thanks to Paulo! Excursion included meal and alcohol or water. All gear included.

Wonderful experience. Rio Secreto was a wonderful experience. Victor was our guide and he did a fabulous job. For anyone with walking issues, it might not be an outing for you. During the tour, we were up and down over various size rocks and boulders. Walking was on very uneven ground, in and out of the water. I did find that I wasn't able to fully appreciate the beauty in the caves because I was too busy watching where I was walking, and passing the info on to the person behind me in our single file row. I never felt that I was being hurried along though, but didn't want to hold up the line so I could spend more time just staring at the beauty. Would I do this excursion again - YES! They had the equipment available for everyone at the facility, so you didn't need your own wet suit, helmet, life jacket, etc. Towels were also available and there was a good free buffet available to everyone at the end of the tour. We did buy the $70 DVD of pictures, but were able to negotiate a much better deal than their asking price.

Rio Secreto. This site was spectacular to say the least. Our tour guide Alberto was not only knowledgeable but his overall enthusiasm and love of nature added even more to the tour. I will be recommending this site to others as a "must see".

Awesome Experience. Rio Secreto was mind blowing! Such an amazing experience, if you are in the area you MUST explore this site. Our guide was named Lia and she was so great, our group was split language wise and she was very fluent in both languages. Very experienced and knowledgeable, we learned so much!After the caves we had shots and a full buffet of great food (not so vegetarian friendly though)Only part that kind of sucked was not being able to bring our camera down into the caves. But after I realized two things; 1: its far too dark to take photos and 2: you are able to enjoy the sites and experience it WAY better rather than worrying about taking photos.They'll try to sell you the photos afterwards, we bought just 1 on disc for $25. Expensive but worth it. Photographer was actually really experienced.GREAT TRIP!

Rio Secreto. Absolutely Awesome. The staff, especially Alex went beyond expectations. They did everything to accommodate our circumstances. Great for the whole family. My teens actually asked questions!

Mind Blowing Adventure. I never thought someone my size (I am a large man) would be able to Spelunker (Caving), but through this tour, entering the Cenote, and wading through the water, around Stalagmites and Stalacites, seeing the creatures, and experience what Pitch Black darkness really is. The time blew by, and the whole family wanted to do it again, and that's the highest praise I can give! Great staff, friendly and the food was a bonus!

Unique experience!. I wholeheartedly recommend this trip to anyone within driving distance of Rio Secreto. I have taken the trip twice now, and I have been blown away both times! As earlier reviewers have noted, be sure not to wear any sunscreen when you go. They give you a chance to shower off before entering the cave system, but the water is pretty chilly. They will also provide you with a wet suit, helmet, water shoes, towels, and a locker to store your belongings. I have a pretty sizable beach bag, and it fit easily in the locker! The only thing you need to bring is a change of clothes for after the tour. Be sure to wear your swimsuit when you arrive! For those who are a bit germaphobic, I would recommend bringing your own water shoes. They have some for sale at the location ($10 USD/pair). The tour starts with a bit of Mayan history and culture as a man gives the group a Mayan blessing, and then you are off. Once in the cave system, you will be in awe the entire time. We did the 1.5 hour tour, and it felt like just enough time to get the gist of what all is down there. The water is pleasant year round. It's not warm by any means, but it's very refreshing and you adjust quickly with the wet suit! Lunch is also included in this price. Nunes was our guide for this trip, and he was so kind, knowledgeable, and fun! He did a great job explaining how to navigate the occasionally tricky terrain. For the most part, the caves you'll be exploring are pretty roomy. Parts can get tight at times: at one point, we had to put our faces in the water in order to get under some low-hanging stalactites, but that was the worst that it got. You can buy photos for $25 USD per single photo or pay more for the disc. My husband and I could not bring ourselves to pay that price, but the memories we made will stay in our minds forever! Really and truly, this is the most unique experience I have ever had in Mexico. Be sure to book this trip!

Impressive !. First time in a cave and it was AMAZING. The guide (originally from Mexico City) was informative and hilarious. We noticed other guides speaking Russian & French to visitors. A must see for any one interested in geo-tourism. The water was clean and crystal clear. And the included buffet lunch was great.

Magical. I am so grateful when a "natural attraction" for tourists is built on a foundation of care, planning, and appreciation for the place itself, which is not always the case in Quintana Roo. Rio Secreto is this. It's also a magnificent experience of the area's subterranean complexity and beauty. The cost includes your wetsuit ( plan to wear it over a swimsuit for time spent swimming underground), a helmet w/ attached headlight, a shower (wear NO nonorganic sunscreen or bug repellant; you're entering the region's aquifer, and its ecosystem), a wooden walking staff (take it! The underwater surface is uneven), and afterwards, a buffet lunch. We spent well over an hour in the cave system, in a small multinational group, with our guide, Jorge, who was deeply knowledgable as well careful and funny. We bought the CD of photos; well worth every peso going to the support of this fine example of true ecotourism. There are no lights, no cement walkways, no intrusions on the experience. A claustrophobe might have a few tough moments; although there are no narrow passageways or crawl-throughs, you are definitely underground, and in a different world. Personally, I felt as if I could have stayed down there much longer, it was all so strange and beautiful. Highly recommended!

Rio Secreto an incredible experience. We loved this trip which I believe was 4.5 hours from being picked up at our hotel (the Barceló Maya Beach) to being dropped back off.: you wear your bathing suit and rinse off from the neck down in an outdoor shower prior to getting in a wet suit and life jacket and water shoes: lockers are provided to stow your stuff and a wrist band they give you is the key to opening it: no sunscreen needed on this trip: it's a little physical so if you can't walk or climb uneven surfaces this isn't for you but you don't have to be athletic or anything. You walk through some scrubby jungle on the way to and from the caves but it's not very far....5 minutes maybe.: the buffet lunch was more than adequate and tasty and you have to pay for the drinks (at the end of the counter) so don't....they bring you jugs of good liquid refreshments to your table which are included: a photographer and your guide are with you at all times. Some photos are taken without you knowing, others are posed.: our guide was Nunes (pronounced New-ness...not sure about spelling) and he was extremely impressive...so knowledgeable, helpful and patient. Our group was comprised of Spanish speaking people except for me and my husband for whom he had to repeat everything in English. I don't know how these guides do it. He is a treasure. (Having said that, one of my least favourite things was having to wait sooo long to hear the English part so I could understand.): we forgot our credit card and ended up wanting to buy the photos but no problem...through email and paypal we just bought them and downloaded them yesterday from back home in British Columbia. They weren't all good...but most of them were and we got 28 photos for what turned out to be about $78 Cdn. Not bad value and they send you a set of stock photos of plants and animals which inhabit the area. Of course you get to see every photo on an I-pad before committing.Go...you must see this :)

Amazing Caes!. Tour was excellent! Guide was great, the caves were incredible!! The provide all wetsuits and water shoes and you walk and swim through the under ground cave/water system. Lunch afterwards was also good.

Exciting, Amazing Experience!. No trip to the Myan Riviera is complete without this amazing adventure. There were new sights around every corner and, just when we didn't think it could get better, something else new and amazing was around the next corner. Rio Secreto more than lived up to the pictures and claims in their brochure.The staff was all professional, well organized, friendly, helpful, and very knowledgeable. Our guide, Mau, taught us so much about the little-known life of caves, in particular, the cenotes of the Yukatan. He answered all of our questions with easy to understand answers that showed not only his amazing knowledge, but his love of sharing the cenote experience with others.If you only take one excursion while on your Myan Riviera / Cancun vacation, make it Rio Secreto. You won't be disappointed.

Amazing Rio Secreto - Mexico. A group of norwegian women visited Rio Secreto march 16th. It was an exciting and wonderful experience ! Our guide Poulo was very knowlagable and proffesional . Very structured and safe tour . A "must do" when visiting Yocatan !

Rio Secreto. The cenotee was beautiful, but a lot of it is above water, I liked the underwater cenotees much more. Once we did reach the water part it was really awesome. They did this weird ritual thing before starting our tour with this local Shaman. I did not like that and would have liked them to warn us and tell us that we can wait for them somewhere else if we did not want to participate.

Amazing experience. The trip was great. Gonzo was our guide and you could tell how much he loved the secret river. He was so informative and interesting. Everyone loved it including 4 teenaged boys who are hard to please. It was my 3rd trip to Cozumel and it was great to do something different. The only downside was the horrible van driver who hit a dog by the entrance gate and kept going. It really upset us but he didn't bat an eye. He just kept driving as we heard the poor dog squealing. Other than that, we really loved the trip and would highly recommend it.

Great experience, natural beauty. We loved Rio Secreto! It was so wonderful to be in a cave that hasn't been overdeveloped to accommodate visitors. There were no lights, no paths, no handholds, it's as if you wandered straight into the jungle and were the first people setting foot into it. That being said, you should be fairly sure of foot to venture here, though they do offer walking sticks that's I'd recommend - I didn't take one but I had a husband to hold on to. :) A stick would have been a bit smarter, mostly for the areas where you're walking in shallow water and can't really see where you're stepping. There were some older folks on our tour and they did just fine.Our guide, Hector, was fabulous and friendly; in fact, everyone there was very cheerful and helpful. The caves were beautiful, swimming in them was a real treat, and the water was not actually that cold. We floated in a small cave area and turned out all our lights for a real sensory deprivation experience. They include a brief Mayan prayer before you go in, and a shot of the local alcohol when you get out (yum). They do give you wetsuits (you don't have a choice), which helps if you might be chilled by the water. Also a helmet and a floatation vest and reef shoes. There's an option to buy shoes for $10 if you don't want to wear the shared ones. Also be advised that you spend a fair bit of time standing around in just your swimsuit, so if you're someone that's shy about it (like me), just brace yourself for it. But it should definitely not deter you.A photographer follows you and you take several breaks to snap photos, of course they want you to buy them. And if you want photos, you have no choice since you can't bring your camera. We bought the CD of them all for $69, it was steep but they say the money goes to helping preserve the natural state (may or may not be true, but hey). I'd recommend this to anyone (as long as they can do the hiking requirements - it's not strenuous by any stretch, but you do need a sure step). There's no need to be highly adventurous, curiosity is all you need. The only folks who might not like it are those that are afraid of the dark or have claustrophobia, since some of the areas have very low ceilings.

Rio Secreto - Beautiful, Unique experience.. My girlfriend and I visited Rio Secreto Saturday, February 22nd, 2014.We booked the 10 am tour and were fortunate enough to have only two others on our tour (couple of crazy girls from Sweden - nice people and we had a great tour).All of the positive reviews are true - and the pictures attest to the natural beauty of the place.When we arrived we were greated by Sac Nicte (means white flower in Mayan). She speaks English, Spanish, French and is currently studying Russian. Very impressive. She answered all our questions, and introduced us to our guide: Nunes. from Angola.Nunes was great and knowledgeable and put up with all of my good natured teasing.THE CENOTE: The pictures speak for themselves - absolutely stunning.PHOTOS: I'd like to comment on the few reviews regarding no cameras allowed (and thinking it was a scam to get you to buy the photos from them). This is not the reason at all. We were in a small group, and I've done a lot of spelunking. Individuals would not be able to keep up with the tour with everyone stopping to take photos. Additionally, you do have to pay attention to where you are walking, so there would likely be injuries / falls with people taking their own photos. Not to mention you likely would not get any quality photos down in the cenote without professional equipment.But, the main reason for no cameras that made sense to me - was people DROPPING CAMERAS into the cenote, and POLLUTING the water and ecosystem when the batteries erode.We bought the entire picture package of photos - and got a nice bottle of the Mayan liquor XTABENTUN. The word xtabentún means "vines growing on stone" in the Mayan language.This is a liqueur made from anise seed, and fermented honey produced by honey bees from the nectar of xtabentún flowers (a species of morning glory whose seeds contain ergine and have hallucinogenic properties------WEeeeeeeee =)FOOD: I thought the buffet after the tour was great ! Variety of options, and eat as much as you want. I especially enjoyed the chicken that I put over the white rice.Overall I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this tour if you enjoy nature and the unique experiences of countries you visit.

A Must See. Rio Secreto is a place that you shouldn't miss. It is a fun experience and is very interesting. The place is huge and the formations are really amazing. The amount of fish isn't that much and they are very small. There are parts where it is hard to walk and you really need to get down low and you can't hold on to any of the formations. The wet suites aren't too uncomfortable but I didn't really enjoy the water shoes that you get for free. The water in the caves are very cold and the caves themselves are pretty dark. They provide you with helmets but again, these aren't the most comfortable things and my helmet smelled like an armpit. Those things don't really matter though, the experience itself was amazing. Our guide Manuel was very good and gave us a lot of information about the cave. We were put with some people from France on our tour so it took a little longer because everything had to be said in English and then French too. Don't get too excited for the lunch after the tour as I found it not very tasty and lacking in options. There are hammocks all around once you are done with lunch but many of them have holes. The overall experience was amazing. From the swimming while underground to the interesting formations. There are some spots that could use improving but that's not the main part of Rio Secreto.

Rio Secreto underground caves.. Excellent tour of the caves. Our guide, Irina, was very knowledgeable. The tour was a little bit physically tiring though. Be prepared to geta few scratches from the rocks!

Something you should not miss. With excellent guides, proper equipment, it is an experience not to be missed. Our guide was amazing and we never even realized that we were underground. There is some walking over uneven ground and as such, this may not be for you, but aside from that. To be able to float in an underground river is something we have never done before, but would do it again. One amazing experience.

Rio Secreto. Rio Secreto is an excursion off the beaten path, for the moderately adventurous. You are given wetsuits, shoes, a lit helmet and life jacket for the tour of the underground river. Best piece of advice is to take the stick they offer. I did not think I needed it but then took my husbands. The footing is very uneven in places and it will be needed. It is very informational, very beautiful and interesting. Our tour guide Sandy, was very knowledgeable, very sweet and friendly. The lunch they serve after was tasty.

Amazing. I highly, highly recommend visiting Rio Secreto. It was beautiful and breathtaking. Pictures and words cannot describe its beauty. Rodrigo was my tour guide and he was extremely knowledgeable, kind, and very eager to answer all questions we asked. There are lockers for personal belongings.

Nature at its best.. This was a cruise ship excursion. I had read the reviews and they were very positive. As a result I my expectations were quite high. Often that leads to disappointment but not in this case. From the get go the staff were very efficient and organised in moving the groups through the prep stages wet suits, helmets, etc. Lockers were available and included in the cost not an extra couple of bucks. A short jungle walk and then enter an underground oasis!This is nature in the raw, at its finest! Walk, wade and swim the underground river. There can be very few sites in the world that offer this experience. I thought I would have liked to tape my underwater camera in but I am glad I didn't. There pics were much better and often you do need to concentrate to maintain balance.We didn't take a credit card but simply exchanged e mails and after paying on line I downloaded a boat load of super hi resolution pics. This was a vacation hi-lite. Though this is a nature preserve I can see the day when the public is no longer allowed such up close access to the caves. Those who miss out on the opportunity to see this natural wonder will regret it.
great. GONZO was the best guide ever. incredibly informative and knowledgable and a load of fun too. now i know what stalactites and stalagmites are... :D

Great excursion, very beautiful. Great excursion if you're staying in the Playa del Carmen area.The experience is great and the views are amazing.The only problem I had was the wetsuits/shoes they give out seemed dirty/smelly/old.Overall, I recommend.

Need to fit and have good balance!. Wonderful experience and a visual delight. A shame they do not allow a waterproof or any camera in and you have to buy your pictures. Guides are good and may speak a bit too fast. Very interesting info and geological facts. The uneven footing is natural and I would not want it any other way. Just be aware that this is physically taxing and those with balance issue, the walking sticks may not be enough. For Canadians... do NOT drink their so called filtered water. Not the same as bottled. My mistake!!

Great experience, CAMERAS ARE NOT ALLOWED!. what i liked? the experience, the tour guide (Khorge i think his name) and the whole 1.5 hour was worth it. what i did not like? so i booked my visit to rio secreto through Best Day who arranged my transpiration from Now Jade to Rio Secreto and the tickets as well, the guy in best day told me it's okey to bring your camera inside the cave, i asked him if video is also allowed and he said yes, i also asked him about the babysitters there and he told me they are all certified babysitters like the ones NOW JADE provide. but he was laying to get me on board.when i went there, Cameras were not allowed not for photography nor for video even if they were water proofed. by the end of the walk they provide you with options to buy the pictures they took for you during the tour, the options are basically pushing you to one which is the $79 for all pictures. you either get that or you buy $25 per picture. the third option was adding more cost for shirts and other worthless stuff. so basically we decided to buy the $79 package, and when we returned home we found out that there is many pictures the photographer had of us which was not included in the CD. the baby sitter was one of the employees and she was not certified. but i decided to go on with the babysitter they have because i did not have any other choice. she did not speak proper English but she was nice. the baby sitter was sitting in an outdoor location which i did not like but we were lucky that the weather was good. overall, it's a great experience, and since we are Muslims and my wife wear hijab, Khorge our tour guide helped us through the process and provided us with the swimsuits in advance and allowed my wife to wear what she need to cover up properly before we began the trip which we really appreciated.

Rio secreto. Jorge was a great guide. We had a lot of fun. The lunch was great. It would be helpful to know where the sharp rocks are located. The staff was very helpful and the service was quite good.

Very Cool. Great treat for something different on our vacation in Cancun. It was a lot of fun and the guides made you feel comfortable. It does stink that you can't bring in your own camera, on the other hand, the tour needs to keep moving and that would be bad to have to wait for someone to take their pictures - it would not be safe either, if someone got separated from their group. But the costs of the pictures is just SO EXPENSIVE. The lunch buffet was not great - just really blah food. I wish there was a way to drive in on your own instead of having to wait to go back with your van. We booked a "tour" which I think this experience would be much better if we had our own car and didn't waste half the morning picking up other tourists from other hotels and dropping them off on the way back etc. That certainly is not Rio Secreto's fault, but just to warn you, your tour in the caves is approximately 50 minutes. It's the drive from the parking lot through the "jungle" and the lunch that is the vast majority of your tour. This tour would be really great for families with older children. I don't know what the min. age is, but I don't think anyone under 10 would be ok with going in the caves. I think a family with tweens would really enjoy this as a neat experience the entire family would enjoy and a memory for life. A group of friends or couples would also like this too. The caves are a really neat experience and I am so glad we chose this over swimming in another cenote!

An amazing experience. We had a great vacation in the Mayan, and this was our favourite excursion. Everything is very well organized, the guides are very knowledgeable and the caverns are amazing. Something different from the everyday, the tacky and the average tourist trap. This is an experience.

Natural wonder.. A recently discovered vast set of caverns 75 feet under the jungle. Stalagmite & stalactite formations thousands of years old. Walk & swim amongst sheer natural beauty. All this & an authentic Mexican lunch. We were so glad we chose this excursion from our cruise ship.

Rio Secreto tour is very interesting. This is a very interesting tour through underground caverns full of limestone formations. The guide was both very informative and helpful. The trip involves both walking through shallow water (uneven surface) and swimming through deeper water. A native luncheon/snack which was enjoyable was included in price and offered at the end of trip. I strongly recommend utilizing the walking sticks offered at beginning of tour as surface is uneven. I would not recommend this trip for any one with significant balance issues, limited stamina or for young children otherwise it is great and worth the fee. Also the DVD that is available for an additional fee I thought was worth the money.

Rio Secreto. Fantastic trip! Disregard the negative reviews here-many written by older people on cruise boats. This is an amazing cave, newly discovered and "raw", in that there's no graffiti and no trash. The delicate stalactites and stalagmites are completely intact, some thin as a pencil, some thick and meeting to form sculptured columns. The trip to the cave involves about 10 minutes on a dirt road. The hike thru it can be done by anyone even slightly active. You will see an untouched cave, with natural pools and caverns normally only accessible on a longer spelunking trip in other caves. Here you can walk/swim through it. Gypsum and limestone sparkle in the light, and the water in the pools is warm and clear. There are a couple short swim/floats (you're in a wetsuit and life jacket, which they supply)-and during these, you can roll on your back and look up to spires of rock better than any cathedral. Caves like this do not last untouched for long and I salute this company for limiting the age and numbers who see it. As an aside, we thought the food was awesome. Tasty chicken and rice with three complex hot sauces to go on top, plus fresh salad w/ veggies from their garden. (Again, the people who complain about the food are most likely favoring the generic cruise food.) Go, go, go if you can-try to do it in a smaller group but see it any way you can. Really. Go. Be brave. The guides are wonderful, will help you get through the tight spots. Go and be grateful. This type of untouched raw gorgeous cave is an endangered wonder.

Wonderful experience, excellent guide!. We chose this as our excursion off our ship. What a winner! Our guide was Carine, and she was top-notch--kind and very knowledgeable. Take the offer of a walking stick due to uneven terrain during the walking portion of the trip. Guides will carry them when you swim if you think it would be a problem. Beautiful cave, best excursion of our trip, although zip-lining was a close second. I am 65 and in reasonably good condition, and had no problems at all. Lunch and a celebratory drink were a pleasant plus. Don't miss this if you enjoy the unusual and something "out of the box." Only problem was getting charged for the CD when I purchased a T-shirt (difference of $52 dollars) which I hope to have remedied later today.

Truly on of the best caves we've ever been in.. We went during an excursion on board the carnival magic. We ported in Cozumel and took the tender.
