The tender ride was the worst experience for my wife and everyone else on board. We hit bad weather and everyone was throwing up on board the tender. To make matters worse, the tender ride was about 45min long. It was not so bad on the way back as the weather had calmed down.  The cave itself was amazing and so worth the tender ride to get there. Truly fascinating. We had been deprecated into a group of 7 and then we had our guide, Jacque. He was from France. He was a great tour guide. We were so secluded from the other groups. They tell you that swimming is a must but you have a life jacket so it is not actually a requirement. My wife cannot swim and was worried but after we got to the part where you are in 30feet of water she just paddled her way thru and was fine. The tour operators are very careful about preserving the stalagmites and I appreciate that very much. The food afterwards was wonderful. The prices for the whole cd of pics runs about 69.00 but very well worth the price. Cannot forget to mention the Mayan liquor that you are given shots of afterwards. It's black licorice liquor, pretty much Sambuca. It was awesome!!! Recommend this tour highly to everyone!!!
The best natural place to visit))). This place just amazing ))))) the wonder on the earth !!!!! Our guides were very hospitality))) thanks to Nico))) he is the best!!!

Amazing. We visited Rio Secreto on an excursion from our Disney Cruise. 2 adults & 2 kids ages 11 & 10. It was amazing!! Our guide Rene was great. It was just a small group of 4 of us. They took pics throughout. The tour lasted a little over an hour. Afterward we had a "celebration drink", liquor for adults & iced tea for the kids. The food was very good. This is a must see if you're ever in the area. The $69 picture CD is worth it. We got lots of pics from the caves.

What an amazing excursion. Except for the very hazardous trip to and from the site, the entire walk/swim through the cave, the quality of the explanations and answers provided by Carim our tour guide were greatly appreciated and the few minutes in absolute darkness 25m(75 feet below ground with just the sounds of the water was just awesome..

Great hidden gem. Epco was my tour guide and did a great job of explaining how everything was formed and how it has developed over the years. Would recommend him !Great overall experience felt like I saw and learned more than most of my friends in geology classes. Literally went in expecting very little as we picked up the tour just for fun without seeing any brochures or reviews.wish we could have brought our own camera to take more pictures. The photographer there is good but there is maybe at most 20 shots of you posing at certain parts. Wanted more pictures of the adventure. They do give you some very nice ones of animals and parts of the cave if you buy the CD.

Great experience . This was an absolutely wonderful experience! Equipment of water shoes, helmet, wetsuit and life jacket are provided, though you can bring your own water shoes or buy them at the facility. I would suggest bringing your own as the rentals have seen better days and we're not in the best condition. The rest of the equipment however was well maintained. The subterranean excursion was so amazing, something that is unique as you walk, wade and float your way through the tour! I was also impressed with the multilingual guides, making it easy to understand directions throughout the tour. Again, so happy we ended up doing this as it is definitely a unique experience!
Wonderful. I've never worn a wetsuit before. The guide was very helpful to me during this tour otherwise I might not have been able to complete it.

Beautiful and astonishing nature, great tour experience. This is one of those experiences you must have at least once in your life, immerse yourself in a subterranean river of astonishing beauty in a safe but thrilling way. This cave is different from your past cave experiences, it's not the die hard espeology adventure, no mud, no crawling on your belly but neither the artificial Disneyland like experience of other caves with paved roads, light and sound, etcThis real cave and subterranean river exploring in a safe, and only mildly demanding way, what a great way to experience a glimpse of the ancient Maya view if the world and to emerge out of the "cenote" as these water deposits are called with a feeling of rebirth, faithful to the Maya tradition.The tour was very well structured, our guide friendly and knowledgeable and everything well organized, they provide all the equipment, wet suit, water shoes and helmet, the tour ends with a nice traditional lunchDon't miss it

What a fantastic excursion!!. I was in the Mayan Riviera the first week of February, and my wife and I, along with two other couples, visited this beautiful site. It was fascinating to visit, and I would go back again! Our guide, Raul, was exceptional. My wife walks rather slowly, so Raul helped her through the entire excursion, which everyone with us appreciated. The best part of the day was when we all turned our lights off and sat in TOTAL darkness for a minute. All in all, a phenomenal day!!

An amazing Adventure!. I visited Rio Secreto in Feb 2014 while on a cruise. I had read the reveiws on Tripadvisor and was eagerly looking forward to this one of a kind adventure and it did not disappoint. Our guide was Mau who is so passionate about this place and eager to share his knowledge. He guided us and was just such a gentle soul you couldnt help but love him. The caves are amazing and I appreciate the efforts that are put in place to keep them as safe as possible while still allowing touring. I LOVED swimming in the clear cool waters! Everywhere you looked was something new and amazing to see. I am slightly claustrophobic but had no troubles at all during the excursion. The food is amazing and the photos are excellent. I highly recommend this adventure..and feel like it is truly an adventure of a lifetime.

This a must do!. This one of the most parts of my vacation. Our guide Kiki was great. I had some difficultly (due to a bum leg) but he made sure I was always on firm footing and he is very informative. The caves were spectacular and surprisingly warm. To think this cave was discovered by accident in 2006 is amazing. It is impossible to describe the feeling you get floating in an underground river. (peaceful). After the tour they fed us a delicious meal and gave us a shot of a special tequila. Mexicans know how to give great value for the price. If anyone is debating doing this tour thet should take it. My friend who is claustrophobic had no problems whatsoever. All you'll need for this tour is a sense of adventure and the ability to walk through uneven terrain. Hope you go!
Indescribable. Amazing experience!!! Whole excursion was very well organized and our guide Alfredo was sooooo nice and passionate!!! Quite expensive, but it's worth every penny! :)

What a great experience!. I visited Rio Secreto caves while in a cruise with my wife. We bought the excursion through the cruise and we were hoping we made the right decision. It was definitely worth it. We were taken in the Catamaran from the port in Cozumel to Playa del Carmen and were greeted there by guides from the get go. Playa del Carmen was beautiful. We were given a few instructions and we were on our way via air conditioned, very comfortable vans. The ride from the beach to the entrance of the cave complex is about 20 min with no to light traffic. Once you get there is about another 10 min through a non paved road with plenty of turns and ups and downs, but the vans are pretty comfortable and the drivers are experienced. When we got here we were greeted by our cave guide Hector, he took us to change and provided all the necessary gear, from water shoes to wet suits and helmets. We were also provided lockers to place our belongings at no additional charge. Our group was ten people. Then our adventure began with a quick walk through the jungle while Hector told us the story of how this cave system was discovered. Before entering the caves we stopped for an authentic Mayan ceremony to grant us permission to descent in to Mother Earth, I thought this was really cool- be respectful during the ceremony- after which we began down into the cave system. It was absolutely breath taking. Our guide Hector was great, he knew every inch of the place, and was knowledgeable about the stalagmites and stalactites and different formations he was eager to show us. He had the group stop at one place while we floated in the water and had us turn off our lights and just feel nature around us for a couple of minutes, it was incredible. To be honest i don't really remember how long we were down there, but as we emerge for the quick walk back to the complex, we couldn't stop talking about the experience. Hector then took us to change and we met for a shot of this sweet liquor - on the house-, we raised our shots and toasted for the awesome day and the chance to have shared the experience. They do not allow you to take a camera into the cave, however there is a second person from the guide team who follows taking great pictures of the group, couples and singles, which is cool as you would probably miss a lot of details if you had to worry about taking your own pictures. Now, this guys were top of the line, by the time we were done with the shots, of which I had two myself, our pictures were ready for viewing on individual iPads for each couple or single person. You get to choose either a single picture for US $25, or the whole thing for US$69. I thought that was a bit pricey, but nevertheless purchased one of the pictures that I really liked. They were all good, to be honest it was difficult to chose, and I was tempted to buy the whole thing, but as I said - it was pricey considering the actual amount of pictures I would've gotten of my wife and I. Anyway, we made our choice and were taken to eat lunch while our picture was being burned onto a CD. Hector then showed us to the buffet and tables, he gave us a quick description of the different foods available and we sat down still as a team to eat and talk, the food was fresh and really good. Meanwhile Hector was actually nice enough to go get some peroxide, cotton and bandaids for some of us who had a small scratch her or there from rubbing against a rock or two. He actually sat down and cleaned the scratches and applied the bandaids. After a plentiful lunch, our picture CDs were delivered and we got to relax for a bit in the chairs, swinging amacas and beds they have in the gardens, before getting back into our van for the drive back to the beach. Our guide Hector was awesome, he stayed with the group until we were all sitting in the van and waved us off. Although you are not obligated to tip your guide I think these guys deserve a little something specially if you're treated the way Hector did my group. The trip back to the beach was a bit longer than the trip from, due to additional traffic during rush hour, but we used the added time to talk more about the experience and check out the city sights. Back at the beach, we still had about 45 min of free time to walk around or hit the beautiful beach just paces from were our van dropped us off, we were told at what time to be back for the ride back to Cozumel via Catamaran, and then released to do as we pleased. My wife and I hit the stores and then came back for a quick dip in the crystal clear water of Playa del Carmen, before we were back in our sits for the ride back to the port. All in all, what a great experience, the right choice of excursion, a great day!

A must do excursion!. This was the best part of my trip! The small group sizes are great, because you get the best experience. Our guide was fantastic! To learn about the cenotes and what they mean to the culture and life of the people was great. The food at the end of the experience was delicious...better than most of what we ate at our resort! Definitely put this on your activities list when you visit!

Sister bucket list tour in the Mayan under world!. We went on the cave and underground river walk and it was an awesome experience! Considered it a 10 and crossed it off my bucket list! We went in a group of 6 participants plus Luis our guide and a photographer. All the equipment was included, wet suits, life jacket, helmet and light and water shoes! Luis explained the safety procedures very well and we walked in the cave for 1.5 hours and really enjoyed every minute of it. Although I'm not a swimmer, Luis was very patient when we had to float across a deep pool and guided me thru this portion. One of my sisters needed extra help with the steps due to balance issues and he totally made it okay and we didn't feel rushed at all! All six in our group would recommend this tour and would do it again!

Adventure Tours of a Cenote. I wasn't sure what to expect of this tour, as we booked through the cruise, but it was great. The price included the ferry from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen and van to the site, as well as gear and lunch. Our guide, Hector, was great and left us all feeling calm, even in the tight spaces of the cave. The photos turned out great, but were a bit expensive at $25 per picture and $70 of the whole package. Lunch was a delicious and fresh buffet.

One of the nicest cave experiences we had. One of the nicest cave experiences we had. This is a beautiful cave system. Walked through a lush jungle to get there. We really enjoyed the experience. No walkways or ladders once inside so walking is difficult at times but you don't care because the place is so breath taking. Some areas you float along. Most of time your in the water usually no more than knee deep. Water is so clear! There is a good reason why they don't allow cameras inside...there is a good chance it will be broken by the time you leave. Very uneven surface...We fell several times...they do have a photographer with your group the entire trip and while the photos are pricey they are very well done. Lunch was provided...it was ok...buffet with one hot entree... Restroom and showers facility nice....Guide Paulo from Costa Rica was very nice and knew his stuff...The lights out was a very unique experience...total darkness inside the cave...hard to explain...something you have to experience yourself.

Wonderful spelunking experience. I've been to many other caves in Canada and New Zealand, and Rio Secreto was amazing. Floating in the water through the caves was a very unique experience. Our guide, Alfredo, was very knowledgeable and made sure we all got through safely. We were in a small group of only about 10 people. I would highly recommend.

Brilliant experience. A very special experience, nice escape to a very serene part of the jungle away from the busy resort of Playa del Carmen, albeit down a very bumpy road. Very well organised and led by excellent guide Jorge, quite challenging negotiating the rocks under water, certainly only for people who have good mobility. So peaceful and very beautiful. Absolutely loved it, shame we have no photos to remind us of the experience as so many were taken by the photographer but couldn't justify paying $25 US for one, sadly they have set this price too high and would sell many more if they lowered it to say $15. But it was so memorable I don't think I will have any trouble remembering the peace and beauty of the underground world just by closing my eyes!

Amazing!. This is a very unique place to visit. We loved it. The most fascinating excursion we've done in the Mayan Riviera area. Keep in mind you can't be claustrophobic in the least. You are underground for about an hour or so. We had a lunch and alcoholic drink called d'aristi xtabentum which was very good.

Brilliant way to experience the cenotes. I loved this trip, it was a fantastic way to experience the cenotes. Our guide Pablo was very knowledgeable and helpful.The experience was great as they seemed to keep the group sizes small - there were only 6 in our group plus guide & photographer. My favourite part of the experience was when we turned all our headtorches off and just sat for a few minutes in the absolute dark - different to most things I've experienced whilst in Mexico peaceful, calming and personal.Be warned you are in underground caves so it is dark, wet and uneven - not suitable for people who experience claustrophobia.Pricey photos again - the only downside again to this experience was the price of the photographs, if you are not going to allow people to take their own photos then the price charged for the professional photos should be cheaper.That said I really enjoyed this trip and I'm really pleased that this was the excursion we booked if you want to see the cenotes this is a great way to do it.
Stalactites and stalagmites. Thanks nico for a very informative tour, great food at the cafeteria and definitely worth experiencing and yes the light green sauce is HOT!

Awesome !!!. We went to rio secreto February 5 and it was amazing the cenotes are beautiful we've been to a few before and this is a definite must see it's like nothing we've ever seen before our guide gonzo was so passionate about the cenotes that you couldn't help but fall in love with them like he is. Pictures don't do justice on how beautiful the cenotes are ! We only went for the half day but next time are going to do the longer tour !!! What a great experience and couldn't say anything bad about it :)

Excursion from Carnival. Took a cruise to Cozumel and a ferry to the mainland. After a 30minute air conditioned van ride to the caves, we got there.Loved this excursion! It was beautiful and Renee, our guide was awesome! Would definitely recommend!

Great excursion. Well worth the money.. We had a wonderful time on this excursion. We were looking for something that would only take up half a day and this fit the bill. Transfer from our resort was on time and very quick. The road in was rough but not as bad as others have mentioned. Alfredo was our guide for a group of eight. He was very knowledgeable and spoke great english. The caves themselves are indescribable! Nice buffet lunch after and prompt transfer back to the resort. All in all a great excusion.

Beautiful cave system. We visited Rio Secreto via a shore excursion on carnival. Our ship docked by Cozumel and we were taken via the ferry to Playa Del Carmen. The ferry ride was terrible... just an FYI for anyone who might have to take the ferry to get to Rio Secreto like we did. We were prepared however and took Dramamine, mints, and sat on the bottom level as close to the center of the boat as possible. This helped to prevent the seasickness. There were other people vomiting on the ferry ride. HOWEVER despite this terrible ferry ride, we would still do it again, because the cave system at Rio Secreto is so incredible! It was worth any seasickness we acquired. Pros:The folks at Rio Secreto provide everything; wetsuits, headlamps, watershoes, walking stick, even a personal photographer who follows you around and takes photos as you go. The guide was knowledgable, funny, and clearly loved the cave system. The cave system is as beautiful as the pictures show. Following the tour in the cave, we were given a lunch that was fairly good. Then we were allowed to lounge in the plentiful amount of hammocks that are around the area. All-in-all it was an amazing day!Cons: We did not like the photographer situation. It's an awesome idea to have a professional photographer take all the pictures for you, it frees up your hands and your attention so you can focus solely on the amazing sights in front of you. However we found that the "candid" shots they take turn out.... funny... most people in the photos have eyelids half shut, odd facial expressions etc. I think it would have been better if they did more pose-type photos and less candid photos.

Worth every penny - do it!!!. My husband and I just returned from beautiful Riviera Maya for our honeymoon. We had an absolutely amazing time experiencing the beauty of the area and the Grand Velas resort and spa. We decided we were going to take one day away from the hotel to experience a local expedition. The brochure at our hotel does not do Rio Secreto justice. We had the most incredible day and loved every second of it. Our tour guide, Paulo - was so awesome and incredible! He truly made our day - he was so fun, cool and just knowledgeable about the history and underground caves we went through. We got to see such beauty underground and do something we would never ordinarily of course get to see/do. Can't recommend this adventure enough. It was easy to get to, once we arrived, the staff was friendly and helpful. We got into our gear, locked our things away safely and experienced an amazing adventure under-ground. We had plenty of room once inside the cave and the water was so pure and beautiful). After we finished the tour, they had the most delicious, authentic Mexican lunch waiting for us. We got to purchase some photos from our great day and then went on our way. We have not stopped telling everyone about Rio Secreto. We loved it sooooo much! Great addition to our honeymoon adventure!
Beautiful. A place to learn and a place to make some exercises. The meal after the activity is very goo. It's not an activity very expensive. You can get your ticket on the web.

Unique and amazing experience. Paulo was our guide - a former professional volleyball athlete in Brazil - he clearly enjoys what he does and was very helpful. The challenge was not to fall especially when trying not to break anything of either the caves or yours! I really enjoyed the floating/swimming parts.
Amazing!!. Rodrigo was our guide and he was fabulous! What a beautiful treasure this place is. We loved the experience... I highly recommend this!!

Absolutely Fantastico !!!. First of all, thanks to our tour leader, Paulo. What a great excursion! Got picked up from the dock in Playa del Carman after the ferry ride from our Carnival Cruise Ship Liberty and immediately put into groups of ten and transported to The Rio Secreto. The ride there is bumpy as the gravel road needs work but once at the site, you are given wet suits, flotation vests, hard hats with lights and amble instructions about the caves and hike. You need to be in relatively good shape for this excursion but not an athlete by any means. Just coordinated !!! Without spoiling the surprise, there is an amazing walk through the underground caves and some water to be swam in but trust me when I say this was an amazing excursion that I would repeat in a second. My two children (girl 10, boy 13) said it was "awesome" and "epic". The best part was that beside the people you're with, you don't really see a lot of other tourists around as all the tours are well spaced. Even during the included lunch, it was very comfortable. And photos taken by your group photographer can be purchased online after you get home so no big sales push at the time.

Beautiful but overpriced. My husband and I visited the Rio Secreto on our anniversary vacation. Please note this is not an excursion for people who have balance problems or back trouble. I have a back injury and I found myself quite sore by the end of the excursion. The floor is consistently uneven and rocky inside the cave therefore it's difficult to keep your balance and even harder if you already have balance troubles. The scenery is beautiful and a once in a lifetime experience. A photographer comes along and takes a lot of pictures throughout the tour which was nice. At the end of the tour we went to look at our pictures and learned that if we wanted our pictures it would cost us 100$ US which was really ridiculous to us. We could get 1 picture for 20$ US which again we felt was pricey. We already paid enough for the tour and we felt almost like we were being ripped off at this point... Needless to say we did not purchase any pictures and left disappointed.

Amazing Experience. Gonzo was our guide and he was a true joy. He loves his job and teaching all about the Mayan culture and cenotes. He was extremely knowledge and treated the history, rituals and environment with extreme care. The drive thru the Jungle was AWFUL. I understand keeping the environment how it is but the pot holes can be fixed easily with sand. If you get car sick, take something for it because our van had to stop on the way there and on way back for a passenger to get sick. I know this person and no, they were not hungover. Even us who are not prone to motion sickness felt ill. When doing this excursion, take time to relax and enjoy the beauty around you, the healing waters of the cenotes and take money to purchase your pictures because cameras are not allowed but pictures are worth it. Would recommend to all
Excellent way to spend an afternoon. Great tour, our guide was was engaging and entertaining. Great value and a fun way to spend a day. The Mexican lunch that was served after was good too

Terrific cenotes - pretty great tour. Rio Secreto is a well oiled machine when it comes to getting everyone through the caves - but not perfect. I stayed at the GBP Sian Ka'an and the driver was an HOUR late picking me up. I admit, this didn't give a great impression for me considering they asked me to be ready at 6:45 AM on my holiday! And when I arrived, with a couple also staying at GBP, we waited another 30 minutes for the rest of the group they put us with to arrive. Happily, they had a little cafe :) Our guide was very knowledgeable, but since the other six people in our group spoke another language, that's the language he spoke most of the time (even though his english was great!). There were lots of other english speaking groups, so I was disappointed to be in a bilingual group, because I think I missed out on a lot of great conversation and information. And for some reason we were "behind" coming out of the caves, so were totally rushed through lunch. And lunch was GREAT! And in a lovely little open air building. They didn't rush us through the sales pitches though - for a liquor they make there, as well as the really expensive photos. As for the actual caves, they were pretty cool. They really respect the environment (warning - cold oudoor shower before you walk through the jungle!). You really have to pay attention to where you're walking in the caves though - pretty much 90% of the time. And some spots are very skinny!Enjoyable way to spend 1/2 day - especially if it's raining or something.Note that they have lockers for you to store you things in while you go to the cenote, so you can put the same clothes back on if you want.Warning - drive into cenote is SUPER bumpy. Like you-may-need-a-chiropractor-afterward bumpy! But not paving the road is part of their respect for keeping the terrain and cenotes in their natural state, so it's a good thing :)

Beautiful Tour. The cave is beautiful, the big down fall is you cannot bring a camera of any kind. But they do take beautiful pictures and you can by the CD at the end. They have an nice area to change clothes and lockers (with locks) to put your dry clothes etc... The guides and staff are very nice and helpful. The ride in from the main road is 7km (if you get motion sickness this is not a ride you will want to go on). It did look like they are working on improving the road. The pictures on the website are very acurate and the cave is beautiful. The walking in the cave is on uneven surfaces and is a little slippery at times. The food after the tour is good. Play close attention to your guides instructions about the hot sauces. The only problem that we had was getting back to the resort, we are not sure if they did not have a person show up or had trouble with one of the vans, but after we were done eating it took them about an hour to find us a ride back to our resort. We asked several times how much longer and always got the answer of just a few more minutes. When we did get a driver she could not speak english, and did not know how to get to the resort for sure. But she was trying real hard to get us back. That is the only reason I did not give them a five for a overall rating.

Paulo is great.. The guide was excellent. Very knowledgeable .Our group had a wonderful experience other then my husbands water shoes fell apart in the first 15 minutes.Paulo offered him his watersocks.What a nice guy.Take this tour it made you realise how old the world is.We were also blesses by a Mayan Holy man.

Exceptional. That was one of the most exciting experience. It's really worth to go. A guide, all equipment you are given -everything serves that you feel safe and you are not afraid (we are not adrenaline lovers:)), you don't need to be a good swimmer at all. They allow only special underwater camera, so if you don't have such, then you may buy CD, which was quite expensive (69 USD) and unfortunately mixed with other people photos. Anyway, professional photos in CD was a good memory of amazing views in the cave. Walking through jungles was amazing experience. Would repeat this again :)
AMAZING. Not enough fish sighting and road to bumpy.The underground is magestic and our of tis world, the tour guide very patient, knowledgeable, friendly and funny

Beautiful, fun,. This is a great activity for those who are adventurous and those who aren't. The cave was so beautiful inside. It was much easier than I expected, but still managed to sprain my ankle. They don't allow cameras in the cave but they have a professional photographer that comes with you to take pictures. The ride out was 7 km on a jungle road, so a little bumpy but good opportunity to see jungle animals.The tour inside lasted about 90 minutes maybe a little more. They feed you afterwards. The food was better than expected. Ou tour guide was Yayo aka Eduardo. He was great. Spoke very good English, explained things very well, very knowledgeable, and obviously loved his job. Very personable and friendly.

The natural wonder of this place was amazing. Well worth the BUMPY ride into and out of the area; our tour guide (female from Siberia) was FABULOUS; we had a really great time. My personal opinion is that the meal after the underground adventure could be eliminated altogether. Just offer snacks that the traveler can pay for themselves. I believe the pictures, although it is necessary to have professional photographer, were overpriced.

Wonderful experience. One of a kind experience floating through the dark, silent underground river. Had a wonderful time with teenagers and small group. If you have a hard time swimming, don't worry. Unique and relaxing. Would definitely recommend to anyone.

Rio Secreto cave tour. Amazing tour of a pristine environment. It was beautiful. Nico was our guide, very informative and passionate about the caverns. It is a unique tour that I think would be hard to find elsewhere. Highly recommend!

What an unbelievable experience, breathtaking!. This was an unreal tour, you can make your own way there using the shuttle buses running from playa and book online or book through a tour company and get a lift there. once there you get a guide and approx six of you go full kitted out (headlamp, torch, wetsuit, wetshoes) i didnt take a walking stick and felt better balanced without, off you go swimming, walking, ducking through the caves and tunnels and the views and experience is a once in a lifetime trip. it was so nice to see the caves looked after and to learn about why they were formed and it wasnt touristy at all. the one downside is that the pictures taken are amazing, but are 75 dollars (i think it was 75) which is a lot for a cd of pics!!! when you get out you get a free meal and drinks which is a lovely bonus.

Awesome adventure. This was definitely one of the most fun adventures we had in Playa. Benito was a wonderful guide who taught us about the ecology of everything we saw. Highly recommended!! Thank you for the experience, Benito!
Amazing. This is a must trip you feel like an explorer I won't tell you to much so it doesn't spoil it just do it

Best Excursion Ever - Thanks Benito. If you ever wanted to really explore a cave this is the excursion for you. The cave is kept in pristine condition by having small group guided tours. The cave and jungle are kept natural and are not over developed and touristy. A excellent Mexican lunch is included.You will walk, wade and swim through this cave. A wet suite, helmet with light, water shoes, and flotation vest are all provided. So you do not need to know how to swim! The cave and water are a constant 77 degrees. Make no mistake this is a real cave exploration! The tour uses a path that is relatively easy to negotiate but if you have mobility issues this tour is not for you.Our guide Benito was fantastic. You can tell he really loves this cave and wants to share its beauty with you while protecting it from damage. He explains the formations, shows you the cave life, i.e. blind fish, cat fish, and shrimp. He explains how it was discovered, the Mayan history of the cave, and its part in the system of caves in the peninsula.A must do excursion.

Superb Guide. Our guide was Nunes for the cave exploration - a .37 mile (according to tour description) of walking, wading and swimming in underground caverns but it seemed much farther. However, started with bone jarring 6 mile van ride in the nature preserve due to mammoth pot holes. Outfitted with wet suit and water shoes, helmet and headlamps, the headlamps providing the only light in cavern. Water in caves relatively warm. Was given a walking stick - the cavern walking was over very uneven, bumpy, narrow trails but you can't touch the stalagmites or stalactites for support. Sometimes we walked in human chain hand-to-hand, which made it difficult with walking sticks. My husband and I made it but probably not strong enough swimmers - just floating on back, dog addle, breast stroke - but we should have been in better shape. I'm glad we did it, but don't know if we'd do it again due to swimming part. Description says children must be 6 - I can't imagine taking children on this at all

Best day of our trip!. We were in Playa del Carmen during a really cold and rainy week, so our travel agent canceled plans for a boat ride and booked us for Rio Secreto. We did a full day tour, which included 2 hours on ATVs in the jungle (and more cenotes). That was a total BLAST, even in the rain! We were driven to Rio Secreto, given a snack, and then down into the river we went! Our tour guide was Rene, I think? He was wonderful, patient with a member in our group who needed help, very knowledgeable...we could tell he loved his job and felt a deep connection to the river. And the buffet lunch after the tour was the best food we had all week, in my opinion! If you are up for a day full of adventure, put this on your travel planning list!

Speechless adventure. These caves are unreal. Our tour guide Alfredo was so informative and nice. He is so passionate about these caves and it was good to see someone enjoying there job. I would totally recommend this excursion. The road to the caves is bumpy but once you get into the caves it's nothing you've ever seen. The whole experience was a pleasure from the food the people and the jungle.

Must do. We were really lucky to be the only ones in our time slot, so we got a private tour. Our tour guide was thoroughly entertaining and the site is amazing. At first it's a bit eerie wading into water in the dark, but once you're in it's breathtakingly beautiful. The water is nothing to be scared of - completely clear and not cold at all. The lunch afterwards was great too. Overall highly recommended.

Spectacular!. Great adventure for all ages. We went as a family ranging in age from 5 to 81. When we went, only 2 holes were open to the public, and are totally different. Can't really say which is better so if it may be a reason for you to go back if you liked it the first time. Guides are entertaining, adjust to guests' physical ability and are safety-oriented. All equipment provided but you may want to bring your own aquasocks and wetsuit if you have one. Since no cameras are allowed, you have the option to purchase pictures or a CD of all the pictures taken. I advise purchasing the CD, divide the price among your group, then make copies or download on your portable device. The pictures turned out great!

Rio secreto. Was one of our highlights of trip..Hector was a tour guide very friendly and informative. We were about 8 ppl and we were with roughly 6 other Mexicans..which was a awesome experience as we got to learn about the real Mexico. I personally loved the food, wanted to try real Mexican food and not the "westernized" quality and type of food. I loved the soup and Hector told us how to add stuff to make it a hardier soup...bring your own water shoes as theirs are old and stretched out. The photos they take are not that many and are really expensive..wish they would let us bring our own camera..I would recommend this tour. It is also cheaper buying online than thru your tour rep.

The place is great but a pretty expensive experience. The cave is worth seeing. The experience is something you will remember. There are three trails - we did the one called happiness. For this reason Rio Secret has the capacity to accommodate more tourists in smaller groups.The guides give brief explanations. I would have preferred more information on the formation, the minerals and the life there. Sometimes I had the feeling that the guide did not understand our questions. However, he was extremely nice and friendly and tried his best so overall I am happy.The pictures are very expensive - 25 USD for one picture and 69 USD for a CD with not too many pictures. It is impossible to share the cost of the pictures within the group because you are offered to look at only the pictures of yourself and not the other participants (except for the group pictures). How they do it so quickly, I have no idea. The pictures do not open on any computer but the older computers have no problem opening them.The food is ridiculous. If somebody pays 79 USD for the experience, that person knows what good food means. To serve a potato puree from powder and a soup where you try to fish some chicken is simply insulting. We are not idiots. It is better not to serve any food in my view than to serve something below any standards. I agree with some of the comments that the Chichen-Itza tourist buffet was less expensive and much more decent. So eat before you go there, if you are a person for whom food matters.Enjoy the cave!

Epic! Amazing! An absolute must in Playa Del Carmen. We booked this trip through our resort at Playacar Palace. The drive here through the jungle is long and bumpy but once you arrive it was all great. The staff is awesome, everyone is very friendly and knowledgeable. Our guide Hector was probably the best tour guide I've ever had. The jungle/forest is beautiful and the caves just blew us away. Luckily we were part of the English speaking group and there were only 4 of us, Hector gave us an amazing experience and said we were lucky to be part of a small & intimate group (the spanish and french speaking groups were 8+). They took some excellent pictures of us as well. The best part (spoiler alert?) is when we got to the middle of the cave, he asked us to sit/squat down and be quiet, and turned off the lights. We sat there in the pitch black for a couple of minutes and once our eyes adjusted, it was probably the best experience of my life. Absolute serenity surrounded by sounds of water dripping, it was perfect. Also, the entire staff is great, the bathrooms/locker rooms are very clean, the mayan lunch served was just a bit boring for us but nothing to complain about really.We booked this excursion through Playacar Palace and were able to get a deal to use our resort credits earned to follow Rio Secreto up with ATV riding just a few minutes away. It was a perfect combo, the ATV property is owned by the same guy, and we even ran into him during the ATV adventure.

Underground beauty. We booked this tour directly through the website a few months before arrival to Mexico. Booking went smoothly and they answered all questions per-arrival.We were picked up at our hotel at 11:00am (on time) and we drove about 40 minutes to Rio Secreto. Once we arrived we were given a bracelet and we headed to a little hut for a quick orientation. After the orientation we were grouped by language and boarded a van to drive 7 km to the site. This was a downside of the tour. It was 7km of extremely rough road so you drive 10km – 20km (if that) so the drive was long. You get bounced around a lot (I had a sore neck the next day), and if you get queasy, this might be an issue for you.After the drive you arrive to the site where you are teamed up with your tour guide and a photographer (you can’t take your own pictures). The guide does a quick briefing and you then need to take a full rinse off in the cold shower (no makeup, lotions, etc). You are then fitted with shoes, a helmet (make sure your light works before putting it on), a wet suit and life jacket. If you tend to get cold easily you make want to bring/wear a long sleeve rashy. You also have the option of taking a walking stick. At first I did not want to take it as I thought it would get in the way. Take my advice… take the stick. I was so glad I did, as was the others I spoke to.You then go for a short hike through the woods and do a little ceremony and then head into the caves.The caves are absolutely stunning. I won’t go into much detail here as you have to see it for yourself. The guide takes through the caves, mostly walking with a little ‘floating’ explaining the different formations as you go. The ground is uneven so the walking stick came in handy. Once you finish you head back to the main area for a buffet lunch which was very good. You then have the option here to purchase the pictures that where taken. This was a huge disappointment. I have no problem paying for pictures. After doing the tour I can see why they don’t want people taking their own pictures (dangerous to balance down there, and it slows things down). However the photographer’s equipment failed half way through the tour so we never had a chance to get shots with your own group. Also, the picture he did take where out of focus. We had no choice but to purchase them as it was the only hard copy memory we had. They did offer us a discount but I’m just disappointed in the quality and lack thereof.Once all was done we hoped back on the van for the 7km rough drive to the entrance, and then straight back to the hotel.Overall I do recommend this tour as it is a spectacular site to see. The food was really good and our guide was absolutely amazing and you can see she really enjoyed her job

Fantastic experience. Was absolutely amazing and should be considered one of the wonders of the world. Our guide was amazing. The claustrophobic in me didn't enjoy the last few minutes and getting out lol but other than that it was incredible. A once in a life time experience and the team there made it such.
very exciting. I have never done anything like this and it was a very nice experience. Staff was friendly and knowledgeable about the area.

Lives up to the name!. We explored the amazing secret river in Dec 2013, while on a Caribbean cruise (Norwegian Cruise Lines) . It was one of the most breath taking places I have ever seen. Our guide was Alfredo, he was very knowledgeable and genuine. We loved him! The entire experience was wonderful and I cannot wait to take the rest of my family to experience it. The natural mineral water was exhilarating and the lunch and honey tequila were delicious! ITS A MUST SEE!

Very nice tour. If you've never been in a cenote before this will be a very impressive tour, The facilities and equipment are very good, the guides and staff were very good and overall it was a very good eco tour.this tour has stairs entering and exiting the cenote, then it is completely natural and no artificial lighting and no walking paths, that makes it very interesting, it is uneven ground above and below water so it can be difficult to walk without stumbling but its a great and fun experienceBottom line: there are probably 100 cenote tours in the riviera maya many are completely natural, some are completely fake, This is an awesome experience with awesome guides great for first time cenote visitors, but could be a little too commercialized for experienced cavers

What An Experience!!. What a FANTASTIC excursion! The rock formations are just phenomenal. The staff was fantastic. This was truly one of the most unique excursions I have ever been on. Would recommend to everyone looking for something unique and beautiful!

Wonderful experience. This was a great excursion. We were originally scheduled to do something else but it was cancelled. We chose this excursion because it looked interesting and the person helping us on Carnival Magic said he had heard great things about it. We took a 45 minute boat ride from Cozumel to Playa Del Carmen. Once there we had about a 15 minute wait then we were picked up and taken to the location. I think it was about 20 minutes. Turned out the guide from Carnival Magic was taking the same excursion and ended up being in our group. If you are able to choose your guide ask for Alfredo. He was great. The caves themselves were amazing. The water perfectly clear. Alfredo was informative and funny. Water was a little cold at first but you get used to it pretty quick. By the way, you really don't need the wet suite. They are kind of smelly and you just don't need it. Just wear your swim suit, life vest and hard hat and you will be much more comfortable. The food at the end of the tour was good. The pictures are a little expensive but they are professional looking. My favorite parts of the tour are when the water is deep enough to float in. Very nice and my wife would add that your skin feels pretty good afterward as well. I guess from the high calcium content in the water. If you are wanting an excursion that is fun, informative and just plain cool this would be my recommendation.

Outstanding Hidden Treasure. The underground river adventure of Rio Secreto is fantastic! The "alive" cave is literally dripping with growing stalagtites and stalagmites. It is a bit difficult walking in the water that you are in the water you are in virtually all the time, but it is well worth it. Be sure to see this wonder if you visit Playa del Carmen.

Rio Secreto has to be on youre bucket list!. This is a true Mayan underworld it's amazing!. This is something you see on the Discovery Channel. The rock formations are amazing some are like a cathedral. Wich take thousands of years to form.The water is a turquoise color, water is so clear and beautiful. The staff is great & well trained. They provide the equipment wich is in good condition & clean. They don't allow any personal belonging's in the underground river. That would include no cameras. Wich is a bummer. But they take pictures through out the tour. Wich are not cheap but worth it. They provided a Maya lunch it was delish! we had seconds. This was a amazing experience don't miss it. You won't be dissapointed and yes I would do another tour again.

DO ! DO ! DO !. This is a must while in Mexico ! We booked a tour through our concierge in Cancun and it was worth every cent and more from beginning to end. Amazing organization, nice experienced staff and when arriving at Rio Secreto, your adopted guide stays with you all the way and even has lunch with his group. Safety is explained clearly and the tour is well organized. The amazing part begins as you go down the caves and walk along below the caves. We visited when it just rained, so many parts where in high water, which made the experience even more amazing as were able to swim a lot. Loved the caves, peaceful and serene, nature at its best !Just book it and go !

always a little different. We took this after reading the reviews and I was worried as some said it was strenuous. We found it to be enjoyable but there is a lot of odd positions one has to assume to pass without injuring yourself. I talked with the guide who said each time in is a little different depending on water height and which cave they go through. We (3) and group of another 5 had a great time. My daughter and I wore our keens water shoes and had to deal with little pebbles so I would suggest closed water shoes, which will allow you to not be distracted while in the caves. I did scrape my leg but it wasn't bad and has healed nicely. The food was good but the hot sauce both red and green are HOT so beware! We got the big package, pictures (CD), a shirt, hat, and bottle of their wine for 125$. Which we felt was a good deal. The CD alone was 69$. Our guide was extremely informative and respectful of the caves which was great. Don't know about taking little ones in the cave, although I am sure they could contort better than I did.

A very special "secret river". Our family group included kids from a seven and nine years old to grandparents in and approaching 70.....because of our excellent guide, Raul (with 3 "r's"), all of us were able to negotiate this underground wonderland safely and without fear. We were outfitted with short wet suits, life jackets and a helmet with a light. Most of the adults used the walking sticks and were glad we did. The floors of the cave are uneven and a little climbing up and down is required. The caves are completely dark...and the headlights are the only source of light. When we turned our lights off at one point, you could not see your hand inches from your face. The caves are magical and beautiful. My husband is very claustrophobic and wasn't sure he'd be able to do it. However, Raul took us on a route with open caves and he was there to encourage him as needed. He was glad he did it. The adventure is followed by a good lunch. You aren't allowed to take cameras into the caves, but a photographer accompanies each group and a CD can be purchases. Well worth it.

Loved wading through stalactites!. This amazing tour is very well run and gives you everything that is promised. We were outfitted with water shoes, wet suit, life vest, and a helmet with a light. After a short walk in the jungle and a Mayan blessing ceremony, we walked down into an opening in the ground and entered the river. Most of the time the water was only a foot or two deep, but a couple times we had to swim a bit as it was too deep to walk. The caves opened up and we saw fantastic stalactites and stalagmites. We didn't touch them, of course, but you had extremely closeup views to see the texture and colors. There were so many shapes and formations. I loved every minute of the couple hours in the caves! Our guide was very helpful and knowledgeable. He suggested we take a walking stick to help keep our balance, and that was good advice. There are a number of places in the river that have rocks and uneven surfaces, but I didn't find it very difficult. The photos on the website are real, but only look brightly lit because of flash photography. Our headlamps were terrific to see where you were walking in the water, and also to see the formations all around the caves. When we all turned our headlamps off, it was totally dark! All you could hear is the dripping and flowing water! Fantastic! After the tour, we tasted a Mayan liqueur made with honey and anise (thick and syrupy), looked at the photos the photographer took, and had a nice included buffet lunch. My only complaint would be we didn't have much time to eat before we had to get back to the main road to transfer to the coach for the return trip to the hotel. Our guide said that was because we stayed in the cave a bit longer than some groups. I just loved this tour and highly recommend it!

Out of the ordinary FUN. This is not your big theme park type adventure. It is a recently discovered river system running through a cavern system under the ground. This is more of a small family owned operation....not a "mass" tour. They limit tours to 9-12 people per tour group...sure makes it more fun ! I know there was a couple other groups in the caverns at the same time we were, but we never saw or heard them.Our guide was wonderful and a wealth of information (and patience:) . By the way...our "group" consisted of only 7 people plus the guide and a photographer that popped up once in a while. While this is a small river flowing through caverns, most of the time you are wading or walking, not swimming. The water is crystal clear and actually safe enough to drink ! While this adventure takes place in a cavern high cellings, there are some places you have to duck low in very short passages to get to next cavern system. A correlation would be that if you can stand riding in an elevator for a min. or two you will not have a problem with claustrophobia(it was one of my worries) on this adventure.We took this adventure while on a cruise to Cozumel and the tour picked us up in a van and afterwards returned us to the ship. I believe only 7 people from our ship of 2,400 people took this adventure....how sad that they missed out on so much fun .Our time estimate includes the ferry ride from Cozumel to Casa de Playa to meet the tour van and return to the ship. Actual time on the tour itself is less than 2 hours...that includes the time for free drinks and lunch AFTER the adventure :)We got back to the ferry dock early and so even had time to do a little shopping before the ferry departed ! I am not sure what the time line would be if you were taking this tour from another area such as Cancun ? .Wife and I totally enjoyed our adventure and would love to do it again with friends.
A magic place!. This place offers a wonderful experience, totally worth it!You are going to see one of the most beautiful creations of nature, a perfect activity for the whole family!

DON;T MISS THIS ONE!!. What an incredibly beautiful, magical place. This is off the beaten path, and offers a very unique experience. From start to finish, the tour was awe inspiring. Although the terrain at times inside the caverns was uneven, it was certainly suitable for people of all ages and physical abilities. The camaraderie felt at the end of the day was unique and heartwarming. Our guide, Alfredo, was so pleased to explain what we were seeing, and very careful to let us know, when we would need to be aware of our footing, and help those following behind us. The safety equipment supplied by the tour operator was great. Certainly above average quality and condition. The lunch included was delicious and offered a variety of flavours and textures typical of the region. Lots of time to meander about after the tour, or lounge in the hammocks before heading back on the bus. DON'T MISS THIS ONE FOLKS.....IT IS WELL WORTH EVERY PENNY. Visit the web site for photos that will knock your socks off.

A must do on your trip to the Yucatan.. This is a nature trip; the guides do a great job in making you understand the delicacy and the beauty of this underground system. You are given a briefing before you start, along with all the necessary gear for a safe and enjoyable experience. I, personally, liked the small cleansing ceremony by the Mayan shaman before we entered the river system. Very respectful of the heritage of the area. Our guide, Jahome(? Sorry for any misspells) was very knowledgeable of the area and of many languages. He spoke to us in English and then to a couple, in French, with amazing ease. The whole experience was very organized; and interesting; and topped off with Mexican food. Also, the pictures are so much fun to have!

More fun than I expected. They picked up up at our hotel at 11:30 and took us to the site. The road to the cave is very bumpy but there are reason for that which is explained on the tour. They gave us wet suits, helmet with a light, water shoes and life jacket (vest). They broke the group into smaller groups based on the language they spoke. We got a briefing before we started so we knew what to expect and I was impressed with how well organized they were. Sandra took my smaller English speaking group into the caves. It's a little slow going at first as the terrain is uneven but everyone helps everyone get through and nobody was left to fed for themselves. The inside of the caves are dark and cool and the water wonderful. If it's a hot day you will LOVE this tour. We learned the history and had lots of photos taken by a professional that we could buy on a disk for $69. The pictures were so great I couldn't resist. art of the caves are in deep water and you float along - a relief after trying to find your footing on the rocks. I recommend this to all the able bodied adventurous people. My friend had a bad back and made out fine. They gave us towels after and we changed and had a buffet lunch included in your package (wine & beer is $3 extra) The buffet was excellent. I would do this again.

An amazing experience. Everthing about this tour was great. We booked through our hotel and the bus picked us up on time. The only slight down side was that we were the first hotel on the pick up point so we rode around for an hour while they picked up others for this tour and for those going to XCARET. We transferred to a smaller bus later who then took us to Rio Secreto. From there, you transfer again and travel 7km on an unpaved road to the caves. Everything was included. They provided towels, life jackets, helmets, head lamp, a wetsuit if you want (which I recommend) and water shoes (though we previously had red we needed to bring our own they gave them free of charge). Alfredo was out guide and extremely passionate and very friendly. Its a very unique experience and you could tell how much he loved going down into these caves which he said was his absolute favorite. Once in the caves you are almost always in water, anything from ankle deep to floating. If you can't swim, its not a problem. When it became really deep we simply floated and used our arms to push ourselves.. there was no actual swimming involved... and the times when you are fully submerged is less then when you wade through the shallows. There are parts which are uneven and slippery so be careful. The water was cool, it was not freezing but I am glad we chose to use the wetsuits though you can go without (lifejackets are mandatory either way). You are not allowed to bring your own camera but they do have a photographer along with you. The photo were great but of course, they cost an arm and a leg. It was $25 USD for one photo or you could get the entire CD of your photos for $69 USD. For $120 USD (I think) they would throw in some bottles of alcohol, all the pictures, a T-shirt and a hat. You don't really have much choise if you want some type of momento given you can't bring a go pro or anything else into the cave. All jewelry has to come off as well, rings, necklaces, earings, etc. When we were done we had a buffet lunch with chips, salsa, chicken, mash potatoes, rice, and a few other options. The food was nothing spectacular but we were not expecting it to be either. Tea and water were free but beer, soft drinks and snacks (candy bars and chips) were extra which you could pay for. We then relaxed in the hammocks for a bit before heading back to hour hotels, this time we had a straight ride and did not have to switch busses.

One of the best tours I've ever done!. We booked two tours while in Mexico last week. One was Xel-ha which I also recommend. The other was swimming in the cenote at Rio Secreto. As other travelers have said, it's only been open to the public for 5 years and only 150 people pass through each day. It is absolutely worth the money. You and the kids will love it. When you get inside the cave, turn off all your helmet lights. It is pitch black in there. We bought the $55 CD with all the pics at the end. The lunch was "ok" but the actual experience is very beautiful and has created a wonderful memory for our family. It's a little pricey but swimming in this cenote is probably way better than what you'll get on a cheaper tour that probably includes a half day ATV session and all that. Don't do it. Stick with this one and you won't be sorry.

Great experience with very expensive photos. The cave and the tour (Nunez was professional and very friendly - THANK YOU!) were brilliant. Nothing to complain about except one thing: THE PHOTOS. I understand that somebody is taking the pics for you and he needs to be paid but 25$ per picture is a misunderstanding.

Best excursion ever. Never seen awesome formations of stalagmites and stalactites so up close and so many of them, our guide rauel was very informative and made it all the more fun. Well organized and despite all the tourists, guides including rauel stresses on preserving the caves and gives loads of information. Truly awesome time.

Great caves. We almost didn't go on this tour, but I'm glad we did. These caves have been open to the public for only a few years and are amazing. You spend 90 minutes underground walking and swimming (really floating). You will wear a wet-suit and life vest the whole time. The tour guide was wonderful. It was beautiful. Mexico has really changed when it comes to preserving the beauty of their country. This tour is not for real young children.

Strangely wonderful. I was travelling with a group of people and one of the things on our "to do"-list was a visit to Rio Secreto. We were taken 7 km into the jungle and then dressed up in wet suits, life jackets and helmets. I was not sure what to expect. Being under ground in Rio Secreto was an amazing experience. Epco, our guide for the day, was full of information and gave us a good tour. At one point we turned off all our lights and just floated down there listening to the drops falling. Such a peaceful feeling. After about 1,5 hrs the tour ended and we got to sit down in the middle of the jungle to a buffé. I highly recommend the lime soup!

Really magical. I was a bit apprehensive at first but my boyfriend was very keen to go. I am so glad I went it was just gorgeous, hector (I think that was his name) was our guide and he was AMAZING ! Highly recommend to do this tour.Only thing I can fault is the food for lunch provided wasn't too fabulous for a vegetarian but above all else very happy!

Must do! Once in a lifetime experience. This was our final excursion on a cruise and it was an amazing way to finish the trip. The site is about a 30 minute drive into Playa from the Cozumel ferry landing, 10 minutes of which is on the city's paved roads and 20 minutes of which is most certainly an off road experience on unpaved dirt roads. The facilities at Rio Secreto were clean and well kept. Upon arrival our group of 8 was introduced to Gouda, our guide, who was multilingual, friendly, upbeat and knowledgeable. We were supplied lockers and asked to shower in order to remove as much of the natural oils and chemicals on our skin as possible so that we would not damage the caves. We were outfitted with wet suits, water shoes, helmets with lights and life jackets. Departing their "base" we walked to a site where we participated in a ceremony spoken in the Mayan language asking for permission for our entrance to the caves. From there you walk down into one of many series of underground caves and climb, wade, swim and crouch your way through. You are asked not to use your hands or touch the walls of the caves and you have your guide and your helmet light to guide you. After nearly two hours underground, your senses are certainly sharpened. Where the water is deep enough to swim is the easiest portion of the tour physically. The shallower water areas and rocky terrain are more difficult to navigate, but not impossible. I believe that most people would be perfectly comfortable with the tour, but I would not recommend it for the elderly or disabled or those who have extremely poor balance. Also, as you are underground in a dark, enclosed and often tight space, I would not recommend it for those who are bothered by those things. Our guide, Gouda, was a really remarkable woman. She was attentive, caring, knowledgeable, thorough and offered many insights into the history of the land and the formation of the caves. The caves themselves are truly incredible to see. In addition to your guide, a photographer accompanies you on the tour. At first I felt that this was just so that they could sell you the photos (which they do), but it truly would be impossible for someone going on the tour to photograph the caves in the way they do and with their equipment. Also, you often need both hands free for balance. When we exited the caves, we were given towels to dry off and taken back to our lockers so that we might change into dry clothes. Then you enjoy shots of a local beverage and lunch. Then you have the opportunity to look at the photos that were taken of you in the caves and purchase them. If you opt to purchase, you can choose to buy just one photo for $25 or you can get all the photos on a disc which also includes some beautiful photos of the caves themselves for $70. For $110 you could get the photo disc with 2 bottles of their liquor. From there a van takes you back to the city to catch your ferry back to Cozumel. All in all, I would highly recommend this attraction for it's unique and awe-inspiring value.

A beautiful Experience. My Nov. 2013 vacation to cancun included a side trip to Rio Secreto. It's an underground river and caves that have been in existence for hundreds of years. The excursion started with a mayan ceremony where we, 8 visitors in my group, asked the mayan Gods permission to enter. Wearing wetsuits, life jackets and a helmet with a light we decended into the cave with our guid Kiki and our photographer. Part way thru the hour and a half excursion our guide had us stop and stand still. he then instructed us to turn off our lights and WOW was it DARK. I put my hand up and touched my nose but could NOT see my hand at all. It was a very interesting an educational trip made more enjoyable by our guide Kiki's on going narrative.

A Once-only Tour. Rio Secreto was the third and shortest paid excursion we took from our Iberostar beach resort. Given that we boarded the van at 1140 hours and were back for supper, per hour, this was certainly the most expensive of the three excursions. The "secret river" is a long series of connected cenotes (underground sinkholes), source of all drinking water in the area, and filled with many fantastic calcium structures. It is worth seeing as a natural phenomenon. We didn't see any bats or fish, but these are said to be there as well. Our guide for this trip, Miroslava, was originally from Serbia. She said relatively little, but looked after us all, competently and kindly, throughout the afternoon. After an uneventful, easy walk through the jungle (several did it in sandals), we met a Mayan shaman who conducted a brief ceremony with a smoking lamp he circled in the air while he chanted a prayer for us before we could enter the first cenote. We then changed into our swimsuits (lockers are provided) and were outfitted with wetsuits, life jackets, headlighted helmets, et cetera. I soon wished I had purchased my own water shoes as the ones loaned me were full of holes and rather roomy. Fortunately, I did accept a walking stick (these should be mandatory for everyone as the "steps" in the cenotes are very slippery) so I could remove the stones which floated into my shoes. A protected natural reserve, the Rio Secreto is billed as a "life-changing experience", I don't know why. The water is clear and lovely, the stalagmites/stalactites/coral structures are impressive, and walking/floating single-file underground is not something most people will ever do, but "life-changing"?? At one point, Miroslava had us sit in the water, form a circle, and turn off our headlights to meditate for a few minutes in the dark. Perhaps it was this that was meant to prompt new insights. I was reminded of yoga, and wanted to end the session with "Ommm".We only spent about an hour in the secret river. A fair chunk of our time there was devoted to posing for expensive photos taken by young Mayans. It was my understanding that we might have toured more of the river but weren't given options. In any case, it was soon over, and it was time to change from our wet swimsuits before lunch. Miroslava provided us with an interesting drink we had not had before. Lunch was a modest buffet of traditional Mayan dishes, much like the lunch on the Ek Balam tour, and unlike the elaborate hotel buffet at Chichen Itza. We didn't have a credit card with us or sufficient cash to buy the photo package, but were told we could do this from home. When I emailed the company, all I received in return was a notice from Paypal to pay $69US. There apparently was no way of previewing the photos, or even of ensuring that I would receive the right ones.There is a companionship that arises among a group of strangers experiencing something new together. We enjoyed chatting with a woman from Sherbrooke and a family from Winnipeg. I think almost anyone would enjoy visiting Rio Secreto, once, excepting those particularly nervous about slippery rocks, darkness underground, or being in water over one's head (even with a lifejacket on). We don't plan to repeat the experience but are glad we did it once.
must see and once in a lifetime experience. Rio Secreto is accessible to people of most fitness level. The experience is unique and it keeps wowing you as you progress along the underground river

Great experience at Rio Secreto. We recently went to Rio Secreto near Playa Del Carmen and would highly recommend it. The tour of this amazing underground river was fantastic and will remain a highlight of our travel adventures. Our guide, Pablo, was not only knowledgeable, he was so very respectful of the unique environment he goes to work in every day. He made all of the tour participants feel comfortable, sharing his information in English and in Spanish. There were 10 people on our tour and everyone had a great time, even though we had not met one another until that day. Go to this amazing sacred place. You won't regret it!

A fantastic experience. On your trip you will be taken care of from start to finish. You are in the care of knowledgeable and experienced people who genuinely care about you and your experience. The caves are beautiful and you will learn a lot about the culture and beliefs of the native inhabitants. You will also learn a lot about caves, the biological organisms living inside them and everything related to them. This was an outstanding adventure/ You will experience local cuisine and customs. Simply amazing. You will receive the best care and service while visiting. One of the best excursions I have ever taken. Superb job. Keep up the outstanding work.
Excellent adventure. Did not what to expect but the adventure that went on for almost 2 hours. Our tour guide Leon was so knowledgable and made the experience the best....

Pleasant surprise!. Sometimes when you book some of these tours you just do not expect much and sometimes that is a good thing!! Because here, I expected to see a small cave and really looked forward mostly to simply kill half of a dreary, cloudy day!! However, this thing shocked me!! Much bigger than I would have expected and certainly nicer than I could have thought! Pictures in a brochure do not do this justice! It is in pristine shape, way back in the jungle. You get to hike, wade and swim through extensive caverns. At all times we felt safe with our knowledgeable guide "Joan", a fellow from Spain, very pleasant. I would suggest this trip to anyone. We booked through the hotel for $89 each and they picked us up and dropped us off. Lunch was included in the price. They do not let you touch the side of the cave, for obvious ecological reasons so there are some areas where more stability is needed. They do offer walking sticks which I did not take and I now think that would have been a good idea. The only bad thing or downside is the absolute ripoff with pictures! They charge $25.00 each or $69 for a few! It really is a gouge and they could sell many more by dropping their price. We were the only people in our group to pay for a picture!

Unlike Anything Else!. Rio Secreto is an incredible experience! After a 20 minute, bumpy bus ride into the jungle, you arrive at the actual entrance where you are outfitted with a helmet, wet suit, and water shoes. Lockers are also provided. Jacome was very knowledgable and guided us though the beautiful caves, explaining everything as we went along. At times, you will need to crouch down and walk through tight spots all while not touching this beautiful natural wonder. The lunch provided was not too bad, either! Like others have said, we were a little disappointed in the high price of the photo CD. There weren't as many shots as we anticipated, either. Be sure to make reservations as they only take small groups on each tour.

A must see if you are able!. All I can say is you have to go. This was a once in a lifetime experience. The tours are so cool, and you go swimming through underground caves. Our guide was really friendly and knowledgable,and the staff were all nice. They take pics of you, which does cost money, but I'm glad I have the quality of pics I have now. It's truly like being in another world, it's a real adventure!

Amazing Natural Experience. WOW! Such an amazing experience. I highly recommend taking the time to see this awesome natural treasure. Our guide Jacome was very knowledgeable about the cave system and underground river. He also made the tour fun. The tour was very eco-conscious. One complaint... they limit everyone from taking photos during the tour and provide a photographer (that has some talent). The problem is the cost of the photos. One photo costs $25 USD, while a whole CD of photos cost $60 USD. I found one shot that I liked but didn't feel that the added expense was worth it for me.

Wonderful experience. I joined this trip with my 7-year old son and we had a wonderful experience. It was very beautiful and our tour guide Mr. Benito was very friendly and helpful. Same with some of the reviews, I think the price of the pictures are too expensive (US$69) for a CD) and the quality of the pictures are not very good.

Awesome cave river tour. While on a great Holland America cruise (Nieuw Amsterdam) we booked a tour of Rio Secreto. The facility was well layed out, attractive, fully equipped. Each of us was given a mini-wetsuit, including boots, helmet with light and a PFD. Walking sticks available. Benito our guide was very well informed, English was excellent. He led us on an almost 2 hour tour of the most fantastic cave passages with water of varying depths from inches to over 7 feet. Crystal-clear, glass smooth with a sand-like bottom. The cavern was festooned with stalactites, 'soda-straws' and stalagmites, some of which had joined with their opposing stalactites to form columns. The limestone of the walls and ceilings pocked with holes, gaps, fissures. Benito kept a constant flow of information going in an easy, manner with humor. Thoroughly enjoyed the tour.

Amazing Tour. Rio Secreto is an amazing underground river system filled with stalagmites and stalactites. Our tour guide Leon was awesome! He was really good at explaining everything in an easy to understand way. My one complaint would be that you can't bring your own cameras in and they gouge on photo pricing.

We LOVED this trip!!. I am so happy, that of all the things we had to choose from, we did this. Rio Secreto is an amazing and sublime place not to be missed! I have been in caves before in Texas and New Mexico, and those are beautiful - but imagine being in there and swimming through it!!We went through Best Day travel for this excursion and paid $89 USD Per Person. We were picked up at our hotel, picked up another couple and were on our way. Once at Rio Secreto we watched a video presentation and got divided up into groups and assigned a tour guide. (This is where we got lucky!) We then took a very bumpy van ride to the entrance of the cave.Where we got lucky - we were assigned Adriana, and she was absolutely passionate about Rio Secreto and about conservation and the spiritual aspect of the cenotes, and especially this one. I loved her knowledge of the culture and history and value to the people that the cenotes meant. She tried to help everyone on her excursion develop that sense of reverence for the place that she has.There was one guy in our group who could not do this due to his claustrophobia. I am slightly claustrophobic and getting into the wetsuit and tight life vest was trying for me (I don't like feeling restrained) but I breathed through that. If you ARE TRULY claustrophobic then this is NOT a trip for you. He walked into the first cave and broke out into a sweat and asked to be taken back.My husband has suffered 2 broken ankles and has plates in one, and he had a tough time navigating some of the rocks, but he did OK. If you have weak knees or bad ankles and can't crouch down and step or navigate your body like that you may have a hard time on this excursion.After the trip we were served a delicious lunch, and were offered photos of the trip (You can't bring your own camera).This was absolutely beautiful and wonder to experience. I am so blessed to experience it and would recommend it in a heartbeat.

A highlight of my trip!. WOW!!! Just wow!! This was definitely a highlight of my trip...an amazing experience and I would definitely do this again. Our guide, Rene, was great...very knowledgeable and funny. And when you're done with the tour, you get to eat a delicious lunch. The only reason I didn't give it an excellent rating is because the photo prices are WAY too expensive for digital photos and the quality isn't that great. One photo is $25. If they lower their prices and take better photos, they would probably sell a lot more of them!

An unexpected trip of appreciation. We visited Rio Secreto as part of a 2 place package for $109 per person. The other place we visited was a ATV 4-wheeling tour across the street. For the price we were picked up, dropped at the ATV place, picked up a few hours later, driven to Rio Secreto, fed at Rio Secreto and driven back to our resort - whole thing lasted about 9 hours.Rio Secreto was unbelievable - I had no idea it was going to be so 'earthy'. You literly are walking down into a real cave with rocks, stalactites, stalagmites, ect everywhere. It was an experience I will never forget. Our tour guide (Anatasia I think?) was amazing. She was so passionate about the natural wonder this cave was, as well as all caves (she mentioned on her recent vacation, she went cave exploring). It was great to see Rio Secreto employing people who were so passionate for this beauty of this natural site. They also fed you at the end of the trip - food was good. There were a number of places to chill out around the main waiting area while waiting for your van to pick up you (hammocks!!). What I will also say is unless you are somewhat physically fit, no knee issues and are open to nature - you will love this place. However if you scared of trying new things, this might not be the place for you. The cave was beatiful, and I do not think I'll ever be able to have an experience like this again.
