But if you are scared of small spaces, walking in unknown waters, scared of the dark, bats - I'd do some more research before going here. I felt like if this such of a place was in the US, they would never allow such a place without additional safety precautions put into place (mostly due to potential lawsuits). I'm not saying that is a bad thing at all - just stating my thoughts on the rugged-ry of the place. The only negative I have is that the picture prices are ridiculous. Since this was such an awesome experience, I fealt okay with buying a picture - but they wanted $25 for ONE picture. I thought okay maybe it would come printed, in a cardboard frame - but nope.....ONE picture on a burned CD in an envelope. That is it. It would have been nice for $25 if they actually gave me a hard printed picture as well.

Amazing experience!. A one of a kind excursion not to be missed. Air conditioned comfortable van picked me up on time. Arrived at the base site after only a short ride from the hotel. We transferred vans and took a bumpy ride into the site itself. We were separated into groups according to primary language to make sure you got the most out of the experience. Amazing range of languages offered by the guides. We were told about what to expect, given the rules and fitted up with all the necessary gear. You only need your bathing suit and lockers were provided.After a brief trek through the jungle we entered the caverns. The route is underwater to varying degrees from knee high to areas were you need to float/swim in your life jacket. The formations were just stunning and just as impressive as I had hoped. A nice lunch followed the trek back to finish off a great day.Definitely something not to miss.

Secret River Nov 2013. We visited the Rio Secreto last week, and the visit was one of the highlights of our cruise excursions from the Carnival Glory. There is older review posted from 2010 which mentions that the lunch was awful....we'll they have definitely improved the selection. They offered local cuisine in a buffet style which was wonderful. Also the facilities including changing rooms, lockers, a dining hut which were first class and appear to be newly built. Groups of 10 plus the guide and a photographer go into the cave. On our tour there were 4 groups of 10, but each group was kept apart to make the tour quite intimate. Our guide, Benito, was great and very informative. You'll love this tour if you're up for an adventure and enjoy natural environments.

Interesting - a few long waits but worth it. Overall - interesting little excursion. Our guide was great - she spoke French, English & Russian.Bring your own wet suits if you have one - the ones there - well - like most places - smell some.The only big down side of this excursion is the paparazzi - a person that follows your group and snaps pictures of you and your friends almost non stop - very annoying. Then, at the end, they try to sell you a kit with book & photo cd for mucho dinero - or just one pic for US $20 - what a joke.If you have mobility problems - I would not recommend this - you have to walk in dark conditions, in water up to your waist or higher, with rocks & stalagmites & cracks etc on the floor.

Amazing and fun experience. While in Playa del Carmen we visited Rio Secreto as an excursion with our tour group. This is an experience one should not miss if in the area! We were briefed on what to expect, given wet suits, water shoes, and flotation devices, and entered the underground caves. In places, the water was too deep to walk, but the flotation devices kept us afloat. The environment in the cave is amazing and wondrous. We had a terrific guide (Raul) who is clearly passionate about conserving this treasure. We spent about one hour in the caves followed by a tasty lunch and the requisite push to buy the photographs they took (though not a "hard" sell!). Caution, though, that the ground is uneven and one should be fairly nimble walking, but otherwise this is a terrific way to spend half a day (especially if cloudy or rainy).
Cave Adventure. Adriana was great, so passionate and knowledgeable. very helpful to those not so comfortable with water and tight spaces. A great experience, would highly recommend this

AMAZING Experience... Nature... Caving... People and FOOD!. This was the highlight of our Disney Cruise. Getting out in the huge nature preserve and floating underwater in the spring fed caves! The staff is happy and helpful. They take professional photos during your experience and you can leave with about 100 photos of your family and the flora, fauna, caves, etc... Gear is provided. We took our 6 year old boy with us. You simple walk and float through the caverns. It is like nothing we've ever done. Lots of history and authentic mexican lunch which is really a dinner feast. We will do this again!

oUR sECOND tIME!. We visited Rio Secreto last year for the first time and we were awestruck. Simply an amazing place, something you may only see once in a lifetime. It is a breathtaking experience to see nature in the making for 1000's of years. If you have a chance to visit Cozumel, you must enjoy the experience we had. We actually just visited again last week for the second time and plan on it again next year.

honeymooners adventure. My husband and I had the most amazing time doing the Rio Secreto excursion. We booked it through our hotel, the Beach Palace and we were not disappointed. The tour through the cave was amazing and Victor, our tour guide was incredibly knowledgeable and sweet. We did not expect it to be as long either so we really felt we got our moneys worth. We also felt it wasn't as commercialized as the other excursions...meaning we really felt we were in Mayan untouched land that hadn't been built up for tourists yet. Silvia was wonderful communication and emailing us our picture too. We didn't have enough money for the pictures but we were able to use paypal and she very promptly and kindly set everything up and emailed us our picture. With that said, I will say the picture packages are outrageous and they don't allow you to take your own camera in; however, it is still worth it to buy 1 picture because it is that gorgeous inside the caves. Our other excursion that was part of the cenote/cave walking and swimming were atv riding in the jungle. Both instructors were amazing and so much fun to ride with. The path we went on was full of mudpits that were so much fun to ride through. My husband and I were laughing so hard and having the best time. We also stopped at a cenote and swam in it for about 20 minutes, and they took us into a cave to see fruit bats. The whole day was amazing and we keep talking about how incredible both tours were. We highly recommend it.

Amazing trip. Excellent half day trip through the underground caves and river at Rio Secreto. Guide Alfredo was passionate about the natural caves and continued exploration of the system in that runs beneath the Yucatan peninsula. Wetsuits were not necessary, but made the water a little more comfortable. It’s warm, but can get a bit chilly when you stop to check things out. A few tight spaces to get through and a couple of tricky bits navigating rocks so not a great idea for anyone with significant mobility issues. Walking and a bit of swimming in the deeper areas. At one point everyone turned their lights off and the darkness was really cool. An amazing place and excellent experience. Highly recommend it!

AWESOME!!!. Great experience!!!Totally worth it. You should go it´s an awesome and natural experience. going inside the caves and walking through them. There was a moment where the guide asked us to turn all of our lights and we stayed in complete darkness just hearing the sound of the pouring water.They don´t let you enter with cameras, there´s a photographer taking pictures along the tour then they sell the for a lot of money.After the tour there´s a buffet that is included food was really good.Bring good water shoes. Keen or vibram I suggest.

Interesting and Educational. Definitely worth the trip to see this underground cave system that incorporates the entire Yucatán peninsula. It is a bit drawn out in the beginning and at the end. Getting situated with the helmets gear and video introduction can be a bit lengthy. They also make you shower under a cool shower before going into the cave. I find this humorous because well that everything in Mexico in not so clean and after a rainfall the run off ends up in the underground anyway. At the end of the excursion they offer you a quick but very enjoyable lunch. They don't allow you to bring cameras along the trip. They have a photographer taking pictures along the way. You can buy six or seven photographs for about $70. A huge rip off. We wanted one photograph the charges $12 for it. Owen they don't give you a picture it's just a JPEG. Other than that it was a very interesting experience I would highly recommend it.

Amazing experience. I recommend a trip to the Rio Secreto to anyone visiting Cancun and surroundings. It is a fascinating place, full of power and beauty. The water can get a bit cold though, so if you suffer from heart or blatter problems it might not be for you. Our guide, Pablo, was great, he passed on his passion, energy and humour to all of us.

Very interesting!. This was an excursion from a Carnival cruise. We docked in Cozumel and got off the ship and boarded a ferry to Playa del Carmen. In Playa del Carmen we signed releases and then loaded into vans and drove to Rio Secreto. Once you get to the entrance of the attraction the the road does get bumpy. You change into your swim wear and you are given a locker for your belongings. They then give you all the equipment you need to enjoy this wonderful walk through a cave. The water was high, so there was one area where you actually swam for about five minutes. The water is cool not cold. I get cold easily and was ok. The rest of the time the water was no higher than waist deep. The guide was very informative and checked often on everyone. A walking stick would have been helpful in some areas (ask for one). Very pretty inside and lots to look at. Pictures are taken of each group. After the tour, you change clothes, eat lunch (good!) and are offered different options on picture purchases. We bought the CD of pictures for $69. Most of the pictures are inside the caves and specific to your group, Near the end of the disk they throw in some generic scenery pictures. Since you can not take a camera (not even a water camera) this is the least expensive option if you want photos to remember this adventure. I would recommend this. It does take about 7 hours from Cozumel and involves a ferry ride. It was nice to get away from the touristy areas and see a more natural setting. I booked the excursion through Carnival.

Beautiful!!. What a fun excursion. The cave was beautiful. You go though the caves in groups of ten. We already had eight in our group so two more were added to ours. They provide wet suits, life jackets, helmets w/ light, lockers, and towels. Also a walking stick is provided, which I highly recommend and think it should be manatory, as they don't want you to touch anything in the cave and it's needed to help with your balance. You take place in a Mayan blessing before going to the cave. Very cool. There is a short walk through the jungle and then down into the cave you go. Some people in our group of eight, had balance issues and hip problems, so we moved a little slower then the rest of the groups. It's pretty physical you are walking up and down over rocks and into and out of water. There is no light except what is on your helmet. Our guide Daniel was great with helping the ones that had issues. You are in the cave for 1.5 hours, I could of been down there forever. Lunch is served when you get out. The food they had was very good. Pictures were $69.00 which I thought was worth it as no cameras are allowed. Each group had there own photographer. Some of the pictures just of the cave itself were special to each group. I think going to Rio Secreto was one of the highlights of our trip. My husband and I want to do the longer cave tour next time. So we will definitely be back.

Awesome, lots of fun. Loved this, it was great fun. Our guide Melina Barrios was super fun, she did a fantastic job. The Mayan ruins were beautiful, the trip was an all day thing, with food and drinks provided. We went to the ruins in the afternoon and in the morning we did snorkling in the cenote , zip lining, repelling and we also had a Mayan ritual preformed in the cenote by a Mayan person. The trip was very educational and adventurous at the same time.

Omg!. I can't believe they let us in into this wonderful underwater river! The tour consists of hiking into this cave that is 35km long, at least of what has been mapped. Don't worry you don't hike all that. There is a very slow, almost still, river flowing int the cave and you get to go in it! This has been the best experience here in Mexico! The lunch afterward is yummy, and the water they use is filtered! If you rent a car through Budget, you will get one free entrance to the park! Go, before they stop letting people into this precious caves...which I'm sure id they were in the US, you would have to get a permit years in advance to be able to enter it!

Simply Amazing. This excursion was not just exploring a cave, but an incredible experience. Rio Secreto is mindful of the environment and the impact on the cave system. We loved this excursion and it was well worth the price. The road to the cave system is a little bumpy, but we really didn't mind considering they are trying to minimize their impact on the surrounding area. Our guide Adriana was incredible and so knowledgeable about so many aspects of the cave system and reserve.

Great adventure! Worth it!. I have found that many "excursions" while on vacation are not worth it... Rio Secreto was not the case! It was an amazing experience. The cave was amazing and our guide Danielo was wonderful and knowledgeable. He spoke both English and Italian while on our trek, which I thought was very difficult but he did a great job. The tour was erfect amount of time. The food that was part of the tour was also great.The only thing I found and it seems to be the norm in Playa del Carmen is the picture packages they push during the trek and are very expensive at the end. I think making the pictures available would save them a lot of time and money making CD's if they would forgo that process and just email the jpeg and lower the prices, they would probable sell more picture packages that way. Just a suggestion.Also just a FYI once you get to Rio Secreto its still about a 15/20 minute drive out to the cave on a potholed road, it made me a bit car sick.

Great experience. This was an amazing experience. Our guide Rene was great. The only reason I gave it a 4 rather than a 5 is the van to the cave to/from the ferry. It was pouring rain and the van leaked. On a very bumpy potholed road, the driver made no attempt to avoid the potholes.

Most Memorable Day!. We visited Rio Secreto on the 4th day of our vacation in Mexico. The bumpy ride into the jungle was exciting and once we arrived we were greeted by Keke, an english speaking guide. From the moment we met, Keke was such a great energy to be around. He helped us with every aspect of the tour and we had the most amazing experience with him guiding us. We will be traveling to Mexico again and we will definitely be visiting Rio Secreto again!
Loved it!. We had a family of eight, four being teenage boys. It was very interesting and beautiful! Out guide Yuyo ws excellent and answered our many questions!

A Worthwhile Excursion. We booked our Rio Secreto excursion through Best Day Travel.  It was incredible to be able to explore this cave system.  Our guide Leon was a pro -- very knowledgable, great English (they split up groups by language so you can be paired with a guide accordingly), good sense of humor.  I don't recall having the opportunity to grab a walking stick as some of the other reviewers mentioned, but be advised that it can be tricky to navigate the uneven cave floor - pay attention to your footing and the person in front of you.  One of the most memorable parts of the experience was when we all sat down in a shallow section and turned off our head lamps. (Our guide asked if this would be a problem for anyone first.)  It was completely black - you couldn't see your hand in front of your face.  It was so strange, a little scary, and very cool!They get you on the photos, but we bought the CD anyway -- we wanted a tangible memory of the experience and buying the CD was the only way.  Though I do recommend just getting the CD and not the special packages that come with other things.  My only concern about the images is that they try to tailor your photo CD so it includes the individual shots of you and your traveling companions, but ours also included a few photos of other couples, so we wonder whether we really got all of the photos of us or not, or if another couple possible had a few of ours that we didn't.  We'd rather just have all of the photos of the whole group, or at least have the opportunity to go through our group's photos with them and point out the photos of us -- especially for that price -- to ensure we got them all. There are lockers and a decent changing facility. They provide you with shorty wet suits and water shoes. The lunch that follows is perfectly fine. Try to allow a few extra minutes to lay in the hammocks along the path before getting back on the bus - it's very serene. I would definitely recommend this excursion to explore a little of Mexico's natural beauty and geology off-resort.

Awesome Amazing Unreal. Newly discovered caves that are simply amazing. You dawn a wet suit and a helmet with a light on it and proceed into one of the most amazing places I've seen. I'm not going to go into to much description as not to spoil it.All I will say is that this was a company event so ours spouses were not involved which was a shame as it was so moving. I felt very bad experiencing something this great without them.

This is amazing, beautiful, and unlike anything else I've ever seen!. My fiance and I were the only English-speakers in the group on the day we went, so we ended up with our own personal tour guide for the cave. Hector was excellent - very friendly and knowledgeable about the cave and the jungle around it! He took us on one of the less-traveled routes through the cave, so we didn't see anyone else the whole time, and it was an amazing adventure. I got a little scared a couple of times, but in a fun way, and I knew we were never in any danger. Hector gave us all kinds of interesting information and was able to answer all the questions we had. We had a wonderful time, and it really was unlike any experience I'd ever had before! I recommend Rio Secreto very highly - you won't regret it!

hauntingly beautiful. we took this tour as an excursion from the Norwegian jewel. It felt pricey when I booked it but turned out absolutely worth the money. Our guide was Victor who impressed us with both his knowledge and his care & concern for the preservation of the cave. They fed us a buffet lunch that was simple but really good, I think canned soda was $2 or so, reasonable enough. Trip to the site from playa del Carmen was short but the van ride over the dirt roads was rough and uncomfortable for some. They loan you a wet suit which I was sort of skeeved out by but wore anyway and didn't end up with a rash or anything. You get a life jacket and a helmet and we brought our own water shoes but if you don't then they can loan. No personal cameras inside which was kind of a downer since they charge quite a lot for the professional shots. However, the photos came out quite good and looked better than if we had taken our own anyway. This could be slightly uncomfortable for claustrophobics or arachnophobes (me) ... I just tried not to think about it and we didn't see anything till toward the end when our guide found a couple of monstrous horrible whip spiders. Fortunately they stayed on the wall and there was plenty of space to avoid them. GO FOR IT, you wont regret...

Rio Secreto Awesome. If you like to see the wonders of the world you have to go on this tour. It was amazingly beautiful and a little scary at times. You almost feel like the some sort of a cave monster is going to grab you at some point. It's very safe though. Our guide knew so much about the under ground river we learned tons of stuff. They don't let you take pictures but trust me if you want unique pictures you should buy them. Very eco friendly park, they truly do love what they are doing and want to protect this attraction for the future. There is authentic Mexican lunch included that was very good there is no alcohol so not a party attraction but if you want to see something you'll never forget go on this tour. It was educational a little bit of exercise and the under ground river was relaxing.

Best excursion yet!. I recommend this excursion to everyone. Amazing educational experience! Absolutely beautiful cave!
Just when you think that having a knowledgeable guide is all you need, along comes Adriana who also knows so much Mayan history AND loves what she does!
If you are staying in Playa del Carmen, call and ask about the free transportation they offer!

This is a MUST-DO attraction!. I visited this "attraction" on a shore excursion from a Carnival cruise on October 9, 2013, and one week later I'm still in awe of the experience!First of all, I have to mention that our tour guide, Hector, was absolutely fantastic! He was very knowledgable about the cave systems, as well as the surrounding ecosystems, and he took every step to ensure that my dad (who has arthritis and isn't able to move around as well as the rest of us) was able to get around okay all the time. He was also very laid-back, yet professional, and his enthusiasm made our tour more enjoyable.The facilities (restroom, lockers, shower area, dining area, etc) were basic, however, they were clean and seemed well-maintained. The buildings construction were such that they didn't seem to be making much of an impact on the land, which is great because it gives it a more natural feel. The caves themselves seemed as untouched as possible, with no man-made lighting aside from your headlamps and the flashlight of the tour guide. There is a moment when you are able to take a seat and turn off all your lights, fully immersing yourselves in the complete darkness of the cave, only hearing the distant drips of water from the stalactites. It really is an incredible experience. Before you enter the caves, you are asked to change into a swimsuit and then step under a shower briefly to wash away any harmful chemicals or oils that may be on your skin. You are also asked to remove any metals (watches, jewelry) as they can also be harmful to the ecosystems inside the caves, but prescription glasses are okay to have, for obvious reasons. From there, you get a wetsuit, then a helmet, then a life vest, and then water shoes. After this, you're fully outfitted and are able to begin your tour (there are no rental fees for the equipment). As people have mentioned before, you aren't allowed to take any photos or video, but a photographer follows your group in the caves to take photos as you go. You are given the option to purchase these on a cd at the end (around $70 at the time). I would highly recommend the experience to anyone who visits this area of Mexico, on a cruise ship or not. I was a bit worried there would be a lot of swimming, because I'm not the strongest swimmer, but the life vest did most of the work for me, and there were only 2 areas that I needed it (we toured the Palacios "route"). I was also a bit worried that we might encounter some spiders along the way, but surprisingly enough I didn't really see many, and the ones I did see were far enough away that I wasn't worried (and they were small). Hector did point out a type of spider called an Amblypigids to us that was hiding in some ficus root. They look a lot more intimidating than they really are, and because they blend in so well, it's really kind of hard to see it without help from your tour guide so you won't have to worry about one sneaking up on you. The only wildlife we saw aside from that was a shrimp. I did hear some bats, but I never saw any. So, if you're thinking you might not do this because you can't swim very well and/or because of the bugs you might encounter, please, don't let that stop you! I can't say enough good things about this tour! If I return to this area of Mexico I will try my hardest to get back there and see a different cave system. It really is an amazing secret!

Incredible! A MUST See!. My husband and I went to Rio Secreto a few weeks ago on 9/30/13. It was truely one of the highlights of our trip to Mexico. Our guide Rodrigo really made the experiance that much better, he was fun, educational and you could really tell he loved showing us this amazing place. At one point he had us floating in complete darkness which was so tranquil and calming. Being in such a natural and pristine place is an experiance that can't be put into words. Plus I love how the money you spend there goes towards helping preserve the caves and the land around it. I highly recommend making the trip to see this place if you are traveling to this area.

Must see. We had a fantastic experience at Rio Secreto. It was informative, clean and professional. Yes, you cannot take photos and yes, you are followed by a guide/photographer and yes, you can buy any or all of the photos for a fee afterwards. This is all explained to you so if you have an issue with that, you should probably not go. Keep in mind that that you have the same thing in the states when you go on tours. Revenue keeps the place running, so you cannot have it all. I think it is very reasonably priced and our tour guide, Adriana, was amazing. If you are unsteady or afraid of enclosed spaces, this may not be for you. You are given everything you need there, wetsuit, helmet, walking stick, towels, shower, lockers, and a nice meal afterwards. Relax and enjoy the uniqueness of the experience. It is a treasure.
Amazing!. It was amazing. It was well worth every penny. The water was so clear and cold. They do give you a wet suit to wear to help with the cold water. There is a lot to see there.

Go....no questions asked!. This was the highlight of our entire trip to the Yucatan peninsula which included Chichen Itza, Tulum, and Xel-ha. This is an underground river that you get to float and walk through. It's so great because it isn't all done up with lights and stuff to make it look fancy. It is natural and the real deal! Almost an out of body experience that should not be missed, and the fact that it is relatively cheap makes it even better! Be sure not to miss out on this one!

Incredible, bumpy, beautiful, totally worth seeing! Awesome experience for sure!. I would recommend being the first group through. Everything is calm and rested not stirred up in the water. It is so crystal clear and beautiful! I would bring your own water socks. They have helmets & life vests for ya as well if you would like a wet suit. Towels are provided and a nice lunch afterwards. Everyone is very friendly and helpful! Nice group working there. Alfredo loves what he does! That is awesome!

Wonderful Family Experience. Two adults and two children 9 and 11. We had an amazing experience, fully recommended. We stayed at Playa del Carmen area and drove to Rio Secreto, parking no problem. Took about a little less than an hour. The entrance was a bit tricky it took us, some time to find the office. We got all the equipment we needed to be in the cave, and swim. Educational, and fun in one for the kids. Sad part you cant take nothing with you inside the caves, I mean nothing. But make sure to pose for photos inside as they come out AWESOME! Good Mayan food after the tour, and some resting time in the "Hamacas." Make sure you plan at least 4 hours for the whole thing. Finally, the staff is very nice and friendly.

More than what I expected. Rio secreto is a "Must Do" at least once in your lifetime. It was more than we I expected, the guide was very welcoming and knowledgable. It was a terrific way to experience one of natures wonders, I would highly recommend it if you are visiting Cancun or Playa del Carmen.

An Amazing excursion. Started off slow, waiting for other groups to watch the video. Then 7km ride through the jungle to get to the cave. Once there they give you water shoes and wet suit and life jacket, and hardhat with a light on it. We were in the caves for 1.5 hours. It was great. With all the rain in September we had a couple of places we had to swim across. The only thing that we didn't like was the price of the photos. we found them very pricy at $69US for the disc. You could not take your own camera with you. So now we only have memories no pictures. But the excursion is well worth the money and time.
wow. it was awesome! learned a lot. loved the Mayan ritual n meditation part of the tour. food was great. the location was beautiful. our tour guide Raul was a sweetheart.

Awesome. This was brilliant. I went with my 14 year old son and he thought it was brilliant also. We spent 1.5 hours walking, wading and swimming through over 1km of underground waterways. The rock formations and water pools were amazing. It was truly spectacular. We felt privileged to be able to do this - there cannot be too many experiences like this around the globe. Alfredo was a fantastic guide - truly passionate about what he does and about Rio Secreto. Everyone should do this if you get the chance. Truly unique and very special.

An amazing beautiful day!. We booked this as an excursion on our Carnival cruise. It was one of the more pricey options, but absolutely worth EVERY penny!!! We were escorted to the park from the port by Angel... Very professional and courteous. Argelia was an excellent guide, very knowledgeable and passionate! I would very highly recommend going on this tour into this truly amazing "secret river"!!
Beautiful!!! . What a beautiful place! Very nice how sacred and how much respect they show to this beautiful pristine place. Highly recommend going on this expedition.

Rio Secreto Underground Adventure. Just got back from Playa del Carmen, Mexico where my wife and I took an excursion to Rio Secreto, an underground river system formed due erosion of the limestone bedrock that is the foundation of this area. On arrival at the complex we were greeted by a multi-lingual host who asked us to wait until enough English-speaking clients arrived to make up a full tour party. The groups are intentionally kept small in order for the guides to be able to work with them properly. There were nine in our group, plus Joan, our guide, and a professional photographer who accompanied us and documented the tour.We started with an introductory video presentation then moved on to get our wet-suits, water shoes, life jackets and helmets complete with headlights. After a cold shower to remove any tanning lotion, oils or other substances which might pollute the pristine water we suited up and headed to the entrance. Before entering the caves we received a traditional Mayan blessing then started our adventure.I have to admit I felt a little out of my element. The organization is very protective of the area and stressed frequently that we should avoid touching the limestone formations or damaging any of the natural features we came in contact with. This doesn't sound hard but when you take into account that you are walking mostly through water on uneven surfaces with half-formed stalagmites and rock formations waiting to trip you up it gets a little interesting. Add to this the fact that water levels were quite high due to recent rains, this was to prove a challenge for a virtual non-swimmer like me.The circuit consists of wading through amazing underground passages that lead to incredible vaulted caves and beautiful rock formations. Joan proved very knowledgeable and informative and explained the geological history of the area. There were some places where I really wondered what I was doing there,especially when we were forced to paddle-swim because the water became too deep to walk. As I mentioned, being a poor swimmer at first I wasn't happy when I couldn't touch bottom, but eventually got the hang of things and started to relax.Probably the coolest part of the trip was when we gathered in one cave and everyone turned their headlamps off. You will never experience such total blackness above ground! And the total absence of light increases the power of all your other senses. Each drip of water from the ceiling becomes the most important sound in the universe, and you can almost hear the caves breathing and feel the vastness around you that you can not see.I have to say that if I had known how challenging this trip would prove before we booked, I might not have decided to go on it. As it turned out, it was one of the best experiences I have had and coming out of the cave gave me a strong feeling of personal achievement. Also the time underground helped me work up quite an appetite, so the included lunch buffet was very welcome.I would definitely recommend this excursion to anyone looking for something a little different and a little challenging.

WOW. JUST WOW! This is a MUST if you are in the area! Plan it taking a total of 5-6 hours of your day. Check in, driving 7 miles to the entrance, getting "suited" up and afterwards enjoying the complimentary buffet.

Unforgettable and great value.. The Amazing Secret River shore excursion (~$110/person) offered by Carnival Cruises at the Cozumel port is by far the best mid-to-high-level activity you could ask for given the value. Approx. 40 min ferry ride (with drinks available) and 20min on bus through a rough, unpaved trail (forewarning), you are brought to a hidden gem in the jungle. Well-equipped with restrooms, showers, lockers, and hammocks, the facilities are maintained better than that of a public beach restroom. The bilingual tour guides provide wet suits, life vests, and helmets, as well as optional bodysuits and walking sticks (both are highly recommended because of the cold waters and limited visibility through the dark waters.) No jewelry, cameras, sunblock, makeup, or accessories are allowed in order to preserve the water quality. Once in the caverns, you will have very limited visibility and trails are quite slippery. This adventure is not recommended for those scared of the dark or confined spaces, and it would be very difficult if you have limited walking accessibility. As avid mud-runners/active athletes, my husband and I still found ourselves quite challenged. Several times you will be forced to swim completely, although the life vests help. However, if you manage to get past a few tight squeezes, you will not regret any of it. The view within the caverns is a once-of-a-lifetime experience and surpasses any postcard you could buy. During our ~1.5h trek, we saw bats, spiders, and explored only 1 of the many cavern paths you could take. After completion, we were given a delicious Mayan meal and allowed to see/purchase our stunning photos--well worth the money ($60 for CD of all photos).If you wish to do something more natural and truly adventurous, do not miss out on this activity.

Rough trip there, but relaxing over all.. My boyfriend and I booked this place as a Shore Excursion for our Cozumel stop during a Carnival Cruise. I had already seen unimpressive caves in Puerto Rico before so I was not expecting much, but aside from the long and tough travel to Rio Secreto I was surprised and happy with our choice. Rio Secreto brings an immersive and humbling experience to its visitors.Our travel time to the destination after leaving the ship was about 2 hours including a ferry ride from Cozumel to Riviera Maya and a van trip from Riviera Maya to our destination. The ferry ride was smooth with some wildlife to see on the way, but the ferry staff are right in your face trying to sell you drinks and snacks. There were some really tough, pothole-riddled gravel roads to travel down on the Van part that had you bouncing around real bad, but it was not too uncomfortable and I believe nobody was injured.The cave trip was beyond expectations; you are not just walking down some safe, well lighted carved walkway in tourism clothes while looking at cave structures with a tour guide. You have to put on gear (a lighted helmet, a wetsuit, a life jacket, and some slip proof water shoes) and you are climbing up and down rock formations and walking through and floating down underwater rivers in complete darkness where the ONLY light is coming from your helmets and a flash light that the tour guide is carrying. There is also wildlife in this cave: we saw crickets, some sort of giant arachnids, bats, and fish.While traveling in the caves, you cannot take pictures, but the staff assigns a trained photographer that follows your group through the cave and takes pictures, both unannounced and posed, through the trip. You can buy the photographs after looking at them on an iPad later outside of the cave, but they are VERY pricey ($25 for one picture or $69 for a disc with all of the pictures).There is a free buffet of traditional Mexican food and drink after the cave, but I feel that I must warn you that flies and other bugs crawl all over the food and get in the drinks since it is right out in the open with no coverings. You can also purchase soda, bottled water, or snacks at the buffet. We had a little bit of time to eat at the buffet and rest in hammocks or chairs and an hour of shopping/beach time in Riveria Maya before being ferried back to Cozumel.I will take the time to point out that our tour guide, Alfredo, was incredibly accommodating and informative. He responded to every request and out-of-place sound that somebody made and tried his best to answer every question. I definitely felt that his name was worth mentioning. There were other guides involved, but my experience with them was average at best.Rio Secreto was realistic and engaged. It you are looking for a more natural option with less commercial flair for your trip to Mexico, I am confident that Rio Secreto is a great choice.

Amazing... Just Amazing. We stayed at a hotel and it rained pretty much the entire time. We wanted to get out and do something as to not waste the vacation. The tour guy had tons of options, but we needed to stay within budget. Rio Secreto was one of the lower end admissions, but it was something I believed I could do since I don't like open water. Let me tell you that it was incredible. We were taken to the site, and after a very long bumpy ride to the reserve, and a very cold shower, were suited up with wet suits, water shoes, life jackets and helmets with lights. We were told of how the Mayans wanted to keep the reserve as natural as possible. We were "cleansed" by a local Mayan and made our descent into the caverns. You travel about 80 feet underground and for most of the time, are knee-deep or waist-deep in water, but there is a stretch where you need to swim.Our guide, Renee, was totally awesome. You could really tell that he was knowledgeable and passionate about the reserve and it made the trip so much more rewarding. He also spoke English very well.It is pitch black down there, so the helmet lights and the guide's flashlight is all you have. This is not America, where we would plow a walkway through the rock so as no injuries to occur. This is all natural and you must walk the way the guide instructs you. There are no rails. You cannot touch the rock. And because of this, the area is absolutely gorgeous. This is one of the most amazing things I have done in my life. I hope to do many more, but I am so happy that I can say that I experienced this. The earth is incredible.

Excellent. Fabulous guide, never spelunked in my life but Roderigo made it all worth while, so knowledgeable and entertaining. It was one of the most exciting yet serene things I have ever done and I would highly recommend it and the guide.

Amazing experience!. Wow...just wow. We booked this last minute - just a few hours before the start and they fit us in. All you need is yourself and a swimsuit to wear underneath the wetsuit they provide. I don't even know how to describe the experience except amazing, breathtaking, and awesome. Our guide spoke both English and Spanish and was very helpful and considerate. You can't take your camera with you, but they will take your picture at certain points throughout the cave. They were a bit expensive, but I definitely bought them all and would do it again in a heartbeat just to have some wonderful mementos of this cave adventure. I'm not a religious person, but something about these caves is spiritual - the calm, dark, beautiful spaces - you can't help but to feel inspired. Anytime I go back to Playa, you can bet I'll be returning to Rio Secreto.Also, the staff is really nice and helpful and they provide a wonderful meal after your excursion. (Though the road you take to and back from the cave is really really rough, so eat light!)

Excellent Experience. This was an excellent tour. All equipment is provided for you as well as a photographer. Adriana was a great tour guide as well as history teacher. She is very knowledgeable in what she does and seems to have a genuine love for what she does. Thank you.

Excellent. Did this with 2 boys, age 6 and 10. They loved it. Older one said, "Wow! This is nothing like the caverns in Minecraft!"Food was very good, guide (Julian) was good. A great experience.Only downside was cost of the photos. $25 for 1! Or $70 for all. Overpriced.

Best way to experience a cenote. The Rio Secreto entrance is just south of Playacar. Once there you fill out a liability form and are assigned to a Guide. You will watch an introduction that is available in most languages. Then you are loaded on to a van for the 7 km ride to the cenote. The road is very bumpy and hence very slow going. The driver must weave back and forth to avoid pot holes. We visited in September which is rainy season and perhaps that is why there were many pot holes. The trip along can be exciting if you spot an animal. We saw a tarantula making its way across the road but other than a variety of butterflies and the odd huge grasshopper that was it. Once you arrive to the cenote you are introduced to your guide. Our guide was Hector and he was amazing. You only need your swim suit on. Lockers are provided for your belongings and you keep the key. Hector had us outfitted with water shoes, wet suites, life jackets and helmets with lights. Our group was 8 people. Once we were ready we walked to the cenote and began our almost 2 hour adventure. If I can do it any one can. The journey through the cave consisted of walking through water, over rocks, under low caves, swimming or floating in deeper water and you never had your head under water. The water is pristine and the bottom easily visible. Hector guided us where to walk and all of us came out of the cave without a scratch. His knowledge of the rock formation was incredible. A photographer shadows your tour and takes pictures along the way. Afterward you may purchase the pictures on a disk. Price ranges over $100 for the disk, book about Rio Secreto and bottle of their liquor to $35 for a single picture. We went middle of the ground and purchase the book and disk for $100. It was a bit expensive but we didn't bring our own camera with us on this trip so it is the only pictures we have of our whole vacation. After the tour there is a buffet lunch of Mexican food that is very good. Then once everyone is ready you are driven back to your hotel. Or you may choice to go ATVing back to the entrance and then get on a van for your resort. This is a remarkable excursion and well worth doing.

A Must See!. This was an outstanding excursion.You are provided with a wet suit , water shoes, a flashlight helmet, and a life vest before walking to the cave. Carine was our guide. She was very nice and knowledgeable. Before going into the cave we were blessed with a mayan blessing of smoke and prayer before entering the "under world". Very interesting. The caves are beautiful. It is a an amazing sight. I feel so privileged to have been able to see this. Most of the formations are still alive and growing. I cannot help but feel that people being down there walking and swimming around will someday impair the beauty of this cave. It was only discovered in 2005. It is a natural wonder! If you have trouble walking or balancing or can't swim I suggest you do not take this trip. You are guided through knee deep water in a dimly lit cave. Only your helmet light and the guides flash light illuminate the cavern.There are many large rocks to step over and many large step offs. Some spots we had to swim. We could not feel the bottom. We were fortunate that there were just us four plus the guide in our group. I feel we got a more personal tour. They served us a meal after the tour. I didn't know we would get a meal with our trip so it was better than nothing. The food wasn't all that great but it was nice to have a beer and sit and enjoy the beautiful jungle around us. Don't miss this excursion! You will not be disappointed!!! Outstanding!

very interesting experience - highly recommend. We saw the good reviews on Tripadvisor & decided to give this a go. We were not disappointed. The diving suits were wet, & my water shoes were full of holes & also wet, which I found gross, but if you can steel yourself & try not to think about it, those were pretty much the only negatives to the tour. The caves are spectacular, & our guide was personable. It was just the right length (around two hours), & being separated into language groups meant you didn't have to wait for the tour to be translated into several other languages.This tour doesn't have much replay value (I wouldn't do it again, because of the cost), & you aren't allowed to take pictures inside (they charge you an arm & a leg selling you CDs of your pictures instead), so take it all in using your senses & save it to your memory. I would definitely recommend doing this tour.

TOUR OF A LIFETIME. This was by far the coolest experience we have had in awhile! We were encouraged to do the 1.5 hour tour by our travel agent at our hotel, in passing he mentioned there is a 4 hour tour called "privilege" that most people don't know about but we didn't think much of it until we loved our first tour as much as we did! our tour guide was so great and made us feel like we were caving champs! Since the weather conditions were somewhat poor the week we were there we decided we couldn't pass up the opportunity to try the "privilege tour", wow did we make a good decision. For a very affordable price we were given the opportunity most people will never experience. We had a private tour (just my husband and myself, Rodrigo and hector our tour guides/ photographer) for four hours exploring one of the most beautiful network of caves I have ever seen! Rodrigo and Hector are amazing! Both have been in the cave at least 1000 times. Hector was one of the first to explore the cave when it was discovered and Rodrigo has a great personality and sense of direction making it the best four hours you will ever have on a tour if you have an adventurous spirit. You need to be in great physical condition, and not be claustrophobic. If you are up for an adventure do this tour! Request Rodrigo and Hector! you will not be disappointed!side note, lunch is included in the price of the tour and it is soooo good

Sin Palabras!. One of the most incredible experiences. Breathtaking underground caverns, actually swimming in an underground river amidst stalactites, stalagmites. Our guide, Hector, is a professional, yet friendly& fun host. Perfect. Do not dare come here and not visit Rio secreto! An absolute must for everyone.

Rio Secreto Cenote. At first I was a little worried about a water excursion because my husband does not swim. After doing a little research and speaking to our excursion specialist I convinced him to give it a try. Great decision!! They suit you up with wetsuits and life jackets, as well as water shoes. After a short walk through the jungle, you are gathered and blessed by a Mayan gentleman for safe passage. After entering the cenote, all I can say is "amazing"! The underground caves are beautiful and the swimming/floating through the deeper caverns was great. My husband felt very comfortable in the water as well. Enjoy!

Get there before it's spoiled. An hour and a half underground, walking and swimming through galleries of stalagtites, columns, and stalagmites. Our guide was informative and professional. I appreciated that they were being strict about not touching anything, so the last five years of use only slightly shows.If you have wetsuit boots that cover your ankles, I would recommend using them rather than the low cut ones provided; there are some sharp formations below that water that can bite.The photo disc you can buy at the end for $70US is a bit much, but you might economize by sharing the cost and the group photos on it with others.

Great Ceynote experience for non-swimmers. While buying our tickets, we categorically told them we are not great swimmers and they kept that in mind, throughout our adventure. The bus ride to the Ceynote was bumpy but we actually enjoyed it. Gives you an idea of how pristine and untouched they try to keep their surroundings. They do tours in different languages and they have small tour batches which means a lot of personal attention. Our guide, Mauricio was excellent. He made extra effort to take my husband and I through the parts that required swimming (the swimming part is not really difficult, but Mauricio took extra care). We stopped at various areas where Mauricio told us some very interesting things about the formations and the marine life that exists in the caves. We had shots at the end of our tour. The changing rooms were exceptionally clean, which is always so important. They even served us a light snack (not the best food we ate in Playa Del Carmen, but decent). Overall, a wonderful experience and a 'must-do'

One of the best excursions of six cruises!. The wife and I recently went on a western caribbean cruise and Cozumel was one of the stops. The reviews for this excursion were 5 stars on a consistent basis, so we booked it early. We're so glad we did! Our tour guide, Hector, was very informative, polite, and overall made the experience a very memorable one. The river, cave system, and the complete authenticity was no gimmick - it's the real deal. We cannot wait to bring family and friends along for a future cruise to Cozumel and show this one off to them. I would not hesitate to recommend this and put it right along side scuba diving in mexico as one of the most breathtaking experiences I have ever had.

Superb !. Its a bumpy minibus ride from the entrance to the centre. You get an introductory talk, shower off your chemicals, and slip into wet-suits and helmet with light on. Soon you are in the underground caves and rambling through cavern after cavern. Huge stalagmites and stalagtites, and a lot of wading. You can even swim. The water is very clean and refreshing. Lots of photos you can buy at the end. Very informative guide, Rodrigo. Lunch provided afterwards. A good few hours went like a flash ! Highly recommended !

Breathtaking. This is an experience that you get addicted to. The beauty, stillness, the wonders that the pass of time in the caves give us is unique. The kindness of the staff is incredible. You dont want it to end. I would like to congratulate Hector for his patience. We got a tour with a family thst was really scared and difficult. He managed to calm them and excite all of us. And Julian my second guide, yes, I came back right away. Was fantastic as well. Both of them are incredible in knowledge, patience. The food is incredible and the pictures are a treasure.

Incredible experience and with Hector even better!!!!. Rio Secreto is a must! You can't miss this amazing experience, the cave is really well-preserved and not-humanized :) It is so much fun and grounding to the nature! Definitely recommend Hector!!!

Worth the bumpy ride!. This was quite an experience that you shouldn't miss out on. The caves are amazing and the water is cold! Don't worry, you get a wet suit! We really enjoyed ourselves and our guide was knowledgeable and funny. Although you don't get to bring your camera, they take a ton of photos of you posed and just walking around. Definitely worth seeing!

Great Experience. My husband and I took this tour while staying nearby in Akumal. We both enjoyed our time in the cave as well as the buffet lunch afterwards. Our guide, Corine, was wonderful. She made me feel comfortable in a totally new environment and was very professional. You do need to be careful while making your way along the trail but the time spent swimming through the water was magical. The pictures are too expensive, however, and we purchased only one. If the price had been reduced, we probably would have taken more. This was certainly a highlight of our time in Mexico.

Very Unique Experience. Rio Secreto is a must stop on your next trip to the Riviera Maya. However just be ready for a LONG, SLOW, BUMPY ride to the caves! That is the only negative so don't worry to much. The caves are beautiful and the water is cold, but it is so much fun! Nunes was a great guide, who kept us moving at a pace we all could comfortable move about the caves. You will do some hiking and swiming all while visiting a place you can't find anywhere else! The photos are a bit pricey, but you have to buy at least one because no one wil believe your tales without a photo!

Rodrigo was the best!. Our tour guide Rodrigo definitely made this excursion for us! The best thing we have ever done! Rodrigo was so intelligent and passionate about the caves and answered all of our questions! We absolutely loved it! Definitely recommend Rodrigo!

Great Time. We went to Rio Secreto as a family of four. With all the activities we did the entire trip, our girls both said that Rio Secreto was their favorite. It was a lot of fun exploring the cave and learning all about it (how it forms, ecosystem, Mayan use, etc.) For my wife and I (in our 30's), we thought the tour was just a little too long. We started to feel cold by the end and were ready to get out. It was a great experience for our family and something we will not soon forget.

Amazing!. The tour of the underground world led by Danilo was truly amazing. It is a bit challenging if you have problems with bending or kneeling, and you should be on the watch-out for underwater rocks and holes. But the beauty of the caves and formations is worth every minute of the two hours you spend in a total darkness! They provide all equipment including reef walkers, helmets with headlights and wetsuits. The lunch after the tour is simple but tasty (sodas and beers are extra). A CD with photos costs $69 (and they would not bargain), one photo of your choice is $25 (we have chosen the CD which also includes professional photos of the caves).

Pictures at Rio Secreto. The excursion waooo (the cave awesome) our tour guide Raul excellent the only negative thing was the amount of picture to buy only 7 picture of 25 are Us. the rest of the picture are with the group. If more individual picture are included (ask the photographer inside the cave) will be better.JaJo2013 Puerto Rico

Great experience!. We had such a great time at Rio Secreto! What an amazing experience! If you are looking for something different this is it. Yayo, our tour guide was full of knowledge about the the cave. The snack that is included is more like a lunch. We truly enjoyed this excursion and would recommend it.

Thanks Rodrigo!. I won't write a lengthy review as previous reviewers have covered everything. In short - beautiful and entirely unspoilt caves, perfect for all ages (4 up as they don't have wetsuits smaller and the water is cold for little ones), delicious lunch (all vegetarian buffet), and great to see immense respect for the environment. My main reason for reviewing though is our guide Rodrigo. If you are English or Spanish speaking and have small children make sure you ask for him. He is awesome with kids!! My 5 year old son Otto cried all the way back to our hotel yesterday (and then some) because in his words "I love Rodrigo so much and can't bear never to see him again." He's still talking about him today and begging me to purchase a $25 photo of him to join the superheroes on his wall. No mightier praise!

Gorgeous Cenote/Cave Tour. What an amazing and peaceful place. Our tour guide Rodrigo was awesome too, very knowledgeable about the caves, the natural environs, and Mexico. The only thing I wished there was less of was posing for the professional photographer. It took up time that we could have been exploring more of the cave or hearing from our guide about cenotes in general.

Amazing experience. This is amazing. Really a once in a lifetime experience. From the hike through the jungle to the tour of the cave it is amazing. Caring tour guides, amazing location, and a relaxing swim make this an experience that you will never forget. Lunch is delicious. If you have any sort of foot or ankle trouble I would recommend using a cane (provided). There are no handholds in the cave and the ground is incredibly uneven. It is all worth it though when you turn off all of the lights and just sit in the darkness and silence of the cave. I have never in my life experienced anything so peaceful!

Best Cenote Tour!. Rio Secreto is an unreal experience and having the perfect tour guide made the adventure all the more better. Carin is funny, full of knowledge of the cave and surrounding areas and we felt well looked after. We had a big age spread in our group - 9 to 63 - and she handled us all with care and humor from the beginning to the very end with drinks, great food and excellent conversation. It was a perfect day of adventure and relaxation.

Fantastic experience. We enjoyed every single moment of this trip. It was a wonderful experience and our tour guide made sure that everyone is safe during the walk and swim through the caves. Highly recommended !

A Great Experience. While staying at Secrets Silversands in August, we booked an excursion to Rio Secreto. We had our choice of morning or afternoon trip. We chose morning, but it was almost a full day of adventure! We were picked up at nine and returned to the resort just before four. It takes some time and several van changes to reach the underwater caves. On arrival the tour company was a well oiled machine. Visitors were divided into small groups based on preferred language for a guide. While there we heard guides speaking Spanish, English, French and Italian! If you have a language request, be sure to look into their ability to meet your needs. The guides are very respectful of the environment and ask all visitors to shower and wear water shoes (which will be supplied if you need them), a wet suit and life jacket, as well as a helmet with an attached light. You just need your bathing suit. The entire time underground is about 90 minutes, but the time flew by! If you have any concerns about mobility, be sure to take a walking stick when it is offered. I did not take one, and regretted it. It can be a bit undaunting to step into water when you can't see where you are stepping, and a walking stick would have been a big help. You don't need to be able to swim as the water never gets too deep. The company takes photos of your group as you tour the caves and then you are given an opportunity to purchase some or all of them before you leave. At the end of the tour you are served a buffet lunch before returning to your hotel. I was especially impressed by the respectful manner in which the environment was always treated. Our guide, Rodrigo, was kind, helpful, funny, informative, and above all else, protective of the caves. It was an amazing experience that I would recommend for anyone travelling in the area.

Awesome!. Amazing experience. Our guide Eddie was so knowledgeable and made the trip even better. Highly recommended!! Accomodations were also great.. Free lockers and towels. Had everything there you needed.

Wow!. It was an awesome experience, by the end of the tour we didn't want to leave. Our tour guide Alfredo was very knowledgeable and was very passionate about the cave. At the very end they have a great full meal waiting for you! We hope we can make it back again.

Amazing. Thank you Yayo...you were a great guide. Fantastic experience, except the spider..,We had another experience buy this one was so much better. I would highly recommend this to anyone wanting to see under water caverns

Gorgeous views. It was really beautiful. Our guide Rodrigo answered all of our questions about these amazing formations and about the situation of the caves in the region. Visiting the site really helps them raise awareness and money to preserve these natural caves from being destroyed by building resorts on top of them :) the visit was really informative and fun, we got to swim in the underground currents and meet some strange fish in the caves :)

going under. An amazing experience. Tours in all major languages. Our guide, Benito, took us on a very spiritual adventure under the ground. Very knowledgeable. He speaks, spanish, french and english. Try to get him, he is good! The Mayan food served at the end of the adventure is also tasty and fun to experiment. No pressure into buying stuff. You decide how much you want to take back with you. We bought the CD. Great pictures. A professionnal photographer accompnies every group so you don't have to worry about taking pictures (cameras are forbiden and I can understand why) It is hard enough to keep up with the group without having to worry about taking pictures.

Beautiful view, amazing guide, great experience. The whole trip was well organized. The bus was on time, a bit of a bumpy ride but not too long. The guide Enrique was very friendly and spoke French very well. He explained the procedure very well and always helped us when the rocks were slippery or warned us about narrow places. Enrique was very knowledgeable about the geology. The food was excellent and very authentic! It is not a physically difficult excursion and no swimming experience required. Recommended to everyone!

amazing. This is one of the most beautiful places I have ever been it is truly worth it and i would highly recommend anyone to go here if you are afraid of caves and deep water than maybe not but i was and now i would go again and again it is the best cave experience you will have .You are in there for like and hour and a half and the tour guides are super nice and they know what they are talking about and they are really passionate about the caves .The tour guide to go for is Alfredo .All in all a memorable experience !!

Must See!!!!!. One of the most amazing things I've ever seen. I prefer to dive on vacation but my girlfriend let me know that instead of me getting to dive that we would be doing this excursion. Very glad that she did because this was a must see life experience and recommend anyone who is going to be close to the area to stop bye and see this place. Our guide Alfredo was extremely pleasant and very knowledgeable throughout the whole adventure. I've never met a person who is a passionate about their job.

Beautiful!. We also had Ridrigo as our guide and he was excellent! A couple members of our family aren't in the best shape so it was a little challenging to navigate on the wet rocks, but it was well worth it as it was simply breathtaking to be in such a pure and beautiful place.

Absolutely fabulous experience. This is the real-deal...proper caving in amazing natural caves (stalagtites/mites everywhere), but in the safe hands of a guide and photographer. In your couple of hours underground you get to walk (dry), walk (in water) and swim. You wear a wet suit and lifejacket (supplied). You have a lamp on your helmet for light.You see the most incredible natural cave formations. Prepare to be amazed.The guide to get is Rodrigo, full of information, and with a real passion for the caves and nature in general. He was an inspiration to our whole group. Thanks Rodrigo.I have seen a few negative remarks about the price of the photos - don't listen to these daft people. There is no way you could take good pictures of your own down there. The photos taken by the second guide are really great. For example, they use a torch to backlight the formations sometimes using a flash to light you - the result is stunning. If you begrudge 60USD for a CD with about 100 excellent photos on it then don't go - go to X-caret or some other kiddie place!

A must do!. This place was great, the caves were amazing and our tour guide Rodrigo really knew his stuff and made us feel really comfortable down the cave. The food wasn't bad either, but watch out for the spicy green sauce!

best attraction in Quintana Roo!. Amazing experience! Diddnt realise the extent of their conservation efforts until Rodrigo, our excellent and enthusiastic guide explained over lunch (which was also the best Mexican food I ate whilst out there, fantastic tamales). Would definitely recommend, ask for Rodrigo too - great guy!

EXCELLENT!! TOO MUCH MONEY FOR PHOTOS .... Trip was amazing and the food provided after the tour was delicious! A must see if you are headed to Cozumel. Travel time to the caves took about an hour and a half. BE PREPARED TO SPEND ABOUT $70 FOR PICTURES!!!!! they DO NOT let you bring your own camera so they can charge you a ridiculous price for their pictures. Other than that the trip is well worth it and absolutely beautiful! Alfredo was our guide and it did an outstanding job!

Amazing!. Took the tour on August 17, 2013 with Eva. What a great experience. We had a 6 person group which allowed Eva to answer questions and share so much info. The caves were stunning and I appreciated the staff's efforts to preserve the aural beauty.

Great Experience. We went to Rio Secreto during our honeymoon. We were recommended to go through the cave tour by someone before we left. Hector was our guide and he was amazing. He had fun with us and since we were the first group to go through the caves he was able to show us some different things and get the full cave experience. We were a little disappointed that we bought a waterproof camera and was unable to use it but they do have a photographer following the group who takes amazing photos, which we purchsed one (the packages were a little more than what we wanted to spend). It was a once in lifetime experience and it was a smooth trip to and from the restor to Rio Secreto. The lunch we had afterwards was very good as well, that was part of my husband's highlight of the trip, having authentic mexican food.

Get off the beach!. Our guide was Benito. He took good care of my family. Outstanding, educational tour of a beautiful ecosystem. Well worth the pesos. This is not a cenote swim. The likelihood is that you will stub your toe or incur a scratch or two, so if that bothers you, this may not be for you. Wonderful experience.

Amazing experience !. We went to Rio Secreto last Wednesday morning and it was so beautiful ! We had Victor as a guide and he was really good, we learned a lot of historical facts about the cenote. Our guide from TMR said Rio Secreto was the best cenote in Riviera Maya area, he was right ! Our trip was in French which was so great ! The water is magnificent and the stalagmites and stalactites are stunning ! After the trip, you get to eat mexican food, it is really good !! Overall, this trip is really worth the visit ! The only advice we would give you is that it is a little bit cold for young children, but perfect for teens and adults !! The whole family really enjoyed it and we highly recommend it !

Awesome experience!!!. We had Eva as our guide on this trip, and she was just fabulous! I really loved the history and background she provided not only at the beginning of the tour, but also throughout. The Rio Secreto van provided transport both to and from our resort, which was great. The video presentation we watched before being driven 7km into the jungle was very interesting, especially as we got to watch it in 3 languages :)Our group of 10 (2 couples and 2 families) had a wonderful time working together, having only met in the van on the way there. To be able to trek through a cave with really cool water was not only refreshing, but truly a one-of-a-kind experience! One of my favorite parts was sitting in one of the caves with our headlamps off, just listening to the silence. It provoked a very peaceful feeling in all of us! The buffet lunch after the tour was pretty good, and the Xtabentun shots were a great wrap up to a very fun time!If there is one weakness of the tour, it'd be the cost of purchasing photos from the tour. $25 for one photo or $65 for a CD with pics from the tour and added stock pictures was a bit steep. We passed, but it didn't diminish any of the experience we had. Hopefully we can find the iguana next time... :-)

A highlight of our trip. Well done!! It felt like more of an adventure than just a tour. Danilo showed us a surprising view of this underground treasure. The lunch that is included was a wonderful and welcome treat. Delicious Empanadas and tamales. It was a well spent afternoon.

How often can you swim through a cave? Amazing!. It was a unique, underground experience in the land of beaches and blue water. If you want to have a breathtaking experience in a beatiful underground world, give this a try. The guide we had, Hector, was extremely knowledgeable, personable, and took a sincere interest in ensuring our enjoyment of the tour. It is a little off the beaten path, down a long dirt road in a jungle ,but I do not know about where you live but I have yet to find beautiful underground caverns where Mayan indians frequented in my suburban neighborhood. It was truly a memorable experience. The food provided after was a nice bonus as well.

Unexpected gem - probably the best excursion in Mexico. This excursion was a wonderful, unexpected surprise. I was with a group of 9 in Playa, and there was interest by some in the group to book this excursion. I was indifferent at the time and mainly decided to go because the rest of the group was in - and since we were all together it would be good regardless, right? Well, let me tell you, this is an awesome experience and shouldn't be missed by anyone visiting Cancun or Playa. Our guide Rodrigo couldn't have been better. He was extremely passionate about exploring the underground river, was full of facts and stories, and seemed genuinely interested in making sure everyone had a great time. With our group of 9, we had Rodrigo all to ourselves - and he seemed very observant to tailor the tour based on the interest and abilities of the group. The underground caves were just discovered in 2006, so they are still in a very natural state. You'll walk and swim through the underground river and the views of the stalagmites and stalactites are breathtaking. When finished, you will be served a great, 'typical' lunch that is really quite good (lunch included, beer/soft drinks available for a very nominal fee).We booked through a travel agent at our resort, and it included transportation from the resort by Rio Secreto. Once at the entrance to Rio SecretoThere are lockers available onsite to use when changing into your wetsuit. Wear a bathing suit, and it's not a bad idea to bring some water and a change of dry clothes a well for when you're finished. Keep in mind that you cannot wear any watches or jewelry, and personal cameras are not permitted.

007 Cave Experience. It started with a 007 reference whilst putting on our wetsuits and the fun went on from there. Our guide, Rodrigo, was very friendly. He helped our youngest son who wasn't a confident swimmer, through the caves and was still able to keep up a great description of the caves and their formation and sing the James Bond theme tune. The caves were beautiful and well worth a visit. I was embarrassed by our limited Spanish but there was no issue as Rodrigo's English was perfect. We were picked up from our hotel in a minivan by a very friendly driver who stopped on the way to show us a massive nest on top of a pylon. You get transported to the caves via a long bumpy trail through the jungle where you meet the guides and get kitted out in wetsuits and life jackets. A photographer accompanies you on the tour and you can purchase photos at the end after you have been given a strong shot of something that helps losen the wallet! I didn't feel that there was a hard sell though which was a good thing. There was a buffet lunch at the end which our guide talked us through and kept checking in on us to laugh at my oldest son who had tried the hot sauce. At the end of the morning we were transported back to the hotel by the same driver which I think made the experience better having that continuity.

Great tour. We had a great time on our tour. The 7km ride to the caves from the entrance was bumpy to say the least but it was worth it. Yes, the suits and helmets were a little stinky but I think thats because of the cleaning agents they use. The tour was amazing. I loved seeing everything and experiencing the caves and the very fresh water. Our guide Danilo was wonderful, very knowledgeable, funny, and took care of our safety. The food at the end was good. Its out in the wilderness so it was what I expected and was delicious. I can't comment about the price of pictures because there was something wrong with uploading them from the photographer's camera and although we were told we would get an email with them if we want to purchase some, we have yet to receive anything (my boyfriend and I each gave our email and neither of us have gotten anything in almost a week). I would have loved to take pictures, especially if they are very expensive or we never see any. We weren't told we couldn't bring cameras so we went out and bought a disposible waterproof one just for this.

Rio Secreto | Highly Recommended. I was on the fence about this excursion, but it turned out one of the best points of the trip. Rodrigo was our guide. He was friendly, passionate about the caves and extremely knowledgeable. This is highly recommended.

Amazing excursion!. My family went on the Disney Fantasy the first week of August- 2013. We booked this as one of our excursions and were completely amazed by the beauty of this cave. We have done several cave tours throughout the Midwest and nothing compares to this! We all loved it-my husband, daughter (age 9) and son (age 7). My 7 year old did get pretty cold as he was in the water more than the rest of us (he is small for his age and had to swim much of the waist deep water). Everyone else was fine, the water is cool but actually feels good while you are walking/swimming the cave. Our tour guide Alfredo was great! Our kids loved him and we will request him the next time we do this-we skip all the other exursions next time but will be returning to do this one again!! Alfredo explained so much about the cave, the area and the Mayan culture. He loved his job and that came through in his passion for nature and the environment. He also went above and beyond and gave our son a piggy back ride so he would not be submerged in the water. They provided all the necessary equipment, we did opt to use our own aqua socks, but theirs would have been fine.

A time-stopping experience!. Just WOW - this excursion went beyond my expectations, and really provided a treat of an experience for the 9 of us in our group. Rodrigo was an exceptional guide - so knowledgeable, friendly, engaging...it was evident that this is a passion for him, rather than work. The reverence and wonder he demonstrated throughout the journey really set the tone for our experience. In particular, the opportunity to bask in the silence of the cave and waters with our lights turned out was unreal - truly made time stop for me. That is something I will hold on to tightly. Do not hesitate to visit this treasure that time has left behind...

HIGHLY recommended excursion!!!!. Rodrigo was our cave guide, and he was AMAZING. He was very knowledgable, witty & charming... and the passion he holds for his vocation is evident! The Rio Secreto is sooooo beautiful. Our friends who made the excursion together agreed that it surpassed all of our expectations. It's definitely a must-see!

Awesome Tour!!!!!!!. Eddie was our tour guide and was very knowledgable of the caves. We had a small group of only 5 people and felt as if we had a personalized tour. Great for the entire family. Swimming, walking, and balancing are all a must. Worth the $$$$$

Best trip ever!. At first I was skeptical, driving down the long dirt roads, but then we arrived. Gonzo was our tour guide and he's the best! Along with the photographer, sorry can't remember his name, we explored for 2 hours. I didn't think my son (22 yrs) and daughter (16) would like this, but they were truly amazed. My wife and I have recommended it to all our friends and family. You peacefully float down the river, stopping in some amazing 'rooms' and learn all about the history of this magical place. it was well worth the time and expense.
Really great!. Amazing attraction! Our guide, Yayo, was really great. Would go again if we ever return to the area.

Best Activity you can do on the Mayan Riveria. Helmet, light, wet suit, vest and water shoes are all provided! This tour is by far the best activity I have done in several visits to numerous others on the Mayan Peninsula. Part of tour on dry ground, part wading and part swimming/floating through amazing underground features! Truly a breathtaking adventure. Photos take by them and sold to you at the end. Top end package was about $120 which included three "gifts" you get to chose from among hats, dri fit shirts and other trinkets. Photos are not copyrighted and you can make all the copies of the photo disc you want with their blessing. By far the best experience and deal in the Cancun/Playa del Carmen region!

Absolutely worth visiting. We went to Rio Secreto and were overwhelmed by the place. It was a wonderful trip, and we had an amazing time. Our guide Danilo was amazing. He showed us so much, and really made sure we had the best experience. If we ever go back to Mexico we will be sure to go to Rio Secreto again. Really a beautiful and breathtaking place!

Wonderful Excursion in Rio Secreto Playa Del Carmen, Mexico. We took an excursion to Rio Secreto off of Carnival Cruise Lines while in Cozumel. Eduardo was assigned to be our guide. I cannot say enough positive about the excursion and our guide in particular. The Rio Secreto is an amazing underground river system that you are allowed to hike and swim through. You will see, like Carlsbad Caverns, growing stalactites and stalagmites and columns and more. I cannot recall the exact amount of time in the cave system we had, but it was close to 2-3 hours.
