Groups are limited to about 10 with enough separation between groups that you do not often see anyone else down there. We were fed a nice local flavor lunch afterwards. Wet suits, water shoes, helmets, lights and a locker are provided as part of the fee. Eduardo made the trip very enjoyable with his knowledge of the Rio Secreto, the local area and his general demeanor. He clearly enjoys what he is doing. The trip is great for the entire family.

Nature Wonder Fun for Fit Vistors. Rio Secreto is a unique experience for visitors to see stalactite and stalagmite limestone formations in watery caves underground. The formations are spectacular to see and experience this way.We were a party of eight (4 adults/4 children). We negotiated $10 per adult to pay $90 each and $5 off per child to pay $45 each. In total it was about four and a half hours from when we left the hotel to when we returned (the excursion was 20 minutes away). Once there, it was a very slow and bumpy 7km ride (which seemed like double) to the eco site. It's a little rough. If I knew about this in advance, I made not have gone! The gear is included entirely - wetsuit, life jacket, water shoes and helmet with light as well as lockers. It's a short walk to the caves and we were inside for about two hours. Our guide was Cesar and he did a great job helping us and explaining the formations. They take safety seriously, which is good and necessary! We didn't take walking sticks, which probably would have helped. We all got a few minor scrapes -the floor is bump and walking isn't stable. We're all in decent shape, but if you're not or you don't like confined space, this wouldn't be a good choice. We did swim through a few parts, but it's mainly walking and wading. By the end the kids were shivering because the water is cool - a nice contrast from outside heat. A photographer is there to tag along and take photos. I actually would have preferred not to have this - it was a little disruptive, the photos were okay but not fantastic and they were more than I thought reasonable. None of us bought photos. The food provided at the end was fabulous. It made the price of the tour worthwhile. If eco tours and natural wonders interest you and you like exercise, then go for it!

AWESOME. This was an amazing place to visit. We went on a cruise and did the excursion. The had everything planned out for us. We got of the ship and cruised to Playa del Carmen, where they had air conditioned buses and it was maybe a 20 min drive to the place. We got dressed in our shoes, life suit/jackets and helmets. All of our stuff went into a nice locker. We had a 5 min walk to the cavern. Inside is really breath taking. Our experience was really fun and our guide was really cool to and loves what he does,his name is Alfredo, so if you have a choice try to get him. After you leave the cave(1:30-2hrs) you get to look at your pictures. The pictures are a little bit pricey so we only got one but they are very nice. Then you get a Mexican meal and it is good and my favorite was there soup.

What a great place! Super no lo ddjen de visitar!. Wao! Que belleza de cueva que atencion! Request that you guide is hector if posible he takes sn smazing care of the group. This place is natural nothing like xcatet or the orher parks ! This place is a must go location! Very well organize and safe congratulations!

Amazing attraction. This has to have been the best excursion we have taken. There was only 6 people in our group with Raul our guide. They provide everything we needed from wetsuits to helmets with lights on them. We walked in through the caves in water ankle deep to over 14 feet deep! The water was so clear. When we were far in the caves we turned all our lights off and you could not see anything at all!! Total darkness. When we came out and changed we had a nice lunch which was included in the tour.It was the best. I would go back again in a heartbeat!

Best experiance ever!. I recently went to rio secreto with 3 family members through the carnival cruiselines. When we arrived we were givena locker to put it belongings in and afterwards were suited up in body suits, water shoes,life jacket, and helmet. Our guide was a very friendly , helpful man named Raul. He lead us throughout the cave and informed us about the history of the cave. He was very funny and had great knowledge about the caves. We hiked and swam throughout the beautiful cave and saw bats! It was the most unforgettable experiance and would absolutely go back! Thank you RRRraul!

Amazing!. This was the best tour that we have had in many trips to Cancun.You must do this. The caves are amazing!! AMAZING!!Rodrigo was our guide(31-july-13).He explain very well and in an easy language. That day it was rainning(do not exclude it because of the rain) and was perfect, because we were inside the caves so the rain does not gonna ruin anything. Rodrigo took us to a high level of experience! He was great...and yes, he talk us about his personal life and make it more comforting and interesting tour to know and share some dacts about the guide. I will not complain about the prices of the fotos because we have to understand they have many cost, wedge, maintainence fee, operational costs. This place is beautifull, please dont be cheap. If you think is expensive make the arrangements and stop buying clothes and jewelry to enjoy this beautifull place. They did not ask for tips at any time in the tour so that has a lot to say. In a the places. Tip them! Thats their passion and jobs and I really enjoy it! We definetly will do this again on our next trip to Cancun! Gracias amigo!Rafa y Maria

An Amazing tour. On our vacation to Mexico, this is one of the tours that we did, and it was the best tour also that we had during the whole time we were in Mexico.This place is stunning, amazing beautiful and breathtaking all at the same time.Our guide inside the cave was Epco (If I wrote it good :) ) and he did so great, about the knowledge he had and we had lots of fun with him, and he took really good care of us and of the cave itself, respecting the system and let us respect mother earth more. Thank you a lot for that :)))The food was also good, my day was so good and I will defenitly never forget this. I will come back next year, to do the other caves.Highly recommended!!!! If you are in Mexico, you need to see this!!!They say: life changing experience, it is defenitly like that

Best Excursion Ever!. I recently took a Carnival cruise to Cozumel and my husband and I chose the Secret River as our excursion. We are so glad we did! It started with a ferry to the mainland and a bus ride (long and bumpy, but worth it) to the site. We were expertly fitted with wetsuits, water shoes, and hard hats. After a special native ceremony, we entered the cave. It truly was amazing. Hector, our guide, was great! He took our group of 10 through some of the coolest places I've seen, and shared a great deal about the history, formations, and wildlife of the caves. Hector made us feel at ease and helped us to enjoy the beauty and wonder of what we were seeing. We were all so happy to have him! My favorite part was actually swimming through the river with the formations all around you. So gorgeous. At the end we had a buffet lunch (which was much nicer than we expected since we were told it was just a snack), and purchased a CD of the pics they took (it cost $69! The only part of the trip that I thought was ridiculous, but we bought it because they were good pics and we wanted to remember the trip). Overall, it was wonderful and I would recommend this trip to anyone who won't be afraid of the water or caves.

Exploration with Quality and Responsibility. Diving in a cave situated 21 meters from the surface is not an adventure, it is a commitment to life.Rio Secreto maintains this commitment to respect nature and to visitors.It was a exciting experience, unforgettable.We spent almost two hours under the supervision of our guide. learning and enjoying.I recommend this tour to anyone who wants to have a "life-changing experience."Within the tour is included wetsuit, towels, locker room and a good breakfast.This is not an amusement park. I liked that.

Best Excursion Yet. We just returned from our carnival cruise yesterday. Cozumel was our first stop and we were blown away by the Rio Secreto. Hector was our tour guide and was an amazing wealth of knowledge. We have a large family (8 of us) and he made sure we all stuck together and got a chance to ask questions and learn about the caves. The actual location and equipment are equally as nice. Highly reccomend to anyone looking for an adventure. We will be back to do more spelunking with Hector!

Beautiful place. Highly recommending seeing this place. There are some downfalls though....you can't take cameras inside...even waterproof. They take pics the whole time and then want to sell you the pics for over 100.00 USD at the end. You can buy just one for 25.00 if you like. The buffet lunch served was not very good. Being in the caves is worth both of those things though. I do recommend you shop around to get the best possible price. Some people paid very little for the exact tour and others paid much more.

THIRD VISIT... IN LOVE AGAIN!. I went for my third visit last week as my boyfriend has had never visited. Once again the experience was UNFORGETTABLE.. this place is sooo magical, sooo special and soooo unique. One thing that caught my attention this time and I didnt remember is that it takes 100 years for a stalacmite to grow 1 cm... and this place has 2 meter stalacmites or bigger. You just forget about stress or everything else as you are sooo concentrated in seeing the beauty around you. I feel extremely lucky to be able to live in a place with such wonders. FACT... From all the hundreds of tours in Riviera Maya, Rio Secreto is #1 MUST in your list.... every cent is completely worth it. ENJOY!

Unforgettable experience.. This place is breath taking. Most of my favorite pictures from my trip were taken at the Rio cenotes. The magnificent clear water in the cenotes is a cool 73 degrees, invitingly refreshing treat from the hot Mexican sun.My guide was Lia who was very professional and informative. She was friendly to all and made sure everyone was safe and comfortable. She explained how the senotes were formed, its anthropological significance and insights into Mayan culture and of course exposed us to the exquisite natural beauty of the cenote itself, and she did all this in three languages.The stalactites and stalagmites were impressive and the dark caverns you explore are mysteriously breathtaking. We saw a rich variety of flora and fauna of freshwater endangered Yucatan blind fish, shrimps and saltwater fish. The experience was amazingly different and something I will always remember.

Secret River / Rio Secreto, Outstanding value for money.. I cannot enthuse enough about this experience.We were on a Disney Cruise at the time and had to position by fast ferry to the mainland first; we were then subjected to a standing in the heat period of disorganisation whilst other members of the party decided to arrive and make themselves known.A short trip by van, with a/c, ended in about 5km of dirt track bumping around to the facility in the 'bush'.Our Guide was 'Leon' and from the moment he took over the experience really started; patiently we were kitted out in wet-shoes, wetsuits, bouyancy aids, helmets and head torches. All in decent condition and of good quality.your personal items are stored in lockers for the purpose and you take nothing with you at all.Brief walk along a trail, a blessing by a Mayan holy man and you're at the cave entrance.There is a reassuring chat again about what we are to see, expect and the rules about what to touch and where not to go.The journey is about 90 minutes and for me I could have gone on for hours more. It was an unbelievable privilege to to visit the river, caverns and see the wildlife living in this environment of total darkness.Leon was patient and took time to answer all our questions, gave us time to keep together and allowed us to stay longer in some of the most beautiful places I have ever visited.Alongside is a company photographer setting us up for some posed pictures, no obligation to purchase.I had with me my six year old daughter and I was very comfortable with how it was ran and she will remember this for the rest of her life.At the end you emerge up a staircase right by those lockers storing your personal items!The meal after is basic but of high quality; the photos are for sale, expensive as single prints but for the cost of three you can actually get an excellent CD of all your family pictures only plus some extra library photos of the flooded caverns and the wildlife you may have been lucky to see.If you do this trip and don't enjoy it, contact me and I'LL give you your money back!

Uniquely Different, Truly Amazing!. I’ll begin by saying that on the 8 cruises I’ve done this by far was, if not the best shore excursion I’ve ever done. It is totally unique and different than other excursions offered for most Caribbean cruises and very cultural for the region.Getting there- The area of the Cave Hike is about 20 mins from the Cruise ship ferry pier in Playa Del Carmen. We were meet there, filled out some paperwork and off we went. Some on Trip Advisor complain about the road you go down to get to the area of the hike. Its not that bad folks, it’s bumpy, its off road and we all had a blast driving down it.The facility- The facility is rather pretty with a nice jungle escape feel to it. They provide you with all the equipment you need, wetsuits, water shoes, life jackets, and then towels for when you’re done with the hike. They also had a wonderful included hot lunch for the groups prior to leaving. The food was very good in fact. We didn’t expect that to be included and were rather glad it was.The Hike- We did the two hour hike, they do offer a 5 hour but being we were on a cruise you have to be back on the ship at a certain time. It’s very hard to put into words the beauty of the cave and hiking through the river. It’s simply amazing and a pure sensory experience. The hike itself isn’t simple yet it’s not overly difficult either. If you’ve hiked before, can swim, and are in decent shape you’ll do fine and enjoy this. You are guided through the caves and our guide (Eduardo) was fantastic! The rock formations above, below, and all around you are amazing. You just can’t wrap your head around how nature formed these.Pictures- So let me address the no camera policy. Very simply folks it would be impossible without professional water proof gear for you to take pictures. The Caves are pitch black and the only light is from your helmet light. Plus you are hiking in neck deep water at times. They take pictures of you and the pictures are rather good. They have several options for you to purchase the pictures that include other professional pictures of the caves a book or shirt and hat. I found it highly worthwhile and I’m glad I bought the pictures. Prices range from $25 to a bit over $100. I did the $90 package which included pictures, a shirt and hat. Overall- If you are tired of the typical excursion on a cruise then do this, it’s amazingly different and something you’ll always remember. This is a 5 star rating all the way!

Unexpected Authenticity. This was a totally unexpected and wonderfully authentic experience. I had cynically assumed that all tourist activities in this part of Mexico were both overpriced and touristy, leading to underwhelming experiences. You join the group, and take a very bumpy, 20 minute ride out to a remote area. There are a few buildings, lots of trees, and some very rickety facilities. Everyone showers off the sun screen and other chemicals (we didn't put any on that day), then don a wetsuit and lifejacket. Next, you take a short hike through the jungle and start your descent into the cave system. You will need to be physically fit enough to do some climbing, swimming, treading water, staying balanced, and sustaining these activities over an hour.This is experience can not be recreated, and I almost wish it wasn't destined to become so popular. It was absolutely gorgeous, exciting, and had me wanting to go right back underground when we were finished all too soon.Afterwards, we had a nice, Mayan lunch with fiery salsa (and we're from Texas - not wimps!) We bought a photo, and considered the inflated price a donation to help conserve the caves.

Rio secreto the under ground river. We have a wonderful time visiting the under ground caves, its an experience of what mother's natures it's capable of creating. The guides are very protective of the well being of the group.I recomend a visit if You are in the area!!!!!Lwe love from the guide to the food, an amazing experience.

Rio Secretto Caves and a bit about Tulum. Done a day trip combined with Tulum and finished with the afternoon at Rio Secretto Caves. I am a lifelong adventurer and have caved on many occasions in a variety of locations, so I said I would give Rio Secretto caves a go, under the belief that they were going to be somewhat false, commercialised, altered for the tourist etc, but I must say I was wrong.On arrival I got the sense of here we go again another commercialised Mexican tourist rip-off but quite shortly I realised once check-in was done that the place was not what I thought it would be.We were told in advance our guides name (Alfredo) and we were grouped with a family from Texas and two German lads and it was a perfect group size, from a safety ratio and from the point of view that we got real good personal attention from our assigned guide.Anyway after a short wait a bus arrived and we all boarded for a bumpy 5-6 km trip to the cave site through the jungle. On arrival we were promptly kitted out in wetsuits, helmets with lamps, shoes and buoyancy aids and the facilities were quite good and to a high standard.From the onset I got a great sense of passion from our guide Alfredo and it became apparent quite quickly that this guy was an honest, passionate, caring individual and was actually quite knowledgeable about his pursuit which I was extremely happy about and this for me made quite a difference to the whole caving experience.We entered the cave and I was absolutely delighted that no alterations, damage or any stupid tourist gimmicks were carried out and the cave was in excellent condition throughout. Our guide Alfredo was at pains to ensure that we caused no damage and he watched out for everyone with diligence.The cave is a high percentage water covered from ankle to knee to waist to chest deep water in places and extremely safe at all times. there was one or two water course sections that were about 15ft deep and no problem at all, your buoyancy aid does all the hard work for you and you just gently propel yourself along, of course there are several dry sections and I felt the balance between the wet and dry sections was just right.We exited the cave after about 21/2 hours and we went back to a jungle camp area where a buffet and drinks were included in the price. During the cave trip a staff photographer accompanied us and photographed us on the journey. But if you are keen to do your own photography ONLY bring a waterproof camera with you as you will be neck deep in water, so any other camera is at risk of water damage.This was a worth while trip and lacked the usual Mexican hassle and bother that accompanies other trips and for the first time ever in Mexico, yes for the first time ever, not one member of the Rio Secretto staff looked for a tip, or hinted or suggested a tip, this really impressed me and so much so the guide got a good tip.Now for the down side, firstly, the cost is unusually high $99USD, but I got Tulum included for $1USD extra on the same trip so that was not too bad.The photography that was done by the resident photographer was quite overpriced and on viewing the copy's I felt that they were not of a great standard, I mean the scenery was lovely in the photo's within the cave but the photographer lacked any imagination where we were concerned and I saw nothing special at all and for the price...no thanks.The jungle area of the food buffet was really nice but the food was only at average and nothing special here at all, drinks were also available free, but you could purchase a beer or a coke or other branded sodas for a very reasonable cost at the camp area.Overall a lovely experience and if you are not looking for the typical touristy, gimmicky, plastic Mexican experiences then Rio Secretto is worth the visit, and if you are coming all the way down from Cancun then visit Tulum as well, and if you want a nicer archaeological experience then skip Chichen Itza if you are planning it, do Tulum instead as you will be scourged by parasitic annoying vendors inside the archaeological site at Chichen Itza selling absolute rubbish from China masquerading as "genuine" Mayan art and ruining your guides explanation of the site with silly wooden toys making fake jaguar noises. Not the case at Tulum, vendors are kept away from the site and that's really a big plus for Tulum.

Amazing experiece!. This was a surprise excursion that my friend had organised on our cruise on the Disney Fantasy ship. He was so excited about going but wouldn't tell me until we got there, and everyone he spoke to was so excited for us as word gets around that this is a great excursion to go on.And they're not wrong.What an absolutely fantastic day. As part of the excursion through Disney Fantasy, you're taken to Playa Del Carmen by boat from Cozumel and escorted to the site by road. You're given lockers to put your stuff in (free of charge), and then provided all your gear - wet suit, wet shoes, life vest and helmet. You're separated into small groups which enter different parts of the caves and you're accompanied by a guide and a photographer (who will take anyone back to base camp should the need/desire arise).The caves are pitch black and the only illumination comes from the lights in your helmet, making this such an atmospheric experience. Our guide, Rene, was fantastic, and would stop occasionally to give details about the caves and the fauna that live there. At certain spots throughout the cave, you'll stop to have professional pictures taken with whomever you came on the trip with. It wasn't until I saw these pictures that I could fully appreciate the beauty of these caves thanks to flash photography. The results were stunning and the pictures turned out fantastic.At the end of the walk/wade/swim through the caves, you give your gear back and you're given a complimentary shot of liqueur (or soft alternative..) and the chance to buy your photos (the whole package is worth it in my opinion as the photos are stunning). Then lunch is provided! It was a 'simple' lunch, but very tasty, and a nice touch to end the trip. Once we'd finished lunch, we had a chance to lounge around in the hammocks while waiting for our transport to arrive to take us back to the port, where we had spare time to wonder round the shops and beach before being escorted back onto the boat to get back to the ship in Cozumel.All in all, an absolutely fantastic trip that is great for everyone - couples, families, friends, solo etc. Nothing to be scared about going in the caves. On my particular the visit, the water levels were quite low as it hadn't rained in a while so most of it was walking or wading through water with only a couple of times where we had to 'swim' (inverted commas as you have a life vest so very little effort needed to move yourself along!). There's no tight gaps or anything like that you have to work your way through.100% recommend.
It was scary but awesome.. My wife and I had an awesome time. I don't know how to swim so it was scary but I made it out of there. It is beautiful in the cave.

Beautiful Rio Secreto!. This adventure is unforgettable! We all 5 (3 kids) enjoyed walking into the cave. The guide and photographer lead you into the underground caves and teach us while introducing you into a place that is so magical! We will not forget when Flora (the guide) asked us to turn off our light and when she turned off her light....Wow, it was so dark! We also After the visit, a local food buffet was served and it was very good. Back to Canada, we bought on the internet, pictures taken during the visit. Fotografia people are exceptionnel to direct you to access your photos. The pictures are beautiful! We will keep good memories on photo and in our hearts! Rio Secreto should definitely be a part of any Playa del Carmen trip.

Wonderful Experience. My wife and I had a great experience at Rio Secreto. I'm not much of a water person and was apprehensive about the tour. No reason to be. It was wonderful. Beautiful and educational as well. The guide was very professional and friendly and made sure everyone was safe. Lockers as well as lunch are provided. Worth every penny spent!

In a word? TRANSFORMATIVE! Do not miss!. Great excursion! You will not come out of it the same as you went into it; definitely worth doing!Rio Secreto is a network of caves connected by an underground river on a Mayan nature preserve. The site is absolutely amazing!Visited with my cousin as part of a cruise trip we took. Refreshingly, the tour included a marked respect for the land & local culture, replete with a brief silent nature walk and a pleasant smudged meditation prior to entering the caves. This is not just some big commercial enterprise looking to cash in on natural beauty, but a locally owned & operated window into a truly magical place.We found the gear was clean, modern & well kept, with more than adequate selection for various sized people, and the staff were attentive and helpful, esp. our guide Victor who engendered a real sense of camaraderie and team-spriit in our otherwise motley group. By the end, we were all friends, helping each other and joking around.On top of all of this, was a tasting of local Mayan anise rum (very tasty) and a tranditional Mayan meal! Offering up buffet-style, we enjoyed various rice, meat, fish and vegetable entrées…. it was SOOO DELICIOUS. Esp. the sauces; if you go, don't forget to try the hot one! :)Only minor gripe is the add-on photo package seemed a little over-priced at first, but in fairness, there was a professional photographer on the tour with us, and he did a great job of capturing not only the nascent group as we navigated the unfamiliar caves, but the natural beauty of the site as well. We opted for the photo package that included up to 3 souvenirs (choosing 3 bottles of the tasty rum!), so was definitely worth picking up the extra mementos. Looking forward to returning for the longer 4hr excursion!Definitely recommend this tour if you're in the Playa del Carmen area!

Underground Beauty. On a rainy day in Cancun, we took a trip to see the Secret River. This river was found in 2006 when a man chased an iguana down a sink hole. The beautiful rock formations inside this cave were formed over millions of years from water dripping down through the limestone above. The cave kept us dry from the rain, although wet suits were provided for us as we sometimes swam through the river. This is a must-see experience. It is beauty that only nature can provide.

Not to Miss. We loved our guide, the uniqueness of the excursion, and the lunch afterward. It really is a once in a lifetime experience. One in our group had a disability and they took extra care to be sure his experience was great. There is a fair amount of unsure footing in the cave and a short time in the water where you can't touch the bottom, but the life vests keep you floating just fine.

A real underground wonder. People are nice, the place is amazing and the experience unforgettable. The guide and photographer lead you into the underground caves and teach as much as they can while introducing you into a place that's simply great. After the trip, you get to eat delicious local food and get a taste of Xtabentun. Highly recommended.

Cozumel Cruise Excursion. We had a group of six (along with a family of four) tour the cave with our guide, "Gonzo" and one of Rio Secreto's photographers. The experience was unlike anything I think you could experience in the United States, although whether the accessibility of the cave to tourists will ultimately be a detriment to its preservation is a little suspect. The tours require moderate effort, including mild hiking and swimming. There are nooks and corners that require some flexibility.No photography is allowed within the cave, although something like a GoPro would be manageable; the restriction seems to stem more from their selling photographs as souvenirs than anything else.A hearty, buffet-style lunch was provided as a part of the cruise excursion (it wasn't clear whether this is included in all tours), as were shots of a honey-based liquor they also sell as souvenirs. Beverages, including soda and beer, were extra.It was an outstanding experience, and the guide was clearly passionate about the cave system.

Highlight of our trip. We were in a small group, our family of four and a young couple from Lima, Peru, so the scale was very personal and engaging. Our guide Alfredo was very knowledgeable, attentive, and gifted at sharing his passion of the cave and its ecosystem with the group. The passion and respect for the sensitive ecosystem of the cave made an impression on our boys who were later upset to see billboards advertising ATV rides through cave that other companies were promoting. The coolness of the cave and the 72 degree water was refreshing. We didn't opt for wetsuits but in retrospect might have for our youngest because being shorter than everyone else he was swimming up to his neck in many parts where the rest of us were walking so by the end he was shivering although it didn't lessen his enthusiasm for the experience.

Cruise Excursion. This was such an amazing experience! It is an absolutely beautiful cave! We went as an excursion on a carnival cruise and had a great time. The employees were great, especially our cave guide Alfredo. He was truly passionate about his job and preserving the cave. He was very informative and helpful while going through the cave. The facilities were very nice and I loved the lunch after our tour. I have been in caves many times and this was not just a cave tour, it was truly an experience!

Interesting half-day trip, underground river in cave. Hiking and floating for approximately and hour and a half through a cave with an underground river. Beautiful stalagmite and stalactite growths during the hike - along with views of a few bats as we disturbed their sleep a bit. Our guide, Raoul, was very informative and entertaining at the same time. Small groups (no more than ten) allowed for more conversation and discussion. It is a moderate difficulty hike, with the largest challenge begin the uneven footing and hidden rocks under the surface. However, when we were there, a number of groups had kids from ~10 years one and they did not seem to have any problems. Very nice break / change of pace from the heat of the beach. Suggest looking online with excursion agents / brokers to book, which will save money compared to booking at the hotels - door-to-door pick-up and drop-off is standard. Do bring mosquito spray for the short hike through the jungle to get to the cave entrance. Adequate lunch was provided after the hike. Unfortunately, the pricing for the pictures (photographer joined on the hike) was much too high; we ended up splitting a package with another couple. The pricing on pictures is the real weak point of this excursion, as you would like to commemorate the trip, but the prices are extortion-level.Enjoy

Well worth it. Rio Secreto should definitely be a part of any Playa del Carmen trip. It is well organized, taking small groups (no more than ten people) into a partially flooded cave. The trip consists of both walking and swimming, with a guide that explains the cave's ecology.The service and the attention are excellent. We arrived a little bit before our reservation time and were quickly send on their bus to cave, 20 minutes on an unpaved road. After that, we were given our equipment (wet suit, helmet with light, life jacket, and water shoes). Our group of ten was accompanied by a guide, Victor, and a photographer, Miguel. The tour is quite interesting and unlike anything that I have done before. The water is cool but pleasant after the heat of outdoors. Most of the water is waist deep for an adult. At times, you do have to swim; the life jacket is high quality and this was not a problem. After the cave, they show you the photos and then give you a light lunch. Then back to the highway again on the bus.The service was good and the tour was well organized. The equipment was first rate. We left a backpack in the truck and when we called them a few hours later, the driver (Zeus) found it. Rio Secreto sent it back to the hotel a few hours later! You don't get this service everywhere!The photos are a bit expensive (US$69) for a CD with a lot of photos, but this is par for the course and the photos are not copied protected. They could probably improve their service by putting the photos online instead of using a CD. Don't take this trip if you have a mobility problem, as there is a lot of walking and crouching. The kids in our group generally liked the tour but at time complained about the cold water and the walking. Highly recommended

Fun cruise excursion. My wife and I went here as an excursion from a Carnival cruise. It was a lot of fun! We've certainly never done anything like it. The cave and river are a natural treasure and a sight to behold. You definitely need to be comfortable doing some light swimming. Our guide, Lia, was very friendly and did a good job. I agree with the other commenter that the wetsuits are a little smelly and the helmets in particular, but it doesn't detract too much from the experience. $25 for one picture is ridiculous, though. The tour includes a small buffet which was pretty good, certainly enough to tide us over.Highly recommend.

Amazing Cool Adventure on Hot Day. After a snorkel trip was cancelled, a hotel travel agent suggested Rio Secreto. We were not disappointed! The cave and river were breathtaking! Our guide, Alfredo, and his trainee were amazing and so passionate about their job. It was great after many days in the sun to be in the cool water. We were pleasantly surprised when at the end we were treated to a wonderful Mayan buffet complete with xtabantun--a delicious Mayan liquor. Throughout the tour, a photographer took pictures which were able to purchase before our meal along with a hat, bag, shirt, and of course xtabantun! We will absolutely return as soon as possible!

Very interesting experience. We did this tour today, with 4 adults and 4 kids, ages 5-10. My very anxious 8 y/o started to get worried at the very beginning that it pull be dark and scary but he quickly got into the experience. My 5 y/o needed quite a bit of help with the swimming parts but it was not too hard for her to manage. I was nervous about feeling claustrophobic, but felt very comfortable. The water temperature was comfortable with the wetsuit. Our guide was good and concerned for our safety, I wouldn't say he told us tons of stuff, but it was informative. Not a great choice for someone with unsteady walking, mobility issues etc, just be aware of that, however, it's not so hard that a 5 year old can't handle it.The food was decent and fresh, nothing gourmet, but it satisfied our hungry kids.We took a taxi from our hotel in PDC, it was about 15 min and cost 300 pesos r/tMy main complaint is I found the wetsuits and helmets to be kind of stinky, and the pictures were expensive. On theo ther hand it would have been awkward to do the tour carrying a camera.

Stunning. Booked a tour with our cruise line and it was the highlight of our entire cruise trip. We've been to Cozumel many times and we were looking for a unique experience. We found it at Rio Secreto. Our guide, Benito, was great. He did a great job with the young kids in our group and keeping everyone together. He did a great job in letting us know where to step, sharp rocks, how to maneuver some of the trickier areas but I could not have done it without a walking stick. The stick saved me quite a few times. Don't know how some folks in our group did it without the walking stick. The cave was truly stunning and the experience of sitting in total darknesss for a moment was priceless. We were in the cave for about 1 1/2 hours and the time went by very quickly. No cameras are allowed and they do have a photographer following you around but the photos are quite expensive at $25.00 for a single photo. Nevertheless, we bought one we just felt we needed a photo to capture this unique experience.

Amazing Attraction made even better by the tour guide and service. My husband, brother and sister-in-law did visited Rio Secreto as an excursion we booked from our cruise on Carnival. Thought it was a long trip from our port in Cozumel, it was totally worth it. The river and cave system was absolutely amazing and like nothing I've ever seen. As our guide, Alfredo, said there really are no words to describe the experience and he's right.Alfredo was an excellent guide who thoroughly enjoyed his job, you could tell this was truly his passion. He was very knowledgeable and helpful. I really felt like I was his guest at his home as he guided us through the caves, not some random foreigner he hoped to make money off of.The lunch provided at the end of the tour was more than adequate and quite good. The entire operation, from start to finish, was smooth and professional. I highly recommend this tour.

WOW! amazing. Just a really great experience!!! Love the scenery, the caves, WOW! Amazing!!!People who attend us were really nice & kind and knows a lot about the place.Rodrigo our tour guy, is an expert on the matter so I felt absolutely secure all along the experience.Thanks a lot for this wonderful time!!!I want to go back 1000 times!!!

Awesome half-day trip!. We went on this with our 5 and 10 year old children and it was fantastic. My daughter was dying to do a swim with the dolphins with her cousin but I don't feel those are humane to the animals. Last minute the other family switched their plan and I had to make good on my promise that we'd do something else cool at the same time. I was able to make same day reservations and we all thought it was amazing. Even the ride from the staging area by the highway to the cenotes was neat, as there was an incredible number of butterflies to watch. The caves are beautiful and fascinating. Our guide Benito had a remarkable depth of knowledge. He was also good with our 5-year-old, who he kept next to him the whole time. Sometimes it's hard to know how much is talk and how much is real, but they seem genuinely committed to preserving and respecting this resource. The Maya blessing beforehand actually seemed respectful of the culture rather than cheesy. Minor details: you're going back and forth between walking and floating frequently, so each time you get back in you get cool water in your wetsuit. The kids got chilly towards the end, but it's the perfect activity to do in the heat of midday. Skip the transport if you have multiple people -- we paid $30 round trip for taxis from central Playa del Carmen and would have paid $90 (and spent more time in transit) for their van. And as everyone else mentions, the photos are a rip. All in all though it's beautiful, shows you something you won't see anywhere else in the world, and does it in a way that tries to be sustainable and responsible. That's a rare combination in these parts!

Really great tour! Highly recommend.. I went with my boyfriend and his sister on this and we all loved it. Our tour guide, Lia (Argelia), was really awesome and did a great job talking about the cave and keeping the group together. She did an excellent job explaining how the cave was formed, about stalactites/stalagmites/columns, small animals in the cave (shrimp and small fish in the water and bats), and she was great about letting us know where to avoid sharp rocks and where to step to keep our footing). She also spoke French in addition to her English and Spanish which I thought was really cool. We were probably down there over an hour, but I didn't have my watch on. Everything was provided (shoes, wetsuit, life vest, and helmet with light). The inside was BEAUTIFUL. It was absolutely worth it to see the cave. I have gone into caves before and this was by far my favorite. Lockers were provided with keys (you can wear the key around your neck). A professional photographer followed us around but we didn't end up buying the pictures because they were super expensive. ($25 for a SINGLE photo and $70 for a package of 8 or something). The food at the end was good but VERY spicy. I'm used to pretty spicy food but have never tried anything with a habañero pepper in it and I was caught by surprise by it. However, I liked the food buffet.

Stunning, fantastic. An absolutely amazing experience underground with my family. The kids were apprehensive about going underground in the dark for all of two minutes, right up until our guide, Enrique, started talking...he was simply phenomenal. From that moment on, we were all entranced with his stories of the cave, the history, the animals, the formations, and what they knew and still didn't know about the site. An absolute must see. You do have to be fairly limber in a few places, but the overall experience is so worth the few minutes of "eep factor" it simply adds to the experience, not distracts from it.

good tour. The tour was good, the inside of the caves was really amazing to see but the guide didn't have "that" much information and felt a little rushed. The food, it was horrible. I was sick for the rest of the day after eating it. Really bad quality they should probably not serve food as a part of this tour but other than that it was really awesome inside the caves!

Great excursion. We chose this excursion when we were on a Disney cruise. The area and the cave were quite breathtaking. You do have to have pretty good balance and mobility or I do not think you would enjoy this. You spend about an hour and half in the cave walking or swimming in crystal clear water. I took my 11 and 13 year old daughters and they really enjoyed it. We worked up quite an appetite and we enjoyed an authentic Mexican food buffet afterwards. We loved our tour guide who was both helpful and knowledgeable in the cave. We hope you get a chance to experience Rio Secreto. You will not be disappointed.

absolutely stunning. I recently ventured out to the Secret River on our cruise and I am very happy we booked this tour. It was phenomenal! The caves are wonderful. Inclusive of the price is wetsuits, water shoes if you need them(we brought our own:), helmet with light and life vest. Everyone gets a locker for your personal items as well.The only major drawback is you are not allowed to bring your own camera witch really disappointed me. I have done a lot of caves tours and all have allowed me to bring my own camera and I ended up with great shots. They do have a photographer that follows you in and you are offered a package on CD but it was a bit steep for what you get.Before you enter the cave, there is a ceremony with local mayans who bless you before your journey. This was very cool. The water is about 75 degrees(very nice if it's a hot day). You spend about an hour and a half with your guide. Some areas are a bit difficult to walk on as the ground is uneven and under water. I am not a great swimmer, but this is not a problem as your life vest keeps you afloat.If you are claustrophobic, it may seem a bit nerve wracking but it is not bad at all. At the end of your journey, they offer a mexican lunch of tacos, rice, beans, fruit, etc. Definitely worth the visit:)

The most AMAZING adventure. It changed our lives !. My friend,3 Teenage girls and I booked this tour sight unseen and by word of mouth from another friend on June 22,2013. We had no idea what to expect. WOW!!!! We had the FABULOUS Alfredo for our tour guide .He knew so much and he truly lives the spirit of El Rio Secreto . I told him that usually I feel fear from doing something unknown like this but felt so peaceful . Maybe it was the blessing from the Mayan elderat made us feel safe ? Who knows but it was a life definitely a life changing experience that Alfredo promised ! A must do !!!!!!

Beautiful experience. We visited Rio Secreto in June for a 1.5-2hr underground walk through a cenote (an opening to a set of caves with a river). It was very professional, safe and enjoyable. I would definitely recommend it.

Worth the money spent. Visited Rio Secreto on 6/20/2013. Our guide Hector was very knowledgeable, funny and very entertaining. If there's one activity I would recommend for families both young and old, it would be Rio Secreto. The lunch that they serve was authentic mexican food and alot better then the resort where we were staying.

Truly magical place but..... I highly recommend a visit here because it's like seeing the full scope of a cenote without scuba diving. The tour guide had tons of interesting information to share. The disappointment is that you can't take a camera (which I understand) and they charge an arm and a leg for the photo packages at the end of the tour. The meal that was provided was fresh and well made but limited. The process from beginning to end is well thought out and the groups are nice and small. So if you're satisfied with being unable to come away with any pics then go and have a WONDERFUL time. For me it was well worth it - an experience I will always remember.

Rio Secreto tour on JUNE 17th 2013. Me my Husband and 2 Daughters, age 11 and 18 visited Rio Secreto on Monday JUNE 17th 2013 and it just happened to be a rainy day(which was PERFECT) because we were under ground. This place was MAGICALLY BREATH TAKING, something you would ONLY expect to see on a NATURE channel in the comfort of your own HOME. To see and experience this place up close and personal was AMAZING. The water was crystal clear and WARM.... Our Tour Guide was amazing and very engaging and knowledgeable. Our group consisted of 8-people + 1 Camera Man. I would definitely recommend this tour for ALL(even the NON swimmers). All you have to do is show up with your swim suit, they provide the wet suit, Life Vest, protection helmet with Light, swim shoes & a secure locker for your personal belongings. We purchased the packed that included the CD ONLY that included(50+ pictures of my family along with the other Tourist as well). Unfortunately they will NOT allow you bring your own camera to take your own snap shots. The only thing I would suggest for "RIO SECRETO" is to invest in better camera's with more clarity(Especially considering this underground cave is COMPLETE DARKNESS without any light) The pictures were very AVERAGE and considering this is a once in a life time experience and the amount they charge $65+(with NO print outs, only a CD) the quality should be TOP NOTCH...... Other than that this place is SOOOOOOO worth seeing. ((You will feel like you're part of History when you leave this place))!!!! Sincerely, LaShonda W. & Family

Educational, spiritual, amazing!. We chose this excursion because it is unique to the Riviera Maya. As a scienc-y person, learning about the cenote and swimming through it sounded intriguing.I really liked that the tour sizes were very small. I think we had 8 people in our tour and that was one of the larger groups!Our guide was phenomenal. He was extremely knowledgeable and made the entire experience great. I have since forgotten his name.You start by getting changed into the appropriate gear - be warned the shower is COLD!Before entering the cenote, there is a traditional Mayan Blessing, which I found very interesting. You then enter the cenote, which is honestly spiritual and majestical. It is amazing to think that you are wading through a cave that has only recently been discovered, but has existed for thousands of years. Our tour guide taught us about the type of creatures found in the cave, how the geological formations came to be, and educated us about the importance of keeping the cenote a natural reserve.My favourite part of the tour came just before we turned around to exit the cenote. We turned off all of our head lamps and the guide turned off the flash light. We were in complete darkness - something that I have NEVER experienced before, and likely never will again. It was amazing.After the tour we had a shot of a special honey liquor, and had lunch. Lunch was traditional Mayan fare. It was nice.The only downside was the photos. The cost for the photos seemed outrageous to me. My fiance and I agreed that we had the memories to last a lifetime and did not need the pictures to aid in those memories. The only downside**TIP #1** TAKE THE WALKING STICK! One of the men in our tour group said he read on trip advisor to take the stick. TAKE IT. My fiance and I are 26 and 27 and thought we wouldn't need them. I am so glad I had one, as the ground is very uneven and there could have been many times I could have fallen.**TIP#2** do not take any jewelry with you into the cenote. The water is COLD. Fingers shrink, rings fall off. If that ring or other piece of jewelry falls off you will never find it - it is very dark.

Beautiful and Enchanting. Rio Secreto or secret river is a must do. You spend 90 minutes in one of the most beautiful places we've ever been. Walking on the rock or in the warm water and sometimes swimming all in an enchanting cave filled with stalagmites and stalactites. This is one of our best travel experiences. Great multilingual guides. We will do this again!

Don't miss this!. Amazing walk, swim, float down a river thru the caves. Not to be missed. This is more like a national geographic adventure then a tourist trap. Better then an afternoon at the spa. Tour guide well informed and professional.

Educational and Fun. If you want to learn about the system of caves underneath the hotels and jungle, this tour if perfect. Unlike other cave tours, it does not involve zip lines or jeeps. You walk in small groups with our guide through a massive cave. They supply you with all the equipment you need, water shoes, wet suit, life jacket. In some parts of the cave, you will float through the water. For most of the tour you are walking in water in the cave.We had an excellent guide. He was very knowledgeable and accommodating. We learned and had fun. Young kids who aren't afraid of the dark can go.This tour is very well done. It is expensive, but is first class.

WELL worth the price of excursion. My family and I have cruised out of Miami for many years and are very skeptical of excursions and tours. Needless to say we are not easily impressed. This trip to Rio Secreto was AMAZING. It was everything we expected: educational, fun, interesting and great for the parents and kids.Our tour guide was Lea and she was so knowledgeable and extremely sweet. Great with the kids. ONE word of advice - If you're going to go on the water taxi from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen (port of entry for this excursion) PACK YOUR motion sickness pills...a bit wavy and bumpy by nature. No pictures allowed other than what they take of you and sell at a premium [this is a tiny bummer - but business is business I guess].Other than that, the actual tour was amazing.My son commented "Mom on a scale from 1-10 this trip is infinity". I guess that says it all.

A bucket list experience!!!!!!. As part of the recommendations of the Oasis of the Seas Cruise my wife and me visited this place. The experience was unique. Having Alfredo as a tour guide really raise the bar. This amazing guy show an complete knowledge of the place and answer all our questions. The service and the love for the nature of all this staff is remarkable. If you are looking for something special in the nature, don't missed it.

BEWARE - parking lot. I really hate for my first review to be negative one, but I thought I should let my fellow tripadvisors know about our recent experiences at the rio secreto. First, the tour itself is highly enjoyable. Our guide Hector did a great job guiding us through the cave. The food at the end of the tour was also a nice touch. Overall, I echo the sentiments of the other positive reviews here. If I could rate the tour by itself, it would be 5 stars. Now for the not so good. When we arrived back to the parking lot, we opened the trunk of our rental car to find that all of our carry-on luggage was gone. Apparently someone had broken into our trunk while we were on the tour. The parking lot is a 20 minute van ride from the caves and easily accessible from the main road. There are signs disclaiming any liability in the parking lot for items stolen from your car, so perhaps we should have taken additional precautions. But they only have small lockers at the cave site, so it's unclear what you should do if you have larger luggage and don't want to leave them in your car. We told the people working at the ticket booth what had happened, but they were incredibly unhelpful (the person working there even said, "well, anyone can access the parking lot"). We asked them to call the police for us. They made one attempt, nut they told us they were unable to get through to them. In reality, we knew that our luggage was probably gone for good, but it would have been nice if they had tried a little harder to help us. Lesson learned: Don't leave anything of value in the trunk of your car while in Mexico, especially at the Rio Secreto.

Just Amazing - Do It!!!. The journey was kind of tough, but the destination was worth it! This is a once in a lifetime excursion, and we are so happy we did this! We took our kids (ages 6 and 8) here, and they loved it! Our guide was Alfredo - he was fantastic! So knowledgeable and patient with our group, and he had such good information/history about the caves. We spent about 90 minutes in the cave. The excursion information said too that a snack would be provided afterwards, but it was a full lunch prepared on site. So yummy - taquitos, tacos, tamales, rice, beans, tea, water, watermelon... Perfect after the tour! Don't hesitate to go explore here!

A can't miss tour. We took this tour in late May. It was fantastic!!!! We really haven't seen anything like this. I was initially a little worried about the possibility this might be too cold and I wouldn't have a great experience. Before we went into the caves, we had to shower off in water from the river. It was about 70 degrees and my husband and I actually decided not to wear wetsuits. We were fine and found the water in the caves to be very refreshing. Our guide, Alfredo was amazing. He knew so much about the caves and could answer the most simple or complex questions. He has such a passion for Rio Secreto and it showed. Once you arrive at Rio Secreto, you have to take a van about 15 minutes into the forest. You then get to the area where you put on your swimsuit and gear up for the caves. You are given a helmet with a light on it, water shoes, a life jacket and you have the option of wearing a wet suit. You are asked to shower off, to keep contaminants from getting into the water. We then walked about 10 minutes down to the cave openings. Once you walk in, you are in a different world. The water is crystal clear. The stalagtyes and stalagmytes are likes works of art. Our guide led us through caves and into rivers that we floated across. At one point, we all sat down in a shallow spot and turned off our lights. It was so dark, we couldn't see our hands in front of our faces. The water was so clear, when a light was placed in the water, the light traveled forever. Our guide showed us the small fish that live in the river, the plankton the fish feed on, and the small bugs that have adapted to live in total darkness. It was amazing. At some points, you can find roots growing down into the cave from the forest floor above. It was an amazing experience. You can't take cameras into the caves. The guides, however, take pictures of everyone. Given the lighting in the caves, this is actually one time where I really appreciated someone taking pictures for us. They knew exactly where to take pictures so we could see the wonder of the caves. When we bought our photo CD, it also had a bunch of other beautiful cave pictures on it. When you meet the guides, and hear their passion about what they do, you really don't mind spending a little extra there to support their cause. Hats off to this tour - you thoroughly impressed us!!!! If you like your guide, give him or her a tip. They work very hard!!!

Great Experience. Did this trip with my wife In early June and had a really good time.Our tour guide was Liah and she was excellent. We did not make a reservation in advance and chose to do this tour on a rainy day since it was underground, and we did not regret it. The tour lasted a few hours and was very educational and interesting. Our tour guide was amazing, and she even did the tour in 3 languages. The caves were beautiful, the water was amazing and we had time to swim around , pose for photos and they even served us food once we were done.The facilities were good to, to change, lock up your valuables and belongings, and they give you all the equipment you need. (wet suit, water shoes, helmet with a headlamp)Do this tour! But i would do it on a rainy day if possible because its one of the few things you can do in all weather. Ask for Liah ! Although i'm sure the other guides are good too.

Quick tour in cave but good.. The actual caves were good an interesting, didn't care for the guide. He moved ahead quickly without regard to checking to see if everyone was okay or keeping up with the group. You cannot take a camera into the cave, not sure why you can't take a waterproof camera, so they have a photographer. I wanted the pictures and after the cave tour we waited for our picture to be posted to purchase. It was really disappointing, the shots were not good and we had individual pixs of other people rather than ourselves on our own disc. Nonetheless we purchased only one as remembrance of our trip. We also wanted to purchase the shirts they offered for sale. They only had smalls for women and medium for men. Not one of the better tours we have been on while in Mexico.

The underworld!. Pablo our guide was very good. this place was beautiful! The tour wasn't rushed at all. Well worth the money. Be prepared for steep picture prices at the end of the tour, but they are worth it! You'll regret not having them to show family and friends. i would have done it again the next day.

This is the best!. We've been to the area six times and were finished with zip lining and jeep tours and wanted to see something totally natural. This place is just amazing and so wonderful for preserving the caves and underground rivers. Our guide was very knowledgeable and obviously loved it. The last part of the tour is swimming/floating in beautiful underground pools that is just breathtaking. The lunch that followed was fine. We rent cars when we are here and so our admission was just about $65 per person - which I don't mind at all as the profits go towards preserving this natural wonder.

Rio Secreto Excursion. Excursion was great. Bought the $70 dvd - took it home, put it in my laptop - AND IT WAS BLANK!!!!!! called them - but no response. All I want is the memories or my $70 back!Please advise them to provide my money or dvd before you buy yours. The excursion was tremendous - very disappointed!!!!!!

Amazing experience, even for the second time. Visited Rio Secreto for the second time, this time with a group of eight family members. They gave us eight our own group, which was great. If you like nature and like series like BBC earth and National Geographic, this is a must see. The caves are very beautiful and to actually being able to swim through them makes this an unique experience. You just can not compare this with any other cave system, because most of them are also accessible with a wheelchair and lack the experience.Hector was our guide and he did a great job. Besides overwhelming us with information about the underwater system he was also a very funny guy.I would suggest bringing your own water shoes. Cameras are not permitted, even if your camera is better than what the crew uses you would never create pictures like the ones available, as you 'll lack the lighting created by all the external flashes. Furthermore you can't expect the group to wait while you are taking pictures. I do think that the pricing on the pictures is a bit rough. However, if they are really the non profit organization that they say they are, I'm fine with that.

Underground amazement. booked through carnival for about $100 each. So worth it. Our guide Carine,originally from France was awesome. I can't imagine there was anyone better. Very environmentally cautious. saw bats in their natural environment. Everything is provided. I did not need a wetsuit and was just annoyed by mine the whole time, I wore it folded half down. The formations were just stunning. You can not take your own camera.so of course they get you with the pictures. We bought just the pictures, I think it was worth it to come home and show the kids. The snack lunch was delicious and very filling! Absolutely no time for anything else in your day.

Awe-inspiring beauty. When we booked this tour, we didn't know what to expect.For someone who can barely swim, let alone dive, Mexican underground caves seemed so inaccessible. Good thing I stepped out of my comfort zone.Rio Secreto has the clearest water and the caves have been sacred places for the Mayan people.In 2007, this underground cave system was rediscovered. Initially the owner wanted to put in a pedway which would have destroyed not only the geological formations, but also the experience of hiking and being in the water.Our guide Alfredo told us that it takes a century for a stalactite to grow one centimetre.We took a short walk through the jungle up to a Mayan elder who sought permission for us to enter the caves and performed a smudge ceremony to cleanse our souls.The caves are home to many creatures from catfish, to the bats whose guano brings in organic material, to insects who use their sensors to "see" in the pitch black caverns.Lunch was included.The guide was exceptional and making everyone feel comfortable as we navigated the cave.Pictures, while spectacular, don't do the experience justice.

Nice but overpriced attraction. The cave is nice, but I expected more for such a money. The tour in cave was short, I expected much more longer tour in bigger cave. Interior of the cave is relatively small. I have already seen more beautiful caves for much less money. I know, this one is great, because we can swim here, but I am not sure that it worth these big money. After I paid almost 60USD per person (in great discount), we were forbidden to enter with a camera. They have own photographer, photos were nice. But... It is very annoying to pay another 100USD for all our photos after paying this big entrance fee (or we can bought one photo for 25USD). Equipment was not in the best condition. At least, that guide was a nice man for the job and the snack was quite good, although it was relatively small selection. It was really nice, but low value for such huge money - totally overpriced commercial attraction. If I could choose again, I would not go for this entry fee.

Amazing Underground Journey. The drive into the Rio Secreto is unpaved and very rough but it's worth the trip. The above ground facilities are very rustic and add to the adventure that awaits us. My wife and I are both over 65 and in good physical condition, this is a necessity for this endeavor.After the introductions about the conditions that lay ahead, you're given wet-suits, water shoes and life vests. The only "downside" of the Tour is; the water shoes do not give much comfort on the rocky, sharp limestone trails and when inside the cave! Hips and knees are definitely challenged during this excursion, but the bottoms of your feet are really sore, even bruised, especially the next day. I'm not sure exactly what could/would be done different on this, perhaps allowing water sandals instead of the thin water shoes??We thoroughly enjoyed the experience, saw some incredibly beautiful cave formations and a couple of really rare little blind shrimp. The Tour Is not to be missed!!!

What a great surprise. Did not know what to expect; guides were great and informative. If you cannot swim they can give you noodles to hold onto; our guide, ALSO , assisted these two people. I am so sorry I have forgotten our guide's name. One thing to remember if you have some kind of hip or knee problem; this attraction can be difficult to manage/ they do offer strong stick-type canes to help you. Highlight of our vacation. You cannot bring your camera; they provide a CD with your pictures and other plant and animal pictures for a fee.

Highlight of our trip. This was a fantastic break from the heat. We went with a large group of friends, and they gave us a private tour at no additional fee (there were ten of us). The ride was a little bumpy but completely understandable as to not disturb the ecosystem by paving the road. Our tour guide Alfredo was fabulous! Very accommodating.

Amazing Cave!!. We booked this through Carnival. We weren't sure what to expect but we were pleasantly surprised. We took a ferry over which I thought was fine. We saw lots of flying fish. We were then split into vans for groups. The van ride is very bumpy but I like to think that adds to the fun.We arrived at the location and were told that we needed to shower off to preserve the river and the formations and then were given wet suits, helmets, and water shoes. There are lockers to put all your belongings in.Before entering the cave we were blessed during a Mayan ceremony. Our guide was VERY passionate about the caves and the beauty and the preservation. I felt he was great in explaining things, answering questions and guiding us. I have been in a lot of caves but this one impressed me the most. It was beautiful, the river running through it was fun to swim, wade and walk through. It was rough terrain and you really needed to watch your footings but again, this is what makes it an adventure. If it had railings or lit walkways it just wouldn't be a natural cave and nearly as beautiful. If you are worried about your footings they do offer a walking stick at the beginning. Take it, it will be helpful! I did not and did fine.After going through the river you get a lunch provided. It was a good simple buffet. Cameras are not allowed but they take great pictures inside the caves with your group and individual shots along the way. Pictures are pricey but we bought all of them on a zip drive and I think they are well worth it. They capture the cave beautifully. Now to customer service: We got home and our zip drive didn't work with our pictures we'd paid about $75 for. I was worried that they would be a lost cause and that we'd never see them. I gave it a whirl and contacted them via the web site. They worked hard to find the correct group, correct individual pictures and we received them all emailed to us in quick time. I was very impressed. I give this group and the experience 5 stars.

Best Part of Riviera Maya!. I booked Rio Secreto not knowing much about it. We have 3 boys, 9,8 & just turned 5. Our guide Rodrigo was superb, as a guide and with the boys. He didn't miss a detail, gave us fun facts, tips to navigate and made it more fun than words can say. We booked other experiences, the dolphin and Isle Mujeres and this was by far the best. I was a little nervous to start as our youngest cannot swim, it was not an issue. Rodrigo not only made the adventure fun, but memorable; he took us on the 'supreme' trail and it was amazing. Do not miss this adventure! If you have to pick between Rio Secreto and something else, choose Rio Secreto - you will not be sorry. They also provided lunch, iced tea/water and of course, great fun! We want to personally thank them for making our family vacation unforgettable.

Natural Beauty at Its Finest. This was an excellent excursion from our November cruise. I am removing one star though for the photos. Many have complained about not being allowed a camera. I understand this. However, my camera (which shoots in RAW and has underwater housing) would have taken better photos than the ones that we got on the CD of us. Most of them were slightly blurry or out of focus (including the ones of the Mayan Blessing which were done in outdoor lighting) and they were very small (5x7ish), so I can’t even print out a nice size picture of us in the caves. Perhaps our photo quality was a fluke since others seem not to have an issue. For a scrapbooker though, the quality (not the price) of our photos is worth losing a star. Also, the bumpy ride in the van was bearable and adventurous, but there was a strong exhaust fume smell that made me a little ill in combination with the road. We had a different van back, and it was better.Everything else was fabulous. We did find the wet suits and hard hats to be a little smelly, but they are wet all day, and I was determined not to let that spoil our adventure. Our guide was Lia and she was very nice and knowledgeable with a calm, soothing voice perfect for inside the caves. We enjoyed the Mayan blessing before entering the caves. The caves were delightful, and they have done such a good job trying to keep it unpolluted that I almost hated being down there putting my footprints on the paths and my body oils into the water.Definitely take the walking stick that is offered. I found it helpful to plant for support when walking on some of the uneven areas or stepping down into the water. We were allowed to wear our own all terrain water shoes (Keene H20s), and we were very glad as they have better arch support and soles than what is offered by the tour. There were some shower facilities, so if you bring some soap, you can wash off the smell when you are done with your tour. They do provide towels, so if you are on a cruise, you do not need to bring any from the ship. One couple had their own head lamps, and the tour guides had no issues with them putting theirs on over the one they provide. This gave us some extra light which was really nice. The water was cold, but one easily adjusts to it and the further away from the earth surface, the warmer the water felt. The lockers have one key that you take with you into the caves, so don’t worry about leaving your possessions there.The caves were fascinating and fabulous. I’m not sure you could do anything like this in the U.S. because as soon as one person got a scratch, there would be safety laws requiring paths and steps and safety lighting and such. Hopefully, the Mexican government will allow this natural site to remain as pristine and untouched as possible. My husband and I hope to get back before laws and regulations and commercialism destroys this natural beauty.

amazing and wonderous. It was beyond my expectations! I so loved the adventure and all the knowledge I recieved from this experience. I show everyone that comes over the pictures of the trek through the underground world. Alejandro was awesome, as our guide. I don't think there was one thing that he missed giving us information on. He was very excellent at his job. If I visit the Mayan again, I would definitely do it again. And the liquer at the end was amazing, I want to savour it as long as I can. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for an amazing adventure..............Till next time.

AWESOME Experience. The cenotes was something that I wanted to see while on our honeymoon (May 2013), but I didn't want anything too commercialized. This was it! You strapped on a wetsuit and a life preserver, you had a hard hat with a head lamp and a walking stick (do take the walking stick as the ground is pretty uneven and slick and you are not supposed to touch any of the rock formations inside). There was more hiking than I expected (and I am not a good hiker at all). I thought there was going to be more swimming than there was (I am a very good swimmer), but that was ok. The experience was worth it! And our guide was terrific! I believe his name was Julian. Just amazing and highly recommended!

Beautiful!. Rio Secreto is absoutly a must see if you are in the area. One of the most beautiful cave systems I have visited. I booked my excursion through Carnival Cruise lines. The Rio Secreto staff were professional and knowledgable. I liked that they do as much as possible to prevent destruction of the cave system while sharing this natural wonder with the general public. A delicious lunch was provided.

The Cenote was great.. Getting into "wet suits" was a little bad and not being able to bring our own camera. If you want pictures you HAVE to buy theirs is not good. The caves were beautiful and worth the trip.

A MUST SEE. These caves were one of the most amazing things I have seen around the world! You can arrange your tour before you go or at the hotel in Mexico . The tour picks you up around 8:30 am and drops you off about 4:30 pm. They provide lunch, great deal.

Amazing!. The tour through the underground caves was awesome. Definitely something everyone should experience in their lifetime. Wearing the old (and a little stinky) helmets, shoes, wetsuits, isn't ideal, but well worth it! Going in and out of the water, with a little bit of swimming makes it a much more adventurous experience rather than just walking on a trail through a cave.

Unforgettable!. The tour guide Jovanna was very friendly and helpful. The cave is untouched and absolutely gorgeous. The views are just amazing. A very special experience - must see! The photos are a little overpriced but turned out well.

sooo Good!!. we had an amazing time at Rio Secreto. our guide, Leon was very knowledgable, funny and an excellent leader. Everythign was very well organized and all the staff were very helpful and all seemed to love their jobs. The van ride to get to the caves was longer than we expected and very bumpy but other than that everything was just perfect. it's a great day trip if you are in the Playa del Carmen area.

Rio Secreto - Amazing. We had such a wonderful experience and our guide Alejandro was very knowledgeable. We were suited up in wet suits, helmets with headlights and water shoes. Exploring the underwater caves was amazing, these are pitch black caves, with large stalagmite/ stalactite formations. It's a cool walk into the caves and you get to witness a Mayan ceremony. There are lots of ups and downs in the caves, so you really have to pay attention to where you're walking, but our guide did a great job directing us, totally an amazing experience. The coolest part was switching of our lights and sitting in the pitch black for a few minutes and enjoying the silence, pretty awesome.

bucket list experience. This is a natural cave, pitch black with water. We had to wear wet suits, helmets with headlights. We couldn't touch anything which didn't help if we fall. There were alot of ups and downs, rough surfaces and plenty of swimming in cool water. It was fun, exciting, especially when the lights were switched off for 1 minute. It was complete darkness and silence. Most eerie moment. Do not eat the lunch or drink the water; it was what caused my husband to be sick that very night. Otherwise it's a must do. Our guide was Victor, nice, affable, experienced cave diver.

Wonderful cave sights. I was a bit apprehensive, having been down similar limestone caves in NZ. In reality, however, this was a wonderful half day. Our group was small, at 7, which was ideal. We were well kitted out with helmets, shoes (ignore the comment on the brochure about having to bring your own), life jacket and stick, which is very necessary over rough terrain underwater. I chose not to take the offered wetsuit, as the water temperature does not warrant it. I am glad I did not need it. There are no paved walkways underground and the going can be little difficult in one or two places. Our guide, Julian, was bilingual, in Spanish and excellent English, and very informative. I was very impressed with the unostentatious help he gave one less able member of the group. The tour took just under two hours and was followed by a drink and buffet lunch. My only gripe was with the outrageous cost of single photos. At $69 for a CD of all 39, a charge of US$25 for one is a rort! One comment: the aquifer is low in water for two reasons: low rainfall over Yucatan and hotels and towns along the coast drawing on it. Time for some desalination and regulation, were it not for powerful but selfishly greedy vested interests!

Amazing!!!. This experience is beyond cool!!! I loved the fact that it was natural- no fancy lights, railings, stairs, nothing. There are other cave experiences in the area, but they were all so much more commercialized. We saw lots of creatures- bats, spiders, little catfish... our guide was Jovanna, and she was great :)A couple things to notate: 1. when they ask if you want a walking stick, take it, even if you are a good hiker. The paths in the caves are very "natural", and when you walk you want to grab something to help your balance (and the only things to grab are the stalactites- which is a no no!). 2. when you are eating lunch, stay clear of the hot sauce. Holy moly! I think my mouth is still burning from it... Overall- VERY VERY AWESOME EXPERIENCE! Do not hesitate to sign yourself up. It's worth every penny :)
rodrigo. Had to do this again, it's beyond cool, 2 million year old cave/cenote?? we really lucked out with our guide Rodrigo, such a good dude. Try it you will love it!

2nd visit to an underground wonder of the world. Obviously this being our second trip, we knew what to expect and our only concern was that we didn't have to explore the same section of river as last year. We made the request online and crossed our fingers. We had seen the "Snakesmouth" section in 2012 and this year we got to see the original section that was first discovered by the property owner in 2006 which was called "Supreme". Yayo was our guide and explained the section and formations quite well. Being a type A personality I couldn't help but add additional information that I had either researched or learned from Francesca on our first visit. But was able to bite my tongue after awhile and just enjoy the experience. I disagree with other posts that say that you MUST use a provided walking stick. If you are still fairly stable on your feet and in your 50's or younger, we didn't see the need. If the guide is moving too fast, just continue at your own rate, they'll wait for the group...no hurry. In the two trips that we've made, only one guy (who has a back problem) has used the walking stick. Yes the footing is uneven and you have to watch your step but on both occasions, though all strangers, the groups all helped each other out. Holding the hands of the older ladies over the rough parts and pointing out any underwater hazards. Teamwork just comes naturally on these life enhancing expeditions!
