One tip that I will include is, on this trip, the guide gave the group the option of NOT wearing the wetsuits. Half the people took him up on this. We were glad to wear the suits as the water is a little chilly in just a bikini or shorts and they were all complaining whenever we had to float for any length of time. Another tip.......DON"T pass up doing this excursion. It's awesome and if you've never done anything like it before, you'll never forget it. Yes, some of it is a little commercial and yes the picture posing is a bit of a pain and expensive but it also costs a lot to maintain and further explore the system. It will someday be recognized as a UNESCO world heritage site! Also, like anywhere in Mexico, tip the guides, they really appreciate it and probably don't make a lot in wages. One last observation, we enjoyed the "Snakesmouth" section a little more because there was more floating along with the current of the river with your knees up relaxing and taking in this wonder of the world.

Awesome!. I had such a wonderful experience our tour guide Eduardo was great. I enjoy how they start with a Maya Ceremony I loved that part. Exploring the under water caves was a wonderful and experience Ill never forget. If you are around that area I recommend this place

Great cave, but.... My wife and I recently visited Rio Secreto, with anticipation of a fun and memorable experience. At the outset, I am an experienced hiker and did spelunking many years ago. The cave itself is wonderful: large stalagmite/ stalactite formations with many amazing intricacies including cave pearls, formations which appear to be defying gravity, delicate layered formations along standing water bodies, etc as well as fairly abundant blind crayfish, spiders, bats, and other life. The experience is wild; no paved paths, electric lighting, railings, or signs which to me was a nice concept. After donning a helmet (with an inadequate head lamp), wetsuit, and very flimsy footware, you travel along very rough and wet paths in the cave, and at one point one must swim perhaps a hundred years in deep water to reach another trail. For a cave enthusiast, this cave had some wonderful cave formations, but the inadequate lighting supplied and the fairly fast pace of the group prevented a real appreciation of the formations. Though this was also meant to be an adventure, the really flimsy required footware on the very rough and slippery trails and underwater obstructions (rocks, holes) caused unwelcome distractions since one had to pay full attention to safely moving about on too many occasions rather than enjoying the cave. When suiting up before the walk began, the guide noted walking sticks were available but optional. Make no mistake about it- YOU NEED A WALKING STICK!! One cannot maintain a 3-point walking stance without one. Finally, the frequent stops to take posed photos was annoying, taking up far too much time better used to enjoy this unique visit. BTW, a single picture is $25 or a CD of the pictures taken is $60. Very commercial! In retrospect, the tour was part nature-part adventure, but the owners did not do either one real well. Perhaps separate types of tours would be more gratifying, depending on one's interests. I know I was disappointed after anxiously awaiting the visit to Rio Secreto for several months.

Great experience underground. Went to playa del Carmen from Carnival Conquest. Booked this excursion through carnival. They picked us up at the pier and took us to the rio secrato safely. The underground caves are amazing! Our tour guide was awesome and was extremely tentative to our group. Some in our group are quite closterphobic and did great. We were suited up in wetsuits, life vests, and hard hat with lights. We got to literally swim in the underground river. They gave us a wonderful authentic lunch buffet and got us back to the port in plenty of time to shop.

Swimming in caves under stalactites. Stunning cave tour, got to walk, wade and swim in the caves while looking at beautiful natural formations. Nice meeting mayan mn with copal on the way in, educational mayan culture. Buffet after tour was decent. Lia wa our tour guide and she was spectacular, giving a bilingual tour and so passionate about the ecology. Caves felt tiny to gargantuan at times. Don't bother with biodgradable sunscreen. - you're in caves and they have you shower to not bring foreign lotions into the ecosystem. Loved the experience and serenity.

Words cannot do it justice. Myself, my husband and our two kids (7 and 9) decided to do this excursion while on our Disney Cruise. We were NOT disappointed.....in fact, it far exceeded our expectations. We were prepared for the beauty, given the photos we had seen, however the serenity and magnitude of the caves surprised us. And to learn at the end that we had only traveled a half a mile from our starting point and there were 17 1/2 miles we didn;t see was even more amazing.Our guide (Rodrigo) was amazing, even holding our 7 year old's hand after she lost her balance the first 5 minutes. He never let her go after that. He was incredibly knowledgeable and patient with everyone, especially the children in the group. The hour and a half went by in the blink of an eye and I was so sad to see it end. You dont realize what the reawakening of many of your senses - in particular smell and sound - when you emerge from the cave but he told us to pay particular attention when we exited and it was so amazing to realize how QUIET it really was. The mayan ceremony before entering the caves was also very humbling.I would absolutely love to go back - it is challenging as there is uneven terrain, however it is not difficult. My kids did better than I did. I would have taken the walking stick they offered if I had it to do over. And at the end, we were served a very nice luncheon and we got all of the photos that were taken as well as three souvenier shirts (not flimsy t-shirts but nice sun shirts) for $99. Very reasonable considering some other excurisons. Don't miss this excursion - I can promise you it won't disappoint.
Great Time!. We had a great time! It was very interesting, the guide was great (Sorry I forgot his name!). Nice to cool off and stay out of the sun for a bit.

A wonderfully unique cave experience. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed Rio Secreto. When they say that the only stuff you need to bring with you is a swimsuit, they're not kidding-- they provide you with a wetsuit, watershoes, life jacket, and hard hat w/ light. They also provide lockers to put your other stuff away in. Some of our companions didn't bring any money with them, which wasn't even a problem when it came time to buy pictures at the end of the excursion-- they were given internet information to view and purchase their pictures from the comfort of home instead.The tour started with a brief orientation, followed by a very bumpy ride in an air-conditioned van through the woods (maybe 15 minutes) to "base", followed by a mandatory shower (to wash off makeup, perfumes, and other artificial substances) and changing into the provided gear. Then came a bit of an ersatz nature walk (roughly 10 minutes)-- our guide was showing how informative he could be already with his patter as we walked, and kept getting better throughout the trip.There was a short (kinda hokey) interlude with a "native" Mayan that blessed our little group of 6 (plus the guide and a photographer, so 8 total), and then we entered the cave by going down a set of stairs maybe 30 feet.Right away, the air got comfortably cooler (a good thing, given the somewhat stifling effect of the gear being worn), and somehow cleaner smelling. As we walked through the caves, there were occasional stops for pictures, along with delays as the group navigated some difficult stretches of terrain. Despite the unsteady footing, my wife and I never felt uncomfortable or closed-in, which is saying something when it comes to caving! However, that same unsteady footing did cause most of our group to suffer minor bumps and scratches, which we were warned ahead of time to expect.After a bit of walking (maybe 30 minutes), we came to a section of wonderfully cool water where we floated (I wouldn't really call it swimming, since it was so leisurely and the lifejackets were so buoyant) for another 15 minutes or so, before finishing up with another 15 minutes or so of walking. According to our guide, we got roughly 90' belowground at our deepest.By and large, the water was beautiful and clear, and the caverns we entered were soaring. Though we spotted bats at a couple of points, there was no evidence of poop or ammonia smell due to the circulation in the caves. At one point, near the deepest part, our guide showed us a deep cleft in the "floor" of the caves, roughly 30' across and 250' deep-- very impressive to see that far down since the cleft was full of crystal-clear water! He explained that the water was from another level beneath ours that was mostly submerged-- a separate underground river, if you will.After getting back to base, we changed back to our own clothes and had a buffet lunch-- the food was so-so, but the salsa dips were good and spicy-hot. Then, after the teeth-rattling return trip via van, we were headed "home".Overall, having done a number of other caving trips in the U.S., this one ranks as the best I've been on, both from the standpoint of the cleanliness/natural state of the caves and the water experience. Our guide was also wonderful. At some points underground, the scenery was even somewhat romantic!

The BEST decision we ever made! not for older folks!. My boyfriend and I decided to share the responsibilities of picking shore excursions when we sailed on the carnival Dream. When he told me he signed us up for the Rio Secreto, I have to admit I hesitated. Our tour guide "Angel" greeted us on the pier and he was the one who took us through our experience of the secret river/ caves. I thought I was going to be chased down by bats and bat pooo but theres no words to express the wonderful experience that I had on the tour. I'll try by telling you that all you need for the day is a bathing suit and possible dry clothes for the return trip. They provide water shoes, wet suits, hard hats with lights, and even food for afterwards. Angel was very caring and passionate when it comes to the history of the caves, and for all that are on his tour, so I highly recommend requesting Angel for the tour guide. He showed us through the most wonderful cave, and what really made this a wonderful experience is the water in the cave. There is not bats and no snakes etc. in the water and how you can tell....... the water is so clean, you can see straight through to the very bottom. At no point in the tour did we go under water but we did get a chance to float (with life jackets) through to the other side (which wasn't too far). They don't allow pictures but a nice lady followed us and took pictures of each person or each group. (pictures do cost a little money at the end of the tour). The cavern was hard to walk through due to the fact its a cave and not a straightened paved man made path etc. But as long as you don't have problems with your bones or joints, you should have a great time. Not for people who want fabulous lights and glamor but this trip is for people who want to see a SECRET river (not open to the public) and see that nature can be a beautiful thing. ** cave lovers!**

A different kind of experience, though not your usual "cruise excursion". We decided last minute to purchase the Secret River or "Rio Secreto" excursion as part of our Princess cruise. I have to admit I was a bit anxious as Princess rated the excursion as "strenuous" with some swimming required, but figured things would be fine since there weren't any age or weight restrictions. Our family, which includes a teenage son and two younger boys as well as my seventy year old mom were not sure what to expect. We took a ferry from Cozumel to Playa del Carmen which was roughly 45 minutes. I almost canceled the excursion once we arrived at Playa del Carmen because the guide, Mena, required that we sign a number of indeminification forms, which basically stated that the Company was not at fault if anything happened to us during the tour---otherwise, we had the option to cancel our excursion. I was pretty turned off with having to sign these forms, primarily because it was a last minute deal where you signed your life away. I decided to sign anyways, because I felt safe enough that if it was good enough for Princess to be affiliated with, it was good enough for us. We were then divided into groups of ten and shuttled into nice, clean and fairly new air-conditioned vans for about 30-40 minutes. The ride was horrible because of the slow, bumpy, pot-hole ridden gravel roads where Rio Secreto is situated. We were greeted by our river guide, Joan, although he pronounced it more like "Joe-Ahn" who was great. He was very knowledgable and considerate and so much better to interact with than Mena. The bathrooms were pretty clean, although the outdoor "showers' reminded me of what you'd find at Disneyland's Swiss Family Robinson treehouse . In addition to lockers, they provided a wetsuit, water shoes, and a life vest. I would recommend you bring your water shoes and aqua socks that are a snug fit as you do not want rocks entering through loose soles that can cause blisters. Also, be prepared for the "smell" when you put on their wet suits. Most of the tour of the cave and underground river is spent walking. There is some wading, and a few pockets where your can swim or dog paddle. Joan took excellent care of my mom since she doesn't swim and he basically towed her in the few deep areas. I towed my youngest son even though he knows how to swim, because he was intimidated being in the cave.Take advantage of the walking stick they provide, because it actually helps to provide balance. You can't grab on most areas of the cave as it is fragile.The ground floor of the cave can be slippery and the walk through the river can be difficult because there are sharp and jagged rocks that are not visible. Got some bumps and scrapes on my shin and legs, but nothing serious. The overall experience was amazing, because it's simply not something folks do on a typical vacation. I would have rated it excellent but had to factor the annoyances I mentioned above. While you have to endure smelly wetsuits, a bumpy ride, I'm glad our family went on this "adventure". It's a great feeling to be in an unusual and "haunting" envirnment and have the opportunity to see a bat, stalactites and stalagmites and a river created from rainfall. I've been to Carlsbad Caverns, which is beautiful and "sparkly", but not at all the same kind of "rugged" experience. Being well rested and fed before the excursion sure helped because it is long and tiring. The "buffet" lunch of taquitos, black beans, and other snacks are bleh. Kids did not want to eat the food. I didn't care for the last leg of the excursion where our tour guide dropped us off at the shopping area for an hour. I just wanted to go back to the ship and relax. You can't bring ANY cameras inside the cave, so you'd have to purchase photos through Rio Secreto for mementos. Frankly, I was surprised there were no "hard sell" tactics and wish we had more money on hand to tip Joan for this worthwhile experience.

In response to Gavin Greenwood on our supposably "money return"- yea right!!!. Gavin,You are mistaken. We never received the money from BANCOMER, your bank. NEVER! Our bank at Schools First Credit Union waited 90 days to recieve our reimbursement form Bancomer, yet not even a dime was sent to us. Rio Secreto needs to hire a different bank to reimburse transactions. Our bank was kind enough and loyal to reimburse us the money. After not seeing any results or hope that our money would be returned by you guys, our bank really stepped forward.... otherwise, I would have still been making phone calls/emails to Rio Secreto admin and gotten NOWHERE!!!! Please use my experience as a fault on your business end (wether its banking or poor follow ups to customers on behalf of administration staff). Obviously I am still not happy with the fact that your business claimed a false statement saying "you guys paid us back". I mean that was a lot of money. It is so easy to charge a credit card when on vacation, but never would have I expected going thru this ordeal of having to go back and forth CONSTANT, I mean CONSTANT times in order to get reimbursed. Something is obviously wrong here & should be taken more seriously.

Not worth the trip!. The walk through the cavern was difficult (we're older folks) and there really wasn't much to see. It was sort of lackluster and overshadowed by getting's the bum's rush through the "buffet lunch." All in all, not the highlight of the trip.

Best attraction in Riviera Maya. Again this year we visited Rio Secreto. This is our 3rd time over the past 4 years. It is by far the best attraction in the area. You walk and swim through an amazing cave with an underground river flowing through it. Groups are small and language specific. Our leader this trip, Antonio, spoke Spanish, English, German and Croation. Don't miss this tour!! We have sent many friends there and they all loved it.

Incredible Adventure. It's been a few years since we went. It had just been discovered about six months before our tour. The ride in their passenger vehicle was a bit dicey....drive entropy fat on some bumpy back roads. The guides were knowledgeable, friendly, entertaining and encouraging. I have been to Carlsbad Caverns a zillion times and assumed these would be similar.I was wrong.These were pristine caves and such a different experience!The wetsuits, helmets and equipment were brand new back then. The prices have gone waaay up since we went, but I still believe they are worth the experience.Seriously check it out while you are in the area. Very cool.

DEFINITELY A MUST DO. On March 20,2013 my wife and I with our two grandsons 7 & 8, off the Disney Fantasy, took this excursion. It was fantastic. The operator is very organized and meets you at the dock. From there you go by 10 passenger van to the Rio Secreto. There is about a 10-15min ride just before you get to the site, and it is a very bumpy pothole filled coral rock bed...but it is worth the ride in and seems much shorter out. At the Rio Secreto we were met by Franchesca, who was absolutely terrific! She was so enthusiastic and knowledgeable regarding the underground river, its initial finding in 2006 and what we saw and did in the approximately 90 minutes in the caverns. My wife was the only one to accept a walking stick, and we would recommend anyone to have one as the footing in the caverns is difficult at times and the stick really aids in balance. The wetsuits work well along with the helmet lights. Not only is there walking at different depths, but definite swimming required--but not difficult. The boys really enjoyed the adventure from the initial Mayan blessing to the accension up the original Mayan stairs to the surface and then a traditional lunch. Along the way they take many photos and we ordered the whole boat which includes the CD of our specific group and then three other items-we chose 2 really nice teeshirts for the boys and a bottle of Mexican liquor(honey and licorice tasting). All was really great until we got home and the CD only partially worked. I immediately called their customer service and they were TERRIFIC and they put me in touch with the photo company and their customer service, and they then sent by email for me to download the entire CD with all the pictures. They all downloaded easily and we have the whole experience to relive again and again. We loved it and would definitely recommend it.

Hidden Gem-Totally Worth It. Typically when we visit this area it is with a cruise ship and we go SCUBA diving. We had a couple of people in our group that weren't certified divers, so I decided to book this unique adventure. I have been to Xcaret and was not impressed, too crowded. I am so glad that I chose this excursion. This unspoiled natural reserve is just amazing. Our guide Eva kept us safe and on the right path. She explained how the cave was discovered and how much had been mapped so far. How formations were made. And what was planned next for exploring the rest of these caves. I love that there has been such great care in keeping this jewel well preserved. The small groups make the trip very personal. We had teens and adults in our group and all seemed entertained. I also saw groups with even younger children that seemed to thrive on this truly unique adventure. It is a must see. Afterwards they served us a buffet lunch that was so yummy, even the green salsa from "Hell". If I ended up in Playa del Carmen again with non-divers, I will visit this place again and ask for a different route. There are 3 available. BEAUTIFUL!!! Purchase the pictures it is worth it.

Neat attraction/make sure your disc has pictures on it!. Took my 6 and 9 year old here in February. This was quite a fun adventure. You must make a reservation b/c the numbers per tour and tours per day are limited. They start you off w/a short video as you sit outside in a covered area. Then your tour guide meets you and gets you set up with the wetsuits, helmets w/lights, watershoes, etc.What I didn't see mention of is that you then have to take a van ride over an unpaved road to the cave entrance...it was extremely bumpy and fast and felt like about 15 minutes long. We happened to be in the back of the van and I was feeling sick to my stomach at the end (and I never get car sick!), so if this is an issue for you be sure to sit in the front of the van. The cave is peaceful and beautiful and our guide Alfredo was truly passionate about his job. You have about 90 mins in the cave which feels like the right amount of time. We were not cold at all but opted to wear the wetsuits for protection from sharp rocks you inevitably rub up against. It was difficult at times to navigate through w/my two kids by myself (husband was sick) but thankfully another mom helped me with my older child. The walking is difficult at times b/c you can't always see where you are stepping b/c the mineral rich water is cloudy. If you are not that sure on your feet then this is not the trip for you.Afterward they walk you into the picture area where your photographer has put all the photos he took on the adventure, and this is why I can't give Rio Secreto 5 stars. I would not call it a "hard sell" but we bought a photo which they supposedly put on a CD. When we got home and I tried to print it, it was blank. You would think a simple email or phone call would remedy this but it took no less than three emails and FOUR phone calls to get my picture, some of which were not free b/c they told me I had to call the non-800 number, essentially long distance from the US to Mexico. This was extremely frustrating and spread out over a few weeks' time. In the end, I did get my pictures, and other pictures taken of us (which I asked for), but I would recommend VERIFYING that your picture is actually on the CD before you leave so you don't have to jump through hoops later.

Rio Secreto. This trip from the cruise ship was well worth the money. The site is so unspoilt, unlike xplore and xcaret. Our guide Julian was absolutely brilliant, his enthusiasm and pride in this underground river and caverns was very catching. Some people may read about this trip and worry about safety and fitness required to do it. I can assure you that if we can do it, so can you. The guides take small groups at a time, well spaced out, we never saw another group at all. All necessary equipment is provided by the attraction, every bit as good as what their site says it is. Adventurous children with no fears of the dark or caves would enjoy this tour, although I would suggest at least 10 years old.The road in, is a dirt track, but accept this as part of the trip - bumpy fun! The food afterwards left a lot to be desired, but this is a minor point and certainly should not be allowed to cloud your judgement.
Worth it!. Recommended by the hotel hostess and it was worth it. Very tranquil and a thing of beauty just to one with the earth. Downside was the cost of obtaining a picture during the tour.

A great naturalistic experience. This was a shot in the dark for us, we didn't want to go to places like Xplor or Xcaret because they are swamped with tourists. This place was recommended by a travel agent and it was definitly worth going. Only about an hour away from Cancum, half an hour from Playa del Carmen, this is a nutarl underground river/cave system. You go in in a group of about 10 people, plus a guide and a photographer, so it also an intimate experience. Great experience overall. Interesting, fun, and enlightening. Our guide Leon was awesome. Highly recommend.

Interesting alternative to the beach !. A very interesting afternoon excursion to underground caves and river system. Our guide Leon was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic and made this a great visit. Food at the end of the tour was not so good (don't imagine it will be a meal substitute!). Very bumpy ride into the jungle to start the walk/swim was all part of the experience. Highly recommended for any age.

Definitely worth a visit. Very informative, the guide really enjoyed the subject. We had a mixture of ages 15-55 and all of us had an amazing time. The food was a bit of a disappointment but other than that it was great!

Amazing. The underground river and caves were beautiful. We were given lockers, keys, water shoes, wet suits, life jackets, late lunch. No cameras allowed, they have a photographer there taking pics while your in the cave, down side there expensive! The bus ride there is horrible for people who get car sick, many many many pot holes!! Overall worth the trip to see the amazing cave !

amazing. I believe this is a must if you are visiting Cancun. it is an amazing and unique experience you won't find anywhere else. my wife and 3 teens loved it.
The lunch buffet was ok, but that did not affect our view of hao great this adventure was.

Challenging & Interesting...until the end :(. Be prepared for the long bumpy ride to the attraction. We brought our own water shoes and I'm glad we did. They do supply them but they are in rough shape! They will offer you a walking stick if you want and I suggest you take it!It is an amazing cave but it's very hard to get your footing. You are walking behind a group of people and the water gets really cloudy. It's comparable to walking on an iron shore (very rough & sharp porous sections of rock similar in look to a sponge, but very sharp) but under murky water. You can't grab on to anything if you lose your balance. The guide wears a full wet suit and large rubber water boots to protect the ankles and knees. It would have been better to have full protection as well. It is very easy to get your ankles and knees scraped up.We found it to be very interesting. I only wished that the groups were divided by language. Our guide had to repeat herself in English and French. I was lucky, I understand both languages but others did not and you could see they were getting bored. When we booked this excursion, we were told to bring some money for souvenirs. They should mention that you should bring lots of money. All the way through the cave, we had a photographer, he took many pictures and family pictures. When the tour was over, we were escorted over to a building and all handed iPads. We looked at our pictures and they were wonderful except for the price. 100 dollars for all the pictures, two t-shirts, and two hats, there may have been something else thrown in but I was shocked at the price. We already paid 200 dollars! You think a picture would have been included! The next price down was 70 dollars for the pictures only or 25 dollars for each picture! That's highway robbery as far as I'm concerned! The food at the end was OK but like another reviewer said, it was probably sitting around for a while. This is a mixed review:I would give the cave experience a 4 starPicture experience 0 starsLunch a 2 star

Historical wonder of the world.. This was truly a very unique experience which you will not find in many places of the world. Amazing underground river/cave experience in such a raw and natural state. We took our 72 year old, healthy, fit parents who also very much enjoyed the tour. Our guide, Luis was excellent and truly took care of our mother who at first was somewhat hesitant.All gear is provided, if your shoes have a hole in them, ask for another pair. We did not take walking sticks but probably would have to assist with the more underwater, uneven portions of the walk.(My parents took the sticks and utilized them).The walk to the caves was not difficult and we had expected more "swimming" thru the caves on the river but there was more walking thru knee high water that floating. If you are not a swimmer I believe this would not be an issue because of the life jackets for floating and your partner or the guide may assist you by gently pulling on you.The Rio Secreto website is very informative and the "Live Chat" option answered any questions prior to our arrival.We had researched out the prices before had and recieved a great price, $52 (spring break deal) for admission only, 2:00pm tour. Currently for the rest of March/April 2013 it is $56 for the 2pm tour, admission only.The included meal at the end was "OK" but we were at the end of the day and not overly hungry.FYI.....Now for the reason of only a 4*.....from the ticket booth/entrance of Rio Secreto (however you get there), you will begin the tour by getting on a 10 person van to travel the 8km "gravel" road.....which is terrible.....full of washboards and holes the entire 8kms......the guide said it's not paved due to not ruining the caves etc.......I understand that but a grater with some gravel would do the trick......I actually think it was limestone road which was packed to be super hard.This 8kms took at least 20 minutes to drive at a very slow speed depending on your driver....Sitting towards the front of the van does help with car sickness.Even with that being said the actual cave is still worth seeing and maybe one day they will get the road in better shape.

A very cool under ground adventure. This was a very interesting tour. Going through an underground cavern and floating down an underground river was very surreal. You need to be in ok shape for this tour as it is a couple of hours of walking through uneven underground terrain.This tour really interested my wife and I as it was a nature excursion. The only artificial aspect were your lights. They gave you a wetsuit and lifejacket to wear, as well as a helmet. So everything is very safe. At one point halfway through the tour everyone shuts off their lights. TOTAL darkness. There are plenty of under ground critters and water creatures to see as well.I highly recommend this tour.

Beautiful Tour. My son and I toured Rio Secreto in March and we both thoroughly enjoyed it. We were with a mixed English / Russian group and our tour guide did an amazing job of making sure we all got the full tour. The 90+ minutes passed very quickly and after the tour we had a nice buffet lunch. I would recommend this tour to anyone, it was amazing!

Unique and exciting adventure. A guide gets you all geared up with helmets, wetsuits, water shoes, and a lifejacket and takes you on a guided tour of the stalactite caves, discovered only about five years ago. Safety measures excellent. Guide knew every rock in the water. Not so much as a stubbed toe. Caves are gorgeous. In one large area you turn off all the lights and think about your life and it is very powerful. Food at end of tour is good. Memories of day will last for a very long time. You should go!

AMAZING!. We booked our trip to Rio Secreto through Royal Caribbean based on the number of positive reviews on tripadvisor. We were NOT disappointed at all. There were 30 people from Oasis of the Seas that morning and I thought the staff did an amazing job from the minute we were met on the pier. The staff on Oasis wasn’t as informative as we would have liked but once we got off the ship and walked down the pier we saw the Rio Sectreto sign and from that point on we were very well taken care of. We had to take a very tipsy ferry from Cozumel to Playa de Carmen - not the best part of the experience but it was brief (30 minutes). From there they broke us into three groups and took us to the cave in three vans on a BUMPY dirt road. We were fortunate enough to be in a group that had some returning guests and they had requested Alfredo. What a great tour guide! So passionate about his job and for the love of the cave - very contagious! Not only was he very knowledgeable he was GREAT with our 9 year old son. I wasn’t sure how my son would do in a dark cave but after having done it I know he will be back and will explore many more caves. Alfredo took my son’s hand and led him through the cave and was also able to make sure that the other 9 guests were taken care of. It’s hard to put into words just how incredible this experience is….my recommendation is if you are anywhere nearby – make sure you go. I thought that the facilities that they have built out in the midst of the jungle were great. The equipment (wet suits, helmets, lights, life vests) that they gave us were also in excellent condition. After exiting the cave and getting changed we sat down to an authentic (I guess) Mexican lunch. I read a few reviews that people didn’t like the food but all 10 of us thought the food was excellent. The tortilla soup in particular was delicious. The staff was also very concerned about getting us back to the ferry and onto our ship on time. Angel (Rio Sectreto staff) stayed with us until he saw and confirmed that all of us made it onto the ferry. We were very pleased and amazed by the entire excursion. If you go… ask for Alfredo...you won’t be disappointed.

Incredible experience!. A must see! Our tour guide, Raul was excellent! And resembled and sounded like Antonio Banderas. An amazing trip underground for about 90 minutes. Not a terrible dark cave with head lamps on. BEAUTIFUL. Wonderful and authentic Mexican buffet afterward.

FANTASTIC!. Did this excursion via Princess Cruises while docked in Cozumel. Met at the ship’s dock and were escorted to the ferry for the ride to Playa Del Carmen. We were then met at the ferry dock and escorted to our awaiting vans. Only 7 – 8 people in a group which makes it real nice – no crowding. The hosts\drivers were very cordial – coordination was excellent. The ride to the cave is extremely rough - if you have a bad back the ride would not be pleasant. Once at the caverns you take a shower, get a wetsuit, water shoes and a helmet with a light. Our guide (Celine) was excellent. The caves are real and natural – no cement sidewalks, stairs, lighted pathways, etc. – only lights are on your helmets and the guide’s flashlight. This tour was amazing – we spent about 1 ½ hours underground and did not want to come up – it was just fantastic. If you have ankle, knee or back problems, are claustrophobic or do not like the dark, this might not be for you. Having said that – My wife had both knees replaced 2 years ago and she negotiated the hike though the cavern without any problem but did use the walking stick they provided. Lunch afterwards was fine. No personal cameras are allowed and the tour photographer’s picture package – albeit good – is expensive at $69.00. You are escorted back to Playa Del Carmen for some shopping time then escorted to the ferry for your return to the ship.

Amazing hike and swim through some of the most beautiful caverns on Earth. Alfredo and Hector were marvelous guides.. We booked this tour through our cruise desk on Royal Caribbean Freedom of the Seas. Our party of 5 ranged in age from 8 to 68. The hike was moderately physical but our guides, Alfredo and Hector were there to help out every step of the way. The caverns were unbelievably beautiful and the swim in an underground lake was truly spectacular.Our guides were extremely knowledgeable and attentive and really made it an amazing experience for the whole family.
Great experience. What a great excursion, it was such a great experience, thanks to our guide Celine, we would recommend this excursion to everyone!!!

Great Cenote Experience. This is a wonderful tour of the underground. Beautiful to see and we had the chance to experience total darkness and total silence - amazing - all while you are floating in the water. I enjoyed the fact that wetsuits, shoes and gloves are provided as the water is fairly cold and we were walking (and swimming at times) through it for 1 hour. Friendly tour guides and a nice lunch was served. This was a nice excursion that I would do again and recommend to everyone. It was very educational also. A must if you want to learn about Cenotes and have a fun time.

Most incredible experience with tour guide Alfredo. I recently went to this excursion booked through RCCL. It was amazing. I am an interpreter for the Deaf and was on the tour with two Deaf clients. Alfredo was so wonderful and patient. He gives an excellent explanation of the cave and it's formations. It's easy to see how passionate he is about his work. Great experience. Worth the visit.

Poor quality pictures ruined the whole experience for me.. Alex was our guide and he was fabulous. The food was mediocre at best. The caves were breathtaking, but due to the horrible quality of the photos taken I will never take this tour again. I contacted rio Secreto and was told someone in the photo department "Silvia Castro" would get back with me about resolving the issue, but after several emails she never did. The pictures are so bad that I can not even make out my face in them. I paid sixty nine dollars for the pictures, because no cameras are allowed.....all I can say is what a rip off!

Absolutely incredible!!!!. I took my wife here for our tenth anniversary, and didn't regret it at all! My wife's knee has been messed up for quite a while now, and i was hesitant to take her because i didn't know if she would be able to through. But once we got there our guide Ava made all our worries disappear. She helped my wife every step of the way telling her about every rock and ledge there was, she was fantastic! One of the best guides we have ever had! The cave also was spectacular! We have been to many other caves (in fact our honeymoon was at mammoth cave, Kentucky) but Rio Secreto was our favorite! So many formations to see, literally everywhere! Then throw in being able to put on a wetsuit and float through a cave, it was breath taking to say the least! I only hope that the land owner continues to allow them to provide tours of the cave, and keeps it natural. The only thing we were slightly put off by was the fact they you can't take a camera down with you, even if it was waterproof. But once we got in, we understood why, unless you wanted to risk taking a expensive camera and flash down with u, it would be worthless, plus it would be way to easy to get it wet and ruin it! The photographer that took pictures of our group did a great job, and i didn't mind spending the extra money to buy the disc of pics. Also the Mayan booze at the end of the your was a nice touch :) all in all, if you like caves or places not so packed with tourist you can't walk, go here, you WON'T regret it!

Wonderful!. This was a great experience! We booked it thinking it was like the lazy river, float through a cave thing but it became quickly apparent it was much more of an active caving tour in a cave where we get to go swimming. I was thrilled but some of my party were claustrophobic and were only pretending to be okay for my sake! We ALL loved it and talked about it all week! Our guide, Pablo, was wonderful and passionate. You could see how inspired he was by the cave and how much he loved his job. It was contagious and our group all bonded and spent the rest of the week hanging out with each other. We all did different tours and this one was not too long, but not so short you felt you weren't getting your money's worth.Because there were four of us who went together we bought the CD with the photos on it. It is a little pricey but we divided it between our group and it was okay. If there had been two of us I'm not sure I would have bought it.This was truly beautiful and I would happily do this again!The only "con" (in quotes because it really barely counts as a con) was the lunch was just mediocre. But you don't go on this sort of thing for the food. VERY happy I got this chance to do the Rio Secreto!

Admirable Stewardship of a Beautiful Resource. This was an amazing experience. We descended into a breathtaking series of underground caverns and viewed remarkable ancient rock formations. I understand this is a fairly recent discovery (2007, according to our guide.) The cave itself is hidden fairly deeply into the Yucatan jungle. Despite the fact that this was only a half-day excursion, it was very involved. The trek from the highway into the jungle site of the cave complex entrance is 20 minutes or so on a fairly rough road. Upon your arrival you are fitted with wetsuit, life jacket, water shoes, helmet and light. Trekking in the cave is lightly physically challenging and the wetsuit does add some degrees of temperature during the dry portions of the trek. The underground journey lasts about 1 hour 20 mins. The last portion is a swim through some of the deeper waters. Our guide, Paco, was knowledgeable and helpful. A great experience; and great to see Mexico's natural wonders being protected through tourism rather than bulldozed.Quick proviso: This excursion is physically challenging, the footing in the cave is uneven, there are small passageways that necessitate bending and fancy footwork. I found myself pretty tired by the end of the tour - I am in my early thirties, but not in fantastic condition, if I'm honest.

Natural Miracle. This was SUPER fun. It was incredibly informative, enjoyable, and gorgeous. I loved learning about it, I loved how precious and preserved the area was, and swimming in the cool, fresh mineral water was exhilarating. We learned so much about the stagmite formation in caves, and we felt as though we got to experience something ancient, precious and untouched. Highly recommend you try this. It was very adaptable and good for any kind of group. We had a few couples, and a family in our group and we all had such a wonderful time. Unforgettable!!!!!

Awesome experience! Face your fear and DO IT!. We will remember this experience forever! In the beginning, I was concerned as I experience a bit of claustrophobia from time to time. Benito was an awesome guide and it wasn't an issue at all! Very informative. Awe inspiring! Always felt safe! Pictures along the way and for once, they were reasonably priced! (Compared to spendy cruise pictures!) Do it. You will be glad you did!

Just do it!. This attraction demonstrates the natural beauty of the area by a memorable and "trip making" 1-2 hour tour through the cenote/cave system. Our family, ages 46 through age 10 loved the visit from start to finish. The cave system is traversed by a combination of walking, and "swimming"-really more like floating in relatively shallow waters. The highlight is swimming (with flotation device on) in shallow water surrounded by stalactites/stalagmites creating a cathedral like effect. Hopefully the tourist industry in Mexico continues to add more natural sites that are as well done as this one-professional and intelligent guides, clean facilities on par with the best similar US facilities and great hospitality. If you want more from your vacation than the classic tourist experience, this is it. Also recommend visiting the Dos Ojos cenote system that is a completely different, but awesome experience combined with snorkeling or diving, depending on preference. The Rio Secreto guide Antonio also deserves a shout out for his knowledge of the cave system, excellent language skills...and, how many times do you get a guide who is an accomplished jazz guitarist who can discuss the finer points of guitar and amp construction? Save room for the free Mayan buffet (excellent quality) afterwards. And yes, you will likely want to pay for the professional photos of you and yours(they are optional) that you will want to help you remember what you did when you were younger and vibrant!

Fantastic!. One of the best places we've ever visited. Water and caves, what could be better!
One of the few places we actually splurged and bought the photos. They are fantastic.

safe advanture. This is the place I will remember forever. If you like adventures, but you do not want to risk; this is the right place for you. The river flows in a magical net of caves and people swim and walk on their way underground. When you get there, there is a team of people who give you everything you need to make your safe return. Even those who can’t swim will find this a great experience. There is a magical world underground and you can feel like in some film looking for a hidden treasure. In fact, the treasure will be around you, on the walls and in the water.

Highly recommend! New attraction 2008!. We thoroughly enjoyed this tour. 1st of all this is so unique. You are underground through the whole tour but not completely submerged. You are required to walk and swim on this tour. There are places that footing is a little difficult so if you have a problem with balance this could be challenging but they do supply walking sticks and everyone is asked to help the person behind them. The stalagmite, stalactite and columns are beautiful. It took nature thousands of years to build this. It is sacred to the Mayans. The water is crystal clear. It is just such a pure place. We are thankful they even share this with the public. It is hard to describe the amazing experience this was. We cannot recommend this highly enough. This ranked EXCELLENT++++++ for us. We are 47 and 43 years old.

A definite "Must-See" - a meaningful & memorable experience. Our family of 4 (2 adults, 11 yr old boy and 8 yr old girl) took this adventure on 2 separate days with 2 different guides and everyone reported back that it "was awesome". I wasn't sure what our kids would think of heading into a cave, but our guides were very knowledgeable and made sure we all had a good time. The kids loved learning about the Mayan culture, the formations, the ecosystem, and eating the Mayan food (Yum!) It is a truly incredible experience! I'd highly recommend putting on your "Bucket List" and we'd definitely go back (they have several areas you can explore, so you can let them know which one you've been in before).It's a great thing to schedule when you either want a break from the heat or the rain. It can get a bit cold, but it's an easy fix with an extra layer - my tiny 8 yr old was fine with a long sleeve rash guard under the wet suit. I did see another reviewer question the eco-consciousness of such an excursion - referring to the merits of allowing many people into a place where the ecosystem is so delicate and must be protected (they require you not wear any lotions/sunscreen/bug spray/jewelry and ask that you do not touch anything). Clearly we need to make efforts to preserve and protect and, admittedly, I thought about the same question. But when you think about it, it is also imperative to educate people and allowing an "experience" is often much more powerful than simply reading about it. I liken it to the many mountain trails and national parks we have in the U.S. Providing places for people to explore and experience the outdoors does make an impact on the environment, but it is evident it is an effective way to inform, educate and hopefully inspire people to help preserve these precious areas. Sure, there is a price: that we provide ("sacrifice") areas/trails where people can go, but the hope is that the benefits outweigh the cost.We had the privilege of meeting one of the owners of Rio Secreto and it was very clear they are passionate about conservation and sustainability. Not only is it affiliated with a non-profit conservation effort, but Rio Secreto has the unique ability to promote conservation and study human impact in a very controlled environment. So, yes there is an impact, but it is intended for the greater good and to have an overall positive effect on the local and broader community, attitude and economy. We and our children left truly impressed by the entire meaningful and memorable experience.

Dangerous --- but interesting. 1/3 of the walk in on the uneven rocky natural floor of the cavern (no problems), 1/3 is swimming (which is great).....but the dangerous 1/3 is wading through murky water where you can not see where to place your feet... and you can not touch anything to help with balance. We were glad to see this cavern in such a raw, pristine, natural state! But, we can not recommend it to anyone that has issues with walking on uneven surfaces (or unseen surfaces!). The best part is definitely the swimming (at the least no worries about footing) -- magnificent views of nature at work. The cavern is not too confining, not claustrophobic.

Worthwhile excursion. Great excursion for the traveler that only wants to spend a half day sightseeing in a small group. The tour picked us up at the hotel, drove us to the property and quickly got us on the tour. Our tour guide, Anthony, really made the trip memorable. He was very knowledgeable about the caves and took time to answer our questions and point out highlights along the way. The other best part of the trip was the small group that we traveled with. We were concerned about going on an excursion with large groups and opted for Rio Secreto because tours were limited to 10 people. It was fun walking and swimming through the cave - something we will never forget. As expected, no cameras were allowed in. Be prepared to spend anywhere from $25 (one photo) to $99 (package of photos and souvenirs) if you want to have evidence of your trip there. They were not pushy at all to buy anything which was refreshing.

AMAZING EXPERIENCE!!!. Giving it a 5 even though the food was not the greatest but the overall experience was AMAZING!!The caves were awesome, our guide was very informative and very helpful to my fiance who was a bit scared in some of the tight places. It was not what I was expecting for an excursion yet so glad we went. They really treat you well. It is well worth it!!!

Enchanting!. While there are lots of cenotes (underground caves) in Yucatan, this is a special one because the tour company works hard to keep their designation as a 100% nature preserve and one of Mexico's leading green expedition companies. We were divided into groups by language, assigned an english-speaking guide who outfitted each of us with a wet suit, life vest, water shoes, hard hat with light and a walking stick. He then led our group of about 10 down into the cave. As we ventured further, we had to be careful to pick our way carefully around stalagmites rising up from the floor and stalagtites hanging from the roof. We were taught to be careful so to not touch them as they are fragile. The walking stick was a great help. At times we were walking on the dry floor of the cave while other times we walked in clear water and towards the end of the 90 minute tour, we had to swim as the water was too deep to walk in. The water temperature was not uncomfortable and our life vests made movement through the water easy. Our guide was fluent in english and very knowledgeable in the geography and geology of the cenote. In all, it was a very unique and enjoyable experience. When we emerged, we were provided with a lunch buffet. While not a highlight of the visit, there was a variety and plenty of food.

What an amazing place!. We visited the Rio Secreto as part of an excursion offered by Holland America during our cruise. When we left our ship, a staff member took our excursion tickets, placed wrist bands on us and ushered us onto a ferry to Playa Del Carmen. Use the rest room on the ferry because there's not another chance before you get to the actual site. When we left the ferry, another staff member walked us to a plaza where she explained the tour and gave us forms to complete. We were divided into groups of 7 to 10 people in each. We then boarded vans and drove to the site. It was a bumpy road through very scraggly jungle, but the driver tried to be gentle. We were given water shoes (you can also bring your own) and lockers and then walked a short distance and received short wet suits, helmets with headlamps and life jackets (they protect from sharp rocks and also provide bouancy). We then walked through the jungle a short distance, received a blessing and then walked into the cave accompanied by our photographer (who stayed totally in the background and was not intrusive at all). . The cave was not colorful--mostly white due to its being composed primarily of calcium) but beautifu and eerie with the soft glow of the headlamps and the reflections of the water. Our guide, Mario, was very informative and helpful and took the time to answer our questions. Occassionally we would encounter another tour group, but only for a few minutes. There was not a lot of climbing but you did need to watch or rather feel your step. When you looked into the water, it seemed you could see where you were going or what you were talking on, but the water made it deceptive. At times we were in water inches deep and other times swimming through water. The water was surprisingly comfortable. My husband can be claustrophobic but had no problems--i believe because you are so involved with what you are seeing and being careful in moving (you don't want to hit the rocks because you don't want to damage them plus they are very sharp) you don't have time to be concerned about being in a tight spaces. The most difficult part was at the end when we had to duck-walk about four steps through a short space. Once exiting the cave, we removed our wet suits and had a buffet lunch (salad, tamales, beans, rice, potatoes, meat sauce, fruit)--we enjoyed it very much. Also had a chance to select photos. We chose to purchase the CD of all our photos for $69. Following that we rode the van back to town, had an hour to shop and then took the ferry back to our cruise ship. We really, really enjoyed this tour and would highly recommend it.

Absolutely unique experience, first choice especially on a cloudy day. Rio Secreto (RS) can be described as nature preserve more accurately than as an attraction. It is a huge, majestic and beautiful cave system , but what is unique about it is the way you visit it. I have been to several caves in US, Russia and Bermuda; very interesting but there you basically stroll like in a museum : electric lights, paved paths, “don’t cross” guardrails. The visit to RS is basically a guided speleological hike : you’ll have to climb, crawl and swim through not yet even completely mapped maze with the help of wet suit, headlamp and a guiding thread. So it gives you not only the incredible beauty (description is impossible) but also a real thrill of adventure and exploration. However there is a small but definite risk of breaking a bone, twisting an ankle, having a panic attack etc, tourists beware. The guides are very knowledgeable and friendly.Some points, tips and advice: - The price , if purchased at your resort, may include a per person transfer fee . If you ask to pay just for tour and no transfer and then just take a taxi to RS you’ll likely save significant time and money. - The tour is not physically exhausting for a healthy person, but probably not for people < 7 or >70’s years old, anyone very overweight, with balance problems, or obviously with fear of darkness, swimming, narrow spaces, bats etc.  - Only things you’ll be allowed, and need, in RS are your swimsuit and eyeglasses (bring eyeglass cord). The rest of your stuff will be locked in a locker, so plan accordingly. - The RS caves have constant temperature regardless of weather, so it makes RS perfect for a cloudy day. But get the tickets early, as everyone will have the same idea. - Photographs and cameras are not allowed in RS (perhaps just as well, otherwise the excited photographers would never leave it). The catch is that a professional photographer will accompany you and at the end of the tour you’ll be offered your ( and cave’s) photos, admittedly of very good quality, on a CD for ~ $70. Of course you’ll buy it. Like it or not, but here it is.  - I am told there are several tour routes at RS, so remember which one you took in a case you want to return again another time and see more.

Great Experience. We loved the Cave experience! I was shocked on how educated our tour guide, Ramón, was. He went above and beyond as a tour guide. The customer service is also great! After returning to the U.S., we decided we wanted the picture package. I emailed the company not knowing if I would be able to purchase or not and they were very helpful in this process. I received my pictures via an online link and was able to download with no problems. Very satisfied...and thrilled to have pictures of the experience!

A great place to think and experience a cave. We went on this tour March 3 and was not disappointed. Short drive from our resort in an air conditionded van. Very wrough road drive into campment. They allocated a locker for each couple or single with key. No jewelery could be worn because it may fall off and be lost forever in the darkness or contaminate the water so just leave it at the hotel. All gear was provided (water shoes (holes and too big), wet suit, helmet with light attached, life jacket) but inquire if you can bring your own water shoes. It was a trip of a life time. Guide was so knowledgeable. Would not recogmend if you have any walking difficulties or back issues as its a mile and a half walk and most in water. All in our group enjoyed the trek. Lunch was included (buffet and picnic tables under enclosure) and change rooms/ washrooms were clean. You could not take any pictures or take a camera into the caves but a photographer came with the group and took pics that were transfered to a dvd for purchase. Well worth the price for everything. I think we would go back again.

Secret River - Rio Secreto - Yucatan Playa del Carmen. A tour of the "Secret River" or "Rio Secreto" was offered as an excursion on our Carnival Cruise. Even though there were 13 of us on the cruise, I was the only person who opted to go to the cave. That's probably a good thing because it was a bit of a physical experience. The drive from the dock to the Secret River entrance was quite rough - about 20 minutes of very bumpy dirt road. But once you get there, everything else is a delight. You have to strip down to a swim suit, take a quick shower, and change into a wet suit which they provide. They also provide water shoes if you need them (I brought my own). I was also given a locker to store my stuff. All of this was included in the excursion price, so no extra hassles. Our guide was Alfredo and was very helpful and gracious. In fact, everyone on the site seemed very helpful and glad to assist. After some brief instructions, our tour guide and my group of about 8 people walked down a trail to the cave. We stopped for a brief 'prayer' by a Mayan guy. That was kind of strange, but it kind of added to the whole spiritual vibe of the place. Then down into the cave. During my visit, the temperature outside was in the 70's which is the same as the cave. Our guide explained it remains about 74 in the cave at all times. So there wasn't much temperature change for us, but I can imagine on a hot day in the Yucatan it would feel good to step into 74 degrees. The terrain is fairly easy to navigate, but there are plenty of places to stub a toe or perhaps slide on a sloping surface. There's lots of interesting rooms the guide led us through, and plenty of stalagtites and stalagmites to view. The best part, though, is getting to slip into the clear water and swim along through an underground creek. Some of the areas are only knee deep, but in other areas your feet won't touch the bottom. The water was a little chilly at first, but it didn't take long at all to get used to it and just peacefully float along. At one point, everyone turns off all their lights (oh, I forgot to mention the only lighting in the cave is on each person's helmet). The guide asked everyone to stop speaking for about 60 seconds. It was totally dark and completely guide. Very surreal experience. At the end, we exit the cave and change back into our clothes. The guide even gave each of us a shot of tequila. :)I've been in several commercialized caves, and this was definitely was one of the most organized. The staff was friendly and our guide was very passionate and engaged. He seemed to actually enjoy sharing the cave with us and teaching everything he knew. The lockers and change facility were nothing fancy, but clean and had sort of a camp ground feel to it. It was fine with me, but I suppose some more picky people might not like it. Overall, this was worth the time and money. I only give it a 4 out of 5 because of the road getting to the cave was very bumpy. It made me feel slightly car sick by the time we arrived.

awesome experience. This was an educational treat. Being 100 feet below the surface, in a 100% clear river. Floating, and then getting to experience complete darkness and completely sound free.And as I stated, learning along the way.Our tour guide Eduardo was enthralled with what he was doing, and passed that to the group. Our tour took 1.5 hours, and the comment among the group was it felt like 1/2 hour.Recommend to everyone.

Amazing underground tour. If you're looking to tour a Cenote and get your money's worth, visit the Rio Secreto. The guides are incredibly knowledgable (Alfredo is awesome and makes an underground dungeon fascinating and fun), the tour feels like your charting unexplored caverns for the first time. Its a great mix of exploration, swimming and tranquility. They even set you up with a local cuisine feast afterward.

If you only do one thing, do this!. Get your own car at least for the day so you can experience this and get further south before or after your tour. If you rent from the Budget in Playa del Carmen you will get a buy one, get one free entry to this place! We ended up buying all the photos and Xtabentun and t-shirt package (well worth it). These are *real* caves with spectacular clarity and no crowding unlike the amusement park places across the road.

Amazing and fun. Excellent half day tour of a cenote, which is beautiful. The guides are excellent. The cenote is a one of kind experience. The lunch afterward is very good. Be prepared to know that the road in is a bumpy backwoods ride. Well worth the trip.

Great Experience. This was an excellent excursion. The guides are very knowledgeable, and the cave experience is something not found anywhere else in the world. However, the professional photographers pictures (which is the only option for pictures) weren't great and very over priced.

Definitely an excursion worth taking. If you are staying at a Riviera Maya hotel, or thereabouts, this is definitely an excusion worth taking. It was advertised as a 1/2 day excursion, though it was only a 35 minute ride form the hotel. You are actually underground for a bout 1.5 hours. You are given wet suits and water shoes upon arrival. Before donning the wetsuits, you head for the outdoor shower (let's just say that was not the warmest shower I have ever taken!!). After putting on the wetsuit and water shoes, you are given a hard hat with a headlamp and it is off through the jungle to the entrance to the River. I am glad we did this trip first thing in the a.m.. I can imagine it would get quite warm walking in all that paraphernalia in the hot sun! I am guessing the path was between 0.5 and 1 mile long. Antonio was an informative and helpful guide. They break the tour groups up by language, so you are sure to understand all the information that is being shared. I have to admit, this took a little more energy than I thought it would. Walking sticks are available at the beginning of the tour - I am in my 50's and fit enough, but I think even I could have benefitted from the walking stick at some points, just to get a feel for where things were on the bottom of the river. It wasn't strenuous, but it was challenging in a few spots. But everyone helped each other out, so everything worked out well. The bottom of the river is rocky, with dips and boulders. In most spots you can walk upright, but in a few places you do have to scooch down to get through. You have a life jacket, so in the parts where it is deeper, you can just float along. This was definitely quite the experience. To actually see the minute water drops on the ends of the stalactites and to fully understand what a process goes into the making of this spectacular place makes this excursion a llittel different than some others that involve underground rivers.. You can see the tiniest of crystals and layers of minerals that make up the stalactites. In the final moments, when every turned off their lamps and we were simply floating in the pitch dark, it was the most phenomenal experience - you could hear the tiniest drips and trickles of the water. It certainly gives you a fuller appreciation of the environment that makes up the Yucatan Peninsula. This is an educational but fun excursion - I think it could be enjoyed by folks of all ages. The meal at the end was a bit disappointing - there was a soup and salad, tamales and empanadas. It was all ok, but that is about it.

Once in a lifetime. Once in a lifetime this is the type of tours people should go on. Lots to see lots to do. Something that can't be see anywhere else. They could however spend a few $$ on the road to the site. It shook the hell out of my back.

family excursion. This was amazing. The guides were super knowledgable and the disk of pictures was certainly worth it. They incude pictures from a professional photographer and they are amazing. never seen anything like this. worth it! awe inspiring.

Sacred underground...simply beautiful. While vacationing on the Riviera Maya we decided to do one excursion which was Rio Secreto. I cannot put into words how amazed and how beautiful this experience was. Our group of 9 were lead by a very informed tour guide, Mauricio. He took his time to reply to questions that were asked, never rushing. What normally took about 1 hr took us almost 2hrs. It is amazing what you can see below. The water temperature was very nice. Walking around with a wet suit gets quite hot at times so it was nice to be in the water once in a while. At the end you do get to try a typical Mayan meal which was ok. Let's not forget the nice shot of Maya Tequila that was also served upon leaving the Cenote.I would definitely recommend this excursion. It's amazing what this Earth is made of.Myself, I have a bad knee but I was determined to do this. Sore the next day but it was definitely worth it.

Incedible Tour!. When my wife and I went to the Riviera Maya, we went to relax and take in a couple of Half day trips(didn't want to waste a full day on those "Cheesie Tours"). This is a trip that could be a full day trip and I would go back for a second day!! The guides were well informed and because they keep the tour groups small, the interaction is great. The only minor complaint would be the cost of the items after(shirts, pictures, etc.) However they don't push it on you.

life changing. this is a must see trip. You will never see anything like this in any other place. I travel a lot to warm locations and take many excursions. This one will make you speechless. Alfreado was a fabulous guide and was extremely informative and passionate about his job. This attraction is doing a wonderful job in protecting this natural resource to make sure it can be shared with our future generations. The beauty of this trip will be a memory forever. I would not recommend this trip for anyone who has difficulty walking or is afraid of the dark. You need to have good balance for walking through the cave.

Add this place to your travel Bucket List!. My husband spotted this excursion on the list of choices offered by our Air Transat rep and, wow, are we ever glad he did. We were travelling with another couple and all of us agreed that this was one of the best excursions we've ever been on.The van ride was around 30 minutes from our Gran Bahia Principe resort to the front lobby area near the road. We filled out waiver forms here and watched a short video presentation about the cave system before taking the 20 minute, bumpy ride through the jungle to get to the main area where we geared up.Every couple is given use of locker to safely store any stuff we brought with us which was great and there are big change areas with individual locked stalls to change into and out of bathing suits.Our guide was Antonio, a very friendly and knowledgeable well-spoken young man. I learned a lot about the local underwater river systems and the rock formations inside the caves. He didn't rush us through the 700 metre hike through the river and answered all of questions. I liked that we were a nice small group, there were only 8 of us in total in our English tour. There were 4 others in our van as well but they all went on the French speaking tour in a different part of the river so we didn't see them until the lunch buffet after. Antonio said that there were actually 3 different treks we could take that this company offered. Our favourite part was when we stopped in a large cave and he had all of our group turn off our headlamps and just listen quietly in the dark to the soothing dripping of the water building more stalagtites and stalagmites. It was so peaceful.We were also disappointed that we couldn't take our cameras but were happy to buy the official photographer's pictures despite the costly price. They are no doubt using the funds to preserve this beautiful area for future generations to enjoy. You can buy just one picture for $25 or all of the ones the photographer took of you and your travelling companion specifically plus some extra scenic photos for $69.As other reviewers have mentioned, the buffet lunch after the hike was delicious. They offered free water and lemonade or you could buy pop or beer. Beer was $3 each.This is a fantastic place and I highly recommend trying this experience.

An amazing experience in a sacred place. Mayans considered cenotes and caves to be the link to the under world and being in this cave lets you experience why. This cave goes on for kilometers, the tour is 1.5 hours and it's only a 10% of the cave. It was amazing seeing the beautiful stalactites and stalagmites that have been forming here for thousands of years. The only negative was our guide, his English was really bad and although he really tried to be helpful he struggled to give us very basic information about the cave. I felt my experience would have been a lot more meaningful if he had been able to give us all the information there was to know about this amazing place.

Secret River excursion via cruise ship. My daughter and I visited on a cruise ship excursion and this is an amazing place to see. It is a newer discovery and is not your typical tourist trap cavern trip like many in the US. We had an awesome guide and very informative about so many things we got to see in the cave. We got lucky and saw a couple fruit bats flying around which normally are asleep and are really cool unlike the bats in the US they dont swoop at you and keep their distance and were really cool. We also saw some fish and very small shrimp the guide pointed out or we would have missed them. the water was really nice and was so relaxing in the places you can float the wetsuits and life jackets made it really nice and the light on the helmet made it easy to see anywhere you looked. My only complaint was not being able to take my underwater camera and the pics the photographer took were of people on the tour while we were in the cave. I would much rather have taken some pics of the sights we saw instead. I would suggest they at least allow people to take their own cams and pay a fee to do so. After the tour we were fed a really awesome lunch with authentic cooking that you wont find in a Mexican restaurant. It was all homemade and just awesome. I would recommend this trip if you want to do something that isnt a typical tourist trap.

nothing artificial on this explor. We were seeking complete authenticity when choosing our tours....this is the real deal..no artificial lighting along the way . Our head lamps were the only lighting with the exceptional lighting for a photo..one too many times for my liking but i understand it helps fund the continued exploration of the caves. I opted for a wet suit and walking stick , 3 out ten opted for them , i was happy i did. Our guide was superb,(recently moved from Mexico city and decided to stay) knowledgeable, patient, and interested. 16 and up i believe can really appreciate the magnificence of this place only discovered 7 years ago. ago...wow.

I didn't think it was that great. My wife and I went to Rio Secreto today and were not blown away as it seems everyone else is. They provide everything you need to go through the cave; water shoes, wetsuit, and helmet (which is necessary as you will hit your head sooner or later.) The sights were great and it was an interesting experience to be sure. As my wife said, she now appreciates the movies featuring dark caves like Sanctum and The Descent much more after being here. What we didn't like: while the paths you are walking have been used before, I don't understand why we are walking over stalagmite or stalagtites. If there isn't a good path, don't use it. If the goal is to preserve this place for the future, I don't see how people breaking the formations helps by either stepping on them or breaking them off w their helmets. Second, if we are already destroying parts of the system, why not put in a few handrails? That would probably save prevent more damage rather than people having to grab on to the nearest formation in order to prevent them falling. Felt rushed throughout the tour. Little time to enjoy the beauty we are in as the tour kept moving. I wish there was an extended version as this one was too fast. Also, the buffet at the end is nothing to look forward to. I know I didn't list the positives much but that is because I am sure you see the rest of the gushing reviews so I don't need to add to that.

Amazing!. On our recent trip to Riviera Maya, we each chose one excursion. Rio Secreto was my choice and it far exceeded my expectations. Not kitschy or overly commercialized. How awesome is it to spend 1.5 hours in a cave in the water? THIS AWESOME. Also, major shout-out to our guide, Rodgrigo. Rodrigo is incredibly passionate about the mission of the preserve and saving the natural wonders of the area. He's also not hard on the eyes ;) Best. Excursion. Ever.

Perfect outing on a windy day. We asked the concierge at our resort what to do on a windy day and he suggested Rio Secreto, an underground river tour in a cave system, just a short cab ride away. After arriving we watched a short video, then got a wetsuit, water shoes and hardhat with a lamp. A van took our group (limited to no more than 10) about 7km into the jungle on unpaved roads. From there we walked about 10 minutes more to the cave entrance. In the cave a guide pointed out and described geological formations and cultural details, while a photographer took pics. Our guide was very interesting and informative. The trip involved walking through water on uneven footing and some swimming. Walking sticks were available and would be recommended. We were underground for 1-1/2 hours and traveled just over a 1/2 mile. The tour itself was a good value, although the picture/souvenir packages were quite limited and a bit pricey.

A beautiful natural wonder. It was pouring rain that day so we decided to go on a cave tour. Rio Secreto is a beautiful natural cave. After watching a short video relating how the cave was found, you were assigned in groups to a tour guide. We were introduced to Rodrigo, who is very enthusiastic about the cave. You are assigned a locker and change into your bathing suit. They supply beach shoes, wetsuit, life jacket and helmet with light. After a Mayan blessing, you follow your guide and enter the cave, at times, wading throogh water, climbing a bit (the grouind is uneven at times) or swimming. The water was very clear (you could see small catfish) and cool, but not overly so. There were bats sleeping in the ceiling of the cave amongst stalactites and stalagmites. There was another guide who took pictures which you could purchase at the tour's end.At the end of the tour and after changing, we enjoyed our Mayan lunch. We really enjoyed this tour. Rodrigo was very knowledgeable and passed on his enthusiasm for the cave.

Do NOT miss this wonder of nature!. We booked our tickets to Rio secreto after reading about it on the riviera maya forums, and seeing it was highly recommended. I booked the tickets directly through their official website without any issues (Violeta was very helpful with all my questions!) and even received free pickup because we took part in a promotion they were offering. The location was about 10 min away from our resort, Reef Playacar. Once there, there's another 10-15 min drive on a VERY rocky jungle road to get to the start point for the excursion. Lemme tell you, this cave is a wonder of nature and I wouldn't hesitate to say it's one of the most beautiful sites I have EVER visited in my life. It's very dark and you have to go in and out of water inside the cave (be wary of rock formations inside the water, which the guide warns you about all along the way), so it isn't recommended for claustrophobic people, pregnant women, and I would also say young children. Our guide, Fransesca was so knowledgeable about the cave and every formation in there, it was great to here her talk about it. The cave is a completly surreal experience which I cannot recommend enough to anyone going to Riviera Maya. You cannot take pictures inside the cave, but you have a professional photgraph following you all along the way to take way better pictures than any of us could have taken anyhow. They sell you the CD of pictures at the end if you wish, its a bit expensive but completly worth it for a souvenir of this once-in-a-lifetime experience. There is also a nice outdoor meal offered at the end of the excursion (mini-buffet), the food was very good. All in all, we must have spent about 3 hours there in total, perfect for a mid-day excursions. Do NOT miss this place!!!

history, adventure, and fun!. The amazing secret river tour we just completed was a pleasant surprise...Not only was the cave walk, swim, and float a great fun adventure, it was guided with care and knowledge. They care for the environment and its preservation while still being able to provide a full immersion experience of traveling underground thru a wonderful cave river...You'll learn about the history, ecology, and science of caves.
