We finished with an interesting but not great mayan lunch and a brief respite in the hammocks under the incredible gardens.If you are in Cozumel or Playa del Carmen make time for this one!
GREAT!. The tour was wonderful and beautiful. The lunch offered was nothing spectacular. You'll enjoy going through the cave!

Fairly new cave discovery - 2006!. The tour of Rio Secreto was one choice of excursions through our Royal Caribbean Cruise. I am really glad we chose this one! The staff was very informative and helpful, and the cave something to experience. One of our group of 12 could not swim and they were extra careful with her and made her feel safe the whole time. Part of the time you are in water up to your neck. We enjoy caves and try to make a point of seeing them wherever we go, so this was right up our alley. I was glad a chose to wear a wetsuit - they give you the option. Also, the photographer that accompanies the tour was top notch ( you can't bring your own camera in). We have a great shot of us in "the Dragon's Mouth". If you like caves - got to Rio Secreto!

Amazing experience!. Rio Secreto was fantastic. Our tour guide Rodrigo was very knowledgable and was passionate about his work. We took the "supreme" tour route. We saw small catfish, bats, thousands of stalactites and stalagmites, and clear waters. The tour was a good length and picture prices were reasonable, especially since half of all proceeds help prevent all the caves from being destroyed for commercial building. If you want an amusement park then don't come to Rio Secreto. It is a quaint and natural experience. Also, the homemade buffet afterwards was better than some of the food at our 5-star resort. We recommend it and would return.

Unforgettable Experience. My fiance and I went to Rio Secreto, both a little nervous (I only swim a little, he doesn't at all and isn't that comfortable floating even). In the end, we both loved the tour.Keep in mind there are multiple routes a tour group can take in the cave, which may explain why the reviews differ. Our group went on the Allegria path - which, about halfway through, was nearly constant swimming or at least water up to our waist. Our tour guide, Paco, was very patient and concerned about each of the people in the tour - one woman was terrified, and Paco guided her next to him the whole time, and allowed her to hold on to his shoulders during the swimming portion. This isn't the place for someone who has trouble walking, that's for sure. The footing can be slippery, some of the corners and areas are difficult to maneuver. You can't touch the walls or hold on to anything (above water), because the oils of the skin will destroy the stalactite and stalagmite formations, so group members are encouraged to help each other out - giving a hand when stepping up or down, giving warnings of tricky areas and how to get through them. They do offer walking sticks as well, to help out.Yes, you definitely spend a lot of time looking down (to be careful). But you're not so rushed through the cave that you can't pause and look around you, too, to enjoy the amazing cave. The water on our path was not murky at all - beautiful turquoise color, when the light hit it. Not as cold as I was expecting either (the caves themselves were quite warm, and wetsuits are provided, along with water shoes). They also provide a buffet meal at the end. The only downside, to me, was the lack of options and price for the photo packages at the end. $25 for one photo, $69 for all, and $99 for a pack that included a few souvenirs in addition to the photos. Because you aren't allowed any cameras in the cave, if you want a memento you're forced to pay the price. I felt the tour was reasonably priced though, and since the photos were very well done, I "caved" and purchased.

Ok but not what we expected. Been in a few caves before. This one was nice but very difficult to see submerged footing making it dangerous if you tripped on the skin shredding formations. Spent more time looking down than at the overhead formations. The floating in the "river" was very short. Mostly wading in ankle deep murky water. Admission cost and photo prices too much for what you get. They give you the line that it goes towards conservation. Food was not great. We were the last tour of the day so it was probably sitting out for a while. They abandoned us in the parking lot at the end of the day. We asked where we could get a taxi but got a shoulder shrug as they all scurried away like cockroaches. Had to cross a very dangerous hi way with 2 children and eventually flag down a taxi. Thanks to the nice taxi driver who took pity on us. Bottom line go to xplor instead. Caves there nicer and much more for your money.

It shouldn't be a secret!. Amazing underground river that we followed for .7 km. The entire river system is about 30 km long. The guide (Julio) was great. They give you wet suits and water shoes. Be prepared for a bit of swimming as well. Beautiful caverns filled with stalagmites and stalactites . It was well worth the money, for such a unique experience.

Wish our friends could have been there. What a fantastic experience. We are both over 65. We have been on many cruises and shore excursions. This is the #2 best excursion we have ever been on. The only one better than this was an Alaska whale watching excursion where we were surrounded by hump-back whales. Our guide was very nice and took my wife by the hand the whole way and made sure she was safe. We would do this excursion again without hesitation. Bring cash so that you can buy the photos. lunch was included.

Wish it was longer. It was fantastic swimming in the caves. The only thing I wish was that it would have been longer.. I would have gladly payed a little more to be able to explore more inside the caves....

Excelente !!!. An experience I'll never forget. It is definitely the excursion of a life time. Marisio was our guide and he was just full of passion about the cave and his expertise made it fun and educational for our small group of 6. From the moment we entered the cave until the end he took my wife by the hand and made sure of her safety. This of course made me relax just knowing she was taken care of throughout the tour. THANKS Marisio your the best!!!
great adventure. excellent - a break from the sun - my 13 year old loved it, and so did I. The entire family can participate - you'll spend the entire time in the water - fun, fun, fun

Rio Secreto team redo brochure it doesn't do you justice. Everyone this is a must see. Forget the brochure my wife didn't want to go after viewing the brochure but we went and now it was one of her favorite tours in Mexico we had Celine (hope I spelled it correctly from Switzerland) and she was fantastic. Caves were great, information was awesome and she spend time with everyone in the group

Beautiful, spiritual, must-do. Seriously, this is a must-do excursion. Forget the other excursions and do this one... it is truly the experience of a lifetime. We were divided into small groups and assigned guides. There were seven in our group, plus the guide. We were issued all necessary equipment for the tour, and lockers for our personal belongings. From the time that we met our guide, Rodrigo, he began to explain the many different levels of significance these caves have. Before we entered the caves, we joined in a short prayer and blessing. We were thoroughly impressed with not only Rodrigo's knowledge, but his passion for this river. There are no words to accurately describe the magnificence of this experience. From the pristine water to the beautiful formations, to the all of the inhabitants of the area, the impact is absolutely dumbfounding. The experience includes walking a short path through a wooded area, up and down some steep stairs, over some very uneven terrain that may or may not be under water. Sometimes you might be wading in water at heights from your ankles to your waist, and sometimes you may be swimming. (Swimming is not the proper description. You are floating and paddling with your arms.) A home made lunch was provided for us after the tour, which was absolutely delicious. The staff took some pictures of our group, which were then put on a CD that included pictures of some of the things that live in and around the area. Their souvenir packages were a good value, and if you buy the photos, the money goes into preserving the cavern (including the portion that is off limits). The advertisements and recommendations suggest that physical limitations might prevent you from being able to participate in this tour. I would take them into consideration before booking, but if you are an active person, you should have no problems. Our group included a plus-sized woman (230 pounds & 5'4"), a single middle aged man, and 60 year old woman with an obvious neck or back problem Everyone in our group was able to master the challenges. Everyone in your group will need a hand at different times, and part of the fun is working together. Our guide told us that he has taken people as old as 89 years of age, and we saw families with young children (they looked to be around 5 or 7 years of age). The bottom of the cavern is not slippery, as there is no algae. Without headlights (which are provided) the cavern is in COMPLETE darkness. To quote our guide "walk with confidence".We found this tour as an excursion on a cruise. After the tour, we had almost an hour until the ferry back to Cozumel, and as soon as we walked up the gangway, the ship pushed off from the dock, so this excursion takes the entire day. Also, Rio Secreto provides towels for you, so you don't need to bring the ship's towels, unless you would like to swim on the beach during that last hour before you catch the ferry.

Great attraction , one of the most magicial places i have ever been!!!!!. one of the coolest places ive been, i did have a bit of an issue, but dont let that discourage you from going on this tour. when we got our life jackets there were ants on it and i got bit, not the big deal yet, we went throught the cave which i beleive to be the most magical place on earth. i loved it down there... when we came above ground we were handed towels to dry off and that when i felt my hand burn, i thought it was those damn ants again but it was a scorpion i got stung... i was a little worried but stayed calm and Alfrado our guide what very quick to go get the plunger thing to suck the venom out. hand and arm went numb but i was fine... and since i'm not dead i thought i would share this experience with you all... i would love to go back to this place... it was awesome and i have a great story to tell my buddys...

Fantastic Afternoon. Our group put on our wet suits, helmets & lights and ventured down into the under ground river system with our guide Raul. He was a wealth of knowledge. These amazing caves were like nothing I have every seen before. Learning about some Mayan history and the importance of this sacred underground water was very cool. We saw some cool creatures that live their entire lives under ground. Many were albino!Raul truely loved his job and expressed that with great enthusiasm. It was a treat to be in his group.The only part I did not like was the hard sell on the photos they took of you in the caves. Great pics, poor hard sell. The meal we enjoyed at the end was also great. Loved the lime soup.An experience I will never forget.

Awesome Adventure!. I would highly recommend this excursion! Upon arrival, we watched a short video giving a brief summary of the cave and the importance of conservation. Then we took a 7km bus ride (VERY BUMPY--not a paved road) closer to the opening of the cave. We were assigned lockers to secure our valuables. They do not allow anything except your swimsuit and glasses (if necessary) to ensure that nothing is lost in the cave. I was concerned about photographs, but there is a photographer who accompanies you on the trip. You rinse off in showers to wash all chemicals off your body as this may harm the cave's formations. Then you suit up: wet suit, life jacket, water shoes and a helmet equipped with a light. You take a quick 5 minute walk to the cave entrance. Our tour guide Francesca was very knowledgeable and took time with all individuals on the tour. She was fluent in english and all of the details about the history of the cave and the scientific names of the formations. I liked that we had a small group -- only 8 people so we got to ask many questions, etc. The tour was AWESOME.... very neat inside, dark and quiet, like a whole new world. There were parts where you walk and others where you swim/float through. After the trip through the cave, we had a traditional mexican lunch. The food was very good and included lime soup, empanadas, rice and salad.The only negative was the photos. You could not bring your own camera and they charged $25 for just ONE photo! There were a few packages you could purchase as well but they ranged between $70 to $100. I did not bring enough money and was disappointed the price was so high.

A great experience. This is a wonderful wonder to see. It is truly beautiful inside. Our guide spoke wonderful english and he was very patient with everyone. He was not in a hurry and we took our time getting through the cave. He was very concerned with our well-being the entire length of the tour. Our group was a mixture of people ranging from early 30's to late 50's and no one had difficulty with any of the tour. Some of us were tall and some shorter. This tour is for anyone of all sizes. The guides are well trained. We donned water shoes, wet suites and a miners helmet equipped with a light. Length of tour underground was well over an hour. The stalactites and stalagmites were beautiful to see with one's own eyes. The colours were spectacular. Saw some bats, catfish, and a blind spider. If you'd like to see this, you won't be disappointed!

Amazing-Not to be Missed!. We chose this excursion on our recent Disney Fantasy cruise and would highly recommend it. Our guide, Jovanna, was excellent. The organization of the entire tour was impressive, from having a representative accompany the group from the cruise ship, to the provision of the equipment (wet suit, life jacket, water shoes, helmet with head lamp), to the Mexican lunch served after the tour. The caves themselves were spectacular and not too difficult to maneuver, even with children. The area of the cave we were in was so large, there was never a feeling of being in an enclosed space. The portion of the cave that we swam/floated at the end was amazing. You cannot bring a camera as you spend your time watching your footing but they have a photographer follow your group and take pictures throughout. The pictures came out amazing and the CD was reasonably priced.The 90 minutes we spent underground at Rio Secreto were a once in a lifetime experience that we would urge anyone traveling in this part of Mexico, not to miss out on!

AWESOME. This was one of the best excursions I have been on. Our guide Joan, was great, informative, safe and very thoughtful. I did not find this at all claustrophobic, it was dark in some places, but I felt totally safe. Our group was only about 12 people so it was a nice size. I would recommend this excursion.

Enjoyed it, but more strenuous than anticipated. We went to a few cenotes... they all seem to have entrances off the road and then a long dirt road to the back. This was no exception. The walking was more difficult than we anticipated, and more difficult than othere cenotes we visited - even with the provided walking staff. I fell and was bruised a few times.Still, it's very nice, staff is attentive and professional, and the cenote is stunning.beware of the following: There are absolutely no refunds, even if you can't make it, even if you can't fit into the wet suit (which you CAN manage without). A meal is provided, even if you can't or don't eat (we couldn't), AND you have to wait for the rest of your group to finish before you can return to civilization.Tipping is appreciated - we did, but many did not.

An amazing adventure, even for someone with physical limitations!. My boyfriend and I had a great time at Rio Secreto. I was very nervous about being able to keep up with the group, as I have a previous spinal fracture and nerve damage in one of my legs. But I REALLY wanted to do this, even if it made me limp the next day. I need not have worried. Our guide, Alanis, put me in the front of the group so I could set the pace. The lady right behind me had bad knees, and she was grateful not to be the most disabled person in the group! The walking sticks that they offered at the beginning of the tour were EXTREMELY helpful, as was our sweet guide. He took my hand at every difficult place and guided me through. It was a wonderful experience. The caves are beautiful. The water was cool and refreshing and gave me a chance to float for a while instead of having to walk the whole way. The lunch at the end was an EXCELLENT buffet. Buy the picture CD! Yes, it's a little expensive- but the shots were great and very personal. How can you resist? Are you ever going to come back? Probably not. So, you must have the pictures! And the money goes to support this important place on Earth that they are preserving. Oh! One more thing, English is spoken by almost everyone there. So, yay!

Amazing Experience. We did the Secret River as an excursion as part of the Disney Fantasy cruise and had a blast. I would even go as far to say it was a once in a lifetime experience. Unfortunately, I can’t remember our guide’s name but he did an outstanding job, was very knowledgeable and you could tell he had a passion for what he was doing.The boat ride from Cozumel was about 30-40 minutes and was very choppy that day (a lot of people got sick on the ferry, to the point where the inside cabin started to smell quite awful). It was about a 40 minute ride from Playa del Carmen to their facility (20 on the roads and 20 on a dirt road through the jungle). Once we arrived, we were given lockers to store our stuff and then outfitted with a wetsuit, helmet and water shoes. The walking stick is optional but a few of us took it and it came in handy. We were in the caves for about 90 minutes. There were other groups going into the caves at the same time but there are different routes so we never saw or heard anyone else. Once we exited the caves, we turned in our gear, changed, and ate lunch, which left a little to be desired but the lunch wasn’t why we signed up for the excursion so no big deal.By the way, there is a point while in the caves where you will turn off all lights and be absolutely quiet… what a neat experience!!

Peaceful and serene beauty. The adventure is not for the faint of heart. It is a long walk into an amazing underground river system and cenote. The caves are breathtakingly filled with selagmites and delicate selagtites of varying shapes. A sight not to be missed.

AMAZING SECRET RIVER LIVES UP TO ITS NAME!. We took this tour as a shore excursion from the Carnival Legend. Being claustrophobic, it was a little outside my comfort zone, but I am SO glad I did it. Ferry ride was approximately 30-45 minutes, then a short but VERY bumpy ride to the Rio Secreto. With swimsuits on, we were asked to shower under outside showers to wash away any lotions or body oils -- COLD!!! Then we donned wetsuits and helmets with lights. TIP: They offer you a walking stick -- take it!! Makes keeping your balance on the uneven ground and in the water MUCH easier. Then there was a short Mayan "cleansing ceremony" and we entered the caves. It was so totally incredible that any fears I had about feeling claustrophobic immediately evaporated. Our guide was amazing and helped us to fully appreciate how incredible this natural phenomenon truly is. Water is chilly, but not really cold, and is incredibly crystal clear. Part of the time is on dry ground, part is in shallow water and a couple of times in deeper. No need to be a good swimmer. If you can dog paddle, you'll be fine. There were some tight places and some climbing was involved, but if you're in reasonably good physical shape, again, you should be fine. When the guide asked us to turn out our lights, it was truly an incredible experience -- almost spiritual -- so much so that one of the members of our party asked that we do it again. Another nice thing is that there were only 6 members in the group and we only saw one other group the whole time. Stayed in the caves about an hour and a half. Then were treated to a "snack", which was actually more of a lunch. Chicken lime soup, empanadas, rice, beans and a couple of other things. I have been blessed to see and do some incredible things in my life, including hot air ballooning in Africa, dog sledding in Alaska and riding donkeys down a mountain in Greece -- Rio Secreto definitely ranks right up there in the top ten coolest things I've ever done. Would do it again in a heartbeat, and hope to be able to one day. Don't miss out on this!NOTE: You are not allowed to take cameras. I read where a couple of people fussed about this. Trust me, there's NO way you could take photos yourself. They have a photographer and we purchased the package of pictures -- 30 for $69. Worth every penny -- they were beautiful!

An amazing adventure!!!!. Booked his excursion not knowing what to expect and concerned about some of my mobility issues. The guides and staff were amazing and so accommodating!!! Our guide, Rodrigo, was spectacular. He had some of the most interesting and informative facts and was wonderfully funny and personable! He was very helpful when I was having a bit of trouble. The light lunch at the end of the trip was excellent!!! A beautiful spot, very well cared for and preserved. Would love to go again and take my kids!!

Attraction Número UNO. Although Playa del Carmen is an excellent place with its European feel, I decided to leave my family for a day and try Rio Secreto. What a great experience! A walk through the jungle, blessed by a Mayan Priest near a makeshift alter, descending into a cave to walk, float and swim in an underground world. I doubt this could happen in the US because of insurance restrictions; it's not easy at times, a little tight in places, but over all spectacular. You would think because of all the signage on the highway and advertising that it would be a tourist trap-- not at all. An experience like no other, natural, informative, and worth every penny. (Yes the CD is overpriced but I felt it was still worth it.)

Fantastic tour of underground river & cave. Totally enjoyed this hike/swim/float through the underground river cenote Rio Secreto. The photographer that goes along with the group takes fantastic pictures. You won't regret buying them all, as they are worth every penny!

A wonderful experience...till I got home1!. This is a must do tour but the only downfall is when I got home and went to show my friends and family my pictures that I paid $99 for I found NOTHING...$99 for a cd and not one single picture of my husband and I, nothing to show for it. VERY DISAPPOINTING!! I recommend you save yourself the $99 and don't let yourself get ripped off like we did, to pay $200 for the tour plus an additional $99 for a cd is a complete scam!! Ruined my trip to find that out!! I would post a photo but I DON'T HAVE ANY!!

DON'T ORDER THE PICTURES. Not sure where to start, we went on the tour Feb 2/13 and the tour itself was amazing and was an experience of a lifetime but I am not so happy that I paid $99 for a picture cd which they showed me the pictures of my husband and I and when i got home to my suprise there was not one single picture of us, all the good pics of the cave..not one on there. I recommend you save yourself $99 and don't order the pictures, I was very disappointed that we couldn't bring our own cameras in there and they charge you to order theirs and don't even give the pictures you ordered...not impressed at all to say in the least. I am rating this a two because the whole no pictures completely ruined it for me and I have nothing to show of the experience. I would post pictures but I DONT HAVE ANY. What a waste!!!

Fabulous Underwater Cavern System. It was a very educational experience to go through the caves and learn about them as well as how the formations were made. This was fairly recently discovered so the caves have not been spoiled. The guide did a very nice job of pointing out the different formations and answering questions. There was not as much swimming or floating as we had expected, much more walking along the paths and wading through the water. Be careful while wading as there are many formations under the water to bump toes and knees on! There were many photo opportunities and very nice pictures to select from at the end. The full package with 2 shirts, a hat and a disc with the pictures was almost $100 US dollars.....a bit steep but the other option was a per picture price of $25. There was an authentic Mexicanmeal at the end of the tour with delicious soup and a variety of other foods along with water or hibicus water. It would have been nice to have more fruit options, otherwise was quite good!

Terrific Cave experience. I have enjoyed exploring caves here in the States, Jamaica and especially in France where I have floated in Padirac and explored many of the painted caves along the Dordogne and Lot rivers. This cave was especially beautiful for both the natural formations and the care given by our guide Alfredo. He has extensive knowledge of the caves and made the trip a delight. Swimming in the cave was a rare treat I can recommend with out hesitation.

A Must Do Cennote experience. There are many cennotes in the Playa del Carmen area, but Rio Secreto provides the opportunity to walk through and swim in an underground cennote.This cennote was only found in 2005, and it is in pristine condition. They only use about 10% of the whole length of this cennote, in order to protect the rest of this cennote system. The Rio Secreto is a dedicated cennote experience (which is what we were looking for), rather than being part of a larger theme style park.The formations are just break-taking throughout the length of the cennote, as are the colours within the cennote. A guide takes you through the cennote in small groups (they divided 12 people into two groups when we were there). The walking inside the cennote is easy, you just need to watch your step, but will provide you with a walking pole if you think you need better balance. The water temperature remains around 25 degree C all year, but you have wetsuits as well.You are not allowed to use your own camera - as this would disrupt the tour for the rest of your group, destroy the overall experience, and slow down the group. A photographer follows you through, and they provide excellent photos of your experience if you wish to buy them.Our guide was extremely friendly, knowledgeable, caring, and above all made you feel very safe. The tour price includes a buffet of local food at the end of the experience.They will do pick ups from your hotel (at an extra cost), but we choose to drive there ourselves and it was very easy to find, just south of Playa del Carmen on the main freeway.

Fantastic experience!!. The entire excursion was not only a natural wonder and exceptionally beautiful, but our phenomenal, sincere and incredibly knowledgeable guide Alfredo was completely engaging and he enhanced the entire experience. He was not only a passionate expert on the site and caves in general, his consideration and attention to participant safety and enjoyment was constant. "There are no words" to adequately describe how much we enjoyed this experience!!

Exciting Day Trip. Rio Secreto was a great way for a little adventure and beauty! This underground river walk and swim was worth the trip. After watching a quick video on the underground river, and how they work to preserve the natural beauty of this underground cave/ river. Our very informative tour guide( I believe his name was Antonio who spent a year in Boston, he spoke good English and Spanish)suited us up with all the equipment we would need and we were off. Keeping the cave as natural as possible there were no walkways so at times footing was rough. I would not recommend to anyone who has any trouble walking or with balance problems. We went from shallow to deep water a few different times, learning about the cave and it's formations! The best of the trip for me was when we were swimming and we all turned out our lights which made us feel and experience the total quiet and darkness of this river deep underground. There was a small section that had about two feet of clearance with the top of the cave and the water which I also found cool and exciting. The formations and natural beauty make this an amazing to experience!

Gods Beautiful Creation!. WOW!!! What an amazing place! It was so magical, beautiful & absolutely breathtaking! Rag203, described the tour very well. So I can add that the wet suits were optional, I was glad cause I'm a plus size girl and have all over arthritis, and a wet suit would have been too much of a challange for me. The water felt great! Yes, I used the walking stick. I knew before I went, that it would be a physical challange for me, but I was bound and determined to see this wonder, and I am so glad I did! As long as my body doesn't get any worse, I would love to do it again. When we were finished our tour, we were offered a shot of, San Marino" Xtabentun". It tastes like Oozo! Also, I highly recommend getting the photo disc! The photgrapher takes many beautiful picts of the group, mayan ceremony, and lots of individual and couple picts. Along with the many picts of your day, there are also, so many breathtaking professional photos added onto your disc. Just think if you were going to hire a professional photographer at your home to take picts of you and your family, how much that would cost you? The photo disc has over a hundred picts on it. Plus for the $99.00 you also get a choice of three items. Can choose, 750ml bottle of the ceremony liquor (30% alc.), or T-shirts (same ones the staff wears) or hats, visors etc. You can choose to have 3 bottles, or 3 t-shirts, or 2 bottles and 1 shirt etc. We have 1 bottle and 2 shirts. So personally, I believe it is worth the $99.00. Memories can fade, pictures will last. (just say'in).

Good Excursion. We just returned from the 7 day cruise on the Carnival Conquest and did the Rio Secreto excursion in Playa del Carmen. It was very well organized. Carnival got us from the ship to the Ferry. Once we got off the ferryat Playa del Carmen, they had someone there to pick us up at the dock and escort us to the bus that took us to the Rio Secreto. There, we were greeted and instructed to suite up (shower, wet suite, water shoes, life vest, and helmet with light) to go into the underground river. It was amazing! Our guide (Leon) was great. He took his time for us to navigate the stalagmite and for us to observe the wonderful setting. The floating in the underground river was the best part. One of my trip mates is closterphobic and did great! After the tour, we arrived back on the surface and ate lunch provided by Rio Secreto. They then returned us to the Playa del Carmen dock with enough time to shop prior departure for Cozumel. Rio Secreto made sure we were back on the ferry in time to get back to our ship in Cozumel. I would highly recommend this tour to anyone!

Not bad. We tried this for something different - I was hoping for more but our travelling companions really liked it. The underground caves were cool but tromping around through stalagmites was a little scary and most of us ended up a bit scraped at the end. The tour guide was a knowledgeable fellow and it was a decent tour, but I think we spent too much time in the caves, it could have been shorter. One lady on our tour got claustrophobic and had to stop for awhile but it didn't hamper us at all. The tour guides were friendly and helpful, I just thought it was a bit too long in the water. Nice area though, and I did learn somethings.

Incredible experience. The whole experience was one that I shall always remember!! It was very well organized and the staff was exceptionally friendly. We descended into caves and made our way through a network whereby we had to walk through some areas and swim through others! Once the excursion is over you are provided with a meal which was really good. There are no cons, however if you are catastrophic or very inactive this excursion is not for you!

Perfect wedding you say?. I went on a trip in Mexico for a wedding and I must say this location is absolutely wonderful for a perfect wedding on the beach. An open walls chapel with ocean view behind the priest at the end of a remote "secret" path is just breathtaking.

Cruisers - Choose this unique adventure!. My husband and I enjoy opportunities to experience adventurous activities when travelling; particularly when cruising. If you are docking in Cozumel or Playa del Carmen, first you must take that 3 hour bus trip to see Chichen Itza. Next time, go to Rio Secreto! To get to Playa del Carmen from Cozumel, we had quite a rocky ferry ride, which left many seasick. However, the trip from Playa to this natural preserve was only about 25 minutes total by way of a van provided by this tour. Our guide (his name is escaping me, and I would love to give him recognition) was a man with an 'R' name from Mexico City with contagious passion for preservation and environmental studies. First, we needed to ask for permission from the Mayans to enter the cenote through a special ceremony. Then we entered a most beautiful, undisturbed, underground world. For 90 minutes, we walked and swam through the caverns; learning about the formations, unique wildlife, and the ongoing work to study and preserve this site. Rio Secreto provided wet suits and walking sticks for those who wanted. This excursion requires some comfort with swimming, as well as balance to maneuver the uneven terrain and rocks. After "surfacing" from the caverns, we toasted with a tequila drink (iced tea for those who preferred). Lastly, we were provided with lunch, which was filling, though nothing too special.The one disappointing note of this experience was the price for photos. They were much worse than I expected ...$99 for a disc, and $25 for a single photo. My husband and I wished to share a disc with two other couples we had befriended on our vacation, however negotiating this was a big hassle. If some of this money were specifically going to the preserve, I would feel differently. We were on a rapelling/waterfall jumping excursion with a dedicated photographer, and the picture cost was far more reasonable. Certainly, an experience I will not forget, with a great tour guide!

Fantastic Excursion a MUST do experience!. We were picked up at our resort on time by a very courteous driver (also taught us some myan language on our way). We were warmly welcomed upon our arrival and separated into small groups according to language understood .Our guide, Rodrigo, was very knowledgeable and absolutely fantastic with our 2 boys (8 & 11) as well as the rest of the adults explaining what we were experiencing each step of our journey. From the Mayan Blessing ceremony through the breath taking Cenote expedition every moment was time well spent. Safety for the participants is top priority providing wet suites, life jackets, helmets with lights & water shoes. The importance of the conservation efforts through education is well worth the price of admission.Memories of your entire expedition are captured by a photographer who follows the group from start to finish and are available for purchase at a reasonable price. We most definitely recommend this excursion.

Great Excursion. We were picked up at our resort on time. We were all given the do's and don'ts via a tv in several languages before being taken to the actual river system entrance. The groups were separated according to language, so there was no barrier in understanding our guide Paulo who was extremely knowledgable and informative on the creation of the various structures we encountered once we entered the cave. Before we entered the actual cave, we took part in a Mayan blessing for our safety. There is a photographer who follows the group around, taking pictures of you and the family/friends you are with which can be purchased after you exit the river system. Great care is taken as far as safety goes. Life jackets and helmets with lights are mandatory and supplied by the good people at Rio Secreto. It was interesting to see a jaguar print that had been left a few weeks earlier near the exit from the system, as well as some bones from a deer that were most probably a jaguar's dinner at some point in the past. The trek thu the river system is quite beautiful, and awesome once it's pointed out how long it takes for the formations to form. After the underground portion of the tour was over, we changed out of the wetsuits(provided) and viewed the pictures that were taken and given several options to purchase at a fair price. We were then given a light meal buffet style and then transported back to our resort. This is not a full day trip, a great way to spend a rainy afternoon. I would definitely recommend this excursion.

Good and bad, very bad. The Good,This was a great tour, the whole underground river experience was truly amazing! The story of discovery and the efforts for seamless set-up were well rehearsed to accommodate numerous groups at a time. The availability to provide guides with French,English, German, Spanish and Italian language skills was appreciated by all. Our guide was enthusiastic, safety conscious and a true gentleman to all. The entire subterranean experience was truly amazing!The Bad,As with many tours a light lunch was provided at the end prior to loading the bus for our return. Well much to our surprise we woke the next morning to nausea and indigestion. We thought a morning walk to place our beach towels would clear our discomforts. Boy were we wrong! It was all we could do to get back to our room and collapse on the bed. It was apparent that we had one seriously bad bout of food poisoning. We spent the next twenty-four hours in the fetal position with only water and trips to the toilet to throw up. Took two days before we could stomach anything. Too bad, could of been a memorable experience, but now it's all I can do to forget it!

Indiana Jones and Marian Beneath the Earth!!!!!!!!!!!!!. My husband and I just returned from a trip to Rio Secreto. At 70 and 73 there isn't much that surprises us anymore BUT this is the exception!!!!!!! First of all you MUST believe the brochure when it states that you need to have no medical conditions including weight, neck, back, knee etc problems. You get the message. Granted, you can't bring in your own camera or video equipment but we understood that thoroughly within the first 10 seconds. For safety reasons you MUST have use of both of your hands. Benito, our guide, was incredible!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Safety is first and foremost on his agenda. LISTEN to him word for word. This excursion is for anyone who, as kids, drew outside of the lines!! It truly is mindblowing. Before you enter the cave be sure to drink a bottle of water (DON'T EVEN THINK OF HAVING ALCOHOL in your system)!!!! The wet suit, etc. is heavy and seems even more so when you first begin When you reach the water it is like a soothing balm. Crack open your wallet and buy the pictures because never in your life may you have another encounter like this again!!! We will remember this forever!!!!!! Thanks again, Benito!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Great short trip for a rainey day. Rio Secreto is a must see! We had a few days of poor weather while staying in Playa del Carmen and this short trip was just perfect. The ride to the park gate is only about 15 minutes. Its another 20 minutes by van down jungle trails to the facility. Once we got there we were assigned a guide (Eva) who took us through the attraction. The undergrounder caves and river system was quite spectacular. There's about a 50-50 split between swimming (or bobbing along) and walking through the water. Some of the formations in the larger caves were unbelieveable and the guide had ways of surpizing us with their beauty.After we were finished the tour there was a light lunch and beer available for $3 each. We left our resort at 7:45AM and were back by 1 PM. By the way, towels are provided so you dont need to steal them from your hotel!I highly recommend this as the perfect tour for when you really dont want to lose a whole day to an excursion (with hours on a bus). Some physical ability is required but i'd rate that as no more than 2 out of 5 in terms of exertion. For balance and mobiility probably a 3 out of 5 required. Its also fairly cheap so if your in the area with a large family of teens and adults this is one trip everyone should be able to experience together.

Incredible. This is a must see trip when in Cancun/Playa del Carmen. From start to finish all of the staff are extremely helpful. The actual walk through the caves is something that I have never done before and is a completely different experience. A little cold when you are in the water but the sight of the caves are well worth it. Something different from the normal holiday attraction.

Beautiful Underground Wold. We timed it perfectly and went to Rio Secreto on a rainy day. We went underground and were amazed at the beauty of the underground rivers cenotes and formations that are out of thsi world. The tours are pretty eco friendly and not Disneylandish. It was nice. Our guide was patcient and helpful to the members in the groupo that needed assitance. Rio Secreto is worth the trip.

Rain or sunny!. What an amazing experience to visit this underground cave of the Rieviera Maya. This is as close as it gets to scuba diving in the cavern of the Yucatan Peninsula.... minus the water and required certification!

Cool Experience. At first I thought it was going to be a bit of a letdown. As we started into it I kept thinking "This is going to be short. It's going to be a little tour and that's it." I was really wrong. It started that way. Our guide Alanis/Antonio was really great. He explained all sorts of things about stalactites, stalagmites and the other formations. I actually learned a lot. And we ended up getting really gritty in this cenote. I was up to my head in the water, with the ceiling right above my head at one point. We were in a chamber in total darkness for a few minutes and it was really fun.During the trek a photographer took some pictures. At the end they wanted you to buy the pictures, as well as some others, on a DVD. The price of this DVD was disgusting. I think it was $69.00 USD. I didn't even bring that much money with me. So heads up on that if you would be interested in buying it. You can't bring your own camera in and stuff, so if you want pictures of you in there you really don't have a choice but to buy it.After the tour there is a sample of Mayan Tequila and a lunch. The Lime Soup was amazing. Aside from the outragious DVD price, it was well worth it!Also once you get there there is another ten minute ride to the actual cenote. Its a bit bumpy.

Amazing experience. Such a cool trip. This kind of thing could never happen in the U.S. The excursion is totally safe, but you definitely don't get the feeling the caves have been "themeparked" for your protection. We came out with a few scrapes and considered them souvenirs. Our guide Flora was incredible. Very sweet, extremely knowledgeable, and made the exploration safe for everyone. Plus her language skills were great (she was French and our group spoke Spanish, English and Portuguese!). Incredible outing, worth the money.

Awesome, scenic experience. This is a great experience! They've only been doing tours here since 2008, so it's very un-commercialized and the cenote was very natural and preserved. There are no artifical walkways or stairs (except in one small area in the beginning and end) which I loved. Beautiful formations and crystal clear water. You have to walk through some parts and swim through others. Swimming was the fun part. There are two separate routes, one of them has a lot more swimming than the other, so call and ask for which ever route you want - they may or may not be able to accommodate you. I think the tour with more swimming is called "Supremo" but I am not sure. I heard it has about 10 minutes of swimming without being able to touch the ground. Of course your life jacket will keep you above water. You don't need to know how to swim to go on this tour. Do NOT go if you have mobility issues or any problem maneuvering through small areas on unsteady ground. You could easily fall and get injured on this tour. It's also very possible that you will get scraped by rocks on your legs.Wet suits, aqua shoes, life jackets, and helmets provided. No pictures allowed. They take pictures for you throughout the tour and you can choose from 3 packages. $99 for all pictures, t-shirts, and hat. $69 for all pictures on a CD. Or ONE picture on a CD for $25. Outrageous prices but you will definitely want at least one picture. That was the only negative part of this experience. Paulo the tour guide was great.

Best Family Excursion we had on Mayan Riviera. We booked Rio Secreto over the phone from the resort we stayed at (Gran Bahia Principe). It was cheaper, we had more options for when the tour started and it was easy to get to by collectivo (minibuses you can catch beside the highway; cost $3 US or 300 pesos). After an introductory video we were taken by bus (20 min) to the site. Our guide was Nunes. You just have to bring a bathing suit. There are lockers with keys to store your clothes and valuables. You get suited up with water shoes, wet suit, life jacket and helmet with light. After a blessing from a Mayan elder we entered the cave. We had never been in one this extensive. It was beautiful. Nunes was very attentive to our safety warning us of any possible dangers. You do have to go through sections where your feet won't touch bottom in the water so if you have any fear of water (in a dark cave) then this trip may not be for you. My daughter saw some of the blind fish. The stalagtite, stalamite and column formations were beautiful. There were some bats but not in huge numbers. We were in the cave system for about 1 h. The picture package at the end varies from around $50 - $100 US. The price is a bit steep but we had never had pictures like these before so we ended up getting them. There was a nice lunch at the end. Don't forget to tip your guide. The kids (8 and 12) loved it. Awesome trip.

Undisturbed natural beauty. This is such a unique excursion. A combination of walking, wading and swimming through and underground cave and river system. The guide was very knowledgable and enthusiastic and did not hurry anyone. The caves are beautiful, only wish the trip was longer. The formations in the caves have not been damaged and I hope they can keep it that way by limiting the visitors. There are 2 routes to travel in the caves and I can't wait to try it again in the future, a must see.
Very unique valuable experience. It was well organized, a very unique tour, not crowded with tourists. The caves are pristine and they take great care to educate you about them. A great experience.

Underground tour. Just visit Rio Secreto on Facebook or on the Internet and you'll get an idea of the place. We visited it and thoroughly enjoyed it. It was a wonderful experience. A visit to Rio Secreto is a must if you visit the Yucatan peninsula.

Participatory fun. This is one of the best excursions in caves that I have ever done. We were a small group of 3 adults and one child. Our guide was Francesca. She was informative, careful, and knowledgeable. She got us changed into our wetsuits and watershoes, gave us sticks for balance. Then we went unnderground and sometimes floated in water. We only haad the light from the headlamps on our helmets. Our life jackets helped us float and keep from geting tired. Though the water was not cold, cold, the wet suits were appreciated. The entire tour is doen by yourself, no rafts, steps or hand rails. Really exciting. To be recommened to everyone. Note, one person who had to drop out suffered from asthma. People who are claustrophobic should not go although I never felt "closed in." During our stay, a photographer took photos of us all.Then we had a soso lunch. I would do tis again in a flash. However, the cost of the photos is simply obscene. I think that they are a ripoff.

Incredible experience!. Rio Secreto was the best excursion my partner and I did on our last cruise (Jan 2013). We were on the NCL Pearl docked in Cozumel and took a ferry over to Playa del Carmen (which is gorgeous). It was a short walk to a van where we drove for about 25 minutes to the nature reserve. Once there, we had to shower off all of our body oils, etc. and then we headed for the caves. Our guide was Alex, who was AMAZING, and there were only 6 people in our group. Before we went down into the caves, we were blessed by a shaman, which was very cool even though he was wearing a name badge (?). The caves were incredible. I thought I would be nervous/scared, but I really wasn't. I can't really describe what an amazing experience it was. We were in the caves for at least an hour, swimming and walking. At one point, we sat in total darkness and silence, it was really magical. The meal afterwards was pretty good and the photos were very expensive, but we paid $69 for the photo package because it really was a once in a lifetime experience that we wanted to remember always. I HIGHLY recommend this adventure!

Can't pass this up…mind blowing!. Paulo was an amazing guide and had a lot of great and interesting facts to share. You can pass this up if you can do it. It's only half a day to take the tour. Not to mention a great shot of a local alcohol. Actually if anyone knows what it's call let me know. I will go back to do it again.

Is great experience. The cave is very impressive, memories forever, no doubts. "Must do" .... if you in Cancun or Riviera Maya areas, service is very attentive, while I rarely back to experience same thing twice, I would do comeback to Rio Secreto.one small disapointing that their prices keep climbing up and up and up

Neat. Overall it was a pretty cool experience. We had wetsuits we wore and were able to travel underground with our helmets. It was annoying that we couldn't take pictures and if we wanted any had to purchase them for a largely inflated price. We chose not to. Our guide spoke French, Spanish, and English, looked like a French Heath Ledger. My husband and I both understand Spanish pretty well so he did the tour in French and Spanish, made it a little more interesting. We had fun but both agreed it wasn't our favorite thing we did. Such as climbing Coba, snorkeling, swimming with the sea turtles...

A stunning adventure. It's hard to believe that this rio was only 'discovered' in 2008, the facility and quality of the tour is really amazing. The ride from the entrance to the staging area can be a little disconcerting especially if your driver is a little heavy on the pedal, but if you ask him to take it easy, he will.Once you're at the staging area and you meet your guide, the ball gets rolling pretty quickly (depending on your group size/composition). Lockers are provided for ALL your things. I say all because the only thing you can take with you are the swimsuit you're wearing and prescription glasses. Watches, jewelry (if you have lots of piercings this can take a while), cameras, hats, all these things will stay behind.Once you're geared, your group approaches the entrance where you have a short ceremony to receive a blessing from the Mayan Gods before entering the caverns, as the Maya treat such things as sacred. Safety and preservation of the natural spaces are always maintained while you walk/wade/swim through the rio. Breathtaking is an understatement for describing what you see (or don't see if your group is okay with a minute of total darkness, do it!!). There was a recent incident where a tourist broke a stalagmite which was tragic from a preservation standpoint, but gave us the opportunity to hold a piece of it up close, which was fascinating.In addition to your guide, a professional photographer is there shooting both candid and posed images of your group and the whole tour. The photo quality of our groups shots was amazing. The price for just a CD of all the images, plus a set of images that was used in their bid to the Mexican government to become a nature preserve was only $60USD, $90USD gets you the CD and any three souvenir items (dri-fit shirt, hat, etc) which is a pretty good value, but I had plenty of shirts already.Buffet meal at the end wasn't extravagant, but tasty, and adds much to the value of the tour cost. All in all a wonderful experience, I would have been quite happy to immediately go through again.

Not to be missed if you like visiting caves. One of the best attractions to visit in the Riviera Maya. Upon arrival we were outfitted with knee length wet suits, a helmet with a light, and water shoes. One of the men in our party was 270 pounds (at least that is what he admits to) and they had no trouble finding a wet suit that fit him perfectly. After a brief Mayan blessing, we descended thru the cenote into an underground cave. The caves are geologically spectacular--we have been to many caves and were in awe of the incredible stalagmites and stalagtites. We walked, waded, and swam thru the cave. They limit the group to 10 people and the guide is very careful to explain to people when to watch out for submerged rocks and where to walk to avoid injury. It wouldn't be a good idea to do this tour if you have serious mobility issues--but my husband was 1 year out from having a total hip and did just fine--especially since they provided him with a walking stick for extra stability. I have "mild" claustrophobia and did fine--I don't like squeezing thru tight places and feeling stuck in caves. There was one area where you had to crouch to get thru--but otherwise, no tight squeezes. We were so impressed with the tour and wanted to preserve memories so we decided to buy the DVD with pictures at the end of the tour--which is very uncharacteristic of us. We are hoping that we can visit again during the "off season". They are planning longer more extensive tours during the summer months.

Awesome Underwater Cave!. We had a fabulous time swimming in this cave. It reminded me of untouched caves I used to explore as a child with summer camp. 10 people in a group at a time, intimate, personal.Lots of swimming and balance - if you are claustrophobic or have balance/mobility/fitness issues, this is NOT for you!$70 for DVD of photos (they will NOT allow you to bring jewelry or any photography equipment downbelow - good thing too b/c you will need both hands for balance) we paid $100 and got DVD of photos, 2 dri fit shirts and bottle of tequila - well worth the money! We did this as a carnival excursion and had a great time.They fed us snack/lunch afterwards - it was not the best food i've had, but it was delicious and i was pretty hungry after swimming around the cave for almost 2 hours :)

Great time, would highly recommend!. This was an experience not to be missed. Our guide was extremely patient with our 80 year old father. Would highly recommend to others, the caves were unbelievable!

Go do this. Our guide had an answer for every question. If you need a break from the sun to let your sunburn heal, do this. No worries about critters interrupting your tour, the most we saw were tiny catfish and a row of albino ants.

Cave diving in Mexico!. My wife was under the impression this visit to the cenotes was going to be near ground level, and a snorkeling adventure. However, this trip takes you almost 250 feet below earths surface to explore underground rivers and caves that are still being explored. Towards the end you actually swim more then walk. Overall, this is a pretty tame guided tour, but if you are afraid of tight spaces and the dark, go with caution. I loved this excsurion and recommend it to anyone!

Wow. An amazing trek through underground caverns and pools with awesome stalactites, stalagmites, etc.
Too bad they charge so much for their photos. I have a hunch they could sell 10 times as many photos if they brought their prices down.

Great excursion to Rio Secreto. We booked via our Disney cruise and had heard good things about this excursion. We loved it! It was truly an amazing, once in a life time excursion. Our guide, Alfredo, was fantastic, we felt comfortable and safe and enjoyed ourselves. Our group ran the gamut from the very fit to the not so fit, and we were all able to handle this excursion and no one seemed either too overwhelmed nor bored or “unchallenged”. The equipment provided was clean and in great condition, the grounds were beautiful and well tended. We weren’t expecting but really enjoyed the inclusion of Mayan culture in the form of a blessing at the beginning of the journey. The information and sights were breathtaking. We are not ones to normally buy excursion souvenirs, but the amazing photos and t=shirt package was, we felt, a bargain at $99. We also were expecting a “snack”, but had a great (really tasty!) buffet lunch with delicious fruits, salads, rice, empenadas, beans - it was really good! I’m so glad we did get the pictures because that place is almost unreal now to think back about the caves and the water.... Thanks for a once in a lifetime experience!! Highly recommend!

Rio Secreto was amazing!. I know there were a few other places to see the caves but this was recommended and it was brilliant! If you are staying between Tulum and Playa del Carmen, take the Collectivo for 35 pesos or 3 american dollars per way. It runs up and down that Highway. Ask about it. It is WAY cheaper than paying a taxi or shuttle 60$. You can't bring any cameras into the cave, which I get because not only are they trying to make money off of you, but they don't want anyone leaving anything down there. This was an amazing experience!! Plus, the authentic lunch after was very good. Much better than the American crappy food served at our resort.

A bucket list item for sure. I experienced this beautiful place just today. It was one of the experiences that everyone should have! I am so impressed that the people running this tour are doing their best to preserve the natural beauty of this astounding cenote. My only complaint was about the driver that was speeding crazily over the rough and hilly road. I finally asked to have him slow down. I was lifting out of my seat at times. Eva was our guide through the cenote. She had a wealth of information, was so attentive to help our small group navigate the uneven terrain and water. One of the most natural and untouched phenomenal place that I have visited. A must see for everyone?

delighful encounter. Rio Secreto is an awsome experience.Our guide was knowledgable and a very nice person.The grounds are beautiful and the inviting way we were greeted was unexpected but welcomed.A real nature adventure.A must do.

Amazing. This was definitely the highlight of our trip! We waited awhile before taking the shuttle to the river, as they were probably waiting for our group to get larger, but other than that it was an amazing experience. Surreal, even. Not great for very small children or claustrophobics.

A must do in Mexico. Loved every minute of this excursion. One of the coolest things I have ever seen and done. You can't wear any jewellery or bring a camera. They do take pictures of you in the cave and it costs but they have to make money some how! You shouldn't wear any sun screen so it won't contaminate the water. They give you towels too and all the gear to wear. Just bring your selves really. They feed you at the end. I didn't like the food but I may be just fussy. The adventure is really what I went for and it was wonderful being down in this magical underground cave.

Amazing experience!!. We booked Rio Secreto on-line months before our travel date through the company website. We were impressed with the follow up service the week prior to our departure asking us to confirm our room and resort for driver pick up. Our driver was extremely punctual and very pleasant. We were taken to a Rio Secreto reception area where we transferred onto another vehicle that took us 10 km over gravel roads surrounded by jungle to the Rio Secreto cave site. Once at the site we were grouped according to our spoken language to ensure we had an appropriate guide and then we gathered on benches to view an information video on the underground river and area. Guides in many different languages are available. We were provided with wetsuits, life jackets, and helmets equipped with led headlights. Our group size was ten people to a guide and photographer and we were traveling with children ages five and eight. We walked through the jungle to the cave entrance where we gathered in a ceremonial setting to receive a Mayan blessing to enter the underworld, which they consider sacred.After receiving the blessing we walked down several slippery steps into a large area inside of the cave where we were informed that the last natural light would be available and we would have to turn on our headlights going further into the cave. Our guide, Paulo, was excellent at pointing out formations and features in the cave that we would otherwise have missed. The cave was magnificent with crystal clear turquoise water, cathedrals, coral formations and magnificent stalagmites and stalagtites. Our children received an excellent educational experience from Paulo, our amazing guide. Parts of the cave were very narrow and some parts very low where we were required to crouch down so we didn't bump and damage a formation. We were instructed to help each other along as we walked single file through the cave and our guide helped people in the group every time they needed assistance to keep everyone safe. If an individual was claustrophobic, had mobility issues, or a fear of swimming in deep water even with a life jacket this cave experience could be problematic. The water we had to swim through was cool but with the wet suit and life jacket we quickly adjusted to the temperature and being inside the cave was so spectacular. Paulo pointed out a spider on the cave wall that had adapted to the total darkness, it had six legs and two front legs had turned into antennae so the spider could find its prey. Cave mappers were mapping the cave while we were there and pointed out a rare find of jaguar footprints near the cave exit. Paulo also pointed out bats in the cave ceiling and fish in the water. The cave system was massive. We were inside the cave for an hour an a half and the company allows only ten percent of the cave to be explored while keeping ninety percent preserved. They have done a very good job keeping the tour groups small for an intimate experience preserving the delicate formations and ecosystem. When we exited the cave we were taken to an area where we were given liquor made from anise and honey and our children were give iced tea and we celebrated the experience with our guide and the group. Our equipment was removed and we were allowed to change into dry clothing and then were taken to a covered shaded area of picnic tables and were invited to a sumptuous buffet of hot foods, soups, fresh fruit and beverages.Cameras are not permitted inside the cave and a photographer followed the group taking individual photos along the way. At the end of the tour these photographs are available for purchase. We bought the complete package and many other photos of the cave and formations as well as photos of the jungle flora and fauna were included and we felt the price was not prohibitive having traveled to Disney knowing the price of photos taken there. For ninety dollars we received a photo CD of all our pictures plus the additional photos (about 79 in total), a bottle of liquor and two t-shirts. A review of this attraction really doesn't do the area justice, one has to see the splendor of the caves to appreciate them first hand. I would advise anyone capable of managing this tour to put it on your "must do" list. Phenomenal experience!! Will definitely go back.

Worth the money. We had low expectations of Rio Secreto, thinking it could be another tourist trap; however we were pleasantly surprised.After a poor start (put driver was late, unapologetic and couldn't asnwer most of our questions about what was going to happen at Rio Secreto) we were wry impressed with the whole operation once we met our guide of the caves. She was helpful (especially towards a less mobile person in our group) and knowledgable. We were also impressed with the photo package (we usually turn these down on tours) which we bought for $99 US and included 2 dry fit t-shirts (which have paid for themselves on many a diving trip since) and a bottle of Xtabentun.Overall an experience well worth te money.

Amazing!. This tour is worth every cent! It is an experience you will always remember! Thank you to our guide Victor who was very experienced and knowledgable! He was always first concerned about our safety and then the preservation of the nature of the surroundings.This is a must for anyone who is not afraid of water and likes an adventure!All the gear is provided. Including the not so flattering wet suit! lol For the ladies they know how to pick the right suit without you having to try and find the right one that fits.Trip starts by a short intro video clip, a ride through the jungle and then leads you down a short walk way through the jungle and then into the caves. I deliberitly omitted a fews extra touches.If you can doggy paddle that is all you need for swimming ability.The water is not cold and is crystal clear! At the end of the tour we were provided with a Mayan lunch and the opportunity to purchase a photo cd of the experience. So bring some extra cash!!!! It is going to a great cause!! They provide keyed lockers for your belongings as well as a towel!!!John and Joan Canada

Fun Exploration. This was a fun trip and nice exploration. You are not in the water very much, which we thought we would be in the water nearly the entire time. They have done a great job of preserving the natural habitat.

Amazing, but a little expensive. Dont get me wrong, this place is amazing, and I've never been to anything like it! Even I, however, found the price a little steep, and I'm always willing to pay for an experience. The guide was quite educational, and overall, I felt the visit was worth it, but I suspect others might not, given the cost. We did not purchase pictures, as they were all staged with the photographer, and you couldn't take up close photos of the stalactites and stalagmites-I'd personally prefer photos of the amazing scenery and not of myself.

amazing caves and guides. Fantastic open cave system well lit and vast beautiful caves to be guided through, Guides are very respectful of the natural cave system and have a true passion for them, great experiance

Excellent!!. This was an excellent tour - swimming, wading, walking, crawling thru the caves. Not for people with claustrophobia or limited mobility. Equipment was clean & worked well, guides were excellent. Great way to spend an afternoon!

Absolutely Breathtaking. I just got back from the Mayan Riviera yesterday and during my stay I visited Rio Secreto with my family. It was the most amazing excursion I have even done. It was only half a day but I wished we stayed in the cave for days. Our tour guide Alfredo made the experience such a memorable one, as you could tell he truly loved everything he was showing us and really meant everything he said. He was so genuine, which made the experience that much better. We were a group of 9 people, and were able to go just the 9 of us. It was intimate and absolutely beautiful. Its a definite must do! I will be returning my next vacation to Mexico most definitely!! When you visit request ALFREDO!!!

Great family excursion. We're a family with 2 kids -- 10 and 15 years of age. All four of us loved walking, scrambling, wading and swimming through these caves with our excellent guide, Raul, who was knowledgeable and attentive to everyone's safety. Raul is passionate about caves and about this underground ecosystem -- and his passion is contagious. It was a lot of fun, and we were impressed with the focus on conservation and education. The tour was well-organized and well-run, and a terrific experience for all of us.

Amazing and Beautiful. Jean our guide was just great as he navigated us through the maze of the underground caverans. I have seen many caves but to be able to explore a cave that really is untouched by man is fabulous. I would recommend anyone going into the area to make this one of their todo items on their vacation. This is not for the faint of heart or any challenges walking. As it does involve some uneven terrain.

Amazing rock formations. This park offers a single hike through the caves. Just the landscape is worth the price! The only thing I would change is that they do not allow you to take pictures and, after you have seen all that, you just want to get something to remember the place by, and that is when you buy the pictures taken by them. It is my opinion that you should be given the choice to buy the pro pictures (theirs are certainly better than the ones you could take yourself), or to take your own pics. But overall I would definetively recommend.

Unforgettable tour. Very unique experience with so much history, we all loved it and Eva is an awesome tour guide. Be prepared to buy the pictures and not because you are pressured to, they are just too good to not get.

Wonderful experience, fantastic guide!. We toured Rio Secreto with a group of people. We enjoyed every aspect of our tour. The attraction feels very unspoiled and natural. It was absolutely beautiful. Perhaps the best part of the tour was our guide, Alfredo. He was extremely knowledgeable and very passionate about the caverns. There was one person in our group who was not able to swim, and while we all had a life jackets, she was really nervous about navigating the areas of deeper water (of which there are few). Alfredo was wonderful with her and got her to relax and enjoy herself. We had a lunch after the tour. The soup was excellent! The folks at Rio Secreto do a super job.

from the womb to rebirth - shore excursion. Booking this shore excursion through Carnival was a good decision for us. Because there are many ways to enter the caves each group is made to feel like theirs in an exclusive journey. After donning our wet suits and water shoes, the six of us plus guide first met a Mayan medicine man who told a story of peoples long ago. Some ancestors found the caves to be like the womb of the Mayan people as it contained the fresh water that sustained them. Others experienced the caves as if it were an underworld like the Greek House of Hades. As we journeyed through the water and passages directed by the beam of our helmet lights and the person in front it was fascinating to imagine both wading through the river of Styx and being baptized in the womb of the Mayan people. If you go expect a short period when the guide asks everyone to shut off his light and be still as you float in one of the cave's pools. It's a trip.

Uniquely Entertaining & Educational Adventure. Thanks to eco-minded folks, this excursion is incredible! The river is a short drive from the docks of Playa del Carmen. We took this excursion when docked in Cozumel for the day, so first ferried to the mainland. The numbers of visitors to Rio Secreto are limited (our group had 10) and great care is taken to limit access to various tributaries of this underground river. Being from Florida, which is built upon a limestone aquifer, I found this incredibly fascinating as we hiked and swam through the underground labyrinth. The water is so pristine and the stalagmite and stalactite formations so beautiful. Your guide is sure to please and do be sure to get the DVD at the end of the trip that captures the beauty of your visit as well as fun photos of you and/or your spouse.

Nice but "touristy". Beautiful space and tour, good guides ... BUT they won´t let you take your camera with you to take pictures with the pretext that it is for your safety!!! Then (of course) they take pictures and sell them to you :)

Rio Secreto, Niagara Falls move over!!!. When we learned that the cost of this attraction was $99.00 each, I said no that's way too much. My wife said "oh come on, we are on vacation, lets try it we may never have a chance like this again", so reluctantly, I agreed. Well, I was blown away by the natural beauty of this cave. It is 100% untouched by man with no fancy lighting or hand rails. All you get is reality in all it's glory. You are taken through the cave with a guide in small groups according to what language you speak, down into a set of stone stairs directly into an area of the cave that acclimates you to what you will be experiencing for the next 90 minutes. I believe this is to check for claustrophobia before embarking any further. When all seems well, you begin your descent and right away you are mesmerized by the natural beauty. As you look up, raindrops glisten like little diamonds under the light from your helmet from all the stalactites hanging from the ceiling. We are 56 and a little heavy weight wise, however we were able to navigate through the cave with very little help from the guide and person in front of us. This is one thing they stress and urge you to do, walk with confidence and turn and help the person behind you, so yes it is a bit of a work out in some parts so be prepared.This cave is not a man made structure, this is Nature in all its splendor. You are given a wet suit, water shoes, life vest, and a helmet with a light on it. There are spots in the water that are 4-5 feet deep but they only span for about 30 feet so your time in deep water is brief, however you float quiet well with the suit and jacket so non swimmers will have no trouble. I found the wet suit to be a little cumbersome but it must be worn to protect you from some of the sharp edges of the cave and stalagmites and corals. A photographer also follows the group and takes group and individual pictures along the way. At one point, we sat in a circle in the shallow water while the guide explained about the organic benefits of the sand and silt, we were encouraged to rub it on our skin as a natural body scrub. Everybody then turned off their flashlight to see how dark it was in the caves, you couldn't see a hand in front of your face.At the end, as we ascended the stairs to exit, was a small alter where any items found in the cave were left as an offering for the gods. Nothing is allowed to leave the caves. All in all, it was an amazing experience that ended too quickly. Our only disappointment was the costs of the photos. We thought that for the costly price of admission, as there is no way you could take your own camera (you need both hands to navigate your way through) one should be given a souvenir photo. Photos could be purchased for $25 each or a CD of about 10-12 photos for $69. As we hadn't brought enough cash or a credit card with us, we left with only our minds eye memories.
Amazing. We visited here in december and the mile long swim was incredible. I did it was other family members and we all enjoyed it

Lots of great activities in Cancun but this is our #1. Rio Secreto will not disappoint! Our family of 4 (2 boys aged 11 and 13 years) loved it. The eco-friendly limestone cave exploration in the dark freshwater cenotes, sometimes wading ankle deep, sometimes wading chest high, coupled with a great guide and fascinating formations was just breathtaking. We were all provided wet suits, life jackets, helmet with a head-lamp - that's all we needed. No foreign items e.g. watches, jewelries, cameras, sunglasses (in a cave?) were allowed. They had a photographer who followed us the entire 1.5 hours and took great photos of everyone in each group on 10 max. Yes, we had to pay a handsome $$ for a CD of photos but they were really worth the memories of this activity. Highly recommended and you will not be disappointed.By the way, a healthy lunch buffet followed the exploration.If you are staying in the hotel belt - this will be a full day activity.

More than expected. Rio Secreto sounded suspiciously contrived like so many other attractions in Cancun like Xcaret or Xplor. I was pleasantly surprised at how natural and intact the site is in its undisturbed state. We selected the visit because it was not an all day commitment during our recent stay in Cancun. We were taken by our Best Day Tour sponsored guide to the site which was about an hour out of Cancun. The location was near the other attractions that are well publicized in the Cancun area. The advertised underground caverns share the same passages and water features that so far have been mapped out to be around 13 miles underground. We were told that the more commercialized access at the other attractions were heavily modified to handle a larger number of visitors. The Rio Secreto operations is sponsored by the original discoverer of the site and has only been open since 2009 or so. The limit the visits to about 400 visitors a day and in groups of no more than 10 per guide. Each group sets off in wet suits, lighted helmet and floatation jacket. We started off with a traditional Mayan shaman ritual before entering the caverns. Since there are multiple trails, you don't encounter other visitors except for your immediate group. They have the capacity to take groups in language specific needs which is specified during the booking process. It was a terrific experience to descend down into the site donning the equipment and appropriate footwear. All equipment was provided on site, along with lockers to store all your personal items. No jewelry, watches, or photographic equipment can be taken along. There is an assigned photographer which while compile images for your purchase at the end of the excursion. The natural formations, pools, and rivers were amazing. We had a chance to follow a trail, float in water filled chambers, and experience a complete light out experience to listen to the water drops falling that formed the many formations. The tour lasted about 90 minutes which is about enough. You had to be careful of not touching or bumping the rock formations. Although it was not physically difficult, those less comfortable walking in dim lighting, along potentially rough surfaced rock formations, and floating in confined spaces may feel a little anxious., My family with kids ranging from 13-22, including my son with special needs, thoroughly enjoyed it. The meal served at the end was very tasty and offered the Mayan style cuisine in a pleasant outdoors setting. We also had the opportunity to see some local wildlife as they passed through our dining area. Overall, everyone in our group of 11 had a great time and note the experience as a highlight activity. I would recommend this without hesitation.
