They provide lockers, wet suits, water shoes, life jackets, and towels. (We took our own towels and shoes) Our guide Raul went above and beyond. He really loves his job and the caves so it makes you excited hearing how excited he is. The caves really speak for themselves with their beauty. The pictures taken are great and so is the price. I loved having a photographer follow us and capture the whole journey. I will be back to do one of the other two cave packages (did suprema). The meal they serve after is a perfect way to end your visit. I highly reccomend this excursion and would ask for Raul...Don't miss this memorable adventure!

Great Experience. You have to go to this, so interesting and the guides are amazing. A long drive and a long day. We got picked up at noon and didn't get back to our hotel until almost 6pm but well worth it.Not for people who have problems walking or climbing as there is some difficult spots but if you want a different experience try it out.
Nice excursion. Available in many languages, this excursion was nice and fun. It was outstanding and the guide was great. Cost money for picture... only disappointment.

I WILL return!!!!. This was an excursion on my last vacation. I will be returning to explore the other two caverns. Worth EVERY penny. Our guide Gonzo was OUTSTANDING. They give a nice light lunch of local homemade dishes. If you are looking for a unique experience to brag about or just a wonderful memory this is the place.

Wonderful!!. Rio Secreto is a must go place, the guides are very polite and make you enjoy every step of the way in the tour. The caves are awesome and you can swim and walk through them.The digital pictures are very affordable !! and the tour not expensive at all.

Excellent experience. This was an amazing experience which we booked and paid for on-line in uk before we travelled. This included transport to and from our hotel. Photos however are not the best quality, so maybe worth just getting one printed rather than buying the disc. Definitely recommend the experience.
Amazing tour. Very organized and not crowded, our guide Pablo was the best! Amazing network of caverns and a lot of fun.

this was great!. Place is amaizing! My 8 and 11 old kids totaly enjoy the whole process of preparation and then actual swimming in cave's river!Photograph made a great pictures, she knew the most beautiful place for it! This was a half-day tour from our hotel in Cancun. Perfect attraction in the hot day.

Spelunking for the rest of us. Really cool experience in a very large Cenote. You walk, wade and swim through these amazing caverns. They provide all the gear you need (wetsuit, helmet, headlamp, water shoes). They do not let you take your own camera, but send down a photographer and sell you photo packages that pretty much equal the cost of admission. I suspect almost all of us will buy the picture package which thankfully comes digitally on CD.The included lunch buffet is pretty terrible... I think they offer hotel transport from Playa del Carmen hotels, but I drove a rental car there because Budget car rental gave us a BOGO coupon for admission.

beautiful place, good option in a rainy day. We stayed in playa del carmen and we had a couple rainy days, the staff in our hotel suggested us to visit rio secreto since the tour is underground. It was an awesome place, the tour was excellent, the guide friendly and great service.

Totally worth it!. Rio Secreto was an amazing experience. I would highly recommend signing up for this tour. It was a bit expensive, but totally worth it if you want to try something different. Alanis was our tour guide who was awesome. Tour takes about 2 hours or so and there are no words to describe everything that you see. The buffet was disappointing so make sure you have a heavy breakfast. Also the wet suits and helmets had a funky odor from being used so much. At the end of the tour you have the option of purchasing the pictures taken which were pretty over-priced ($69 for a full cd of all pictures of $25 per picture), but given the breathtaking experience I still ended up purchasing it to keep as a memory.

Rio Secreto. I love it. but the trip is quite short comparing to the others like Tulum tour.The distance from Cancun is around 2 hrs one way. If you have a car or a rental car in Cancun, you by yourself is highly recommended.

incredible adventure. An Indiana Jones like adventure into the cave! Your kids will enjoy this one! This was one place that I got my moneys worth. Not cheap, but worth the money. The meal afterwards was fantastic!

Money Well Spent!. The tour was absolutely breathtaking! We weren't sure if we were going to go because it was expensive, but it was totally worth it. We had Alfredo as a guide and he was awesome and delicious buffet included at the end of the tour! DO IT!

You have to go here!. Rio Secreto is the best. very interesting and once in a lifetime experience. feels like you are in an adventure movie once inside. this tour is half day. u'll start the day by going to their "lobby". kinda long wait but it's ok. after that u'll be hopping on a van to go to the location where the cave is. roughly 20-30 mins. it could be just 10 mins if it weren't for a bad road. take note that if u have motion sickness it's best that u bring a plastic bag or something because u'll be bouncing your head for the whole transfer. all in all this activity is awesome. i can say that u should put this on your to-do list if u visited RM. food is good too. and they have a hammock area where u can relax. breath taking scenes once inside.

nice place but I wanted more "aventure". The tour is ok but I was excepting more aventure! For that price, I thought we could spend some "free time" in the caves and swim. This is not what I was expecting. As a fan of caving, I would say this is not the best visit I've done. The kids were bored and thought the visit was too long.

Unforgettable and amazing!. We traveled to Cozumel onboard the Carnival Liberty and arrived home on August 18, 2012. This was our 9th cruise, and we do excursions everywhere we go, but this was by far the most amazing excursion we’ve ever taken to date! It was simply thrilling… Our guide, Dante was brilliant. We learned so much, and will never forget that day. It was very intense and much more than we had expected from the benign Carnival description. We felt like we were filming a National Geographic episode… and the cruise ship definitely didn’t describe how amazing this excursion would be… we have 2 kids, ages 11 and 7, and we were all awestruck from this experience. Dante taught/showed us so much about the biodiversity of life in the caves, and about the history of the Mayan explorers that has been evidenced down there. We saw a blind fish and other amazing sights that you would never have an opportunity to come across in day to day living. While hiking back to the lockers, a huge tarantula literally walked across our path, and a beautiful pea-greenparrot was sitting in the trees above our heads. The cave-exploring was definitely more arduous than we had expected (the swimming portion at least), which was great after over-indulging ourselves at every meal on the cruise ship, and Rio Secreto provided us with a lunch (which the cruise ship had not told us about either). Over all, this was simply a perfectly unforgettable adventure, and my family loved every second of it. We bought the pictures (be forewarned that they don’t take AMEX), and will treasure them as reminders of a truly fantastic and unforgettable experience.

Rio Secreto is an absolute MUST!. truly, this excursion was one of the most memorable of our whole trip. worth every penny; the pics are amazing, the staff are outstanding. our guide, Lia, was super knowledgeable and went out of her way to connect with everyone one-on-one.

No Words!!!. It is impossible to put into words just HOW AMAZING this trip was! It was the best thing we did on our recent vacation! Rodrigo, our guide, was fantastic! He was so knowledgable and really enhanced the experience. The caves are stunning and unlike anything you can even imagine. Lunch after was tasty and relaxing in the hammocks in the middle of a rainforest was a perfect way to end the perfect day! a MUST visit!!!!!
WOW!. Julio was a wonderful guide. the water in this cave is so pure. this was a great excursion to experience.

A MUST WHEN COMING TO PLAYA!. I am a local from Playa del Carmen and have been to Rio Secreto 4 times!!! Is my favorite tour BY FAR!!!!!! Every time I have guests coming to visit... I take them to Rio Secreto. The feeling you get when you get inside the underground river is unexplicable... an experience that everyone must try once in a lifetime!!!! In addition, all the guides are very knowledgeable and explain you every single detail on the color, forms, etc.... All the surroundings are breathtaking and you feel blessed to be able to see what nature has taken to build millions of years!!!!! ... MUST MUST MUST!!!!! worth every single cent. P.S. remember to not bring any deodorant or sunscreen as they really preserve the underground river!

Rio Secreto was Absolutely Beautiful. Our guide - RAUL - was FANTASTIC. He was knowledgeable, entertaining and fun to be with. I would recommend EVERYONE to check out Rio Secreto and say hi to Raul!!!

Jean Paul is the man!! Fun trip!. Great tour! We had so much fun on this tour. Jean Paul was our guide and man does he have a passion for what he does! It was so refreshing to see someone love what they do. We received a little Mayan cultural lesson as well as geology and conservation message. Such a good tour and a must! Ride out to the river is pretty bumpy in the van but fun and completely doable. Food was amazing and cooked right there at camp. Go on this tour and ask for jean Paul!

An Awesome Experience!. My husband and I went to the Rio Secreto on August 23, 2012. A 25 minute ferry ride (can be rough so if you get motion sickness, do plan for that ahead) to Playa del Carmen and we met with our guide to the Rio Secreto, Tomas. He was very friendly to our group (8 total) and made sure we got back to the ferry on time in the afternoon. Tomas and a driver brought us to the Rio Secreto about 20 minutes from the ferry dock. I will tell you that the dirt road into the reserve is rough and has many potholes, but the driver does his best not to make it too rough. once at the main part of the reserve, we met our underground guide, Jean-Paul. He was also great. He fitted all of us with water shoes, wet suits, and life jackets, and after an introduction about the underground river (how it was accidentally found) and the surrounding jungle, we were off. We walked a short 10 minute hike into the jungle where we met with a Mayan priest. He blessed us and protected us from the Mayan Gods before we went in the caves. There are no words to really describe what we had the privilege of seeing. Beautiful stalagmites and stalactites of different colors, along with coral (on the roof of the cave) that was once under the ocean. At one point we stopped and just sat in a circle, turned out our headlamps, and listened to the sounds of the water and the cave. Jean-Paul was very knowledgeable about all points and stops during our underground tour. He also told us where to walk and what not to touch, how to swim, etc. The swim in the river is not too tough and everyone helps each other out up and down the climbs and drops. I was a little apprehensive about the swimming part, but a simple dog paddle is all that was needed. After an hour and a half in the cave we were back above ground. We were served a nice lunch of different flavored waters, soup, tacos, tamales, rice, fruit, etc. That was delicious and the whole group enjoyed the meal together at one table. There are also photos of your adventure underground available for purchase. We purchased all the photos on a CD ($70 US) so we could show our family all we were able to see. There are also single prints for purchase if you desire. If you ever get the chance, you should experience this. It is dark, and at times it does become tight quarters, but if you can handle that and are in reasonably good shape, you should be good to go. We agree with the other reviews in saying that it was very organized, friendly, and professional from beginning to end. Not just any cave, but a fragile, living, breathing eco-system. An amazing, breathtaking tour that we are so glad we did and we will never forget.

Excellent and a real Cenote!. My girlfriend and I visited during August and we were blown away by this tour. I've been to other cave and cenote tours in the past, but this one really topped it off. The tour called for a hike through a cave with obstacles that requires some team effort, some swimming and picture taking. It wasn't utterly challenging, but it's definitely an experience. I was a bit apprehensive at first in reading some of the reviews that complained about the picture taking, but after realizing that normal point and shoot travel cameras can't capture pictures as accurately - due to darkness and the terrain (i.e. can slip or hurt yourself while navigating and taking pictures), i think having a professional photographer there added to enjoying and sharing the experience with friends and family. Our tour guide, Lia, was great and helped ease my girlfriend's nerves as she couldn't swim... I had to do a lot of negotiating and even had to compromise sitting through a 50 minute spa treatment with her, so I could drag her to come. But in the end, she definitely enjoyed the experience and was happy that she came along.The tour provides water shoes, wet suit, life vest, and helmet with a light, so all you need is to bring a bathing suit. And the tamales during lunch were also great. The bus ride on route is a bit bumpy, but i think they fixed the AC problem as the buses we took all had AC, which wasn't bad at all.This excursion is definitely a to-do on your vacation list!

Life changing and breathtaking experience!. The last time I was in this area (about 8 years ago) Rio Secreto had not even been discovered- and what an amazing discovery it is! This is an opportunity to explore hidden underground caves, and swim an underground river with millions of breathtakingly beautiful stalagtite/stalagmite rock formations and crystal clear water. It was kind of an impulse decision for us to go, but it turned out to be both a spiritual and family bonding experience we would not have missed for anything. What an opportunity we have been given- to see a place like this!That said, this excursion is not for everyone. Use your good judgement here- if you are elderly, or overweight, not in decent shape, or have trouble walking or any other sort of infirmity, you should really pass on this- you will most likely have a hard time, and it's not fair for the guides or the other people on the trip.We didn't know what to expect at all, so I will try to give a good description. First, yes it is a little expensive, but understand this is NOT Xel-ha, where they can run thousands of people thru per day. This company is very sensitive to keeping the ecological balance, and showing proper respect to the site- and part of this is having small groups that are carefully guided through. It's pretty small guide to group ratio- as it should be. The tour has to remain financially viable for those that run it, if people want to continue to have access to this amazing place. And that is what you are paying for, so keep that in mind before you complain about the price. It most certainly is NOT a tourist trap.When you first get there, you board a van that goes 7 km thru a kinda crazy bumpy road into the jungle. You get tossed around a bit, and the vans are understandably torn up. I do think it would make sense for them in the long run to invest in vehicles with sturdier tires and suspensions, for the longevity of the vehicles and visitors' comfort.Once you arrive, you get a short presentation to let you know the basic rules and what to expect. Then you get a locker and they provide you with helmet, lifevest, watershoes, and wetsuit. The wetsuit can be a little bulky but I recommend wearing it, if you are sensitive to the cold. It is not terribly cold at all, but I was happy to have the suit. You are in a group of about 12-15 people and assigned a guide. Our guide was Jovana, and she was great- personable, very knowledgeable and made sure each person in the group was doing okay.You take a short hike through the jungle and arrive at the entry spot where you take part in a Mayan blessing with a priest. I felt this was a considerate thing to do, and showed respect for this sacred site- they are clearly not just trying to rush big groups through here.The first part of the trip through the caves was probably the toughest, as you are having to navigate over lots of rock formations, and it can be slippery in spots and hard to see where you are stepping or how deep the water is, in the spots where you walk thru shallow water. It's especially tricky because you are not supposed to touch the rock formations or you will permanently harm them. Makes it hard to balance though. It's a beautiful walk though, and our guide provided good instruction as well as lots of interesting information.Then comes the really magic part- you get into the deeper water portion and swim through the caves. It's a leisurely pace, with plenty of time to take everything in and enjoy and absorb it. We never thought we would ever have the chance to ever see anything like this- it is an incredible opportunity and one that really should not be missed- I would pick this over almost any other excursion offered. We have a 12 and 14 year old, and both did fine physically and were amazed at the beauty of the site. You really work as a team with the other people- helping each other across each obstacle, and keeping together in a line as you move thru the caverns. It is a wonderful experience.After you emerge, there's another short hike back, and they serve you lunch, after a toast with a Mayan liqueur. Believe me you will be hungry! We found the traditional Mayan Lunch to be very delicious. Once you finish you can lounge in hammocks until the transport is ready to take you back.My one complaint: the photo set up. I know part of the reason they do this is to maintain the financial viability of this, but the prices are truly ridiculous. If they were sensible, I think they'd find they would sell many, many more pictures. I'm sorry, but $25 for one picture is way too much. If the photos were $15 I probably would have bought 2 or 3! And if they were thinking through how they do the digital pictures, they could sell those to people for $5-8 apiece and just give them a code so they could log in and download the pictures when they got home. It would eliminate the need for CDs, and the only costs on their end would be server space and the photographers. And people would be able to afford a souvenir of their visit. I was really disappointed that after such a magical experience for my family we had no photos. But after spending over $350 for all 4 of us to go, we just didn't feel good about putting out $25 for one picture, and couldn't afford $69 for the disc- nor we're we inclined to have to safely get a CD all the way home.That aside, this is an opportunity of a lifetime, that I am so grateful we were able to experience. High praise to the company for their care and respect of the site, and for having such a friendly, thoughtful and able bodied staff. We came out truly feeling that we had taken a spiritual journey. If you are in the Mayan Riviera area, don't miss the chance to do this!
Very different activity. Great attraction. Very seldom can someone walk into a beautiful subterranean river. Do it!! It is very well organized and very professional. You will not regret it.
amazing cave. My buddy and I were here while it was not that busy at all.The cave was like it should be.A must do when you{re in the area!

AMAZING!!!. My boyfriend and I had an amazing time here! Rodrigo was an amazing guide! He took us on the 'Joy' path. I highly recommend asking to take this route. My only critique is that the food at lunch could use a bit of work. Overall it was an amazing experience and would recommend to everyone.

#1 Must visit attraction in the Riviera Maya. This was one of the coolest and most memorable experiences on our trip to Playa Del Carmen this August. The views of the cavern are breathtaking and the professional pictures they take are well worth the money. After arriving to the site, you will meet your guide (ours was Alfredo), and take a 10 minute bus ride to the cave site. There, a shaman will bless you as you enter the Mayan "underworld", then you basically walk right down to a huge hole in the ground and descend into an awe-inspiring landscape of crystal clear water, millions of stalactites/mites, and even a few bats. You will walk, wade, and swim through the caves for about an hour and a half, as your guide teaches you about the caves and rock formations, and your other guide takes beautiful photos of your experience. After you exit the caves you will be treated to a small mexican lunch buffet and are able to lounge around in hammocks as you wait for your pictures to be ready. The guides are very passionate about what they do, our guide Alfredo personally shared with us that he is living his dream and has been exploring cave systems for over a decade. They will go out of their way to make you feel comfortable and safe along the way. The only con: The photos are sort of pricey, but well worth it. We bought a cd with pics of us and the caves, got two teeshirts, and a bottle of Mexican liquor for $99USD. After seeing our pictures all of our friends are jealous that we got to experience this. Overall, if you are looking for an excursion in the Riviera Maya, this is definitely the most exciting. You must see it to believe it! You wont regret it, and will never forget it.

Great!. This was truly an amzaing adventure. Our guide Benito was excellent and so informative. The cave was in it's original condition, with no electricity or man-made additions. Truly a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. You'll be sorry if you don't go on this tour!

FANTASTIC. I had read all the reviews and they are right, the boat trasnfer is 45 mins, the first transfer thru town about 15 mins then about 20 mins up a bumpy roadOnce you reach the main complex in the jungle your guide meets you and it all falls into placeTHey have you shower and then kit you up with wetsuits, lifevest and helmets and water shoes!I would suggest traveling in shorts and shirt change in swimsuit then shower after and change back they provide towels and everything the place is flawlessly cleanI cannot describe the actual caves and it would take too long BUT THE ENTIRE EXCURSION IS FANTASTICThey sell a CD of pics for $69 which I thought was not a bad dealThey provide an excellent lunch THIS EXCURSION IS QUITE POSSIBLE THE BEST I HAVE BEEN ONWOULD HIGHLY RECOMMENDEmail me with any questions Ian and Nancy Orlando

Awesome!. This was by far one of the coolest things I have every done. My girlfriend was hesitant to do this but she couldn't be more happy that we did this. Our guide, Pablo, was great. I can't say there are too many things I'd like to do over and over again but this is one of them. After this amazing excursion, lunch was included on-site. The food wasn't great but it really wouldn't matter what they served after this excursion. The experience was that amazing!

Awesome but pricey. Pluses - excellent site, well managed, guide was excellent, lunch was good.Negative - waited around at the main site before transfer not knowing what was going on. Not necessarily over priced for the activity but the pictures that they want to sell (you can't take your own camera) were very over priced. But unless you only want your memories you're kind of between a rock and hard place.

Great Experience. From a carnival cruise ship, this was a seven hour excursion starting with a pleasant 40 minute ferry ride to the mainland from Cozumel. The staff let us know what was next and was professional. Next was the worst part, a 45 minute van ride, over 30 minutes of which was over terrible road...but hey,you are going 7 km into the jungle.Alejandro was our guide, and suited us up in wetsuits, life vests, and helmets with lights after a quick shower to get rid of any contaminants. A short walk through the jungle too, us to the entrance to the cave/aquifer complex. The formations were amazing! The water was cool and clean. At times we floated up to our necks viewing various cave formations, getting our pictures taken (for sale later, of course) and partaking in a couple Mayan rituals.Afterwards was a nice authentic Mexican buffet, and the trip home.It was a fantastic excursion, well worth the money.

Great family experience. My family (wife, myself, teen and adult children) took this excursion via Carnival Cruise Lines. We had an excellent time. The walk through the cavern was fun and informative. Our guide (Carin) was very interesting as well. This was probably the highlight shore excursion of our cruise. Lunch was provided as part of the tour, it was very nice as well. I would definitely recommend this excursion.

Rio Secreto. UNBELIEVABLE!!!!!!! Best excursion ever. Our guide Maurice was very knowledgeable and polite. The meal after was unexpected but was it GOOD. If you like caves and water you wont find a better trip! Cant wait to go back again.
magical experience. This was the most unique experience =) Paolo was a passionate and fabulous guide!If you do nothing else during your stay, do this!

STUNNING,AWESOME !!!. My husband and I Visited the Rio Secreto on aug-06-2012 ..This was by far the BEST excursion we have ever been on in mexico ...A MUST SEE if cave exploring is your thing .Very well organized 'very informative guide (ours was Ceclia). only draw back was the VERY bumpy ride through the jungle to get to and from the caves...other than that it is well worth every penny..would do it again in a heart beat !!!!!!

Truly Amazing!!!!. This is just an amazing experience! The caverns were only just discovered in 2006 and first opened to the public in '08. They are still exploring them- sooo extensive--and plan to open another section in October of 2012. I was speechless. So beautiful. Not ruined by commercialism but maintained in its natural state. And the guides insure it by expressing the importance of not touching everything. You walk through, wade through, and swim through the caverns, admiring the stalagtites and stalagmites in all of their hatural beauty (and some of the negotiation between them is tight but so cool). We had a fantastic guide, Mauricio, whose enthusiasm and knowledge was infectious. They have a few areas where you can stop to take photos, and their photographer will take them. You have the option to buy all of the photos or pick and choose. The cd with all pix was only $69 and totally worth it I think for memories like this--I mean, seriously, this is not something you can do anywhere, in fact, I imagine it is a 1 of a kind experience. I would recommend it for all ages- our group ranged from 25-68, I even saw other groups with 5 year olds! They provide you with shoes, a wetsuit, a life vest, and a helmet, as well as optional walking sticks, which even I opted for to help feel my way around the rocks--very helpful! Lunch was terrific- traditional authentic mexican fare, and as a vegetarian there was a great deal for even me to choose from. The entire excursion lasted about 6 hours. The only 'not so fun' thing was the drive from the welcome are to the site itself. The roads are far from smooth and the bumps are unbelievable! The entire rear portion of the van slides wildly left to right as the driver tries to avoid the 'bigger' bumps! It felt like driving on ice with giant holes. A rather unpleasant 20 min ride. I imagine in time they may be able to pave these roads, if funds allow for it. Regardless, the ride is negligible when compared to this truly amazing experience! I can't wait to go back!

Incredible experience. In all the yucatan peninsula is about cenotes, caves full of fresh water, the underground rivers. But Río Secreto its part of this but it is more for expeleology, they give you a bodyglove, special shoes and a helmet with a lamp, no one place but RS does this, and is because you need it. The 80% of the tour is about walk un low level water caves and we saw a small snake, blind fishes, a inside cave which looks like natural jacuzzi and a hoot. The experience was amazing!

Awesome!!!. One of our ports was Cozumel and our kids wanted to try something new so we picked Rio Secreto... We did see some reviews that it was fake... There was 7 of us ages 14 to 65 and we all enjoyed it. Our guide Jean Paul gave us tons of facts and was really friendly. The caves were beautiful not to mention that after the tour we got to eat some great food there....the picture cd was $69.00 at first we thought wow pricey but reality is the pics were way better than if we were to take them plus our whole family were in the pics instead of one of us missing Because one of had to snap the shots.

A Must!!. This is an absolute must for anyone able to do it. This is a truly magical experience. Rio Secreto was only discovered in 2006, so this is a vastly unexplored underground cave. It is located on a very large property that is pretty untouched as far as development, there is a welcome area, a small shop and bathroom facilities. There is also a small sitting area where you wait for your ride to the cave entrance. You can purchase native juices or other treats at the small store/coffee shop. Once you take a ten minute ride in their van to the cave entrance, you are assigned a locker (you keep the key until you return), more bath and shower areas and changing areas. They provide wetsuits, watershoes, lifevests and a helmet with a light to help you view the wonders of the cave. After a brief history of the cave and the Mayan culture that was present in that area, you take a short walk to a Mayan Shaman, who blesses you after you 'ask permission' of the gods to enter the sacrad place now called Rio Secreto. You then climb down into the mouth of the cave and then the story begins of its history as well as safety measures. After that, you begin to walk through the cave and water. The water is strangely white, from the calcium and other minerals. We were lucky enough to see the 'white blind fish' that only sometimes appear during tours. Also, the water was pleasantly cool, not cold, cool. You are not allowed to touch anything on the inside of the cave because the oils of our hands can corrode the minerals. They do offer walking sticks if you have trouble with balance. There is a place where you have to swim, so if you're not a good swimmer, they won't allow you to go inside. There is a photographer that follows you throughout the cave and takes plenty of pictures of you and your group so you have lots to choose from. You have options to purchase a CD of pictures, shirts and even a liquor that they produce from some of the native plants. The more people are in your group, the longer the tour takes. With four people the tour took us about two hours. I beleive the limit of people is ten, so that of course would at least double the time. Everyone was very friendly and if you are looking for an english speaking tour guide I highly recommend Benito. He was friendly, very knowledgeable and very fun.

A once in a lifetime experience. A must-do for eco & adventure enthusiasts! This is probably the least "touristy" feeling of the toursity things to do. Our guide Benito was great- he really knew his archaeology and was very respectful of the environment and the cenote. If you ever wanted to be in the movie "The Goonies" now's your chance...but beware, you have to be in somewhat decent shape to enjoy it.
Amazing!. Short and sweet -- by far the greatest adventure I have ever been on. Do not miss this! Ask for Gonzo as your guide if you can!
Money Grab. Loved the experience!!Hated the fact that all excursions in this country seem to be a money grab !!!

Highlight of our holiday. Rio Secreto is an incredible sight made even better by the enthusiasm of the river guides. Rodrigo was an outstanding guide who clearly loved his job and the caves. Absolutely fantastic day.

amazing place with great rock formation. I went to Rio Secreto on my own and was put in a small group with 2 couples. We had a great guide, a Costan Rican lady, very helpful and she gave us a lot of information. The tour through the water through the caves is breathtaking, great what nature did with the stalactics and stalagmites. Sometimes the floor was a bit rough and we couldn't see well. After the tour we good some delicous Mexican food. This is probably one of the best attraction on Riviera Maya,although a bit expensive.

Stunning tour of a national treasure. After much consideration we chose Rio Secreto for our cruise expedition, the reviews were good and we hoped to experience something unique as well as educational. We were not disappointed, the trip began with a ferry ride, approx 35 minutes, smooth water that day but we've been told it can get quite rough so take some dramamine if you're prone to motion sickness. We were then greeted enthusiastically by our guide and escorted to a "semi" airconditioned van. The van travels through the city and then takes you down a roller coaster of a dirt road which winds through the jungle and ends at the little village of Rio Secreto. You then divide into groups of approx 10, change into bathing suits and/or wet suits if you like, shower to remove all oils and chemicals from your body to protect the river and lock your belongings in a locker. You're guide will provide you with a life vest, water shoes and a lighted hard hat. As you head toward the river on foot your next stop is the Mayan Shaman who provides a blessing, the Rio Secreto is considered a hallowed place which requires your body and mind to be cleansed before you may enter. Our guide Alfredo was both informative and genuine in his love for the caves. A twenty year veteran of cave exploration, Alfredo was respectful and grateful for the opportunity to work in such spectacular natural wonder. You then enter the caves and the journey begins. There is nothing commercial about this tour, you will make your way through the caves step by step, feeling your way "with confidence" says Alfredo. It would be easy to slip and fall so take it slow and don't try this if you've had recent knee surgery or back problems. There is a photographer following you at all times snapping pictures which can be purchased at the end of the trip. The river winds and bends, offering a multitude of opportunities to appreciate the underground wonders of Rio Secreto, stalagtites, stalagmites, natural formations, sink holes, underground pools and a moment of the most complete darkness and silence as you wade, shuffle and swim through approx 1 1/2 hours of exploration. Alfredo kept a close eye on the group offering a helping hand when needed as well as encouraging questions as he taught us about his beloved caves. At the end of the tour we returned to our lockers, offered iced tea or a sample of a homemade Mexican liqueur then treated to a delicious Mexican lunch of tortillas and salad, beer and soda are offered at a reasonable price if desired. We were then left to rest for a bit in a garden area complete with hammocks and rustic chairs until the van returned for the ride home. A complete CD of your pictures is available for $69, you can also purchase a Tshirt as part of a package. Per our guide the property above Rio Secreto belongs to the owner who discovered the entrance to the caves six years ago. Mexican law claims all underground property and the caves are considered a national treasure. We loved this trip and considered it a privilige to be allowed to participate in what has to be one of the most beautiful places on earth. Thanks again Alfredo! A trip we'll never forget.

Amazing Underground River-Gorgeous. We went to Rio Secreto on the spur of the moment, met up with the rest of our group at a large palapa where they also had a coffee shop, cold wet paper towels to cool off, pretty lawn chairs and gardens. After a brief presentation, we embarked on probably the bumpiest ride I've ever been on to the cenote. We had lockers and took showers before getting in wetsuits and hard hats. Our tour guide was Benito, he was very informative about the formations (we had been snorkeling at Hidden Worlds and it was nowhere near as decorated). He told us about the water minerals and how it forms different shapes and colors as it drips through the limestone. Your hands are really soft after you've been in this water awhile and it is a fairly long tour. Benito could tell I was the clumsy one so I made sure to stay close to him, it is hard to get your footing because you want to look all around you. They do take photos of you that are beautifully set and lit-they take the lighting out after the last tour. Danny was our photographer-he would really try to make sure the photos were good. The photos were way too expensive though. $69 is as much as the tour. I would have liked to have photos, but couldn't justify the cost. We were lucky enough to see the blind fish, cave spiders, bats, and a muk muk (bright blue) bird. The moment of silence so far underground in the large cavern was a great experience as was being blessed by the Mayan shaman before entering the cave. It was just as incredible all throughout the cave as the entrance going down the stairs and climbing out into the sunshine at the end. We tried some anise liquor and had a vegetarian lunch, use the yellow dressing on the salas, empanadas, and plaintains were good. We tried the chala drink, very "healthy" tasting. We highly recommend this, especially if you've never been floating in a cenote before, this is the one to see!

A Bucket List Type Attraction. I took this tour with my wife and two daughters - ages 11 and 15. One of the best experiences - and values of the trip.
As long as you're prepared for the light physical side of the tour, and don't panic in deep water, I can't imagine that you won't love the tour. The caves are amazing.

AMAZING!. My boyfriend and I visited Rio Secreto in May 2012, as an excursion on a Caribbean cruise. The entire trip was absolutely amazing! Be sure to follow the directions to prepare yourself: they make you rinse off under a shower prior to going into the caverns. It helps to preserve the natural state of the water and structures. Had I truly known, I would not have lathered with sunscreen and other lotions, hairsprays etc before leaving the ship! The tour itself is incredible. The caverns are breathtaking, and words truly can not describe them! They provide you with lockers, as you are not allowed to bring ANYTHING into the caverns (no hats, sun glasses, watches, camera etc). They provide wet suits and water shoes, however we were able to use our own water shoes. There are facilities for bathroom and changing purposes. Our guide was amazing (they deserve their tips!). It is obvious that the guides truly honor the privilege of being allowed in the caverns, as they consistently promote nature preservation. The food afterward was also phenomenal! You will not leave hungry! Although, be sure to bring cash for purchasing carbonated beverages (there is beer for purchase!) and also for purchasing pictures. The picture is worth the $$!! I can't say enough positive words about the experience.

A Must Do!!. Went with several girlfriends on this excursion in July 2012. This is definitely a must do on your list if you are in Cancun/Playa area. The fee is very reasonable for what you get and it's pretty much all inclusive except getting to/from original check in point. You check in one area, then there is a van that takes on you on a 10/15 min bumpy ride to the actual location right where the cave is. You change into a wetsuit and life jacket and water shoes, you are also given a locker for your personal belongings. Our guide was amazing (forgot his name, thin gentleman), however he was just so knowledgeable and so passionate about the nature and history of the cave. The caves were one of the coolest things I have ever seen. There were a couple parts where you do have to swim there (no fear for non swimmers as the life jacket keeps you afloat while you paddle). Rio Secreto is something you will not see anywhere else.Also the neat thing about the excursion is there is a professional photographer who accompanies the group. At the end there are a couple options to purchase. A disk full of the photos is about $69 USD, not bad. After the tour of the cave, a small simple Mexican lunch is included which is a nice surprise. It's nothing fancy so don't expect a whole lot. Overall, I agree with other reviewers, this was one of the best excursions!

You wont be disappointed. This is one heck of an excursion. I had fairly high expectations for this and was therefore a bit apprehensive of being let down. No chance of that.Our guide was Lia who was fantastic. The cave system just has to be seen to be believed. There was ten of us in the group, 3 couples and our family of four. I'm not sure who enjoyed it the most, the kids with their eyes wide at every new marvel, or the adults with their eyes wide at every turn of the cave...The DVD they offer at the end is very well worth the extra cost, the pictures they took of our family were absolutely perfect.If you have the time, we highly recommend this tour.
Fullness surprise. This is the best excursion experience I have ever had in my life. It is like a piece of paradise or heaven on earth. Pablo was our tour guide and he is amaizing!!!
Cool place... Benito was our guide. My 8 y.o. loved it. It was far away from my cruise ship, but I would do it again.

Amazing Secret River. All I can say is do not miss this tour. The Amazing Secret River excursion booked thru Carnival Cruise lines is by far the best tour that I have ever booked. Our tour guide Mauricio was very informative and friendly as was everyone associated with the tour. We were picked up at the dock and went to the cave by van. We then rinsed off under a shower to get all the oils off our skin before entering the cave. We were given water shoes, wet suits, life vests and helmets with a light attached. We were divided into groups of 8-10 with each group having their own guide. The groups were spaced out so that the tour was very personal and you felt like your small group was the only one in the cave. There was also a discrete photographer that followed each group to take pictures as you were not permitted to take a camera with you. Part of it was shallow and was more like hiking and part of it we had to swim. The entire cave was beautiful and breathtaking. You were told to try to not touch anything because the oil from your skin would be damaging. They offer walking sticks to increase your stability. Our family was a group of 8 ranging in age from 17 to 79 and was enjoyed by all. The 79 year old was also assisted and helped by our guide when needed. There are parts of the cave where there is not much clearance between the water level and the roof of the cave ~ just enough for your head and helmet to pass thru. The tour was truly AMAZING! I also enjoyed the lunch after the tour that was also included. I thought the CD for purchase that included over 60 pictures that were taken by the photographer was also very reasonable. They had different packages for purchase. I believe we paid $90 for the package containing the CD of over 60 pictures (which were AMAZING) and 3 shirts in whatever sizes we wanted. (I think the CD on it's own was $60) When you consider that the pictures taken on the cruise ship run anywhere from $10 to $20 and above for ONE picture ~ I think the price was very reasonable in comparison. Yes, if you were permitted to take your own camera you could take pictures for free, but I don't think you would be able to get the same shots and you would be missing half the tour trying to get your shots. It's worth it to buy the pictures of this experience. I can not recommend this tour enough! :)

A must do. This tour was excellent. The ride to the cavern was very bumpy. You are asked rinse off to keep the water as untainted as possible ( in case you have lotions or sunscreen on your skin). We were able to store our clothes and cameras in lockers (no cameras allowed in the cave) that were provided. We were given wet suits, life vests, water shoes and helmets with headlamps. We then had a short walk to the entrance during which we discussed the Mayan rituals, safety, etc. This activity is not difficult but it is challenging to walk through rough, bumpy cave paths, often in water unable to see your feet or touch the cave walls. The water was deep in a few areas and a little swimming was necessary. The whole cave experience took approx 90 min. There was a buffet lunch that was just OK. Our guide was Alfredo and he was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and engaging. This was an enlightening and incredibly beautiful experience. This was a reminder to take care of our planet and water system. I would definitely do this again the next time I come to Cancun! It was disappointing not to be able to take pictures. I did not think that the DVD was worth the price.

Rio Secreto a highlight or our trip!. Well worth the trip to Rio Secreto. It was one of the highlights of our trip. Rodrigo was a great guide and evey minute was breathtaking. We wish we could have been there longer....Marina wants to be a guide! The lunch was great. But I can just not say enough about the tour, not to miss.

Do not miss!. The Secret River excursion offered through Carnival cruise lines is something that should not be missed when in Cozumel/Playa del Carmen. This is a hike through a pristine cave discovered within the last 6-7 years. We were driven to the site 40 min from the dock in a van. Then we were asked to rinse off our sunscreen and chemicals to keep the water as untainted as possible. We were able to store our clothes and cameras in lockers (no cameras in the cave). We were given wet suits to use and offered water shoes (you can bring your own), and given helmets with headlamps. We then had a quick hike to the entrance during which we discussed the cave's discovery, Mayan rituals, safety, etc. Although the activity is not difficult, it is challenging to walk through rough, bumpy cave paths, often in water unable to see your feet. At a couple points the water was deep and a little swimming was needed (in life vests too). Someone here recommended taking the offered walking stick, and I would agree with that in hindsight. After the 1-2 hour cave experience there was a buffet of locally produced native cuisine that was delicious. Our guide was Jean Paul and he was spectacular-patient, knowledgeable, and engaging. This was an interesting and incredibly beautiful experience.

Breathtaking. This outing is definitely worth every penny and I would do it again in a heartbeat. I recommend this to anyone who is physically able. Since it has been maintained as naturally as possible there is quite a bit of unstable walking. We are both grandparents and were able to complete it without too much difficulty. The dvd they prepare for you at the end is a must have.

Incredible!. Jean was our guide. He was was multi-lingual and very knowledgable. Cant believe we crawled and swam through a cave! Accept a walking stick to increase stability. You will need it. Will remember this forever!

Do. Not. Miss. This!. Wow! Just wow! I have been on a lot of interesting outings, and have visited many caverns but this was fabulous. They have kept the caverns as natural as possible, with no improved paths or anything, something I have never seen. So you have to really clamber, wade, swim your way through. More of an untouched cave experience than any commercial cavern I have been to. The guide was excellent, explaining a lot abou the caverns, how it was formed, how the various formations came about (I have a geology degree, and he got it all right). They only let a limited number, about 90, people in each day, in groups of about 10. They serve a fabulous lunch buffet when you come out of the cave. Our group had 4 teens and 1 young girls and they loved it, as did the 6 adults. They also take fantastic pictures of each group and individuals during the tour that are worth buying at the end.It is a pretty long ride out from town, nearly an hour, but worth it.

Quite an Experience!!. Decided to go to Rio Secreto last minute and very glad we made that decision. It is quite an experince, amazing how nature build its own Art and compared to other places in Cancun, Rio Secreto tries to keep it as natural and spiritual as it is. It is a 3 hour tour (about 2 hours in the caves the other hour is transportation, food, and change of clothes). Our Tour Guide was wonderful on explaining everything and being patient and carefull with us. At the end of the tour you get also a very good buffet style lunch with authentic mayan food. I recommend this to anybody looking for unique way to see the "underworld" of the Mayans, and for all of those that wonder if its scary down there, I can tell you that I am a nervous person and I never felt claustrophobic or in danger.
AMAZING!. If you have the opportunity to see these cenotes, you must! It was an amazing experience that I will cherish for the rest of my life!

Really worth every penny!. If you like caves, this one is not to miss! It is just beautiful and well preserved. Our guide was very friendly and funny. You have a ride in the jungle and very little walk to do. They give you everything you need. No need to save passport and money in many zipblocs... They have lockers. You don't need to know how to swim (just let you float and move forward), but be aware you have to bend and walk on uneven rocks, in and out fresh (not freezing) water for 1h-1h30. No weird bugs or spiders, just a few catfish and bats. Food is served after the visit (included).Photos are expensive, but, hey! well done and you probably be in there once in a lifetime...
Wonderful place. This place its AMAZING!!.. This tour touched my heart!!.. Thanks to a great guide I learned a lot from the Mayan Culture. They were on time and made a WONDERFUL experience our visit.
Amazing. Me and my husband visited this place when we honeymooned in Mexico and it was just stunning, would certainly recommend to anyone.
Great Experience. Great experience. Make sure Linda is your guide. Very knowledgeable and patience. Breath taking experience.

Truly Amazing.. A fascinating and beautiful trip. The cave was spectacular. I took my two teenage sons and we all enjoyed the trip. The commute by vans was not too far from the port. The tour was not as rigorous as I thought it would be but it may not be as much fun if you do not know how to swim. They provide a locker, wetsuit, water shoes, helmet, and life jacket. The water was very refreshing!There were eight in our group led by Alfredo. I could see the passion that Alfredo had for the area which projected to his explanations. All this and the value was very fair. Lunch was provided once the tour was complete.PS...I have never felt the need to write a review before; however, this is a tour that shouldn't be missed.
Excellent. We went here for a few hours and it was unlike anything Ive ever seen. Definitely recommend

Don't skip this place!!. Rio Secreto was one of the best things we did on our trip to Mexico. We stayed in Cozumel but took the ferry over to Playa de Carmen - from there we jumped in a taxi for the 10 minute ride. The provide everything you need for the exploring, even lunch and drinks (you have to pay for drinks) afterwards. Just bring your swimsuit. We have explored caves before, but not while swimming through them. Our guide Rene, was very knowledgeable about the eco system and the history. They take all the pictures for you and is completely worth is so that you are hands free and able to look around freely. Don't pass this up it was beautiful and great to experience an underground river in the middle of the jungle!
AMAZING. loved this! Great time in the cool underground river. knowledgeable tour guide. we enjoyed the food as well. not to be missed.

crazy cool experience. Dark, wet caves? That did not sound too appealing to me but my boyfriend wanted to go. However, after reviewing the pictures and reading some reviews online, I was intrigued.They picked us up from our hotel. We arrived and had to take another bus to get closer to the caves. It was the bumpiest ride ever on a dirt road. We should have been on a Jeep/Hummer or even a horse would have been better to ride.I was scared but I am definitely glad I did it. I'm also a germaphobe so I was nervous about the wetsuit thing but it was no big deal... I didn't try to smell it though... LOL. You put it on wet and wear your bathing suit underneath. Note the wetsuit is however optional but I recommend it as it provides some padding in case you rub against a rock or something, which is inevitable. Hard hats with lights and a life vest is mandatory and provided for you.Bring your own water shoes cuz using old wet shoes is especially nasty. In case you don't have your own, they have water shoes you can borrow. I was about to wear my Teva close toed sandals but I don't think those would have flied... I wore my Speedo water shoes instead and our tour guide checked the bottom of my soles. I think they want the soles to be pretty smooth so you don't disturb the area too much. Please note that it is pretty uneven terrain on the short hike before you even get to the caves... like if you aren't careful, you could twist your ankle. In the caves it's kind of more treacherous as you can't see the floor through to the bottom so you don't know what kind of terrain is underneath.They require you shower off beforehand but no one explained why until we were already in the caves. I barely made an effort to shower cuz I wanted to keep my sunblock/repellent on. Our tour guide showed us that even the natural oil of our bodies disturbed the natural balance of the water in the caves... she touched her face and then touched the water and the calcium carbonate layer on the top of the water spread apart from where the contact was! Please rinse off well and don't bother with sun block since you won't need it underground. The views are spectacular and unreal. Our tour guide's name I think was Adriana. She was very knowledgeable but sometimes it was difficult to understand her English. I can't really swim well. Make sure you tell your guides if that is the case for you. She let me walk in front of the rest of the group so I could be directly behind her so she could help me. During parts where you have swim, she let me hold on the strap behind her vest and just pulled me in the water. You aren't like hella swimming at any point... you have to paddle your arms underneath the water to minimize waves disturbing the area. At some points I was just floating in my vest and paddling through the water by myself. Note the swimming is minimal as you never submerge your head under the water. Sometimes the ceiling was less than 2-3 feet from our heads so it was a crazy experience.No cameras allowed. They sell you pics on a CD at the end. Too expensive. We only bought one for $25 USD.Stay single file in the caves and watch where the person ahead of you steps and try to follow. Point your lights to the ground where you walk. They have waterproof cases for your inhaler if you're asthmatic. I didn't even bring my inhaler but luckily no attacks for me. Air was cooler in the caves.Small buffett lunch served afterwards. Lockers provided beforehand.

Absolutely amazing.. My girlfriend and I took our five kids because my son wanted to go spelunking. We thought we were doomed when the kids started complaining about putting on the wetsuits even before we got into the cave. Our tour guide, Mauricio, was great with the kids. Once we got into the caves we were all spellbound. The cave was wide open and lit by or helmets so none of us ever felt claustrophobic, which had been a concern. Our guide showed us all kinds of cool stuff and swimming in the cave was really amazing. Afterwards we asked everyone to rank the experience and all five of us gave it a 10, adults and kids alike. Getting the kids to agree on anything without bickering is a feat, so the fact that we all agreed says something. It was the best excursion we have been on in any vacation, ever. I ended up with poison ivy from the walk to the cave-- the guide warned us but be careful!

Do NOT pass this up!. My husband and I took this tour while on the Disney Fantasy this past April. We had not heard of this tour before we boarded the ship but we saw that this was only tour that was sold out prior to departing Port Canaveral. Just seeing that, we HAD to see what this was all about and we went on a waiting list for an opening. To our surprise, two spots opened up later that evening and our tour advisor insisted we don't pass up this opportunity to visit the Secret River. I'm so glad we were able to expeince this. No pamphlet, review site, tour guide, r website comes close to accurately portraying what lies beneath the surface deep into where you will venture. Shortly after a native blessing ceremony, which I now see why they do after what our journey entailed, we descended deep into the caves. Our guide was very detailed and clear as to what was ahead, how we were to walk, when to swim, and made me feel so comfortable in the darkness of the caves. I must say I was shocked a few times during our tour, to the extent at which we were maneuvering through teeny, tiny spaces. At one point we were swimming through the water and were told to submerge ourselves so that only our nose and head be out of the water due to the low cave ceiling literally inches above our helmets. I am terrified of enclosed spaces and I will admit and I never felt uncomfortable or nervous. It was probably better that I didn't know the extent of the small spaces we would be in ahead of time, I may have backed out. But, I am sooooooo glad I did this and we say that we would do it again in a heartbeat when we return on a future cruise. The pictures they offer you are a little pricey but oh so worth it. It's a great memory of where you were and what you saw. You wont find anything else like this in the world. Please take our recommendation and do this tour!

Our amazing adventure. My husband, granddaughter and I just came back from a cruise on the Oasis of the Seas. We decided to take the Rio Secreto tour in Mexico because I love spelunking (cave exploring). It was the most amazing adventure I have ever experienced. Our tour guide Jean was excellent. He made sure we were well-prepared and safe. He explained everything in detail. We all had our wetsuits and life vests on and proceeded to tour the cave. It was breathtaking. The stalagmites and stalactites were wonderful. To be able to walk then swim was such an adventure. I still can't believe we explored this natural cave and saw its incredible beauty. This experience will be forever etched in my memories. Thank you Jean for the great tour and education on this gorgeous cave. Just a note: lunch was provided for free. Also, you could purchase pictures at a decent price. You will want to get the pictures because this is an experience of a lifetime.

A must go!!!. If you can ask for tour guide Pablo, guy is just genuine, spiritual and great communication skills. He made our visit very worth our time, explained everything about the caves and really cares about the preservation of this amazing place. The underground caves and river is just jaw dropping. Its not one of those places you say "oh been there once and thats enough" when I go back I definitely will go again!! amazing how well preserved they keep it.

Amazing Experience. One of the best tours we have ever done. The shaman's blessing at the beginning of the tour was a neat experience and was great to experience a little more culture then just the environment. Everything we needed was provided, towels, wet suits, water shoes, etc. They also give you lockers for free to hold your stuff which was nice for the peace of mind. The tour was amazing, a beautiful natural wonder that is completely worth seeing. The company takes VERY good care of the cenotes. They stress heavily to follow them through completely so less of the cave is damaged, as well as encourage showers before to not pollute the water with sunscreen or other lotions. Our tour guide, Pablo, was a REAL treat. One of the best so far, he spoke English very well, and went through instructions carefully and was very safe through out the tour. As well, he is quite the humorous guy! Absolutely, request him if you can!As well, the food after the visit was quite good too! it's not what you would find at the resorts, but if you are open to trying new things and tasting Mexican food cooked by the people themselves, this is a cultural treat you can't miss out on!Only issue was the pictures were EXTREMELY expensive, but the profits go to nature conservation for the park, so paying $25 USD for one photo was justified,

Best Day. Friend recommend and so glad this was the most amazing trip! We had the best tour guide - Gonzo! Best money spent. There are Cenotes every where but this is so different. 3 Hour tour plus lunch!

Nice 1/2 tour. We chose this tour because it sounded interesting but it was supposed to rain that day (it had rained all day the day we booked this) but it didn't. It would be a good rainy day choice. Our tour had transportation included and it was 20 minutes late, apparently he had to ask for directions, he also got lost on the way back! The tour itself for well run, and our guide was very helpful. There were just 6 of us on the tour so that was great, we always felt like we were the only ones down there. The walking through the cave was uneven but we never felt rushed and helped each other out. The rocks were sometimes uncomfortable with the thin water shoes. Some of the cave features were spectacular. I enjoyed the swimming part of the tour, and felt there could have been more of that. I also liked when we turned off our lights and floated in complete darkness, it was freaky! At the end of the tour we all had a shot of a Mayan liquer, it was okay if you like black licorice. Then we looked at the pictures (a photo guy is with you, you can't bring cameras with). We were planning on buying the photo cd, $69, and it is high priced but single prints were $25. So since we were planning on buying the cd at the start we posed well for pics. There is another package for around $90 that included the cd, 2 tee shirts, and a bottle of the mayan liquor. AFter that we got back into our normal clothes. It was a little gross using the shoes and wet suit but I didn't break out into a terible rash. They do provided a locker for you to use, so that was nice. Lunch was provided and it was okay. I would have rather skipped it and went back to the resort. Lunch was really all carbohydrates, no meat provided. And since I'm diabetic, a lunch of all carbs isn't a great idea. The lime soup and the spinach tamales were the best part of the lunch. I wouldn't do the tour again (been there done that), however it was a neat experience. I liked that it didn't last all day, and if it had been raining it would have been a good way to beat the rain. If you have questions please feel free to message me!

In top 3 of things you must see in Yucatan. This is a must see, one of the best attractions in Yucatan. Easy to reach via the 'collectivos' from Playa del Carmen. You cannot bring your own camera, a photographer of the organisation will go along, and you will pose in a number of locations. Admission is 69 USD pp, and the photo's are another 60 USD (per group), so quite pricey but worth it!

Wonderful Cruise Excursion. Our family did this as a cruise excursion from the Disney Fantasy when they docked in Cozumel. Our girls are 11 and 14 and absolutely LOVED this experience. They supply all that you need, the water shoes, helmets, wet suits, life jackets, lockers, and hard hat with light. All of it feels clean. The changing areas and restrooms are clean. We started in Cozumel and the excursion company met us the moment we stepped foot off the ship and escorted us the whole way. We took a ferry from Cozumel to Playa Del Carmen. Then they broke us up into groups of 10. From Playa Del Carmen, they supplied transport to the Rio Secreto. The road to Rio Secreto is long and BUMPY. A ride in itself. But once there, you see that this is a top-notch, newer attraction. (I asked and it is only about 4 years old.) The facilities seem newer, but you do not lose the charm of this ancient land. Our guide was Gonzo and met us when the taxi dropped us off and stayed with us until the end. He was excellent with kids. We had a 5 year old in our group and he took special attention to keep an eye on her.Our girls LOVED floating through the underground river. They were never scared. The guide ensures that the group of 10 rotates, so that everyone gets a chance in front and a chance to bring up the rear. A photographer is with you the whole way and takes GREAT pictures. The CD purchase is worth it. We had a lunch served after the walk and we were surprised at all that they had. It was wonderful and very filling.The taxi took us back to Playa Del Carmen where we met our excursion guide. We were given 1 hour to walk around town. The town seems nice and quaint, but we went straight to the beach and had about 45 min. to swim in the BEAUTIFUL ocean before we had to board the water ferry back to Cozumel and the ship.We highly recommend this! The off road ride is quite bumpy and you do have to crouch and duck through some of the walk. You have a life jacket to float through the very SLOW moving part that you cannot touch bottom on. The property is beautiful and we cannot say enough about the staff! A very different Mexican experience and it's in the SHADE the most of the time.
Don't miss this!. Spiritual, mystical and inspiring---an adventure like no other I have attempted---wow!

OMG Ah. Ma. Zing.. Seriously, when's the last time you swam about 70 feet underground? Rio Secreto is totally deep jungle mysterious coupled with being impossibly delicate and surreal. The guides go through great pains to keep the system pure and pristine as well as keeping you safe and relaxed to take it all in. The beauty of it is beyond this review box... trust me when I say it's a rare day out unless your some fearless cave diver or Jacques Cousteau-type. Most swimming levels can do the system but it helps if you're in decent physical shape. You'll bend and climb over rocks a fair bit. Most of it is fairly level but you have to stay alert constantly (I recommend NO hangover). I'd be more worried about people with claustrophobia issues. Some areas are a bit close (there's no squirming to get through places, however). Make sure to leave all sunscreens and make up off before you go. They'll just make you scrub it off (for very good reason) before getting your wetsuit. Water isn't too deep and you'll wish you could spend the whole day down there swimming with its beauty baiting you into wanting to take offshoots deep into the unknown (you can't -- they keep you accounted for at all times). Take in this natural wonder! It's breathtaking!!!

Wonderful Experience!. We thoroughly enjoyed this experience. It all went by so fast and we could have spent much more time in the caves. They were amazing! Our guide was sweet and very into her job. She had a lot of passion for the caves. The food afterwards was a traditional lunch and delicious. It was half a day well spent!

A must see!. If you want to do something while in Playa del Carmen, I can not recommend going here enough! This place is amazing and the guides (ours was Julio) really care about the environment! The guides take their time explaining everything about the cave system, what you can and can't touch as well as Mayan culture. It truly is like entering another world! It's a slow paced tour of caves, cenotes and underground rivers. There is so much to see that if you went back two or three times, you would see something different each time! Plus, they feed you a very nice lunch after your trip.Everything is included such as water shoes, wetsuit, floation jacket and helmet with light. They do take pictures while you are underground and they are available for purchase afterwards. But they are a bit pricey. Also, there is a 20 minute van ride from the welcome center to the actual cavern entrance. Seriously, the van ride is part of the adventure! It's like driving off road in a full size van. I think we caught some air time when we flew over one of the hills on the road.This really is something to see/do while you're in the area!
Best thing I did in Playa!. Benito was our tour guide and he was the very best!
Great underground river experience. More than a cenote, more than an underground river. An underground world of ancient Mayan culture. Experience for yourself, if you dare!

Not for us. Caves were beautiful but walk was too long and dark. Got really cold. Food was not good, beer was expensive and even though our resort wasn't that far we had to wait until they brought people to all the other resorts first. Not something we would do again.

Ethereal... a must do!. Great guide, unbelievable experience overall. Food was 'meh'.... but really who cares! The experience underground was right up there with diving in Roatan and watching the sun hit the Taj. Do this. You won't regret it. (just careful with small kids-- we saw a couple little ones get scared of the dark water and need to turn back). It is about 5 hours counting transportation.
Holy Moly. Take the long tour and dont settle for the short one. Its an experience of a lifetime so be sure to take your waterproof camera.

Beautiful! but the guide was a DEVIL!. Hello,Well last year we went with some friends to PDC and we thought I'd be interesting to take this tour to Rio Secerto! Well at first It was all very good, We were explained the rules,then got our Guide Kuri! At first he was nice, but then he turned into a Devil!!!! Our friend's 4 year old Daughter stepped on his foot (not on purpous) then he started to scream at her! After he was just crabby! He kept on Hurring us. We're with 4,6,11 and a 12 year old we'd remind him.. But after he kept on complating that we where the bad ones! He was YELLING AT US! Then wen we arrived back to "Base" He complanted to ALL his little friends and staff. Then the maneger heard and said: "Good afternoon, we would like to know what hapened with Kuri please" Then we explained everything above and they gave us a free visit back, but we did not execept. The place is beautiful, but if you get Kuri, I reccomend you leave or ask for another guide because he'll ruin your visit! (I think he was fired though!!(I hope so) )

nature's wonderland at a great price. I wish I'vecould have spent all day in this place. grwat peope and fantastic tour. The guide should have spent more time taking us deeper into the cave, but If you do not knw about Mexico's underworld, ths s a must see. the food is not great.

BEST CAVE TOUR I HAVE DONE. You cannot image how beautiful an underwater cave is until you see one in person. We recently visited Rio Secreto as an excursion though Carnival Cruise Lines and were blown away by the scenery as well as the experience and care the guides took. Our guide was Adrianna and you could tell very quickly that she not only took her job seriously, she was also VERY knowledgeable. We were fitted in wet suites, helmets and life jackets, then off into the forest we went. We asked permission of the Mayan Gods to allow us in the caves and keep us safe in a ceremony outside of the mouth of the cave. Our group of 9 (small which was nice...lots of individual attention), then headed into the caves. Adrianna and the other guides at Rio Secreto took special care to be sure our passing would be safe for us as well as for the caves, preservation of this special place was defiantly a priority. We spent over an hour wandering though the caves - in and out of water - seeing all sorts of cave formations. There was a photographer on the tour with us (provided by Rio Secreto) who took photos of us along they way. I knew in advance that we could not bring our own camera so I was prepared to spend money on the ones they took...that being said the photos were worth EVERY CENT! ALL of the photos were CRYSTAL clear, with PERFECT lighting and showed a bit of everything, With the personal photo package we also got a bunch of "stock photos" of the caves...82 in total for $69!! Having the photos taken for us meant we were free to take everything in, we had both hands for balance (which you need on an uneven cave floor), we did not have to worry about getting good lighting, or holding up the group while we tried to get the perfect shot....it was all done for us. After the tour we were provided with a snack which turned out to be a HUGE lunch with chicken soup, tamales, tacos, rice, beans and home made hot sauce and salsa...YUM!!! All we could say the whole trip was how cool it was and how beautiful the caves were. EVERYONE should experience this amazing place, you really need to see it to believe it!

Amazing, but disappointed. Cost for pictures is ri-donk-ulous.. Amazing, amazing experience, but I was so disappointed at the end. It kinda ruined it for me.Cancun is not cheap. The tacos taste delicious, but I can honestly find better mexican food for 1/2 the price here in LA. For me to spend $$ on something it has to be unique.The good- off the beaten path experience. I have been in caves in Thailand, but did not get to really explore far or have the experience of swimming through it. The guide was very good and it felt like a good amount of time down there (about 1.5 hours). This is like being in national geographic...you would never get to do this in the US.The not so great- the equipment is very smelly. I doubt that these are disinfected after each use. I don't understand the point of issuing wetsuits when they don't even fit. They are so oversized so they don't offer much warmth and rub. The water is surprising cold down there and you're in it about 60% of the time. It had just rained so the water level was high in there. If you have your own water shoes bring them. After this experience I have decided to for sure buy my own b/c the thought of ever wearing shoes that a ton of other people had their bare feet in grosses me out. The BAD- you cannot bring your camera into the cave. They have a photographer that follows the group around. The cost is ridiculous. $25/each for individual shots, $69 for the package. Really I only saw 2 pics that I liked of myself. The others were bad angles and not good. I was prepared for $5-10 each per pic thinking that I would just suck it up to buy 1 just to have the memory, but what they were asking for is not justified. Especially when all they are doing is burning a disk. From what I read on the reviews the resolution is not great so you cannot even make it bigger to print. For $69 you get your handful of individual/group shots and then a bunch of stock photos. Lame. I went to a really great cave in Thailand and the pics on my camera where much better quality than what was offered at Rio Secreto. After paying a high price for admission there should be better deals on pictures. I would rather pay a fee to bring my own camera. I understand that they would really have to limit this as you would miss out on the true cave experience with 6 flashes going off all the time. But I think people would be respectful enough to not take mulitple pics every 5 seconds. Or just have designated picture taking areas only. The meal at the end was just ok. Just eat enough not to passout and wait to eat at your hotel. Don't fill up on all that because the ride back to the main road is 20 minutes of bumps and swerving. Cost- I paid $99 and booked it through my hotel. Don't do that-- Do the research and find a better deal. A guy on my tour paid $75 through another company. Would I do it again- yes, but I would find a better deal. It's a very unique experience, just be ready to pay $$ for the memories. For that price I hope it's the right angle and you're happy with it. Looks like people uploaded some of the stock photos (just pics of the cave, no people) from their trip so I'm just going to lift these for free. Giving it a 4 rating just because it really is a cool site to see. *Not good if you have difficulty moving around (large ppl or older). It is narrow in there and I did incur a couple minor scrapes and bruises. *there are NO ATMS on site (so pull cash before you go for tipping). They only accept visa/mastercard for the pics. **excellent alternative on super rainy days.

Amazing for the whole family. So glad we did this. Went with out kids (6 and 9) on a rainy day. About 1.5 hours from Cancun. Beautiful setting. Bumpy, but fun van ride in to the site. They give you everything you need - wet suit, life vest, helmet, water shoes and towel in the end. Just wear a bathing suit and you are good to go. The tour was amazing - beautiful, tranquil, unique. Our guide, Adriana, was fabulous. She held on to our son the whole time and even carried him on her back much of the time. We only had 6 people in our group so it was a very intimate, personalized experience. Tasty lunch after. Pictures were very good, but expect to pay for them. Definitely a unique and special experience.

Great excursion, but I have some suggestions.. This excursion was very beautiful and exciting. Positives:Great tour guide (Mauricio) He was awesome. He was very helpful, sweet and just an all round great person. Spoke amazing english and really loves his job. The scenery is gorgeous inside the caves. You really feel like an explorer. The groups are small which is great.I did not feel rushed either...Negatives:You cannot take your own pictures and they charge 69$ if you want a cd with the pictures that they're photographer takes ...which are only like 8 of you and some are not even in focus. The quality of the images are also very poor....too small to enlarge. They should allow tourists to take their own photos. Tour should be slightly longer...like 30 minutes.The lights on the helmets are so poor that you can barely see the surroundings unless your tour guide point his flash light around. The equipment smelt very bad. The food that they serve afterwards is very basic and not quality at all. They only offer water to drink, unless you pay.

Beautiful underground tour and swim. This attraction is new(ish) and still in development, but even the long bumpy ride to ( and from ) the area didnt detract from the great experience! We walked down into one of the underground river systems, through watter most of the way and swam through the cave system. it was unbelievably beautiful, calming, quiet, and blessedly cool Our guide, Pablo, was a joy. Knowledgable, pleasant and full of the joy of the place. Highly recomended - we sent at least 12 other people there in the last day and a half that we were in Mexico - wonderful! And the meal aftrerwards was marvelous.
