AGES OF CHILDREN WE HAD: 5, 14, 12This trip was very interesting and fun, some people complained about it and called it a "tourist trap", but maybe that was their tour guide of experience. We had a great tour guide who really knew what she was talking about, unfortunately I forget her name (she was female though) but I give her credit for speaking to half of the group in spanish and to us in english.TIPS/THINGS YOU SHOULD KNOW:-Some people said it was a tight space, but you are moving around and seeing all these amazing formations that you kind of forget about it, and their are only some parts where you have to crouch down.-When your tour guide asks you if you want a WALKING STICK SAY YES! Even though you have to swim with it, it is very helpful considering you can't touch the formations.-THEY SUPPLY TOWELS AND LOCKERS TO PUT YOUR ITEMS IN-They give you a "snack" after you are done, but it is lunch, its a small buffet sort of thing, and the food was good.

Very fun underground world. This was a very enjoyable trip. It was a 1/2 day excursion for us, staying just outside of Playa Del Carmen. It was a fun and enjoyable tour of this underground cave. Very neat to see this new world. Fun to walk part way and swim part way. Guide (Tanya) was excellent. Food was fairly good. I have to say the pictures were quite expensive ($25 for 1 picture). We only bought one, however, would have considered buying more if they had turned out properly. I think the photographers should put more time/effort into ensuring a good picture (ie. no one blinking). When you first pull up to Rio Secreto you wait until there are enough people to do the tour (we waited about 15 minutes) and then were driven down a bumpy dirt road to the entry point of the cave (about 15 minutes). It is there that you are provided with your wetsuit, water shoes and guide. The tour itself is about 1-1.5 hours in the cave. Following this you can dry off, change, look at your pictures and eat.

very fun experience, but could be more pleasant!. Love the underground river. The staff and guide did an amazing job reminding us not to touch the surroundings. The spiritual ritual was eye-opening too. The only complain will be the gears: wet suits, headlights and water shoes are very stinky, which deducted some points from the trip. The lunch was surprisingly good too. Some people in our trip were complaining about the bumpy road; however, I think it was very fun. Bathroom is clean as well.

What an experience!. This was an absolutely fabulous adventure! We were a group of 8, mostly adults and one teenager. Alfredo was our amazing guide, and his passion for the history of the Mayan people and the geological forces that created this incredible natural wonder made our experience even more unforgettable. Thanks Alfredo!!!

One of the most AMAZING and NATURAL sites we've ever experienced!!!. First off, I want to start off by tipping my hat off to Alfredo our tour guide!! Alfredo has such a passion for exploring caves and the natural beauty of Rio Secreto, that like he explained, this isn't a job for him, it's his lifes passion. He was so knowledgable, and full of information. Anyone who decides to view this natural wonder, and is fortunate enough to have Alfredo as a tour guide, will surely not be disappointed. As I think of things to write in my review to describe in a few words how amazing Rio Secreto is, I'm left with a loss for words, as words just can't explain how breathtaking this tour is. What I can say is that visitors get the oppurtunity to explore something that has been a million years in the making of natural wonder and has only just been discovered. From the amazing crystal formation to the clear blue waters, this experience was absolutely wonderous. The fact that half of the proceeds from photos purchased goes to preserving the area makes it that much better. I would recommend this to anyone, old or young.

great day trip. We took the booked the tour at our resort, Barcelo Maya Colonial, and were picked up from our hotel lobby. We had a great 1/2 day and were provided with wet suit, water shoes, headgear and lunch. Our tour was well organized and very informative. Our Tour Guide was Jon Paul and he was full of interesting facts and information. We would definitely recommend this tour. Money well spent and we purchased the CD of Photos as well. Thanks for the Great Tour

Alfredo is the MAN. Just a quick review to state how amazing Alfredo is and how incredible the cavarn's are.If you go... I insist you have Alfredo be your tour guide. His passion for this place is unmatched. He still gets choked up talking about how it makes him feel. One other recommendation. Stay away from the Habanero salsa when they feed you! Five AlarmEnjoy!
Great tour!!. It was only 4 hours - but the views and what you see is amazing. Not too expensive, close to playa and they have great service!!

AMAZING!. The whole experience in the secret river was awesome. I have seen some pretty amazing places in the world and this has been added to my top 5!! It's astonishing what lies underground. I am so glad they discovered this hidden gem - everyone needs to see this. The guides were great, learned alot, safety was priority, They warned us that there may be bats, blind eels and cat fish in the waters. We only saw baby catfish. Nothing to be afraid of in the waters. Water was very clear not murkey. The waking paths in the secret river can be challenging. lots of rocks and things to step over. They offer walking sticks to people who may need extra help as you cannot hold onto any of the rocks or walls in the caves. All equipment is provided - water shoes, wet suit, life jacket and helmet with a head lamp. You only have to swim for about 5 minutes of this tour and the swim is the best part - so cool!! water temp is good. Not very cold. Hot lunch included after the tour - it was delicious (traditional mexican food) I highly recommend doing this tour! We went March 5th 2012.

Amazing experience. Do not miss!. In the last week of February we have been at Playa del Carmen, in a resort.As usual, during our stay, we took a tour. This time we chose to go to Rio Secreto.Our choice was the best one. Peninsula Yucatan does not have rivers on the surface; they are all underground, creating kind of network in their way to the sea.Rio Secreto tour gave us the amazing opportunity to explore a cave crossed by a river. In that world of dark and silence, such beautiful stalactites and stalagmites are shaped though endless time.The tour is very well organized, tourists are receiving protection helmets, wetsuit and life jacket and staff is helpful. A guide and a professional photographer are assigned to a small group of people for the time of the tour.Our guide, Santiago, was very knowledgeable and friendly.Do not miss this amazing experience!

WOW!. What an amazing experience! You get to swim and walk through caves. The visuals are unbelievable! Unfortunately you cannot take any pictures. They will take your picture in very special spots and then sell them at the end. What they don't tell you is that it will cost almost $100.00. You cannot just buy one picture which is too bad as all of the people in our group just passed on the pictures altogether (and were kind of mad). In spite of this, I would recommend this experience to anyone.

An underworld experience like no other - JUST DO IT. We decided to take the Rio Secreto tour from our hotel, and we were NOT disappointed. We were picked up in a mini-van and taken to an open-air "office" to register, then another van drove us along a very bumpy dirt road for about 15 minutes to get to the cave entrance. We were outfitted with wetsuits (don't expect a perfect fit), water shoes (you can wear your own if you have them), lifejackets and a head lamp. Everyone was encouraged to rinse off first, as the water in the cenotes is pure and they don't want it contaminated with human's sunscreen, body lotions, make-up, bandaids or deodorant. You're given a locker to keep your valuables in. We were split into groups, depending on the language spoken. Our guide, Mauricio, was young, energetic, helpful, interesting, and obviously loves his job.We walked 5 minutes down a jungle path and stopped to be blessed by a shaman. Apparently the Mayans believe the caves are the "underworld" so a prayer was said for our safe return! From there we walked down some steps into the mouth of a dry cave, where we were given a safety talk and a brief explanation of the do's and don't (ie: be careful where you step, don't touch anything as the oils from our skin contaminate the limestone, etc.) Walking sticks are provided for those who wish them.From there we walked deep into the cave, which gradually dropped down until we were wading knee deep, then thigh deep, then waist deep, and eventually we were swimming .8 km through the most remarkable maze of caves you can imagine! There's a "lifeline" in case you get lost, to help you find your way out. Mauricio told us that there are two main tours - "Joy" which is the one we were on, and "Supreme". Although the tours depart regularly, we didn't see or hear anybody else during our entire adventure. There were only 7 of us in our group plus Mauricio and our own personal photographer (we weren't allowed to take our own camera). Pictures were taken periodically - some posed, some not.Suffice it to say that you have to see it to believe it. I've attached some pictures, but they don't do it justice. It takes years for stalagmites to form, and even longer for stalagtites as they grow up instead of down. You will learn lots, but it isn't the boring kind of talk that reminds one of school days gone by. It's fascinating lore, eg: we learned that 20% of the Yucatan's drinking water comes from the cenotes.We were underground for about an hour and a half, and when we emerged we were in a different part of the jungle. It was a short walk back to the start, where we handed back our borrowed gear and were given a fluffy towel to dry off. We were taken to a building and shown the pictures that were taken (done with face recognition so only the ones you're in show up, which was very cool!). The price was high - $25 per photo, or $69 for a CD containing all the photos plus 50 professional shots of the flora and fauna of the area. Half the proceeds, we were told, go towards conservation so that made me feel good.We were then given a hot Mayan lunch which was a nice surprise! When we were ready, mini-vans were waiting to take us back to our hotel.This trip was a real treat - the guides were great, the scenery was spectacular, and it was a very DIFFERENT kind of adventure. You can't do this just anywhere, so do it when you're in Mexico - and have fun!

A truly amazing experience!. The tour and the actual guides were exceptional. The Mayan lunch was an additiional plus. İ would recommend that anyone with children take the time to visit this natural sanctuary.

If you need a cool excursion.... Great experience with a great guide (don't remember her name but she was French). Try to go in a small group (maybe the earliest morning tour helps this) and don't expect things to be a colorful as they look in the ads because it's dark inside. Really cool when they turn the lights out inside the cave and you're in the pitch dark hearing only the sound of drops. Also the Mayan blessing before going into the underworld made the experience that much more interesting!
An Amazing Experience. Liked everything, especially that you can take the bus and enter the park yourself for $30.00 less than what you pay when booking at the resort. disliked nothing
excellent day out. We really enjoyed this experience and would strongly recommend it.

Amazing and breathtaking. This is another must do in Playa Del Carmen.
Walk and swim in a cave that was discovered only 5 years ago. This is an experience you will never forget. If you go, do it because I'm pretty sure that this will will not remain open to the public for very long. It's a natural treasure

Amazing tour. Signed up for this tour on one of our cruise stops and didn't know what to expect. When we saw a large number of people at the main office we worried that it would be just another "cattle call". However, they limit groups to 10 and everyone is in different parts of the cave. We never saw anyone else while on the tour. The cave is amazing and like nothing else we have ever seen. Bobbing along through the crystal clear water our friendly and helpful guide showed us everything about this cave. A photographer took pictures along the way and at the end we were able to purchase a CD at a reasonable price. The company was very professional and safety conscious. Everyone we came in contact with tried to ensure our experience was a good one.

Amazing Experience, Off the Beaten Path! Fantastic One in a Lifetime Opportunity!. I was recently on a cruise with my family making one stop in Cozumel. I have been to Cozumel numerous times and was looking for something a bit different to do. I had done Tulum, snorkeling, beach parties and so on. I was originally thinking about doing to the sweat lodge (#1 tour on trip advisor) but though the price was a bit too high ($80USD pp). Ultimately, due to laziness I was stuck on a cruise ship with no excursion. Typically, I would never pick an excursion off the cruise line menu but I was stuck with no other choice. I decided to go with the most adventurous activity in hopes that I would be shuffled around like cattle on some slow moving tour. I can tell you know I made the right decision as there were only 6 people on the tour with us. Rio Secreto offered one of the most unique experiences I have had. With a short ferry ride over the main land we were picked up by a van and driven through the city to the jungle. Beware this is a very, very bumpy ride. After 45 minutes or so you end up in a park-like setting where you will change into wetsuits, be fitting with a head lamp and meet your guide. This is when the adventure begins!I learned that this cave system was just discovered in 2007 when the land owner was hunting iguana and when the iguana went into a hole he heard something hit water. Now, I have been in caves in the US and Belize and I have never seen anything like this! At the beginning of the tour we were greeted by a Mayan shaman who smudged us since we were headed into, what the Mayan's believe is the underworld. After this ceremony we are lead down some steps and into the cave system. Please keep in mind you should be in decent physical shape as you have to crawl, step over rocks and swim in this system. I decided to be in the back of the line since I knew I wanted to take my time. Again, it was quite slippery and I fall a few times, no harm done. There is also a professional photographer in the caves to take pictures...but, they are on the pricier side 70$ for the CD of all photos or $25 each. Bottom line, if you see something on your cruise excursions called Amazing Secret River BOOK IT! It is completely worth it. Check out my photos and feel free to ask any questions you may have. Fee for the excursion (through the cruise line) $99 ppFeel for all photos $70Amazing lunch buffet INCLUDED Transportation INCLUDED

A must do!. With so many attractions to choose from in the Playa del Carmen area, I've picked this one as it sounded less commercial then many others. I was not disappointed! This excursion into the underworld of the Yucatan peninsula was absolutely breathtaking. To experience this spectacle of nature was the highlight of this vacation and any other before. The small group of likeminded travelers and our very knowledgeable guide made this adventure an absolute pleasure. I highly recommend this "venue" as I am not certain that there are any other places like this in the world that the public can visit. I would not advise this for young children nor people with walking impairment.

Yucatan cenotes - amazing!. We had read about the cenotes in the Yucatan and knew a little about the vast network of underground caves. We decided to take this tour upon the recommendation of a couple from Vancouver. It was amazing. We were picked up at our hotel by a van and driven to Rio Secreto. We were met there by the wonderful staff. We were given a brief introduction and then fitted with wetsuits, life jacket and water shoes. Our guide was Mauricio and he was wonderful - very knowledgeable and friendly. The entire tour lasted about 5 hours. It was definitely one of the many highlights of our trip!

gorgeous and pristine. This cave/cenote/river system is in excellent condition and it's clear that the owners/managers take their stewardship of this natural treasure very seriously. Simply amazing. Loved the Mayan blessing before we entered, our period of time in the dark, and, of course, the caves themselves. Our guide Benito was fantastic--he loves his job and really knows his stuff. He fielded some fairly complex questions and we all came out better educated than when we began while having fun at the same time. Finished up just as our stomachs were starting to growl and found the included meal to be pretty good. Other details: Yes the dirt road is bumpy getting there...so what? You're in the country in Mexico, and that's how they are. People complain here on TA about the wetsuits stinking--for us they were wet but not gross. Same with the shoes. Take note, however: I'm not a feeble person, but with all the uneven footing on top of not being allowed to touch anything (skin oils will damage the formations) I highly recommend the walking sticks! You'll get to look up more and less at your feet.As for the picture taking, I have mixed feelings about them. I too would have preferred more time spent looking at the formations and less posing for pix. It just reeks of "prepackaged tour" when that's happening, something I generally avoid when traveling. But half the $$ earned goes to preservation of the caves and I believe them when they say that. We were 8 in our group so it didn't cost much to buy the cd and share.All in all it's a well-run if sometimes overly scripted tour, especially with the corny pictures. Based on other reviews here, it seems the quality of the guide staff is quite high, though. We sure loved ours. So if you're going there to get inside those exquisite caves and discover for yourself what lies beneath your feet when in the Yucatan, you'll feel (like we did) that you've gotten more than your money's worth. It's jaw-droppingly beautiful, spiritual, and awe inspiring.Kudos to these folks for doing a sustainable operation in a region that is generally happy to sell out to the highest bidder, no matter what the environmental cost. I do wish, though, that they'd do the tour at a more leisurely pace with a bit less energy devoted to the pictures.

Amazing!. This excursion is truly amazing. I went with my 2 teenage sons who were totally thrilled. Exploring the cave, all the interesting formations, swimming in the river - it was awesome. Our guide was very knowledgeable and obviously loved what he was doing. He was always lending a helping hand to help you through the sharp stones edges (I did get a nasty scratch from one of them). The drive in is very bumpy, but the locals that live along the route are all smiley and wave at you as you go by. Definately a must see.

Wow, Wow, Wow!. We will be telling our friends to not miss this one, when they travel to the Mayan Riviera!Absolutely amazing! No need to worry, we were concerned about feeling claustrophobic, but we all were just fine.
Amazing excursion. Something like you'll never see anywhere else! Great way to spend your day!
Amazing!!. One of the best experiences of my life! Gods natural beauty at its best! Would go again in a heartbeat. Highly recommend this to everyone!
Wow. Brilliant, our guide was enthusiastic and passionate about this amazing river. I have never seen Stalactites like this ever, it was awe inspiring!! Loved this tour!

Awesome Place.. Took our young son and adult son to visit the caves. Really enjoyed this attraction. Our guide by the name of Alfredo was so knowledgable about everything that we asked. If you have very young children, our son is 9 then you must be careful because the caves are slippery and uneven. Our youngest did just fine though. You will be swimming at one point the water is app. 15 ft. deep. You have on a life vest and a wet suit to keep you warm. My oldest so loved it that he wants to try every cave out there now. The lunch after was very good also. I packed some snacks that we ate before we went into the caves and I'm glad we had them because the bus ride was long. They drop you off at a check point then you take another ride in there transportation thats about 15 min. That ride is a tough one. It's through the jungle and of course the roads are not paved and it's VERY bumpy. In the end it was all worth it. If you can request Alfredo, do it he was great. I'm sure the other guids are very good as well, I'm just partial because Alfredo was our guide and we liked him very much. Do not forget to tip your guide, they deserve it!!!!!
Incredible!. Worth the cost, and request Carine as your guide! We loved that it was only half a day's worth, and that we got our money's worth in the 2-3 hours that the tour lasted.

Too rushed. If you have any knee, back or feet problems, this is not for you. The water shoes they give you are so thin that by the end of the tour your feet are just painful. I am in my 50's and it is hard to keep up with the tour as it goes so fast you have to watch every step and you don't even get to look up at the beauty of the cave. The gear they give you is falling apart and still soaking wet. I don't think that they are even sanitized between uses which is just nasty. The price is way to high, and you should not have to pay to eat that buffet at the end of the tour. We were the last tour of the day and the food was setting out, and not kept up to temperature. Come on, it was stone cold, tasted terrible and flies were everywhere. The tea was all water as they don't want to make more at the end of the day. It was a hot mess. It's unfortunate that a nice place is run in this manner. They need to do away with the buffet. I'm lucky to not have walked away with food poisoning...then again, I only ate a banana....never, never eat any food that is cold, unless it is meant to be. I would not recommend this tour. There are way to many free and cheap places to discover if you do your homework.

Enchanting. What an experience, first of all I have to congratulate Raul Padilla for an amazing, well gided tour, not only he guided us through the vains of an underground cavern but he was able to take us through time and really made us feel like we were there thousands of years ago!Go for it! Amazing, amazing , amazing.
loved it. wouid have stayed longer under ground nice hidden treasure

A MUST SEE!!!. Bought the excursion and Pick Up at Hotel was 11;20 AM. Picked up 4 more people at 2 different Hotels. Arrived after a 45 minute Van Ride.. switched to another Van with a 10 minute ride to Check In. Divided into Groups depending on your language spoken. Rodrigo was assigned to the English Speaking Group and he is oh so wonderful. Very informed, friendly & spirited.You are fitted into Water Mocs, Wet Suit & Life Vest. You are then led to a Mayan who blesses all who enter the Underground. This AMAZING Underground River reveals incredible formations created by the stalactites & stalagmites that have been in development these last 2 Million Years. It was only discovered 6 years ago and opened to the public 4 years ago!!! One of those experiences you never forget.No individual cameras aloud but they have a Camera team that take set up shots which you purchase later.After the Rio Secreto Experience a small lunch is provided with a lime chicken soup & other edibles. There is a seated area to eat.A truly unforgettable experience.

Too fast and have to be carefull..... Nice to see but were rushed and rushed to do the caverns while inside....So fast that we put time looking at our feet than on the cavern walls themselves...Pictures are sold for more than the cost of the expidition and the food was not terrible....Have to be carefull all time because inside the caverns it's very slipery...and rocky in the water trail....More time and less rush would been excelent...but....
Amazing is all I can say. "Guide was excellent" inside cave was not flat make sure you go slow and listen to instruction

Very nice,mbut could be better!. It was a very nice expercience, but i think that was overpriced, and that they had a few missing points there!
Our wetsuits were very old and stinky! The food that they serv is very poor! BUT the place is realing amazing! I have never seen such a hidden beauty in my life!

Really cool. "Really cool" that is what our two kids said after coming out of the river - ages 12 and 10. Being down in the earth looking at the beautiful formations, it is hard to really take all of the granduer in. Swimming was so fun and so relaxing. While down in the river we saw catfish, shrimp, grasshoppers,and also a scorpion. Go see this awesome natural wonder - you will be so glad you did.
More than Expected. Nothing that we disliked. We did not expect a completely pristine cave, with clean water no alge, but were extremely pleased with the entire adventure.

Stunning. This is definitely a unique experience. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit. We had a great guide who knows and respects his environment. I am glad we went. Unfortunately none of our pictures were worth buying, but many people in our group purchased their packages. They are not pushy about it at all. The lunch was very good too.

Magic!. I've always wanted to go spelunking, but this is oh, so much better!Rio Secreto is part of the underground river system in the Yucatan, and is a nature reserve.We got our gear (they provide helmet w/lamp, wetsuit, and water shoes) and descend into an amazing underground realm of stalactites and stalagmites. Our "underground sherpa," Rodrigo, was extremely knowledgeable, a passionate environmentalist, and a wonderful teacher. The pictures we bought (from the venue--guests are not allowed to bring *anything* into the delicate underground ecosystem) are spectacular. The lunch (included in the price of admission) was fresh and delicious.

Best excursion in Mayan Riviera - a must see!. Our guide, Rodrigo, was absolutely fabulous! He was insightful, witty and full of educational information about the caves. We had an amazing time with him during our tour (Supreme route). I sprained my ankle earlier in the year and Rodrigo made sure I was taken care of at all times. He even gave me a nice wood cane to help me during the route. It was a fabulous experience walking / swimming into the many caves and learning how they were formed. We were taught not to touch anything since any human skin oils would kill the formations. Rio Secreto is very environmentally responsible which is admirable - they have 3 routes and rests one so you go on 1 of 2 routes. We were also given a locker, wet suit, life jacket and helmet with a light, and had to shower to remove all skin/hair products before entering the caves.We were blessed by a Mayan elder before entering the caves since the Mayans consider them the underworld. The path was not slippery and the waters were pristine. We saw several small bats and a fish. Rodrigo turned off the lights at one time and we were in complete silence and darkness for a few minutes - it was very peaceful and wish we could have taken a nap (lol)! We went through many caves and saw many gorgeous formations. I would highly recommend this experience!!At several selected points the photographers took pictures of us. We got the package of all our photos on a CD, plus photographers' photos of the wildlife and caves, plus 3 items (a RIo Secreto t shirt, a 4G usb thumb drive and a honey liquor bottle) for only $99. Compared to other tourist places, this was an amazing deal.The lunch afterwards was cooked by local Mayan women and it was delicious. Loved the lime soup with chicken. Rio Secreto opened for tourism in 2008 after being discovered in 2006. It is seeking UNESCO world heritage status and we hope it will obtain it soon. This place needs to be protected and it was an absolute privilege to be able to visit! I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND Rio Secreto above all other excursions in the area, especially if you are drawn to the miracles of nature.

Dont go if you have any mobility issues!. I read alot of reviews before we went and none of them said anything about howprimitive these caves are. I even called and was told "you walk on a path"-----well the path is totally uneven ground. My husband turned back and then the guide thought I should do the same. I am not that unfit but he made me walk behind and hold his hand--he totally ruined the experince for me. He also hurried everyone so fast I am surprised no one fell down---stopping only for pictures. No where in the literature does it say you need to be able to navigate very rocky slippery paths ----the lunch was good. Someone on our tour approached me saying I should ask for refund for my husband as he agreed they are misleading about how easy the caves are to go in. They did give my husband a refund

Incredibly Awesome Experience. I loved the trip i took with work colleagues so much i brought my husband the following weekend. On the first trip we did Supreme with Rodrigo. He was very informative, friendly, and cheerful. We really enjoyed the trip with him and the cenote was very grand and impressive. I went back a few days later and walked/floated through Joy with Alanis. He did a great job of giving the entire tour in Spanish and in English as we were the only 2 English speakers on that particular tour. I liked Joy a bit better because it had a lot more swimming and the passageways were narrower so you felt a bit more like you were spelunking. But either one is sure to make you feel like it was worth every dollar. They really do it right there as the complex is well done, the guides are well trained and there's a tasty lunch afterward. Just plan to make it an all day trip bc on the second trip we had to wait almost an hour for the van to come pick us up to go back to the entrance.

amazing experience. Once in a lifetime experience,you have to see it to believe it.Would highly recommend you go see one of these caves in the area,This one I would not recommend if you have health issues,can be physically demanding,The minus ,we booked through Air transit and it was expensive and the pictures they take are expensive to buy.

Fabulous! Will go again my next trip to the area.. After reading the negative comments, I wondered if we were on the same tour! Our trip was very organized (we went with a group from our cruise ship), the food was delicious, the scenery was esquisite and our tour guide was wonderful. I give this 5 stars plus! I do have to agree, tho, that the price of the photos was outlandish. They would sell many more photos if they would lower the price.

An experience of a Life Time.. This was our best excursion . Talk about being a part of the water & land. The underground is spectacular. Linda; our guide, made this trip one that we will never forget. We will remember this as the "BOTTLE" experience. Gracias! Rob & Sharon. Asta La Vista.
Unbelievably beautiful. Excellent knowledgeable guides who truly care for their environment.

Well worth the money!. First of all, what everyone is saying about the 15 minute ride to the caves is absolutely right-- the worst van ride ever! But besides that, I thought everything was very good. Our guide Corinne (spelling) had a very thick French accent but I managed to understand most of what she said. I was concerned about my claustrophobia and another woman was hyperventilating even before our tour started (her fear was water), but the guide helped us both through it. The caves were stunning. We were disappointed, though, that there wasn't really any swimming, due to low water level. The last five minutes of the tour, though, involved a very low ceiling, so I don't see how we could have gone through that part if the water had been any higher! Some of the reviews mentioned inadequate food, but that must have changed because we had a very nice buffet lunch. Also I don't agree that the photo prices were out of line. Go to any tourist attraction where they take pictures and you'll find the same thing. If you go to the Skywalk at the Grand Canyon you'll pay even more, as they too don't allow cameras or any other personal items. This is just a part of doing touristy things--get over it and move on! But overall we felt that the trip was well worth every penny, not only for the great photos and memories, but also for the fact that I conquered one of my fears.

don't eat the food. my husband and i went on this tour. paid $99 per person. they provide transportation, drop you off at a waiting area until there are enough people to go on the tour. we sat there for probably 45 minutes. the 15 minute ride to the actual rio secreto tour was incredibly rough and i was sitting in the back of the van. i felt like i was on a fair ride. i'm not a fan of fair rides. i found my wet suit/life jacket to be incredibly stinky and had to endure this smell for the whole hour and a half tour. i thought our tour guide did a good job considering he had to say all his speeches in english and spanish. i would have liked him to have stopped from time to time so we could look at our surroundings. the terrain was very uneven so you really had to watch were you were stepping, rather than looking at the cave which we went to see!!! they do not allow you to take pictures on the tour, i guess so they can charge you for the pictures they take of you through out the cave. at a cost of $69 we were not willing to pay that price (or you could buy one for $25). after the tour they feed you a meal. i did not eat much because i get sick easily and prefer not to eat food off the resort. my husband on the other hand tried everything. on the way back to the hotel the van kept losing power and the driver would stop, put it in park, shut off the engine and restart it again then we would be on our way........until it happened again. we barely made it back to the hotel and my husband was on the toilet for the entire night with vomiting and diarrhea. food poisoning obviously. he was not well the next day either but did manage a piece of toast for breakfast and some broth soup for lunch. i went down and informed our tour company that he got extremely sick from their food and they contacted rio secreto. rio secreto got back to them and said that my husband was the only one who complained and therefore they would not compensate us. they said he must have been dehydrated????? we were in a cold cave in cold water!!! he didn't get dehydrated on any other tour we went on. i think it was a poor decision considering my husband lost a day and a half of our vacation. i wouldn't recommend this to anyone after the way we were treated.

Great experience. Rio Secreto is an underground river in the jungle near Playa del Carmen, Mexico.We went on a tour from our cruise ship, so with having to take a ferry to and from the mainland, it took about 7 hours. . Our guide, Alfredo, was very knowledgeable about the cave and river, and very patient. You don wet suits and life jackets and water shoes before going into the cave. You walk, wade, and swim on your journey. Your head has to stay out of the water when you swim, so it's more like a dog paddle. Cameras are not allowed in the cave. There is a professional photographer who takes pictures as you go through, and you can purchase a disc at the end of your trip. This is not a trip for small children. We had a good, authentic meal afterward that was included with our tour.

Into Mother Earth - Amazing. amazing, once you finally get there. The trip from the highway to the actual place is a royal pain. Very bad road. It takes at least 15 minutes to get there from the highway. If you have any mobility issues, don't do this tour! It's not for folks who have any issues with getting around at all!
TOURS. ATV and Cave Tour. Amazing,beautiful and fun. Booked with Mexxtremo Tours.
amazing!!!!!. The tripp to rio secreto ws worth every penny!! Just loved it!!

excellent. Rio Secreto is a nature reserve , a treasure that contains a sebterraneam universe of crystal , clear water and ancient geological structures of an infinite varienty of colors and textures, an extraorinary sensory experience.Swimming in Rio is an unforgettable experience...........................worth your monies..............

Out of this world. We wanted to do something different as we have seen all the man made attractions, and wanted the real Mexico. Our Best Day tour guide told us about Rio Secreto, and promised it would be worth it. Lihana was true to her word because this tour was the best one yet. Take your time, don't rush,just enjoy everything.

You have to do this!. One of the coolest things I have done in my life. And I have done some cool stuff. You learn a lot about nature and even about life itself while you are down there. The guide we had, Jean Paul was fantastic. His passion for the caves was palpable. I will be going back!
Beautiful, great value.. Beautiful caves/underground river. Guide was very informative. Great value for the money ($99).

Spellbinding!!. We were picked up at our hotel and carted off to the Welcome Centre. We switched vans and then took a 15 minute ride further into the jungle. Our tour guide met us and he was great at getting us ready for the afternoon. He was very knowledgable and personable. After suiting up we walked to the cenote.The tour was fantastic. there is so much to see, the caves and caverns are mostly spacious with just a few tight spots. The water is not that cold, pretty comfortable actually.Tour was followed by an authentic local lunch buffet - loved the soup!My only complaint is that the water shoes are not comfortable. Lockers available on site and washroom/change room is adequate.
The most amazing ground river I've ever seen. Rio secreto is an incredible experience, you will be 21mts underground so you will live something totally different than usual

Awesome Experience. The only down fall of this trip was the 15 minute van ride on a dirt road that felt like we were two tracking. The road back to the cave was in poor shape and it was 15 minutes of bouncing. However, this 15 minute ride was worth the experience. These undergound caves were amazing. Also while going through the cave they take a lot of pictures for you which you can buy at the end of the excursion. After getting through the beautiful caves the staff provides you with a great lunch! All in all this excursion is definitely worth the money. Our guide was Rene as well...he was a a great leader and a lot of fun!

The best $69 I have spent on a trip.. You know why they charge $69 for this trip? Because anyone who has not done the trip would not know that it is worth way more than that. The trip is amazing and so worth it. My only complaint, as others have said, is that the cost of the photos is ridiculous. I was expecting maybe $40, would have paid $50 but no way was I paying $69. The meal afterwards was just OK but still, it was all included so why complain?The total length of this trip is near or just more than 3 hours.

Amazing cave. We opted to go here to get a break from the hot sun while in Mexico. It was a great decision! The caves were so amazing and our tour guide was very knowledgable and friendly. Upon arrival you must check in and then they take you on a very bumpy ride on a truck to get to the cave. You then are fitted to get wetsuits and helmets and walk over to the cave. The experience was amazing!! The tour was part walking on rock and part swimming in water....it was such an incredible experience. We were with another couple and so did all of our pictures together. We then split the difference for the cost of the CD which we thought was well worth it!!

Great tour don't buy the pictures. The pictures are not very becoming and are not worth the $60.00 US. Take your own pictures outside and enjoy the memory of going into the cave. The snack turned out to be a meal and was excellent. Our guide Gonzo was very informative and we did enjoy the cave

A Must Do!!!. This place is absolutely beautiful! The tour is great and consists of a little bit of a geology lesson, mayan history and adventure seeking. You are 65 feet under ground and it feels like a completely different world. They provide everything for you from towels, lockers for fee and food they call a snack but is a meal. The pictures are expensive (about $69 for pictures of your group and professional shots of the caves and area) but to be honest you do not want to worry about taking pictures in there. It is an absolute stunning place that is still active in its growth and great experience.
quite a long ride into the bush. I didn't like the upsell for photos, plus their visa machine was off and on, so we had to pay the admission fee with cash. $69.00 each
Very worthwhile!. Fascinating and everyone should do this tour! However the drive from the front to the back where they suit you up is very bumpy and lasts about 15 minutes.

Magical!. What an amazing day. Our guide Paulina was magificent, the tour was very informational and we can't wait to go again! If you are a plus size person, you are still able to do this excursion! Just take your time and you will do just fine! The meal provided after the tour was great! Beware of the salsa's, and pay attention when they tell you which ones are hot and not...lol

"AMAZING SECRET RIVER" TOUR AT RIO SECRETO NATURAL PRESERVE. We were passengers on Carnival's Inspiration. We generally avoid cruise tours due to their high cost and filled to capacity bookings. We made an exception for this tour due to the logistics of taking a ferry from the port on Cozumel to Mainland Mexico at Playa del Carmen . From there, you've still got about a 20 minute trip to the nature preserve. Overall, it seemed risky to try it on our own so we reluctantly booked with the cruiseline. Well, we're here to report that it was an amazing trip - about 8 hours long, all logistics taken care of from the ferry to the caves to lunch (a good buffet of local fare at the nature preserve) time to explore the shops or beach of Playa del Carmen before returning to Cozumel by ferry. The best part of the trip were the caves. You gear up - short wetsuit, life vest, helmet, lights- and are taken in small groups (8 of us plus our guide) in to the cave for about 2 hours. We were told that there are so many entrances that they never have to have more than one group in one section of the cave so you feel like you're the only ones in the entire cave - no distracting lights or noises from other groups. The caves are beautifully decorated and you walk and swim through them in crystal clear water. A photographer takes pictures at various pre-lit areas in the cave and you can purchase a disk when after your tour (pricey , diisks start at about $70!, but since camera's aren't allowed on the tours if you want photos they've got you!) We generally go caving instead of on cave trips but this was one of ourmost memorable cave trips ever. No experience really needed - just the ability to walk and float through gorgeous caves. If any of this description sounds interesting to you ... DO IT,!!

An experience of a lifetime...... This is just a super cool excursion. There's something eerie and intriguing about being down below in a secret mayan cave. This is something you must experience if you do any excursions at all. When my daughter is old enough, I will definitely take her into the underworld.....wow!

Once in a lifetime. We nearly didn't do this tour because of the cost. At 89usd we thought it pretty expensive but I was really glad we did. Rio Secreto is an underwater cave system that was discovered in 2006 but only opened for tourists in 2008. You are decked out with water shoes, wetsuit and life jacket then taken on a 700m walk through the cave (there is a little swimming involved but nothing strenuous). You also wear a helmet with a light so you can see where to go. The water is crystal clear and the caves are full of stalactites and stalacmites and is truly beautiful and incredibly interesting to see. I believe this is the only place in the world todo it. My sometimes hard to please 13 year old daughter rated it her number 1 tour of our trip which is not easy since we have been to San Francisco and New York as well. After the trip they show you photos taken inside the cave by a photographer that goes with the group. A bit pricey at 69usd but we bought the, anyway. Lunch is served which was surprisingly good and then you are transported ack to your hotel. An incredible experience and one I won't forget.

What an awesome experience.. This event involves walking a short jungle trail, which leads you into an underground river with stalagmites (sp??) and stalagtites (sp???). They provide you with water shoes, swim vest and helmet with light - you need all of these for your adventure. To sum it up, it is like an undergrond hike - then a lovely swim (underground). The guide was great, fun-loving (our group was having a wonderful time - lots of laughter) and informative, but careful to help those (of us) who were a little older and maybe not as nimble on our feet as the young ones in the group. This is a 1/2 day event and worth every penny. When you are finished your "hike" they provide a lunch - which in our case was a litle rushed because we were having so much fun!!!
Cool adventure. Beautiful to see, but felt too short....considering wandering the caves for 90 minutes, it must have been good!

Amazing! Its a page out of a fantasy book!. The trip was so much better than I expected. Our tour guide, Joan (pronounced Juan), was awesome. He took his time and explained everything to us. As we made our way into the caves we came upon the river. You only get to explore a fraction of it so as you walk/swim through you just see endless amounts of off shoots inside the cave. The water is so nice too. You can see perfectly to the bottom even in the parts that are 15 feet deep. It was really an amazing trip. They say you get a snack at the end of the trip but its really a meal served buffet style. We had potato rolled taco's, tamales, salad, fresh soup and salsa's, beans and rice, etc. Don't be a woos, go for the green salsa.

Natural wonder. Would be difficult to take little kids through this as you are not able to touch walls or stellegamites (sorry don't know spelling). Rocky terrain, swimming involved. Great experience. Not good for people that are claustraphobic, some tight spaces. Seen fresh water shrimp and tiny catfish in water, bats. Some eels but we did not see any. Very beautiful to experience.

incredible experience - worth the ride and the money. Had an incredible time on this cruise excursion. Long ride to the cave but beyond worth it. One of the most fascinating places I've ever been to. The floating is the best part - something you won't get to do anywhere else. Tour guide Alfredo is so passionate about his job - this is what really made the experience for me.

Amazing. You walk&swim in an underwater cave You are fully equip, the water is very clear, you won.t beleive how deep .. Take the walking stick it helps your balance.. No cameras. They do feed you the food was good. They will ask for a tip. A long van ride to rhe cave but it is worth it.

Very stinky equipment!! Very good tour. I will make short and sweet.Bad: Very stinky equipment, we were the first one in the morning( 9am) to wear it, and the smell was very strong on the head gear and the wet suit, tip: bring your own headband and wet shoes, and try taking the first tour, when the water is crystal clear and you can see your shoes, after the first tour, you disturbed the water and it becomes murky, like when you add salt/sugar to a glass of water and stirred.Towels: Come on Rio Secreto!!!! you charge $69US (that's if you drive there), for the tour and at the end you give me a a brown rag full of holes called towel to dry myself, come on!!!Pictures: Well, you all know that's a rip off, don't bring your cameras, take a mental picture, it will last longerGOOD:If you drive there (wish I strongly suggest) is right off the highway, you can't get lost, lots of signs on the road, do not buy a tour from your hotel, they wanted $120US per person to do the same tourMy guide SANTIAGO, was very good and informative, did not ask for tips and helped all of us throughout the tour, nobody stayed behind, I tipped him for his good service.I read bad comments about the " snacks" at the end of the tour, but i was fed a good meal, salads, fried beans, beef tacos, tamales, enpanadas, rice, lots of salsas, fruits, and plenty of fruit juices, beer and pop is extra, all in a buffet style. no chips and process chesse!!And that's all I have to say about that!!

Entering the heart of the underground river system. There are no words to describe this experience, you have to live it for yourself...What makes this place different from many other attractions, (apart from the mind blowing natural wonder that it is) is that here they actually care for the environment, truly. It is a first priority, just the way it should be. The guide that took us really knew what he was talking about, and gave us an extra long tour and we had a moment in silence inside of the cave... very powerful!

Outstanding. Trip booked through Grand Mayan; transportation was on time and driver very competent. Transfer to jungle transport smooth and timely (road into the jungle rough). Information provided prior to trip very well presented by "Benito" guide bilingual (excellent). High level of care and understanding of the environment by guide. Equipment in very good condition and met requirements for all conditions on tour. Respect for Mayan religion and values very good. Guides knowledge of all aspects of features and evolution of caves minerals and hydrology excellent. Lunch was much more than what most would ever expect. Not hurried to leave the area and to return to home base. Photos of our party very good (camera’s no allowed in cave), will take a second tour if we return to the area. Able bodied youth to older folks must be able to swim (life jackets and wet suits provided). This is a true outdoor adventure.

Not to be missed. If you are travelling to the Yucatan; riviera Maya or Cancun, Rio Secreto is just one of those hidden gems you should not miss. For those in the know, the YUcatan Peninsula was hit by a meteorite many mellenia ago in it´s history. This created a network of underground rivers, sacred wells "cenotes" and caves that are great for exploring. Rio Secreto gives you access to these underground rivers where you can snorkel and swim, and caves full of stalactites and stalgmties that will let your imaginaton run wild. A place for adventure and fantastic photography for most age groups. While not wheel chair accessible, Rio Secreto does not require previous training.

We were completely Awe struck - family favorite, don't miss it!!!. Rio Secreto was incredible. The tour was well organized, interesting, informative, fun, and appropriate for everyone in our family (ages 65, 40's, 13, 11 and 9). Every detail was perfect, from the necessary equipment provided, to the Mayan blessing , ending with a wonderful meal. It was beyond our expectations, enjoying every minute. The cave and its entirety are beyond words. Our guide was incredibly informative, interesting and always cautious and safe. He did a wonderful job of involving our kids. The photographers did a wonderful job capturing our families experience and the picture prices are very reasonable. We would highly recommend this experience to everyone, Thank you Mauricio!!!

Amazing!. This was one of the best cave adventures I have ever been on. Small groups so there was very personal attention. It was exilerating wakjung in the river in the underground cave. Rauol was very knowlegable and fun to spend the time with. Would go again.

one of the best attractions I have ever gone on. Rio Secreto is a tour of cenotes where you walk, flost and swim through the caves. All the equipment is supplied - helmet, wetsuit, swimshoes & a walking stick if you need it.. You are not allowed to bring a camera but they take pictures for you. The tour is a couple hours and they fed us an excellent lunch after which they called a "snack". Mauricio was our guide. He was very knowledgeable, helpful, friendly and spoke English very well. Different guides speak different languages. My favourite part was flosting through the caves and when everyone shut off their lights and we sat in the darkness. You could not see your hand if front of your face. Make sure you do as the guide tells you and take big, high steps - it helps get your footing.
nice experience. impressive, especially when everyone has to shut is lamp out...ouf!

One of the coolest places we have been to. We loved the entire trip. Well run and efficient operation. The wetsuits were the first I have rented/used that did not reek. The access road to the site was a bit of rough ride but it was all worth it once we got into the cave. Absolutely amazing! As a family, we have never all agreed on ratings for an outing, until now. We all loved the tour. The guided tour was just the right amount of education and Mayan culture. 90 minted is the perfect amount of time. There was plenty of silent time for us to take in the incredible sights. The food was delicious. The people we met were friendly. We all had the best time. i would highly recommend to any family.

Great experience. We did not know what to expect when we booked this activity, but when we were done, it was one of the best experiences ever. Our guide, Mauricio, could not have done a better job with this, not only the experience but to explain the detail of this awesome place. He did an excellent job! It's obvious he likes doing what he does there.We truly recommend going to this experience, I won't even call it a tour, because it was much, much more than just a "tour". It was a learning experience. Myself, at 55 years old, it proves "you can learn something new every day." Great, great trip.

Amazing Place... Go here instead of Xcaret!. We decided to go here on a whim without doing any prior research. We didn't regret it a bit. The guide takes a small group equipped with provided wet suites on a trip through natural underground river system. The place is extremely beautiful with pretty stalactites and stalagmites. The is a bit of swimming on this trip. This place is a way more interesting and natural than Xcaret. I would advise visiting Rio Secreto over Xcaret.
Great half day trip & good value. We really enjoyed this and the guide was very informative and made sure we were all safe and comfortable. Beautiful inside the caves and felt very magical.

Great Experience, Even Better Guide. this was a great natural attraction, and our guide ALFREDO was fantastic. the first part of the trip is walking/picking your way through the somewhat rocky subterranean. my wife was nervous about this, but alfredo was soooooooooooo reassuring, and helped her at every step until we got to the river part. you need to be careful. but it's very safe and not hard. we loved the sights, and would do this again.

Very special place. My family loved it. It is an underground cavern/river tour. The difference here was that it is still "alive". Great precaution is made to offset continuing damage people can (unmeaningly) do to the delicate ecosystem there. The groups are no more than 12 people and you are with a same language speaking group. Our guide Dante was well spoken in several languages and passionate about what he was sharing and teaching us.This tour is not for those who are out of shape. Though it is not rigorous it is challenging. To start with it it a 10 - 15 minute drive in a van over a rough road. Neck or back troubles.... I don't recommend it. For the river tour I was skeptical but wanted to try, I am a large lady with a bad foot. Between the heat, the of climbing (stairs and mounds) and the very uneven terrain in the cavern I did not make it very far in. (My foot was hurting me greatly). From the beginning the very friendly staff let all of us know that we could bow out at anytime. They were encouraging and very helpful but I was slowing everyone else down and it was just to much for me, so I opted to go back. One of the 3 guides helped me back to the closest exit. I was happy with my choice after I had a cool shower and sat for awhile I just enjoyed being in the jungle. I was never made to feel anything but a welcomed guest.When my family finished their tour we were taken to have lunch at the buffet area. It was a very basic buffet and the food was very good. The tortilla soup was muy bueno!My husband has an issue with confined spaces and he had no problems with the caverns. My daughters, 19 and 22 who, after we booked the excursion were "not really into going", absolutely loved it.

Best Excursion Of Our Trip. If there is one excursion you should do on the Riviera May, do Rio Secreto. There is nothing like it. We went with a family of four (including kids 9 and 11), and everybody loved it. We took a taxi from the Barcelo Maya Palace resort. It’s only 15-20 minute away. Taxi was something like $20 one way. Our taxi driver met us a few hours later to take us back, which was really nice because we did not have to wait. Rio Secreto is right on the main highway, so they can either call a cab for you or you can try to flag one down. Rio Secreto costs $59/adult and $30/child. The tour is about 3-4 hours long. After a quick orientation at the main entrance, they take you in a van to the main staging area in the jungle. The drive to the staging area is really bumpy and takes at least 15 min, but it adds to the adventure. Our guide was Benito. What a great guy. I’m sure all the guides are good, but he really made a difference. The groups are small, maybe 10 people. We started the tour by getting our wet suits. There are small lockers where you can store things. All you really need is a swimsuit and water shoes (plus the wet suit and helmet/light they give you). No lotion is allowed in order to protect the caves. No cameras allowed either. You can purchase pictures they take afterwards. Once you’re suited up, you take a small trek through the jungle to the cave entrance. Before you enter the cave system, there is a Mayan ceremony to request permission from the gods to enter the sacred mother Earth. It’s really cool and sets the tone for the rest of the excursion. The caves themselves are really beautiful and very large. Benito gave us a great explanation about all the various rock formations we saw, and about the unique animals and small fish that live in the caves. We actually saw a bat sleeping and fly away. What’s great about this tour is you hike through knee deep water about 2/3 the way, and then swim the last 1/3 of the way. The guides light up the caves with lighting that makes it spectacular. The water is so clear and the sand (actually powdered calcium) is pristine white. It’s phenomenal. It’s so quiet and peaceful. At one point, Benito turned off all the lights and we sat in the dark listening to the drip of water in the cave. The whole experience is very spiritual.At the end of the tour, you are “born back onto the Earth”. There is a toast with a local liquor that’s sweet, but good. The kids had some type of (apple?) juice. You can buy a DVD with all the pictures they take for you. The pictures are high quality and worth the purchase. I think we paid $70 for the DVD. As you wait for your DVD, there is a simple, but nice lunch (nachos and cheese, watermelon, salad, etc) that is included. What an amazing experience. You should try this yourself. You won't regret it.
it's awesome. you gotta walk/swim in a cave with all the natural beauty you can imagine

interesting yet structured. Riu Secreto was really neat to see and explore, only because of the delicacy of the caves, your whole experience is you following a guide thru the tunnels. no chance to enjoy swimming around in the cave or exploring offshoots. You aren't even allowed to put your head under water. You are not allowed to bring a camera with you which means that if you want pictures you are forced to but the ones that their photographer takes and the pictures aren't that great or plentiful. I wouldn't recommend this trip to people looking to have a bunch of fun but it is good for those who are interested in geology

Awesome!. This was definitely a highlight of the trip. We enjoyed scuba and snorkel but the swim through these caves was absolutely amazing. Our guide Jean Paul was very genuine and made sure that we were content and happy. The formations were exquisite and the tour was well thought out. At the end there was even a nice lunch. If you are up to it I would recommend booking online and driving yourself to the site. We booked through an agency in Cancun and the van trip ended up making it an all day trip. The cost was only six dollars per person so it was a good deal from Cancun but make sure you discuss how the pick up and drop off are going to work.

Natural Wonder not to miss!. This is a fascinating and beautiful experience. We went on a morning tour and we were in a small group of four. We were outfitted in gear including, wetsuit, helmets with lights and water shoes. We descended down into the caves and traversed across the ground and into the water on a magical journey of underground sights. We really enjoyed it and the guides are very professional. Please note that you should have good balance for all of the walking in and out of the water between the formations. Professional photographers document your trip as no cameras are allowed, so at the end of the trip you are offered a cd to purchase. A unique and tasty lunch was included also followed by a rest in hammocks while you wait for your return transport. A top ten experience for us for sure!

Very fun - but wish they would fix the road. I get it - it's Mexico - the weather is tough on the roads - but after braving the very rocky ferry from Cozumel to Play del Carmen...the last thing you want to do is get into a van and deal with an unbelievable drive to Rio Secreto - not long but...very very rocky, bumpy, etc!! My DD got sick along the way...now with that being said - once we were there and experienced the caves...we all enjoyed the experience very much! Great experience, great guides, okay food, and I'm very glad they dropped the price of the CD's from $100 to $69...I still crave the three or so minutes that we had in the caves when everyone turned off their lights and it was total darkness and total silence. I could use that experience everyday of my life! I recommend this experience but not for those that experience motion sickness!

Natural Beauty ... Awe-Inspiring. My wife and I visited Rio Secreto and LOVED it! The attraction is a good deal more rugged than places like Xel-Ha or Xcaret, but well-worth the visit. An underground river with limestone formations, completely natural and beautiful. Be careful not to touch anything (which you will be reminded!) and leave all as you left it. The guide (Kuri?) was excellent in providing us (small group) with an appreciation of the place and was also very entertaining. Tip: Try to go with group that speaks one language ... otherwise guide has to speak much more rapidly to describe things as you walk along Rio Secreto.

Amazing cave experience but very disorganized. They don't let you take your own camera "for your safety" but it's really because they want to sell you photos at $30 each. The photos were very bad and no one from our group was interested in buying them. After we finished with our fantastic cave tour we had to wait an hour and a half just to get a van back to our rental car. I would recommend this experience to everyone if they get their act together. Also the wetsuit, life jacket and helmet were stinky.

Beautiful and (somewhat) exciting trip.. Rio Secreto is definitely worth seeing, especially if you've never been caving before. I've been caving once in Waitomo, New Zealand, and it was better; but Rio Secreto is still a great experience. Our guide Victor spoke excellent Spanish, French, and English and was very informative. The caves are of course beautiful. And the meal afterwards was quite delicious, too. My only complaint -- a little too much focus on safety. "Watch out for this rock, rock on the left, rock on the right, etc., etc." diminished the thrill/excitement. When I went caving in New Zealand, there was none of this.

Very unique experience. First the bad. The boat ride from the dock to the mainland was horrible! It's about 30 - 40 minutes and on the particular day we went the seas were choppy. A lot of people got sick and were thorowing up. Then the bus ride from the mainland to the actual tour is another 30 minutes. Now the good, it was a very unique experience. The caves are beautiful and the guides are very friendly. I would not recommend this for anyone who is rather heavy (not trying to be mean just trying to help) or anyone who has bad knees,etc. You are walking on uneven ground and it can be a bit tricky at times. My wife and i are in our 40's and our kids are early 20's. We all loved it!

Excellent. I was not expecting it to be so good and was very pleasantly surprised. I tried to avoid all the tacky parks in the area and this worked for me.Small parties go into the cave/s for about 90 minutes (I think -no watches allowed).The caves are beautiful, the experience of walking, crouching, going in the water and swimming is really very pleasant indeed. Our guide was helpful and enthusiastic and I think that we got as much out of the experience as we could without a lot more effort from us clambering around.They provide all the gear and it does the job. There's some pleasant food at the end (I didn't see them advertise it so that was a bonus).I drove myself there from Cancun which was 'interesting'. To get to the cave there is a bumpy road for about 20 minutes, I guess they can't fix that.It's not cheap but I think it's good value. They want the same as the entrance fee for a full set of photos or one photo for US$25 (ouch!). That's the only bit that let's it down but it's not a really hard sell. At half the price I'd probably have the photos.

Great time at Rio Secreto. This was the one excursion we decided to take on our trip last week, and we were really happy we did. The agent at our resort was right on when he said it would be 5-6 hours, but it was well worth it. Quite an experience swimming and wading through the underground river, wonderful guide giving us lots of info, no rushing. Well worth it!

This was an excellent activity and I would highly recommend Alfredo as a guide!. I went with my girlfriend, sister and her boyfriend, and my cousin. We are all between the ages of 21 and 23. You cannot beat this for the price. The cave was extremely interesting and the food at the end was great. Our guide, Alfredo, was great and I highly reccomend asking for him as he knew everything there was to know and had a genuine passion for leading others through and educating them.

A fantastic experience. An unforgettable experience and we are so glad we took the time out to visit this spectacular place. Felipe, our guide, was very informative. Only half a day, including the transfer from and back to our accom, it included a beautiful lunch.

Add this to your bucket list. MUST SEE!. My family had the good fortune to visit Rio Secreto this December. We chose to take the excursion on our cruise. This was the big excursion that I splurged for based on reviews I found on the Carnival website. I'm so happy I booked this trip. We had the most amazing experience on the tour. The tour operator takes great care to preserve the area and as such there are strict guidelines in terms of what you can bring down into the area. Trust me - when you see this natural wonder in it's most preserved state, you will agree it's worth it. I should also note that groups are deliberately kept to a small number to enhance your experience. Our guide, Benito, was most fantastic. He took extra special care of our daughter Lucy, making her feel not only very safe, but also very special to be leading the tour group with him. Additionally, he laid any fears the adults had to rest with his expert knowledge of the secret river and the caverns beneath the surface. It's impossible to describe what we seen and experienced in words, it's best experienced first hand. We were served an authentic Mexican lunch, which was excellent. The pricing for the photos after was reasonable. Don't miss the delicious adult beverage after.I wish I could thank Benito again. His gentle spirit and genuine love for what he does made the experience once we will all cherish for a lifetime. I hope we cross paths again!!!

Rio Secreto, a new little known wonderful attraction. We were picked up by bus from our resort, and brought to the Rio Secreto grounds. After we gathered with others, we were driven down to the actual attraction area, about a 20 minute ride of road, that's why it's secret. We were divided up into groups of 10 or so with our guide, Alfredo. We were all (mandatory) told to shower, to help remove oils, and then fitted with a wetsuite, water shoes and a hard hat with headlight (flashlight). Once ready we hiked down and observed an Elder performing a ceremonial blessing for our journey. Then the fun really started. We hiked down into the caves, some ground was dry, most was ankle deep, some was waist deep. Being a non swimmer I was uncomfortable with the part that we had to float in. The life vest and Alfredo's help and understanding allowed me to get through it. The hour and a half tour was phenomenal! Alfredo explained it was discovered by the property owner 6 years ago, took 3 years to map out and get ready for tours, so now they have been in business 3 years. A true hidden jewel. Long story short, we had a lunch buffet type meal waiting after we were done. Even being a non swimmer, I would definately do this again if we are ever in Cancun area again. A must see attraction!

A Phenomenal Memory. My husband and I (ages 59, 63) had some trepidations concerning this excursion; however, it totally surpassed our expectations!! Our guide, Felipe, took us under his wing as we were around 35 - 40 years older than the other 8 members of our group. This was indeed a memory never to be forgotten. It was awe-inspiring experience and a MUST-DO! We would do it again in a heartbeat!

Serving you've probably never done before!. My husband booked this on our cruise and it was wonderful! Our tour guide, Benito, was a knowledgeable, passionate conservationist who you can't help but appreciate. The tour was amazing but not for the person who is afraid of tight spaces or dark. There is some swimming involved but nothing to go underwater for. We were a small group which was perfect for this tour. Beautiful caves to see!

Totally amazing experience!. We took the tour to Rio Secreto while in the Mayan in Nov 2011, and it was amazing. Had an incredible time with our wonderful guide, Rene, who was awesome! (Ask for him!) My only recommendation is that if you have mobility issues or are scared of water, this might not be for you.

THE BEST TOUR EVER!. My husband and I (ages 59) and my son and his fiancé all took this tour offered thru Carnival Legend cruise. We all loved it. It was a little outside of the box for all of us but we think it was such an adventure and know we will never see anything like it again. All I can say is, Go, Go, Go. Our guide was Linda and she was fantastic and the pictures are truly a memorable keepsake. If you want to do something a little different, take this tour.
heavenly. amzing beautifully amazing especially our guide he was so heloful we had 4 year old kid and he carried him all the way he was so helpgul
Very fun. We went with our kids 10 and 12 and we all had a great time.It's a very special place.

Amazing must-do experience. Rio secrets should be top thing to do in the Mayan riviera. The guide takes you through the underground river, walking in underground caves and swimming in crystal clear waters. Our guide Alfredo, was enthusiastic and made this a great experience!
Nice experience. Pretty knowledgeable guide, love his stuff, makes it an unique experience. The bad side, pictures are too expensive.

Wow. My husband and son really like caves (they have gone in to quite a few over the globe) and we had read in the Houston Chronicle that Rio Secreto was a do not miss if you were in this part of Mexico. One of the things mentioned in the article was that many of these diving/Cenotes palces only give a person 5 to 10 minutes exploring but at Rio Secreto you get a full hour and a half (with a guide naturally), which my son and husband got. When you arrive you get a safety lecture and all of that and put on snorkeling attire and a hard hat with a light on it. You still need to bring a swimsuit however. You then spend an hour and a half down there (inside two string lines and you are absolutely not allowed to touch the formations and ruin them-good for the owners) and they could not say enough good things about their day. This place is not all lite up and fake, it is the real deal. The also had an unexpected surprise when they got out of the cave and back to the meeting area, there was food ready for all of the adventurers. My husband said it was the best Tortilla Soup he has ever had and that is saying a lot as we live in the greater Houston Texas area and we never eat at chain Mexican places. One important tip would be to make advance reservations online or do it through your hotel as you cannot just go there and hope to get in.

Experience of a lifetime. (We went September 2009) We've hiked and rode through several caves in Europe, but none of those experiences compare to the Amazing Secret River in Cozumel! We feel blessed to have had the oppotunity to swim through caves and get up close to stalactites and stalagmites. The guide was very passionate.The ride there is incredibly bumpy but worth it, make sure you take some dramamine beforehand if you are prone to motion sickness. Also, our snack consisted of cheese/bologna sandwiches, so have a big breakfast or bring your own snacks if you aren't a fan. Don't bother bringing a camera, you aren't allowed to take pictures of your own.

Amazing. This morning we did a Trip to the Rio Secreto – Reserva Natural. We were told to be there for 8.30 as we had asked for the first time slot of 9am.This was truly amazing 9 miles of underground caves, which were found 3 years ago. Then a minivan took us deeper into the jungle for about 15 minutes on an unmade road. We were lucky enough to see a rare sighting of a deer, the guide was excited she had never seen one here. We put on wet suites and shoes and helmets with torches and showered. The guide Paulina took 12 of us through the Jungle to a hole and down we went. We had an hour and a half walking and swimming in half a mile of caves. This natural phenomenon was just incredible. Some of the caves were massive and some were just small and filled with stalactites and stalagmites which were just beautiful. Some places we had to squeeze through and be so careful not to touch or bang our heads and break anything. We saw a couple of large stalactites that had fallen down. We also saw in a couple of places some tree roots that had drilled down for the water. The oil from our hands our skin can damage the fragile system, so we tried to be so careful not. The floors were not flat so we had really watch where were walking or swimming and it was great to just stop and stare at this amazing world. We saw one spider and a few Cat fish. At one point in a small cave we all floated in the water and turned all the torches off. For two minutes we just lay in the dark and listened to nothing. One of the men had a walking stick and you could hear it was hollow underneath us and there was another cave system under us. At one cave there was a large hole and you could see the caves lower down. The water was just so clear. It was just magical in there when we came out we felt so alive we just wanted to pay again and go back down. There was a young man following us about taking photos, they sold us the CD after After we got our clothes from the lockers and used their towels to dry they then supplied a lunch whilst they developed pictures. The pictures came out really well.
8 th wonder of the world. this is a must go to place when in mexico if u like caves that u can walk and swim through stunning

You will never forget this place :D. This is a lifetime experience and you will be amazed! Not for someone who is afraid of the dark or claustrophobic, but I never thought I could do this and I am so glad I did! I've seen movies that were about this kind of place and it is truly beautiful. We saw "Alegria" and our guide Adriana was wonderful. I will go back if I have the opportunity to visit the Mayan Riviera again. Don't bring a camera, as they won't let you in with anything but your bathing suit. They have a photographer along on your tour who takes pictures and then they are for sale at the end. The lunch provided at the end of the tour was more than I expected...very tasty!

Truly AMAZING!!!. Don’t think about leaving Playa del Carmen without checking out this incredible nature reserve. It is a totally breathtaking experience. The water inside this cave is so clear and so pure, it is water you’ve never seen before! An opportunity like this is rare, so I highly suggest you all go visit this place or what I like to call: The Fountain of Youth!……And you’ll be absolutely lucky if you have Benito as your guide. He is extremely passionate about preserving one of the great wonders of the world and very informative throughout the tour. Go on and book your Rio Secreto (aka ‘Amazing Secret River’ excursion for Carnival Cruisers) tour today! :O))Visited November 4, 2011

Amazing day at Rio Secreto. Visited on Allure and booked through the ship because I couldn't find a much cheaper way to put it together ourselves. The ferry from Cozumel was rough, but no one lost their breakfast thanks to modern meds. From there, it is about 15 minutes to the entrance, followed by a very rugged 15 minute ride to the opening of the cave. The rugged ride adds to the authentic nature of the experience, so here's hoping they never pave it. Our family of five was placed with two couples for our trip into the cave. They provided the water shoes, wet suits, helmets, along with some instructions. Our guide Pauline was fabulous and took special care of one of the members in our group who had a harder time getting around. Rather than describe the cave experience, we hope you decide to do it yourselves. After the cave experience (which takes about 90 minutes), we were treated to a shot of a local specialty and a nice buffet lunch (which they call a snack). The entire experience was well worth the money. Made it back the ferry in Playa del Carment just in time for the "early" ferry back to the "other" pier in Cozumel and then $11 cab ride got us back to the International Pier in Cozumel.
