Amazing Natural Wonder. We toured Rio Secreto and had a wonderful spelunking (caving) experience!!! The company provided equipment (wet suit, water shoes, life jacket, helmet) and our adventure started with a nice hike to the river entrance. Upon entering, we received a wonderful tour that involved wading, climbing, and swimming in the cave. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and helpful. The underground river features amazing stalactites and stalagmites, unlike anything I have ever seen. The tour also explained the rivers significance environmentally and for the Mayan culture. We also purchased professional photos as mementos. I have been on many excursions and this is one of the BEST - organized, safe, professional, and a truly unforgettable experience.

An almost spiritual experience, amazing!. It was amazing, and very educational! They take a lot of pictures for you while you are there and you are able to purchase them if you would like to. Also the lunch they supply was out of this world and very authentic. The people were very nice and very knowledgeable about the caverns. It was a great value as well! I highly recommend!
Awesome experience. Wow! Unbelievable excursion. Great experience. Great guide in alfredo. Highly recommended.

Fabulous Adventure. Rio Secreto has only been open to the public for 3 years and they've done a great job keeping it natural and authentic. No artificial lighting added for effect here. They provide wetsuits, helmets with head lamps, water shoes, and life jackets. You can bring your own water shoes if you want.After walking about 5 minutes through the jungle, you enter the cave and the tour begins. You walk and swim (with arms only) through the cave for about 90 minutes, and then have a great lunch. The water is 'fresh' (cool), but we got used to it since you're walking in it when you're not swimming it it. Our guide was Jean Paul. He was knowledgeable, fun, and helpful. You can't take your camera, but they have photographers throughout the cave to take pics of you and your group. You can buy them at the end of the tour.Tips: 1. If you get motion sickness, take something before you get there because the 20 minute ride from the reception to the cave is rough.2. Watch your step because path is rocky (and can be slick). Also, there are lots of rough/rocky areas under water that may be difficult to see. The close supervision and instruction of the guides are helpful here.3. If you think you'll need it, ask for a walking stick when you get your wetsuit and life jacket. Great for balance on the path and in the cave. Also good for those with weak knees.4. Have fun & enjoy the experience! It's a once in a lifetime opportunity.

Best adventure in Mexico. Thanks to our passionate guide, Alfredo, we enjoyed one of the best days we have ever had in Mexico. The undergroud beauty is too much to explain, but the US does not have any experience like this. As an eco-enthusiast, this tour is one of the few that believes in the conservation of this area in its natural state. The experience of walking and swimming within the earth's layers is truly a lifelong memory for us. Thanks, Rio Secreto and Alfredo for your passion and for sharing this underworld of beauty with us.

Great attration that you would not normally do in the tropics.. We decided to try this excursion and it was great. If in the Cancun area this is a must do. You are in caves for around 1 1/2 hours and this includes some swimming. Great photos taken. Our guide was Felipe and he was fun and knowledgable. Lunch was part of the package and it was good.The only negative was not being able to take a camera into the caves.

Rio Secreto = fantastic experience. It was such a great experience and definitely worth it. Our guide Benito was fantastic, personable, and very knowledgeable. It wasn't a typical experience, but it was wonderful and I would do it again. The underground cave system was just found in 2006. It was a fantastic experience and we walked away with a new appreciation for Mexico's nature, Mayan beliefs and amazing pictures.

Want a real cave adventure in can cun???!!!!!. this was the real thing!!!! we went wayyyy down into the underground caves. you have to be physically able, because the terrain is very uneven and at one point you swim to the next cave. not touristy, small group of six only. tour is about 1 1/2 hrs,1/2 hr to gear-up, 1/2-hr to 45 min to eat and undress. my 67 yr old mom and i loved this. the sights are amazing!! transportation from can cun palace took 2 hrs to get there=we were picking up others for xcaret also. would suggest looking into getting your own transportation. the light lunch was ok. pictures a little pricey- and you cannot take waterproof cameras. this definately was an experience!!! 59 w/o transportation--98 with. u.s $$

Marvelous place, amazing staff. Good afternoon, I went to Rio Secreto yesterday, the most amazing cavern experience in my life, Rene was our guide and he did his job perfect, since the welcoming until the final good bye everything was great.The company is taking care of the nature very good, they are interacting with it, instead of destroying like almos everybody does. I wan to add that the FOOD at the very end of the trip was DELICIOUS, thank you all, thank you RENE...

What an amazing experience. An underground cavern left in natural state, partially filled with water, stalagtites and stalagmites, amazing natural formations, good narrative from our guide. A must see the next time you visit Playa del Carmen. Not recommended for young children as some areas have deep water and uneven surfaces. All gear supplied including helmets with light, wetsuit, water shoes and life jacket.

Educational and Different. We went on the Rio Secreto tour, and thoroughly enjoyed it. There is a bit of a sense that this is yet another "ecotourism" adventure, however the experience of being in the caves was like nothing else I have done. It is truly an amazing world underground, and our guide Raphael, was interesting, educational, and funny (spoke English and Spanish during out tour and i felt that he gave equal information to both groups). I highly recommend the tour.

Underground marvel. We usually visit Playa del Carmen twice a year and this time we selected Rio Secreto asour adventure experience. It is a wonderful place that combines hiking and swiming in the underground. Caverns and marvelous and at the end you can buy beautiful pictures to remember this attraction that is like nothing else around. The food at the end of the trip is just average but useful to recover some energies. I do not recommend this attraction for childrenunder 12 , seniors above 70 years old or handicapped people.

It's a once in a lifetime experience. I saw pictures of Rio Secreto in a random travel book and it was the whole reason we decided to travel to the Playa Del Carmen area. It did not disappoint. It started off a little slow with a 15 minute drive to the site from the entrance area and the first part of the tour was pretty good. But once we got to the part where we started swimming in the crystal clear waters and navigating inches away from huge stalactites - it was AMAZING. It felt like a dream. Our tour guide's name was Pablo and he had such obvious respect and love for the place that it really rubbed off. They provided a free lunch afterwards which was a nice surprise - we didn't know it was included. The only reason for a less than perfect review was that the pictures on sale were ridiculously priced ($25 per picture or $75 for the whole CD). If you're going in the low season, you should check online for special discounts - we got 15% off admission.

Had a good time.... My wife and I decided to do this on a rainy day. It was a great little trip. It's basically caving with a wet suit and through water. Very fun. The only real downside that we noticed is that there is a 15 minute van ride to the actual spring from the road location and the road to the spring is awful. We were stuck in the back row of the bus and by the time we made it to the spring, we were both feeling nauseas because it was so rough back there.Otherwise, the visit was good. The snack at the end (beans, chips, rice) was pretty decent, and our guide was friendly and helpful.
Was great. Very educating nd great to do when the weather is bad, when it rains it looks like crystals. Well worth it.
A must see!. Our guide Alfredo was the best. I've never met anyone who loves their job more. He kept us entertained as well as educating us on caves. I'd definitely go again!Dianne from Texas

Great excursion. This is a great place to visit, difficult to see anything like this in the UK!Alfredo was a great guide and demonstrated both good english skills and a good knowledge of the site. Definitely would recommend it to anyone who is visiting the area.My only criticism would be that the price of the photos at the end is a little steep at $25 (US) per picture, or a CD with all the pics on for nearly $70 (US)Snacks are nice, the red hot chilli sauce is great on the nachos!!
Don't Miss!!. A fabulous day. A learning experience more than a "theme park". Kuri was a fabulous guide, very patient with the kids. The experience is unforgettable.

Amazing, truely breathtaking!. The Rio Secreto was so beautiful. Our guide was what made the trip so great. Alfredo was very knowledgable and so friendly. My husband and I went on our honeymoon and had a fantastic time. I would recommend this to anyone!!

Most beautiful and amazing tour ever!!. My husband and I loved this place! The underground river is beautiful and the cave is so breathtaking. Our guide was Alfredo, he was funny, very patient and professional. Alfredo took the time to point out special things like the blind cat fish, crickets, bats and other things that make Rio Secreto beautiful. If you are in Playa del Carmen or Cancun, I definitely recommend you go to Rio Secreto. They pick you up at your hotel and provide all you need, just bring a bathing suit. They will take pictures and I suggest you get the Jumbo Packet, you will not be disappointed. This is a great experience!

Great experience with my 7 year old son. I think by now if you read any reviews you will realize something... you can't bring your camera. And honestly 49 out of 50 of us do not have good enough cameras nor the skills to capture ANY shots that are halfway decent in the caverns. The professional photos you see us posting show those caverns in a bright lit way that you can't see in reality. So I just wanted that out of the way. I'm not going to hope that people stop complaining, but seriously you'll be fine with just a few professional pics or only your memories! Past that, here was our experience: I booked online without transportation as we were staying in PDC. My hotel misinformed me on using collectivos (I swear I thought they were getting kickbacks from the taxis). You can take a taxi from a hotel in the downtown area for around 130 pesos plus tip to Rio Secreto. Or you can walk to 2nd and 10th, find a collectivo and spend about 15 pesos pp and get there pretty fast too. The Rio Secreto stop is right past the Xcaret turn off the highway heading south from PDC. It's clearly marked and any collectivo heading south will know it/ see it. Also collectivos will stop anywhere on the way. So you CAN get there using a collectivo, although I unfortunately followed my hotel's instructions and took a cab. For the return we ran across the highway (there is no stop heading back north towards PDC) and flagged a collectivo down. This is what Rio Secreto told me to do (they'll also call you a cab). The area you arrive at has a small parking lot for travelers with wheels. If you purchase online, bring your printed receipt. I had no issues with check-in. My son and I were issued wristbands and brought a waiting area that was outside. They offered water to those who were waiting and there swings. Vans arrive and you take a 30 min bumpy ride through the jungle to where the real action is. When you get out you meet your guide (we were divided by language). They take you to a locker/ bathroom/ changing area. The lockers are free/ included. You strip to your swimsuit (that you should wear there) and shower outside. Then you are given shoes to wear (water shoes). You cannot wear ANY jewelry. You walk over to another little building to get your shorty wet suit and helmet with light attached. Layered on over that is a lovely life jacket. After 1 group pic, you head down the jungle path to the caverns. We stopped first to receive a blessing from a Mayan shaman before entering the cave. It involves incense and simply respecting the culture. After you descend slippery stairs the real tour (about an hour and a half) starts. Many parts involve treading shallow cold water and walking on very uneven ground. You also walk through water that's about ankle high--but that means you can't see where your stepping after the first person moves the silt and steps there. You need decent balance and the ability to crouch. The coldness of the water was more an issue for my son and a few others in our group than anything. I was fine with 72*F, but others are not. Our guide was very informative and very interesting. He was passionate about the cenotes and caverns. There is also a really low tight tunnel you wade through--if you have claustrophobia or a fear of darkness, then this is not the tour for you. They give you moments to ponder in absolute silence and darkness the wonder of the nature and profound blessing it is to be inside the earth without any modern distractions or noises. Twice we turned off our lamps and just listened to silence. It was awesome. The guide was also awesome with my son--he frequently towed him in the water and had him follow right behind him. I was very impressed. He kept insisting he take my son so I could also enjoy the caverns. We did stop for photos at a few key places. And I was happy to do so. It didn't take a lot of time. There were only 8 of us. After we came out we strip off the gear and they hand out towels. We walked up wear we had a toast of Mayan moonshine tequila (your guide and my child get tea), After that we were shown our picture options. I chose for $25 to get 1 pic and it is your choice to get it printed as an 8x10 or on a disc. I chose on a disc. You can get all the pics for like $69 and you can add on prints and t-shorts an alcohol starting at like $99 to $200. When you first arrive, they have a noticeboard letting you know that at least half the proceeds from the picture sales goes to the preservation of the land there. As I stated at first, you can't get decent pics anyways with your own camera--flash or not. Our camera guy took photos of each of us and would retake if someone moved, etc. He was also there for safety. Each pic he took with his camera took 12x longer than my point and shoot because the camera was absorbing light for the picture (I can't really remember my freshmen photography class). So we got 1 pic pic for $25 for the memory and coolness of it and we weren't griping. Of the 8 of us, my son and I and a British couple bought 1 pic, the French Canadians bought a disc of pics, and the Californian honeymooners bought nothing. so it's your choice. I did not feel pressured. After you are done looking at your pics (which you can skip if you like), you are brought back to your locker area where you give up your shoes, hit the bathroom, and change into your dry clothes. Then as a group we were led to the snack area (a place to wait really for vans to come up). They had juices, water, chips and cheese, salads, salsas, and bean empanadas complimentary. They offered quesadillas for a few dollars. We ate what was free and were fine until we made it back. They ask you while you are snacking/ eating (many Americans will call it a snack and some Europeans will call it a meal if I'm permitted to use a generalization. I KNOW it is a generalization) to fill out a questionnaire regarding your experience. Everyone I saw marked the guide, service, and caverns as awesome and the transportation in the middle. (barring a better road, they really can't make it better) This is also where your guide will probably say "If you'd like to leave me something extra, this is the time to do so". He says that because this is the last you see your guide. So we all tipped him as we handed back in our questionnaires. And I was happy to--he did great. After "snacking", you head straight back on the van to be driven down to the entrance. Extra advice: do not put on any lotions, creams, repellents, sunscreen before your tour, but afterwards while you are in the shade I would bring some repellent to put on to keep the mosquitoes at bay. We really enjoyed our trip into the underworld beneath the Mayan jungle and feel the tour was very well-run.

Should be listed as one of the wonders of the world! Amazing!. This was a shore excursion booked as part of our Cozumel cruise package. I've never seen anything quite so mysterious and beautiful! Rio Secreto should be listed as another wonder of the world! We walked, crawled, swam and shimmied our way thru a half-mile loop of a breathtaking 8-mile cave (and yes, there were bats!) Our tour guide (Alfredo) is super passionate about his work, and filled our tour with education and fun. I have a 29-year old daughter with Cerebral Palsy. Physically she's highly functional, mentally she's about 13. Alfredo took great care with her, both physically and intillectually. He safely guided her thru every step, and held her on a flotation device thru the swimming spots. He made sure she understood everything from instructions to education, to guarantee her the same WOW experience the rest of us received! He was truly outstanding! His passion tripled the pleasure of this event! This was the journey of my life, and I'll never forget it. Treat yourself to an amazing day! You'll be so glad you did!

Amazing Experience!!. Just came back from Cancun and we had the pleasure of going to Rio Secreto, a fairly new attraction which takes you through and undergroung river sysytem. This was one of the best treks I have ever been on. Our guide, Lia was so helpfull and knowledgeable. It was obvious that the staff respects the natural environment and works to create not just an activity, but an experience. Felt very safe and taken care of.The river and caves were absolutely beautiful! It is all natural, no manmade trails or pools. I recommend taking the walking stick for balance as you cannot touch most of the structures inside the cave for balance.The swimming was, for me the best part...so calm and beautiful!I highly recommend this if you want an adventurous experience away from all the touristy park-type attractions.

A singularly natural thrill in a region that overpackages nature. We visited Rio Secreto in early September 2011 after studying the brochure and asking around among other travelers. We had a sensational morning -- one of the highlights of a family vacation for our kids and us alike.My wife and I have been regular visitors to the Riviera Maya over the last ten years, and have had a lot of wonderful experiences in and on the water, in the towns, and visiting the historic ruins. One thing we have avoided like the plague is the so-called "nature parks" like Xelha and Xcaret, which have only a little more in common with nature than a day in Disneyland. I don't doubt they're fun if you like that kind of thing, but we'd rather snorkel or kayak through the mangroves than drive an ATV or ride a zipline. As such, we were really encouraged by the description of Rio Secreto, which claims to be a truly natural attraction, in harmony with its surroundings. For once, the brochure told the truth.Rio Secreto is a large natural cave system running through the limestone substrate of the jungle, only discovered about five years ago. It is on private land owned and managed by an indigenous tribe, and the stewards seem very sincere in their desire to bring in guests while respecting the delicate environment. Five stars to them! Your journey starts from a new 'base camp' right off the main highway, with a friendly welcome by hostesses and a video presentation. You board passenger vans for the very-rough-road drive back into the jungle, maybe about 20 minutes, and a bit queasy-making if you're prone to motion sickness. When you arrive at the cave entrance, you are paired with a guide, who oversees your outfitting after a mandatory shower (you're going down into an underground river with pristine waters -- you HAVE to wash off all sunscreen, lotions, bug spray, etc.). You're given a caving helmet with lamp, wetsuit, personal floatation device, and watershoes. You take a short -- maybe five minute -- walk along a jungle path to the cave entrance, where the adventure really begins.You need to know, this is a wild ecosystem, and you'll be walking, shuffling, squatting, and swimming your way through a cave. There are no boardwalks. The surface is rough and slippery in places. You have to squeeze (a little) through narrow passages to avoid damaging the cave walls. It's a little bit of work. And in exchange, you get to see some breathtaking sights... lovely stalactites, "flows" of limestone, beautiful, crystal-clear pools. It was a very real version of what you "experience" as you go through wild rides like "Indiana Jones" at Disney parks... except instead of being strapped into a bucking ride, you're swimming through peaceful waters and experiencing utter silence and true darkness.Our guide, Pablo, was sensational -- funny, soft-spoken, extremely well informed, and sincerely reverent about the beauty and meaning of the cave and ecosystem. He made sure we were comfortable and safe, and gently drew us into his view of the world and of Mayan beliefs. It really was a bit of a spiritual awakening.Rio Secreto was a great experience -- one of the highlights of our vacation -- and wonderfully in line with our personal philosophy of respecting and enjoying nature, rather than packaging it for mass-market sensibilities. Strongly recommended for able-bodied travelers who want to experience a true adventure and feel close to nature (and maybe something larger).

Awesome, as always.. I visited this cenote for the fourth time since 2008, and it was as amazing as the first time. Our guide, Gonzo, was excellent, my friends (who were first-timers and were brought there by me) enjoyed his tour very much. I recommend the route Supreme above the other two - it is the most beatiful one and has the most of water in it.

What an interesting and fun experience!. I was a little scared when we first started to tour because I didn't know what to expect. It turned out to be such a wonderful, educational and adventurous experience! The hour and half tour went by too quickly. Next time I will make sure to take a longer tour!
it´s unbelieveble. itá a beautifull place , under the ground 25 m , it´s feel surreal and absolutely magic.

Absolutely amazing and worthwhile--ask for Rene. We just went to Rio Secreto as part of a organized trip, and it was well worth the drive out from our hotel. Be sure and ask for Rene, who was our tour guide, he was absolutely wonderful--he was a good guide, thoughtful, knowledgeable, paid attention to each visitor when we were traversing through tighter areas, and was also quite a good sport and had a great sense of humor. The tour was absolutely amazing--the caverns are incredible, the stalagmites and stalagtites are gorgeous, especially when you're able to get so close. It's absolutely beautiful, the water is clear, you'll see a dozen caverns, and even a few fauna. We took the 1 1/2 hour, small group tour which took us through about 1 km of the underground caverns, which involved some degree of swimming, a bit of wading through water, occasional crouching, and a bulk of it walking. You'll have a wetsuit (the water's about 75 degree's) and a lifevest, so swimming is fairly easy, but you will need to know a modicum of swimming. Overall, it was the highlight of our trip, and we'd recommend anyone thinking about going to go, unless swimming or claustrophobia are issues. Apparently there are longer tours (up to 6 hours,) which we're quite intrigued by. And ask for Rene!

Amazing nature. The tour was great, the guide was good! The river is just awesome!!! The park takes very good care of nature and the is very well organised . The only thing I didnt like were the overpriced photos.

Incredible experience but don't expect to take photos. This was an incredible experience; we have never done anything like this before. My Wife was a little hesitant to try this because she gets claustrophobic, but she loved it. Our tour guide was fantastic, very knowledgeable and very enthusiastic. The caves are so beautiful, we had never seen stalagmites and stalactites before and they are awesome. You can wear a wet suit if you want because the water is cold; however you soon get used to it. In some places the water is just ankle deep and in others it reaches to your chest, but you never need to go under the water. They give you a hard hat to wear complete with a built in flashlight. In some places you have to watch your head does not bump off the ceiling or off a stalactite. The whole cave system is amazing to experience. However the best part for us was when they asked us to turn off the lights and just lay still in the water in complete blackness and silence. It was an incredible and peaceful feeling. The only disappointment with the trip was that they would not allow us to take our own cameras into the cave system. They have their own photographer who takes your pictures, both individual and group shots. Then when you’re done with the tour they want to charge you a ridiculous amount for the pictures. I think one digital picture was $25.00. We felt this was a complete rip off and we were not very happy. But apart from the photos if you are travelling to the Mayan Riviera Rio Secreto is something you must experience for yourself.

Beautiful !!. This was an unbelievable experience, the most amazing part is when you and the group turn off the lights, the rest ... you have to be there, simply beautiful and amazing. !I'll do it again !

Stop! Read This is five Star All the Way A Must go!!!!!!. From first contact all the way until we finished this was absolutely top notch!> We arrived not knowing we should have a reservation and they made arrangements for us to go. We were transported in an Air Condition Van a few miles deep into a wooden area where we arrived at the site. Our group consisted or about 10 people all speaking Spanish except my wife and I. Our guide "Felipe" was very patient to translate everything to us in English so we understood.  The Tour- Everyone was fitted with wetsuits, life vest, water shoes, and Helmets with lights then a short walk took us down a trail where we met a true mayan shaman. We were then told a little about the underworld we were about to embark on and a short prayer was said to bless us for safe passing. From this point on our journey underground began. You will be absolutely Amazed at how well protected and beautiful the underground cave is. We spent a lot of time traveling through water and around the natural beauty of the cave all while our guide told us about different areas of the cave and what we were looking at. All questions asked were answered with great understanding as our bilingual tour guide kept everyone informed in both Spanish and English. You will go from water just at your ankles to well over your head as you move throughout the cave. We experienced the sight of small Catfish, very tiny shrimp and bats.  This experience was so great that we're going back next year to take our two boys ages 10-13. In my opinion this would be great for ALL ages. Our tour guide said the oldest person he had the pleasure to show the cave to was a 90 year old person. You will need to be in decent shape and not afraid of small places. If my 100lb wife could do it you can too. Towards the end- Once we emerged back to topside from the cave we were taken back to the changing area where we freshed up to then find out we would be having lunch with our tour guide there on site. We ate a great lunch that was well prepared before relaxing a few minutes in the hammocks before being transported back out from the forest to the initial site where we first found Rio Secreto.In closing We live in Maryland and this was our first trip to the area. We are already making plans to go back and specifically Rio Secreto. They have really done a top notch job or making sure you get the best experience and without breaking your wallet. Plan to spend a few hours meet their friendly black/grey cat at the waiting area before getting transported back and don't worry about what to bring they provide everything including a locker for your belongings while your down in the cave.

A MUST SEE!!. Awesome adventure through the cenote cave! The stalactites and staglamites formations was beyond what we imagined. Our english-speaking guide Gonzo taught us alot too! Great service with snacks provided after the tour. We had to buy pictures as we were not allowed to bring cameras into the caves and it cost $69USD, which is quite expensive. But the whole experience was definitely worth it!

Totally Awesome. One of the greatest adventures we have ever been on!
Guides were awesome!
We have been twice once in 2010 and this year 2011.
We plan on going back for the 4 hour tour.
Totally worth the money!

Beautiful caves!. This was a very interactive experience...from hiking to swimming in the caves. Great guides. Interesting experience of sitting in complete darkness inside of caves. Fun place to take guests.

A must see!!!. Tour guide Mauricio was great. He was very well versed & knowledgeable of the underground river. It was an amazing experience & a must see. All equipment was included & even a nice snack after. I only wish we could have our own cameras to capture the experience. So bring enough cash to be prepared to buy the pics from their professional photographer who's with you on your journey. I highly recommend this tour.

So commercial and over priced!. I did a good amount of research on travel excursions in the Riviera Maya before my trip to know about the options once we got down there. We opted out of going of xcaret of xplor initially as it seemed over the top and way too commercial. I also questioned the environmental impact of such theme parks. I had read about Rio Secreto through several sites and kept it as an option. But when our snorkeling tour got canceled due to bad weather at the last minute, Rio Secreto became the best option. They had last minute availability so we decided to go for it.I was suprised at the fancy digs and waiting room upon arrival. And even more surprised at the hi tech picture viewing room they force you into when the tour is over. I asked if I could go to the bathroom and the tour guide said I could go but one of us (my boyfriend) had to stay and wait for the picture rep. What am I on a field trip?! We waited for the previous group to see their pictures before they let us in and then talked to each couple individually about the package options. It felt like a timeshare presentation. And the packages were so ridiculous in their offerings that you were left with no choice but to do all or nothing. Buy the entire CD with your pictures and their gallery for $69 or buy one picture for $25. The CD's are carefully crafted so you can't split the cost with another couple since they only have shots of yourself and a few group ones. As I look back I am even more turned off about the whole experience. They don't allow cameras of any sort, make you walk in single file the entire time, and have lights carefully positioned in certain places for shots just so they can get you at the end. The worst thing is that I bought the CD and you can't even copy the pictures or upload to any picture sharing sites. Isn't that the reason you want the pictures to begin with? What's the point of having the CD laying around the house? I was so upset it prompted me to write this review so others are aware. This place is completely commercial and if you are expecting anything special, DONT! The worst thing is they claim they have to charge such high prices to prevent the government from taking the land. Weather that's true or not, I don't know. Just seemed suspicious that they have such a high tech space in the middle of the jungle and have branded everything down to the warning stickers in their van with "Rio Secreto". Yes, the stickers in the van that pointed to the first aid kit, fire extiguisher, and windows all had their logo. Seemed a bit over the top.The actual tour was just ok. It was shorter than I thought and it felt somewhat rushed. When all is said and done you are only down there about 1.5hrs even though the whole excursion is 3.5. They fed us tortilla chips with processed nacho cheese and beans. If you want a quesadilla you have to pay extra. For $70 they could have at least fed us a real lunch. Oh and they tell you you are not allowed to touch anything and stay on the trail to preserve the place. Yet the photographer is free to run around and climb the colums as long as he gets the shot.

A great experience. My family loved the caves even though at the entrance of the cave my 3 girls started criying. They were very afraid at the beginning but 5 minutes later they wer okey and enjoyed very much.If you go to Playa del Carmen dont miss Rio secreto. AWESOME!!!!!!

Amazing experience!!!!!. My husband and I have decided to go to rio secreto while on our honeymoon!so far it is by far the most fun and interesting tour we've ever taken in Mexico!!! We just loved it !! Felipe who wad our tour guide was just amazing.He was knowledgeable, fun ,interesting and very engaging!!!we learned many things while having so much fun inside the inderground caves! This place is just fascinating,just swimming in on underground cave ( with deliciously fresh cooling water) seeing the amazingly shaped stalactites and stalagmites.Knowing that this was also a sacred place for the Mayans who considered these underground caves as the infraworld !!!! Very nice and authentic experience!!!!!

Beautiful exerience!. On our vacation to Riviera Maya our travel agent suggested we try Rio Secreto as an excursion. As my husband has health problems I decided to go myself. It was beautiful! We went in a small group that was warm and friendly, the staff was great! Our guide Alfredo did a wonderful job, it was easy to see he loves what he does each day! I would suggest this for your visit! It is a bit physical but they go slow and remind you to walk with confidence and take your time! Hope you have as much fun as I did!

THE BEST COMMERICAL CAVE TRIP POSSIBLE!!. If you are a caver and shy away from Commerical cave trips - this is one commerical cave trip that you will want to do. The staff does an excellent job in preserving the cave - you are required to take a shower prior to putting on your wetsuit and life jacket and heading into the cavern system. No hokey colored lights and our guide, Mau was outstanding! He explained to the non cavers about the importance of not touching the formations and demostrated a true love of the underground. A cave photographer followed us in and took some beautiful photos of us. After the trip, we were treated to a wonderful snack (heck, it was a meal) and we were hungry!

Beautiful and well managed attraction. My wife and I visited this attraction while staying in Akumal. It is very well run. The cave has been extremely well-preserved and they take greta care to see that there is no damage done due to human visitation. Our guide, Gonzo, was extremely knowledgeable and helpful to us in assisigtng my wife with her bad knee to get through all parts of the cave. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit and highly recommend this to anyone who is visiting the area.

Very Rugged Adventure - Fantastic Guide. Three not-so-fit mature ladies from NYC visited the underground river and caves with our kind, patient and oh-so-careful guide - Senor Alfredo. When we booked the trip, we had been told there were few stairs and the excursion could easily be done by older knees/hips as well as very rudimentary swimmers. Alfredo guided us, slowly, step-by-step, alerting us when there were sharp rocks to either side of us. He told us "lift your knees with confidence!" (it was his mantra!) and he helped us enjoy a truly challenging 2 hour underground trek. A mom, dad and their two young boys (from London) were in our group and they had a much easier time of it than we three - the kids got a big kick out of the bats, the catfish, and the nearly invisible shrimp in the river. Life jackets, water shoes and helmets required - wet suits optional (all provided by the preserve).

Best experience in the Yucatan. I grew up in the mountains of Colorado and caving was one of my favorite activities- in fact, my brother and I would scour the hills and try to find unscouted caves in addition to the ones that were on maps. Rio Secreto was incredible and likely the best caving experience I've ever had the fortune to enjoy. The natural beauty of the cave with its formations, fossils, water system, mayan archaeological remains are part one to the formula- incredible guides and a well run company are the second. It was the highlight of our trip to the Riviera Maya- kids, adults, cavers and non-cavers alike. We had our kids- ages 10-12 along and they were able to do the experience as well and also claimed it as their highlight.

This Cave is alive!. Having explored a good number of sizeable caves in Colorado, Rio Secreto goes down in my book as the most amazing cave I have ever experienced. This cave is bursting with life... full of more stalactites, stalagmites, columns, heliotites (sp.?), flowstone, and crystal clear water than my mind could take in. Many people think of caves as dark places underground where most living creatures avoid. We had the pleasure of observing cave crickets, bats, catfish, fresh water shrimp, and other fascinating creatures of the underworld, not to mention the ancient fossils and evidence of the Mayans. This experience was by far the highlight of my entire trip to the Riviera Maya. I appreciate how the staff at Rio Secreto seeks to conserve these wonderful places and create an unforgettable, safe, nature experience for anyone willing to take the plunge.-Ryan Stowell

Neat experience. Hadn't planned this one, but no regrets. Amazing expience. Our guide, Alfredo, was the best and very well informed. You walk through majority of the caves, about 1/3 is water that you can actually swim in. that was our major disappointment. We thought most of it was swimming from the brochures. The guides go a little too fast. 1 1/2hr tour. As you are walking on uneven ground in the dark, your eyes are focused on the ground ahead of you, so you're missing the views. need to slow it down a bit.excursion included "snack" which consisted of fruit and natcho's with cheese. you CAN purchase additional food. not impressed with "snack"no cameras but they do sell you cd pictures, naturallyoverall give it a thumbs up!

An awesome Secret Experience. When I was first approached with the idea of exploring these caves, I must admit, I was not too enthused. However, from the moment we were picked up by the tour company in Playa del Carmen, all the way through to the end, I had a great experience. Our tour was Alfredo and you could tell in the way in which he explained the history and different caves we explored, the love he has for what he does. We were all very impressed with our tour and recommend anyone who is visiting to take the time to visit Rio Secreto. It's not going to be a secret much longer, so go soon!Be ready for some cool water, but they have great gear to protect you from that.

Pretty Terrific and good for all ages. So my husband-to-be (who is claustrophobic) suggested that we go into a cave on our carribean honeymoon and I said "What? The last place I want to be is a dark, damp cave while in the Carribean". He then insisted that the reviews of this little known treasure on Trip Advisor were great. Well, after going, I had to admit for the first (of many) times I would have to admit that he was right. First of all, by the time our trip to Rio Secreto had arrived, we were looking for a morning break from the sun. As this trip was 10 minutes from our hotel (literally right outside of Playa del Carmen), it was very convenient to get to. Additionally, as the whole tour was only about 2 hours, it did not eat up too much of our day so that we were free to get back to lounging on the beach sipping cocktails after we were done. The cave was amazing, the water was awesome (so pure that the salt from your skin divided the salt in the water) and our guide was phenominal and so knowledgeable about the archelogical as well as practical facts about the cave. Just have to give a shout out to the reviewer who suggested buying the print package and sharing with someone as it made the prints so much more affordable. The downfall is that the person buying the prints after the fact gets all of the group shots, extra pictures and then the individual shots only of the person who actually paid. Thus, factor this in when deciding how to split the cost. When we realized we felt bad at first, but then realized that we gave the rest of the group a free lift back to their hotel, so it saved them a $20 cab fare in any event. As to restrictions you should be aware of, they recommend that anyone with bad knees or ashtma not go in. Now, I have bad knees and slight asthma, and did not have any problems, but be mindful of this with regard your group's limitations. Additionally, age wise, I would recommend anyone over the age of 7 yrs old who is in good physical shape. There is a lot of squatting and some tight spaces. Our group had 3 teenagers, a middle aged woman, my husband and myself, and, once you got the hang of things, no one seemed to have a problem. One critique, though, is that the "lunch" they provided really left much to be desired. It was nachos and some fruit, and that was it. As I am lactose intolerant, I had a couple of chips and ate lunch when we returned to the hotel. They really should either make it more lunch-like or not advertise that they serve lunch at all as we decided not to eat breakfast to ensure that we did not have to take care of any "business" while in the cave and were ravenous by the time we got back to the hotel. One more note, please respect the rules regarding sunblock and bug spray. This is a pretty unique bit of nature that was only recently discovered and the foreign sprays really do affect the ecosystem there.

Amazing Experience!!!. I cannot rave about Rio Secreto enough. The staff our friendly, the experience is unforgetttable and one in a million, and the scenario is breathtaking. This is an experience that you cannot get anywhere else. It is definitely one of the great wonders of the world. It was a stunning underground river with thousands of dramatic stalactites and stalagmites. They do not lie when they say that it’s like stepping back in time to witness something mysterious and truly spectacular. It is enchanting and spiritual.Our guide was Benito who was very well spoken, put safety first, and was funny, friendly, and nice. My wife cannot swim, but they provided her with a life jacket, and Benito checked on her safety throughout and floated her through the few minutes of area where you were unable to walk. They give you free food and beverages, but there are more for purchase. In addition to the cave, the jungle surrounding this location is beautiful!

Really a cool experience!. We booked this excursion for one morning on our vacation July 2011. We are glad we did. The underground caves are beautiful and our guide Alfredo was great!They give you all the gear you need. The water in the underground river is clear and cool and it's not scary at all. Our group had older adults who were a little slow but still able to do the tour. At the end they provided us with some nachos and juice, nice touch.One thing we were disappointed about was the fact that cameras are not allowed down in the caves. The photographer they send along with you takes some really nice pictures but they try to charge you $25 US for one print at the end! This is ridiculous! Not a single person in our group purchased a photo. If they lowered the price to $5-10 US I guarantee everyone would have bought at least one if not two. It's unfortunate that we do not have any pictures to keep our memory fresh.Overall, this was one of the best excursions we have been on!

Better than I had expected. I purchased this adventure for my boyfriend and I while we were on a family vacation to Mexico. I was a little leary at first about this, I wasn't sure I was cut out for it, but I truly enjoyed it. We arrived to the main waiting area which very nice and the staff was great. Here we waited for others coming in for the 9am tour and then headed on our way up the bumpy road to the changing area. We got our stuff locked up, showered and got our gear on and headed to the cave. It was gorgeous! Our tour guide Benito was extremely knowledgeable! We got to see a couple of bats and a fish and Benito taught us all about the different rock formations. After we exited the cave, you go get out of all your gear, priview your pictures, redress and enjoy a very nice snack buffet. At this time we got to visit with the folks from our group which was great getting to discuss our favorite parts of the tour and learning more about the people that you have just spent several hours with. I wasn't sure that I would love this excursion, but I absolutely did. I want to go back and do another one! Thanks Rio Secreto!

Once in a lifetime experience. Rio Secreto was $79 per person for transportation, a 2 hour tour, and lunch. It is totally worth the money and a once in a lifetime experience. You get to see naturally made caves from underground rivers, swim in the water underground, learn about how the formations happened, and much more. Our tour guide was Victor who was very professional and nice. There is a professional photographer who takes photos of you through out your tour. The pictures are sold on a CD for $69, which is pricey but when will you ever have photos like this again? I'm not sure if you aren't allowed to take cameras but our guide instructed them to leave them in our locker. I have a waterproof digital so was tempted to bring it but I'm so glad I didn't. It would have taken away from the adventure. I would put this at the top of your list for activities while visiting Playa, Rivera Maya, or Tulum. Great time with spectactular scenery!

Incredible Experience!!!. If your planning on visiting the Riviera Maya and aren't sure what tours to do, well, Rio Secreto should be on the top of your list!!!! I came upon this tour through trip advisor and read all the reviews and it seemed to me that everyone loved this cave experience, so we decided to join in and see what it is about. We loved everyone minute of it. First Id like to complement on everyone that works for Rio Secreto, they are extremely nice, attentive and knowledgeable about the underground water rivers. Benito, our tour guide made us feel very comfortable and relaxed.He knew all about the underground water system in the Yucatan Peninsula which is extremely important when taking on a tour like this.They pick you up from your hotel...this is a plus!!! You provide them with the time and they are there no minute later!! Upon arrival we were greeted and taken to the actual site where we needed to get ready for our adventure!!They then gave you all the necessary gear that you need like the wet suit, water shoes, and flash light helmet and towels We only had to bring our bathing suits. That was a big plus for us that we didn't have to purchase anything extra or lug anything around. Throughout the tour, Rio Secreto has provided your group with its own photographer capturing memorable moments within the cave. You are not allowed to bring your own cameras....its all natural!!! They do not want anything in the cave that can contaminate it.After, they provided us with a small lunch buffet and a nice shot of their homemade liquor...felt just right after the experience we just had!!! You have three different options of souvenir packages to choose from depending on what your budget it. They range from 25 dollars to 100 dollar package. You definitely want to bring something back with you, so bring some extra cash! Don't forget to tip you tour guide...they deserve it!!!!We left Rio Secreto with an experience we will never forget. This tour made our trip to Mexico even more amazing!!! We highly recommend Rio Secreto!!

Awesome! worth every cent you gotta go!. If you are interested in mayan culture and caves this is a great place to go. It was tons of fun. I really cant say one bad thing about this place. The guide was great and very knowledgable. As far as not bring cameras thats common sense if you've been to this tour. It is very important that you dont bring anything extra into the cave. You could accidently lose it and it can offset the environment. They even make you take a quick shower in your bathing suit before you set off to go down into the caves. This was such an awesome trip. After a 15 minute ride through the jungle you get to the area where you change and get geared up to go into the cave. Then you walk through the jungle 5-10 minutes to the caves. Right before you enter the caves you receive a mayan blessing (small cermony) which was awesome. Then off to the caves. You are walking on and off down there about 45 minutes and swimming about 10 minutes if that. It really is beautiful down there. I really love it. Then a short walk back through the jungle. The pictures are 69 for the cd or 25 each. We didnt purchase them but we may of gotten one if ours came out. Any how if you are thinking of this tour do it! its worth every penny!

This is a MUST!. I went on this just last Thursday and I absolutely looooved every part of this adventure! It feels like you are a true explorer in your wetsuit, helmet, and headlamp and the caves themselves are just breathtaking! You cannot take in a camera with you but they take pictures for you and even though you have to pay for them they are taken with a very nice camera and turn out wonderfully and are worth the price to have nice pictures from this beautiful place! Don't miss out on your very own Indiana Jones moment!!

AWESOME!. This was the highlight of our trip. Our guide Alfredo was AMAZING. We had our 5, 7 and 12 year old boys with us. The 7 year old as a little scared to start, but was trying to lead the tour by the end. Our 5 year old was scared almost the whole time and our guide CARRIED HIM THE WHOLE WAY. He didn't make that seem like a burden, either. It was a great experience. DO IT!Although there is a cost for the Pictures, it is much less expensive and you feel less ripped off than you do at other excursions. For the $99 package, you get three souvenirs. These include a choice of bottle of local liquor (Xtabeltum?), swim shirts or printed photos. This is in addition to the CD of photographs.

No reason why a camera isn't allowed- except ripoff. I paid 79.95 for the tour and they did not allow cameras. You had to be in your bathing suit so you could not sneak in a camera. They say no metals are allowed but yet they had plenty of metal too. There of course was plenty of photographers who charge 69.95 for all the pictures. This is a ripoff

amazing not to be missed. was fantastic not to be missed i was taken for my birthday and WOW what a great trip you don't need to take anything really as all provided wet suits & towels i am a bigger lady and i still managed and our guide was fantastic

An amazing sight. We booked the Rio Secreto Tour after reading the Trip Advisor reviews and it did not disappoint. The fun starts when you get on the van and go for a bumpy ride to the rally point where you meet your guide. Our guide was Rafa. He was very friendly, knowledgeable and truly loves what he does. He stressed the importance of respecting the site and not disturbing anything in the cave. The best part is when he tell you to turn off your headlamps and you sit in complete darkness for about a minute. You are not allowed to bring anything on the tour so they have a photographer follow your group around and you can purchase the pictures at the end (a little expensive but they are worth it). The snacks at the end were good but don't expect them to fill you up. Skip the parasailing and wave runners! Rio Secreto is a must!

Absolutely Loved It!. Me and two of my friends decided to go on this underground river expedition while on Spring Break. We were on a cruise that stopped in Cancun and while most people spent the entire layover drinking at Senor Frogs, we took the ferry over to the main land to Playa Del Carmen. We weren't sure which activity we wanted to do but I'm so glad we chose this one. As many have said it starts with an unbelievably bumpy, long van ride through the jungle. Not the most comfortable trip, but it was amazing at how long we kept driving and all we could see was jungle around us. Once there you get your wetsuit, life vest, helmet and water shoes. Once your in this very flattering outfit you head to the mouth of the cave. Then it's an hour and a half to two hour adventure through this unbelievable sanctuary. I'd been caving once before, but I liked this experience much better. The fact that you're going through a river makes it more fun somehow and adds to the colors. At a few points the water was deep enough that we had to swim, but it's mostly wading. I can sometimes have issues with claustrophobia and the movies where people are trapped in the caves terrify me, but I never once felt uncomfortable while in the caves. Afterwards they have some side dishes for you to eat and quesadillas that you can purchase for like $5, which I definitely recommend, they were delicious. Pablo was our guide. He was the absolute best!!! He changed my perspective on life a little bit. Before we went in he told us to leave all our worries about work and school and whatever behind in the outside world, and just enjoy being in the now in the beautiful caves. And we did, and it was so refreshing and uplifting and it stayed with me even after I left. They take some photos of your group at a couple points in the caves and everyone asked Pablo to be in their pictures. On the way back, he told us a little about his story and how he ended up working there. And hearing how much he loved his job and where he lived really inspired me to try for what I really want. Sidenote: We were on the Carnival Cruise, and picked this out of their booklet of activities. Some of them are way overpriced (don't do parasailing, you can find it cheaper on your own), but this one was great. It was $100 and it included the ferry ride from Cancun to the mainland, which was a gorgeous trip on its own, transportation to the activity, and then the expedition itself. We also had about an hour after getting back from the caves to explore Playa Del Carmen or go to the beach there before getting the ferry back to Cancun. And we still had a little time to see Cancun too.

Best tour ... Hands down. First let me start out by saying that from the moment miguel picks you up from your hotel to the time you arrive at the staging area, you can tell its a top shelf operation. The briefing area was impeccably maintained and the organic coffee bar was a treat :)The real adventure starts when you climb into the van from the staging area and head into the jungle to the entry point, about a km. There we were introduced to our guide Dante. Dante live eats and breaths the caves. Which made him an absolutely stellar guide. He made what would appear to anyone watching the discovery channel dangerous, treacherous or scary into one of the coolest experiences of my life. Hats off to Dante and the crew at Rio Secreto for what can only be described as amazingThanksDoug & Jessica

Recommend. We recommend this attraction if you like cenotes and water and caves, they have an amazing cave network and they can even take you ou to different routes if you go more than once, be ready to walk and do some exercise. Have fun!

Like Another World!!. This tour was absolutely amazing!From the moment you enter the cave, you truly feel like you have entered another world.Some of the staglagmite and stalagtites were at least a million years old. Our guide was Benito and he was very informative and took the time to explain things to us all along our tour.One of the coolest things for me was, we entered a large chamber sat down (in about a foot of water), turned off all lights, with complete silence for a few minutes. Complete darkness that far underground...very intense!As you walk, the footing is unsure and you must walk single file. All this while not touching any of the formations around you. At some points you take a drop down into the water and swim for a bit....this was one of my favorite parts.This truly was quite an experience, like nothing I had ever seen. Highly recommend!

Enchanting!. Rio Secreto provides a river caving experience. All gear is supplied: aqua shoes, swim vests, short style wet suits, helmets with head lamps. A nice snack is provided at the end of the tour. A tour guide leads the small groups into the cave. You must walk through the river within the cave and sometimes swim through certain parts. The only lights are the headlamps on our helmets. The experienced guide explains the formation of the stalagmites and stalactites, the kinds of animals that live within the cave, etc. A photographer snaps pictures in various locations for optional purchase before leaving the grounds. This was a wonderful tour - not for kids under 12, I would say - that requires some flexibility in movement - crouching, stepping on slippery rocks, swimming - all without touching the stalagmites/stalactites. Some passageways were a bit narrow. The only thing that marred this tour was the push to purchase expensive photos - which of course, thankfully, you do not have to. If you are claustrophobic, don't go.

Unbelievable experience- unlike anything we'd ever done!. Swimming by headlamp through crystal clear water, surrounded by stalagmites and stalactites and other amazing rock formations, was one of the absolute highlights of our vacation in Playa del Carmen! We were truly in awe and our guide was very knowledgeable and excited to be there with us. I was a little nervous going into the tour since I've always been a little uneasy in caves but I was so distracted by the incredible sights around us that it never bothered me at all! There's tons to do in the Playa del Carmen area but the Rio Secreto is definitely worth some of your time!

Fascinating, fantastic and fabulous!. Everybody should do this one!I really did think that I would hate this tour because I am a little clausterphobic. And, yes, it was a little scary at first when I saw how dark it was but I'll admit I was too fascinated by everything I saw to really notice. And most of the path they took us on was relatively open anyway.On your trek through the 'Secret River' you see amazing rock formations and interesting animal life (we saw a spider, a few fish and a couple of bats) as your guide describes it all to you. It was very informative and quite an experience - I never thought I'd go spalunking!Our guide was really good - very knowledgeable and friendly.Having the professional photographer follow you around to take pictures was also a nice addition (you aren't allowed to bring ANYTHING on the tour with you - including a waterproof camera). The CD was expensive though (especially compared to other tours we took on the same trip) and we only bought one shot of us in the cenotes. But its a great one!Just a suggestion - there are several different tours around Mexico that will take you down to underground cenotes so make sure you don't book the same thing twice. We did a full-day tour a few days later and did another cenote tour (not as involved but very similar). 2 notes...they do provide you with everything you need for the trek - including watershoes. You have to leave everything behind - jewellery, wallet, cameras, etc...and they provide a locker with a key for each person. BUT each key opens all the locks - we had no problems but I'm glad I hadn't brought anything valuable. Second - the food that was provided at the end of the tour wasn't very good so bring your own or eat when you get back to your hotel!

Forget the beaches, the pool and the sea, take the time to visit this natural underground wonder.. If you are in the Cancun or Playa del Carmen area of the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico, take the time to visit Rio Secreto. Forget about the beaches, the pools, the paragliding and all the other myriad of day activities offered in the area and spend a couple of hours walking half submerged through the caves and caverns of Rio Secreto. Ask for Adriana as a guide and you will get a heartfelt and sincere guide who clearly enjoys what she is doing and this is reflected in the way she expresses and conducts her tours. For an area of Mexico that is mostly known for its beaches, water sports and nightlife, this is a great change of pace and certainly worth doing. As the attraction offers several routes, it can certainly be visited more than once and the next time I am in the area, I will go back.Also keep in mind that this is a tourist attraction, they will try to sell you a souvenir CD with pictures (taken at selected locations during the tour) at the end of the journey (no personal cameras or camcorders are allowed inside). Included in the price of admission is a snack and they will pick you up and take you back to your hotel as far as Cancun (about 1hr by car) which makes the journey even easier.

terrific experience. There are a variety of amazing sites and attractions along the Mexican Yucatan, and on a vacation of a limited duration, you need to choose them wisely. Rio Secreto is a fantastic experience and one which I highly recommend to folks who want an uncrowded, non-touristy natural adventure. The beautiful underground cavern/river is inspiring, spectacular and in a fully natural state. The educational and adventurous tour is led with sensitivity and relaxation. The groups are small enough to feel personalized. My teenagers really liked it -- headlamps,dazzling formations, hiking, ducking through dripping stalagtites, swimming across crystalline pools, and more. The post-tour liquer drink and the fruit and chip snacks were nice, as were the fresh showers and the lockers. If you are tired of bustling ziplines, crowded cenotes, and touristy Xcaret, then put this at the top of your list. My only issue is the one others mention -- you cannot take your own camera inside the cavern. However, I do feel that the tour would probably be really obnoxious with constant picture taking by every group member -- and their photos would likely turn out poorly anyway given the difficult lighting down there. In this respect, the professional photographer on the tour is probably the best compromise. Just buy the picture CD and consider that to be part of your admission price. The professional pictures look really good (although I would have liked the guy to have taken more than one shot of each setting.) Along with a full day with Edventures, a tour with Rio Secreto is an outstanding way to see some of best of the Yucatan.

Rio Secreto should be included to the 1,000 places to see before you die.. I was hesitant to write a review for Rio Secreto because I would like it to remain a secret from the world. I am afraid if it gets too commercial the many visitors may have a negative impact on the pristine and preserved environment inside of the cave. If you do visit please be sure to not wear any sunblock, perfumes, or creams because the chemicals affect the organisms in the water inside the cave. I can't say enough about how much I learned with our guide, Dante. He was very knowledgeable and remembered all our names! I went with my teenage sister and 65 year old father,(Sergio) and both had an amazing time! We came back to the states with a new appreciation for what lies beneath the surface of the earth and even more respect for mother nature. I love it. All the guides are fluent in many languages so you will learn and have fun no matter where you travel from.Well worth it! Get the picture package. You will regret it if you don't. We did and they pics are very professional. It was a memorable experience.Thank you, Dante!!!

A sight that must not be missed. Myself and my husband have just return from Mexico and the only thing that we keep talking about is this hidden treasure.If you love cave and caverns this is a must even if you don't you should go.Our tour was for 1hour and we ended up being in the caves for 2 hours just couldn't get enough. Many thanks to our wonderful Guide Gonzo he has a great passion for this natural wonder,and because of our interest he extended our time there. If you are at all claustrophobic don't go, or small childern

Best Kept Secret on the Yucatan!. My husband and I have visited the Yucatan and Cozumel numerous times. We thought we had exhausted all that we could do in the area. We are very into the Mayan culture. We have visited all the local ruins in the area and thought we could not expand on the culture any more. This cave experience was awesome! Alfredo our guide took us into the caverns and explained how Caves were sacred to the Mayans and we were able to experience the beauty and an old Mayan ritual while in the cave.If you have never explored a cave this is the ultimate experience of going into one. I have visited dry caves and scuba dived into caves and this gives you the experience of both types with out having to dive! My husband and I both came home with a memorable experience!

Absolutely breathtaking & beautiful!. When booking our excursion to Rio Secreto, I truly underestimated the experience we were about to have at this location. Our tour guide, Gonzo, informed us that we were about to experience true beauty, and that is what we saw. Words cannot express our experience. My teenage son and I had such an enjoyable time. Everything was amazing and the memories will last forever. Do not miss this excursion when staying in Mexico!

Goes Beyond the Expected: A Must Do. We did the 'Rio Secreto' or 'Amazing Secret River' adventure as part of a shore excursion off the Oasis of the Seas. It stands out as one of the highlights of our awesome 14-day cruise.We've been around the world and 'done' a few caves - Jenolan in the Blue Mountains, Australia and Cango Caves in South Africa come to mind immediately; this one goes over and beyond those great experiences!Rio Secreto is like a guided tour into the core of the earth where you encounter crystal clear water, dark caverns, awe-inspiring stalactites and stalagmites, underground vegetation and more... The tour begins with an ancient Myan invocation for a successful and safe journey, and togged in your wet-suit (optional), water shoes, life jackets and helmet with light, you begin your descent into a truly dark world with your cave explorer guide. You find your way gingerly through rocky terrain and ankle deep water in a single file, trying to keep your hands off the walls lest you mess with the natural formations. At various points your guide stops to display and explain the wonders of nature around you. You swim (or float!) through one long stretch and that is the best part of the entire experience. An accompanying photographer captures your expedition on camera.The underground part of the tour takes about 60 to 90 minutes, but you do not feel it. Would definitely not advise it if you have breathing problems or are not able to adjust to dark, damp conditions and walk uneven surfaces. We are not swimmers but had no problem with the life vests and the expert guidance of our guide Alfredo who was articulate, experienced and immensely helpful.You have lockers to leave your stuff, an on-site cafetaria with some great quesadillas and you can pick up your adventure pictures before you leave. Truly an experience ....... would highly recommend it for those who want to go off the beaten track!

best excursion during my stay in mexico. this trip was amazing. views were awesome, guide (gonzo) was wonderful/knowledgable. they picked us up from our hotel on time and everyone was very friendly. they have a shuttle from the check-in to the area where the lockers/showers are (about 10min) ride which they call the mayan massage because the road is so rocky and it really is like a roller coaster. the helmets/wet suits were smelly but i expected that from the other reviews. But once you get into the caves, you forget about all of that because it really is an amazing sight to see. the water is really clear, and the formations inside the caves were spectacular. I too was bummed out that i couldn't take my waterproof camera into the caves to take pictures, but once you get inside there, you realize that even with a professional grade flash, you would barely be able to capture what it looks like. Without flashlights, it's pitch black. we ended up buying the picture cd at the end of the tour for $69. we splitted it with another couple that we did the trip with so it wasn't so bad. the down side was that the lunch they serve is just nachos and fruit. wish it was something more substantial but you'd have to pay extra to get more stuff. overall it was a great experience and would definitely recommend to all.

Rio Secreto - Awesome Cave Experience. I book this through Carnival Cruises while in port Cozumel. Dwfinitely worth the time and money. There aren't many places you can actually awim through underground caverns, examine cave formation from inside, etc. You are provided a good quality wetsuit, water shoes, helmet, and life vest. All you need for a great adventure. This does require some climbing, swiming, and access to tight space but its quite possibly a once in a lifetime opportunity. Id highly recommend Rio Secreto!

The best Excursion of our trip. We actually booked this one with the ship. The challenge of getting there from a ship was a little daunting so we let them guide us door to door. We started early on the ferry to the mainland. Sitting on the stern we had a wonderfully bumpy ride and chatted with David who is from Halifax. He was on this trip by himself as his wife was not really an underground secret river type person.Angel met us at Playa del Camon and our group of nine now boarded a van. It took us about 20 minutes to get out of town and then up a very bumpy road into the jungle. We were in introduced to our guide Gonzo and he outfitted us with wet suits, watershoes, helmets, and lights. He made us hit the washroom and have a shower. THIS TRIP WAS AWSOME!!!We started into the caves, (cenote) at times we were walking, wading, swimming and walking chest deep down the river. The sights were more than I really could imagine even having seen the photos ahead of time. We saw crab spiders, also know as whip spiders, bats and catfish. Gonzo was so excited to share his love of the cenote we were in you couldn't help but realize how lucky you were to have him as a guide and to have the honour of exploring the river. We were not to touch things, not to pee in the water, and no cameras. One area had the stalactites quite red/brown looking. That apparently was created by a fridge door being dumped on the jungle floor and left to rust.Two hours sped by and out we came for a light lunch and relaxing in the hammocks.Angel met us and back to Playa del Carmon where there was time for a wander though town and a dip in the water, Berfore we took the ferry arriving back on the ship at 4:50 with a departure at 5. We were fine with the photo cd and the cost was high, but the photos were great and it was something that I enjoyed completely.

Really cool, fun, different experience on vacation!. My wife and I booked this excursion from our Royal Carribean Cruise stop in Cozumel. It was a great experience. Dante was our guide. Very nice, friendly, educated, & fun guide. Never been in caves before, always looking for that different experience... go to beaches all the time. They do not allow you to take your own pics, you have to buy theirs. $69 for allyour pics of the day plus a bunch of stock photos. I think its worth it, gotta have pics of this to show your friends and family.Would highly recommend this trip.

Amazing Experience with Some Tacky Issues. Let me first say, this is a must when visiting the area. I am so glad that we decided to visit Rio Secreto on our last day in Playa Del Carmen. The underground caves are absolutely stunning and amazing and when would you ever be able to do something like this again? It is simply breathtaking and worth the $59 for the guided tour. What is unnecessary about the tour are the constant stops to take pictures of each couple/group/family. During the tour you are followed by a photographer who makes you stop and pose in just about every cavern whether you like it or not. Not only do you stop and pose for pictures, but the photographer is also taking candids of you as you try and navigate the caves without touching anything and falling on your butt. To say it is annoying is an understatement. The reason for all the pictures is because they try and sell them to you for incredibility inflated prices at the end of the tour. No, I did not buy any pictures, but you do have a few months to purchase them through pay pal once you return from your trip or so they say. When I got home and tried to contact them to see the pictures so I could debate for a 2nd time if I wanted to purchase any, I was told that you first have to pay before even viewing them. Actually when I e-mailed them they did not even respond, but sent me a pay pal order form 3 times without ever allowing me to first view the pictures. The lunch you are promised after the tour is not a lunch, but simply a snack of chips and fruit. If you would like something more like a simple taco then you have to shell out more money. Also, I encourage you to tip your tour guild because they do an excellent job informing you on all the great aspects of the caves, but what I don't recommend is the staff asking you for a review of their services and a tip at the end of the tour while you are at the snack area. Tacky yes........

Awesome 1/2 day trip!. If possible, go early! The water is clear, and the wet-suits a little bit dry. No snorkelling, and my swim ability is minimal, but I was fine. Pictures at the end were the usual tourist trap (can't bring your own camera). If possible book with Benito, he was GREAT!

Want to go back...for 5 hrs next time!!. My husband and I went on a tour to Rio Secreto on Jun 1. This place is so cool! We took the colectivo from our hotel (VIM)....well, we took a colectivo, got kicked out then took a cab the rest of the way. We still aren't sure what was going on with the colectivo getting pulled over and all the passengers getting kicked out, but we still made it for our tour on time. Back to the review... we were in a group of 10 - the max for a group. Alfredo was our guide and did a wonderful job!! Our tour lasted about 3 hours or so, but didn't feel like it at all. We could have stayed down there and explored much longer. We found out later that there is a longer "VIP" tour that we could take, but that one isn't advertised online. Our next time in the Riveria Maya, we'll definitely do that.You walk, wade, squat walk in some places and swim through this magnificent wonder. If you have knee problems, claustrophia or nyctophobia this may not be for you. If you can't swim, it's not a problem though. You are required to wear a life jacket the whole time. The life jackets are great. I couldn't sink if I wanted to! The snack at the end isn't all that great, but the quesadilla for purchase was good. It was $3 and a good size one. We got 2 cokes and a quesadilla for $7. I do think they should include just a little more for the snack, but the tour was worth it. We also bought the picture CD at the end for $69. We knew how much the CD was going to be and that we would want it so every opportunity we had we asked the photographer to take our picture.As others have mentioned in a few other reviews, expect a bumpy ride from the main gate to the cave staging area. They do pack you in the van, so be prepared to get cozy with strangers. :)

Loved it and greatly appreciated the optional walking sticks. Touring Rio Secreto is a fantastic experience. We were a group of six in our late 40s to early 50s. We all enjoyed it immensely, including our one non-swimmer and two clausterphobia-prone individuals. There is no real swimming involved, only leisurely floating with heads out of the water in the life jacket they provide. The cave is hugh with high ceilings, so no one in our group felt closed in.The guide offered us walking sticks made of sturdy, yet lightweight, wood if we wanted them. All three females in our group opted for the walking sticks and were so glad we did. The walking sticks gave us some security as we navigated the uneven terrain in the cave which had no lighting except for our headlamps and guide's flashlight. The walking sticks were also good to stick down in the water to measure how deep the next step would be. I used the walking stick to "feel" my way through the underwater areas instead of leading with my shin. :)Regarding the photos at the end--I guess I have been on a few too many cruises to be shocked by the price of the professional photos. And at Rio Secreto you get an entire cd of pictures, not just one shot. The photographer uses a large flash so the pictures have enough light. We loved having someone else take the pictures so we could actually be in them together. It was also great to be able to focus on the beauty of the cave without worrying around with a camera. I have enjoyed showing off my incredible pictures since I have been home. Don't let a few dollars keep you from a wonderful keepsake of your cave experience.Rio Secreto is a gorgeous, living cave with unbelievable formations and beautiful water. I was awestruck thoughout the entire journey. Our guide, Karen, was enthusiastic and well informed. Overall, this is a not-to-be-missed experience. We will definately do this tour again the next time we are in the area.

Unbelievably awesome!!!. To see nature at its most beautiful. I was amazed by the beauty of it and the pure silence. Eddie our tour guide was the best!! and we were very impressed with how they are trying to preserve it while enjoying it.A definite must see!!!

Absolutely Amazing!!!. We booked this tour through Carnival Cruise Lines, and went on 5/25. We had very high expectations, and this tour EXCEEDED them. The caves were amazing, and our tour guide, Alfredo, was SUPERB. He was very knowledgeable and friendly. Inside the caves were stunningly beautiful and Alfredo made us feel very safe and answered all of our questions. You truly feel like you are experiencing something that nobody has ever seen before when you take this tour. Very professional staff. We were in good hands and had an amazing experience.
