Well worth the price, and I will surely go back again the next time I'm in that corner of the world.

It was Fantastic, highly recommend it!!!. Went on this tour through the carnival Imagination. Was well worth the money. We were a group of 6 people with the tour guide Alfredo who was Great. Ask for him. He is very informative and passionate about cave exploring.They give you all the equipment you need and nice facilities. Went on 5/25/11.

boring Marxist tour guide drone cancels out beautiful cave. Spend top dollar for a walking tour of pristine underground water caves of all the while suffering through the tour guide's endless harangues against wealth (the same wealth which is paying her salary).The tour guide informs you that humans are extraneous, people shouldn't be born. This is irksome when you are taking your own children at a cost of multiple hundreds of dollars on this tour.The tour guide naturally doesn't consider herself "extra" (after conversation) so the implication presumably is that you or your children are. The tour guide is opposed to tourism, considering it one more rape of the landscape and local populace. The tour guide opposes people's visiting the pristine cave, furthering despoiling of the environment.All this begging the question of why she is there and from whom her salary emanates. She has all the familiar Marxist rants, saying that "rich people having too much money" is evil and "should have their money taken away to give to the poor".She tried to show us the "quiet" of the cave, but only after 12 minutes of speech enforcing everyone's guilt at breathing and living.(except of course for herself, because she is one of the "good people").The tour guide is not native to the area, coming from middle class, middle-Mexico, with a college degree, and fashionable PC/socialist juvenile theories; yet of course she is not an interloper. This is particularly tiresome after the tour, she is effectively begging for her tip (interrupting our normal flow of conversation to repeatedly mention tipping practices after such a tour); all while pimping $60 photograph-CD's (we are not allowed to bring our own cameras on the tour). All to the good because we have "redistributed" our wealth to her own!Avoid this sanctimonious drivel, which ruins a beautiful cave.

SIMPLY MAGICAL. Visited Rio Secreto on 5/16 and returned 5/17 to tour a different section of caverns. You walk, wade, and swim through an underground caverns full of stalactites and stalagmites. This excursion, is not an easy walk in the park. You are in natural caverns and you do need to have good balance and stability as the areas are sometimes very narrow, uneven and slippery. Plus, you need to be very careful how you move around both in and out of the water. The cave formations are extremely delicate, so you need to be careful of what you touch. Touching them can easily break them off which can ruin what it has taken thousands of years to develop. It is truly an unbelievable "National Geographic" experience. I will return next spring to tour yet another section. Don't miss this experience!

Worth the money. We made our reservations on line and did not choose to be picked up at our hotel - we saved $30 each by taking the colectivo. This was one of the more spectacular trips we have taken in the area - nearly 3 hours of walking, wading, and swimming through a cave full of fantastic stalactites and other formations. Walking on the very uneven surfaces was a challenge but the provided water shoes had good traction and there were no slippery areas. At one point, our guide Alfredo (great guide) had everyone turn off their lights for a couple of minutes and be quiet. That was the scariest part of the whole trip. Everyone was happy to see that Alfredo was still there when the lights came back on. I would highly recommend this tour.

AWESOME OTHER WORLD EXPERIENCE. We usually stay away from things like this, but after reading all the reviews and seeing the pictures, we thought we'd give it a whirl. So glad we did!! Even getting to the site is an adventure over a roller coaster type road cut through the jungle. It is amazing that this place was only discovered a few years ago. It's absolutely breathtaking inside with so many formations - and the funnest part is floating along through the river - it feels Disneyesque, but it's real! Our guide was great and very informative. The only thing I would have changed was that our group of 6 English speaking people was put with 4 Spanish speaking people - so everyone had to listen to everything twice - making it a bit long. I could do away with the "snack" at the end also. But - be sure to buy the pictures, as you can't take your camera with you. The pictures are spectacular. The rental gear is in good shape - but we took our own water booties. We are divers and have dived in cenotes before - I enjoyed this experience more than a dive - there was so much to see from every direction. Don't miss it! It's worth the $60.00. Probably wouldn't take children younger than 8-9 on this. Length is at least 2/12 to 3 hours.

Amazing Experience!. I recently had the opportunity to visit Cancun with my Father and Brother and we had about half of a day that needed to be filled. We decided to try Rio Secreto "Secret River" and it was a great experience. We got to wade/swim through an underground cave full of stalactites and stalagmites. Does it get any more adventurous than that?!?! Even though the tour group was made up of about 5 Spanish speakers and 5 English speakers, our tour guide Jorge was able to bounce back from Spanish to English easily and he made the trip through the caverns not only enjoyable but fascinating. Two thumbs way up to Jorge!!! I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a bit of adventure.

WHAT TO EXPECT AT RIO SECRETO. Coming to Rio Secreto is an unbelievable and amazing experience you will remember for a life time. The caves are beautiful and the water filling them even more stunning. When inside the caves, you will feel like you're on the National Geographic Channel - it's that amazing! Your experience can really be enhanced with the right guide too. This excursion, however, is not an easy walk in the park. You are in a natural cave formation and you do need to have good balance and stability as the areas you will be walking in are sometimes very narrow, uneven and slippery. Plus, you need to be very careful how you walk and what you touch. The cave formations are extremely delicate, and touching them can easily break them off which can ruin the cave's beauty.When you arrive at Rio Secreto, you will take a 15-20 min. "bus" ride down a dirt road to the entrance of the caves. Once there, you will be fitted with swim shoes, a wet suit, life jacket and helmet (with head lamp). FYI - the caves are cool and so is the water that you will be swimming in. If you get cold easily, make sure you ask to wear the thicker wet suit that cuts off at the knees. They do have full body wet suits but the material is very thin and you could be feeling uncomfortably cold. With the shorter suite, you may knick your knees and get a couple scratches but I think that's better than freezing the whole time you're down there. Once you have all your gear, you will take a 3 minute walk down a jungle path and then some steps down into the cave. (You're not allowed to bring your camera or anything else into the cave!) Once inside, you will walk around the cave's formations and down specific paths and will eventually encounter water, then more water, then pretty deep water where you will need to swim. A photographer comes into the cave with everyone and they take several pictures which they charge big $$$ for you to buy if you want your picture after the tour. There are 2 tours available - the basic tour and the "privilege" tour. I have done both. With the basic tour, you're in the cave 1 1/2 to 2 hours. With the privilege tour, they take you very deep into the cave until you reach another end, where the cave collapsed, and sunlight comes through - you then take a slightly different route back and out. Altogether, this tour is approx. 5 hr. It may seem long, but honestly, the time went by so quickly because the caves and water are so stunningly beautiful and there's so much to look at. The privilege tour, is however, quite difficult and you have to be physically fit and flexible to maneuver around. Also, it's good if you're not too tall. My husband is 6 feet and he did ok, but much taller and limited flexibility, you're in trouble !! The reason I say this is because at one point, the roof comes down so low, you really only have approx. 1 to 1 1/2 feet of crawl space where everyone is literally dragging themselves on their stomachs in order to get through this area. Very challenging and difficult! Not to mention other areas of the cave where you have to get down on your knees and crawl your way through.You can expect to see bats, catfish, the odd bug and crab spiders while in the cave. While these things do live in the cave, they are now rarely spotted because so many visitors have frequented the caves, that these creatures do a really good job of hiding or have found another area of the cave to live in so as not to be disturbed.When my husband and I went on the Privilege tour, our guides were Aida and Inga. Both very sweet, friendly and had lots of knowledge about the caves. The only things we didn't like was that when we got to the collapse for a break, the two of them were smoking. For us, it was a real turn off considering we were in such raw beauty, and seeing the guides pollute this beauty with their cigarette smoking was disappointing. Also, we were quite hungry because the tour started at 10am and by the time we made it to the collapse it was already 1:40pm. The guides only had chocolate bars and fruit bars, which in my opinion, was not enough for "lunch." We had a very hearty breakfast but because this tour is so physically exerting, we were quite hungry and were expecting at least sandwiches or cheese and crackers or beef jerky or something more substantial to eat so we could be properly re-fueled before heading back. FOR MANAGEMENT of RIO SECRETO -- If your guides are smokers, it really looks unprofessional for them to be smoking in front of paying customers. You should really have them wear the patch or chew nicorette gum or something while they are wokring. Also, the privilege tour is expensive. You should really pack a "lunch" for guests which should include sandwiches, cheese and crackers, celery sticks, beef jerky as well as chocolate and fruit bars. It's the least you can do to make the tour more enjoyable and comfortable - we are after all, paying a lot of money.

Spectacular caves & excellent guides. Spectacular caves, well organized operation and a very informative & passionate guide (Alfredo).We booked a tour that included transportation from the hotel - in retrospect, I would have just booked the tour without transfers (saving ~$30USD each) and then caught either a taxi or collectivo as it was very close to our hotel (Gran Bahia Principle campus).

A very worthwile adventure. We had a chance to visit Rio Secreto last visit to Mexico and we were very impressed. The guides and staff are very knowlegable and are passionate about the preservation of the caves and the natural habitant. It was like a trip with National Geographic. Very Interesting.Thank youHAL & JUDY

hope you have a good memory, because you can't rely on the pictures. First off, we were told we were not allowed to bring our own underwater camera on the tour because we needed both hands - this was the first red flag. It has more to do with the fact that if you don't have your own pictures they can gouge you for their pictures at the end of the tour.The tour itself was ok, the tour guide was at least friendly and knowledgeable (the only reason I didn't give it a 1-star). If you're looking for excitement, this isn't it - think more discovery channel documentary in HD. What really left a bad taste in our mouth was the fact they wanted $70 for a CD with pictures of which 95% were pictures of us "just walking" from one location to another, now honestly what am i going to do with these. I asked how much it would be to have the two good pictures put on CD or printed out... $25 each picture. REALLY???? there were 6 of us on the tour and we wouldn't even split the cost 6 ways just on the principal. By the end of it we all felt like we just wasted a day in Mexico. I would not recommend this tour to others.On a side note we also did the the Jungle Maya Expedition through Alltournative. Now that was an excursion that made our trip! loads of fun, plus you can (and should) bring your own underwater camera. we got some amazing photos and we also bought the CD at the end (only $50) and that's because their pictures were amazing! so many shots we wouldn't have been able to get ourselves. that tour goes highly recommended.

One of the best day trips/Rio Secreto. Well worth the money. They provide everything for your tour (wet suit, water shoes, helmet with light). All you need is a swimsuit. Mariana was our super enthusiastic and thoroughly knowledgeable guide. She was a blast.

An awesome place to be and see!. We took a colectivo out to Rio Secreto, which cost 40 pesos total for 2 of us. Then we had a bumpy ride in a shuttle van out to the actual location of the underground river. We met our tour guide, Filipe, and he told us all about what to expect. Then we had to take quick showers and put on aqua socks, wet suits and helmets to prepare for our descent into the cave. That was the only bad part--the equipment had been worn a million times by a million different people, and they probably weren't cleaned very often. If you get the heebie jeebies from thinking about germs, you may want to skip this trip :)Anyway, then we walked as a group (there were 2 couples and a family of 5 in our group) to the cave entrance--about 5 minutes. We went in and got more instructions and information from Filipe, and then made our way through the cave. It was beautiful--but definitely not suitable for anyone with any sort of physical limitation. It was great to be in the water because we had worked up a sweat walking over there and through the cave.You are not allowed to take cameras into the cave, which everyone questioned, but you understand why once you start walking through. You need both hands for the entire length of the exploration. To deal with that, though, a professional photographer joins the group and stops to take posed pictures at predetermined locations throughout the cave. These photos are available for purchase once you get back above ground--but one photo was $25, so we skipped it. The quality wasn't all that great, and that's a really high price. After we got back and changed, we were given a light lunch of fruit and chips, with the option to purchase a quesadilla for $3. Then we were driven back to the home base. The entire experience probably took about 2 hours, not including the rides to and from Playa. To get back, we had to dash across the busy highway to stand and wait for the next colectivo. Fortunately, we didn't have to wait very long--we would have gotten way too hot because the waiting spot on the side of the road was right out in the bright sun. But all that was worth it because it was a fraction of the cost of a taxi. We each paid $59 for the adventure.

Wow what an adventure. I went on vacations with my mom and 2 of my sisters this year, and the Air transat agent recommended the Rio Secreto excursio. It was amazing, best excursion I have ever taken from an all incl trip. Our mother is 77 yrs old and she came with us and had as much fun as we did. We were very lucky, our guide was Benito (french tour) and we got the best! If you have an opportunity to do this tour, go for it, dont think twice. Benito, on behalf of my sisters, Denise & Nicole, my mom and I (Nancy) Thank you! Hasta la vista!

Amazing and so different from anything we've done!!. Our family of 4, including kids age 13&9, did this tour on a recent trip. It was outstanding in every way! We knew it was a cave with water, but that was where our expectations ended. Our guide Juan helped us get our gear (wetsuit and water shoes, plus a hardhat with a light) and we were off!From the moment we stepped into the cave, we were amazed!! This is not a touristy cave attraction, it is a real cave and the only light is from your hat! We were partnered with one other couple a so it was a small group with only the lights from the helmuts and our guide's flashlight. Juan explained all about the cave and words cannot describe the beauty! The time flew by as we walked carefully, then swam through areas of the cave. He said we went about 900 meters (I think) into the cave and came out another entrance.We all loved the experience and the pictures. It is $69 for the disc with all of the professional pictures, which is a bargain compared to a lot of places I've travelled that charge $25/piece no matter how many pics you buy!Btw, we didn't take their transportation. We just hired a cab and he met us there after to take us back to our hotel...it was much cheaper and we didn't have to stop!

Amazing Experience - Highly Recommend. What an experience. While the others from our HS senior cruise checked out Senor Frog, we chose this excursion and no regrets! The ride to the site was an excursion on its own (though must depend on the driver as the ride back was not as adventurous) and our guide, Aida, was the best. One of the guests had significant knee problems and she made sure he was well taken care of. The pictures they offer at the end is well worth the cost ($50?). I have yet to upload the CD purchased from the cruise but the ones from the cave have been shared with friends and family. What a treasure.

Great experience...not touristy". We went yesterday with our 14 yr old and two 7 yr olds, really a unique adventure that provided a great sense of the natural beauty of the area. The underground caves were hard to navigate at times but worth it as it was really an uncomprimised spectacle. Wouldn't necessarily recommend for kids under 6 or people over 6'4", but otherwise a great time. Jorge was our guide...fantastic.George A. - Chicago
One of the best things I've ever done.. It was a beautiful day in Mexico, Pablo was a great guide. The food was fresh and the birds were entertaining.

The caves are magical, the guide charming.. We loved getting out of the heat and wind in Cancun and enjoying the quiet beauty of the caves. Our only complaints would be (1) the hotel put us on a bus with people going to Xcaret, and we drove everywhere picking people up and (2) Rio Secreto stops to take too many photos. The lunch should include something more than the fresh vegetables, though those were good. it's an expensive event, and they could offer a little more food and better hotel transport.

Amazing, MUST SEE. my boyfriend and I went on this excursion on April 15th and it was absolutely breathtaking! It's a half day excursion, we got picked up from out hotel at 8 am, and got back at about 1 pm. The site is really close to playa del carmen, so not too long of a ride on the shuttle! I liked that it was a small tour group (8 of us in total plus the guide), makes the tour much more enjoyable! You get dropped off at their 'welcoming' area in which at that point they arrange their own ride to bring you into the actual site where you can enter down into the river. It's about a 10-15 min ride (a really bumpy ride because the roads aren't exactly perfect) into the actual site from the welcoming area.They provide you with the wet suits, water shoers, helmets, and life jackets. You just have to be dressed in your own swimsuit. Our guide was Alejandro/Alex, who was spectacular! Trilingual, so he can communicate in English, Spanish and French.You walk down to the openning of the cave, so it's not physically strenous.The water is refreshing, the wetsuits keep you comfortable in temperature though. They have a photographer who follows your group to take pictures for you through the excursion underground as you're not allowed to bring your own camera.If you have claustrophobia like myself, not to worry, the ceilings are very high, there's no squeezes that make you feel uncomfortable!The one thing that my boyfriend said was less enjoyable was the fact that you always had to keep your eyes on the ground. The ground is pretty uneven from the stalagmite formations, so you really have to be aware of where you're stepping on to avoid any falls or scratches to your legs! But it's all part of the beatiful nature of these caves.We were underground for about 1.5 hrs, and this intro tour takes you through approx. 600 meters of river.There's a longer tour, which is 4 hours, I would definitely return and take this one!They provide you with drinks and snacks afterwards as well.After you exit the cave, you're brought to the photo shop where they show you your photos. They even separate your (you and your party) photos form the rest of the group to save you the hassel of picking and choosing out your pictures.I got about 20-25 photos of me and my boyfriend, and of course group shots in total. The CD with all your digital prints is 59 or 69 USD (can't exactly remember now..)The excursion itself was only 89 USD per person which I think is well worth it to see mother nature at it's best!The staff were all great!

Outstanding. What an amazing day! Our 11 year old son picked this excursion and I agreed reluctlantly. It was such an amazing day! Our guide was a wonderful lady from Germany. She was friendly and made our experience. The caves are so beautiful. Buy the picture package...well worth the money.Loved how Eco-Friendly the company is.This is our favorite excursion ever!

prestine, wonderful. Benito was our guide during this adventure and he made it truly special. He was knouledgable and experienced. He made a difference because he truly enjoys his job and shares this unusual place with respect and pride.The best part of course is the prestine condition of the cave and river. It was surprisingly NOT slippery. The formations were out of this world.....best secret of Playa del Carmen because it seems not too comercialized yet....BUT the pictures were too expensive. The snacks could be improved on specially if you joined a tour group from the hotel.If I have to do it again, Just like any other atrractions along the highway, I will just get the collectivo to go back to Rio Secreto....I imagine it would be a lot cheeper specially if you are in a big group.
AMAZING!. This attraction was amazing!! Our guide, Alfredo, was very knowledgeable and funny. We had a great time with him. It`s a must see!! don`t miss your chance to go see this.

Spectacular, Special and Safe. This is a must visit attraction if you are in the Playa del Carmen area. It is an awesome adventure, which you should not miss. This is an adventure romp in a place not normally visited by many people. The facilities are fit for purpose and the staff is great. If you get the privalege of having Benito as your guide he is something special. As a non-swimmer I felt very safe and the backward floating tour provided by the guide when necessary was appreciated. Once they get the road into the site up to snuff this will easily rate five of five stars. Don't miss the opportunity to visit this spectacular place.

The most amazing adventure!. My friend and I were on vacation in Cancun and we wanted to do something we have not done before in Cancun since we have been many times. Exploring caves was something that always interest me so when I saw that they had an excursion through our hotel to Rio Secreto we booked it right away. Our tour guide Alfredo was amazing. He explained what we would be experiencing as well as the history of how they found the cave over 6 years ago. Once inside the cave it was a bit scary but so amazing that it was quite an adventure. It was one of the most beautiful experiences of our lives. alfredo was the best! Not only is he experienced in knowing the cave but he is very patient. They had photographers taking pics of us exploring the cave for over 90 minutes. We got the pics on a CD. THIS IS A MUST SEE!

Rio Secreto Time Well Spent. Our group of 12 recently vacationing in the Riveria Maya spent the afternoon at Rio Secreto. In previous years we visited other attractions in the area and were looking for something different. We found it in Rio! Under the guidance of Dania (the MOST awesome, spunky guide), we had a great time exploring the million year old caves. Our kids (ages 12 and 15) enjoyed it almost as much as we did. We purchased the CD of photos to help us remember our afternoon for many years to come. We would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a little adventure in the mayan holiday.

Return to the Cave. What a wonderful and amazing adventure- side trip from our cruise with Royal Carribean. We had an awesome tour of this natural wonder. Our guide Joan (Juan) was knowledgeable, humorous, and provided us with so much information about this cave experience. He was very enthusiastic and accomodating as were all of the staff at the attraction. Today, when the world is getting me down, I can just close my eyes and dwell in the stillness of the cave for a few minutes and breath thanks to having experienced this adventure. Very Cool!! I hope it will be conserved and cared for so that others will be able to enjoy this wonderful place.Dorothy Cast

A fascinating and unique experience not to be missed. This trip takes you to explore a flooded cave system. You explore the caves walking through ankle to chest deep water. The caves are full of beautiful "arrangements" of stalactites and stalagmites - quite stunning. Almost like a cathedral in their splendor. The caves are dark, but you have a helmet with a miner's light on it and it is easy to see. You are also given a wetsuit and a life-jacket to wear. Our guide, PABLO, was really interesting, knowledgeable and charming. I would highly recommend this tour to anyone who is physically fit - it is not for anyone with walking difficulties as the cave floors can be rocky under the water. You cannot take your own photos, but the photographer takes photos throughout and these are for sales for a CD of about 60 photos (yours and ones of the caves) for $70 USD, or $25 for a single photo.

An amazing underworld experience.. We absolutely enjoyed this activity. Pablo our guide was very knowledgeable and made this trip extra special. We would recommend it to anyone who is looking for an experience to remember.

Spectacular - Great Excursion for active people, Pablo Great Guide. Highly recommend this trip. We are active family of five, kids are 13, 12 & 10. We have made family trips to Hawaii, Singapore, Indonesia and Mexico. I have been traveling to Mexico and the Yucatan for 30 years.The cave system is facinating, and is a relatively new attraction for the area, only discovered four years ago. The company seems to be making a genuine effort to balance conservation and tourist. Our guide Pablo was very informative about the geology and history of the cave and are, and seemed very passionate about the cave and its preservation.The tour itself is arduous, but not difficult, for active people. However, It goes about two hours, and you must be prepared to hike up and down some mildly difficult terrain, often on very slippery surfaces. Also, you will not be able to use the bathroom during the tour, so keep that in mind.You are not permitted to bring cameras, or any other foreign object into the system. On the one had they seem very serious about preservation and on the other they do need to make money to preserve the place. They take their own photos and allow you to purchase a full set on dish at the end. The pictures aren't cheap, but I thought they were worth it.All in all this was a fantastic and facinating adventure, but be prepared. This isn't something out of disney or an american theme park.

Best excursion of our trip to Playa del Carmen, but only for the nimble. If you enjoy caves with lots of stalactites, stalagmites, and other formations, this is a stunning tour. You'll spend 1 1/2 hours underground, sometimes walking, sometimes swimming (more like floating, with an occasional dog paddle.) The cave is packed, end to end, with beautiful formations. Use the shoes and (short-sleeved) wet suits that they provide. Our guide, Alfredo, was great! Very warm, personable, and enthusiastic. Also very careful to look after his guests. My balance isn't the best, so he put me at the front of the group so that he could give me a hand over the rough spots. Yes, there are rough spots. They have kept the cave "natural," without constructed walkways. You will have to take big steps up and down--sometimes in the water, where you can't see the floor very well. You will also have to cross brief stretches of sloping, uneven rock. Fortunately, the shoes grip very well. But, while trying to keep your balance, it's easy to whack a jagged stalactite with your hand or leg and get an abrasion. (We did.) I would recommend this tour ONLY for those who are reasonably limber and comfortable doing a bit of clambering up and down. One family brought their five- and seven-year-old children. They managed well and the kids seemed to enjoy the tour, but Mom and Dad did a bit of carrying, and the five-year-old was quite chilled by the end of the tour.The cave is in a nature reserve, and you will do a few minutes of strolling through the "jungle," but that's not the highlight of the trip. It's all about the cave. They do provide a snack afterward.The only down side is a very bumpy 15 or 20-minute ride to the cave--in a van that may or may not be well air conditioned. But it was worth it!

Fantastic!! A once in a life time experience!. The adventure is a life experience. Alfredo the tour guide is excellent. He is passionate about the natural creation of this underground cave water system. He is one of the best tour guide who makes you feel safe following him for 1 1/2 walk through the water cave which is a sight of wonders. You have to be there to experience once in a life time this magnificent natural wonder.

Highlight of our trip to Mexico. Looking for a boring ordinary excursion?....this is not the place to go!!!! Rio Secreto was suggested by our resort, and we're so glad we took their advice! It was the most unique, unforgettable adventure in Mexico! Our guide Pablo was very knowledgeable and passionate about the preservation and exemplifying what the Mayan people were all about! We were underground, in the cave system for almost 2 hours, but felt like it was 10 minutes! We could have stayed all day! Thanks Pablo!

Simply a MUST DO on your Bucket List. We decided to check out this park based on the recommendation from friends that had gone on the tour the year the park opened. It was the only tour that they had done on the Riviera Maya that they were willing to eagerly repeat. So off we went to explore. I can simply say it was one of those truly right decisions. The river and cave system in simply stunning! But all that aside it is the method in which this natural wonder is presented to you that makes the tour so much more enjoyable. By the end of the tour you fully understand you were just blessed with observing a stellar gem in Mother Nature's inventory. All the guides in the various groups were enthusiastic and reverent of Rio Secreto. Our guide was Pablo and if you get the chance request his tour. Not only respectful of the eco-system but extremely knowledgeable about the Mayan and Aztec cultures and religious implication of the system. Pablo made the whole tour complete and helped us leave the area with the sense of awe you should have after being allowed to experience such a pristine part of our fabulous planet. Put in on your Bucket List and check this on off as soon as you can get yourself to this awesome part of the world. We will definitely repeat this tour when we return to the area.

A RIO GOOD TIME. A great excursion, worth every penny. The water may be cold but the site is hot. You will be amazed at the sites, the history and the adventure. A special thanks to our guide Gonzo. He was very well versed in all aspects of the Rio Secreto, spelunking in general, and tequila liqour.

Interesting, Off-beat Tour for Light Adventure travelers...but quite a treck for Cruisers. The Tour is best for those seeking an unusual natural adventure. Many reviewers have given wonderful advise and descriptions about these very cool caves. So, I will just add a few comments. These caves are left as Natural as possible, which makes them very interesting to explore. For many of us, this will be as close to spelunking as we could ever get. That is a thrill in itself. We even say Jaguar paw prints!!! For those with ANY issues walking, keeping balance or fears of dark or closed spaces -- pick something else. You are constantly walking on VERY uneven, steeply sloping surfaces. At points your are simultaneously stepping over and under stalagmites and stalactites -- all while trying your best NOT to touch anything but the person in front of you. At points, you step into water..and sometimes you even swim. It is a unique adventure for those who are willing and able to enjoy it. We did!PHOTOGRAPHY - You cannot take your camera. Accept that now. There is a professional photographer with your group and you can buy a picture or a CD. At first, I thought that this was a money making scheme..and the pictures are too expensive. However, you cannot safely carry a camera through the caves. Even if you could, it is very dark. You will not get good pictures. Let the professional take your pictures and decide whether you wish to purchase any of them. GETTING THERE: This put a damper on the whole experience. You must take the ferry from Cozumel to the mainland. The ferry is ROUGH. The day we took it, it was VERY rough. The majority of the ferry passengers were seasick. Those who weren't still had to witness a lot of vomiting. Not a great way to start. Once in Playa Del Carmen, we had to wait another 20 minutes, then take vans another 30 minutes or so. The van was decent but very crowded. The first half the trip is on a highway, the last 15 to 20 minutes goes into the jungle. For those still trying to recover from the ferry, this was hell. While I do not suffer from seasickness, the journey was fine but not fun. After the tour, you have a little time in Playa Del Carmen. Then, we returned to the ship in time to depart. While I enjoyed the tour, it does take a whole day. If this is your first trip to Cozumel, you may want to consider whether you wish to spend a whole day on this type of excursion. If you frequent the area, this may be an interesting alternative to the norm.

Most Awesome Excursion Yet!!!!. We visited the Amazing Secret River while on our Royal Caribbean cruise -- As noted in other reviews, this series of caves was only discovered about 5 years ago and only 10%Our guide was Eddy -- and he was nothing short of outstanding. has been opened up to the public in the last 2 years. Upon arrival at the location, you'll be given all the equipment you need (water shoes, wet suit, life jacket, and helmet with light). Although much cooler in the cave, you do tend to get warm hiking through the cave with the wetsuit and life jacket on. Once Eddy lead us to the cave entrace, he stopped to explain the layout. He was very proud of the site and rightfully so. The views inside the cave system were absolutely amazing. And the pictures that they provided ($59 for the CD), although a little overpriced, were absolutely beautiful!!! I disagree with one of the previous posts, you do not really need to know how to swim as the life vests are plenty for this trip. There are only about 2 places where the water is over your head. One person my group had been on nearly 10 cruises and said that this was the best excursion she'd ever been on! I can only say that, for me, this was an absolutely fantastic excursion that I would absolutely recommend to anyone!The down sides of the trip were the van ride to/from the site. Lunch provided was really just a snack - however, you could buy some food from the stand - they really had amazing chicken fajitas (very large) for only $3!

Alfredo was an amazing guide. An amazing experience, Alfredo was an amazing guide. Very knowledgable about maya culture and how it relates to the cave and all the natural elements, structure, etc of the formation of these caverns. Would recomend in a heart beat and would love to go back for the longer excursion into the underground systems. The photos provided by the photographers were A+ grade and worth every doller.

This is a "must do" if your ship stops in Cozumel. We've enjoyed our fair share of great tours of many interesting places, but Rio Secreto, Amazing Secret River is at the top of our list, along with diving at the Great Barrier Reef. The cave and water are stunningly beautiful and Benito, our guide was informative and entertaining. He took great care of us. Every time I look at the photos (worth purchasing -- $60.00 for the CD) I want to go back! Also, chips and drinks are provided, but for just a few $$ you can get a delicious quesadilla so bring money. Lockers, towels, wet suits and water shoes are provided. Leave your jewelry at home.

Absolutely breathtaking. One of the things I really wanted to see while in Mexico this time around were the cenotes. We heard about this one through our travel agent and booked it right away. We descended into the cenote with a group of people and were led by our guide, Adrianna (I think), who was just amazing. She was really passionate about the environment and the place in general. Inside was an eery kind of beauty that I have never experienced. It's actually indescribable. At one point, we turned off all the lights and were sitting in the dark. It was the loudest silence, and the most brilliant blackness I have ever encountered. Kind of like what I imagine outer space to be like.Now onto the details:- You are given a wet suit, hard hat with light, life vest (there are some areas where you can't reach the bottom) and water shoes for your journey- No cameras or anything else are allowed for the journey, even if they're waterproof. While you are walking around, there is a photographer who runs ahead (somewhere, somehow) and takes photos of you, there are some beautiful photo areas with lights set up. Personally, we found the photos too expensive ($20 for one, up to $120 for the whole shebang) so we left with our memories.- They seem to have different paths for different ages/abilities. We saw a group of seniors just back from their tour, and we definitely did not hear or encounter them when we were on our's.- After there is a complimentary snack area with fresh fruit, nachos and salsa. There is also a cash snack bar where you can buy pop and fresh made quesadillas. The quesadillas are very good, but you need to get to it right away, because you only have a small amount of time before the bus takes you back to your hotel.The trip was roughly $100 per person including a ride to/from, all rentals and the snack.It's definitely worth checking out.

Second Tour - Even Better than the First!. We took the tour in December 2009 and thoroughly enjoyed it. This year we rented a house with friends neat Puerto Morelos and recommended that we visit again. In 2009 we thought that we’d Learned what we could in an hour and a half tour – this year we met Pablo. Not only did we re-learn the geological significance of these wonders, but he patiently taught us the spiritual significance as well. If you want to blend an education of science, culture and religion, got to Rio Secreto and ask specifically for Pablo.

Worth the visit. A girlfriend and I visited Rio Secreto in March 2011. We opted for just the tour and skipped the transportation which was an additional $30 per person round trip. The colectivo, which runs from Tulum to Playa Del Carmen, drops you off right in front of Rio Secreto. It is safe and easy to take and costs about $3. The cave itself was beautiful and a sight to be seen. Our tour guide Mauricio was knowledgeable and more than willing to answer any questions we had. From arriving at the sight to walking off the lot the entire thing took about 3.5 hours so we had plenty of time to do other activities that day.

Awesome. We were pleasantly surprised by the length of this expedition. Our guide Pablo was very knowledgeable and we learned so much about this river system and how important it was to the Mayans. Pablo kept the journey light and fun. It was my family's favorite part of our March 2011 spring break!

Family Fun Adventure!!!. What a fantastic adventure! It was so much more than we expected. Our guide, Karen, was incredible. Her enthusiasm was infectious and her knowledge was remarkable. Most impressively, she handled all six kids in our group with grace and skill. She knew when to gently tell the 10 year old boys to get in line, she knew how to reassure our five year old girl that she shouldn't be scared, and she knew how to help the adults navigate the rocks. As an added bonus, Karen entertained us with her knowledge of Spanish and French - she can do the entire tour in three languages! We ended the tour with surprisingly delicious food. What a terrific adventure!

Excellent excursion for the family. We read about this excursion last minute as we were trying to decide what to do in Cozumel for a family of 5 with a 13, 11, and 7 yr old. This was a great decision. From Cozumel you take a 45 minute ferry ride to Playa Del Carmen. From there you take a 15 minute extremely bumpy but fun van ride to the Secret River site. Once there you will meet your guide who will get you ready with water shoes, wetsuit, life vest and hardhat with light. They also provide towels to dry off afterward. Wear a swimsuit. They will make you rinse off before putting on wetsuit. They also provide lockers to keep your belongings while on the tour.The caves are breathtaking. The water was cool but not too cold for us. The wetsuits helped. You cannot bring your own camera but you need to have both hands free to manage the underground terrain. The stalagtites and stalagmites were incredible and we also saw the remains of a coral reef. At certain points the water is deep and you must swim, but you have a life jacket on. Our guide was excellent and there are photographers following your tour group to take your pictures which you can buy at the end of the tour. Individually they are $25 dollars a piece but we chose to buy the cd of all our pictures and they include many local nature pictures as well as pictures of the cave with this. This was $59 which we didn't think was too bad. After you have dried off and turned in your gear , they offer a small snack of nachos/ drink ( included), and there were enchiladas for sale as well as canned drinks. After that you can relax in a hammock unitl the van is ready to drive you back to Playa Del Carmen where you can spend a little time shopping before catching the ferry back to Cozumel.

A Great Experience. What an adventure!! My whole family enjoyed this excursion. The staff was great--our guide spoke several languages fluently. Our group consisted of our family of four and another couple on their honeymoon. The English-speaking guide was easy to understand and her knowledge of the area and history of the caverns added to our experience.Due to an issue with our rental car, we were unable to make our initial reservation. However, we simply called them and they easily changed our reservation to the next day. I was very glad they were able to accommodate the change because it was one of the highlights of our trip to Cancun.The provided lunch was only fair, but we enjoyed tasting the local liquer.

Don't miss out!. This tour was the highlight of our cruise. Well worth the money. Exciting, beautiful, and awe inspiring. Our tour guide Pablo was highly knowledgeable, fun, and captivating.This tour should not be missed. You won’t regret it.
Worth Every Penny!!. We had an amazing tour through the caves. Every bit of it was amaing and our guide(Pablo) was knowlegable and friendly!

Fantastic. Went with husband and two teenagers (11and 14), we all loved the experience. The tour was well timed and spaced. We learned so much - we will never forget it. We skipped the pick up by their bus and just took a cab from out hotel in Akumal - worked out well (much cheaper).

Very cool experience for all ages. Our family, ranging from age 6 through teens to adults, all thought this was a great tour. Our guide, Inga, made it even better. There are TONS of stalagmites and tites, and lots of interesting information about Mayans who used the caves. Swimming through part of the cave was a highlight. The two things that could be improved are the incredibly bumpy drive from where you pay to the cave, and the snack at the end. I would do it again!

A truely beautiful natural wonder that everyone should experience!. Rio Secreto or the "Secret Undergroud River" is a truely amazing natural wonder that everyone should see. Only if you are claustrophobic, should you NOT experience this AWESOME wonder. All the staff were extremely helpful. Our guide Kuri was incrediblly knowledgeable. He showed a real passion for showing off as well as preservation of this natural wonder that has been developing for millions of years. All the photographs taken by their staff were brillient and of high resolution. This is something everyone should see once in their lifetime.

Hidden gem in the heart of the Mayan Riviera region in Mexico. Thanks to fellow travellers' reviews on Trip Advisor, we visited Rio Secreto earlier this month along with our two daughters. We were greeted by a team of professional staff, dedicated to preserve these caves and to educate people. Our wonderful guide Lia offered us a unique and memorable visit in french, all dressed up with our wet suits, hats and surf shoes; make sure to bring your bathing suits and be ready to do a bit of swimming! They offered us afterwards a typical drink for adults and another for the kids, made a toast and we were offered also a wonderful snack! They also provided us the chance to buy a CD with pictures taken during the visit which I highly recommend to buy in order to share the memories after. Don't miss this visit, be prepare to be delighted!
A unique experience. An hour and a half long walk/swim through limestone caverns. Our guide Pablo was fantastic.
Great time!. We had a great time and loved swimming in the caverns. It was a little expensive and the pics are super expensive. Alejandro was a great guide!

Spend the Money and DO THIS!!!!!. Read the reviews as they tell the truth. This is awesome. The only complaint is that the photos that you are offered after the tour are too expensive. They would sell a lot more if they would be $35.00 instead of $59.00 to over $100. The tour was about $89US per person from our hotel, a small lunch and 1 1/2 hours in the caves. Nothing to be afraid about. This is well run and has experienced well trained guides. Just enjoy the beauty.

If you are planning to go to the Mayan Riviera, THE place to visit definitely. Guau! I'm still amazed at the beauty of this place. I've been at the Mayan Riviera about 10 times, but never saw that kind of beauty. Since you arrive to the last goodbye, the staff is knowledgeable, professional and very friendly. They make you feel safe and therefore, enjoy the experience 100%, and now I can confirm "The most beautiful underground river". if you have the chance to go when visiting the Riviera Maya does not think 2 times.

The very best natural reserve cenote in the Playa Del Carmen area not to be missed by any tourist.. This is an exciting tour through the underground natural reserve which comes at a very reasonable price and makes a great family adventure. The guides are excellent and take you through an incredible experience to see a most beautiful preserve of underground rivers in their natural state. Truly a wonderful experience for any age.

You MUST see Rio Secreto. Having visited the Mayan Riviera frequently for the past ten years, I can honestly say that Rio Secreto is THE place to see. The staff is knowledgeable, professional and very friendly. The facilities are well equipped and clean. The experience of going underground is stunning and simply unforgettable. If you decide to visit Rio Secreto, it will be the best money you will spend in the Mayan Riviera.

An incredible underground experience. After gearing up in a wetsuit, life jacket, helmet and headlamp we descended the stairs into the cave system with the river. We saw incredible formations. Our guide Felipe was very knowledgeable. Although I am not really comfortable swimming and have some claustrophobia, I felt totally comfortable during the entire hour long walk through the caves in the river. The organization who manage this tour go to great lengths to maintain the pristine state of this natural treasure. I highly recommend this tour. Be sure to take money or credit card to purchase the amazing photos that they take of you underground.

Excellent time. Well worth the price. This was a great excursion we went on from a Carnival Cruise ship. We were ferried from Cozumel to Playa del maya and then bussed to the site. The ferry ride was a little rough with very choppy water. We were given our gear and taken through the caves. While the description in the Carnival magazine said very strenuous activity, we had a elder woman whom had a full knee replacement 5 years ago in our group and she did just fine. The snacks afterward consisted of various fruits and nachos. Quesadilla were also available for purchase.

An Amazing...Breathtaking.....Stimulating....Spiritual tour..... This was my favourite tour during our recent trip to the Mayan Riviera . After a short van ride from the resort we arrived at the staging entrance . Information was a little scarce after we first arrived but after a short time we were grouped and on our way in to the jungle to start our journey into the "underworld" . The van ride is about 15 - 20 minutes down a bumpy gravel road . ( sometimes wonderful amazing places are off the beaten path ) . Once we arrived at the cave area everything could not have been better . I can't speak for all the guides but Inga our guide was absolutely perfect . Not only was she professional , but very approachable and knowledgeable .  After a thorough briefing and getting outfitted we were off to the caves . Inga was excellent in her knowledge and understanding of the jungle and the caves which we were about to enter.....from the moment we started to the moment we finished our safety and enjoyment was Ingas priority . The caves were an absolute wonder . A place so different and beautiful . Inga's passion and love for her job was more than apparent . She made the journey through this magical place , informative , amazing and touched a place inside I didn't expect . Kudo's to every one at Rio Secreto for keeping this jewel in such a natural state . When I left the caves and walked back through the jungle I couldn't help but to think about what was under my feet.......Thank -you Inga......

A unique experience away from big crowds. My wife and I took this tour and really enjoyed it. You'll be a bit concerned as you start out traveling down a long and beat up road for a good 20 minutes or so. However, stuff like this scares away the crowds, so we took that as a good sign. You should know that you'll want to be in reasonably good shape for this tour. There is a fair amount of crouching and squeezing through tight spaces. You'll probably get a bit scratched up too, as the surface in the cave is very uneven and will be hard on your feet. The operators give you a wetsuit and some beat up water shoes, but I banged up my feet pretty well. One of the big advantages of this tour is your group will be small. Ours was 6 people, plus our guide and a photographer. This really keeps the cave from being beat up by large groups, and it allows you to have a better and more relaxed experience. Our guide was Fabio and he did a great job of taking us through the cave in a responsible manner. You'll learn that the cave is a very fragile resource and you'll need to take extra care to make sure you don't harm it. The operators of this tour make everyone take a shower before they go in to remove any lotion or oils that are on your skin. Also, great care is taken to make sure you won't touch any of the fragile formations in the cave, and they've done virtually no alterations to the cave (all the lighting is from handheld battery flashlights carried in, and the surface of the cave has not been altered to allow for people to move through with ease).Overall the tour operators do a great job and the experience exceeded our expectations.

Amazing!!!!!. Do not miss this tour, it is totally awesome. It is a pristine underground river with magnificent stalagtites and stalagmites. You travel through the caves in awe of the beauty. It is well preserved.

Rio Secreto is a hidden treasure.... Did this tour while vacationing in the Mayan Riviera. It was a great time although the drive up to the cave was like being on a roller coaster, as the road was really chopped up. If you tend to get car-sick, take a Gravol! The cave itself is spectacular (although the wet suits and soggy water shoes were a bit stinky) but the minute you get into the cave, you forget about that! Adriana was an amazing, enthusiastic guide who was really knowledgable and obviously loves her job! You get to swim at times as you move along the cave. Lots to see but you have to be careful not to touch any of the formations. Totally worth the trip!

Once in a lifetime experience. We chose this as our shore excursion from our cruise. It was amazing. The trip started off with Angel meeting us right @ the dock & taking us to the Rio Secreto. He was very nice and answered any questions that we had. When we got to the actual destination Lia took over. It was soo nice to be with her because not only was she very knowledgable but you could see how much she loved her job & was very personable. You are not allowed to take your cameras in for good reason - you need all your senses to walk/swim through these amazing caves. We did spend the $60 to get the DVD & it was worth every penny. My 11 & 13 yr old loved doing this & would recommend it to anyone who has teenagers that like the adventure or us older people that still have an adventurous spirit. Angel & Lia just made the trip even more enjoyable with their personalities

Great underground system after you get over the original lack of organization. We had Juan and found him to be really good and had a great sense of humour. We liked that there hve been no lights strung through the system and we had to wear headlights.hopefully that won't change.PROS: Was breath taking and tour guide was helpful with information. Small group (not really small enough for us). For those who are a little concerned about swimming or having their head under water - you will have both a wetsuit and a life jacket . Juan was so considerate to the one lady that was concerned. He helped position her in an floating position on her back and helped guide her through the area. she did awesome!Snacks provided at the end and there are washrooms to use prior to and upon leaving the cenotes.CONS: You cannot take your own camera and although they say it is for safety reasons, I really question that ruse. They provide their own photographer who has a great camera. (We did not feel pressured into the purchase of these photos even though we did in the end buy them due to the quality and the fact that we wanted the moment memoralized).All in all - if you can get over the fact that lots of people show up and there is litle info while you are waiting, then you will be fine. the ride down the bumpy road in a crowded van should be lessened by the experience of the underground pleasure.

A must do. This attraction is a must do at the riviera maya. It is very interesting and beautiful. the descent into the unknown is exciting. Alejandro, our guide was very professionnal and provided many explanation about the cavern formations.

A must see!. This was an absolutely amazing experience and definitely the hightlight of our recent trip to Mexico! Our group included 4 adults and 2 teenagers and all of us felt the same way.This outfit is very committed to the preservation of this remarkable wonder and our wonderful guide, Felipe, was very knowledgeable and made us all feel very comfortable (including one adult that is not a swimmer). You will not be disappointed!

Amazing trip through the ceynotes (underground caves).. Diego was our guide and he was terrific. Not only did he impart his love of the historical and natural aspects of the Ceynotes but he was very knowledgeable and solicitous of all in the group.

If you can get over the transportation disorganization, the tour is wonderful. Our tourguide, Inga, saved the trip. with mixups, putting us with the wrong language group and disorganization at the entrance, we were initially put-off on this experience.however, inga really has a passion and lots of knowledge about the caves, the mayans, the area and nature. she made the trip worthwhile and helped me feel safe on a scary bucket list item of mine.It really is worth the trip-though if you are not physically fit or have very young children who cannot swim, it may not be for you.they were safe, concerned with preserving nature and at all times aware of all the travelers in our group. We definately all felt bonded after our experience together.

Experience the tranquility and Beauty in a Cave. We had a fun wonderful experience At Rio Secreto the cave was beautiful and had a feeling of peace while we were going through this underground cave. Our guide was very knowledgable and passionate about the cave and our experience. It is a must see.

A Place of Learning, Wonder, and Family Bonding. My family took this trip after a friend recommended it to us. We chose it over snorkeling by the reef, and we were not disappointed. We toured underground caves that were decorated with intricate stalagmites and stalagtites, learning about everything from their history to their future to their chemical makeup. My family members and I had to depend on each other for balance and communicate clearly as we navigated the sudden dips and steps hidden in the dark. There was even a mystical element, if you enjoy meditation or imagination. Our guides, Adrienna and Alfredo, were fantastic, full of humor and knowledge. Afterwards, we were treated to a refreshing snack. Even my youngest brother, aged ten, appreciated this trip. I recommend it to anyone who has a passion for learning and time for entertainment.

Unique and AMAZING. Our personal tour guide included a trip to Rio Secreto in our itinerary. We were not expecting such a great experience. After you have paid (a reasonable price for 3-4 hours they spend with you), you spend a few minutes in a hut with tv's, coffee, water and very friendly guides. You might even be visited by Philippa - a very friendly puppy! Once the guides give you the run-down on what will happen on your tour, you're whisked off in a van to the cave site. The ride is about 15 minutes long and very bumpy in the back of the van. Those who get the first tours in the morning might see monkeys, tucans and other jungle wildlife. Once at the cave site you will change into wetsuits, helmets and life jackets - lockers provided. Then you spend an incredible hour and a half in a stunning underground world. We were blown away by the beauty and the personal touches the guide and photographers offered us while on our tour (about 8 people). This is a fascinating place!!! After your incredible tour, you will be given a tasty shot of Yucatan liquor to warm your insides and celebrate the beauty of mother nature. Then you get to chose your photos if you wish to purchase (expensive but worth it if you just get them put on cd). After that you'll get a tasty snack and a few minutes to relax. We were very impressed with the concern for nature and preserving the site in its current state. Overall, this was something that is great for the whole family and is a one of a kind, incredible experience!

An Adventure to Remember. Just returned from Riviera Maya ... Rio Secreto is a definite must see for the adventuresome. Our guide Pablo was magnificent! He has a true passion for his work and it was event throughout our tour. Highly recommend as it is an experience like no other. If you are looking for a unique adventure, this is definitely worth your time!

Rio Secreto should be at the top of the must see excursions.. If you are traveling to the Mayan Riviera this is a must see place. We were in awe at the beauty of this place and loved learning about the geology of the region. We were picked up at our hotel by a cargo van and driven to the entrance. From there we had a 20min van drive over rough dirt roads. Our driver did his best to miss the rough spots but as we ATV in northern Ontario it really wasn't that bad. Once we arrived at the change rooms we were given a lock for a locker to put our belongings into. We put on wet shoes, had a bit of a splash in an outdoor shower and then were given wet suit, life jacket (standard vest that really was not cumbersome) and a helmet with a headlamp. Walk to the entrance was maybe 5 min. The first half of the trip is mostly hiking through ankle or knee deep water. Our guide was terrific at explaining how stalagmites and stalactites are formed, the different types and how this affects the growth of flora and fauna above ground. The last half you do get into deeper water where you can swim in beautiful crystal clear water. All I can say is the cave views are amazing, cool, awesome..like nothing I have ever seen anywhere else.  We lucked out and only had one other couple on our tour. I believe you can have up to 10 people in a group. After the tour we were offered a shot of a black licorice liqueur, fresh fruits and water for free. Other food and drinks were available to purchase. Pics were taken throughout the tour, which we decided to purchase as this is really a life time opportunity that I want to remember. It was $99US for the pictures on disc, 2 shirts and an 8 x 10 of one of our pics. We could have substituted a bottle of the liqueur but not my taste. A little expensive but things that are worth treasuring sometimes are. This was definitely a big highlight of our trip!

RIO SECRETO THE PEREFECT PLACE FOR REPEATER TRAVELERS IN CANCUN AND THE RIVIERA MAYA. Hello, hello, my name is Gabby Castañeda. My friend and I went on a trip to Rio Secreto last week, and i think it´s an amazing place to visit for travelers that have been in Cancun or the Riviera Maya before.Normally on our first visits to the destination, we do stuff like mayan ruins, islands or eco-parks, and after that, we think we´ve done it all and we get bored at the hotel´s bars, but, Rio Secreto it´s a whole new concept of * excursion* .First of all, the ride in the middle of the jungle to get to the entrance of the river was a fun adventure, then the tour guide, * **SEBASTIAN*** welcomed us, he was excelent and did a great job giving us all the instructions very clearly. Then, when we got into the river, you can easily tell that it is a real underground river (NOT MAN MADE LIKE THE OTHERS). The adventure of exploring the cave seeing the rock formations (stalactites and stalagmites) through the years, the few marine life (since it´s a cave) and some other animals it´s an outstanding experience. There even was a point where we turned off our lights for a minute and just enjoyed the peaceful darkness and the beautiful sound of the drops of water forming the stalactites. ** SEBASTIAN ** was very knowledgeable about the river and the area and made our excursion in the river very interesting and dynamic. The trip inside the underground river takes about 1hour and 30 min. When we got out they gave us some water and snacks which we needed cause we were exhausted and ready to go home. ***SEBASTIAN*** stayed with us during the whole journey even at snack time and then he said goodbye. We were very thankfull to him and the whole crew of Rio Secreto.I work for Apple Vacations* and since we had such a great time and the tour guide was excellent i will be recomending this trip to my costumers. We loved the trip, thank you so much Rio Secreto and Sebastian.

Outstanding. This was an exceptional tour that exceeded my expectations. Should be noted however, that due to pure luck, my tour consisted of my wife and myself, led by 2 tour guides. I believe the groups are generally 6 - 10 people large and I think I would have not liked the tour as much had that been the case.Make sure you ask for Felipe. He was a great tour guide and was very knowledgable about the area and the caves.

Fantastic display of nature at work and a priviledge to witness. This is a spectacular site to explore. Undisturbed nature at its finest. The guide we had (Felipe) was exceptional. Patient, friendly, communicative, and very knowledgeable in the background, history, and development of the site. It was a very revealing experience and I would certainly recommend this adventure. Photos are available for purchase as a photographer will accompany the group on the tour.

Priceless. We visited Rio Secreto today after pouring through the reviews on Tripadvisor. In my opinion, I would advise you not to hesitate paying the admission price as I feel it may be worth even more. It was an unbelievable learning experience for my whole family and you spend A LOT of time underground with a knowledgeable guide, learning about the formation of stalagmites and stalactites. Felipe was our guide, and he was fantastic. You'll be fortunate to get him as your guide. I would highly recommend this activity.

Photo ops. went with a group of 4 to the Rio Secreto. We were to be there for 10:30 and didn't actually get into the caves for another hour. We waited for people from Cancun, hmmm.Drove down a dusty and verrrrrry bumpy gravel road for 20 min to the actual Caves. Spent lots of time int he preparation before getting into the cave, wet suits (mine was huge) whimpy water shoes that you felt every little stone, helmet with light (cool) and best of all a hot, heavy and huge life jacket. That did me in as we only had about a 25 foot swim. Every 5 minutes we had to stop to have our photos taken, good grief. It was a slow and grueling experience. Granted the cave was cool but enough with the photos. We were not able to take in our own cameras.Got out of the cave and were given a honey/anise liquer and shown the many photos after we took off all our gear. We were then ushered tothe picnic tables where we were given a snack. Liquid cheese, sour cream (non of which were over ice) nacho chips and quesadillas to purchase. By the time we left the Rio Secreto it was 5 hours later. A 1.5 hour tour took 5 hours. The driver took us back to the Gran Bahia and l forgot my bathing suit in the van. They did not respond to my e-mails and did not somehow find the suit when we called. I would not recommend this excursion.

RIO SECERTO. I have been on several excursions in my past 8 times cruising with Carnival and THIS IS THE BEST kept secret REALLY... Pablo Salce Zambrano was the best guide- informative, interesting, enlightening, well versed, experienced . He made the experience something you will never forget and really want to go back and do it again!! Thanks Pablo I met some really nice people in our group who will end up being friends for life, Clifford, Steven, Stavie... the experience you took us through Pablo is only one can experience to understand the awesomeness of the surroundings and the majesty of the environment & culture... and the wonderful rebirth.....go do this one, you'll love it!!!

Rio Secreto. To anyone traveling to this part of the country, this was by far one of the best tours I have ever been on. For those looking for a tour that gives the feel of being on a expedition this is it! From the time my wife and I got off the ferry from Cozumel to meet our transportation guide Angel, who drove us to the caves was perfect! Our tour through the caves with our guide Inga, who was truly passionate about her work. I especially enjoyed the conclusion of the tour that ended in a shot of D'Aristi Liqueur, and a wonderful Chicken quesadilla. I would do it again! If you choose not to take this tour you will miss out on a unforgettable experience! Gracias a todos en secrato rio que estan haciendo un gran trabajo! Jake and Melisa

Absolutely amazing, truly unique experience!. We took this excursion through our cruise, and it was amazing!Felipe was our tour guide, and his passion and excitement for the caves was contagious, and made this trip amazing!It's very educational, but adventurous and fun at the same time!After the trip, they offered us free snacks and drinks, and we had the opportunity to purchase photos from the trip afterwards, which I encourage you to take advantage of!Highly recommended!

Rio Secreto---- FANTASTICO!. WOW what a fantastic attraction! We are seldom impressed with so called "tourist traps" but Rio Secreto is far from being a boring attraction. We were fortunate to have Maite was our guide. Her presentation was very informative and her extensive knowledge and passion of the underground river system was evident. As mentioned in other reviews the ride from the highway to the entrance was fairly long and bumpy making for a rough start to the tour. The wetsuits are not the nicest smelling but with the humidity in Mexico nothing really has a chance to fully dry. A small inconvenience for a truly amazing tour. We would highly recommend this tour.

At Río Secreto, you will a fantastic experience of the silence of a world below. RIO SECRETO IN RIVIERA MAYA MEXICO - An unbelievable and fantastic life experience in one of the most incredible cenotes in the earth's centre We were greeted by highly trained guides and equipped like a professional dive master. They supplied us with a wetsuit, helmet with a special lamp and wet shoes.At Río Secreto, you will experience the silence of a world below, crossing for an hour and a half through the crystalline water museum. Filled with a kaleidoscope of speleothems, walk an easy 600 meter route amidst the thousands of stalactites and stalagmites found in this protected natural reserve. This is an underground adventure like no otherI want to share this spectacular with everyone and hope that you will have the same one day! It is a must for everyone!!!!A special thanks to Gavin Greenwood gavin.greenwood@riosecreto.com

This was amazing.. The ride in the van to the underground river is VERY bumpy you drive on a rock road. Once you get down in the underground river you can't believe your eyes. This underground river is very large and beautiful. The tour is about one and a half hours long and part of the time your in water. The water is anywhere from ankle deep to your chin deep. Towards the end of the tour your floating in deep water just enjoying the scenery it is very relaxing. I would recommend this tour to anyone.

The AMAZING SECRET says it all...WOW. A day filled with beauty around every corner. From the time we left the ship until the time we returned we were treated amazing. Our guide Mariana was wonderful and so caring of her surroundings. She made our day. We were her only guests a group of 8 with 4 teens(no easy task). The teens were amazed at every corner. Thank you Mariana.
Nothing Like it!!!!. Been in alot of caves. This is by far the best. Marianna was the best guide. Had 4 teenagers in awe.

Just Do It. A very cool cave not to be missed. We both hiked and swam through amazing caverns and formations. We saw bats, fossils and a host of geologic wonders. You get a ton of information along with some great food at the end. The photo disc was reasonable and the pics were great. The swimming portion in crystal clear cave streams was like a dream.Highly recommended.

A truly spiritual experience. My family of 8, ranging in age from 30-66, thoroughly enjoyed our tour of "Rio Secreto"it's an ancient uncovered cenote and underground lagoon.Our guide was wonderful, we walked, and swam our way through, stopping for a minute of silent meditation, in a most glorious cave, we saw bats in the stillness of the cave.An experience I will never forget.If you're a spiritual person, and believe in conservation of natural beauty you will love this.DebbieNorth Vancouver,CanadaMy only criticism would be the ride out to the cenote in old Vans on terrible roads, I think it have added to the adventure to go in open air trucks, rather then these old broken down, crowded vans.

Not for the weak kneed or ankled!. This is our second time to the Riviera Maya and this time we decided to go to Rio Secreto, especially after hearing our Transat rep describe it as an attraction for all activity levels, anyone could do it. We were told at that time that this attraction did not allow any cameras, underwater or otherwise. We were intrigued to hear that it had been featured in an IMAX film so thought we'd take it in. We were picked up from our hotel by the Rio Secreto minivan and after about a 15 minute ride were dropped off at the attraction's welcome centre. There is an enclosed welcome centre with two large flat screens playing Planet Earth - Ocean that you can watch while you are waiting for the group to be assembled and sign their waivers. At that time we noticed a large board in the area describing all the things that were not permitted in the caves - watches, jewellery, band aids, cameras, nothing that could be taken in the caves except your swimsuit. Had that been on our list of "not allowed" provided by our transat sheet we would have definitely left our watches locked in the hotel safe rather than in a tiny locker with a padlock. At that time we were told, "Does anyone have back, neck, or knee problems" and learned that it was discouraged for those people with those ailments. This includes my husband and I but we certainly were not going to get our money back at that point so we decided to keep on (there were a couple of quite elderly people with us so thought, if they can manage we can too). We were then loaded into another van and taken down a 7 km bone jarring pothole ridden road to the briefing place - this is where you are given your wetsuit, watershoes, helmet. Our guide again asked us if there were people with back or neck problems, and asked us if we could "squat walk" - move ahead a few feet forward while squatting down. We were also given the option to use a cane or walking sticks for balance, and we all decided to use them, which was actually a good thing. You are required to shower prior to putting on your wetsuit. They explain thoroughly that they need to remove all chemicals and oils from your body, as these substances may prevent the stalagmites/tites from forming as the water will slide off and they want to preserve nature as much as possible. (note: when we returned from our tour there were maintenance men working on the showers and turned the water off, but they just took the groups of people through anyways) There are only three stalls in the bathroom so if you can, wear your swimsuit there to save time changing at the beginning. Wear their wetshoes if possible, I know that most people including us have an aversion to wearing other peoples stinky wet footwear, but their shoes have thicker soles and aren't as painful to walk in over the uneven rocks in the cave. The wetsuits thankfully came in all sizes but they smell like a fish filetting house. You are provided with helmets with headlamps, tilt the light downward so you can see where you are walking, that's vital. The caves themselves are marvelous with all the rock formations, stalagmites and stalagtites. There are narrow points that you will need to duck and squeeze through, trying not to break the rock formations with your helmet or hands. The ground is uneven, slippery at points, with deep drops inside the water. There is a part in the caves that you dogpaddle through with the help of the lifevest, definitely deeper than you can stand so be prepared for that. At one point she brought us together and we sat in a group, talked about being spirits inside Mother Earth's womb before we were born and the belief that we were brought back here when we died. Then we shut the lights off and just listened in the silence. There is no light that reaches this place, complete blackness which was simply amazing. If you have claustrophobia, fear of the dark, you might not do well here. One of the elderly women in our party fell trying to do the squat walk through that narrow opening and cut her hand. She seemed to have balance problems also and I'm pretty sure that had they known what was going to be physically demanded they would not have gone.Thanks to Aida, she was a great guide who spoke very good German for the Deutch guests, and did not even mention once about giving her a tip - that's why she got one from me. I am glad we had the opportunity to do this, but I would just be careful to know your limitations before you go.

Great, unique experience in the quiet cenote!. We loved this!The small groups and the great guides make for a wonderful experience, buuut we were blessed to be a part of a nice, quiet group. A few others that arrived at the same time as us were NOT as lucky as they ended up in a group with the messiest, noisiest little boy who seemed more interested in shining his headlight into our eyes (we had the bad luck of meeting them half way through and he got in our face immediately, trying to blind us, jumping from the frail rocks and just being a bothersome and annoying brat, altogether) than in experiencing the caves. I'm so happy we weren't in THAT group, because the guide was too nice to tell him off and the parents apparently didn't care.Anyhow - OUR group was nice and quiet for the rest of the time and everyone seemed to enjoy the pace. It was a refreshing trip and the sights are amazing!The only downsides (apart from afforementioned brat) was that the food wasn't exactly the best. A snack would have been a better way of describing it, than "lunch", that the photos weren't only expensive but bad too (and don't get the Xtabentun here! It's WAAAAY overpriced!) plus that the wetsuits & life jackets were small in sizes. There were nothing bigger than XL and there were people in our group that had to get too small ones because of that. Hardly comfy.Our guide, Dania, was super sweet and charming - and the experience was fab.Do this!

Don't miss this natural wonder. For a bit of history, We were told that 5 years ago, the land owner had found the underground caverns when he was hunting for iguanas. The iguana ran into a hole and the owner went in after it. 2 years ago the cavern was opened to the public and managed by Rio Secreto. They vow to advocate for environmental conservation of the site. This became very evident during the tour.I visited Rio Secreto December 13, 2010. I was able to book the tour through the hotel tour agents very easily, for the same price as other reviewers ($89.00 USD).
