I was picked up promptly at the scheduled time and it was only a 40 minute ride from the Puerto Morelos region (Excellence Riviera Cancun). Once the briefing and showers were completed, we were suited up with helmets, headlamps, wetsuits and water shoes. The attraction was out of appropriate flotation vests, so only 1 person in the group really needed one. I'm a confident swimmer and opted not to use one. Our guide had mentioned that the remaining vests may not be as helpful as needed due to the age of the vests and they would be less helpful in the water.I'm a stickler for safety on excursions. I found this to be my only concern of the whole attraction. I would have liked to see up to date flotation vests - as the ones used at Xel-Ha and have these vests used as mandatory devices for all guests I did make this comment at the end of the tour both written and personally to our guide. She did mention that the comments were very important the operation and safety of the tours.I hope the operator addresses this safety issue.For those people with issues of claustrophobia / darkness / swimming I don't recommend this activity. Your only light comes from the guide and the headlamps of those in your tour group, and It took a bit to get used to. Also persons with back / neck / knee issues may want to consider another attraction. In some spots you have to squat / walk to manoeuvre the paths.As for physical activity... 2/3 of the trip were walking on solid ground, 1/3 in the water and half of that actually swimming. Having an appropriate floatation vest would have helped enjoy the spectacular sights of the limestone formations. It would have been nice to float on my back and look straight up at all the sites. Our spectacular guide (Aida) spoke Spanish, German and English fluently. It was evident that she was passionate about the caverns and it's history. She was wonderful and the service that she offered was some of the best I've ever come across.Don't buy the Anise / Honey liquor they offer for $30 USD - you can buy it for $15 USD at duty free on your way home.Do buy the photos. Carlos made a great effort to get approximately 8 - 10 photos including 2-3 group shots. The CD was only $59 USD and included some stock photos taken at earlier dates.

This is a MUST-DO!!!. We booked this tour via "Best Day" from our hotel for $89/pp and it was TOTALLY worth every penny. Rio Secreto provides the tour guide, wet suits, water shoes, and lunch. After arriving at their "welcome center" we took a bumpy ride in an old safari type vehicle to a set of buildings where we met our guide (Phillipe), put on our wet suits, and rinsed off under extremely cold water (much colder than the water in the cave). Phillipe was incredibly infomative about the cave and it's preservation. During the tour, you aren't permitted to carry your own camera so there's a photographer who occassionally takes pictures of your group. Our group was made up of only 6 people and was the perfect size because we weren't rushed nor were we in the position of having to wait for lots of pictures to be taken.The only "negatives" to the trip are the cost of the photo packages (i think they ended up being an additional $50) and the lunch. The food was bland at best. I recommend anyone who visits the riviera maya visit rio secreto.

Amazing Attraction. Rio Secreto is a tour through a cave on foot with some wading required. Everything here was so professional, from picking us up at our resort at 11:30am to the time we were dropped back off at 6pm. It was about a 45 min ride from Mayan Palace in Riviera Maya. At first we were brought to an area where we filled out forms, and then we got into a van that drove us to the cave about 30 minutes on the most bumpiest of roads imaginable. Once we arrived, we changed into our bathing suits in the bathroom (I would suggest wearing your suit, only 3 stalls in the bathrooms), we had to shower in an outside shower to remove all body oils, and then we were fitted with our wet suits and water shoes (if you have your own fitted water shoes you can wear those). We were all a little apprehensive about putting on a wet suit but our guide Aida was great at making us feel comfortable with the process, we also had to wear helmets with headlamps and life vests. We were in a group of about 10 of us. We had a short walk before we finally arrived at the entrance to the cave. Once we arrived we were all in awe....it was just amazing, everything was dark except for the lights on our helmets! If you go I hope you get Aida as a tour guide, she was so thorough at explaining everything to us and made it fun!! I was a little concerned once we arrived at the water in the cave, because my husband can't swim, but the life vest held him up just fine and didn't have to swim. After about an hour or so in the cave we returned to a nice buffet lunch, and went back to see all of the cool pictures Eddie had taken. This was a great experience and would highly recommend to anyone enjoys the outdoors and natural beauty!! If you are wondering about bats, snakes, etc.....we didn't see anything down there except a few small fish. I say go for it, you won't regret the experience!!

Majestic and enigmatic. FIrst i didnt want to go cause i want to do more adventure tour but at least i go mith my bf so we went into this marvelous underground world where i find peace! I can feel my heart and also forget about the real world, it was like enter to a fantastic cristal world with formations that makes u appreciatte what mother earth do for us! Its a really amazing place u cant lose the chance to visit RIO SECRETO its awesome!

Rio Secreto was the most amazing experience of my life! This tour is not to be missed!. This underground cenote takes your breath away, It is unbelievably beautiful and a almost spirtual experience. I can recommend this tour to old and young alike and should be on the top of your list when you visit Playa del Carmen!

Tourist trap. no pictures, no informational tour guide, no excitement. this place is $80 per person but it is so not worth the money. you have to buy their pics for $100 usd and it is basically following a guide through an underground cave for an hour with no interesting information. you can see the same thing at other cenotes such as kantunchi for $10 and take your own pics. our guide alejandro had no fun in him at all, he took us to the middle of the cave to meditate in the dark. wow! that is so lame. please dont get sucked in to this tourist trap. we were tricked by our concierge at the mahekal beach resort probably because he gets more commission from these guys.

A MUST SEE TOUR!. I just took this tour/excursion while on a Carnival cruise Nov 2010. The whole experience greatly superceeded my expectaions. I would Highly recommend this tour to everyone and would do it again tommorrow!AIDA our guide was awsome! It was so noce to meet you. We were provided with lockers and locks to keep our personals. AIDA was very informative and a great guide keeping everyone together and not missing out on anything from the first persom in line to the last the entire time. This is a PHYSICAL TOUR so you do need to be able to bend, crouch, walk, swim/wade, and should have no problems with darkness, water and they say claustrophobia. There is really no tight spaces so do not be too discouraged about this. Water is fresh-water, crystal clear and about 70 degrees. They offer a walking stick. I say take it since the tourain can be a bit rough at times and better safe than sorry. i even suggested to the guide that they just pass them out to everyone instead of offering. You are not allowed to take any cameras or anything into the system. You get a knee length wet suit, swimming vest, water shoes and hard hat with a small light. DEFINITELY check and make sure your light works and is not dying before you start the hike. The sights are amazing inside the cavern and the photographer that tags along takes great photos. They are offered to purchase at the end. I took the entire CD of approx 30 personal photos and an additional 50 added cave photos for a reasonable price. WORTH every penny! Rating 10 A+++ Can not wait to return on my next trip with some friends. Thank You Tom Wisk, Pennsylvania, USA
BORING!!!!. Don't waste your time it's a rip off 100 dollarsForPictures. You can't take them yourself and it is aTourist trap

Rio Secreto - An Unforgettable Underground River You Must See. Close your eyes. You hear nothing but silence and the faint sound of trickling water in the background. Imagine you are 80 feet below ground with your eyes open in the pitch black. You are one with Mother Earth. You are somewhere along an 800 meter stretch of a 14 kilometer underground river that originates in the interior of the peninsula and empties into the sea. The lights come back on. Look up and see thousands of jagged-edged stalactites pointing towards your head like the tips of poison Mayan arrows. It looks like you are either on another planet or on the set of a blockbuster Hollywood movie. This is Rio Secreto.Good friends of ours, Jim and Janet, won free passes to Rio Secreto while Jim was volunteering at Mayakoba. We have been talking about us all going for months, but could never seem to coordinate our schedules. Then unfortunately due to medical problems Jim and Janet could no longer use the tickets and gifted them to us. Not wanting the passes to go to waste since they expire this winter, we arranged a trip this past Friday.We really did not know much about Rio Secreto other than it was another cave/underground adventure, and that the likes of Samantha Brown from the Travel Channel and other famous figures had visited the eco-park. Despite our lack of familiarity we were game for another wild experience.Our day began like any other Friday in recent memory: we packed the car with friends, drove to the park and proceeded over extremely bumpy roads several miles into the jungle to the entrance to the cave. At the park we were provided with complimentary wetsuits, life jackets, water shoes and helmets with lights. Then we walked a few hundred feet back into the jungle to what looked like any other cave we've seen on the peninsula.We were soon surprised at how different Rio Secreto is from other caves we've been in. Rio Secreto is like stalactites on steroids. I have never seen so many in one place. Then the cave is completely dark - there is no artificial lighting, other than the light on your head, and no other groups - just you, your guide, and your group of up to 10 or so people, wandering through an underground river 80 feet below the ground. The path was quite treacherous: up and down, in and out of water sometimes above your head, crouching down to fit below low underpasses. Luckily the terrain was not slippery. It is certainly not for the faint of heart or for anyone with health problems. This is most definitely for those with an adventurous spirit.At one point we entered a cavern that was filled with giant coral formations which were so large, I felt like a spec drifting among a reef in the sea. This was all ocean at some point millions of years ago. We trekked along this river for approximately 1.5 hours, exploring just a minute part of this gigantic subterranean aquatic highway. I can say we have never experienced such an amazing cave system so far in our time in Playa del Carmen.What's striking is that Rio Secreto was discovered only 4 years ago when this 80 year old man saw water vapor rising from the ground. He began to dig, discovered the river, and then mapped the 1st kilometer himself, before opening the river to the public 2 short years ago. To preserve the system they have 3 tours which cover different routes along the river, and alternate them over time, shutting one off and opening others to prevent wear. Lack of lighting helps prevent the growth of algae and maintain the authentic underground experience. By arranging small tours at 9am and 1pm, they stagger the river's visitors aiding in making you feel like you and your group are alone in the river, rather than running into other people multiple times.We highly recommend Rio Secreto to all our Playa del Carmen rental guests. At present we are going to rank it among the top 3 greatest activities we've experienced in Playa and the surrounding region. At only $59 USD per person or $250 pesos for locals with valid proof of residence, it's a real deal. You should call the park ahead of time and make a reservation.

Amazing Secret River!!. This was one of the most spectacular natural wonders I have seen! The opportunity to walk, wade and swim through an ancient underground cave was truly amazing. The stalactites and stalagmites were simply beautiful. I would recommend that you definitely know how to swim or float to take part in this adventure. You will have to swim about 300 yards total in the river. The water is cold so be prepared! The life vests that are provided are not the greatest, but they will keep you afloat as long as you are at least dog paddling. You cannot take any waterproof or regular camera into the cave but you will have an opportunity to purchase a photo CD or single shots before you leave. The CD was $60.00 (US). The only negative was the 3 to 5 mile van ride to get to the location. The road was not paved and was very bumpy. Overall, it was an experience I would highly recommend to any adverture seeker.

Awesome experience. Loved Rio Secreto! The walk/swim through the cave was awesome. Our guide Eddy was great and spoke english very well. He led us through the cave and explained the different rock formations we saw. The cave was discovered only 5 years ago and it has since been declared a national park. Eddy told us only 10% of the cave is open to the public and they can guide you on 6 different routes, the route depends on the conditions in the caves as the water level changes based on the amount of rain the area receives. It was truly spectacular experience. They provide each guest with a wet suit, life vest, water shoes and a helmet with a light. ( Just be sure your helmet light works, my husband had a hard time seeing well in the cave as the only lights in the cave are the lights you bring in) After we exited the cave we had the opportunity to purchase pictures of our family taken in the cave. The pictures were beautiful, you can purchase a CD of all the pictures for $59. Just be careful you get all the pictures you expect when you pick up your CD.After you change out of your gear you are offered a light lunch. Unfortunately the lunch was terrible. I definitely would suggest you eat before you go.Even with the extremely poor food it was still a great experience.

Best place i've visited in Yucatan!. Don't miss this. Forget about Xcarets, Xalas. or Xplores. This is a "must go". The tour takes about 1h30m and it's amazing. In the cave is all dark but you carry light with you. On the way to underground river we even saw a tarantula on the road. If you miss it you WILL BE SORRY!

The most humbling experience...put this on the Bucket List. The experience was enhanced by our passionate guide. He explained the respect for the Mayan culture and this beautiful place was most important, as well as the safety of the visitors. Everything was provided from wetsuits, vests, booties, helmets and headlamps, towels, shower facilities, lockers and lunch. The people were very helpful, courteous and gracious. My tip would be to inform your credit card company you will be in another country. There were several cards declined and you will want the pics. No cameras are allowed inside the cave and you will understand why when you go. You NEED your hands, balance and eyesight to navigate the waters safely. You will not be able to be attentive and keep your equipment and yourself safe if you are trying to get pictures. Their photographer takes great ones. This is a miraculous place and experience.

Not worth the money. While Rio Secreto is beautiful, it is a very restricted place. While I appreciate them wanting to preserve a natural wonder, I feel like it was more about getting money than preservation. They don't allow you to bring cameras for fear of damage to the caves, but a few photographers follow your group to take pictures, with flash! At the end, you find that to purchase like 8 pictures will cost you about $100USD. They offer a lunch with the trip, but it is shady at best. They also offer people a way to save money by not paying for transportation to the cave. DO NOT DO THIS unless you plan on hiking. We took the transportation, but saw others walking. It was like a 20 minute drive through the jungle on unpaved roads, I can't imagine walking. While beautiful, there are many others places that are just as great that don't have as many restrictions.

An experience like no other - don't pass on the memorable opportunity. While recently vacationing in Playa del Carmen we visited Rio Secreto and participated in an experience we will never forget. Our family of five (two adults, three teens ages 17, 15 & 15) had visited a cave previously on another vacation, however this was unique and quite different. Rio Secreto is nature at its finest and possibly unlike any other place in the world. The formations inside are unbelieveable and reflect natures work over 1,000s of years. No words can accurately describe what we saw and the water inside makes the location all the more special.We had the last tour of the day, so once we arrived at the facility, we checked in and waited for another group to join us. As it turned out they were a no-show so our tour was just our family. How lucky were we?After a brief preview of what we were about to do, off we went in a van that took us on a jungle road for a fifteen to twenty minute drive to the location of the cave. Our ride there was longer than the return trip due to our driver carefully avoiding water filled ruts and potholes. More about the return trip later.Once we arrived at the cave site we were greeted by Aida, our guide for the afternoon. She was awesome! Very knowledgeable and definately enjoys her work. We were issued a locker to store our belongings, asked to shower off at an outdoor shower similar to what you would see at a beach so as to not contaminate the water or the inside of the cave. We then put on wet suits, a life vest and a helmet with a light on it. There was a short walk to the cave entrance where we went down some stairs for our first look inside. At that point the only light was from the entrance of the cave. The inside of the cave was spectacular as we hiked through shallow water, waded through knee to waist high water at some parts, and even had some swimming through the cave where the water was about chest high. There had been a lot of rain recently so the water was a little higher than usual. It was dark inside except for our headlamps and Aida's flashlight. With the water crystal clear our lights made for some spectaculer scenery. It had to be the clearest water we had ever seen or been in. Cameras are not allowed, although there is a photographer that follows along snapping photos that you can buy at the end of the tour. There are some opportunities for posed shots, although most of them are candids that he takes along the way. I would highly recommend purchase of the CD as it not only has your pictures on it, but many beautiful shots from inside the cave that have been taken since it was discovered a few years ago.The entire tour inside the cave was probably an hour or hour and a half, although it seemed much longer.After we emarged from the cave we returned the gear, showered off and dried with towels provided by the Rio Secreto staff. We had the opportunity to review and purchased the photo CD. We were then provided a light lunch and loaded up on an old open air military truck along with all the staff, as it was the end of the day, for the trip back to the home base. That ride was quite an experience as well. Being it was a larger vehicle the ruts and pot holes on the road were still there but we just went right over them. It was a bone rattling ride that just added to the great experience.We would recommend Rio Secreto to anyone looking for a once-in-a-lifetime experience you won't soon forget.

This is a very unique exp, combining.... This is a very unique exp, combining natural site n physical activities (a bit of hiking n swimming). Inside the cave it was incredibly beautiful n mystical. They have small groups going in at 9, 11, and 1pm. We only come across one other group whole we were inside. Master piece of mother nature!

untainted, picturesque nature. i get the feeling that as soon as the masses catch wind of this gem that it will become americanized. as for now, it's one of the most amazing experiences of my life and i've been a few places... this is a hands-on experience that includes eyeing stalagtites and stalagmites, viewing underground foreign animals and swimming through the purest water you'll skin will have ever touched. in america, this place is impossible, here you have to duck not to hit your head on the stalagtites! i would have paid triple for this experience. at the time it was $59 per person plus an additional $59 for a cd of the images. no outside cameras allowed...

Rio secreto is an experience you will always remember.. My family and I went to Riviera Maya for one week and decided to go to Rio Secreto as one of our excursions. What a fantastic choice! The calcium stalagmites and stalactites are amazing and the coral is beautiful, too! Our guide's name was Diego and he was very knowledgable but a little bit aggressive when it came to tiping him at the end. The experience however was mindblowing. I will never forget it. The excursion also allows you to purchase photos taken by a professional while you are on the excursion which is a nice memory to have. Go!!

Best Excursion. Been coming to the Mayan Riviera for the past 12 years and have done about every excursion the area has to offer. I have swam in these underground rivers before but never one like this. This one is still very much alive and well unlike many others they charge for you to see.First I want to say our guide/teacher Alfonzo was such a great person for our group. We were lucky enough to go on the tour with only four people and Alfonzo took the time to explain everything about this amazing underworld and made sure we were all safe. This is not only the most beautiful place in the Yucatan but the people who work here make a effort to preserve as such. Our trip was about 2 hours long and we really enjoyed it. I will say that if you have back or knee problems you should not go on this as you need to be very careful where you walk. Your guide will help you just move slow and careful. There will also be a professional photographer that goes with your group to get some good pictures, yes its worth the extra $55 dollars. Make no mistake this place is the real deal and if you want to do something both educational and fun this is your tour. Very few people will ever get a chance to see this underworld intact, see it now before you no longer can.

A must do. What a great time had exploring Rio Secreto. We booked over the telephone as the internet wouldn't accept out booking. After reading previous reviews on Trip Advisor we chose not to pay the extra $$$ for the five minute drive from our hotel in Playa del Carmen to Rio Secreto but opted for the public bus instead. It was easy, dropped us out the front and was an eighth of the cost. Rio Secreto is very professional and well run. Once everyone arrives you are told the rules and what you are about to experience. You need to shower beforehand to get rid of any chemicals on your body and must remove all jewelry. They are very strict as they want to preserve this beautiful nature. No sunscreen etc. You are not allowed to take cameras inside the caves. Some people aren't happy with this but you know why once you are inside. There is a professional photographer who will take more than enough snaps for you that you can purchase at the end. I did find the disk of photo's a little expensive at US$55 but what are you going to do if you want the photo's??? Exploring the caves are wonderful. Without saying too much, you really need to explore it yourself to see its glory. Once finished you are given a light lunch, pick up your photos or disk and depart.

DO NOT MISS RIO SECRETO!. This is such an awesome and beautiful experience, you are really doing yourself a favor when you take this trip! We booked this trip through the travel agency at our resort in Playacar because we had some tropical storm-related weather and were looking for an activity that we could do rain or shine. We were transported from our resort to the check-in area at Rio Secreto where we were given a brief overview of what to expect on the tour. We were then loaded back into the air-conditioned vans and driven into the jungle. That ride alone is worth money - it's very bumpy and exciting, but if you are prone to motion sickness you should probably ask your group if you can sit up front.Upon arriving at the actual site where the caves are, we were introduced to our guide, Pablo, who is now one of my favorite people ever. We were all instructed to shower (it's really just rinsing off and is done in your bathing suit - make sure you bring a bathing suit!) to rinse off any lotion or chemicals that could dilute in the river and cause damage to the caves. They also provided lockers (you get to keep the key with you during the excursion), water shoes, wet suits, life jackets, and helmets with lights. Visitors are not permitted to bring anything that could get lost into the caves. No jewelry, cameras, hair clips (elastic hair ties are ok), nothing that could fall off or be lost and cause damage to the cave. A second guide accompanies each group for safety and also to snap photographs that are available for purchase after the tour. Then it's party time!As we went through the jungle and into the cave, Pablo explained their geological and spiritual significance. Once down in the caves, they are simply stunning. There are parts where you walk through and parts where the water is so deep that you swim (or bob around in your life jacket). There is hardly any current and it's more like swimming through large crystal clear ponds. The caves are dark in most places but the guides have extra spotlights and the light on the helmets provides more than enough light. The caves don't have any musty smell and they're not slimy or gross. Walking through the caves is not particularly difficult though it is more physically demanding than walking normally. You cannot touch the cave walls because the caves are still alive and growing.We had a group of six young(ish) adults so we made pretty good time through the caves. At one point, we all sat down and had a rest in the water and just listened to the water droplets pinging off of the surface. This was by far the most meaningful, informative, and simply beautiful experiences that I have ever had on vacation or at home. After coming up out of the caves we got to see all of the pictures that the second guide took. They are AMAZING. They're a bit pricey but worth it. If you purchase the printed photos they are each about an 8 1/2" by 11" and very high quality. Then we had time to change and have a light lunch. Sandwiches, salads, and the like are included with the price of the tour. They also have some hammocks you can lounge around in.The staff at Rio Secreto were amazing. Extremely cordial and friendly. Our guides were very knowledgeable. Our tour was conducted in English by Pablo and he did an excellent job. I believe that there are several English-speaking guides. There were at least two working on the day that we went. I don't know if there are tours available in languages other than Spanish and English.I can't stress how pleased I was with this tour. Everything was of high quality. I highly, highly recommend this to anyone looking for an interesting and different experience of Mexico.

Rio Secreto- Riviera Maya Gem. We arrived early for the tour, they didn't have our reservations in their system-I made them from home. I had the conformation page with me, so they put us with other people and our group had a total of eleven people. i think it would have been better with the advertised six people. I was a little apprehensive because of the claustrophobia issue, but I spoke with one of the guides Aida before the expedition and she assured me that I would be ok, and she would check with me after the tour-which she did, and I told her it was awesome. Our tour guide was Felipe- he was very patient and informative. The light from your helmet, along with his light provides enough light, we never felt as though it was too dark for us. We brought our own water shoes, but if you don't have any they provide them. You are in the water a lot, and it is quite slippery in some place and the ground is uneven. The cave is in a pure state,just as it was found, and hopefully it will stay this way, and not become overcommercialized as some tourist destinations in the Cancun area. At the end of the cave tour there are stairs that bring you to the surface, then you take off your wetsuits, and go to a buiding to view the pictures. I forgot to mention that there is a photographer that come along with your group. after the photo viewing there is a lunch with refreshing water plain and flavored, salad and sandwiches. I did not like the van ride back to the road, (about 3 miles) I was the back seat and the airconditioning didn't work back there. Other than that the whole trip is woth it, something different to experience, while it is still a gem in the rough.

If you do one thing, do this!. This is a great attraction in the Playa del Carmen area..its simple no ziplines,no bars, no stuff..just a cool nature walk down into a really cool "cenote"..a fresh water cave..replete with bats high up on the ceiling and lots of stalagtites and stalagmites. The tour guides are multilingual and are very serious about preserving this special natural resouce.

Amazing Adventure. Rio Secreto is an amazing experience. You will arrive at a visitor center right off the main highway in Playa Del Carmen. We took a cab from Playacar for about 120 pesos (US$10), and asked our cab driver to meet us after the tour, which he kindly did. After meeting the staff you will be organized into groups of 2 - 6 people and taken by van about 15 minutes into the jungle to the actual facility. You will be given a locker and then have to remove all of your jewelry, watches etc (I was permitted to bring my eyeglasses) you then shower and are given a wet suit, helmet with light, life vest and water shoes. The equipment is top notch and they really took the time to be sure everything fit correctly and that you were comfortable. The tour lasts about 2 hours. You can walk park of the time or wade or swim depending on the water level. You will see some of the most amazing natural beauty ever! The water is crystal clear and it's very safe. After the tour you can shower (towels are provided) and you are given a light lunch of sandwiches and salads. A photographer goes along with each tour group (you are not permitted to bring your own camera), and photos are available for purchase after the tour. We purchased a cd with 20 or so high quality photos for about US$55. This is a great experience, don't miss it.

Do NOT miss this one. Rio Secreto is very new (only 2.5 years open to the public as I write this). The caves are pristine and they are very serious about protecting them! You must shower on-site before entering. You must wash off any deodorant, bug spray, perfume, etc. I was told to remove my band-aids! Ladies had to remove all jewelry. You are requested to pee before entering the cave.The water was crystal clear. We drank it! The tour is a long one, about 2+ hours. They give you a little bite to eat at the end. Photos were $25 for one printed in cardboard frame, or $59 for the DVD of all of them. Sad truth: as we toured, the place was so beautiful, I knew I'd have to buy the DVD, which I did.Fernando was my guide. He spoke Spanish to 4 ladies in my group (I was the 5th wheel) and then English to me. Sometimes felt like I got the abbreviated version, but it was all good.The best part of this tour is: they really care about the natural beauty, and they are serious about protecting it. You aren't permitted to touch anything, you must tour single-file, etc. Another cenote I visited, Dos Ojos, was more like a playground, lots of tourist-damage to the beauty. Having visited both these cenotes, I enjoyed both, but greatly appreciated their differences.From Playa de Carmen find the "collectivo" on 2nd St (or thereabouts), heading towards Tulum. It leaves every 15 minutes and is cheap: $4. Ask to be dropped off at Rio Secreto. When done, simply stand by the highway and the same or similar bus will pick you up. NO NEED to take taxi here. Collectivos between Tulum and Playa are frequent!

Amazing natural adventure. Rio Secreto was an amazing experience. While on our 6 day trip to the Riviera Maya this was the only "tour" that we felt worth paying for. We wanted to avoid the theme parks that are common south of Playa but also wanted to experience things specific to the Riviera Maya. We made many other day trips using collectivos to visit Tulum, Akumal, etc. Rio Secreto was definetely worth spending the extra money and adding to our itinerary. The staff attempted to make the trip peaceful and fascinating by focusing on the cave, the natural surroundings, and the native/Mayan culture rather than the mass marketing employeed by other local attractions.

Incredible experience. Wow, i went to Rio Secreto after reading the positive feedbacks on TA and i have to say that it exceeded my expectations! if you are not claustrophobic and not afraid of dark, you should not miss this adventure!

Best tour we did on our whole trip. I was a little nervous when my husband said he wanted to do this one...but I thanked him afterward! It was just amazing. It is something you probably won't find anywhere else. We had a great guide named Fernando. You could tell he really loved his job and was very knowledgeable. I think he was just excited to show us everything as we were to see it! I was afraid that it would be too cold, but the wet suits really made it tolerable. I wasn't cold after I put my legs in for a few minutes. It was really beautiful to see all the amazing rock formations and gorgeous water. The tour is a full hour and a half, so it is worth the money. After the tour, they served us a light lunch at no additional charge. The pictures are a little pricey, but probably worth it. You are not allowed to bring a camera into the cave, and even if you were, it would be difficult to get good lighting since there is complete darkness in there and everyone in your group has a head light on! The photos they took are better then anything we would have taken with our own camera. We really loved this tour and we definitely look forward to it again!

I just came from the adventure of Rio.... I just came from the adventure of Rio grande, WOW. To think that we just witnessed a passage through time,4 million years! The cool fresh water,the formations and amazing natural energy of these caves is life changing, cleanses your spirit and I consider myself very.lucky to have seen that with my own eyes. Tour guides were rich with info on the history of the Mayans. A must!!!!!!!!!

Amazing life changing experience. tranquil, informative, humbling. It was amazing! we heard about it from the people who booked our reservation, and we were NOT disappointed! ASK FOR PABLO TO BE YOUR GUIDE!!! he was funny, energetic, and you could tell he actually loved his job and loves coming in to work everyday. the caves were formed over 2 million years ago and the mayans would go there to worship and meditate. this is a humbling experience, you see all the stuff formed millions of years ago, and it's still being formed today. if you are in the area you HAVE to check it out!!! breath taking!!! and again, ASK FOR PABLO!!!!!!!

It is truly an AMAZING, priceless experience!. We took an excursion to Rio Secreto while on a Carnival Cruise. We paid $89 a person which included round trip transportation from Calica and lunch. It seems others have paid less, but we felt this experience was priceless. The ride was extremely bumpy, but the van was clean and air conditioned. All the equipment needed for this experience is provided except your swimsuit. They give you a miner's helmet, wetsuit, life vest, and swim shoes. Don't bother with sunscreen (which you don't need anyway) or bug repellant as they make you wash it off prior to entering the cave. This is done to help preserve the caves. No cameras are allowed. I'm confused by people who've complained about no cameras as I don't see how one could manage a camera while hiking and swimming anyway - especially if you're trying to be sensitive to preserving the delicate formations in the caves. You have to be very careful and need both hands free at all times as it can be perilous. Professional photographers follow you through the cave snapping pictures all along the way. Some photos are staged while others are action shots. We took our 4 children ranging in age from 10-13. They loved it! We were in a group of 10 people. Our guide was fantastic and very knowledgable. I would recommend this excursion to anyone unless they might have trouble swimming and hiking. You need to be flexible as going through the caves requires stretching, bending, squatting, balancing, and of course swimming. After the tour ended, we were given lunch which was delicious. Various sandwiches, ceviche, tortilla chips, fresh fruit and vegetables were laid out on a buffet along with 4 different drink choices. We purchased one picture for $25 after being told that all the proceeds of sales go to helping preserve the caves. You can purchase all of them for $60 which quite frankly I think is a very fair price for 15-20 professional photos. Not all groups had the exact same number of photos taken. If you have the chance to see this AMAZING site - do it!

no cameras no good mis-sold. i was sold this tour by the thomas cook rep ( price $89 usd). who didnt mention anything about not being able to take cameras in. when the driver pick me and my snorkel stuff up (in a transparent bag) still no mention. not until i get to rio secreto after you have signed a disclaimer they then point you to 2 cardboard signs listing all rule and everything you cant do. at this point i raised the issue that may be this list should be part of the flyer so as not to mislead people. this is roughly the point i started filming so ill let the pictures do the talking.

Underwater Caves - An unforgettable Experience. We took a cab to Rio Secreto from Playa del Carmen, some agencies just charge $40 for the transportation, with a cab it is about 150 pesos one way from Playa and the entrance fee is USD 49, but is worth the money. You get a watersuit, watershoes, a helmet and towels. A guide provides explanations about the discovery of the cave and the formations... The tour is about 1.5 hours and you go really deep into the cave until you have to swim, the stalaktites and stalagmites are astonishing. The only drawback was that no cameras were allowed, a crew member took pictures, but at the end they charged USD 25 per picture or USD 59 for a CD with all the pictures, which we considered very expensive.

if you do anything do this in Playa do thyis. This is one of the most amazing things I have ever seen. It was only opened within the last three years after it was discovered by the owner of the property. Every attempmt is being made to protect this site environmentally. This is a short hop from Play to the base where you are transported by trucks into the jungle; you don wet suits and helmets and are given a great orientation by a guide (ours was Aida) and then you make a trip into another world exploring for 1 1/2 hours an underground cave with the most magnificent stalagtite/mite formations. You have a life jacket and swim through much of the trip. I have a little claustrophobia and it did not bother me. This is one of the best things I have done any where. From age 10 to 54 we all loved it.
wonderful!!!. it is a great and unique experience!!!! don´t miss it!!

interesting and unique experience. We were lucky and had only the four of us in our group.. Felipe was our guide and did a great job! the website tells you to wear walking shoes no flip flops..so we lugged around our gym shoes, which was annoying because once you get there after a bumpy ride in a van(sit at the front if you can, the back had no air, thought I was going to die) you get your water shoes..so no walking in gym shoes what so ever! we had my son 10yrs and daughter 15yrs.. at first my son was a little hesitant thought it was going to be boring.. the highlight was having to actually swim through the cave.. I thought from the pictures you were only wading through it..no, its deep and you do have to swim.. I would recommend it for something different..

One of the must beautiful places i've ever seen. This place is incredible, it's beautiful...you really need to be there to truly understand what i am talking about. Rio Secreto is the second largest cenote in the Yucatan peninsula, is a very large underground cave that has been recently opened to the public. When i visited this place i decided to take the bus from Cancun to Playa del Carmen and then from there a taxi to Rio Secreto. In the end I paid about 30 bucks for two people to get to Rio Secreto and back to Cancun, so I saved about 60 dls. and with that money i bought the pictures...oh yes...they don't allow you to take pictures, even with a waterproof camera...so don't bother. The price for the pictures is 59 dls and they give you a CD with a whole bunch of pictures of your tour. You can also buy one picture for 25 dls...so obviously is better to get the CD. The photographer is a professional guy so the pictures are really good and it's definitely worthed to have the pictures of yourself in this beautiful place. The guide i had for the tour (Eddie) was very fluent in both English and Spanish and was really a great guide, even though our group was very large (9). The price includes the special equipment (suit, helmet , life-jacket and shoes), the guide and the entrance to the place. This place is definitely a must see...although i have to recognize that at first I was a bit skeptical because you don't see many adds about it in Cancun...you only see adds about Xcaret, Xel Ha and Xplor...but it's probably better because there aren't a lot of tourists here...I definitely recommend the place.

Scary ride in: FABULOUS time!. Took a bus from resort to Rio Secreto. Air conditioned comfort. Got to the attraction and had information in broken English. Difficult to understand.. but got the gist of it. They managed to squeeze 14 people in a 12 person bus.. I rode in the back; and there was no air.. the driver drove like a nascar driver and the roads are dirt, and REALLY bumpy. We were surpristed the shocks could take it! Once there you locked up your items in the locker, washrooms were clean and tidy. We were informed on no suntan lotions, or any lotions (possibly contaminate the crystal clear cave waters) no jewellery and no cameras.Our guide was Aide? Spelling?Spoke English extremely well, and one of our group members is a bit nervous of all nature.. dark.. caves, bats.. bugs.. everything.. and she really enjoyed it!I'm a bit claustrophobic and when we went throught the 'throat" I thought I'd have a rough time but I didn't. It just looked small.We had kids 8-14 with us. Those ages were perfect. Very safe; please listen to the guide. Preserve the area as much as possible so that other people in the future can enjoy it as much as we did.Stalagmites, stalactites and columns. Crystal clear river water, that IS drinkable AND tastes great!If I remember the excursion was 89/pp..I think... I can't remember..but I think it was worth it. They took pics.. fab pics that we could never come close to even with my lovely digital SLR camera! The CD they offered was 65 US; and I think well worth it. They served lunch afterwards, buffet style; a few sandwiches, a few salads, bread, juices, etc.We got a shot of Mayan Liquor; which tastes a lot like Zambuca.. licorice in flavour, but I think watered down.I would recommend this excursion. Good for kids and adults alike.

Perfect Choice - Nature Unadorned. This is a great choice for a half day excursion that is a true wonder of nature, one that hasn't been Disney-fied into a theme park but left to speak for itself. The caves are extensive, starkly beautiful, and something you won't see elsewhere. Except right at the entrance, they are exactly as found, without adornment other than some lighting, The guide was helpful. The only catch is that they spend too much time posing you for pictures they sell you later. The cost is also a lot lower than some other sights, if you take your own taxi from your hotel (a very cheap ride from playacar hotels), since they overcharge for their bus pickup. They even serve some food and a tasty local alcoholic beverage at the end. You have to be a bit nimble to do this tour - not recommended for the elderly or claustrophic - as there are no ropes etc - and you might get the odd scratch if you touch the rocks as you swim by. But we saw young kids go through without trouble. Dont miss it.

Amazing stalactites, stalagmites, and dried coral. My husband and I went to Rio Secreto on March 3rd and it was beautiful! I would recommend calling Rio Secreto and booking your date, no payment is required over the phone. We checked with the people booking trips at our hotel and they wanted $89/person. When we checked the price to book directly it was $49/person. I called Rio Secreto and received a confirmation number with no payment. When we arrived we gave the cashier the confirmation number and she took our payment. Our taxi from Playacar was $24 roundtrip.When you get there a van picks you up and drives you to the cenote. It takes about ½ hour. Then you walk through the jungle and go into the cave. You do not need any sun block for this excursion. In fact, they do not allow sun block unless it’s biodegradable but we never saw the sun.It is amazing down there! The water is very still and the stalactites, stalagmites, and dried coral were breathtaking. My favorite part was when we went through this opening and our guide made some waves with his hand and the sound the water made against the stalactites was…words cannot describe! It was the most prettiest/natural sound I have ever heard. Seriously, if they came out with a relaxing CD with just that sound I would buy it and I’m not the kind of person who sits and listens to those type of CD’s.I believe there are a couple routes around this cenote. Our guide said we were on the one which had more walking. I really wish we had the one which had more swimming. Reason being, it is really rocky down there and you have to watch your step everywhere you go. I found I was watching were I was going more then I got to enjoy the scenery. But this is a minor complaint.Our guide showed us a lot of things. He even took us off the path and took us into a tunnel where we all turned off our lights. Wow, now I know why some of the animals down there don’t have eyes or are completely albino. We saw a catfish which all the catfishes down there are as big as index finger. When we asked our guide what they eat he took the time to point out this tiny white fish about the size of an eraser on a pencil. He also told us to touch the sand. Really cool. One lady complimented on how it would be a good exfoliant and he agreed and told everyone to try it. I have to agree. One of the best exfoliates I have ever used. At the end of the trip you can purchase pictures for $25 of $55 for a CD which you check before you buy. I saw some complaints about having to stop every two seconds to take a picture and wait for the other people to get their picture taken in the group. I didn’t mind this, in fact I kind of liked it. Mainly because I enjoyed the scenery while they were taking pictures. The price for pictures/CD is really high. After you tour you take a shot with your guide. Take the shot, it’s really good and not like taking a shot of tequila. It’s sweet, evidently it had honey in it. You also eat lunch and the lunch was really good. If you have any questions about this excursion, please feel free to email me.

The Rio Secreto excursion is one of the most amazing things I've ever done!!. Not only was the Rio Secreto excursion the best day of our recent trip to the Riviera Maya, it was honestly one of the most fascinating things I've ever done. I've traveled throughout Europe and their castles and palaces have nothing on this spectacular wonder of nature. I was awe struck from the time we entered the cave system until well after we left. A week later I still can't get over that I got to have that experience, and can't wait to go back again some day. I was upset when I found out we couldn't bring cameras, but it really turned out to be a blessing. For one, you really DO need to be focusing 100% on your footing. And secondly, it's great for just once to EXPERIENCE something rather than photograph the heck out of it (like I normally do). The CD they offer at the end for $55 was cheaper than I expected and offered a great selection from our trip and of professional photos of the caves. I'm going to make sure that everyone I know who visits the Riviera Maya takes this excursion!! You can't miss it!!

You must experience a cenote. If you’ve never been in a cenote, you should check it out. Rio Secreto gives a nice tour of a large cenote system. The tour takes you inside the underground caves. Guides were well versed in several languages. A more detailed scientific explanation of the many aspects of the cenotes would have been nice, but may have bored others.They provide all the gear and make the tour an eventRio Secreto is a $10-$15 taxi ride from Playa(confirm price with Taxi driver before getting in the Taxi).

Incredible Experience - Worth the trip!. We had a great time on this trip and it is definitely an experience worth the money. A great trip to the "underworld" of the Maya Riviera. Not only did we enjoy ourselves but we learned a lot about natal formations and the history of the region. No need for sunblock since you are underground most of the time. I saw other comments about the photo policy and although we did not intend to take photos ourselves there anyway, the prices of the photos were astronomical and most of the people in our group did not purchase them. $25 for one and $55 for a CD of all. Also, because of the single-file structure of much of the tour, and us being at the end of the line, we felt like we did miss some information although our guide was very good. I would try to secure a spot at the front! Also, the food at the end for the lunch was not all that good with skimpy sandwiches and not much of a selection. However, all in all a great experience we would not want to have missed!

Superb - a "must do". A fabulous experience - spoiled only by the rather lukewarm "meet and greet" service but once we had met up with our guide Mariana things went from great to excellent. Other reviewers rightly sing her praises so I will not duplicate - suffice to say she was FAB!! The photo "scam" is not a scam really - taking photos would have distracted from actually looking at the fantastic scenery in the cave system and other people's flash photography would have been irritating - also without a water tight casing the camera would prob have been damaged. The photo CD is $55 which includes all the photos wth you and your party PLUS about 100 other pictures taken in and around the cave system. Some superb shots which I think are worth every cent! Alltournatives - the parent company I believe has a genuine interest in conservation of both the natural wonders and the Maya peoples livelihoods and I would wholeheartedly recommend this and the other trips they do. See my review of Maya Encounter! :o)

Beautiful But .... My husband and I had a chance to go to Rio Secreto during our honeymoon in Playa Del Carmen.The cavern system is wondrous and beautiful -- a piece of art made by nature. Since neither my husband or I scuba dive, it was fantastic way for us to experience an underground river .Our turn off with Rio Secreto was the photography scam. You are not allowed to take your camera with you. The reasons being varied. Instead they send in a "professional" photographer with your group and have you take photos every few minutes. Having your photo taken every few moments really distracted us from the experience of being in such an extraordinary place. Then at the end of the tour they charge you $25 US for one photo or $55 US for a CD with all the photos. i felt that the no camera policy and then charging people an exorbitant amount for a photo was a way for the tour group to make big bucks while taking advantage of tourists who want to preserve their special memory. This on top of the $49 US each price tag to take the tour. I understand that the alltournative company bought the land where the Rio Secreto sits for their own private use. i just hope that they are sincere in their conservation efforts and are not just using the eco spin to help sell their product.Oh, and one last thing the unimog (jungle truck) shown on the brochure was not used as our transportation. A van was used instead.The cave itself is a 5. But the photography bit makes me give Rio Secreto a three rating.

We took our young kids and they did great!. We visited Rio Secreto last week and my kids aged 7 and 9 are still talking about it. The tour started off with a very bumpy ride in an open air truck to the cave. If you have back problems or motion sickness the ride may be a bit of a problem. I think the ride to the cave was around 20 minutes but I could be wrong as we were all wanting to get there sooner or latter. After we got there our tour guide, Eduardo, welcomed us. He fitted us with helmets, water shoes and showed us the nice locker area and the washrooms. Following that we all had to shower to remove any oils that we may have put on in order to protect the cave. Then it was off to fit the wet suits. My 7 year old daughter had been afraid of the dark but over came her fear by going to Rio Secreto. Eduardo was great with the kids and acted like we were on a mission to find things and really made it fun and relaxing for my kids. They absolutely loved it! Even when they got to the deep water they were very confident. My daughter started off gripping my had tightly and by the end she was up with Eduardo and my son showing us where to go. After the tour there was a buffet of salad and sandwiches and drinks. Then it was time to ride back to the parking lot. This time in a nice van. For me it was a bit more nauseating than the ride there because at least with the wind blowing in the truck I didn't feel as nauseated compared to being in the back of a hot van (there was air conditioning but I couldn't get the air to point towards me) so needless to say I needed a 2 hour lie down when I got back to the condo. The visit was awesome except for the end when I felt a bit ill because of the bumpy ride. I would still recommend this experience to anyone. It was great!

A once in a lifetime experience!!. What an amazing experience!!! The tour starts by going on a short walk to the entrance of the cave. The tour guide was fantastic. He spoke perfect english and offered us a wonderful history of the area and how the caves were formed. We did the first trip of the day which is a 7:30am pick up at the hotel. We ended up in a small group with only 6 people total. The groups that were coming in after us were still smaller but had a few more people. You aren't allowed to take pictures in the caves but there is a photographer who comes along is is taking beautiful pictures that can be purchased after the trip. The pictures are $25USD each or you can buy a CD of all the images plus a few of their "gallery images" for $55USD. The money goes to maintaining the caves so its worth it and the pictures are great. If you only do one thing in Playa Del Carmen, this should be it. Have fun!!

If you have a chance to see this don't miss the opportunity of a lifetime!!. Ricardo was our tour group leader. I have a back problem and he guided me along the whole way. He was very informative. A few years ago i could not even stand up long enough to brush my teeth. And to be able to experience something this wonderful was amazing for me. I cant say enough about Ricardo he was the best!! He took the time to explain everything about the cenotes. It was great not only to learn about them but to see the beauty so far underground was an experience i will not soon forget.

Magical, unique experience. We took a cab from Playacar to Rio Secreto for $15 each way. Our cab driver even offered to be there for us when we finished. Easy to do and saves you a bit of money rather than booking transportation with Rio Secreto. As with many excursions, much of your experience is dependent upon the skill of the guide. Our guide, Marianna, was amazing. She effortlessly transitioned between Spanish, French and English. She was enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and obviously has deep passion for Rio Secreto and environmental preservation. Her passion is contagious. She likened our experience of going underground and later ascending to a Mayan belief about dying underground and being reborn upon ascent. She encouraged us to think of ourselves as expolorers embarking upon an adventure discovering a new and special place. Sounds a bit cornball as I write this, but it really did put you in a frame of mind ready to embrace the beauty and history of the place.I sincerely appreciated Rio Secreto's committment to preserving their treasure. All guests are asked to shower briefly to remove any lotion, deoderant, etc.. that could possibly harm the delicate ecosystem below. Once inside you are requested to avoid touching anything unless given permission. You can expect to walk, climb a bit, step over rocks, wade though water and finally swim, keeping your head above water always. It's pitch black in the cave and light is provided by a flashlight on your miners helmet. There are three spots where you pose for pictures. They're mindful to use flash photography rather than electric lighting to avoid heating up the cave and causing damage to it. At first I was annoyed that we couldn't bring cameras, but in hindsight I truly think people's cameras, videos and flash would have seriously detracted from the quality of the experience. You can purchase photos at the end, and yes they are expensive. We paid $59, if I remember correctly, for four photos on a CD. Highly recommend Rio Secreto, but there are a few cautions I'd advise people of. First, you are climbing and stepping over uneven terrain, sometimes squeezing through tight spots. If you have bad knees or hips this could be challenging. One man in our group was assisted by Marianne several times. He was a trooper, but I could tell his knee was really hurting. Second, you may get scraped on a sharp rock. Several times you enter the water that's been muddied up by those ahead of you. You can't see where you are putting your feet so it would be quite easy to get a nasty scrape. The guide tries to warn you of any obstacles, but those in the back of the group don't have the benefit of clear water to see the obstacles. If you'll freak out over a scrape, this might not be the tour for you. Also, if you're claustrophobic, you might have a hard time. There are areas where you are swimming and the head clearance is pretty tight. You're also in a dark area with bitty fish swimming around you and bats occasionally above you. If that would bother you, then Rio Secreto might not be good for you. Last, the cave is about 8 km down a very bumpy road from where you check in. If you have bad neck or back problems, this could be hard on you.None of the above are meant as criticisms or meant to deter you from what was a fabulous experience for us. I just know that not every person enjoys the same things, so it's good to know if it's not for you before you spend the money. Thanks, Rio Secreto, for a memorable Mexican experience we'll never forget!

Great Day at Rio Secreto. We decided to something different as just hanging at the beach. Rio Secreto was highly recommended, and so we do now as well. The operation is flawless with a big focus on keeping tourism in balance with nature. we had a fun german guide - Danela - which explained everything in detail. We never felt rushed and perfectly taken care. The caves are fascinating and spectacular to visit . Even after the trip we had a simple, good lunch.

Natural Wonder Ruined By Commercialism. First off, Rio Secreto isn't a river. It's a semi-flooded part of an extensive underground cave system which has been opened up to controlled and guided public access. It is incredibly beautiful and impressive - if I were basing this review on natural beauty and "Wow" factor, it would get 5 stars. Sadly, the whole experience of Rio Secreto was ruined by 2 things. The first was the blatant over-commercialism of the place. Cameras are not allowed inside the caverns for obvious reasons; it's dark, dangerous, and wet down there, so there are stops for photos (taken by on-site photographer) at various points along the route through the caves. Too many stops though, the main point of which are to get you to buy photos at the end of the tour. Predictably, the photos are very expensive indeed (I can't remember the exact prices, but I do remember being shocked). The other reason for disappointment was the guide who took us round. I wasn't looking for a dry fact-heavy geological commentary, but neither did I want drivel from an inarticulate and ill-informed college student who couldn't even pronounce the features she was describing.In the interests of fairness, the place itself is amazing. You get to spend about 2 hours underground walking, wading and swimming through flooded caves surrounded by the evidence of aeons of geological time. Safety standards and equipment quality are high. You get fed and watered after the tour, while being shaken down for tips.Another word of warning - The posters and brochures advertising Rio Secreto give the strong impression that the place is naturally well-lit. It's completely subterranean, with no penetrating sunlight. The light in the advertising is artificial.

Mother Nature offers the best excursion. We just returned to Atlanta after spending a wonderful week in Playa del Carmen, and cannot say enough good things about the time we spent underground in the amazing nature reserve of Rio Secreto. This is a spiritual setting -- not a waterpark -- and if you want to experience the beauty of this area, spend some time here. We selected this as one of our excursions based on the reviews on TripAdvisor, and had prearranged the day/time of our trip there before we left the states. A driver from the site picked us up, took us to there, and returned us to the hotel -- no problemo! I do recommend that you not wear ANY sunscreen when you come to this site. A woman in our group felt bad about the potential of her leaving some of the lotion in the river since she had loaded up before coming. There is no need since you are underground the whole time! Our guide was a very spiritual person, who shared the history and science of this underground treasure. And it is a treasure. Take some time out of your busy vacation schedule to get back to what really matters and go to Rio Secreto!

A "must see"!. Our group ranged from 12 years old to 71 years young. Be warned the footing was a bit uneven for my Mom. We had the best guide in the world, Ricardo, who took her arm and guided her successfully through the entire attraction. What a treat and an amazing feeling of accomplishment for her! Even my (hard-to-please) 12 yr old loved it.The cave itself has to be seen to be truly appreciated. It is a natural wonder. I would recommend Rio Secreto without any reservations. Our guide was not only helpful, but was also very well informed and fluent in english.DO WEAR YOUR BATHING SUIT under your clothes to Rio Secreto. You will be leaving your clothes in an outdoor locker and walking a bit to receive your wetsuit and gear. A LONG walk in in your undies!

Amazing & not overly crowded like many of the excursions. My husband and I visited Rio Secreto for our honeymoon in July and it was simply amazing! We were shown endless amounts of excursions to go on, and while they all looked nice they all seemed like 8232348 other people would be there as well. Rio Secreto is a rather new discovery & spot for tourists to go to - we were SOO THRILLED we went on it!! I think paid $60 for the tour & transportation from our hotel, it was very much worth it. Lunch was included as well as some yummy shots of a honey flavored sambuca (which we picked a few bottles up at the Duty Free store @ the airport.. ha!).The excursion itself is out of this world.. one you can only attempt to describe by showing pictures of it to friends and family online but cannot get the real glimpse of the beauty & fascination until you go there. We forgot our wallets that day, which totally freaked me out in case we had to pay money for a locker or whatever might come up and we were pleasantly surprised that we didn't have to pay extra for anything other than tips & pictures. We felt horrible we didn't have money to tip our guide b/c he was quite fascinating and well versed in the history & science of the caves. You are not allowed to bring any cameras into the cave so we were also really bummed that we couldn't get any pictures from the camera people b/c they were truly breathtaking & someplace we'll never go to again.If you are only going to go on one tour.. make this the one. You can do zip lining anywhere (we did it while in cancun.. it was fine but you can do that in the US), or rite and ATV or jet ski... the other historic locations are great, but they will hands down be 100x more crowded than this place. The one on one attention & atmosphere makes it even more satisfying. Go Rio Secreto!! :)

Don't miss this. An enchanting, delightful experience. Pablo was our guide - his enthusiasm and passion for the caves was impossible not to catch. He was quite knowledgeable and intent on the ecological preservation of the caves and respect of the Mayan culture that worshiped in the caves. Swimming through the caves was amazing. The water is crystal clear. The lunch afterwards was simple, but good with loads of fresh fruit and juices and a tasty ham and cheese sandwich on a croissant. It was definitely the high point of a wonderful vacation and I highly recommend it. I paid for the transportation, but I would have saved about $35 had I taken a taxi. However, there was no waiting, no guesswork about getting the right taxi, and the man driving the van (Sergio) was courteous and professional.

What a fantastic experience!. Rio Secreto was awe inspiring and and an absolute otherwordly experience. It is a truly fascinating and wondrous place. When in the area and looking for a unique and memorable adventure, this should top your list. I even took my 7 year old daughter and she had a magical time!

Unique and wondrous place. I went to Rio Secreto in mid October and it was amazing. The cave was very unique. It was lucky for us because on our trip to Mexico the only time it rained was when we were in the cave. The weather does not effect this excursion at all because you are underground. It may even make it better when it rains because you can see and hear where the water actually comes in. It is a hike to get there and it is amazing that they even found this place because it is so remote. You are basically walking into a whole in the ground and it is amazing how it opens up when you get down there. The guide took us through the cave and showed us some points of interest. The water is crystal clear and you may even run into some fish when you are down there. Some things to remember before go to Rio Secreto are you are not allowed to bring cameras of any kind. We were told by the place we booked it through that you were allowed to bring water proof cameras but when we got there we found out we couldn't. Eat before you go. We left kind of early and didn't eat before it and I was hungry half way through. They do have a delicious lunch when you are done though. Watch out for little formations that are growing in the cave. Our guide told us to watch out these little things on the ground that looked like eggs and I thought she meant farther up. (Crunch, Crunch) I didn't see them and what took thousands of years to form I destroyed in seconds. The guide was not too happy about that. So you really have to watch where you are going and it does get tight in some places so watch your head! You have to take a freezing cold shower before you enter the cave to wash off any chemicals that may be on your body. Once you rinse you have to make a dash for the place where you get the wet suits. It really isn't too bad and once you start moving you will be warm. You can buy pictures there that they photographer takes but they are expensive. 25 dollars for one picture. It is worth it because you will probably never be anywhere like it again. I got one and it came out great. Overall it was an awesome trip I would highly recommend it. You will never see anything like it in your life. The people are nice, there are small groups and you will be amazed the whole time your there. The time you are in the cave is about an hour and a half and there is completely different scenery around every corner. The swimming is fun too. You do a good amount of swimming which was my favorite part.

5 stars is an understatement.. Stepping down into the caves, was like entering into a different underworld, dazzling, serene, and creepy all at the same time. Untouched by humans, the caverns seem to swallow you whole, and it's almost like you dont know where to look first to take it all in. The stalagtites dangling precariously, the stalagmites, the crystal water.....ok I'm being dramatic, but it blew my mind. Practically, we took a bus from our resort and really didn't know what to expect. The staff greeted us and took us (7 of us) in an airconditioned van, deep into the 'jungle' until we reached the base. There they have lockers where you can store your stuff, washrooms, and after showering off you can don one of their wetsuits, a life jacket, a helmet with a light and you're off! The caves are all inter connected and marked off with rope. The tour guides took us through...walking, wading, and swimming from cave to cave, explaining the way the different rock formations formed over time. It was spectacular. A photographer takes pictures, as you are not allowed to bring your own equipment. They emphasize not touching or disturbing the rock formations...after travelling underground for 1.5 hours, you resurface and climb out. By the time you return your gear they have processed the pics, and you may choose to buy any number of packages of photo/dvd. They serve you a shot of some honey/anis liquor (deliciously like sambucca) and then you go and have a sandwich/salad....and you've earned it!! Cost was 89$ US and worth every penny. Service was excellent. Guide was knowledgeable, friendly, and spoke English. The caves, breathtaking. Not touristy AT ALL. From departure from hotel, to Rio Secreto and back again, it took 4.5 hours. All equipment is provided, including watershoes. Not a place for toddlers or babies.

A Natural Beauty, must see for the family!. The tour guide was fantasic, either spanish or english speaking tours. They provide you with the wet suit, water shoes, helmut & life jacket. You go in the cave in a small group, we were with 2 other people. The staff at Rio Secreto really want you to enjoy the caves, but your not allowed to touch the limestone. It can be difficult to walk as the floor is also rocky, so if you have some disibilities that your not able to walk well, or have very small kids. Then this is not for you. Probably good for kids 7 and up, depending on your child of course. But the beauty is so amazing that it is worth it to bring your kids if you need to!!We just went to Rio Secreto on our own, and didn't go through a tour group. We took the local bus system, Collectivo, from our resort and it cost us $25 peso each way (about $2 US) way cheaper then a cab. It was about 5 or 10 mins from Playa del Carmen.

Magical!. I toured this absolutely magical reserve this summer. It is untouched by the typical tourism one finds in resort communities. The guide was professional and well educated on the site. One travels truly the underworld that is often only seen via a media source or in your imagination. The hour and a half tour took our small group of 5 through twists and turns of the caves. At times we swam, other times we walked or crawled. But every turn was fantastic with beauty beyond words. A very peaceful and unforgettable experience.

Fantastic!. The variety of cave formations was amazing. The 5% of time spent swimming was a bit chilly but not too bad. We were so busy taking in this new world that our time went by far too quickly. Fernando is an excellent guide whose enthusiasm for the caves was contagious! My son & I are extremely claustrophobic and we never, not even once, felt the least bit uncomfortable. Our bus driver went cautiously down the road between the meeting station and the caves. The road is rough but not enough to warrant complaint. If you get carsick easily, ride in the front passenger seat. This adventure should be at the very top of everyone's list!
A Must See!! Unforgettable experience!. OMG....I don't know if I have the words to describe the experience. It was absolutely breathtaking and unbelievably beautiful.

WOW! A must see once in your lifetime!. I was quite skeptical after my husband brought up the idea of this adventure but after some convincing and research, I gave in and I am so glad I did this in September 09! We booked through our resort for the next morning (picked up at 7:45 a.m. ) and a short trip on an air conditioned van, we arrived at Rio Secreto. We signed the usual paperwork, loaded into another van and off down a pretty rocky dirt road to the caves. If you get carsick - this would be the time to take come anti-nausea meds! However, the drive is only about 10 min. or so and when we arrived, we were greeted by our guide (name escapes me now!! ), a small bit of history of the discovery, a shower to wash off any deodorants, oils and such on your body , then fitted with water shoes, wetsuit and helmet complete with flashlight. A short walk through the jungle trails and we arrived at the caves. I've never considered myself claustrophobic but on the walk down to the cave, I really had to breath and concentrate on the magical sites I was about to see. Our guide could tell I was having a time so he stopped, breathed with me and was so comforting! After initial apprehension, stepping into the caves and seeing the breathtaking sites, all my fears disappeared! When you realize that you are in a place that was untouched for hundreds of years, you will be in such awe that you will forget about anything else! For the most part, you are walking in ankle deep to knee deep water and swimming through a portion of it. I am not a strong swimmer but didn't need to be since you pretty much float along and take in the sites. It is quite a hike with a few parts you really had to balance on (without touching the sides to prevent damage) but our guide helped us along the hard to walk places. There was a photographer that would follow along and take photos in different areas, which we thought was a nice touch! After the tour (I believe it was 1 1/2 hours long), we changed into our regular clothes and were escorted to the picture viewing area. It was very professional done and while the pictures were amazing, they could do no justice to the place! Unfortunately, my husband forgot his credit card so we were unable to purchase any at the time (they were pretty overpriced if I recall) but they gave us a card to contact them and we could purchase any we liked at a later time. We were then taken to the lunch area which consisted of sandwiches, fruit and drinks. Nothing fancy but were weren't there for the food right? After lunch, we were taken back by van to our original point and back to our hotel by 11 in the morning. We loved the fact that it did not take all day to enjoy this experience but we are so glad we took the time. All in all, it was definately worth the money as the tour guide was exceptional! I would not recommend this for small children as the walk can be a little difficult along the formations and you have to be very careful not to touch anything! We highly recommend this for a once in a lifetime experience!

Most unique experience in the area. The one thing you might read about the most is the cost of the pictures. Considering you have a professional photographer the whole time who trials your group, and consider that they have strategically placed remote flashes set-up throughout the cave, its no wonder they are priced higher than your average souvenier photos. They have actually come down on the price and we got all of our pictures on CD for $89, US. Since their were 5 of us, I consider this a bargain for the quality that you get, and you do not have to worry about lugging a camera (they are not allowed anyway). Get the pictures you will enjoy them for years. Our guide, Fernando, was very knowlegable about the history and geological events that led to the creation of the cave system. The water is about 65 degrees, but it is a cool welcome from the sometime oppresive heat of Playa del Carman. It is not scary at all, children do this tour. Most of the time you are walking in about a foot or so of water, and a few times its chest high, and only about 20 feet or so do you need to swim (more of a vertical dog paddle as your float perfectly between the wet-suit and the life jacket. It is a truely amazing site to see, we did the 2 hour tour, but they do have a 4 hour tour that takes you a different route, so we do have something to look forward to next year, as we will definitely do again. They are ways to make this a cheaper trip if you get your own transportation, it is only $49, US each to do this. We took the bus and saved at least $50 that way. The staff are friendly, knowledgable, and love what they do. THIS IS NOT ONE TO MISS, check out the photos, it is actually better than the pictures, if you can imagine that!

... stunning! Worth it.. Yes, it's an expensive outing. And speaking of expense, we actually haggled with Best Day Travel (agency down there) for a price that started at $119/person (!) but got it down to $81 (which included park fee, lunch and transportation from the Cancun hotel zone). It would be cheaper if we'd taken their $41/person entry deal and rented a car, but we didn't want that hassle. So it was, yes, $182 for two people. That's a lot, but it's a truly unique experience.
