We left by 9 and returned by 3 (with the actual tour and lunch taking about 3 hours). They take smallish groups at a time... ours was 9, which seemed about right. In the price, you get a simple lunch and lockers. Everything is orchestrated and well-explained. There are changing rooms and they provide towels.The trip is stunning. I've visited a number of caves. These are huge but are extensive. You begin near the highway and they take you inland to the site (about 15 minutes). They then provide a wetsuit (with booties) and a helmet with lamp on it. You get a lot of educational information... and our guide Alfredo was a terrific guy. There were a few places were you could get slightly claustrophobic, but it's actually fun. Most of the time you're simple walking through 10" deep water, but near the end we got to float up to our shoulders. Stalagtites everywhere, and no natural light - so the lamps were essential.OK, let's talk photos. We had previously read that the photos were expensive in the extreme (and you can't take a camera along). They've got a second guide that takes photos at many designated places (including places where they pose you, or a couple, and that was very nice). The good news is that I think they may have developed a sensitivity to this because the prices had fallen. At the end of the tour, after a drink, you are taken into a modern room with computer terminals where you get to look at the photos they too (of you or the group)... and order any combination. They'd burn these on a CD and you'd leave with the photos. Yes, the prices were high, but the best deal was to order all 8 of you (or couple) and take their general scene photos of the area... all for $80 (which was, supposedly, an "end of summer" price reduction of 36%). This was tolerable given that the shots were very professional, we so did it.All in all, we loved it.

Rio Secreto - the one "DON'T MISS IT" in Playa Del Carmen. We've traveled to Quintana Roo 8 times over the years, and done a lot of fun things. However, Rio Secreto is easily the best thing we've ever done. It's a true cave exploration... hiking, wading, swimming. The sights are incredible, showing you formations of all kinds, and a wonderful narrative on how the company works to protect this wonderful site.When were there, May 2009, the site was fairly new, only having been discovered a year or two before. The staff is entirely focused on keeping it untouched for years to come. Unlike some other excursions we've seen, complete with caves carved out so the boats can fit through, this one is exactly as it was found. Please listen to your guide carefully to do your part to help keep it pristine.Everything is provided... hard hat, wetsuit, booties... and yes you'll appreciate all of them. Lot's of opportunities to clonk your head. The wetsuit makes the transition from the Mexico heat to 60 degree F water tolerable. My wife, who hates anything cold, said she did just fine until the long swim at the last, about 10 minutes non-stop. Don't worry about the swim. You wetsuit has enough flotation that it's really more like a float down a river.Lots of pictures are taken along the way (you can't bring your own camera). The shots have been professionally set up, and they are extraordinarily good. They are quite expensive to purchase tho. Don't leave without getting at least one.Mariana was our guide, and she is also a dear friend of many years. We have explored the area through her since 2004. This is her best excursion yet. She actually was part of the team that designed this trip, and her expertise and sensitivity to both the site, and her guests shows everywhere. Be sure to ask her how little Max is doing.One big plus - This tour takes four hours or less from start to finish (including driving from Playa). For us, this is much preferred over tours that take all day. You can sleep in a little while, got to the tour, and enjoy lunch, and return to your resort in time for some pool time.DON"T miss this tour! The ride down the dirt road to the site is longer than you might think, and a very rough road. But once you get out your are in heaven.

My favorite adventure in the area. Rio Secreto was an incredible surprise. I had never explored any caves before so didn't know what to expect. I loved the idea of slipping on a wet suit and a helmet with a light on it and plunging into darkness. The price seemed a little high ($50 or so) but I can say it was money incredibly well-spent. This system of caves was discovered only 3 years ago (after sitting there for millions of years) and was recently opened to the public.I went with my two young daughters (7 and 10) and my husband. The group was very small (we were 6, in all). The journey begins with a primer from the guide and some things you can and can't do down there. The caves are pristine so you have to be careful that you don't grab on to the stalagmites and stalagtites. Once you are down there, it truly is breathtaking. The darnkess and stillness and the fragility of the place was thrilling.Our guide, Andres, was great. He held my eldest daughter's hand and was so sweet and patient with her. She loved it. He explained everything as he went along and was great at spotting small cave-dwelling insects and fish. We saw a tarantula, which was pretty cool.You spend part of the time swimming and part of the time walking. You are down there about 90 minutes or so. A photographer takes pictures along the way. The photos are expensive, which was the one thing that was a drag. We only bought one large photo ($25, I think). If they made them cheaper (and smaller) we would have definitely bought more. It's a shame the photographer does so much great work and then his photos don't get purchased because they are too expensive. That is my only quibble with the whole experience.After the caves, you are given a small snack and can lounge about on some hammocks while you wait for the van to take you back to the entrance.Can't say enough good things about this attraction.

A Must while visiting Playa Del Carmen!. A trip to Rio Secreto is a must while in the Playa Del Carmen area. It was a 100 peso 10 minute cab ride from Playa (tip - if you´re in Playa, don´t pay for their additional fee for transportation which will run you an addition $30-40 per person). When you are ready to leave, a cab can be called in for you.The tour is beautiful, unique, and most of all fun. It seems a bit off the beaten path and it is well worth the $49pp admission fee which does include a small lunch afterwards. You spend about an hour and a half in the cave system with a knowledgeable guide. Tailing the group the entire way is a photographer. They prepare certain areas for photographs which you can pay for at the end. As many other reviews have mentioned, the pictures are EXPENSIVE. A CD of the photos for the entire group was $89 (which was on sale from the normal price of $139). We opted to purchase 4 photographs on a CD for $59. The last option was for one photograph printed for $25. Yes it is quite a rip-off. However, the photos themselves turn out quite nicely. There were not more than 4 that we wantedto keep which was why we opted for the $59 CD option. I would definitely recommend this to anyone. I wouldn´t recommend this tour for small children.

If you do one excursion in the Riviera Maya - don't miss this one!!. The caves at Rio Secreto are amazing and the tour is definitely worth it!!The only downfall is that you are not allowed to take any pictures. However, they will stop you along the way to take their own pictures to capture your experience....but they are a bit pricey (one picture is $25US). Although, looking back now, had we been allowed to take our own pictures, it would have taken away from the relaxing experience you have when you go through the caves themselves. If we are ever in the Riviera Maya area again, we will definitely go back!! The experience was amazing and our guide Mariana played a huge part in that. You can definitely tell that she is passionate about what she does and it shows! Thank you Mariana for doing such a wonderful job!!

You MUST Go!. This was an awesome excursion, well worth the $50 a person for the trip. It was an amazing experience that you will not soon forget! The only downside is that they charge a bit much for the pictures they take of you inside, but I think they are well worth it. Go- you will be glad you did!

Rio Secreto. Just got back from a week in Playa. One of the things we did was visit Rio Secreto and we were very impressed. Personally - I think it is one of the "must -do's" while in the Mexican Rivera. Just a couple of minutes from downtown Playa the cave/ underground river is amazing. The tour groups are small, the guides (in our case Marianna) were knowledgable, down to earth and maybe most of all the beauty of the cave / river is not "tourist-ized". This is a great tour and I highly recommend it. This is a tour where you put on a wet suit and hard hat and you explore an underground cave system w/ all it's natural beauty. I realize that might not be the "thing" for some folks - but give it a chance - the experience is amazing.

The end of the trip.... Rio Secreto has to be the most beautiful place I've ever been. We were underground for about an hour and a half. The tour guide was so passionate about his work and was very respectful towards natural elements. We were set to visit Rio Secreto on our last day in Playa. After a whole week of excursions, we were all a little tired of "doing" things. We kinda wanted to stay by the pool at our resort. We were sooooo glad that we went there instead. This trip was absolutely wonderful! The only downfall was the van ride to get there. The road was really bumpy and the a/c didn't work very well. Make sure that you get as close to the front of the van as possible. All in all-I would avise anyone to visit Rio Secreto!

A truly unique experience!. I didn't know what to expect when I decided to go on this outing, but I am SO glad that I did. Rio Secreto is a natural treasure! The calcium stalagmites and stalactites are amazing and the coral is beautiful, too! Our guide, Karen, was wonderful and took time to explain each "room" that we entered. They don't even know how extensive the underground waterway is yet. This was just discovered a couple of years ago and just open to the public for about a year. They are doing a great job to keep Rio Secreto as pristine as possible. The only people who might not enjoy this excursion are those who are claustrophobic. Some of the passageways are a tight fit, but it is SO worth it. Yes...as you've probably read...the pictures are pricey. I just bought one and I have the others locked away in my memory. If you are visiting Playa del Carmen, you owe it to yourself to visit Rio Secreto. You won't be disappointed!

Amazing Experience. Rio Secreto was a last-minute fill in activity after the swine flu forced the closure of all archeological sites. At first I was upset that our trip to Coba was cancelled, but Rio Secreto was so amazing that I quickly forgot my disappointment.A few notes/comments:1. Skip paying for their transportation. The listed price for the tour is $49/person without transportation, $89/person with. We spent $10 for the 15 minute cab ride down there, and on the way back their transportation vans dropped us off back at the hotel for just $10. By arranging our own transportation we saved $60! Another option is to take the bus to Xcaret, then walk the half mile down the freeway to the entrance. This would run you about $2/person from Playa.2. Once you arrive at the entrance you take vans into the jungle to the cave openings. If you experience any sort of motion sickness ask to sit in the front of the vans. I hadn’t been carsick in years but the 20 minute bumpy/bouncy ride was more than my stomach could take.3. Our guide, Fernando, was wonderful and was by far the best guide we had at any attraction in the area.4. They provide wetsuits, hard hats, life jackets and water shoes. Fernando mentioned that I could skip the water shoes and just wear my own Keens and I regretted it – the sand at the bottom of the water is so fine and it kept getting stuck in the nooks and crannies of my shoes. Next time I’d wear their shoes, for sure!5. As mentioned by many people, the photo prices are outrageous. A single photo is $25, CD with 4 is $69 and a CD with every pic they took is $169. Ouch!With all of that having been said, this was one of the best activities we did on our trip. I can be a bit claustrophobic but that wasn’t an issue at all. The rock formations were amazing, and I found myself gasping in awe each time we entered a new “room”. At one point Fernando took us into a side area and we shut off all our lights. Sitting there, in the absolute darkness, with no noise except the dripping of water, was a remarkable experience.

Great even if you are claustrophobic. I got a little nervous about going to this place because I can get claustrophobic in tight places. Have no fear. It is fantastic. You walk through caverns into large open spaces that are beautifully and tastefully lit for your group. The silence and darkness is unlike anything I've heard or seen before. The guide's primary purpose seemed to be to show us the underground river in hopes that we would leave this area with an understanding of how we must all preserve natural places for future generations. It was very nice and the guide appeared to be very environmentally sensitive. There was also a nice lunch after the tour. Be warned, you will want to buy the photo cd after the tour and it is quite expensive. We bought the cd and are happy to have the memories. The quality of the photos is good.
10 out of 10. An incredible experience. Pablo, our guide, was absolutely amazing. One of the best experiences our of lives!

Unique experience. Rio Secreto is series of connected, water filled caverns (they become cenotes if the roof collapes) under the Yucatan peninsula. You don a wet suit and helmet with a head lamp and a guide takes you through the caves. The caves are incredible with amazing stalactite and stalagmite formations. In places, you have to swim through the caverns, however it is not claustraphobic as you don't have to squeeze through any tight opening. The guide was extremely knowledgeable and there was a nice lunch after the tour. A unique experience.The tours can be booked on line or if you're staying in a resort in the area. It's only a few miles south of Playa del Carmen

An amazing, espiritual trip underground at night for honeymooners. You must go to a least 7 caves around the world to see the types of formations they will show you in this trip. We went on a night trip. Started at 17H00 and got out of the cave at night below an amazing star filled sky. After te trip and a shower a romantic candel lit dinner with were good food and a mariachi playing a guitar and singing mexicans balads.Underground my mouth was never closed because of the beautifull scenery.BE AWARE: this is not a tourist excursion, it is a real expedition full of strict rules to protect this natural reserve. If you want just to have fun in caves go to XCARET.

Good Cenote Choice. Since Cenotes are almost unique to the Yucatan, it seemed I must try one. There are so many to select from and various types. Rio Secreto is very new and said to offer more cenote characteristics than any other single cenote.About 15 minutes into the journey I asked myself “what am I was doing here” but 15 minutes later, I was really enjoying myself. I am not a cave enthusiast but I do like to do different things, learn different things and this definitely fits the bill. The cave is very beautiful and they are making an effort to preserve it in spite of its commercialization.Our guide was knowledgeable and seemed enthusiastic about his job. The equipment was adequate and they provide lockers, showers and towels and an ample, however basic, lunch following the cave journey.I did not but pictures, but the prices I heard seemed exorbitant.

Truly amazing and different. A "must" do in Mexico!. What an amazing adventure under the earth! Walking, wading and swimming in an amazing underground cavern system for about an hour an a half. This is definitely something different to do if you are in the Cancun/Playa/Riviera Maya region of Mexico. I would suggest "Christian" as your guide. He was VERY knowledgeable about this tour and he speaks 6 different languages! They provide a very light lunch after you come out which was good. The only downfall to this is the ride back to where the caverns are. A VERY bumpy and long 20-30 minute ride on a dirt road. Also bring some money if you want pictures. They do not allow cameras while you are in the caverns and I don't blame them but the photos are expensive, $25.00 US dollars for ONE picture. Overall this was a great excursion that I would highly recommend!

Amazing experience, which is nearly impossible to capture (in photos at least). Rio Secreto is a truly amazing attraction, which should not be missed if you're in the playa del carmen or tulum areas. There are a lot of cenotes on the Peninsula, but this feels like a real river running underground with tons of the amazing geological formations (stalagmites and stalagtites) which can only be seen in a cave like this. Our guide, Fernando, was incredible, and was able to show us some of the really cool stuff in the cave. Most important was the first time I have ever experienced true absence of light, which in and of itself was worth the trip.The only weird thing is the photo situation. You can't bring your own camera both to keep foreign objects out of the cave, because THEY want to take the pictures, and because it might get ruined if it's not waterproof. They do take a lot of pictures for you, though, and they come out pretty cool (although don't really capture how dark it is in there because there is a lot of flash). The problem is how ridiculously expensive they are to purchase (25 for one or 60 dollars for four photos on a CD or something absurd like that). That doesn't matter though because the experience is so great.

Great attraction, photo sales annoying. We have been either on walking tours or scuba diving a number of the cenotes in the Mexican Riveria Maya. This one is the most interesting because it is quite different, in that it is less developed and you swim part of the way through the caves. The company is relatively well organized supplying lockers, reef boots, wet suits, floatation vests, towels, showers (cold) and a small snack afterwards. The down side of the attraction, is that they want to make their money from selling you photos. The photo prices are outrageous - $169 USD for a CD or $25 USD for 1 photo!!! The number of stops to fill the CD with photo's was also annoying. However, the attraction is spectacular. If you want your own photo's of caves, we suggest you go to Atkun Chen - also very beautiful, and easy walking. BlaineWinnipeg

The Very Best..... with a Drawback. I have to say five star as this is the most breathtaking excursion I ever took. Everything needed is included - from water socks, wet suit, floatation, to miner's hat with lcd lamp and locker. 600 meters of underground exploration. You walk/swim along an underground river. Light lunch was included.Located across Hwy. 307 from Xcaret. You travel north from the front gate on a dusty, bumpy road - 2 to 3 miles.I overheated in the wet suit but our guide quickly had me stripped down above the waist and cooled in the water. My only fear was going too far into heat exhaustion and having to be extricated. I am just over 200 pds and it would have taken at least four strong men to get me out of there.Ah yes, the one major drawback - the photo packages are up there with highway robbery ! $34 USD for ONE 8 X 12 ! Yes, you heard right. The CD plus 4 photos is $139 USD. I kid you not. No cameras allowed !One other minor drawback, most of the staff very helpful and friendly but a few with the 'authoritative' attitude and some of the support hombres looked and acted like thugs.Still a five star in my book !

An Experience to the Center of the Earth. It's just unbelievable! It's amazing, it's unique!The place was opened only 8 months ago. There we can feel what nature really is without man's interference. There I could listen to the eternal silence and feel part of the process of the formation of the world drop by drop... We can "see" the darkness of the beginning of the life and we can "feel" that the colours are alive when we get out of the cave. This tour was one of the most wonderful moments of my life.The guide is very professional, the people there are very nice, the place outside the cave has an excellent structure to receive tourists. The photos are expensive but it's impossible to get out of there without a concrete proof that we weren't dreaming.

Amazing underground adventure, minutes from Playa. So yes, the big disappointment about this trip is the fact that if you want photos, you will have to buy the very expensive ones offered at the end of the trip. And no, you can't bring you're own camera, not just because they are trying to make money on selling you photos, but because without background lighting, your photos won't show any of the background cave detail. They take great pains to stage each photo and each photo site contains synchronized flash attached to the walls that light up the whole cave when the trigger is depressed. Also, I wouldn't want to be on the tour where everyone is taking their own photos, you would never get out of the caves! So anyways, the tour was great. Try to negotiate a better price upfront, especially if you are with a group. We paid $45US each from a travel agent on 5th ave in Playa (alltournative), which was a few dollars less than people were paying at the gate. This paid for our cab fare there. Here's another tip, don't pay for the transportation there, you will be charged almost as much as the entrance fee. Just cab it there, should only cost around $10US each way, it's about 5-10mins outside Playa. You could even take a collectivo there if you wanted to, it's off the highway on the way to Tulum.The tour is very well run. we were in a small group of 6. The guide was very knowledgeable and also passionate about his work. He took his time explaining everything about the caves and constantly reminded us about how fragile all the formations where. We all were very careful not to stomp or grab hold of anything we weren't supposed to. It was amazing to swim/wade through the cool clear water underground, surrounded by amazing rock formations. The place is still active and felt very much 'alive'. Along with the guide, a photographer accompanies you to take the staged photos. At the end of the trip, they present you with photos specific to you. If you are a couple, they will show you photos of just you. The prices of the photos are $25 each. Cd's of 8 photos are $80US. Yes, a lot of money. Since we were travelling with another couple, we negotiated one CD of 8 photos, 4 of each couple. They were very reluctant to do this but since we weren't going to buy anything if they didn't cater to us, they eventually agreed. The end of the trip featured a decent lunch, sandwiches, fruit, juice and salad. Overall, an amazing experience and well worth it even if you don't end up getting photos. Imagine, swimming through an underground cave system, in pitch black with only your flashlights and guide to show you the way. Rock formations all around you that have taken thousands of years to form and are still forming. All a cab ride away from Playa. Pretty cool.J

Cool experience, only turkey this Thanksgiving was the photos. This review contains a "spoiler", for those that like everything to be a surprise. My husband, 12 & 19 year old sons and I went here last Wednesday. We booked the 1pm tour that morning from the Alltournative booth in Playa del Carmen. At 12:15 pm, we went to the booth, and the sales guy actually walked us a couple of blocks up to the main drag to hail a taxi. Price 120 pesos for the 4 of us. That's right, about 12 bucks; a lot cheaper than the 20 dollars per person extra that the girl the night before was trying to sell us. Taxi ride is about 15 minutes to Rio Secreto. If you decide to go this route, take along the phone number to call for a taxi to take you home, otherwise you'll be stranded. The jungle ride aboard the trucks to the cenote site was long and Very rough. The experience was fantastic. I've been to dry caves before, but this was really cool and my kids loved it, which is amazing given the age difference. You are given a wet-suit, life vest and water shoes. Make sure you wear a bathing suit, because you have to parade across the grounds to get your gear. My youngest can not swim and the water is over your head in some places, but he doggy paddled it and the life vest held you up just fine. I am slightly clausterphobic and when we first descended, I started to feel panicked, but I concentrated on where I was walking and on breathing deeply and after a few minutes it passed. There is a lot of walking over very, very uneven ground, often in water. The good news is that there's no sunlight, so there's no algea to make things slippery! It really was beautiful. I even mananged not to freak out when they sat us down and turned out the lights for about 2 minutes. So there's your warnings, if you are clausterphobic or disabled. They don't allow cameras inside and they follow your group around and take periodic pictures, which they sell to you afterwards. $25.00 U.S. each They had other options of buying all the photos on CD, but as I didn't do that I can't relate the price. I seriously doubt that Rio Secreto is going to ever allow anyone to take their own cameras into the caves. This is a business and they are out to make money, but I do hope they have the good sense to see that they are charging far too much for a single photo. Pictures sell future tourist's trips to Rio Secreto and if no one's taking their photo home because it cost $25.00 then than effects future sales. They need to ask themselves how many hours does the average tourist have to work to afford that photo?!! So how did I manage to post photos? I scanned my $50 worth of pictures, cropped my family out and posted them for you. Enjoy.

Great Tour, Great Guide but NO PHOTOS ALLOWED?. This was a true adventure in underground exploration. You are literally in ancient caves with stalactites an underwater river, even some bats. We traveled underground for about a half mile over a two hour period. We wore full wet suits and life jackets and headlights. Each turn was like seeing a new planet moonscape it was an alien world that we absolutely loved.HOWEVER..... Now I'm a bit unusual in having an underwater digital camera but not that unusual. Rio Secreto will NOT allow you to take a camera on your tour as of this writing. They have a "photographer" follow the tour and take photos a specific points. Sadly the photos were not that good despite the equipment like advanced flash set ups and top quality digital cannon SLR's. They tell you no cameras because you need your hands on the caves but thats not true. It's a simple rouse to get you to spend way way way to much money to buy the photos they take of you.....$25 per photo... for the love of god 25 bucks!Because we could not take photos we chose to go to another cave tour the next day. It was cheaper and only about 10 min south of Rio it's called Hidden Worlds and it was not only caves but zip lines, sky bikes, rappelling into caves (spelunking) cave snorkeling (all optional) plus they allow cameras.We really like Rio Secreto and their environmental commitment to the cave but we hope they change their "no camera" policy soon.

great surprise midway in trip. We decided to do Rio Secreto, as it was about a 4 hr tour vs. an all day tour somewhere else..It was a great experience..very interesting..some things to consider...it is not for everyone..it requires pretty secure footing, you will be provide with rubber water shoes, but you need to be very sure on your feet to do this trip...also, you will be swimming for a bit, over your head....this was the best part, but maybe not for the faint of heart...Our guide was awesome, very knowlegable...there are some suprises that I will not divulge here...I don't want to spoil it ! Some hints: don't wear jewelry, you will be required to remove it...you can wear flipflops there, as they provide your water shoes..and your wet suit over your own bathing suit..they provide lockers...you can't bring a camera into the cave itself, so that leaves the photos limited to the unimog you drive there in...they pile you on this huge 4WD vehicle...it takes about 20 min drive into the jungle to get to Rio Secreto...another FYI: our driver decided to give us the ride of a lifetime on the way back out of the jungle over extremely bumpy, and unruly terrain..there were a few times, when I thought the vehicle was going to roll over...but we made it fine, but I really didn't enjoy that part of it too much..they give you a basic lunch after the trip, ham sandwiches, drinks, salad...it was fine...we weren't there to eat...they take a ton of photos of you...and at the end of the trip you can purchase them for 25.00 a piece...but honestly, I bought one, and I'm glad I did, as they put it in a really nice folder of the inside of the cave, and the photo is an 8 x 10...I felt it was well worth it...you can pick from many...there are a lot of cool parts once you are inside the cave, but to tell you will spoil it...just know you will swim...and float...enjoy this cool eco trip...

Loved being able to swim in the cave. My husband and I went on this tour. It was very nice and tranquil in the cave. You have about 8 people in your group and a guide. We had Dania - she was very pleasant. After driving in the back of a truck down a bumpy rough road thru the jungle for about 15 - 20 mins (it was kinda fun) you'll end up at the cave.They suit you up and off you go down a trail to the cave. It's wonderful inside - being from Missouri - we've been to several caves - so the stalagmites are the same. But in the Rio Secreto you get to swim thru part of the cave. There's a lot of walking on lumpy surfaces so be careful. It's amazing how the deposits from the water create columns and cathedrals. They take A LOT of pictures. They want you to buy their pictures. You are NOT allowed to take your own camera. We loved being able to swim thru the cave. Very majestic. Water is so beautiful.Total time thru the tour was about 1 1/2 hours. Then after you remove your wetsuits, etc. they have a nice light lunch for you.

best excursion in playa del carmen in my opinion. i can't say enough good things about my experience at rio secreto. the caves were overwhelming...i kept wondering if i'd stumbled into another world because it was so quiet and serene yet exciting because the surroundings were so different than anything i've ever seen. The entire adventure was beautiful and informative. Please don't miss this if you get anywhere near playa del carmen, it was worth every penny (and i would have paid double the price knowing what i know now about its magnificence!)

Must See!. This is a must see if you are anywhere near Cancun or Playa Del Carmen. It's less than 1 mile south of Xcaret heading towards Tulum. There is a small sign that reads Rio Secreto. The tours are booked for 9am, 11am, or 1pm. It was $49 USD per person if you book on site. This is my favorite place that I've seen in the 15 countries that I've visited. AMAZING! You take a bumpy ride on a dirt road for a couple of miles and then an reach an oasis in the middle of the jungle where you prepare to see the secret river in an underground water filled cave (cenote). You will love it! Worth every minute and every dollar.

Amazing and Beautiful!. For something very different and interesting, visit the cenote cave of Rio Sectreto. I have only been in one cave before, Merrimack, in Missouri, and this beats that caving experience by far! The cave system has a fresh water (incredibilly clear) river that treks through it. You walk through and swim through the cave in a small (6 person for us) group with a guide who was very knowledgable about the history, culture fo the region, and science of the cave. Excellent guides!They provide a half wet suit (half your arms and legs are exposed), which was perfect, since the water is pretty cool, but not too cold. Water shoes, helmet, lifejacket, and light on helmet also provided. Very easy.I am afraid of sea life touching me (stingrays, eels, etc.), and I am happy to say that there were no such living things in the water there. First of all, it is fresh water, so no sea creatures could live there, and second of all, it is a COMPLETELY dark cave. Without your lights, there is NO light. So only bats (never saw any), and fish that rely on touch (they will avoid you, we never saw any) can "get" you.The rocks were amazing. Stallatites, shiny crystals, beautiful formations, were all abundant. I was a little nervous stepping on some rocks that appeared to be slippery, only to discover that they were not slippery at all - just a pretty shine to them. No algea or anything because again, you are in a cave with zero light. It can't grow.One thing that I have to warn about is that if you are truely clausterphobic, then you may want to know ahead of time that there is one area that to get through, you have to float on your back, and the guide pulls you through a very small opening. Your face is only inches from the cave ceiling, and not enough room to extend your arms. I am would think they probably have an alternate route through this area, but I was taken by surprise.Also, if you have a really hard time getting around (like my older parents), it may be tricky in some spots. One critique... The photos they take of you as you go through the cave are great. However, we did not purchase any because they were $25 US dollars apiece. Kind of expensive for a photo. If it was 10 or 15, i may have considered purchasing.I would definately do this tour again, and recommend it to others (as long as they are not elderly people who loose their balance easily). It is a great experience, and I have heard that it has only been open to the public with tours for about 5 months, so go soon, while all the natural beauty is undisturbed by man.

Best Holiday Experience Abroad. As a seasoned traveller I älways look for the off-track options that a destination may offer. Rio Secreto, which is managed by Alltournative, is a must-see place. It is an underground river that has to be one of the most beautiful places that I have seen on this planet. Filled with hundreds of pure-white stalactites and stalagmites and incredibly clear fresh water this place is like being in a fantasy world. What really did it for me was the great service that the knowledgable Alltournative tour guides offered and the easy access to the river. I would recommend this experience for all travellers, young and old alike. Thank you Alltournative for a memorable day!

RIO SECRETO/ Riviera Maya Cancun. You will be amazed even my teen age kids were. It will take yourbreath way. You'll enjoy the underground rivers like never beforethey provide all the gear including the wet suits. All very worth itfor only $40.00US Dls if purchase right there. Only 15 min from Playa del Carmen it's right next to Xcaret
